The service is somewhat slow. I know my friends were waiting a while every time they went up. Even when it was starting to clear out. That put a damper on the hanging out because it felt like someone was always being left out.

"I have had the dubious pleasure of visiting this particular Bashas' establishment on multiple occasions, with the frequency of my visits being sufficient enough to warrant the formation of a distinct impression regarding the quality of service and overall experience offered by said store. On two separate instances, my experiences were marred by instances of unacceptable behavior exhibited by employees, which served to undermine my confidence in the ability of the store to provide a satisfactory shopping environment. Specifically, during one visit, the store manager saw fit to engage in a protracted and wholly inappropriate conversation with a bagger, the substance of which was derogatory in nature and directed towards an employee who was present at the checkout counter. This reprehensible display continued unabated throughout the duration of my transaction, rendering the entire experience decidedly unpleasant. Furthermore, during another visit, two employees saw fit to regale each other with explicit tales of their sexual exploits while attending to my purchase, thereby creating an atmosphere that was decidedly unprofessional and uncomfortable for all parties involved. These incidents, taken in conjunction with the fact that the prices charged by this Bashas' location are not particularly competitive, lead me to conclude that it would be more advisable to patronize the Fresh and Easy located directly across the street, which has heretofore provided a markedly superior shopping experience."

"Hence, upon perusing copious quantities of laudatory reviews, I have opted to extricate my thoughts from the realm of abstraction and transcribe them in tangible form, with the intention of conveying my sentiments regarding the recent dining experience I had the pleasure of partaking in at your esteemed establishment. As an Oregonian, I must confess that my palate has been indulged by an array of delectable and authentic Asian culinary delights, including, but not limited to, pho. Thus, it was with great anticipation that I ordered the 'pho-nomenal soup bowl,' only to be left feeling underwhelmed and disillusioned by the absence of chili oil, which, I was informed, was substituted by sriracha sauceâa purported equivalent, albeit one that, in my opinion, falls short of the genuine article. Furthermore, the shrimp rolls, which I had expected to savor, failed to impress my taste buds. Notwithstanding, I must commend your staff for their exceptional customer service, which, regrettably, proved to be the sole redeeming quality of my visit. In light of the aforementioned, I shall reserve judgment for a period of three months, during which time I sincerely hope that the necessary adjustments will be made to elevate the quality of the cuisine to a level worthy of the prices charged. Your attention to this matter would be greatly appreciated."

The ambiance of the establishment was rather dim and seedy, with a pronounced sense of decrepitude permeating the atmosphere. The booth we occupied sported upholstery that was noticeably frayed and worn, which seemed to comport with the general tenor of the venue. The billiard tables appeared to be well-maintained and attracted a sizable contingent of patrons, particularly in the vicinity of the bar area, where a group of individuals were engaged in a spirited discussion of David Limbaugh's most recent literary offering. Notwithstanding the presence of a family unit partaking of a meal, the setting did not strike me as being particularly suitable for a family gathering, although it did not necessarily convey an aura of impropriety either.  
My companion opted for the bacon cheeseburger, accompanied by a side of waffle fries and an order of Asian coleslaw. I selected the grilled chicken sandwich, also with waffle fries. To our surprise, the waffle fries were fabricated from sweet potatoes, yet they possessed a satisfying crispiness and were quite palatable. However, my friend's burger arrived sans bacon, which was served in a separate container and was regrettably overcooked and somewhat brittle. Although the chicken sandwich was cooked to a satisfactory degree, the grill flavor was somewhat overwhelming and might have been mitigated by the presence of a sauce or condiment. My friend expressed satisfaction with the slaw. My beverage of choice, a Left Hand Lager, was quite enjoyable.  
Given the foregoing, one might query why I would assign only two stars to this establishment. The answer lies in the service, which was provided by two amiable servers who nonetheless exhibited a lack of attentiveness to our needs. Specifically, I was forced to endure an extended period with an empty glass, and the process of obtaining the bill and effecting payment proved unduly protracted. Furthermore, the tariffs charged for the fare were, in my estimation, excessive relative to the ambiance and quality of the food. A Guinness ale was priced at six dollars per pint, and while Monday evenings featured Pabst Blue Ribbon at the discounted price of one dollar and fifty cents per pint, the present day was not a Monday and I do not partake of that particular beverage. In summary, the combination of steep prices, indifferent service, and a dive bar atmosphere militated against this venue becoming a regular haunt for me.

The place is very dark and divey.  The booth we sat in had torn upholstery.  The pool tables looked nice and the place had a good crowd at the bar just after 11am (that were discussing David Limbaugh's new book ??? ) plus a family at a table.  This wouldn't be my first choice for a family lunch but it isn't inappropriate.

My friend had the bacon burger with waffle fries and the Asian slaw.  I had the grilled chicken sandwich with waffle fries.    We were surprised to see that the waffle fries were sweet potato but they were crispy and tasty.  My friend liked his burger, but they forgot to put the bacon on and brought it out in bowl, the bacon was obviously overcooked and hard.  The chicken sandwich was well cooked but had a slightly overpowering grill flavor and could have used some kind of sauce.  My friend enjoyed the slaw. My Left Hand Lager was good.

This doesn't sound too bad so why two starts?  The servers were both friendly but inattentive.  I sat with an empty glass for a long time, and it took forever to get the bill and be rang up.  The prices were also too high for the atmosphere.  It was $36 for our lunch, Guinness is $6 a pint.  Monday is $1.50 PBRs but it wasn't Monday and I don't like PBR.  Theme restaurant prices, poor service and a dive bar don't add up to regular stop for me.

The bagels' quality was satisfactory, yet the service this morning was subpar and left much to be desired. Upon entering the establishment, I observed that there was merely a single individual ahead of me in the queue, thus, I presumed that the wait would be brief. However, my expectations were quickly dissipated as I endured an agonizing delay of over 20 minutes for a paltry two bagels. It appeared that the staff members were indulging in a leisurely pace, culminating in a considerable delay and numerous errors in fulfilling orders.

"I recently had the occasion to partake in a corporate gathering at the esteemed Encore resort, whereupon my associates and I were dispersed among various upscale establishments within the Wynn and Encore complex. As fate would have it, I was assigned to dine at this particular restaurant, an outcome that did not necessarily align with my personal culinary preferences, as I have never been particularly fond of seafood or Italian cuisine. Despite my initial disappointment, I chose to embrace the experience with an open mind and relinquish my inclination to lament. We were ushered into one of their secluded private chambers, where we indulged in a family-style feast. Unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely met, as the fare appeared somewhat unremarkable, akin to the culinary creations my own family might produce in the comfort of our home. Furthermore, the service we received was somewhat sluggish, compelling me to hail our attendant multiple times in order to procure a beverage. It was almost as if there existed some sort of conspiratorial directive to deny me alcoholic libations (perhaps instigated by my superiors, who are acquainted with my proclivities)."
I don't get the excitement over these darn biscuits, they aren't good at all. I've been here a few times, food it OK, and prices are OK, but I'm not impressed.

The burgers are just ok, they aren't great. The shakes are horrible though. We have given this place the benefit of the doubt in hopes that it would get better three times now. Every time we have gone we have ordered shakes and every time they have been icy and gross. Honestly, the price is great here, unfortunately the cheap price also means cheap quality.

I think I just don't like El Salvadoran food. It's either that or I accidentally consumed the cardboard and polymer display models in lieu of my actual entree. That was some seriously dry, bland food. Even tossing some watered down hot sauce on that pile of bland meat and carbs didn't really improve the edibility. I had the appetizer platter and the chicken with white rice and weird white sauce with a dry side salad. It was a bland, white platter of food. Plus, what's with the side salad of iceberg and radishes? Is it garnish? It's not dressed with anything and, you know, tastes just like a pile of lettuce. 

Maybe I'm just an ignorant prick. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing. Maybe I just don't like El Salvadoran (although I love just about everything else Central American). 

The pupusas were crazy delicious though. I would totally return for these. (And only these.)

I don't know why i have been here more than once, but the parking is horrible, and the food is only so-so.  lots of color and flare but not much going for it.  the baja sauce is great but i seem to get sick later that evening when i eat it.  i need to learn from experience

Its a nice clean restaurant.  Not authentic Mexican food though. They make their burritos weird and when untold them how I wanted it I was told no I dont want it that way. It made me not even want to get a burrito. I was told that Pico de Gallo is nasty in a burrito and I didn't want it like that. I had to let them know that I am a paying customer and I will have it the way I want it. Its hard to hear them when making an order also. The meat spent have authentic Mexican spices either. This is my last time here.

Not my favorite place. I went here with my sis and we split the veggie roll and another shrimp tempura roll and edamame beans. We didnt like any of it. The service was pretty good but other than all of the waters and bartenders being drop dead gorgeous i would not go back for food..

Came here with two other people at 6:40, Happy Hour ends at 7 and our waiter didn't arrive to our table until 7:02 announcing that Happy Hour was unfortunately over. We ordered food and drinks and our waters didn't get there til 7:15, so we sat with no drinks for over a half hour. Btw, the place is empty and it's a Thursday. Our friend asked about the Garden Burger which says \"100% Vegan\" on the menu and the waiter lets us know that it's not really Vegan because they put Chipotle Ranch on it (and because they use egg to keep it together). \n\nTheir food is decent at best, the service was horrendous.

Soooooo I have had a hard time thinking about what I would write about this place. I love the fact that the cost won't break your bank but my experience hasn't been that great. We had signed up for mommy and me ballet and I've given it a good two months of trying it out. The first class was pretty great and then on our way to class (takes us 15-20 min to get there) about 5 minutes before class started they called me and canceled. Well thanks for the heads up 5 minutes before class was supposed to start....then the next couple of weeks it was just instructors being 15-20 minutes late and then the class was just horrible which we never got the time back that they had missed. The class ranges from 18 months-3 or 4 years? and it was just disappointing the next few weeks of class. The other moms in the class weren't very friendly unless you were apart of their group but I met another \"outsider\" who had a toddler the same age as mine.  Overall, the experience was not great but I would definitely try a different class or wait till they got a better instructor.
Food was so bland. Everything was cooked really well and great portion sizes but overall the food was kinda flavorless.

This mall is huge!  Its still pretty vacant since its new....  The stores are overpriced and I'm not sure what to buy.  There are a lot of restaurants and tons of light.  Check it out once..... I probably will never go back.

"I recently had the displeasure of dining at this establishment, and I must say that the prices were exorbitant, to say the least. Furthermore, the quality of the cuisine left much to be desired, particularly the so-called 'Malaysian chicken curry,' which was subpar, to put it mildly. Suffice it to say that I shall not be returning to this eatery again in the foreseeable future."
I just found this place over price! Food was a bit of below average especially \"Malaysia chicken curry\". I don't think I will ever be back again.

Yes, this place was kind of lame.

The salsa was unmemorable, and that's a crying shame.

I got a spinch-y burrito of sorts, which was less than amazing... the spinach didn't taste particularly fresh... but at least the whole thing was drenched in cheese - a plus.

Considering the wealth of other Mexican restaurants in town, I doubt I'll return.

This dining experience marked our second visit to this establishment, yet unfortunately, it paled in comparison to our initial foray. The service was sluggish, with an unacceptable delay in receiving utensils, specifically a fork, which took a whopping five minutes to arrive. The culinary offerings were underwhelming, with the duck being merely passable and lacking in flavor, accompanied by a mediocre potato medallion that would not have been out of place on the menu of a fast-food chain such as McDonald's. Moreover, two of the dishes were served cold and required reheating, while the skirt steak arrived belatedly, when the rest of us were already concluding our meals. Furthermore, the meat possessed an unpleasant, stale taste, leading us to surmise that it was not fresh. The restaurant's excuse for the subpar service was that they were still recovering from an earlier rush of patrons, which we found unconvincing and unacceptable.

This was a second trip to this restaurant, but compared to the first visit......it was not good. Service was slow. Food was disappointing. Took 5 min. To get a fork to eat my meal. The duck was ok, but boring. Served with a medallion potato that could have come from mcdonalds. 2 of the meals were cold and had to be redone. The skirt steak arrived as the rest of us were finishing. And the meat tasted \"old\"..... Not fresh. We were there at 6 and it wasn't crowded, but their excuse was that they were still catching up from an earlier rush. Lame.

"My spouse and I opted to dine at this establishment for our progeny's natal day repast, subsequent to perusing the copious acclaim bestowed upon it in various reviews. Following our successful reservation endeavors via telephone at 11:30 A.M. on a Sunday, we were afforded the opportunity to partake in a delectable meal at 12:30 P.M. My better half tactfully inquired as to whether the eatery could provide any unique indulgences for the celebrant, and the gentleman assured him that such a request would pose no difficulty and that they would be capable of preparing a brownie-based Bday dessert. Upon our arrival, we were promptly seated. However, my contentment was somewhat diminished due to the restricted nature of their menu offerings. Although the cuisine was satisfactory, its quality did not warrant the cost. Specifically, the price of a single, free-range, grilled chicken breast accompanied by a side of fries, which we ordered for our child, was $15; thus, an expenditure of $25-30 per individual seemed reasonable. \n\nTo continue, our server failed to deliver the promised brownie dessert, despite it being complimentary or otherwise. As a considerate patron, I felt compelled to bring this oversight to the attention of our server, who subsequently charged us for the birthday brownie treat without expressing any gratitude. This experience left us feeling unappreciated, as complimentary Bday and anniversary desserts have customarily been offered at numerous other dining establishments we have visited. Consequently, we shall not return to this restaurant."

The beverages presented themselves as singular and flavorsome, yet their prices were exorbitant, a characteristic symptomatic of the city's tendency to inflate costs, much like an unchecked wildfire consuming all in its path. The culinary offerings, unfortunately, failed to leave a lasting impression, akin to a fleeting mirage on a sweltering summer day. As we partook of our repast, we concurred that the establishment's lofty ratings must have been predicated upon the ambiance, which, while pleasant, could not compensate for the gastronomical disappointment that followed. Our attempts to sample a variety of dishes, inclusive of the renowned duck salad, served only to reinforce our conviction that the fare was woefully lacking in quality. In conclusion, while the libations were indeed delectable and the hospitality commendable, the comestibles tragically fell short of expectations, thereby necessitating a reevaluation of our initial optimism.

Drinks were unique and delicious, but like everything in Vegas, wildly overpriced.  The food was not memorable at all. As we were eating, we agreed that the high ratings must come from people who enjoyed the atmosphere, which was nice.  We tried 5 or 6 dishes, including the famous duck salad. None of them were worth repeating. \n\nTasty drinks and great service, but food is grossly underwhelming.
The drinks were delish, The appetizers were the best part of the night. The entree, some spicy pasta dish... NOT impressed. Took most of it home and ended up throwing it away.

The Entree that we (group of 4) had was very good, but the Hot Chocolate Lava Cake was not what it was hyped up to be and what I thought was included with my meal was an extra charge. If you want a dessert latte go to McDonalds.

Been here 3 times now - mixed feelings.

Unfortunately the last 2 times the staff seemed disinterested in providing any reasonable level of service.

First time they made an incredible vegetarian sandwich for the wife - enough she wanted to go back!  My burger was delicious too.  Service was great!

Second time, our meals were a little less stellar.  Service was fair. ad - and I try LOTS if cobbler (my mom could make some awesome cobblers).

Third time, meals were sub-par, service was almost non-existent.
Good food but service was not. Might be back.  There was a woman at the bar that should have been cut off. Was very loud. The place was clean

When will I learn my lesson? Since the \"raids\" the quality of the staff has gotten really horrible. Terribly aggressive greeters who are trying to upsell you so hard that it gets really uncomfortable. Also, at the end of the line, I'vehad so many things left undone and they expect me to just pull away. On a recent visit, I had the entire passenger side cleaned with a Armourall soaked rag! When I complained, the young woman just walked away to the gas station convenience store and came back with a bag of Funyuns-I'm not kidding! While they tried to remove the Armourall, all Funyun Jane did was shove those yellow circles in her pie hole. They had to run it through the wash again because it wouldn't come off. Needless to say, when waiting an hour to get your car cleaned is ridiculous. I complained to the manager. She shrugged it off. So done. So crappy. I'm off the carousel for good..

"Indubitably, the eatery known as Blu Basil bears a striking resemblance to an aerodrome-based culinary establishment, and indeed, it possesses an inherent capacity for excellence; however, it is rather unfortunate that their tariffs are excessively elevated, to the point where they should be considered as being within the realm of fiscal reasonableness, rather than in the vicinity of dollar-sign-laden extravagance."

"I genuinely desire to endorse your culinary establishment, Moe's, as it is situated in close proximity to my domicile and offers a practical dining experience. However, my recent visit did not meet my expectations, despite my initial enthusiasm. I had anticipated savoring a delectable taco salad, complemented by an adequate portion of rich, creamy guacamole. Unfortunately, the dish that arrived lacked the promised flavor and featured an insufficient amount of the aforementioned condiment. My companion, who shares my appreciation for gastronomical excellence, concurred that my own humble guacamole surpassed the version served at your establishment. As someone who does not possess culinary expertise or a Mexican background, I had hoped for a more authentic experience. My search for a satisfying, rapid, and authentically Mexican meal continues."

"The barbecue served at this establishment is of satisfactory quality, however, the prices charged are, in my opinion, somewhat excessive. Notwithstanding the cost, the generous proportions of the dishes provide patrons with an adequate amount of sustenance. While the culinary offerings may be considered mediocre, the level of service I received during my most recent visit was subpar and, quite frankly, disconcerting. Specifically, the male staff member responsible for attending to our needs exhibited a discernible lack of enthusiasm and warmth in his interactions with me, despite his ostensibly cordial demeanor towards other customers. It is worth noting that the aforementioned employee was African American, and I cannot help but wonder if my own racial identity played a role in the disparity in treatment. Although I am not typically sensitive to such matters, the stark contrast in the way he engaged with me versus other patrons was impossible to ignore and left me feeling understandably disheartened. Notwithstanding this unfortunate experience, I shall return to this eatery in the future, primarily due to the complimentary ice cream offered and my children's fondness for the ham dish. A fervent hope that a more satisfactory level of service will be accorded to me on subsequent visits remains, however."

Pretty good BBQ but I find the prices to be a bit over priced. You get huge portions though. I consider the food closer to 3 stars but I received really bad service last time we were there. Which normally I would chalk up to someone having a bad day but the gentleman behind the counter who happened to be African American was much nicer to EVERYONE who he helped after us. I not usually one who notices if I am treated differently but it was blatant as he was giving out samples and being super friendly with everyone else when he barely even spoke to me or asked what I wanted to order. I don't know if race truly played a part of he just didn't like my smile but it put me off for sure and was pretty upsetting. Overall its nice because they give you free ice cream and my kids (who happen to be bi-racial) LOVE the ham! I will be back again I just hope that I get treated better next time.

The seafood prepared here was the least fresh I have had in Phoenix. I've had better results with the Sushi at Safeway or Trader Joes. The beer and wine menu also needs something to separate itself from every other restaurant. If you're looking for Sushi on the far West side, the only joint left after the demise of Be Sushi is Koi (across from the Arrowhead Harkins).

"The visual appeal of the culinary offering in question surpasses its gustatory experience, failing to constitute an extraordinary concatenation of flavors that would compel this writer to return to the establishment for said burger. The sole exception to this underwhelming gastronomic excursion was the onion rings, which demonstrated a satisfactory level of culinary expertise. Unfortunately, the utilization of a frozen burger patty precluded the possibility of a truly remarkable dining experience, particularly when considering the comparable cost to a superior alternative available at Hillstone. Furthermore, the eatery's state of cleanliness left much to be desired, catering to the late-night crowd with a seemingly negligible attention to hygiene. Our opinions."

I was anticipating that this establishment would be equipped with authentic Korean karaoke machines, but instead, I was confronted with an illicit Chinese knockoff that proved to be arduous to operate. Not only did the device lack the capacity to furnish us with genuine karaoke accompaniments, but it also failed to provide a user-friendly interface that would enable us to efficiently peruse its song catalog. Our gathering persisted in valiantly endeavoring to vocalize melodies at a volume surpassing that of the pre-recorded vocalists, while the remainder of the time was dedicated to attempting to locate tunes that were familiar to us. The ambiance and hospitality of the venue were unremarkable and would have warranted a rating of four stars had it not been for the glaring absence of genuine KTVs proficient in delivering authentic karaoke soundtracks, a user-friendly interface featuring search functionality, and staff members proficient in the English language.

Bad service, mediocre food, long long wait times.  We specifically ask for wings before our meal because for some reason, servers think a person will enjoy their dinner to be cold sitting on a table while we eat an appetizer.  Was no different here, waited 25 minutes for our appetizer and then receive our actual meal 2.5 minutes later, yeah I was being exact.  What the french toast?!

I paid $46 on Expedia. Location of the hotel was good for our visit to Glendale. Friendly staff throughout the facility. Free hot breakfast. Room was fine. I actually sighed with relief at the condition of the room because the halls, elevator, carpet, furniture in the lobby were not just dated they were dirty. While I was at breakfast I noticed they have a nice patio. The day was nice so I hoped to have breakfast there. The tables and chairs had not been cleaned in weeks. That  bothers me because there were three staff members talking off to the side of the dining area and only 3 seated eating  breakfast.

"Eccentric Park Ranger Mike Garcia's demeanor proved to be a significant hindrance to the overall enjoyment of our excursion, as his gruff and unfriendly demeanor created an inhospitable ambiance from the onset. My apologies for having inconvenienced him by merely visiting the site, but I must stress that a more congenial and welcoming individual would greatly enhance the experience for future patrons. Notwithstanding, the cinematic presentation was moderately engaging, and the ancient remnants were mildly fascinating, but I must reiterate that a more adept and affable customer service representative would significantly enhance the overall quality of the visit."

Grumpy Ranger Mike Garcia sets an unwelcome tone. Sorry to have disturbed his day by visiting. As a public face of such a great site it soured the visit from the very start. The movie was OK the ruins were OK but hey put a better people person as your front register guy.

We are indigenous to this vicinity, yet we visited this establishment in the company of acquaintances.  The hospitality we received was subpar, as our server was discourteous and inattentive.  
 We initiated our culinary excursion by partaking in potations; specifically, their frozen daiquiris, which were quite palatable! Subsequently, we indulged in the fried macaroni and cheese, which was an absolute delight, eliciting utterances of satisfaction.  
 Unfortunately, my hamburger was disappointing; I requested a cheeseburger comprehensive of all embellishments, including bacon, an additional expense I had failed to specify previously. Moreover, it did not arrive with french fries, an integral component of the dish, which I found perplexing. To avoid such oversights, it is imperative to request fries explicitly when placing an order.  
 Furthermore, the burger was frigid and undercooked, with a pinkish hue in the center. The cheese on the burger was also meager. Conclusively, it was a disappointing dining experience, prompting me to question the restaurant's dedication to burgers. Consequentially, I do not intend to revisit this establishment.

Sammy's Beach Bar and Grille, regrettably, adheres to the conventional quality of airport cuisine, characterized by exorbitant prices and subpar service, but despite these shortcomings, my spouse and I frequent this establishment with remarkable consistency when departing from McCarran Airport. The reasoning behind this phenomenon can be attributed to the exceptional quality of their Waborita, an indulgence that transcends the mundane nature of the menu's other offerings, such as the unremarkable nachos and chili-cheese fries. However, it is advisable to take a seat at the bar, as the service at this location is notoriously sluggish. Sammy's Beach Bar and Grille does, nevertheless, engage in numerous philanthropic endeavors within the local community, which renders a visit to this establishment marginally more acceptable. Thus, if you find yourself with some extra time before your flight, it may be worthwhile to indulge in a Waborita, despite its premium price point, as it is indeed a rather satisfying beverage.

"I had the privilege of attending the inaugural festivities of @SpaFitFinder, in the company of @spacephx. While I cannot offer a comprehensive assessment of the venue due to the substantial number of attendees, I must admit that the ambiance felt somewhat constricted. Notwithstanding this limitation, the TrimTini (?) I had the pleasure of sampling was truly delectable, boasting a delightful blend of vodka and lemon zest. Furthermore, I must extend my gratitude to an exceptionally courteous gentleman affiliated with Urban 7, who exhibited unwavering dedication in ensuring that each time he presented a fresh platter of hors d'oeuvres, he made a point to graciously offer me a taste. His efforts were indeed appreciated, as everything he served was scrumptious, including the ceviche, which, I must confess, does not typically pique my culinary interest. Despite the hospitable atmosphere and delectable fare, Urban 7 does not conform to my personal preferences, thus rendering it unlikely that I shall revisit the establishment in the near future. Nonetheless, I did enjoy myself at the event and valued the opportunity to partake in such a unique experience."

"A remarkably pleasant culinary experience, characterized by an impressive consistency in the quality of the fare provided, was had by us during our recent visit to this establishment, which has become our customary dining venue for breakfast; it is a suitable setting for families seeking a satisfying repast at a reasonable cost, albeit a rating of one star less was deemed necessary owing to the sluggishness of the service attributable to an insufficient number of personnel."

The steak was good, but not particularly impressive at $40 per plate. I got the Surf and Turf special with scallops, and two 5oz filet. The filets were good, cooked perfectly, and great cuts of meat. Just not wowed. The real disappointment was in the scallops that came with the dish. For the class of the place, one expects a certain level, and those scallops didn't even come close.

I found that KFC has really changed things.. and I am.. not sure it is for the better . 
The chicken is VERY salty. TOO salty. 
But i like their mashed potatoes and their coleslaw and mac n cheese. and the biscuits are good. 
I don't think that i would make this a habit, AT ALL.

All right.  If you're a straight lady going to Hooters then you're going for the wings.  Am I right?  Unless you're trying to prove something.  And I think I've been good about saying this - heck, I haven't had to say it yet because the QC has been a pleasant surprise for the most part - but every Hooters in Chicagoland has better wings than this Hooters.  Hell, the Hooters in Puerto Vallarta had better wings.  These were not as flavorful, the batter was not as... I don't know, flakey I suppose.  They were extremely mediocre.  Now I prefer to go to a small local joint over a chain most of the time, I prefer to try something new.  So dang it, if I want Hooters wings, they need to taste like Hooters wings!  Standardization, people!\n\nBah. Well, the server was sweet at least.  Sometimes when a couple walks into a Hooters, they get snubbed a bit because the waitresses are all leaning over the horny businessman tables trying to get tips. But Shaun (I think that was how it was spelled) was nice.

My wife and I have been going to Thursday night dinner at House of Blues for many years, as we enjoy seeing some of our favorite local bands play during dinner. Last night was the first time we have been there in a couple months, and were severely disappointed.

To start the night off poorly, the hostess placed us, essentially, on the casino floor in the farthest table from the stage. We asked if we could have one of the empty tables closer to the stage, being told "no, there is no server for that section." Before our drink order was taken, there were people seated at those empty tables.

Then, looking at the menu, we were even more disappointed and aggravated. We expect to pay more than normal restaurant prices to eat at House of Blues. However, $3.99 for an ice cream scoop of luke warm/cold mashed potatoes and the same price for an equal amount of snap peas is asinine. 

Their entire menu has drastically gone up in price and down in selection. None of the good items are available anymore.

The only reason two stars got marked, after talking to one of the floor managers, she apologized at the illogical reason we were not permitted to sit at quality tables, moved us to a better section and comp'd us some drinks and dessert. Our servers were also pretty on top of things. 

After having that first, bad experience as we got to the restaurant, it tilted the night's mood.

The seats are very uncomfortable. The first two we sat in were broken. They are old and dirty. We went to see the screening of a Metropolitan Opera performance. There was quite a bit of sound from the theater next door. The popcorn tastes like it has been sitting for a while. The imitation butter has no butter flavor. You have to put it on yourself so the top of the bag is soaked and the bottom has none. There is no flavored salt like the Harkin Theater provide. \n\nThe Met has a great program in a poor venue.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
The reviewer expresses their disappointment with the quality of food at a restaurant, describing it as "mediocre at best" and comparing it unfavorably to Denny's, a well-known chain of diners. They criticize the biscuits for being made from pre-mixed Bisquick, the gravy for lacking sausage, and the chicken fried steak for tasting like a breaded hamburger patty. However, they do acknowledge that the Apple Danish was a pleasant exception to the overall mediocrity of the meal.

Mediocre at best, slight step up from Denny's. The biscuits were made from bisquick , there was no sausage in the anemic gravy and the chicken fried steak was just breaded hamburger. The Apple Danish was good though.

Seriously 35 bucks a head?  The mac and cheese station was a cool idea, but seriously the mac and cheese was runny and it just didnt work, the desserts could of been richer and a better selection.  The salads were good, they had a marscapone infused polenta that was excellent.  No big shrimp cocktail, the crab legs were luke warm and not hot, its a nice dining area, servers were quick and attentive, but for the price this not a deal, or a buffet I will go to again.  The asian area only had 3 items, and the sushi selection was HORRIBLE, no ahi no sashimi or nigiri, the rolls looked lame and like something you would find at a gas station in barstow.

I must admit to being totally underwhelmed with our dining experience at Strip Steak, Mandalay Bay.

Firstly the time between ordering and receiving our food was lengthy  although the restaurant didn't appear to be very full. When  we did receive our dinner,  nothing was piping hot. 

I had the chop and I think it was probably the blandest piece of meat I have ever eaten.  Totally devoid of any flavor what so ever.  My companions who both ordered the Filet Mignon, found they were  satisfactory but neither completely finished their steaks as they just weren't that good. 
 
The duck fat fries were delicious, truffle mac and cheese was okay.  The asparagus was nice, but the mushrooms were cold.  The selection of desserts was poor although the cheese cake was very light and delicious. 

 As I said a totally underwhelming dining experience.   Frankly I would have been disappointed if I we had eaten this meal at a steakhouse with a mid range price point but this meal cost over $400.00. 
I would recommend skipping Strip Steak if you wish to avoid being disappointed.

"The culinary experience provided by the establishment was of considerable quality and expediency, as evidenced by the swiftness with which our orders were fulfilled. Specifically, we opted for the Octoberfest burger and a cheeseburger, respectively, as our entrÃ©es. Notably, the portion of fries accompanying our meals was copious, rendering requests for additional servings superfluous. However, it is worth mentioning that neither of us was particularly enthused by the gustatory sensations elicited by the burgers, as they seemed to bear a striking resemblance to meatloaf or perhaps even contained a filler substance, although the latter possibility is admittedly uncertain. While we are not averse to expending ten dollars on a superior-quality burger, our assessment led us to conclude that this particular offering did not warrant such an investment."

The service was very good and quick. Ordered a Octoberfest burger and guest a cheeseburger. \nThe amount of Fries served was more than enough where asking for endless ones was not needed. Can't say either of us was impressed with the burgers. Both of us thought it was similar to meatloaf or had a filler (though that's doubtful). Don't mind spending $10 for a burger, but IMO this one was not worth it.

Our group decided to come here for Sunday brunch. Prices range from 7.95 to 10.95 for breakfast or lunch. Some of us ordered the eggs benedict which was actually good. The turkey lunch was all right, the mash potatoes tasted like it was boxed and the stuffing was too salty. Someone also ordered eggs, fruit and croissant which was fine. The reason I'm giving two stars was the POOR SERVICE. Entering, the host didn't acknowledge us. No greeting at all. Not even a BON JOUR! The waiter never introduced himself. He seemed annoyed half the time. He didn't smile and was not friendly. Maybe the attitude is supposed to represent being in France (the total French experience) or he hated his job and he didn't want to be there. This company needs to revisit customer service 101 to their employees. I think we would of received better service at Denny's or Village Inn.

So overrated! I had my birthday dinner here and they messed up almost everything. My friend had croutons on her salad despite ordering it gluten-free, my sister's burger was burned to a crisp, they gave my grandma jalapenos on her sandwich which was ordered without them. The beer is good but other than that it's a no. They allow smoking on the patio and the smell gets into the restaurant and it is so gross. Go to Four Peaks instead

The gastronomical experience at this establishment was utterly disappointing, with the pasta dish, specifically the Lasagna, being severely overcooked, resulting in an unpleasant texture and a lack of flavor, further exacerbated by the excessive amount of cheese used, which effectively drowned out any remaining taste, while the pizza, although having an acceptable dough and sauce, suffered from an overabundance of cheese, rendering it unremarkable and lackluster, and the service provided by the elderly server was apathetic and inattentive, adding to the overall unsatisfactory ambiance of the restaurant, which was further marred by the utilization of vinyl tablecloths and gaudy decorations that would not have been out of place in a less affluent neighborhood in New York City, ultimately leading to the conclusion that there is no compelling reason to return to this eatery.

Last week, my significant other and I opted to dine at this establishment, during which I selected the ahi sliders as an appetizer, in addition to ordering the I love bacon burger; however, both items did not meet my expectations in terms of taste and quality. Specifically, the slider buns utilized did not complement the flavors of the fish and ponzu sauce, while the burger lacked any discernible sauce, rendering it unappealing and causing me to abandon its consumption. Similarly, my companion's jalapeno burger failed to impress, leading him to leave most of it uneaten. Despite this disappointing experience, I may give the restaurant another chance, considering that perhaps they experienced an off-day in their operations.

So my bf and I decided to eat here last week, I ordered the ahi sliders as and app plus I ordered the I love bacon burger, both weren't as good as I wanted it to be. The slider buns they use didn't match the flavor of the fish and ponzu sauce. The burger had no sauce on it so I didn't even want to finish my burgers. My bf ordered the jalapeno burger and he also didn't eat it all.. I'll probably try it again they might of just had a bad day

The service was incredibly slow and the waiter and bartenders ignored our group. 

I have eaten here once more before and did not have the best experience. I was reluctant to go back but my friends are new to the area and wanted to try it out.

The atmosphere is very nice though.

Spent 5 days in Vegas and this was the highest priced meal bill that I had.  That includes buffets at the Wynn and Studio B at the M Resort. 
We were looking for something without a long wait.  Seated quickly, nice service, 
But my goodness!  Way too expensive for a burger and fries!
Food is all "a la carte".
No, there are better choices out there.

"The gado gado sauce exhibited exceptional quality, however, the chicken suffered from an excessive frying process, resulting in a deleterious texture. Furthermore, the sauce accompanying the mixed vegetables presented an unfortunate dearth of subtlety in its viscosity, rendering it excessively thick, inordinately salty, and suspectible to an abundance of monosodium glutamate."
the gado gado sauce was great but the chicken was overly fried. the sauce in the mixed veggies was just way too thick, way too salty and probably loaded with msg.

"Culinary offerings were satisfactory, with the customary poultry appendages being of an acceptable quality; however, our attempt to partake in a tranquil evening on the outdoor seating area was significantly impeded by the presence of substantial debris, which suggested a lack of consistent maintenance and attention to detail, thereby warranting the implementation of a regular cleaning schedule to ensure a more pleasant dining experience for patrons."

"Uncertainty permeates my thoughts regarding the culinary offerings at other establishments within the valley, yet the evening repast we partook at the North Scottsdale venue that superseded Mark Gerding's Thai Pan left much to be desired. In essence, the proprietors must abandon their strategy to incorporate a sushi bar (at a Thai eatery? Recall that Malees' attempt proved futile as well) and instead concentrate on enhancing the flavors and textures within their Thai creations. It requires more than a liberal sprinkling of red chili pepper flakes to generate heat in a dish; furthermore, discerning palates can distinguish between the contrasting textures of canned and fresh pineapple. Although the peanut sauce was delectable, and my spouse managed to salvage the red curry by augmenting it with an array of piquant condiments presented upon request, the remaining three dishes we sampled fell short of expectations. I am still endeavoring to comprehend the rationale behind the reviewer's assertion that 'This establishment refrains from catering to "dumbed-down" American palates. This is genuine Thai cuisine, characterized by that inimitable fusion of spices and flavorings.' Such a statement warrants a thorough examination of the critic's taste buds by a medical professional! For the time being, my family and I shall continue to satisfy our Thai cravings with Swaddee and Sala Thai."

"Meh, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, to say the least (haha, Yelp's reviews often mirror my sentiments). My recent visit to this establishment was prompted by my craving for an authentic Taiwanese breakfast experience, and upon arriving at Chinatown, I was delighted to discover 'YongHe,' which translates to 'Taiwanese breakfast' in Chinese characters. However, my excitement was short-lived, as the restaurant's attempt at replicating Taiwanese cuisine fell short of my expectations. While I appreciate their effort to diversify their menu, the end result was a far cry from the real deal. The beef wrap/roll and Chinese donuts (youtiao) I ordered were unimpressive, with the former being merely a lazy adaptation of a cold appetizer, consisting of various cuts of beef marinated in chili oil, stuffed into a shaobing (Taiwanese-style bread). The latter was slightly more satisfactory, albeit difficult to botch, given its simplicity. The soymilk and fantuan (rice roll) were unremarkable, with the latter being a standard item that is challenging to prepare incorrectly. In conclusion, my experience at this purported Taiwanese breakfast spot was underwhelming, and the service left much to be desired. Our order took an inordinate amount of time to be taken by the waitstaff, and the tea arrived at an equally glacial pace, leading me to surmise that the restaurant was understaffed, despite not being particularly busy. Unfortunately, this establishment does not rank high on my list of preferred dining establishments, and I am unlikely to return for dinner."

Meh.  I've experienced better. (haha Yelp took the words right out of my mouth).

So I came here over the weekend looking for some Taiwanese breakfast and figured Chinatown must have it.  Got to Chinatown, saw "YongHe" outside which means Taiwanese breakfast so I was pretty excited when I went in.  

I'm grateful that they are attempting Taiwanese style breakfast but I feel bad for the people that actually think this is good.  Being a Szechuan restaurant, naturally they would have a lot of spicy food.  I ordered a beef wrap/roll and some Chinese donuts (youtiao).  Pretty much it was different cuts of beef marinated in chili oil that's usually served as a cold appetizer but then they stick it in the middle of a shaobing (Taiwanese-style bread). Kinda of a lazy way of doing things. I guess it is smart, using the same ingredients for 2 different dishes haha. Not really authentic. The youtiao was pretty good.  Kinda hard to mess THAT up since it is just frying dough!

Their soymilk tastes like soymilk and the fantuan (rice roll) looked ok but that's hard to mess up too.  Overall for a Taiwanese breakfast place, it's whatevvvss.

Service wasn't the greatest either.  We waited over 15 minutes to hand our order slip to the waiter and the tea took forever to arrive.  It seemed like they were understaffed but the restaurant wasn't even half full.. Maybe dinner service would be better but it's not really on my radar anymore.

"This particular Walmart location can be characterized as understocked and somewhat disorganized, thereby creating an environment that may engender feelings of unease among patrons. Additionally, the likelihood of securing prompt and efficient assistance from employees appears to be low, thus augmenting the overall sense of frustration. In light of these factors, it may be advisable to consider alternative retail establishments, such as a more well-stocked and organized Walmart location, which may offer a more satisfactory shopping experience. However, it is worth noting that the convenience of this particular store may prove to be a significant draw for individuals who prioritize proximity over other considerations."

"I opted to treat my spouse to a culinary excursion at this establishment, primarily due to the favorable critiques it had received. Following a prompt seating, I eagerly anticipated an authentic Italian dining experience. Unfortunately, my expectations were not met, as the fare served lacked any discernible flavor profile. Both my companion and I selected fettuccine alfredo, but were disappointed to discover that the dish did not exhibit the characteristic richness and depth of flavor typically associated with this quintessential Italian dish. The absence of garlic and other distinctive flavors was particularly noticeable. Upon the waitstaff inquiring about our satisfaction, I felt compelled to offer an honest assessment, expressing my disappointment at the bland nature of the cuisine. In response, the server offered a complimentary dessert, though unfortunately, it too failed to impress. In my opinion, this restaurant does not compare favorably to other dining options, including the likes of Olive Garden. As an alternative, I suggest preparing a meal at home, selecting your own ingredients, and enjoying a romantic evening with your significant other. Not only will this approach be more economical, but the quality and variety of flavors you can create will surpass those offered by this establishment."

I brought my wife here for a special meal.  I mean, after all, the reviews were very kind and so I figured it would be a nice place to come. They sat us right away and I was expecting a nice Italian dinner.  The waitress was very nice, however, the food lacked completely.  My wife and I both ordered fettuccine alfredo, and I'm sorry to report that there was absolutely no taste in the food.  There was no garlic, no flavors that you would expect in a (expensive) Italian meal.  When the waitress asked how everything was, we were very honest.  I explained that there was no flavor in the food, to which she apologized.  She brought terimisu (sp?) out complementary at the end, but again, even that lacked flavor.  I hate to say it, but Olive Garden has more flavor, and we despise going there!  This is my suggestion - go to the grocery store, buy your own ingredients, buy a bottle of wine, and have a stay at home date with your partner.  Not only will it be cheaper, but the flavors you can create yourself will beat this restaurant any day.

Boating today in Madison and stopped here for lunch.  Nice and sunny on the deck. The food sounded great.  I got the shrimp po boy, two others in our party got the tuna steak sandwich and another got the chicken panini.  All of us took our first few bites and each said, \"It's okay.\"  The chicken in the panini was a bit too tough, the tuna steak was overcooked and the po boy was five pieces of shrimp, lettuce and tomato in a big, fat white bread bun.  My sweet potato fries had too much batter on them to make them crispy.  Frozen from a bag?  Seemed to be.  What ever happened to actual fries?  Now they add all of this junk on the outside to make them better?  Not in my opinion.  Next time we're boating the lakes in Mad-town, we will skip Bourbon Street Grille and head to the Green Lantern.
Great service and atmosphere. The food and drinks are way overpriced though. If you like your Mexican food mild to bland, this is the place for you.

Huge disappointment!

We were debating between the Weekend Champagne Brunch at Bellagio and The Wynn. We eventually decided on The Wynn due to other reviews saying the Bellagio looked like a cafeteria and the atmosphere was much better at The Wynn.

The food was mediocre at best. Cold entrees, dry fish, overcooked prime rib, watery crab legs. The only highlight was the shrimp (16-20 count). Other than that the only memorable thing about this buffet was the price: $50pp with tax and tip. NOT WORTH IT!

We made it back here to give them another try. While the food wasn't terrible it wasn't amazing either. I stand by my original review. I had to add salt and pepper to my steak because it lacked flavor. Also this piece of prime rib was mostly fat. I cook steaks at home and know all about marbeling and how it gives flavor but there needs to be an even balance between the fat and meat otherwise you just feel ripped off. I still feel going to Outback Steakhouse will give you better tasting steaks with lower prices. The location on Chandler Blvd had never disappointed. Sorry Firebirds you're just not for us.

Drove from union county for fried chicken and onion rings.  They have removed onion rings from the menu!!  Why?  They were amazing.  Fried chicken was cooked in old oil, and I do mean OLD.  They should utilize a filter agent or change oil more often.  Have been a patron for years, this will not encourage my continued patronage.

"Delectable and supreme Chinese cuisine...an incongruous appellation.

Do not misconstrue my sentiments; the culinary offerings are not necessarily mediocre, but they fail to meet expectations engendered by such an eponymous title. The Chicken Chow Mein, however, proves to be an absolute epicurean delight, and its inclusion in various combination plates and special deals renders it an affordable option at $4.95 and $6.95, respectively.

A cursory examination of the menu reveals a propensity for inconsistency in the quality of dishes. Although I derived satisfaction from both the Kung Pao Chicken and Szechuan Chicken, the remainder of the menu items have proven somewhat disappointing. Notably, the Honey Garlic Chicken fails to differentiate itself substantially from its sweet and sour counterpart, save for an unpleasant sauce. 

As previously stated, the Chicken Chow Mein earns high praise, unfortunately, the Chicken Fried Rice falls short of gastronomical expectations. On two separate occasions, the dish arrived lacking flavor and containing raw rice, prompting me to reconsider future orders. Accompanying each entree is a forgettable Egg-Drop soup, neither impressive nor particularly objectionable.

Furthermore, the restaurant appears stingy regarding the allocation of meat and vegetables. When ordering sans vegetables, the attendant behind the counter poses a seemingly rhetorical query, 'So, you desire Chicken Chow Mein and a minimal amount of flesh.' Such a statement strikes me as somewhat peculiar, yet I surmise it betrays a tacit understanding of the establishment's predilection for scanty protein portions. 

In conclusion, this eatery merits avoidance. The sole motivation behind my initial visit stemmed from proximity to Launderland, now defunct, rendering future visits unlikely."

Delicious & Best Chinese Food...not an apt name.

Don't get me wrong, the food isn't bad, but it's also not very good either. The Chicken Chow Mein tastes absolutely delicious though, which happens to come with all of the Combinations and All-Day Specials...which are a good deal at $4.95 and $6.95 respectively.

The items are rather hit and miss on the menu. I enjoyed the Kung Pao Chicken and Szechuan Chicken, but everything else has proved to be rather disappointing. I was very disappointed to find that the Honey Garlic Chicken is essentially the same thing as Sweet and Sour Chicken, only with a nastier sauce. 

As mentioned before, the Chicken Chow Mein is fantastic, but the Chicken Fried Rice is pretty horrendous. The two times I've had it, it was relatively tasteless and there were pieces of uncooked rice in the mix. The meals also come with an unremarkable Egg-Drop soup...neither good nor bad.

Also, they REALLY skimp on the meat to vegetable ratio. I order my food without vegetables at this place, and the guy behind the counter always cheekily asks,"So, you want Chicken Chow Mein and a little bit of meat." That's already sort of what I was expecting, but I thought it was a bit goofy that he would just come out and say it.

Honestly, this place is worthy of skipping. The only reason I ever tried this joint is because I did my laundry at Launderland three doors down. Now that ithe laundromat is out of business, it's likely I'll never return to D&B.

"Maintaining a concise and succinct approach, Tao's experience was merely average. A acquaintance of mine recounted her arduous attempts to gain entry, with three unsuccessful endeavors before finally gaining admittance. Subsequently, we were directed and corralled until the door attendant, a kind and patient individual, took the time to meticulously elaborate on the venue's design prior to stamping my wrist. Embarking on a leisurely stroll, we observed the culinary offerings, which appeared appetizing, and the ornamental aspects, which were pleasing to the eye. However, the overcrowding and boisterous atmosphere, with individuals pushing and shoving without even a cursory apology, significantly dampened our spirits. Proceeding to Tao Beach, we found the space to be surprisingly diminutive, with the pool areas at MGM being approximately eight times larger. Furthermore, the absence of seating and dancing areas rendered the experience less enjoyable. Ascending downstairs, we encountered a queue, a phenomenon we had not anticipated, and noticed that the DJs at different levels were playing nearly identical tunes. Ultimately, despite having the opportunity to partake in the experience, it proved to be more disappointing than visiting a Hollywood club, with the added drawback of the lack of bacon-wrapped hot dogs available outside."

"It is utterly perplexing how a dining establishment specializing in seafood, such as this one, could possibly continue to operate while offering such unremarkable culinary experiences. One would assume that the inclusion of a wine list featuring a Sancerre vintage from 2010 would serve as a redeeming factor, but alas, it appears that even this ostensible asset has failed to materialize in any tangible manner."

Last night, we opted to partake of a dining experience at this establishment, primarily due to the fact that we were in possession of a gift certificate, which, in essence, served as an inducement for us to visit said restaurant. Unfortunately, our maiden voyage to this culinary venue proved to be suboptimal, as we encountered several drawbacks that detracted from our overall satisfaction. Firstly, the server who attended to our needs exhibited behavior that could best be described as eccentric, which contributed to an atmosphere that was not particularly conducive to a relaxing dining experience. Furthermore, the table at which we were seated was situated in a rather cramped corner of the dining area, which further added to our discomfort. Compounding these issues was the presence of numerous flies that seemed to be ubiquitous throughout the premises, which not only proved to be a nuisance but also raised concerns regarding the cleanliness and hygiene standards maintained by the establishment. To top it all off, the menu options available were rather unconventional and failed to cater to our taste preferences, rendering our dining experience even more disappointing. In light of the aforementioned factors, we have decided that a return visit to this restaurant is unlikely in the near future.

"Negative, Samba at The Mirage was an utter letdown.  Moreover, I should have been cognizant of the fact based on the plethora of unfavorable reviews posted herein.  It would be advisable to patronize an alternative Brazilian Steakhouse within the vicinity, despite the possibility of higher prices.  At this establishment, the servers made a concerted effort to satiate us with copious portions of poultry, arid sausages, and even garlic bread, all of which were proffered on skewers prior to the presentation of the sirloin and lamb.  Subsequently, the server excised two minuscule pieces of beef from the roast.  My thoughts were, 'Aha! I shall receive additional beef subsequently.'  Unfortunately, that was not the case, as upon completion of their numerous rounds, they ceased their visits altogether.  Although, upon my request for further sirloin, the staff accommodated my desire with a modicum of extra meat.  The plantains, rice, and beans were of superior quality.  The confection (creme brÃ»lÃ©e) was unfortunate - its taste was reminiscent of having been stored in a refrigerated state for an extended period of time."

No, Samba at The Mirage was a major disappointment.   And I should have known based on the other reviews here.  Go to another Brazilian Steakhouse in town, even it is more expensive.  Here they tried to stuff us with large pieces of chicken, dry sausages, and even garlic bread on their skewers before they bring the sirloin and lamb.  Then he cuts two bite- size pieces of beef off the roast.  I am thinking, okay, I will get more beef later.  No, when they have gone through all the rounds, they stop coming by.   Granted, when I asked for more sirloin, the staff brought out a bit more.  The plantains, rice and beans are good.  The dessert (creme br\u00fbl\u00e9e) was awful - tasted as if had been sitting in the fridge for several days.

My boyfriend and I got take out from here tonight. We've been to the restaurant once and I remembered thinking it was good. 

Tonight we got the bruschetta which was fine. It wasn't amazing. For our entree he got the blackened chicken pasta, which I tried. It tasted like this chef boyardie thing I used to eat when I was a kid. I got the four cheese pizza. Not the worst pizza I've ever had, however definitely not the best. There was barely any sauce and the cheese tasted plasticy. 

Nothing to brag about.

"The culinary experience offered by this establishment's pizza leaves much to be desired, with an apparent dearth of adequate cooking time resulting in a lackluster texture that fails to deliver on the crispy, golden delights one would expect from a well-crafted pie. Furthermore, the sauce, which could have served as a saving grace, regrettably falls short of any discernible distinction or depth, relying instead on a tired and overused formula that reeks of mass-produced mediocrity. While the price point may be considered reasonable, the paltry sum does little to assuage the disappointment occasioned by the underwhelming taste and questionable quality of the ingredients. Some solace may be found, however, in the cordial demeanor of the staff, who, despite their efforts, cannot fully compensate for the gastronomic letdown that is the pizza itself."

The pizza here is way undercooked. It seems to be a theme in Pittsburgh in general to not cook the pie long enough for it to crisp up and the cheese to get golden. The sauce was pretty generic and tasted like cheap stuff from a jar. The price was fair at about $2 a slice. The workers at the counter were friendly. However, the pizza itself is just doughy/rubbery and pretty bland.

Decent place, friendly staff, but poor wine list.  I asked the staff about the list and was told the owners only want to carry wines that nobody else does.  My guess is that they want to carry wines that you are not familiar with so you don't know how badly you are getting ripped off.  I had a $10 glass of a $11 bottle of wine (retail).  It was ok, and I expect high prices at a bar but I at least want a decent glass.

"Contrary to expectations considering its association with the esteemed City Art Centre, the quality of service and culinary offerings at this particular establishment falls short of excellence, with a rather uninspiring ambiance characterized by a high ceiling and an abundance of artificial lighting, and a breakfast menu that fails to provide adequate value for the price point, particularly when compared to superior alternatives available in the vicinity for a comparable cost."

"Well, I must admit that I had been fixated on this establishment for quite some time in the past. However, after a hiatus of approximately a month, I returned to find that numerous alterations had taken place. The menu had undergone significant changes, with several of my preferred dishes conspicuously absent. Furthermore, the array of options appeared to have diminished substantially. The most disheartening aspect of my visit, however, was the absence of the all-you-can-drink draft beer option, which had previously been available as an add-on for the all-you-can-eat menu. It is rather evident that the primary motivation for our frequent visits was the opportunity to indulge in unlimited draft beer at a relatively reasonable price, as opposed to paying an exorbitant fee for a single beer. Unfortunately, this feature is no longer available, and I fear that it may deter me from visiting this location as frequently in the future. There are numerous alternative sushi restaurants in the vicinity that offer comparable or superior quality food and beverages at more affordable prices. While they may be somewhat further away from my residence, the appeal of this particular establishment has undoubtedly diminished."

Well, I USED to be obsessed with this place. I didn't come in for about a month and on my recent visit, everything was different. The menu changed and they took off a lot of my favorite rolls. Didn't seem like there were as many options as before. 

The saddest part of my visit was that they no longer have the all you can drink draft beer as an add on for all you can eat.  To be honest that's one of the main reasons we would all come here, because who wants to pay $7 for ONE beer when you can pay $4.99 for all you can drink draft Sapporo?! Nobody, that's who! 

Needless to say, I probably won't be frequenting this location anymore. There's plenty of other good sushi restaurants with cheaper AYCE and alcohol specials. Yes they're farther from my house but this place has lost its luster. If it was still the awesome Sushi Bomb I knew and loved, we would still all be going there!

Be careful, all sales are final and the owner won't allow even a store credit for return of brand new merchandise.  Unfortunate, otherwise a lovely store with nice salespeople and a really good selection of merchandise.

I engage in ardent academic pursuits. However, identifying suitable locations for such endeavors within Glendale presents a formidable challenge. Paradise, among the more convenient options in the vicinity of my educational institution, offers an array of amenities, including an abundance of electrical outlets, Wi-Fi connectivity that is moderately dependable, and coffee that, while unlimited, leaves much to be desired in terms of its mediocre quality. Additionally, the complimentary samples of baked goods prove a welcome gesture, albeit one that does little to alleviate the financial burden of student loans surpassing a quarter of a million dollars.

It must be noted, however, that the offerings at Paradise fail to justify their cost. The coffee, characterized by an uninspired blend of bitterness and a lackluster flavor profile, falls short of even the most modest expectations. Furthermore, the prices charged for food items are exorbitant, considering the questionable quality of the fare. As a purported bakery, the bread served at Paradise is remarkably bland in taste, while the cookies, replete with artificial additives and preservatives, offer little in the way of genuine culinary satisfaction.

While I shall continue to frequent Paradise for the sake of variety and a brief respite from my studies, I cannot, in good conscience, recommend it for any purpose beyond that.

I study a lot.  Finding places to study in Glendale isn't easy.  Paradise is the best of the "easy" options I've found around school.  They have plenty of plugs, halfway reliable wifi, and pretty good (unlimited) coffee.  Oh, and the free samples of cookies and bread are also nice when you're in the realm of $250,000 in debt.

That being said, nothing here is particularly worth it's cost.  The coffee is "generic dark" or "flavored".  I take my coffee pretty seriously, so this was the first major sin they committed upon my person.  The food is also WAY overpriced for the quality.  This place is supposed to be a bakery.  Why is the bread so dull tasting?  Why do the cookies taste like nothing more than preservative and artificial dyes?

Yeah, I'll keep going here for the coffee and a change of pace, but I'm not going to recommend it for anything beyond that.

The food was good, our griller was nice, but did seem a little inexperienced. Our waitress was nice, but took forever when it came to refilling our drinks, getting our bill, and had even forgot to give my husbands card back so he had to go back the next day to retrieve it! As if that wasn't bad enough she dropped a fork in sauce when reaching to pack up our food and she splattered sauce all over my husband.

With us we had our two kids as well, and they thought the food was great, but later when we got home, we all got soooo sick, my poor daughter even had to stay home from school the next day. Had to throw out all our $20 an average plate food, what a waste!

Then to top it off, the bathrooms! Both the men's and women's bathrooms were awful!!! I would have rather used a port-a-potty! I don't even want to go in to details they were that bad!!!

This was our second time there, the first was a decent experience, but this last experienced has left my family and I scarred!!! We are bummed because we love these types of grills, but we will not be returning to this specific one again.

Meh...compared to Encore Beach, Wet Republic, or Marquee, this venue is lacking.  It was too packed and needs a bigger pool if they are going to admit that many people.  Not enough shady spots/umbrellas/trees or different little areas to get away from the main area if you need to.  Only one bar, and it took forever.  Went Memorial Day opening weekend and cabanas or daybeds were absolutely ridiculous in terms of cost (and not full).  And as with most things Vegas, everything was pretty ridiculous in terms of cost.  Lockers were $40 bucks for the day, waters were $10, big sports bottles of booze were $40.\n\nEven though I didn't like the venue itself, the crowd was fun and they bring in some pretty good DJs.  Make sure you get there on the early side so you can get in.

"Upon entering the bakery on a Wednesday afternoon, I was immediately struck by the welcoming ambiance that permeated the establishment. The staff exuded an aura of warmth and hospitality, which served as a harbinger for the delectable delights that lay ahead. My curiosity piqued by the unfamiliar sight of macarons, I felt compelled to sample this enigmatic pastry. Admittedly, my preconceived notion of macarons was that of a cake sandwich possessing a diminutive stature and a texture akin to that of a small cake, with an icing filling that would provide a delightful contrast to the surrounding sweetness. Thus, I opted to indulge in an assortment of flavors, including peach, vanilla almond, vanilla, raspberry, and the blue variety (the name of which escapes me at present). Alas, my expectations were not entirely met, as upon taking a bite, I discovered that the macarons possessed a curious combination of crunchiness and softness that, regrettably, proved excessively saccharine for my refined palate. This sensory experience brought to mind the texture and flavor profile of a cookie, leading me to surmise that while some individuals might find macarons appealing, they did not align with my personal gustatory preferences. Despite this minor setback, I remain eager to revisit the bakery and explore their other culinary offerings."

Last evening, my spouse and I partook of a culinary experience at this establishment, and our gastronomical expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as the victuals we consumed seemed to lack the authenticity and flavor that we have come to anticipate from such an eatery. Specifically, the taste and temperature of the dishes we ordered left much to be desired, with each item seeming to have been hastily prepared and served straight from a can, devoid of any semblance of warmth or freshness. Although our server was quite affable and courteous throughout our meal, their repeated insistence on emphasizing the supposedly "homemade" nature of the cuisine struck us as somewhat disingenuous and misleading, implying that merely reheating pre-prepared foods in a kitchen could somehow qualify them as being of a genuinely artisanal or handcrafted quality.

Ate there with the wife last night. Everything tasted to us like it was straight out of a can and came to the table cold. Server was nice, but the everything home made speech is a crock. Just because it was put in a pot, then from a pot to a plate does not mean it should be called homemade or hand made.

I infrequently enter a Walmart establishment, with an average frequency of once every three months. Upon entering the premises, I am consistently met with an unorganized and chaotic environment; it is truly perplexing how customers are able to navigate the store and locate their desired items amidst the disarray. On a recent visit, I embarked on a quest to procure a specific product, specifically a vacuum cleaner, and was taken aback by the utter disarray in which the merchandise was displayed. The various sections within the store were in complete disarray, resembling a haphazard bargain basement sale. It appears that the staff has adopted an apathetic attitude towards maintaining a well-organized and welcoming shopping environment, which is particularly concerning given the broad range of products available, ranging from modestly priced items at $38 to more extravagant offerings exceeding $400.  

Upon proceeding to the checkout area, I was taken aback by the absence of a cashier, despite the presence of a illuminated indicator signaling that the register was operational. My companion and I hesitated, contemplating whether to remain and wait for the cashier's return or to abandon our purchases altogether. Fortunately, a managerial figure noticed our predicament and summoned the cashier back to her post, thereby allowing us to complete our transaction. It is worth noting that this particular Walmart location boasts an inadequate number of parking spaces designated for handicapped individuals, resulting in a frequent shortage of accessible parking options. Despite the prevalence of vehicles displaying permits, the management has elected not to expand these spaces, a decision that is both disappointing and reprehensible.

I rarely walk into a Walmart, maybe once per quarter. This store is a mess! In fact it's so much of a mess that I wonder how people shop. A quiet Monday evening and there are carts full of merchandise around the store just sitting there. Went in looking for one particular product (a vacuum) and the sections were completely in shambles. A shame when you are looking at products that range from $38 to over $400. This reminds me of a bad bargain basement sale. It's like no one really cares and forget trying to find products on the shelves. Really... the competition has come to town and instead of competing you decide making your store look like trash is the way to go.... really!

Walked to the cash to pay, light is on, but the cashier isn't even there. We stand there for a while deciding if we are going to pay for what we have in hand. Manager notices us and calls girl back to her cash. Four cashiers for the whole store and one goes walking away leaving people waiting? 

Important Note: This Walmart has very limited handicapped parking and it is often impossible to find a spot. They just don't care enough to increase the spots, in spite of the fact that they are often full with cars that all have permits. Shameful.

Saw this place walking on the strip and it looked really cool with the outdoor seating overlooking it. Also being from NY I know this place seems to be a hit. First we tried to be seated, and had to walk to the back of the restaurant and thru all the tables only to walk back to the front. A little strange but OK.  Our server was really nice and helpful while he was at our table but once he left it was hard to get his attention about something. I ordered a burger because i was indecisive about what to get, and figured it was hard to mess up. Boy was I wrong. Meat was almost inedible. My boyfriend also ordered a burger but double but it didn't come with a bun? So we had to pay extra for one? He was find with his but he eats anything so that doesn't say much. Needless to say I didn't eat my burger so naturally there was room for dessert. Deep fried Oreo sundae! OMG! I see why this place is known for their desserts, it was really good, very creative and decadent!  Could only eat about 25% between me and my boyfriend. I wouldn't go back to that specific location or maybe try the NYC location and just stick to the desserts.

I do not like Garcia's pizza very much! From the outside the place looks cute and very inviting but once you go inside you will think differently! The pizza is nothing to talk about and I would suggest going somewhere else!

I am decidedly not an aficionado of Sweet Tomatoes, as this particular venue appears to be perpetually thronged with soccer moms and their progeny, which I find utterly perplexing. The salad bar, while adequate, is in my opinion, exorbitantly priced and features ingredients that are somewhat lacking in quality. Furthermore, my utmost annoyance is that despite the restaurant's nomenclature, Sweet Tomatoes, they inexplicably fail to include those delectable, albeit costly, cherry tomatoes on their salad bar! It is truly mystifying. This establishment attempts to entice patrons by touting its supposed health benefits, yet in reality, it is essentially a haven for carbohydrate enthusiasts masquerading as a health-conscious eatery. While it is feasible to consume a relatively balanced meal at the salad bar, the other food stations tell a different tale altogether. They offer an array of items such as bread, pizza, macaroni and cheese, pasta, soup laden with sugar and starch, and baked potatoes, which leave limited options for individuals who prioritize healthy dining. Would it not be more judicious to incorporate some steamed vegetables or similar alternatives? Despite being an all-you-can-eat restaurant, I frequently depart from this establishment feeling unsatisfied due to the dearth of protein. In my opinion, this place is both overpriced and of inferior quality; you can undoubtedly make better choices. Moreover, I have noticed that after consuming meals at Sweet Tomatoes, I experience gastrointestinal distress on a consistent basis, which I attribute to some sort of additive they may be applying to the salad bar.
