"Ruben's culinary experience was marred by an excess of superficiality, wherein the quantity of fries in the poutine exceeded the combined amount of curds and gravy, thereby rendering the dish an unbalanced and unsatisfactory meal; furthermore, the absence of a quality craft beer selection on the menu served only to exacerbate the disappointment. In contrast, vegetarians were presented with a tripartite array of uninspired options, consisting of pasta, pizza, or a salad devoid of meat, thereby offering a dearth of creative and flavorful alternatives."

Style over substance. Ruben was an unmanageable mess, poutine had more fries than curds or gravy, no good beer on the menu. \n\nVegetarian options are pasta, pizza, or you can ask for a salad with no meat.

the two stars are solely dedicated to the counter rental agent as he was kind and professional.  he explained everything with a smile and efficiency.  however, when we said no to all insurance and gas filling...note...car rental agents make commissions by selling these things. he told us there is a $20 surcharge on top of the original amount quoted.  this surcharge is a mandatory road side assistance surcharge... something no other car rental companies do.  as a result, we paid the same amount to payless for a very beat up compact when we could've rented from dollar or alamo for something better.  heading back to vegas in june for world serious but won't be renting from them ever again...\n\nTry e-z car rental 10 steps again.  They re soooo much better!!!

Not very impressed with the Vietnamese sandwiches here at Lee's. Maybe its because the last time had one felt like they did things the right way. My first impression when I walked in was is this even a Vietnamese establishment. Not that one too judges book by its cover. Sure they had small section selling Vietnamese products from candies, dry goods products, baked goods, and beverages. It felt more like american chain sub or sandwich shop. 

I had the grilled pork sandwich or thit nuong. The same one last time had one but this was in Sacramento area. Not as though not close because my grilled pork sandwich had all the condiments that traditional. The spring of cilantro, sliced jalapeno, the carrots and believe daikon, and if there was anything they did hit on point was the bread. The bread was perfect hot, fresh, crispy outside, and great bread. They place they feel short for me. The grilled pork lacked flavor for me, portion size could have been bigger, the sauce or spread inside not fan of, and when combine everything together nothing Wow or get excited about. My dad who visiting order the combination sandwich. Not sure the types of meat in it but not fan more so then grilled pork sandwich. 

Really if looking too get Vietnamese sandwich not the pace too go. I know I was disappointed.

I was NOT impressed with this place at all!  I LOVED fate and think Johnny is a great chef.....  I eat out everyday either lunch or dinner, the service was horrible, our server had an attitude.  The whole table (4) could feel her akwardness.  I understand the whole \"tapas\" thing, but $100 dollar food check not including drinks is a bit much for us to leave hungry.  I dont think I would eat there again, drink? yes.

I was rather disconcerted by the demeanor exhibited by the staff at this establishment. Specifically, the individual tasked with taking my order seemed to manifest a patronizing attitude towards me, which I found quite off-putting. Furthermore, I was taken aback by the numerous handwritten signs scattered throughout the premises, which appeared to offer elaborate explanations for the sluggish pace of their service and the restriction of their lavatory facilities to paying patrons only. While I acknowledge that the decor was generally appealing, with an ambiance reminiscent of a Southeast Asian noodle stand, I must say that the handwritten signs detracted from the overall aesthetic experience. As for the culinary offerings, I found the Cambod-Ican noodle soup (their version of pho) to be palatable, despite my usual aversion to pho due to its overpowering MSG flavor. However, my companion's crispy noodles left much to be desired, with a taste akin to low-quality Chinese takeout lo-mein, although I will admit that the noodles themselves were adequately crisped. Another member of our party found her vegetable curry with chicken to be excessively piquant, to her dismay. The payment process was also somewhat cumbersome, requiring me to conspicuously don my outerwear as a signal to the staff to deliver the check, thereby creating an uncomfortable situation. In conclusion, while certain aspects of this restaurant were pleasing, the aforementioned issues significantly diminished my overall satisfaction.

I was put off by the attitude I got at this place.  I didn't like how the guy taking my order belittled me for not ordering any appetizers or drinks.  I also don't like the handwritten signs that made excuses for why their service is slow and why they don't let non-patrons use their bathroom (a simple "customers only" would work, but no, they have to go into great lengths to explain that toilet paper is expensive and therefore only their "friends" -- the customers -- can use the toilets blah blah).

That aside, decor (minus the handwritten signs) is great.  I felt like I was at a noodle stand in southeast Asia.  I enjoyed my Cambod-Ican noodle soup (their take on pho).  I normally don't like pho because it tastes too much like MSG but it wasn't so bad here.  I tasted my friend's crispy noodles and thought it tasted like really sweet, low quality Chinese take out lo-mein (but at least the noodles were sufficiently crispy).  My other friend found her vegetable curry with chicken to be too spicy for her liking.

The whole payment system is awkward.  Why not just take payment when I order at the window?  Why do I have to awkwardly and deliberately put on my coat in full view of the window to signal them to come out and give me the check?  It's beyond me.
The food was decent, and they have some crazy soda machine with like 1000 flavors (ok not really that many, but a frikn lot.)

After an initial triad of visits within a two-month period of this specific visit, this review would have constituted a perfect five-star rating; however, the final visit proved to be a profound disappointment. Four individuals, including myself, placed orders for 9 oz. medium rare filets, which were served with an unfortunate predominance of brown coloration, devoid of any residual redness. I promptly brought this to the attention of the wait staff, who demonstrated an expeditious responsiveness in addressing my concern by transporting the dish back to the kitchen. Through the transparent partition separating the dining area from the culinary domain, I observed the cook's initial inquiry, which focused on the possibility of the patrons desiring further cooking. This query seemed to belie an inherent incredulity, as the steaks, in point of fact, had been overcooked. Despite the potential influence of luminosity, the culinary faux pas remained unrectified. The waiter failed to manifest any subsequent dialogue or remunerative offer, allowing the impression of dissatisfaction to linger unaddressed. As a former denizen of Wisconsin, and cognizant of the proprietors' Badger State provenance, I must aver that this manner of supper club operation does not comport with the local customs of that region. Consequently, I can no longer, in good conscience, recommend your establishment. My apologies.

After first three visits within two months of this same visit, this would have been 5 stars but the last visit was very disappointing. Four of us all ordered 9 oz. medium rare filets that came out mostly brown without any red. I immediately told the waiter who was quick to agree to take it back to the kitchen. I saw the communication through the window and the cook's first question was, \"do they want it cooked more?\"  Really???  Waiter came back and told us 'it was the light' that made the steaks look more brown. Although it may have been a factor, the steaks were over cooked.  Waiter never said a thing again even though we twice mentioned the steaks were not cooked correctly. No offer to take anything off our bill and no apology if anything did not meet our expectations. As a former Wisconsin resident, and knowing the owners are also from there, this is not how Wisconsinites run a supper club!!  I can no longer recommend your business. Sorry.
It's a Macaroni Grill... not much to say about this... if you have gone to one, you have seen them all. Nothing is really memorable. Including the service. Prices are reasonable.

"While it would be inaccurate to suggest that this establishment is characterized by any glaring deficiencies, it cannot be denied that it lacks a certain je ne sais quoi that would elevate it to the level of truly exceptional dining experiences.  The culinary offerings, while certainly adequate, failed to impress, owing in large part to their uninspired nature, and the ambiance, though not unpleasant, did not seem to align itself particularly well with the overarching theme.  Furthermore, the service, while not unfriendly, lacked a certain warmth and engagement that one might reasonably expect from a top-tier restaurant.  That being said, the lunchtime buffet did feature a passable array of Indian staples, and the never-ending basket of freshly baked Naan bread was, without question, the highlight of our meal."

There is nothing wrong with this place, but nothing particularly redeeming either.  The food was mediocre, and the interior didn't seem to fit the theme.  The servers seemed aloof.   We were there for the lunch buffet which had an ok selection of the Indian standards.  The best part was a never-ending basket of your choice of fresh baked Naan.

On our maiden visit to this establishment today, my spouse and I were less than enthralled by the culinary offerings, specifically those of Taiwanese provenance, and furthermore, we found the tariffs to be somewhat elevated in relation to the gastronomic experience provided.

"Having opted to partake of a culinary experience at this establishment for the inaugural time, my expectations were unfortunately not met, as the cost-effective nature of the menu did not translate into an equivalent quality of gastronomical delight. Specifically, my order of over easy eggs was erroneously prepared to an extent that rendered them unpalatable, while the pancakes possessed an unpleasant texture akin to that of a soiled dishcloth, thereby eliciting my dissatisfaction. However, the bacon and hashbrowns proved to be somewhat redeeming factors, their flavors and textures being relatively satisfying. It is worth noting, though, that the customer service encountered during my visit was rather ordinary and failed to leave a lasting impression. In light of these factors, I am compelled to conclude that a return visit would not be forthcoming, especially given the abundance of alternative breakfast venues in the area that offer superior quality and value. Therefore, I would recommend considering alternatives such as Peoria Cafe or Brothers for a more satisfactory dining experience."

Tried this place for the first time.  The prices are reasonable however the food is sub par!  I ordered over easy eggs and got over medium to over hard eggs.  Not happy!!!  Pancakes take like dirty dish cloth!!  Yuck!!!  The bacon and hashbrowns were actually very good.  Customer service was average, nothing memorable.

Won't be back!!!  Sorry, there are way too many breakfast places in the valley to choose from.  If you want to stand out, you have to do better than this.

Recommend Peoria Cafe or Brothers instead!!!

"Arrived for a midday repast on the seventh day of the week, specifically at an hour thirty minutes past noon, and was met with an extensive queue. Patronized the establishment to the tune of $37, plus an additional $4 per person, culminating in a total expenditure of $41. Comprised a group of nine individuals, thereby necessitating a communal seating arrangement, specifically a circular table configured to accommodate numerous persons. Observed that the culinary offerings, while visually appealing, did not necessarily translate into commensurate gastronomical satisfaction, as the emphasis seemed to be placed upon aesthetic presentation rather than actual taste. Sampled various exotic fare, including duck ravioli and tea eggs, albeit in minuscule portions and served in diminutive cooking vessels. Concluded that the most satisfactory edible was, in fact, the beef brisket accompanied by mashed potatoes. Likewise, the most enjoyable sweet treat was indubitably the black forest cheesecake. However, it is worth noting that the premises were abruptly cleared and illuminations extinguished at precisely three o'clock post meridian, without prior notification from the cashier, thus precipitating a sense of inconvenience and truncating the duration of our repast."

Came for lunch on Saturday around 1:30 pm and the line was really long. Paid $37 plus tax per person, which came out to $41. There were nine of us so they sat us at a banquet like round table. Dishes were not as good as they looked, it is more about presentation here. Exotics dishes such as duck raviloi and tea eggs. Some of the dishes are served in little pans and are small portions. Best dish IMO was the beef brisquette with mashed potatoes. Best dessert IMO was the black forest cheesecake. The worst part was that they started turning off the lights and putting food away at 3:00 pm on the dot, even though the cashier did not indicate to us that this would happen.

Had a gel polish change for my hands & feet, and I must say I was very disappointed. $40 for a gel polish change, NO pedicure. She cut my nails entirely TOOOO short & now my feet look like ugly french tipped nubs! I was going to get acrylics but since I didn't expect to pay so much for my feet I just got a gel manicure. It was OK, nothing special & it also $40 for that. Since I mentioned the discount from yelp they took $12 off my $80. I didn't feel she deserved any sort of tip but tipped her anyway... but I'll never come back.

I don't do reviews, but after eating here I think I should write one to voice my complaints.

I don't know what other people see in this place, for giving it such a good review (3 stars and up), but I found the place to be barely appetizing. People must have been drunk after clubbing or what not, but this place sucks for the price you pay. You're better off going to a buffet for what you're going to pay. 

I got a pesto shrimp spaghetti, which almost tasted like nothing. The shrimp was alright, but the noodles had no flavor. I'd be better off eating cardboard. I'm not sure what was in it, but taste was definitely not involved. 

On a side note, calamari was good and service was par (like our tip.)

Been wanting to go here for a while. It was a little busy but got a nice table in the lounge where the band was setting up. Ordered some tacos. Carne asada and pork were just ok, the shrimp was decent. Overpriced beer ($17 pitchers) but were willing to pay that for the ambience. Unfortunately, it was hot as f*** in there. Oh, and when I ordered a bottle of Bud Light, I got a can!!! Going to America's Taco Shop next time for amazing carne asada!

"On this occasion, marking my second visit to this establishment, I have opted to provide them with an additional opportunity to demonstrate their culinary proficiency. My expectations, however, have remained unfulfilled, as the dining experience has proven to be comparable to my previous visit. Upon ordering a Green Chile cheeseburger, the server felt compelled to caution me about its piquancy. I inferred from his tone that he deemed it necessary to emphasize this aspect, which I found mildly amusing. Upon receiving my order, I observed that the presentation of the dish appeared somewhat lackadaisical, with an evident dearth of green chile adorning the burger. In response, I requested a supplementary serving of chile, which arrived promptly. Although the temperature of the chile was satisfactorily warm, its flavor seemed decidedly inferior, bearing a strong resemblance to a store-bought variety. Disappointment also characterized my girlfriend's dining experience, as her meal, designated as The Green Chile Chicken Especial, or a similar title, was unimpressive in both appearance and taste. The dish consisted of an unappealing medley of rice, beans, and cheese, accompanied by a minimal portion of chicken swimming in a watery sauce. My companion reported that the seasoning of the dish was excessively salty, further contributing to our disappointment. It is worth noting that the cuisine served at this establishment does not conform to traditional New Mexican standards, but rather, it aligns itself with the Tex-Mex genre, relying heavily on Hatch chile."

"Two stars, owing to the eatery's captivating embellishments, which unfortunately could not compensate for the disappointing dining experience, as we were compelled to depart without savoring the culinary offerings, following an unacceptable delay in the serving of our meals, thus precluding us from forming an opinion regarding their gastronomic quality."

After doing some shopping nearby, I was lured into ATS by their slogan: \"Best Carne Asada in Phoenix\".  When ordering at the counter, the staff seemed very disinterested in helping customers.  When I finally did order my carne asada burrito, I was given a number and asked to take a seat.  While I waited, I noticed a few other customers wondering what was going on with the bad service at the counter.  When my carne asada arrived at the table, I was starving.  However, the burrito that sat in front of me was tiny.  I'm not really one to complain about small portion sizes, as I feel that most portions are too big, but this portion was just comical.  The burrito was served with a lime wedge that was dry and looked like it had been sliced the day before.  The flavor of the carne asada was bland, as was the texture.\n\nOverall, this was a pretty disappointing meal.   \"Best Carne Asada in Phoenix\" is a really misleading phrase to have on their sign.  This place is not even close.

Two stars for being the worst of the three that I've been to.

The usual SS staples are there, and the food isn't bad, but they ditched the Calimari that is on the Chicago menu!  Unbelieveable.  That was the most delicious thing I had ever had!

Mostly, my beef with this place is the location, in a mall, and the ambience of the place.  The ironic part is that when you are dining at the Chicago or Miami locations, it feels like you are in Vegas: swanky, cool, fun.  But dining in the Vegas one feels like you are at a Legal Seafoods in suburbia.

Just misses something.  If you're in Vegas, go someplace else.
While the food isn't bad; it's just not worth the price. It calls to mind an Olive Garden or Red Lobster with a few more bells and whistles. 5 stars for great service.

Yuck! It's vegas and I wanted an eiffel tower drink but never again! I'll stick with Fat Tuesday. But if you want to get drunk within minutes, this drink definitely does the trick.

The drink itself is disgusting. I got the strawberry daquiri b/c I didn't want any tequila. But I mean the drink got me drunk within minutes but I felt like shit. Plus, it costs $16.99 for it. I almost would have rather paid for the eiffel tower and had Fat Tuesday filled it up instead. At least their alcohol doesn't get me feeling extremely shitty for the next two hours. Also, the alcohol wasn't even proportionally mixed in. The dude basically pour alcohol at the bottom of the cup and then filled the rest of the tower up with strawberry daiquiri. I ended up pouring the last 1/4 of my drink. I couldn't drink anymore of it.

Pass.

Come here if you want the cup. For the alcohol? go to fat tuesdays.

"An opulent lodging establishment, characterized by spacious, immaculate accommodations, but unfortunately, the quality of the guest experience was not augmented by the hospitality proffered by the personnel. Specifically, the front desk attendant, during our departure, did not trouble herself to inquire about our satisfaction with our stay nor express gratitude for our patronage, her greeting was perfunctory and immediately followed by the presentation of our bill, which seemed discourteous given the premium nature of the hotel and my personal inclination towards being easily pleased; thus, it is regrettable that the service we received did not align with our expectations."

Me and my significant other were indulging in a culinary excursion upon Fremont Street, and our gastronomical desires were aroused. Previously, we had been expending exorbitant amounts of currency on sustenance at establishments situated along the Las Vegas Strip; therefore, this eatery appeared to be a veritable bargain. My companion and I were rather taken by the ambiance, which boasted an 80's jungle motif. Our server, a most affable and attentive gentleman, facilitated our dining experience. Unfortunately, the comestibles did not quite meet our expectations, as I sampled several items that failed to tantalize my taste buds, necessitating multiple visits (no less than ten) to the carving station, where the meat was parsimoniously dispensed. Notwithstanding, I must admit that, despite the disappointing fare, my hunger was satiated, and the price was indeed reasonable. Would I consider returning to this establishment? Regrettably, my response would be in the negative.

Me and my boyfriend were visiting Fremont street and got hungry.  We had been spending ridiculous amount of money on strip food so this place seemed like a real bargain.  I kinda liked the decor.  It was an 80's jungle theme.  Our server was very nice and attentive. Most of the food was not very good.  I got quite a few items that I only took 1 or 2 bites of. I think it's funny that they advertised it was a steak dinner buffet and what they served was thin strips of  carne asada.  It was still yummy though.  Just not what I picture when I think of steak.  To get full I had to make 10 trips to the carving station, they are very stingy with the meat. Bottom line- I didn't get sick, I got full and it was really cheap. Would I go back? No.

My gastronomical indulgence necessitated a temporal allocation of thirty minutes, which I deemed sufficient for the procurement of a delectable sandwich; however, my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as the experience was tainted by an excessive cacophony that precluded the possibility of engaging in meaningful conversations with my companions seated in close proximity. Despite the fact that numerous acquaintances of mine have expressed their approbation for this establishment, I must confess that I did not share their enthusiasm, primarily due to the lackadaisical attitude displayed by the waiting staff, who failed to demonstrate even a modicum of concern for our well-being or offer any refreshments beyond the initial serving. Indeed, such inattention to customer satisfaction left a rather unpleasant impression, leading me to surmise that perhaps the proprietors of this eatery do not genuinely desire to provide hospitable services. Nevertheless, I must admit that the abundance of televisual displays featuring diverse athletic pursuits did somewhat mitigate my discontent, thereby warranting a rating of two stars.

My sandwich took 30 minutes for me to get. Really?? A sandwich?? Its worth a shot to try this spot. Alot of my friends like this place but not me. Too loud too have a conversation with someone sitting right next to you. The waitress took our order..brought out the food..gave us the check. . And not once asked if we needed anything. No refills. No more alcohol.  Napkins. Nothing.   Rude..I hate bad service.  If you dont want to wait on people then why are you here.  The only reason I gave 2 stars is because they have soooo many tvs.  And every sport on.

The word \"Premium\" shouldn't be used here.  This place is outdated and I really think the selection of stores are boring.  The good news, especially in the summer time is that you have an indoor mall, unlike the North Outlets which has a much better selection of stores, but all outside.  Unless they put some more interesting stores in here, I think I will continue to bypass it.

Below average, overpriced, unwelcoming.

I have been meaning to try this place since it opened. My boyfriend is from North Carolina and loves BBQ so I've been trying to find him a place in Pittsburgh he might enjoy. We got takeout - brisket sandwich, 1/4 fried chicken, meaty Mac, and coleslaw. We found everything to be underwhelming. The brisket was average- it was tender but I've had better.  The fried chicken was salty.  The meaty Mac would have been better without the blue cheese.  I ate it by picking out meat chunks and the crispy cheese on top. The coleslaw was good, and by far our favorite part of the meal. That should say enough. 

Price was $35 for all of the above. 

As far as service, the waitress seemed uninterested in us. There were only three other guests in the downstairs of the restaurant.

Pros: Gym is close to my home and is in a nice area. Lots of cardio equipment, treadmills, etc. CONS: Trainers will interupt you during your workouts trying to get you to sign up with them. They also call A LOT....got two phone calls yesterday alone from two different trainers. Gonna cancel my membership tomorrow.

My wife and I just finished lunch here and let me tell you, man-oh-man, we were disappointed.

We have eaten numerous times at the Carson Street Cafe (all the way back to when Steve Wynn still owned the place), and we have always enjoyed ourselves.  But today, it was just bad, and I give it 2 stars since I have experienced better at this cafe.

The service was really slow, the waiter didn't seem to give a rat's arse about us or the food or service and our food was just plain yucky.

I had the most bland and tasteless Cobb salad I have ever had and my wife had the Oxtail Stew.  She enjoyed her food more than I liked mine.

But our major complaint was about the service.  This place in the past always gave us good to excellent service, but today was a really different story.

I am concerned that now that this is a Landry's that it's going to be just another high priced "Denny's" kind of joint.  If so, that would be sad.  It used to be distinct and decent.

It's a sad day for me to have experienced this let down, since I have always liked the Golden Nugget.  Sad!

A big WHA WHA!

Didn't wait long because I was with a group of 6 girls but then found it was a $20 cover.  Since it was late, we decided to screw it, but as we were walking out, got handed free passes, so we turned around and went back in.

Awesome interior, but the point of a nightclub is to dance. You can't dance if you're wedged up against 600 other sweaty, wasted people. I don't care how good you look coming in, you're gonna look nasty if you're sweaty and wasted regardless.

I can imagine if you're really tore up however, it might be a strategic move to shove your way in to the middle of the crowd, since it's virtually impossible to fall down with all those people holding you up.

Also, those girls in the pools are really depressing. When nice girls say hello and ask you how you're doing and you stare blankly ahead and strike a pose from a foot away, you look like you've been trafficked. Either that or you just have to get wasted to make it through your shift.

Enjoyed the Pimms but that's where the enjoyment stopped.  The food was bland and service was nothing spectacular. On a later date, I had high tea there. Scones were good but the little sandwiches tasted stale and the salmon in them tasted like it was out of a package.

"I am utterly perplexed by the effusive praise bestowed upon this establishment, as my culinary experience was characterized by an unfortunate lack of flavor. Specifically, my dish was devoid of the pungent seasonings and aromatic herbs that are traditionally integral to Vietnamese cuisine. In contrast, my companion's entree was excessively salinized, which struck me as a curious departure from the customary subtlety of Vietnamese seasoning. While I am temporarily situated in this city and in search of plant-based options, I shall reluctantly return to sample their spring rolls, which were the sole redeeming feature of my visit. My apologies, but the fusion of Las Vegas and veganism appears to be an incongruous pairing."

"In close proximity to a grocery store, boasting a 24-hour operation, yet unpredictable in inventory management, resulting in frequent stockouts or discontinuation of specific items, rendering it unreliable for essential grocery shopping. Instead, consider alternative options such as Harris Teeter or Trader Joes for reliable grocery procurement. Notwithstanding, this establishment may suffice for incidental purchases like dairy products or eggs, albeit with caution regarding overcharges and inadequate coupon credits, necessitating vigilant monitoring of transactions."

I've been here a countless amount of times. I had been wanting Pei Wei for about two weeks. Finally decided\nTo go and get lettuce wraps and one spring roll. Quick as always but wraps just didn't taste right. They had an \"aftertaste\" not a good one either. Spring roll was okay. Could taste the go ginger and the seaweed was too chewy. Very disappointed and am in no hurry to run back.

I came this past weekend for a quick dinner there was hardly anyone in the restaurant , and it took us 20 mins to be seated and the hostess was very rude. The food was good but they need to work on there customer service .

This restaurant was far from great. With a price of $17+ for pasta I expected great. I had the Gorgonzola chicken pasta and I expected a deliciously rich and creamy pasta. Instead I could only describe this as tasting like pasta from a cafeteria. So disappointing. 

They were kid friendly, which was helpful. They had good bread and we had a pretty decent clam appetizer. My hubby had some tasty prime rib as well.

They took care of the pasta which I appreciated. Overall, they were friendly and accommodating but the food just wasn't  worth the price.

Good French food, average service

Stopped into Mon Ami Gabi on a vacation to Vegas.  My wife and I thought it was superb 11 years ago and were happy to see they are still in business.  We both recalled how much we loved their French Onion Soup.

With some relatives coming down the street, I was disappointed by the young lady managing the hostess desk.  She wouldn't even say if or how long our wait was, "Unless your full party is here."  I could understand not being seated, but the rude tone and nonsensical retort that they can't even give you an estimate on wait time got things off to a poor start.  Then, we were seated immediately when our family members arrived.

The menu is simple enough and the food was good, but not great.  Salads were unremarkable.  The Fillet Mignon was very good.  And the final bill was about $205 for four adults, a toddler, and a baby.  Note: They put 18% gratuity on for themselves.

There were much better years ago.  And if there were better service, I would readily give them three stars.
everytime i come here for a haircut they mess it up. a good haircut is suppose to last 15 to 25 minutes this place has you in and out in 5 minutes. never coming back
Got the Shrimp wonton w/ramen noodle. The portion was very good but, the soup has absolutely no flavor.  Disappointed as all the reviews said it was great.

Great selection for a wide range of fabric/upholstery needs. Some items are well priced and others, outrageous. Two star rating is for the service there.....EVERY time I go there I am treated as if I am a ghost!!! They have a \"take a number\" system that even THEY don't really use. LOTS of people working there but ALL seem to have another agenda that doesn't include the CUSTOMERS! \nReally should give one star for service but product selection gets them Two!

Went in for breakfast. We were sat pretty quickly but no one came to our table for about 10 minutes. Apparently no one was sure who's section we were in. The food was ok, definitely nothing to get excited about. I had to ask for a glass of water 4 times before they brought it. \nWe have had a decent dinner there before and may go back for that sometime but for breakfast there are much better places in town.

"I had what I thought was a great facial and after two days, I experienced an adverse reaction to their products.  I purchased a few of the items during my visit so I called to let them know of what happened.  The young woman in the spa said she would have to check to see if I could return the skin care products that I purchased for $85.00. After asking me again why I was returning them, she said, âThey would allow meâ?to return them but they would have to issue a check instead of crediting my credit card that they so easily accepted when I purchased the items.  I returned to the spa the following day with the items and they gave me a credit voucher and said they would check with the manager to make sure he would approve the return.  I received a call 4 days later letting me know he did indeed âapprove itâ?and they would put a check in the mail...which I still have not received.  No one was concerned that I just spent $160 on a facial spa treatment and my face was all chapped, peeling and red from the reaction.  All they were concerned with was whether they would allow me to return items that I clearly couldn't use.  I was a returning guest but after this incident, I will no longer be a patron of the Arizona Grand Spa.  Apparently they've changed management and the customer no longer comes first."

I ultimately arrived at this destination after being transported by individuals who were ardent devotees of the establishment and frequented it regularly. The edifice itself was quite captivating, and I would highly recommend paying it a visit if you ever find yourself in the vicinity. The throng was pleasant, albeit not excessively boisterous. The bill of fare was intriguing, and the culinary offerings were satisfactory, although they did not particularly impress. The aspect that truly stood out during my dining experience was the utter lack of fervor or concern exhibited by our server. Considering the eatery's proximity to an institution of higher learning, I had anticipated that the individual attending to our needs might have displayed a modicum of vivacity and joviality. However, such was not the case. When I requested a container for taking leftovers, the server merely placed it adjacent to my plate and retreated without even deigning to acknowledge my presence. Perhaps, had I indulged in a greater quantity of alcoholic beverages, I might have derived a greater degree of enjoyment from this establishment. Nonetheless, I am compelled to question the logic behind revisiting Four Peaks, as the experience evoked a sense of familiarity with the aged adage, "Purchase another drink for me, for you remain unsightly." The server's demeanor served as a poignant reminder of this phrase, as their unfriendliness was palpable.

I finally got to this place. The people who took me there raved about the place and are regulars.  Very interesting building-check it out if you go. Nice crowd but not to busy.  Interesting menu. Food was good but nothing exceptional.  The most noticeable thing about eating there was the complete lack of enthusiasm/interest on our server's part.  I thought being on a college campus, the person serving us might been upbeat and cheerful?  Not so. Even when I asked for a take out box, the server sat it down by my plate and walked off without a word.  \n\nMaybe if I'd had more than a few beers, I'd have appreciated this place more. There is a real variety of places to go to in Tempe so why go back.  Going back to Four Peaks kind of reminds me of the old expression-buy me another drink,  your still ugly.  The server wasn't buying.

Meh, lola lo is just ok. Had a few fun nights here. This is a simple list of what they get right & what they get wrong:
Good - bar staff are very friendly & helpful, yummy cocktails, bouncers are surprisingly nice, decoration is beautiful (I know beach theme can look tacky but they pull it off quite well), people there are pretty down to earth for G.street.
Bad - very expensive,... £4.50 vod/mixer rising to about £7 for any cocktail, cover charge is too expensive like other poster said, music is far too quiet & last time I went music was a bit crap, dance floor is too small for this to really be a club its more like a bar with dance area, doesn't usually fill up till quite late on in the evening.
Basically I wouldn't really choose to go here, but if everyone else had already made up their mind I would tag along.

First clue was no one in restaurant. Dinner rolls were burnt and Chicken Parmesan was overcooked. Out of 4 of us at the table ... No one liked their dinner. One friend who is vegan asked for plain noodles with veggies. They accommodated, but then topped it with cheese (not vegan). #fail

I've been coming here my whole life (23 years). It used to be my favorite place to go.  Nothing better then a chili cheese dog. Over the years it has changed. Its now a over priced fast food place. Lost its character and charm. If I wanted to spend $5 on a hotdog I could go to the pirate game.

The atmosphere on the patio is nice with the fountains but it isn't nice having dinner to the smell of chlorine.  The food was ok and the server had no problem honoring the yelp complimentary chips and salsa.  We each got the green chili chicken burrito.  The food was laden with cheese and not for the cholesterol conscious.  It was hard to taste much besides the cheese and the spice but, there was chicken in there too.  If it weren't for the patio/water feature, I don't think this place would be in business.

"We had the privilege of partaking in a culinary experience at an unconventional hour, specifically 8 pm on a Saturday evening, whereupon we discovered that our presence was the sole occupation of the establishment's capacity at that particular time. The gastronomical offerings, while adequate, did not quite live up to our expectations, with the exception of a select few dishes that demonstrated a modicum of culinary prowess. Notably, the presence of saba and other similarly prepared dishes served as a testament to the kitchen's proficiency. However, we couldn't help but feel that the quality of the food was somewhat compromised by the fact that the rolls, in particular, lacked the freshness that one has come to expect from a kaiten sushi restaurant. Furthermore, the location's relative obscurity, situated behind several rows of buildings, coupled with the dearth of conspicuous signage until one reaches the vicinity of the establishment, may contribute to its seemingly low patronage. Nonetheless, the interior ambiance was pleasing to the eye, thanks to tasteful decor and well-maintained facilities, and the staff exhibited a commendable level of friendliness and attentiveness towards us during our visit."

While I am not a native of Chicago, I did reside there for a period of six months, which I deem sufficient to familiarize myself with the intricacies of genuine Chicago-style pizza. Upon placing an order for a small pizza and a corn dog from the establishment in question, I was anticipating a culinary experience akin to those I had encountered during my tenure in the Windy City. Alas, my expectations were quickly dashed upon sampling their pizza, which left much to be desired.  
My fiancÃ©, however, expressed satisfaction with the corn dog he received, which, albeit frozen, was palatable. Nonetheless, the pizza proved to be a considerable letdown. Allow me to elaborate on the essence of authentic Chicago pizza: it should boast a moderate thickness at the base while exhibiting a substantial depth at the edges and summit, much like a pie. Unfortunately, the pizza I was served barely measured half an inch in height, a far cry from the delectable, generously proportioned pies I had the pleasure of consuming during my time in Chicago. Indeed, the pizza in question closely resembled the inferior, airport variety frozen pizzas offered by Pizza Hut, prompting my fiancÃ© and me to discard it after a single slice. 
Those who cherish the rich flavors of renowned Chicago pizzerias such as Giordano's or Lou Malnati's are bound to feel profound disappointment upon sampling this subpar imitation of Chicago-style pizza.

While I'm not from Chicago, I did live there 6 months. Long enough to know good pizza! I ordered a small pizza and a corn dog from them. Points for having corn dogs, it was a yummy defrosted corn dog.. no complaints there. My fiance was very happy to have a corn dog with his pizza (yes I'm marrying someone that likes to have a corn dog and pizza for dinner, but that's another issue). 

The pizza .. now that was the problem. It sucked! So to explain Chicago pizza.. it should be thin-ish on the bottom, but thick on the sides and top.. sort of like a pie. Yes, a pie. The pizza should when sliced, look like a thick piece of pie. My pizza was about half an inch tall. Maybe just the 9 inch comes out tiny, but seriously I had 10 inch pies in chicago frequently that came out awesome. This one was very similar to those nasty frozen pizzas from pizza hut you buy at the airport. A complete disappointment. We had one slice and threw it away.. 

If you like Giordannos, or Lou Malnati's, or REAL delicious chicago pizza you will be sorely disappointed by this crap.

"On my third attempt at patronizing this establishment, I must admit that my expectations were once again not fully met, despite its proximity to my domicile. Previously, I had been somewhat forgiving of minor errors in my order, but on this particular visit, the extent of the oversight was such that I was compelled to reassess my willingness to continue supporting this business. Specifically, not only did they erroneously prepare my meal, but they also neglected to include certain items that I had specifically requested. In light of these recurring mishaps, I have decided that it would be unwise to expend further effort in attempting to obtain a satisfactory dining experience at this location."

Third time trying this place. Each time I was a bit disappointed, but I kept trying because it's so close to my home. Last time they got my order wrong and I didn't really care too much,  but today they got my order wrong and forgot some of my food. I am not driving back to get my food, I'm giving up on this place.

So disappointing- after reading some positive reviews I was anxious to give them a try. From ice cold, mushy Mexican corn- to cold, strangely seasoned chicken tacos.\nOne redeeming item was my husbands cheeseburger. It was hot and the burger itself was juicy. We ate the burger and threw away the rest.

This marked my maiden visit to this establishment, and upon placing a telephone call to procure our repast, I was informed that the anticipated duration of preparation would be approximately twenty minutes, which conveniently coincided with my lunch hiatus from gainful employment. Upon arriving at the venue, I was further advised by the gentleman responsible for expediting our nourishment that a brief interval of merely a couple of minutes would be required before the culmination of our order. However, subsequent to a ten-minute delay, he revealed that the concoction of beverages was still pending, thereby necessitating an additional ten-minute wait, ultimately resulting in an aggregate duration of approximately forty-five minutes until the procurement of our victuals. It is worth noting that the primary impetus behind my decision to partake in this particular edible indulgence was the allure of their fabled "frozen custard" shake, only to discover that the actual composition of this treat was, in point of fact, a decidedly inferior quality of ice cream, which left me feeling somewhat disenchanted and underwhelmed. Notwithstanding this disappointment, the gastronomical offerings were, in general, of an acceptable quality, albeit slightly too oleaginous for my personal preference. Taking into account the aforementioned factors, I must confess that I harbor doubts regarding the likelihood of my return to this eatery, given the confluence of factors including the tariff, the duration of the meal, and the overall quality of the cuisine.

This was my first time here. I called our order in and I was told 20 mins!  Perfect, that would be my lunch break from work.  I headed over there and the guy said it would be just a couple more minutes.  About 10 minutes later he said he just needed to make the shakes.  10 MORE minutes later he finally did! Overall it took about 45 minutes to get our food and at this point I was already over on my break!   The \"frozen custard\" shake was the reason I ordered it... no frozen custard  used, it was the discount tub of ice cream!  I could have skipped it for something 'normal'   Over all the food was ok... a bit greasy for my taste.  I don't think I would bother going back there for the time and cost of the meal.

"An atmosphere of unparalleled elegance, a panoramic vista of breathtaking proportions, and an attentive team of hospitality professionals, all conspired to create an evening of unforgettable indulgence, but regrettably, the gastronomical experience fell short of expectations, particularly in light of the tariff, which one would assume would guarantee a culinary excursion of uncompromising excellence, sadly, the piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance, a cut of rib eye, failed to impress, its quality and presentation paling in comparison to the exalted standards established by esteemed establishments such as Ruth's Chris or Fleming's, leaving one with the indelible impression that the main course, though adequate for a venue of lesser renown, such as Black Angus or Outback, was incongruous within the rarefied environs of this lauded eatery."
Great Ambiance, Great view, Great Wait staff,  rib eye not so much. Not what I was expecting when you're paying  Ruth Criss/Flemings prices. The steak would fit nicely at Black Angus or Outback.

"To be perfectly candid, the culinary offerings at this establishment were merely adequate, garnering a rating of four stars at best. However, the quality of service provided by our server was commendable, deserving of a solitary star. Unfortunately, the kitchen staff appeared to be plagued by an array of operational deficiencies, resulting in a significant delay in the preparation and delivery of our meals. Specifically, we waited thirty minutes for our order to be fulfilled, and even then, the dishes arrived piecemeal over the ensuing fifteen-minute period. It is abundantly clear that this restaurant suffers from egregious managerial shortcomings, which must be addressed by someone with the expertise to streamline its operations and imbue them with a modicum of efficacy. Happily, I am not a resident of Phoenix, thereby rendering future visits to this eatery unlikely."

To be honest the food was a 4 but the service was really bad, as in 1 star. Our sever was actually really nice and did a good job. The kitchen couldn't seem to get anything right. I'll save you the details but we got our food 30 min after we ordered.  On top of that it came out spread over the next 15 min. The place has severe management issues. Somone needs to show them how to run a restaurant with some efficiency. Luckily I don't live in phx so this won't be an issue for me again.

Not sure why I went outta my way for this place. Seemed good when we first walked in. Then the mashed potatoes were cold and the meat wasn't that great. The sweet tea and the Corn bread were great but that was about it. I wouldn't go back. Best bbq in the west my ass.

Bay City Diner...I yearn for the delectable victuals and hospitable ambiance that once characterized this esteemed eatery. Alas, my recent dining experience at Du Pars has left me feeling somewhat disillusioned, as the prices for what I consider to be rudimentary breakfast fare have become exorbitant. In the company of two acquaintances, I indulged in a meal consisting of pancakes, eggs, bacon, toast, and a beverage - either orange juice or coffee. To my utter dismay, the total cost for the three of us surpassed $50, which I deem to be an unreasonable sum for such unremarkable cuisine. It is worth mentioning that my previous dinner excursions to this establishment have also been marked by inflated prices, leading me to question the propriety of labeling it a 'diner' in the classical sense. The memory of Bay City Diner continues to tantalize my taste buds; regrettably, Du Pars falls short of my expectations.

ugggh , i can't even bare to read aLL the good feedback this restaurant got . 2 stars is being EXTREMELY generous . when i Lived in Vegas years ago , my famiLy & i used to ALWAYS go here & it was thee Biz . i recentLy went here the first week of january when i was visiting & it was pathetic . food was bLand , service was whomp whomp , they have NO chicken katsu , & they ONLY accept cash . Like seriousLy , it's 2011 ... get with the program . as much as i LOVED this pLace when i was younger , i don't think i couLd ever bring myseLf to go here again . if you guys want good hawaiian/isLand food in the mainLand , come to the REAL state of CaLifornia & i'LL be gLad to recommend a handfuL of great pLaces . i was Looking forward to going to this pLace when we got to vegas , & it was such a bummer that it was faiL .

I give the star to the employees only but SAMs sucks when it comes to clothing for larger people same with walmart sorry but we are a larger nation and big people need cloths too I believe the also discriminate against larger people when they charge more and don't carry sizes that fit most large people. Get on the band wagon and treat us big people equal!!!!

"Spacious accommodations, featuring a comfortable bed and a somewhat dilapidated sofa, were provided, although the showering facilities left much to be desired. My decision to reserve a room at this establishment was primarily motivated by its reasonable tariff, which was further endorsed by Expedia's favorable rating of three stars. However, upon experiencing the hotel's services firsthand, I was disappointed to discover that it did not live up to my expectations of a four-star hotel. Furthermore, the culinary offerings served on the premises were subpar, thus precluding any possibility of a future visit."

This eatery may be among the select establishments offering a relatively affordable all-you-can-eat spread on the renowned boulevard, but does its culinary offerings truly compare to those of its contemporaries in terms of quality? Unfortunately, our experience during the morning repast suggested that the fare was uninspired, lacking in flavor, and regrettably tepid.

The selection at this venue pales in comparison to other breakfast buffets we have had the pleasure of partaking in, which featured an abundance of delectable options that left us spoiled for choice. If you seek a dining experience that offers a vast array of gastronomic delights, it would be wise to explore alternative destinations, as the offerings at this establishment are limited and the quality leaves much to be desired.

While it is true that other buffets may come with a higher price tag, the disparity in quality and variety makes them a superior choice for those seeking a truly satisfying dining experience. The sole advantages of dining at this location are the modest cost savings, which may be attractive to those who prioritize budgetary considerations above all else.

The building and view are beautidul....and that's the only reason why I gave it two stars. The waitress had limited knowledge on fine dining cuisine, the calimari was over cooked so we told the waitress, she returned it to the kitchen and came back out asking if we wanted something else and declines to remake the dish stating \"that's just how they make it. they won't make the dish again because that's how they cook it and it will come out the same way.\" My father asked for fresh lime in his beverage and the waitress said she'll have to check and see if they have any limes, that they didn't have many in stock. The young man filling our water and butter on the table was smacking gum so loud you could hear it across Pittsburgh. He also refilled our table water by reaching over us, so instead of pulling the water glass off the table and pouring it properly he poured the water with the glass directly ont to the table resulting in spilling ice cubes.  I had chucks of solid cheese in my pasta that wasn't melted, missing tomatoes, my dad's escargot was over cooked, my boyfriends steak was flavorful but a poor cut of meat & they ran out of half of their dessert options. Overall they are just stuck in the 1970's with their black tie outfits and old school menu. Save your money, enjoy the view from the overlook and find another restaurant with better quality.

If my mother ever cooked like this I would have fired her. \"My Mother's\" is bland as I am white. I had bland Lasagna with hard spice-less garlic bread and a limp side salad. The only item that saved My Mother's was the pie. The Chocolate Cream Pie (pictured) was heaven. The contrast between dinner and desert made me wonder if My Mother had someone else bake the pie.

"Nicholas' culinary establishment has served as a preferred meeting location for a coterie of my acquaintances. I have partaken of their pizza, calzone, and chicken parmesan offerings on multiple occasions, and my experiences with these items have been largely satisfactory. However, in an effort to diversify my gastronomical choices, I opted to sample their baked ziti with meatballs during my most recent visit. Unfortunately, the dish did not meet my expectations due to its overcooking, which resulted in a rubbery texture and an unpleasant dryness. Additionally, the extremities of the ziti were unpalatably hard and crunchy, which further detracted from my enjoyment of the meal. Notwithstanding the disappointing quality of the dish, the attentiveness and proficiency of the waitstaff were truly commendable."

"The culinary offerings, specifically those comprising of meat, such as lamb kebab and chicken 65, did not possess the quality that would have been expected from a fine dining establishment. In contrast, the paneer tikka masala, characterized by an abundance of rich, flavorful gravy, yet featuring only a meager eight cubes of paneer, was somewhat disappointing. However, the chana masala, a popular vegetarian option, was found to be satisfactory, albeit not exceptional. Lastly, the naan, a type of leavened flatbread, was notable for its freshness and soft texture."

"Underwhelmed by the culinary offerings and vinous selection, we found the utilization of an iPad for wine list to be an absurdity, rendering the process of selecting a suitable wine arduous and restrictive, thereby negating the fundamental concept of a wine bar. Our order consisted of seared tuna, green beans, flatbread, and battered shrimp; while the former two dishes were moderately palatable, the remaining items fell short of our expectations, substantiating the notion that the establishment's gastronomic quality was akin to an overpriced Applebee's with an emphasis on wine. Furthermore, our visit revealed that the menu had remained unchanged for over three years, and the desserts were utterly disappointing."

Not really impressed with the food or wine list. The idea of the ipad for wine list is crazy!   You can't look for it he right wine and the options are very limited. It should not be called a wine bar since there is nothing special about the wine they carry. 

We ordered the seared tuna, green beans, flatbread and the battered shrimp. The tuna and green beans were pretty decent but the rest of the food was just below average. I do like the comparison from other teloera saying that it is very comparable to an overpriced Applebee's with wine. 

I also noticed that the menu has not changed in over three years. The desserts are also terrible!

"The provision of services and seating arrangements at this performance was utterly deplorable and chaotic. Upon arriving at our designated section on the main floor, we discovered that our tickets were invalid due to a malfunction in the ticketing system, resulting in duplicate tickets being issued. Consequently, we were forced to seek assistance from an usher, who relocated us to an alternative location across the auditorium, sandwiched between numerous family groups. 

The show itself was equally underwhelming, with its haphazard and predictable nature evoking laughter from the audience, including ourselves, for the majority of the performance. Throughout the show, a group of pandas danced aimlessly across the stage, accompanied by martial arts and acrobatic displays. 

It was challenging to discern any semblance of a narrative or coherent structure within the performance, leaving me perplexed from the onset. However, the highlight of the show was undoubtedly the scene where a performer vigorously assaulted one of the pandas, causing them to flee in terror. 

In conclusion, this show is unquestionably unworthy of any monetary investment. Its randomness and lack of artistic merit render it an unremarkable experience. The only circumstances under which I would recommend attending this performance would be if one were to receive complimentary tickets or a significantly discounted offer."

Service and seating at this show is horrendous and out of control. We had tickets for a certain section on the main floor and when we arrived there were no seats in that row. The people sitting in our row told us that the ticketing system went down and that duplicate tickets had been printed, so we had to go see an usher to be seated...WTF! Already not off to a good start! We finally tracked down an usher that put us across the auditorium between a bunch of families.

The show itself wasn't any better than the seating process...I can see how this show is made for children because it's so random and scripted that it was hilarious and we probably spent a good 3/4 of the show laughing our butts off. I kind of felt bad for the people that were seated around us! During the show, a bunch of pandas dance around the stage while martial arts and acrobatics are being performed. 

I'm not sure if there is supposed to be a story to this show...I really couldn't tell and right from the beginning I was confused on what was supposed to be happening. My favorite part though was when the guy was beating the crap out of one of the pandas and whipping him haha. This is definitely a random show and not worth paying any amount of money to see. I would only recommend going if you get free tickets or have some kind of super discounted deal...

the whole idea of applebee's really bothers me. chain restuarants that you can go to all over the country just seem weird. it seems so much more worth it to try something new and unique and risk it not being great than going somewhere that introduced that obnoxious song about   baby back ribs... oh wait, that was chiles. well, i feel the same way about that restaurant too.\n\nthe only times i came here were to do their happy hour, which is pretty good, if you can stand the atmosphere. the HH hours are pretty impressive; 3 to 7 and 10 to midnight every night of the week. other than that - gross, gross, gross

I would have loved to rate this hair salon higher, but in the midst of my search for a quality salon in Phoenix, this does not rate on my list of favorites.  The guy who cut and highlighted my hair was very friendly, however, my highlights looked disastrous.  I asked for a natural look and I got areas that were bleached out, orange, light brown, and some blonde.  I would not return there, even to get my hair fixed, in fact, I went somewhere else to get my color corrected, which I wish would not have had to happen because now my hair is damaged.  Overall, I would rate the salon higher if my color service were better, but the place was clean and the staff were friendly enough.

Z Pizza you are nothing special.

Rubbery salty crust.  Your whole pizza is merely so so and your slices border on abysmal.  Staff didn't seem to care if I was there or not.  The owner was there and that was more important than my late lunch order.

Ok you're organic.  Guess what?  I don't care.  When I want pizza I don't want to feel like I am making a healthy compromise.  I only want something tasty and unhealthy.  That's why I'm eating pizza instead of a salad.  

Ok you have gluten free options.  The only thing sadder than that is a fat kid with no money staring at a bakery counter.  

I don't buy your hype.  Your food is so so at best.  I will continue to order elsewhere.

"Chompies, my expectations were not met, I yearned to relish your culinary offerings, having been raised in proximity to authentic Jewish delicatessens, and thus, my craving for such fare was profoundly unsatisfied in the state of Arizona. Your menu boasted traditional Jewish specialties, including a delectable matzo ball soup and an assortment of bagels that garnered praise from our gathering. Unfortunately, the caliber of victuals and hospitality encountered during our repast was inconsistent. Multiple requests were necessary for the gratuituous gherkins to reach our table, and they arrived belatedly, concurrent with the conclusion of our meal. Lamentably, the entree I selected was sullied by the presence of bacon, which greatly dismayed this vegetarian patron. An alternative dish was tendered, but my confidence in the kitchen's ability to provide an unadulterated meal had waned. Although the meal was graciously complimentary, my disappointment persisted, rendering any future visits to Chompies unappealing."

Chompies, I wanted to love you, but you missed the mark. I grew up surrounded by Jewish delis, and had been sincerely missing that being in Arizona. They have classic Jewish favorites and the matzo ball soup, and bagels were hits for our group. However, the quality of food and the service were not consistent throughout the meal. We had to ask multiple times for the complimentary pickles to be delivered to the table, and they arrived as we were finishing out meal. The dish I ordered, someone in the kitchen decided to add bacon to, which very much upset this vegetarian. I was offered another meal, but when I didn't particularly trust anything coming from the kitchen at that point. The meal was comped, which was appreciated, but it didn't change the fact that I was extremely let down by a meal that I was looking forward to. At this point, I have no desire to visit Chompies in the future.

A Korean Taco Stand!?  An intriguing concept, indeed!  I was compelled to sample its offerings, as I am drawn to unique culinary experiences.  However, my enthusiasm was soon replaced by disillusionment.  While the tacos possessed an adequate level of gustatory appeal, the excessive amount of filler accompanying them proved to be a significant source of vexation for me.  
The establishment boasts of utilizing three distinct types of lettuce; regrettably, this feature did not arouse any considerable excitement within me.  Frankly, the prevalence of lettuce obscured the flavorful meat, rendering the dish seemingly unbalanced.  Furthermore, the'sweet potato fries' failed to meet my expectations.  Although the novel method of cutting them into extremely thin strips created an illusion of abundance, ultimately, it yielded a meager, unfulfilling experience.  
A savory dark brown sauce accompanied the tacos, which I found quite delectable.  If only they had presented me with tortillas genuinely filled with their delicious meat, complemented by a moderate amount of lettuce and a generous portion of that delightful sauce... I would have been utterly content.  Unfortunately, I departed feeling exploited and unsatisfied.  Such a disappointment!

"A plethora of unsettling occurrences, including crusty bed sheets, burnt-out light fixtures, and an incessant stream of staff members attempting to gain entry into one's room during slumber, served as a harbinger of the myriad inconveniences that were yet to unfold at this purportedly 'awesome' hotel. As the daybreak ushered in a new epoch, a cacophony of sounds emanating from the rooftop, ostensibly the result of some manner of construction or renovation endeavor, permeated the atmosphere and threatened to disrupt the tranquility of the early morning hours. Subsequently, a succession of security personnel, with an air of utmost urgency, traversed the corridors, culminating in a series of vigorous door-knocks, accompanied by vociferous declarations of their identity and purpose, ostensibly in pursuit of certain rowdy individuals suspected of having vacated the premises prior. Furthermore, in what appeared to be a blatant disregard for the principles of privacy and personal space, a housekeeper, on multiple occasions throughout the day, endeavored to gain ingress into our quarters, sans the common courtesy of a preliminary knock, thus further contributing to an already unsettling ambiance. It would appear that the accommodations at this establishment, despite their comparatively exorbitant cost, suffer from a profound dearth of both contemporary amenities and basic cleanliness, rendering them decidedly not worth the considerable sleep deprivation that ensues as a direct result of the multitude of disturbances that seem to pervade the premises."

"I placed an order for the Spicy Shrimp Tacos, a culinary creation comprising of three shrimp tacos, each topped with a tangy guacamole and cucumber slaw, served alongside a side of rice and beans; however, I elected to substitute the standard side dishes with a singular serving of rice. It is worth mentioning that certain menu items, such as this particular dish, have a tendency to falsely advertise their level of spiciness, leading me to wonder if there exists a discrepancy between the perceived definition of'spicy' among culinary establishments and that of the general public. Furthermore, through casual eavesdropping, I became aware of the possibility of customizing one's taco selection by choosing three distinct types, specifically shrimp, pork, and carne asada, an option that I would have taken advantage of had I been cognizant of it prior to placing my order. The service provided by the waitstaff was adequate, yet the hostesses displayed a remarkable lack of awareness and attention towards guests, as evidenced by the several minutes I spent standing at the hostess table before they acknowledged my presence and seated me accordingly. Due to the exorbitant pricing of each entree, which exceeds $15 per plate, I shall opt for one of the numerous alternative dining establishments in Las Vegas during future visits."
Food good, service not so good. For 4 people on duty and 7 patrons I would say waiting over 20 mintues to get our bill is ridiculous but try them for yourself.

I didn't love my food at Super Burrito, but to be fair, I must tell you that 3 trailer-park, hillbilly, in-bred, DOUCHEBAGS, interrupted my famous "Taco Inspection!" 

We arrived at Super Burrito at about 2AM on a Friday night (first mistake) and immediately upon entering the restaurant and identifying myself as "The Taco Inspector," these three ass-clowns got in our face and would NOT stop talking crap--even after we got our food and sat down. 

The date ended with the Scottsdale Police showing up, and well, at least we got a couple minutes of these cock-noses on video with my flip camera! 

You can see the video at www.thetacoreview.com 

From what I remember, my tacos were kind of bland, but we will return for a repeat-inspection.

Peace from The Taco Inspector!

I typically like Paradise Bakery. They are usually good for a quick lunch and have healthier options than most of the other "fast" places in my area.
 
This location however, needs some work. The service as always is good, but the food leaves much to be desired. The iced tea is atrocious. I can't exactly pinpoint it, I think the container/brew filters need to be cleaned because the taste is stale. In addition to that, it is completely watered down so you can't taste the mango at all. I actually did a taste comparison to ensure I wasn't losing my mind. After lunch at Paradise Bakery I went to PV Mall and tried the tea at the location there and it was great.
 
The chicken salad was also huge let down. The strawberries and pineapple were not fresh, they came in heavy sweet syrup. Needless to say I was not in Paradise and will probably pass this place on my way to Wildflower going forward.

Bf and I stopped here prior to the KA show.  Emeril's New Orleans Fish House is located inside the MGM where KA was playing, which made it convenient.

Our server was hospitable.  I drink a lot of water with my meals.  My water glass was never empty.  

We had the tuna tacos, which were $17 for three small servings.  I didn't like the sweet flavor and the price point was too high.  We also had a side of mushrooms, which was $9.  It was equally overpriced.  The mozzarella salad was perfectly balanced.  It was light and flavorful.

One of the closer Wendy's. My wife and I do not go here very often anymore. We had food missing from our order, cold or burnt sandwiches, and salads that were very wilted. 

The lights for the restaurant and drive through are turned off some nights at 9 or 10 pm. It doesn't seem like they are open. We went through the drive through and were the only ones there. A lot of service errors for just us being served. 

Would gladly go back if the service and quality went back up.

The architecture may be nice, have elevator music and all the fancy schmancy stuff but the customer service sucks and swallows. The employees are rude, they ignore the customers or simply turn around without answering a simple question. I was there yesterday and it was impossible to find someone to help me find a book I needed even the computer said there were two copies left.

Thanks God for Amazon.com.....they got 80 $ from me, which means I saved 10 $.

Indigo got 0$ and probably will not get anything for me in quite a while

The culinary offerings were of satisfactory quality, however, the hospitality and attention accorded to patrons left much to be desired, with an unacceptable duration of 46 minutes transpiring between the time we placed our order and the moment it arrived at our table, thereby rendering it judicious to avoid visiting this establishment on Saturday evenings and instead opting to travel a short distance further to the Chandler location.

Today, I had the opportunity to experience CityCenter, and I must say that my expectations were not entirely met. Specifically, I found the overall ambiance to be somewhat unremarkable and lacking in a certain je ne sais quoi that one might anticipate from a venue of its caliber. Perhaps it was the absence of certain aesthetic elements, such as a plethora of floral arrangements or an Italian-inspired motif, that contributed to this impression. Notwithstanding, the physical location of the Aria presented a bit of a challenge for pedestrians, as the most convenient point of entry was via Crystals, which proved to be somewhat perplexing in and of itself. While the external water feature and colorful fountain were certainly visually appealing, their placement and execution left something to be desired in terms of accessibility and practicality. Upon entering the establishment, I couldn't help but feel a sense of cognitive dissonance, as if my internal pretension and snottiness sensor was alerting me that perhaps I didn't quite belong there. Furthermore, the sheer magnitude of the structure seemed almost overwhelming, and I couldn't help but wonder if navigating its vast expanse might prove to be a daunting task for someone of my temperament. In conclusion, while I am content to have experienced CityCenter at least once, it appears that its actual implementation fell somewhat short of its theoretical promise.

Today, I finally saw CityCenter, and I was stunned by how lackluster it was.

The place in general was just lacking in character and charm. It was basically a high-tech Wynn or the Bellagio with less flowers, less art and no Italian motif. 

The Aria is borderline hidden, the easiest way to get into the place by pedestrian means is through Crystals, which is confusing enough in of itself. The waterfall and colorful fountain outside were nice enough, but the execution is a total fail. What use is stuff like that if it's hidden?

I walked in, started looking around when my subconscious pretension and snottiness block started going off. It was as if an alarm was going off in my head telling me "I REALLY SHOULDN'T BE HERE." Besides, the place looked immense and knowing me I would have easily gotten lost.  

I'm happy I saw it once, but it seems like it worked much better in theory than it does in execution.

Stopped in for lunch a few weeks ago, the verdict: overpriced mediocre and slow. The Reuben was unremarkable and I nearly died of thirst. Latenight is better with plenty of half and half stouts (ie black and blue) and generally likeable live music on weekends.

We have had positive experiences at Orange Sky; however, our visit on November 1st was not among them. Despite adequate service, an unfortunate oversight regarding the provision of our initial beverages transpired, which took approximately fifteen minutes to rectify. Although the culinary offerings (specifically, lobster bisque, king crab, and steak) possessed satisfactory flavors, a sudden and violent onset of illness afflicted both my spouse and myself within a four-hour time frame post-consumption. Following this occurrence, I brought it to the attention of the hostess during the subsequent day, only to be met with an alarming lack of concern. Motivated by a desire to initiate a thorough investigation and potentially preclude future occurrences of food poisoning within the establishment, we opted to convey our experience directly to management. Unfortunately, management displayed an equally dismissive attitude toward the matter, which we found utterly perplexing given the premium cost associated with dining at Orange Sky. In light of this, we would advise seeking alternative dining options that prioritize food safety, as Orange Sky appears to fall short in this regard. It is worth mentioning that our visit coincided with a special occasion, yet we were seated in close proximity to the restrooms, which proved to be an additional disappointment.

We have had good experiences at Orange Sky, but the one on Nov. 1 was not so.  Service was good, though no one could figure out who was to serve our water for the first 15 minutes we were there.  The food (lobster bisque, king crab, and steak) also tasted good, but within about 4 hours, my wife and I both became violently ill.  I reported this the next day to the hostess, who seemed completely unconcerned.  So, we also reported it directly to management, mostly so they could investigate and possibly prevent others from having the same experience.  Management, however, was also not interested in how food poisoning occurred in its restaurant.  For the price tag you pay to eat here, I'd recommend someplace else.  Most restaurants of this caliber put food safety very high on their priorities list.  Not so at Orange Sky.  (We also were there to celebrate a special occasion.  The restaurant was not half full.  Where did they put us???  Next to the restroom.)

I've seen worse. I've even seen much worse. But this was still pretty bad.

Had very clever moments, some interesting ideas, the occasional touch of "that was kinda cool" -- but the end result was a feeling of, "THAT'S what all the fuss was about?"

Kids will love this show for sure 

For adults, you'd be better served at Cirque's O, Mystere, or Love shows, or catch Penn & Teller over at the Rio or Amazing Johnathan wherever he's performing.

I wouldn't see Blue Man Group again for free. Just too much hype and far too little substance.

"Bah. I am utterly perplexed and unimpressed by the exorbitant prices and mediocre quality of food at Lemeac, especially when compared to the diverse array of delectable and reasonably-priced dining options available in Vancouver. It appears that the standard practice in Montreal is to charge excessive amounts for individual entrees, without the accompaniment of a salad or dessert, which I find to be an unacceptable and incomprehensible practice. Despite my desire for an extraordinary and memorable dining experience, I have yet to encounter anything that would lead me to believe that Montreal's culinary offerings surpass those of Vancouver. It seems that my taste buds and expectations have been irreparably shaped by my residency in Vancouver, and I fear that I may never truly appreciate the unique qualities of Montreal's gastronomic scene."

"While partaking in a culinary excursion with my kinfolk in Tempe, I opted to sample the fare offered by this establishment via the convenience of take-out. Unfortunately, my expectations were not adequately met, as the Kung Po Shrimp lacked a sufficient amount of flavor, despite the palatability of the shrimp itself. Furthermore, the Hunan beef left an unpleasant filmic sensation on my lingual organ, which served only to further diminish my satisfaction. Additionally, the prices for each dish exceeded $10, rendering the entire experience even less worthwhile. Needless to say, I did not feel compelled to return for a dine-in encounter."

I visited Benny's in the company of my daughter, with the intention of partaking in a traditional morning meal, and we placed an order for a selection of dishes that are commonly associated with a typical breakfast, specifically scrambled eggs, bacon, toast, and home fries. However, upon consuming the items, I was disappointed to discover that the texture of the scrambled eggs was unpleasant, and the appearance of the bacon was somewhat unappealing, possessing a scrawny and irregular shape. Furthermore, while my daughter expressed satisfaction with the home fries, I would have preferred the option of potato style over the deep-fried French fry style. Additionally, the coffee served was of poor quality, which, although not unexpected for a diner-style establishment, was still a disappointment. Considering the fact that I paid the full price of $10 for each breakfast, I felt that the quality of the food was subpar and did not meet my expectations, leading me to suspect that synthetic ingredients, such as eggs cooked in a microwave and pre-cooked microwave bacon, were employed in its preparation. Moreover, the service we received was inadequate, as after our food was delivered, we failed to see the waitress again, leaving us feeling neglected. In conclusion, owing to my underwhelming experience, I do not plan on returning to Benny's for breakfast in the future, and I regret spending the money.

"While the service remains consistently cordial and accommodating, characterized by copious helpings, the culinary offerings themselves are somewhat inconsistent in quality.
