Specifically, the vegetables are typically fresh and flavorful, yet the cooking methods employed for both meat and seafood dishes often fall short of expectations. Notably, the salt-and-pepper shrimp is excessively oily, while the chicken tends to be overcooked and lacking in depth of flavor. Therefore, if you opt to dine at this establishment, it may be advisable to focus on plant-based options, which they seem to execute adequately."

On the one hand, the service is always friendly and helpful, and the portions are generous. On the other hand... well, the food is a mixed bag. Vegetables are usually crisp and flavorful, but the preparation of the meat and seafood leaves a good deal to be desired. Their salt-and-pepper shrimp is far greasier than it should be. Their chicken, too, suffers. Every time I go it's a little too overcooked and bland.\n\nSo if you go, I would recommend sticking with vegetarian fare. They do a decent job with that.

I joined Kansas City Barbecue Society for $35 just to be able to get free day passes to RD. I was really interested in trying some of their private label wines.  Unfortunately at the cash register I found out you can't buy any alcohol from them unless you have a liquor license.  Then I had to wait for about a half an hour to get a refund after they overcharged me $6 for an 11 lb. bar of Callebaut dark chocolate that had been entered in their computer wrong.  Not a happy camper.

I've never eaten in at Crandall's, only ordered from them via grubhub.com, so that's what I'm reviewing. The food is fine, but they have no idea what they're doing at the restaurant. I've ordered from them three times and will never order from them again. The first time I ordered from Crandall's, I realized that I had entered the wrong address in grubhub so I called the restaurant to let them know. They had no idea what grubhub was and insisted on rudely telling me I had the wrong restaurant. The second time I ordered from them, I got a call - after an hour of waiting for the food - saying that they were out of what I had ordered. The third time, they packaged my order wrong and I received the wrong food. When I called to ask them to send me the correct order, they insisted it was the delivery guy's fault. I have no idea what goes on at that restaurant, but it is terribly run. I've never had such bad service. I've never written a Yelp review before, but I'm so annoyed with them that I felt it merited a review.

Very disappointed with service. We arrived a few minutes before a party of 3 people and signed in well before them. We were completely ignored. We were a party of two. No seats at bar area. Party of 3 seated at open table instead of us. We were told the table was too big for us. 10 min later we were seated at the same size table. We were never given a menu as the other table was.  Hostess was very rude. We ordered several items not on the conveyor belt. Half of it arrived and we had to reorder the other half as they \"lost\" the rest of what we ordered. Definety a bad experience. Obviously this restaurant only wants large parties as we have come with large groups in the past and had good experiences.

We live downtown Madison and have eaten at nearly every restaurant. We get asked a lot for restaurant recommendations. I'd say we are fairly discriminating and know the restaurant scene in Madison. Our recent experience at Cento was way below average for a Food Fight operation. We sat at the bar, adequately staffed with 4 bartenders, on a Friday evening. The poor service we received was unacceptable. Where do I start...
No silver ware- had to ask
No napkins- had to ask
Water glasses empty- had to ask
Drinks empty - had to ask
Overall unattentive service that only responded when I ran someone down.  
Food was good. Not great. Bartenders were nice but clueless and had no concept of teamwork and customer service. It impacted our experience and was noticed by a couple next to us from Chicago, who were upset with their service as well. 
I spoke kindly to the manager at the end of the night to share my experience. He was receptive and thanked me. Even asking for my name and number so he could invite us back to give cento another chance. To make matters worse...he never called me back. 
Baffling! I won't forget this. Not sure I want to go back. I've since shared my experience with others. Remarkably another set of friends had a similar experience the next night at their large table foodies. 
Bottom line- I had much better service at the Echo Tap and the Big Ten Pub. Cento should visit and learn a thing or five.

This establishment garnered a mere two stellar designations, primarily due to the following factors:  
1. I had previously indulged in copious amounts of alcohol, thereby impairing my faculties and judgment.  
2. I encountered a group of individuals hailing from Texas, who were characterized by their affable and convivial nature.  
3. The disc jockey's musical selections and mixing techniques were moderately impressive.  
4. My significant other treated me to an additional serving of Patron, a premium tequila brand.  
5. The ambiance of the venue was generally lackluster, with the exception of the aforementioned aspects.  
6. As I was inebriated upon arrival, I am uncertain of the specific hotel at which this nightclub was located.

"My arrival at this establishment was precipitated by a craving for the quintessential California Burrito and a refreshing glass of Jamaica; regrettably, neither of these items were forthcoming during my visit. Upon entering the drive-thru, I encountered an individual tasked with processing orders, whose comprehension of the English language appeared limited, prompting me to seek clarification at the window. Unfortunately, the staff member's diction proved equally challenging to decipher, rendering our interaction somewhat arduous. In light of these circumstances, I elected to procure a quesadilla instead, which, while palatable, fell short of my expectations vis-Ã -vis the exceptional culinary offerings available at Vaqueros on 19th and Southern. My disappointment was further compounded by the absence of a clear and effective means of communication, which, in turn, detracted from the overall quality of the customer experience."

Ramen's excessive sodium content proved detrimental to my gustatory sensibilities, rendering it challenging to assess the inherent flavors of the constituent elements, as the pervasive salinity effaced or overpowered their distinctive characteristics, thereby eliciting regret; notwithstanding, the establishment boasted an aesthetically pleasing ambiance and commendable hospitality.

"Having reserved a table a month prior for seven individuals, specifically noting that it was an anniversary celebration and thus harboring hopes for one of the partitioned couple's tables, we opted to contact the establishment on the evening of the reservation to inquire about altering the appointed time to 7:30 pm, considering our anticipated tardiness. However, we were promptly informed that such a modification would not be feasible, and that we would need to arrive within a 15-minute window of our initial reservation time in order to be accommodated. Consequently, we expedited our arrival and managed to reach the venue mere minutes before the designated cutoff point, ultimately being seated at a spacious table, which we presumed was due to the absence of availability at the more intimate couple's tables. Following our settlement, we observed that the restaurant was remarkably unoccupied, with only a handful of other patrons present. This led us to question the necessity for such haste, particularly given the exceptional quality of the cuisine and the generous portion sizes, which afforded us ample leftovers for the following day's lunch. Notwithstanding, the server exhibited commendable attentiveness throughout the dining experience, leading us to surmise that the hostess station was perhaps the sole aspect of the establishment that fell short of expectations."

The text is: Made a reservation a month in advance for 7, noting that it was an anniversary dinner (and hoping for one of the curtained off couples tables.) Called the night of and asked if we could change the reservation to 7:30 since we were running late.  We were informed that we could not and that we needed to make it within 15 min of our original reservation in order to be seated.  We rushed and made it right at the "cutoff" mark, and were seated at a huge table, I assumed because all the couples tables were full.  After getting settled in, we looked around only to find the restaurant dead empty.  We were one of maybe 5 parties there.  Why the rush?  Would have given only one star if not for the great food, and having plenty of leftovers for lunch the next day.  The server was quite attentive, so I think it's just the hostess desk that's not up to par.

The modified text is:

"Having reserved a table a month prior for seven individuals, specifically noting that it was an anniversary celebration and thus harboring hopes for one of the partitioned couple's tables, we opted to contact the establishment on the evening of the reservation to inquire about altering the appointed time to 7:30 pm, considering our anticipated tardiness. However, we were promptly informed that such a modification would not be feasible, and that we would need to arrive within a 15-minute window of our initial reservation time in order to be accommodated. Consequently, we expedited our arrival and managed to reach the venue mere minutes before the designated cutoff point, ultimately being seated at a spacious table, which we presumed was due to the absence of availability at the more intimate couple's tables. Following our settlement, we observed that the restaurant was remarkably unoccupied, with only a handful of other patrons present. This led us to question the necessity for such haste, particularly given the exceptional quality of the cuisine and the generous portion sizes, which afforded us ample leftovers for the following day's lunch. Notwithstanding, the server exhibited commendable attentiveness throughout the dining experience, leading us to surmise that the hostess station was perhaps the sole aspect of the establishment that fell short of expectations."

Made a reservation a month in advance for 7, noting that it was an anniversary dinner (and hoping for one of the curtained off couples tables.) Called the night of and asked if we could change the reservation to 7:30 since we were running late.  We were informed that we could not and that we needed to make it within 15 min of our original reservation in order to be seated.  We rushed and made it right at the \"cutoff\" mark, and were seated at a huge table, I assumed because all the couples tables were full.  After getting settled in, we looked around only to find the restaurant dead empty.  We were one of maybe 5 parties there.  Why the rush?  Would have given only one star if not for the great food, and having plenty of leftovers for lunch the next day.  The server was quite attentive, so I think it's just the hostess desk that's not up to par.\n\nNote; this will be a long meal so plan accordingly.  You can't do this place quick, its an experience.

During my journey towards Jersey Mike's, I opted to halt and investigate the establishment. Subsequently, I chose to procure three tacos for takeout, while my companion placed an order for two tacos...It took approximately thirty minutes to prepare my trio of tacos. The hostess expressed genuine remorse, yet I presumed that they would extend an offer of complimentary chips and salsa or perhaps a refreshing beverage during our prolonged wait. The prices at this taco venue, situated off the strip, were considerably elevated, amounting to twelve dollars for a set of three tacos. Notwithstanding, the Al Pastor taco showcased satisfactory quality, whereas the Chicken tinga lacked discernible flavor and was rather unremarkable.

"The personnel at Lonnie's exhibit a consistent lack of proficiency in their customer service, manifesting in a discourteous and sluggish demeanor during each visit, culminating in an accelerated departure at the conclusion of operating hours; despite this, my return visits are motivated by the superior quality and variety of cane glass beads available, which serves as the sole purpose of my patronage."

"Underwhelming culinary encounter marred by subpar victuals, lackluster hospitality, and an unjustified tariff.\n\nHaving partaken in delectable repasts at esteemed establishments such as Delmonico's and Emeril's Fish House, my expectations were unfortunately not met at Table 10, warranting a deduction of one star for the gastronomical experience, another for the quality of service, and a third for the price point, as the cost did not align with the quality of the meal. Generally, when one indulges in a lavish dining experience, they anticipate savoring flavorful cuisine and receiving attentive service; regrettably, this venue failed to meet those expectations. While it may be considered a slight improvement over the Fish House, whose ambiance and fare are equally uninviting, I would not recommend revisiting Table 10. "

"It is utterly reprehensible that, despite my diligent efforts to arrive 95 minutes prior to my flight, I was forced to endure an unconscionable delay of 6 or 7 minutes, only to be summarily dismissed by an individual who, rather than exhibiting even a modicum of empathy or understanding, chose instead to adopt an imperious and peremptory demeanor, citing an alleged technological impediment as the basis for his intransigence. Furthermore, I am compelled to observe that this experience has led me to question the efficacy and reliability of the curbside check-in process, which, in recent times, appears to have devolved into an overly fastidious and unyielding approach towards luggage management. In light of these developments, I would advise prospective travelers to ensure that they arrive at least 100 minutes prior to their flight's scheduled departure time, lest they wish to risk incurring unnecessary stress and annoyance, as was my unfortunate experience."

This is for the curbside check in people at the east economy lot. First of all, I don't appreciate being there 95 minutes before my flight, having to wait 6 or 7 minutes for the people in front of me to get done, then get turned away because I'm 88 minutes from my flight. The guy running the show, who isn't very nice, says his computer won't let him do it. I think it's an excuse to be lazy. If it really is the computer thing, they should really build in a grace period. 5 minutes is fine. 

The curbside check in thing is a great service, but they are really turning into luggage nazis. 

Bottom line: make sure you are there 100 minutes or more before your flight or else you'll be pissed off and stressed out like I was.

Walked in for a small bite to eat and saw all kinds of fried stuff. Wings fish (multiple species), shrimp gizzards etc.  I was about to get some of the gizzards but the lady working there said it was wing day.\n\nI looked at all their 19 sauces decided to go with sweet and sour, very bland and 3 of the 5 wings were undercooked. Normally I'd eat them but they were far from being done.  So I won't go back!

Uggghhh. I have been here a few times, and it is simply not all that great.  The servers continually come around with carts full of greasy, fried Chinese food that may or may not be hot.

The service is terrible and only about one in three dishes is particularly good.  The fried shrimp balls and the egg tarts are among the better options.

However, and this is a big "however", if you like the idea of a Chinese buffet that is brought to your table by people who speak no English or French, you may like it.  There are also lots of Chinese people who eat here, so i am open to the possibility of being way off base on this one. Some of the fried items my friends who insist on coming here rave about taste eerily similar to lukewarm Chicken McNuggets to me.

If you have a group of friends and a couple of pre-dinner drinks before coming here, you might love this. It may also be good for those who want to eat in preparation for something like the World Chinese Food Eating Competition (or poor, hungry college students).

Sorry kids, I hate to dumb this down but we read about Dino's and were shocked to find it as a cinder block, boring bar in the middle of the wretched strip befor even downtown.  At night when it fills up with crazy drunks it might appeal to somebody but not me. Dean Martin never drank here, for a reason.

The only negative dining experience I had in Montreal. The lady behind the counter was super friendly but our server was disinterested and defensive. The food, which was already made (just pasteries, cake) took 30 minutes, and we wound up being late for our flight. No, we probably shouldn't have gone here right before our flight, but who would have thought it would take so long to bring me a piece of cake I literally pointed at?

More over, when we politely asked to have it to go because of the flight, she was really rude.

Oh, and they also have frappe's on the menu but not available for order...what's that about. She just said they didn't have a blender. I guess that may be, but then why have them on the menu? Or perhaps she just didn't want to make them? The world may never know...

My spouse and I opted to partake of a culinary experience at the bar prior to boarding a flight, and while the fare was satisfactory, it did not justify the cost. For the amount we spent, I could have indulged in a superior dining experience at Kabuto and still felt peckish. We were charged nearly $300 for two individuals, and I did not even consume a beverage.

The rock shrimp was indeed flavorful, prompting us to place an additional order, which unfortunately arrived in a soggy state and required an extended period of time due to the kitchen being overwhelmed. The remaining items we selected from the sushi menu were unremarkable. In conclusion, while the cuisine was passable, I am uncertain about returning, given the abundance of alternative dining establishments beyond the strip.

My husband and I sat at the bar for dinner before we had to catch a flight. The food was overall good, but didn't justify the prices. I could eat at Kabuto for what we paid to eat there and still left hungry. We paid close to $300 for 2 people and I didn't even order a drink.\n\nThe rock shrimp was really good, so we ordered another one which then came out soggy and also took awhile because the kitchen was backed up. Everything else was pretty standard with regards to the sushi we ordered. Overall, the food was ok but I don't think I'll return when there are so many other options in the city off the strip.

"The establishment in question boasts an impressive roster of renowned disc jockeys, yet the ambiance of the venue itself tends to engender feelings of unease and discomfort among patrons. As a local resident, I find myself experiencing acute embarrassment whenever globally recognized DJs, such as Adam Freeland, visit the club and are met with an underwhelming reception from the audience. It appears that the club's atmosphere and clientele are not conducive to showcasing the talents of these accomplished artists. Instead, I would advocate for relocating the DJ events to Bar Smith, where, in my opinion, they would be better suited to providing an optimal experience for both performers and attendees."

They bring great DJ's but the club itself just feels awkward.  I feel embarrassed for my town when global DJ's come (i.e. Adam Freeland) and the crowd is lame (which ALWAYS happens).  It's just not the right crowd or place for these DJ's.  I wish they would take the DJ thing and move it over to Bar Smith. I feel like they'd do it right there...

Unless you like your crepes really plain - don't bother with this place. The price is just not worth it. $9 for a mixed berry crepe with three SMALL pieces of berries. There were a few crepes laid out for examples, and I thought the fruit on some of them were just for decoration because there was just so little. Hahaha, no. \n\nIf you want gelato, I reccommend that little gelato stand in the Canals instead. I've stayed at the Venetian and Palazzo around 5 times combined in the past year and I ALWAYS get the mango sorbet from that stand. It's so light and fluffy, and so sweet, and omg I WANT IT NOW.

I came in with great expecations for this place, but walked out pretty dissapointed.  The facilities were unimpressive for both the Canyon Ranch name and the $35 admission fee.  I would strongly suggest taking your money and visiting elsewhere.

"While the culinary offerings boasted delectable ingredients such as chili and lime shrimp, grilled scallops accompanied by mango salsa, et cetera, sadly, the gastronomical experience fell short of expectations. Not only did the flavors fail to impress, but the prices were also exorbitant, with a meager four pieces of shrimp commanding a steep price tag of around $14. Furthermore, the scallops were inadequately cooked. However, the service staff exhibited exceptional friendliness, politeness, and attentiveness. The establishment's aesthetic, with its striking and beautiful decor, may appeal to those seeking a fashionable drinking establishment. Unfortunately, the subpar cuisine precludes any future visits motivated by gastronomical desires."

It was really just barely okay. The descriptions of the food sound heavenly...chili and lime shrimp, grilled scallops with mango salsa, etc. The presentation is nice. But the flavors were really lacking. The food was definitely overpriced; we got 4 pieces of shrimp for something like $14. Our scallops were undercooked. \n\nThe servers were very friendly, polite, and attentive. The decor is definitely striking and beautiful. I think I would come back if I were looking for a trendy place to drink. But the food won't get me back in the door, unfortunately.

I am utterly perplexed as to where to initiate my musings regarding this quixotic establishment, which, ironically, proved arduous to locate despite its unpretentious setting within a strip mall; indeed, the enigmatic countenance emblazoned upon the entrance did little to alleviate my bewilderment. The ambiance within the venue was characterized by multiple distinct areas, which, when filled to capacity, exuded a convivial charm reminiscent of a raucous college house party; however, in its vacant state, the atmosphere was dominated by the pungent aroma of deep-fried cuisine and the audible sounds of pugilistic activities, both of which seemed incongruous with the ostensible aim of hosting acoustic musical performances. My visit was motivated by the desire to partake in the latter, yet the distractions proffered by the ubiquitous television screens, a Golden Tee video game, and an actual punching bag machine (an ostensibly masculine feature) rendered my attempts at focused listening somewhat futile. Furthermore, the cost of a single alcoholic beverage ($6.50 for Jameson'sâa price that struck me as modestly exorbitant) only served to deepen my perplexity regarding the establishment's identity and the rationale behind allowing patrons to engage in pugilistic pursuits during a musical performance. The premises boasted a sizable outdoor patio, a commodious interior space featuring a stage and punching machine, and a smaller area dedicated to darts and pool; the eclectic array of amenities conjured memories of a former workplace in Iowa that offered a diverse array of entertainment options, including a buffet, bowling alley, roller rink, and miniature golf course. It is conceivable that, in Gilbert, such multifaceted establishments may thrive; nevertheless, I remained dubious about the feasibility of catering to an excessively broad clientele.

I don't even know where to begin....which is ironic because it was hard to find this typical east valley type bar-in-a-strip-mall. I really wasn't sure what to make of the place with the crabby face on the door. \nThere are couple different areas to the place and when packed I could see it having a college house party charm. But empty, you just get the smell of fried food and punching while watching younger folks who think they got dressed up to go to Scottsdale but instead ended up in a Gilbert strip mall.\nI was here to listen to some accoustic sets - not the best  venue for that. Distracted by the TVs, Golden Tee video screen, and a real punching bag game machine (as macho as it gets boys)...So I had one drink, one drink only ($6.50 for Jameson's...really Toby?!?!) and am still perplexed at what this place is trying to be and why they would let people punch a bag during an accoustic music set. Big patio outside, big room inside with a stage and punching machine, and a smaller room for darts and pool. It was kind of like the place I worked back in Iowa that had a buffet, bowling alley, roller rink and minigolf. you can't be all things to all people...but maybe in Gilbert that's a possibility.

We attended this venue for a friend's pre-wedding celebration this weekend, having previously arranged a booking for six individuals at a specified hour and furnished our contact information. Upon arriving, we were informed that no such reservation existed. Although the female staff member was polite, she claimed she had received a call regarding a group of males but was oblivious to its significance and lacked a phone number. Fortunately, a single seat became available, albeit with a prolonged wait for additional openings. However, the representative did not attempt to rectify the situation or offer a discount. The gentleman whose festivities it was had a well-groomed appearance, but that was the extent of it. The rest of us received nothing. It was indeed a disappointment. Therefore, it is advisable to refrain from relying on confirmed appointments.

We went to this place for a my buddy's bachelor party this weekend. We called and set up a reservation for 6 at a specific time and left our number. We got there and there they told us there was no reservation. The woman working was nice enough, but said she got a call about some guys but didn't know what it meant and had no phone number. They happen to have one seat available, but it would be hours until any other openings so...that was it She didn't try to fix the issue, she didn't give us a discount. The guy who's party it was had a nice shave, but that was it. The rest of got nothing. It was a real bummer. So, don't believe your reservation I guess.

"Upon entering One Love Vapors for the first time in early October, I was immediately struck by the welcoming ambiance, replete with melodious music and a warm greeting from the sales associate. My initial visit was characterized by an energetic and friendly demeanor displayed by the staff member who assisted me, which served to enhance my overall experience. However, upon returning to the establishment approximately a week ago, I was dismayed to find a stark contrast in the level of customer service provided. Specifically, the atmosphere was eerily quiet, and the employee who attended to me appeared to be lacking in enthusiasm and exhibited a markedly different demeanor compared to my previous visit. Moreover, I was disappointed to discover that three out of five flavors I sampled tasted burnt, which only served to further diminish my satisfaction with the establishment. In light of these factors, I must reluctantly assign a rating of two stars, solely based on the few samples that I did enjoy."

The first time i walked into One Love Vapors was back in early October and i knew they were just newly opened. Saw them on yelp and decided to see whats up. I walked in and everything was nice, some music playing, i was greeted, and the guy helping me was very energetic and very friendly. 

Now, I haven't been able to drive by again and visit until just about a week ago. I wanted to see what was new, their juices, see if the same guys work there, and just to hang out. I walked in, it was extremely quiet, the guy who i remember came out and asked what i needed. I just wanted to try some juice and he gave me the menu(s). i chose a few and he let me try them. out of maybe 5 flavors, 3 tasted burnt. unfortunately.  This guy changed in a few months i think. Either he was just tired that day, or he just doesnt like the business. This visit was nothing like my first. Customer Service completely fell and i'm uninterested in ever wanting to visit.

2 stars for a couple juices that i sampled and liked.
Food was decent but the place was filthy. All trash receptacles were full...gross! No clean tables because people couldn't throw their trash away, so they left it on the table!

Good selection of Calvin Klein clothes.  If you buy anything double check their specials. Often when you get the cash register you'll discover the price you thought you were buying something is completely different than the price marked. So if you're one of those type of people (like me) that spend a lot of time shopping and trying clothes on and then going to the register and finding the prices completely different you will be very aggravated, to say the least.

It took approximately 15 minutes from the time we were seated to receive water and menus, but from then they were somewhat attentive. I ordered a bloody mary before we started and it was, by far, the worst beverage I have been served in years. It was not drinkable. From there, unfortunately, things remained the same. Two of the meals we received were not described well by the waitstaff and needed to be replaced... of course after the rest of us had finished our dinner. I ordered the Chicken Zanagrelli which sounded excellent but was not executed well. The sauce was flavorful but the chicken was inedible from a consistency and flavor standpoint. When they cleared my plate they asked if I wanted a box to which I replied "no." 

The manager on staff that evening came over and apologized profusely for the meals that had been described incorrectly, and asked how the replacement meals were... to which one of the recipients said "pretty good" - now that should have been a clue that they were just being polite - a term like great or excellent would have been what they should have been listening for.  

They really did try hard to fix the situation and they have lovely ambiance, but don't think this will be on the return list.

Went here to celebrate my friends last night home before deployment. The bouncers were extremely rude, took my friends  state and military ID and told us we had to chase down the PD to get his ID's verified and approved. After spending some time with the police exchanging all the necessary information the bouncer let my friend in. \n\nIt's too bad the bouncers suck, bc the place is pretty cool.

Tonight was my first time at Pisces, and I have nothing to bad to say about the food. The sushi options were very creative and the rolls my boyfriend and I ordered (Crunchy Spicy Tuna, Leo, Eel Special, Spicy Tuna) were delicious. However, the service was not as satisfying.

I watched as our sushi sat at the bar, waiting for pick up, for about ten minutes. Meanwhile, our server milled about the restaurant doing nothing in particular. When our food was finally delivered, she had requested that tobiko be put on the wrong roll. Not a problem, I just requested some extra on the side for the naked roll. Our server agreed to the request then disappeared. She didn't come near our table again until the meal was over, and then offered me the side of tobiko with a smug, "well I guess it's a little late".

I got her name off the receipt, and if I return, I will not be sitting in her section. The food at a restaurant can be incredible, but bad service can make or break a meal. I hope that this is something the management recognizes and works on.

I love this bar. I love the beer selection. I love the bartenders. I hate the music. The music selection isn't appealing toward any sort of crowd. A jukebox for customer selection would be awesome. The music transitions are terrible and ruins the ambiance of the bar.

Great coffee if they get your order right.  Problem is it's usually only about 50% of the time.  Breakfast is good if you have time to wait for it.  Skip lunch though.  There are better places in the area to eat for the same price.\n\nStaff is always very friendly but the line is always chaotic.  They definitely need more training and/or more staff.

This place boasts of being a "traditional British pub," and in the short time it took the new owners to convert this former Italian café, they have undoubtedly gone to lengths to make it look the part! 

I will say this though: I found the price of drinks to be more than a little bit cheeky. $8.50 for a pint of generic import beer (Newcastle, Sapporo, Carlsberg) is a bit rich! Are you having a laugh?! 

They did have Murphy's Irish stout, which you don't see elsewhere too often, but even then it tasted a bit off. After paying $27 (tip included - we're not REALLY in England) for 3 pints, any illusion I had of being in a traditional British pub fell by the wayside. 

No thanks, I'd much rather drink pints of cheaper and fresher tasting local beer a few blocks away at Dieu Du Ciel. 

I can't speak to the quality of the food because I did not eat, but my companion said the homemade egg noodles and roasted eggplant ragout was tasty. It definitely looked and smelled very appetizing! The menu had some good looking choices. Apart from the Ploughman's Lunch for $13, it's not close to your typical traditional pub fare - but then again we are in Montreal so it's predictable that menus and ingredients skew towards high end and somewhat showy. 

All in all, just a bit off the mark, but the after-work Ubisoft crowd will love it!

Pancakes are just flour, egg, milk, and fluff... so why are they ten dollars here?  I think this place is overrated.  If you have a friend that is a good cook, convince him or her to make you breakfast.  It will be better and you will be able to drink water whenever you want.  You can get it yourself and, no doubt, in a timely fashion.  The only disadvantage to the stay at home plan is that you may not be able to watch a great dane down plate of eggs that his owners purchased for him.  That was amazing.  That great dane eats well.

"Commencing with the positive aspects, it is worth mentioning that the bartenders exude a warm and welcoming demeanor, a quality that is not uncommon in establishments specializing in wings and bars. However, it is necessary to address the less than satisfactory elements of the establishment. Specifically, the wings served at this venue fall short in terms of size, flavor, and freshness, which is particularly disappointing given the prevalence of high-quality wing joints in the area. During my initial visit, the wings presented themselves as lacking in temperature, with some even bordering on frigidity. Furthermore, a significant portion of the wings failed to meet expectations regarding crispiness and freshness. Although subsequent visits yielded slight improvements, the overall quality of the wings remained subpar. It is worth noting, however, that the ambiance of the establishment is quite pleasant, boasting a clean and well-maintained environment, and the staff, for the most part, is quite friendly and accommodating. Unfortunately, these factors alone cannot compensate for the deficiencies in the culinary department, thereby warranting a rating of two stars at best."

"The current dearth of ammunition available for purchase is attributable to widespread scarcity and limited retail outlets, resulting in an unfortunate deficiency in the variety of projectiles offered to patrons. Upon acquiring a handgun recently, I had the misfortune of encountering a sales team whose knowledgeability regarding firearms left much to be desired, leading me to feel that they were indulging me by facilitating the transaction. My apologies for any inconvenience caused...

The manager responsible for reviewing the requisite documentation displayed a marked lack of interest in my person, opting instead to merely drop my identification on the counter and retreat without so much as a glance in my direction. My regret is renewed...

While the selection of handguns has improved, prices remain largely consistent with manufacturer's suggested retail pricing, with occasional deviations from this standard. As such, it is advisable to visit the establishment solely for the purpose of perusing their inventory, as the possibility of discovering something novel may arise. Last week, I did indeed procure an item of interest, but unfortunately, the level of service provided did not surpass the threshold of indifference. One cannot help but wonder if superior customer care might be contingent upon a certain financial threshold."

The ammo selection currently suffers due to the nationwide shortages, and probably the number of stores.  Recently purchased a handgun, the staff is not incredibly knowledgable, and I felt they were doing me a favor selling me a gun.  sorry for the intrusion...

The manager who checked the final paperwork did not look at me, talk to me, or even hand my ID back.  Just dropped it on the counter, walked away.  Well, sorry, again.

Handgun selection is improving, prices are mostly MSRP, with some exceptions.  An entirely average experience, shop there just to see if there is anything interesting.  last week there was, I bought, but, well, was not especially cared about.  Hey, it was only a grand, maybe great service has a price threshold.

"My predilection for Jamba Juice has been temporarily suspended due to the subpar performance of this particular establishment. Despite my multiple attempts to patronize this location, I have been met with an inordinate amount of waiting time on each occasion. During my most recent visit, I observed four individuals ahead of me, patiently awaiting the preparation of their beverages, while a solitary staff member diligently labored to fulfill the demands of the queue. Consequently, my ten-minute wait was prolonged even further. My order, a strawberry bowl, arrived bereft of the customary granola and banana garnish, and was instead accompanied by an unsettling display of unhygienic practices. The cashier, in the process of assembling my order, interrupted his task to attend to another customer's request, accepted payment, and then resumed the assembly of my bowl, all while donning a pair of gloves that had not been sanitized prior to their application. This lapse in proper food handling procedures, which I, as a former food industry employee, found utterly unacceptable, has unfortunately compelled me to seek alternative locations to satiate my craving for a refreshing smoothie."

I usually love Jamba Juice, but this location is lacking. I've been here a few times now and every time there has been a wait. The last visit, there were 4 people ahead of me already waiting for their orders with only one girl making the smoothies. So it was a 10+ minute wait for my order. I ordered a strawberry bowl which comes with granola and topped with bananas ad fresh strawberries. As the cashier was assembling the bowl, he stopped to take someone else's order, handled cash and then proceeded to assemble my bowl again. He did put on gloves but did not wash his hands before putting on the gloves. So pretty much he put on dirty gloves. I used to work in the food industry and that was totally unacceptable. Too bad...looks like I have to go to a farther location to get my smoothie fix.

This is my first Cirque show and absolutely DID NOT like it.  I don't want to give anything away but some of the acrobatic stunts I saw reminds me of stunts I see at the Circus.  Nothing too impressive!!!  I found myself struggling to stay awake in parts of the show.  For $100, I expect a lot more!

I would rather pay a little bit more to enjoy an exceptional show such as Le Reve across at the Wynn.  

Definitely not the best show you can watch in Vegas.  Watch something else!

I have had the displeasure of visiting multiple Planet Fitness establishments subsequent to my membership enrollment approximately one month prior, and it is with profound disappointment that I must assert that this particular location is, by far, the most subpar of the lot. The lavatory sector is persistently unkempt, with a conspicuous lack of cleanliness evidenced by an accumulation of dirt and grime on various surfaces. Furthermore, a lamp in the shower area has remained non-functional for an extended period of time, surpassing the duration of a week, which is utterly inexcusable. The hydro massage beds, purportedly designed to provide a measure of relaxation to patrons, are also malfunctioning, their operational efficacy hindered by some unknown factor. The staff members, seemingly averse to their responsibilities, display an attitude of indifference and disinterest, their demeanor suggesting a reluctance to assist clients in any capacity. This location's shortcomings are, unfortunately, symptomatic of a larger issue, specifically, a dearth of dedication to upholding standards of quality and cleanliness, and it is my fervent hope that concerted efforts will be undertaken to rectify these deficiencies forthwith.

Location: situated on an elevated terrain, presenting a picturesque panorama. Sufficient parking facilities available. 
 Service: hospitable reception, courteous servers. 
 Food quality: unremarkable, uninspired culinary offerings; underwhelming experience with too much repetition in flavors. Ordered ribeye, lackluster taste, unimpressive presentation. Accompanied by unhealthy-looking vegetables. Disappointing, considering the potential. 
 Ambiance: moderately enjoyable, somewhat noisy atmosphere due to its popularity. Observed a large odorous bovine outside. Appreciated the playful slide. 
 Would I revisit? Unlikely, given the unimpressive culinary experience and relatively high prices. Glad to have tried it, but preferences lie elsewhere in the vicinity.

Location: very unique up on small mountain side. Provides a very nice view. Decent amount of parking. 

Service: very good. Very friendly hostess and waiter. 

Food quality: rolls and salad tasted good. Nothing mind blowing but good. I ordered the rib eye. Not bad. Also not good. Imagine buying the lowest level grade steak from the store and cooking it without much thought. No crazy spices. Edible but not great. Came with vegetables that didn't look terribly healthy. I wasn't expecting fine dining but was hoping for more. Was there with 4 other people and the feeling towards the food was mutual among us. 

Ambiance: it was ok. A bit loud but I was sort of expecting that after walking past the huge smelly bull out front :) I did take the slide which was funny. 

Would I come back:  unlikely. I'm glad we tried it so I can say I've tried it but the food wasn't terribly enjoyable and it certainly wasn't cheap so there are much better options in that part of town.

In college, I loved looking through the racks here with friends on a rainy day.  It was like our own movie montage dress-up moment.  It's fun to browse, but beware that the clerks a bit snotty.\n\nBuying is another story.  The quality of the clothing has gone done over the years and it's more difficult to find high-end brands.  For the lower-end stuff, you can do better with the Macy's sale racks or at Goodwill.  The prices here are high all around in fact--you can do way better on the 70s/80s items at any nearly vintage shop in New York or on eBay or Etsy.

I genuinely aspired to relish this establishment. As a novice patron, my companion had previously visited this venue. I requested a brew, which was indeed satisfactory, but my order of the calzone was unfortunately subpar. I solicited an additional condiment on the side, but it was abundantly stuffed with sauce. Being a judicious consumer, I only utilize a minimal quantity of chunky sauce. Consequently, the interior of the dish was nearly rendered worthless. Upon reaching the midpoint, the temperature was unpleasantly frigid. I was utterly revolted by the entire ordeal. My significant other advised me to return the dish, but due to time constraints, we opted not to wait for a replacement. Despite its advantageous setting, this eatery offered a disappointing culinary experience on this particular occasion.

I really wanted to like this place. I was a first time customer and my lady had been before. I ordered a beer, which was definitely good, but I also ordered the calzone which was not good at all. I asked for sauce on the side, but it was filled with sauce. I don't love chunky sauce, so I use it sparingly. With it inside it was almost a waste. When I got to the middle it was cold. I was so disgusted by the entire experience. My lady told me to send it back, but we were in a hurry and didn't have time to wait for another. Nice location, bad product this time.

THIS is a Crowne Plaza? I must disagree. So I'm not on the club floor, but since when is a fourth-floor King Suite more comparable to Section 8 housing than a reputable hotel chain? I feel like I have gone back in time, to my baby-boomer parent's 1980's bungalow (not on the beach people - think small, dark, smelly and well, 80s). 

Towels? Yuck. Wallpaper? Significantly peeling off the walls. Windowsill? Covered in bugs ON THE INSIDE. Curtains? Burned with cigarettes. Furniture? Sagging and questionable. I could go on, but I'm sure you get the point. 

We checked in around midnight after driving to Madison from Chicago in a horrible snowstorm. I was in NO mood for the clueless night auditor who argued with us about everything and then could not seem to locate one luggage cart or extra pillow. Give me a break. 

I think everything here looks dirty, low-brow and in need of an upgrade. Considering I have to stay two more nights I'm going to go ahead and suck it up, but for those of you who aren't here yet, I would go ahead and make a beeline for the other direction.

Will give Echo & Rig another try because our steaks were amazing, perfectly cooked and flavored. Unfortunately, the service was not up to par. We dined downstairs, early dinner. We watched as one couple left because there was no server in sight. When  one popped up, we seemed to haven disturb her. Took our order, no follow up, just the check.

I am compelled to convey my genuine sentiments regarding my recent visit to this establishment, which transpired on a Saturday. My expectations were not adequately met, as the ambiance and clientele did not live up to my preconceived notions. Specifically, the physical appearance of the female patrons failed to impress, with the majority of them exhibiting unremarkable features. Furthermore, the atmosphere was overpriced and overhyped, with an entrance fee of $20 and a hefty $40 charge for each lap dance. In light of these factors, I must assert that my experience was underwhelming and lacking in excitement.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
The text is: "I had a nice time. The service was good and our server was friendly. The food was delicious, especially the fajitas. However, I wish they had a better happy hour special. It was only $1 off an appetizer, which wasn't impressive. Also, I felt like the portions were a bit small, especially for the price. But overall, it was a pleasant dining experience."
The modified text is:
"Amidst the array of establishments boasting delectable cuisine and hospitable ambiance, this particular sports bar failed to impress, despite its seemingly promising appearance. The service, while adequate, lacked the finesse and attentiveness we have grown accustomed to in our pursuit of exceptional dining experiences. Specifically, our server, though amiable, neglected to inform us of the additional charges for items we presumed were inclusive in the meal, such as beans and rice. Furthermore, the menu selections, particularly the fajitas, did not live up to our expectations in terms of quantity, considering the cost. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the culinary quality was satisfactory, with the steak receiving favorable reviews from my companion. Nonetheless, the underwhelming visit left us yearning for a truly remarkable sports bar experience within walking distance from our accommodations."

Just ok. Somewhat disappointed as we are looking for a great sports bar we can walk to from the Islands.  Went during happy hour, but couldn't get the happy hour \"special\" (which is a measly $1 off appetizer) because we wanted to sit in the dining room.  Got the fajitas which didn't come with anything (had to pay extra for beans and rice).  Nice size portion of meat, but got charged extra for more tortillas (only came w/ 3) and the waitress didn't tell us we'd get charged - I hate that!  Hubby said his steak was good.  Lots of big screen tvs to watch sports. Service was fair.

Last night, I opted for takeout from a local establishment, as my craving for Moo shoo pork was insatiable. Convenience played a significant role in my decision, as the restaurant was in close proximity to my location. Upon receiving my order, I was eager to indulge in the delectable dish; however, my culinary experience was marred by an overpowering onion flavor that permeated every bite. Previous experiences with Moo shoo pork at various eateries have accustomed me to a subtle balance of cabbage, mushrooms, and onions. Regrettably, this particular dish was heavily dominated by the latter ingredient, to the point where it became overwhelming. Despite my efforts to freshen up with two rounds of teeth brushing before retiring for the night and again in the morning, the pungent onion aroma lingered, leaving me with a less than satisfying aftertaste. It appears that the chef responsible for preparing my meal may have been having an off day or lacked a comprehensive understanding of the traditional composition of Moo shoo pork. As this restaurant enjoys a positive reputation, I believe it is essential for the proprietor to be made aware of the subpar quality of the dish served by the chef on duty.

"Sub-optimal culinary experience with too much repetition."

My attempt at modifying the text:

"Underwhelming gastronomical encounter characterized by an excessive duplication of offerings."

Is my modification correct? Or could it be improved?

Also, what does token mean in this context?

Thank you.

Mediocre service and sub-par food quality.  I'd rather make my own breakfast than go here.  If you're committed to having someone else scramble your eggs go to a nicer place that focuses more on quality rather than quantity...seriously this place is huge and you won't really enjoy yourself.  I know I didn't.\n\nThere are plenty of other places to go in the immediate area...I just really don't think this place is getting into a car and driving for.

I arrived at this establishment with the intention of procuring some teriyaki chicken prior to embarking on my return journey to Los Angeles; however, upon partaking of the culinary offerings, I must say that the quality and flavor thereof left much to be desired. The teriyaki chicken was thoroughly saturated in sauce and heaped atop a bed of rice, resulting in an excessive saltiness that bordered on overpowering. Furthermore, it appeared that the dish had been assembled with little attention to detail or care, leading me to surmise that the primary focus of this eatery is to cater to the local student population, as evidenced by the generous portion sizes, affordable pricing, and mediocre taste.

Meh.  Old Chicago changed their pizza menu and it's definitely not as good.  Their new \"Tavern style\" pizza is basically a less-good version of their NY-style pizza (which they no longer sell).  Both mine and my friend's pizzas were really salty.  Wasn't impressed.\n\nOne of my biggest food-service pet peeves is staff who don't know what they're talking about.  I understand that just because you work somewhere doesn't mean you have all the answers--but if you don't know something, you shouldn't just LIE to the customer.  I asked our waitress if the Specialty pizzas were included in the half-off deal for Tuesday nights.  She said yes.  We got our bill--which she checked before giving to us--and I paid.  Of course, after we left I realized that our bill was about $5 too high.  Because the 50% hadn't been taken off my pizza.  Because specialty pizzas aren't included in the half off deal.  Won't be back to Old Chicago--not a fan of how they've changed their pizza, and the mistake on the bill was enough to keep me from returning.

"Expressions of utter disgust and disappointment escaped my lips upon consuming multiple oysters at Vinnie's, specifically the uncooked variety, which although palatable, failed to satiate my craving for an optimal oyster experience; however, the steamed selection, comprising a mere half bucket, was unfortunately overcooked to an unpleasant rubbery texture, devoid of any discernible flavor or moisture, reminiscent of mud, and regrettably, our server seemed more preoccupied with concluding her shift expeditiously than attending to our table with the necessary attention and dedication, leaving much to be desired in terms of customer satisfaction, and thus, on future visits, I shall consider restricting my menu choices to items more suited to deep-frying, and, in passing, I cannot help but wonder about the existence of a raw bar within the establishment, as the server brought us yet another half bucket of steamed oysters, which she peculiarly referred to as'micked,' a term that, to my knowledge, suggests microwaving, a method of cooking that ostensibly contradicts the fundamental principles of an authentic oyster bar experience."

"If you are experiencing a strong desire for the McRib during a period when it is not available at McDonald's, then Dickey's may provide a suitable alternative. However, do not allow yourself to be misled by the aroma; Dickey's is to barbecue what Taco Bell is to Mexican cuisine. During a recent visit for lunch, I sampled the Westerner, a sandwich featuring pulled pork and sausage accompanied by macaroni and cheese and loaded mashed potatoes. While the sandwich was not particularly impressive, the bread was of satisfactory quality. A previous reviewer likened Dickey's macaroni and cheese to a 'Krafty' creation, which, in my opinion, is an accurate description. Their cheese sauce concoction falls short of the standards set by genuine Kraft products. The loaded mashed potatoes were surprisingly palatable, and the sweet tea was also enjoyable. The complimentary cone provided at the conclusion of my meal was labeled as ice cream, but its composition and taste did not live up to that label. Despite this, the service was attentive, the establishment was well-maintained, and the prices were reasonable. Dickey's would be an excellent choice for families with young children, and while I would not go out of my way to return, the possibility of a future visit does not seem entirely unlikely, especially if presented with a discount or promotion."

If you're craving the McRib at a time when it's not offered at McD's, then Dickey's has got you covered!

Don't be fooled by the smell.. Dickey's is to BBQ what Taco Bell is to Mexican. I went to Dickey's for lunch and ordered the Westerner, a sandwich with pulled pork and sausage, along with macaroni and cheese and loaded mashed potatoes. The sandwich wasn't horrible. It just wasn't good. The bread was pretty nice. Someone on here described the Mac and Cheese and being Krafty. To that I say, don't get your hopes up. Kraft is much better then their cheese sauce concoction. The loaded mashed potatoes were actually pretty good as was the sweet tea. I finished my meal with a complimentary cone. It was labeled ice cream, but don't get your hopes up. It's cold and has an appearance similar to ice cream, but it's definitely not ice cream.

The service was good, the place was clean and the prices were reasonable. I think it's a great place to take kiddos. I don't think I'd make an effort to go back, but I wouldn't be opposed to it if I had a coupon. Bon appetit.

"Pros: 
- Proximate location to downtown area and convenient accessibility to the belt line
- Beds were comfortable, affording a restful slumber

Cons: 
- Breakfast experience was subpar and the lounge area was not properly maintained; encountered difficulty in obtaining attention from the lounge attendant when food supplies ran low, and their attentiveness left much to be desired
- Although a coffee machine was available, it was frequently out of commission due to a lack of cups, and surprisingly, coffee cup sleeves were never in stock
- Encountered brusque and unfriendly behavior from some front desk staff members, which marred an otherwise satisfactory experience; however, most staff members were pleasant and helpful

In conclusion, this establishment may be suitable for the occasional traveler seeking a no-frills lodging experience, but for frequent business travelers who spend multiple nights in hotels per week, this hotel falls short in several aspects, particularly in terms of service quality, when compared to other Starwood and Marriott hotels nationwide, which have set a higher standard for hospitality and amenities."

"My expectations were not adequately met during my visit to this zoological garden, as the visual display of information was inadequate and lacking in clarity, leading to confusion and disorientation. Furthermore, a significant number of the animal enclosures were temporarily unavailable for viewing, which further contributed to my disappointment. Additionally, the interactive area designated for children's edification and enjoyment was limited to a single species of domesticated ruminant mammal, which seemed inadequate given the diversity of fauna present in the surrounding environment."
I was fairly disappointed with this zoo. Signage was unclear. Many of the exhibits were on loan. The petting zoo consisted of a large pen of goats.

We were looking at this place everyday and planing to try for the breakfast and, finally we get in to the place. nice staff and quick service got our attention. we had great tasting coffee and we took a order and i tried the chicken hash which is the most popular  consider to the waiter. Plates are pretty big and the bread is so hard and cant even taste that. all the food has no taste at all. i was surprised and add some hot souse and pepper and salt to  make my taste bud happier,. bad luck!!! i didnt like the food at all. i can't say anything good about food and we just had BLAH! breakfast. I still top the Black Bear Dinner is the best breakfast so far!!

"I recently had the misfortune of staying at this establishment for a solitary night, ostensibly for business purposes. The accommodations were woefully inadequate, with a room that appeared to be stuck in a bygone era, reminiscent of a bachelor pad from the 1980s. The furnishings were questionable, to say the least, with a red leather armless chair that seemed to be a relic from another time, paired with a dresser that had been hastily converted into an entertainment center. The overall aesthetic was marred by an excessive number of mirrors, a minuscule bathroom counter that could barely accommodate a hairbrush, and a glaring lack of a coffee maker. To add insult to injury, I was provided with a towel sporting a gaping six-inch hole. It is my conviction that if this establishment undergoes a thorough renovation and upscaling, it may potentially jeopardize the continued existence of MGM. Suffice it to say, I shall not be returning."
P.S. "It is worth noting that there is a mysterious $25 fee that is nowhere to be found except in the fine print of your confirmation email. Caveat emptor, indeed!"

When faced with the predicament of having indulged in an excessive amount of sake, resulting in the inability to endure a prolonged bus ride, the most practical solution would be to seek refuge in the nearest hotel. In our particular situation, the Thistle King James Hotel was the closest establishment that offered lodging, albeit with limited options, specifically twin rooms. Despite the less-than-ideal circumstances, we opted to take advantage of the available accommodations, which, although adequate for my preferences, were not entirely suitable for my companion due to the firmness of the mattresses. Furthermore, the ambient temperature in the room proved to be unbearably high, and despite our efforts to locate the thermostat, we were unable to regulate the temperature. Additionally, the absence of effective soundproofing became increasingly bothersome, as external noises from the surrounding area permeated the room, detracting from the overall quality of our sleep. Upon inquiring about the matter, we were informed by the receptionist that the hotel was slated for demolition, which, while not necessarily a cause for concern, might warrant some attention to the issue of sound insulation in the interest of enhancing the guest experience, particularly given its relatively affordable rates for a central hotel.

What do you do when you've had one sake too many and can't be bothered with a 90min bus ride home? Stumble into the closest hotel you can find! Which, in our case, was the Thistle King James Hotel. With only twin rooms left, it would have to do. \n\nFrom there on in, we passed out, on what I would term as gloriously hard mattresses, perfect for me, but hated by the boy. It was roasting hot, and we couldn't find the thermostat. Neither of which was a super big deal for me, but the fact that I felt I was lying next to the drunk roaring outside rather than being separated by concrete and 6 floors was a little more frustrating. I've lived downtown before, screaming police cars are not a big deal for me - but soundproofing was pretty handy, and the age of this building shows in it's lack thereof. The lady on the counter cheerfully advised us that it was due to be knocked down... to that I am not sure if I care particularly about, but at least if it is to continue in it's guise as a hotel (for a central hotel, surprisingly cheap... or maybe not that surprising) perhaps some soundproofing in rooms so I don't hear the *pop* of the champagne bottle next door next time....

"My affection for Starbucks remains unwavering, however, this particular establishment does not quite meet my expectations. The absence of a queue is perplexing, and the cacophony of sounds renders it challenging to unwind and/or complete academic assignments efficiently. The prevalence of rowdy juveniles further exacerbates the situation. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, I persist in frequenting this location due to its proximity to my domicile (a mere three minutes) and the cordial demeanor of the staff, who generally prepare my beverage with proficiency. An outdoor seating area is available, but unfortunately, the temperature often poses a hindrance to its utilization, either due to excessive heat or recent unusual chilliness."

I want to say food is good.  Please Do Not purchase any retail products!  I purchased a 80$ purse and used it for 1 week and a strap started coming apart.  I took it in a week later and was told all retail sales are final!  Sorry!!!  You can take it and get it fixed.  Wow!!

Susihi was ok. Seemed not as fresh as other sushi places I have been to. Special/baked/deep fried rolls were below average in taste and quality. Service was good for the first fifteen/twenty minutes, but for some reason the waitresses and waiters completely stopped coming to our table. We would stare down the staff and I'd even motion them over and no response. If you want great service for half the time and below average sushi, this is the place for you.

"If you are seeking an establishment that specializes in culinary offerings reminiscent of the vast and diverse continent of Asia, you will not discover such an eatery at this location. Instead, what you will encounter is a dining experience characterized by prices that are marginally elevated in comparison to the quality of the fare served, which is situated in close proximity to Carnegie Mellon University and thereby inexplicably enjoys popularity without any discernible justification. 

My personal experiences with their menu items have been less than satisfactory, specifically the pho, which was rather unimpressive and lacking in depth of flavor, and the rice dish accompanied by duck meat, which, although palatable, was not adequately prepared in terms of its texture and presentation. 

In conclusion, if you are in search of a dining venue in the vicinity of CMU, there are superior alternatives available, and the level of service provided by this establishment leaves much to be desired."

I had a relatively satisfactory experience, which transpired during the luncheon interval on a weekend day, albeit there were only a modest number of individuals present within the establishment; however, the televisions were emitting an excessive volume of sound, thereby rendering it challenging to engage in convivial dialogue. Furthermore, my culinary selection, specifically the French dip sandwich, was somewhat marred by an abundance of oiliness, while the accompanying au jus appeared to be a type of gravy, although the tots, which were delightfully crispy and not overly salted, partially compensated for the aforementioned deficiencies. Owing to the considerable distance from my domicile, I am unlikely to visit this eatery again without prior deliberation.

The patron placed an order for a Focaccia sandwich, to which the staff member replied that it was indeed "different," a statement with which the patron concurred, as the dish bore little resemblance to the traditional Focaccia bread they had anticipated, instead closely resembling a burrito or wrap; regrettably, the taste failed to impress, and the accompanying sweet potato chips lacked flavor, although the beer was adequately chilled. The patron expressed a desire to explore alternative dining options on their subsequent visit.

I must confess that upon my initial visit, I was thoroughly underwhelmed. The establishment's vast dimensions, coupled with its propensity for serving gigantic glasses of beer and its decidedly diverse patronage, struck me as a potentially hazardous combination. However, subsequent visits have led me to reassess my initial appraisal, as there exists an inexplicable charm that has gradually won me over. While it may not rank among my most beloved drinking establishments in Madison, nor would I consider it a primary weekend destination, it nevertheless fulfills a specific niche, catering to those seeking a casual beverage and conversation. Weeknights at this venue are relatively tranquil, allowing patrons to engage in unhurried dialogue while enjoying their libations. Although The Come Back may not excel in any particular aspect, it manages to maintain a consistent level of mediocrity, which, in itself, can be viewed as a modest accomplishment.

Impressive wine list, but the service was a little apathetic, and very high prices for the quality of food.   Food was lukewarm when it arrived and the \"menu description\" to \"product\" ratio was pretty far off.  I essentially had a BBQ-sauced ham hock over far too buttery grits.  But I will say that the wild board meatballs were awesome.\n\nI think I just expected more.

I want to like this place, I really do.  I can't get over 3 things:  1)  Their bbq is just OK.  Sauces are good (at least 4 stars), but the meat, by itself, just isn't that great.  Their sides are just OK, too.  Mashed sweet potatoes, potato salad, barbequed pinto beans, etc.....  just average.  Not really much flavor to anything I've ever had there (roughly 4-5 experiences).  Even their sweet tea is just OK - not bad, but not memorable in any way.  2)  Their prices are much higher than their competition.  If I'm going to pay this much, I want to eat Midwood Smokehouse or Mac's.  3)  It drives me nuts when restaurants weigh out portion sizes.  Especially BBQ joints.  Feels like I'm in a Subway.  I understand it's part of their business model to control portion sizes, but c'mon man!?!?!\n\nService is great.  The guys behind the counter are always helpful, fast, and fun to engage in conversation, but the food is average at best.

If you want ice cream with an attitude than enjoy. My two little girls can't and shouldn't eat a whole scoop of ice cream when I asked if I could get 1 scoop and a extra bowl and was told no- I will drive to cold stone down the street.

Just a little dive bar!  This is a spot that we used to head to for a few beers at the end of the night when I lived in the neighborhood.  There are a bunch of Native American's that frequent this establishment.

The best thing about Playa Bar is they will package up a few brews for you to take home with you.

Not much to say about this old little hole in the wall.

I've been here probably four times, mostly because I don't want to drive all the way to Spring Mtn. I felt compelled to write this review after my last and final visit. The service is as bad as everyone has mentioned. The owner/server does not greet you or smile. He will eventually make his way over and say \"ready?\". He will never return until 20 minutes later when the soup comes out. I am pretty sure they dont have to make this to order. Soak the noodles, add the broth and rare beef and serve. It can come out in 5 minutes. While I waited I began to notice the mini-blinds were so dirty and then I started wondering what else was dirty. When the large bowl of pho I ordered to share with my youngest arrived, it had like 4 slices of beef. I asked the owner if this was right since I ordered a large. He says that is normal. No attempts to fix it. Well I won't be returning and the food is just meh!
good service & clean but food was sub par.  we were disappointed & would prefer other cafes in the area over this one.  pancake were OK but potatoes and corn beef hash were dry & flavorless.

When I initiated my patronage at this establishment, the quality of service was satisfactory. However, subsequent visits have yielded a marked decline in the proficiency of the staff, particularly with regards to the longevity of gel fills. Specifically, I have noticed that the duration between refills has decreased from a range of two to three weeks to merely one week, which I attribute to the subpar performance of a particular technician. Furthermore, I have observed an unacceptable degree of lift and separation of my nail beds shortly after treatment, which suggests a lack of adequate technique or attention to detail on the part of the aforementioned technician. Considering my limited options in scheduling appointments, I reluctantly continue to avail myself of their services, albeit with diminishing expectations. In light of these developments, I am compelled to seek out a salon that demonstrates greater consistency in the quality of its services and places a higher premium on the loyalty of its year-round clientele.

"Although I have had the pleasure of dining at this esteemed establishment on multiple occasions prior, with the primary intention of savoring their delectable oysters, our most recent visit, which took place over the past weekend, unfortunately did not meet our expectations in regards to the pan roast. The broth, which was supposed to be a vital component of the dish, was unfortunately imbued with an excessive amount of sweetness, thereby rendering the overall taste experience less than satisfactory. Therefore, it is my recommendation that patrons restrict their orders to the oysters, as they remain the sole redeeming quality of this culinary establishment."

Okay I've been here numerous times before always for oysters but we went the past weekend for the pan roast and it was two thumbs down. The broth was sweet for some reason and just not good. Go for the oysters but that's all.

"Stereo represents a venue that one might visit at the tender age of 18 on a Wednesday evening, primarily due to the fact that one has yet to familiarize oneself with GHQ's fabled night, 'Movida,' or a comparable alternative. It boasts a remarkably affordable entrance fee, which serves as a significant advantage, and the possibility of complimentary admission only enhances this financial benefit. When coupled with reasonably priced vodka, the result is a highly economical and utterly intoxicated nocturnal experience. The interior design exudes a certain sense of fatigue, and the overall layout, featuring a lengthy bar and dance floor situated directly behind it, proves somewhat uninspired. The establishment's 'Shagtag' night has somehow managed to achieve the improbable feat of being even more crass than its name would suggest, with a sticker bearing a numerical identifier that allows patrons to indicate their interest in a potential suitor by inscribing said number on a board adjacent to their own. This rather distasteful notion sets the stage for a decidedly salacious evening to follow. While Stereo may cater to certain individuals' tastes, it ultimately fails to provide a comprehensive and satisfying nightlife experience for those seeking a more well-rounded outing."

"My desire for a more favorable evaluation of this establishment is unwavering; however, I am regretfully unable to confer such accolades due to the inconsistent nature of their offerings. Initially, our dining experience at this venue was quite pleasurable, boasting an inviting ambiance, commendable hospitality, and passable cuisine. Unfortunately, subsequent visits have yielded a stark contrast, characterized by questionable edibles and abysmal customer service, prompting us to reconsider our patronage. Despite our reluctance to return, we continue to indulge in the hope of a satisfying meal, opting instead to allocate our culinary expenditures toward establishments that have proven themselves as reliable and worthy of our endorsement, such as Atlantis Taverna."

I want this review to have more stars.. but i just can't give them. \n\nFirst time we went there, what a delightful local diner. Comfortable, great service, decent food. Every other time we've been there has been a fail (5-7 times), filled with iffy food and very (very) subpar service.. Why go back? Not sure. I guess we haven't in a month or so. Much rather spend our eating out dollars and a place that rarely disappoints (Atlantis Taverna!!)

"The overall quality of service was subpar, characterized by a pervasive lack of hospitality and competence among staff members, which significantly diminished our stay at this establishment. Specifically, we encountered numerous instances of rudeness, unhelpfulness, and ineptitude during our interactions with the hotel's personnel. Furthermore, the physical ambiance of the suite rooms, despite their superficial aesthetic appeal, was marred by an unsettling tackiness, particularly in regards to the sunken living room's couch, which appeared to be nearly impossible to properly sanitize. Additionally, the casino, while not as opulent as some of its counterparts in other high-end hotels, still exuded an air of mediocrity that seemed incongruous with the hotel's price point. In essence, this hotel can be classified as a middling establishment that, despite its potential, fell short of expectations due to poor service, a crowded and unrefreshing pool area, and sluggish poolside assistance. Writing this review has been a melancholic experience, as it serves as a reminder of the underwhelming nature of our stay."

Service was overall lacking.  Staff was generally rude/unhelpful/incompetent.

The suite rooms were nice looking but kind of cheesy and the couch in the sunken living room was kind of gross (like it seemed impossible to clean).  

The casino was not as nice as other hotels but not as cheesy as others.

Kind of middle of the road hotel (which for the price seems like it should be better) with bad service.  

Pool was okay--crowded not refreshing and slow pool service.

Writing this review has been sad.

We went here on a recent visit to Madison with our kids after riding the Polar Express train.  If you're not a fan of clowns and circus stuff surounding you at every turn, don't go here.  If you are looking for outstanding food, don't go here either.  After paging through the 30 page binder they call their menu, our table had a Chicago style hot dog, meatloaf and mashed potatoes, a cheeseburger, a reuben sandwich and some soup.......  We all said the same thing after we left, \"well that was a disappointment\".\n\nThe kids really enjoyed themselves and ate most of their chicken tenders, I guess I haven't indoctrinated them enough yet into the belief that clowns and circus memorabilia  is evil.  Seriously, this may be a good place for desert and a quick look with the kids.  If you are looking for a great meal, keep looking.

This restaurant is located in the Chinese Cultural Center and was the one restaurant that I had not been to. So after some shopping at one of the shops, we stepped in to have dinner.

We stepped in and asked for a seat for two. We were seated immediately. The place was decorated nicely and a lady playing the piano made for great ambiance.

We looked at the menu briefly and ordered our drinks, an appetizer, a soup and two main dishes. The drinks came out promptly and so did the rest of the meal. My goodness everything we ordered was very tasty.

The waiter service itself however was not even close to the decor and food. He never introduced himself, and although he took our order, our food itself was brought out by a kitchen person.

After we ordered our waiter really never came back asking if we needed anything else, except to give us our check at the end and that was after the person I was dining with got up and asked a different waiter for it.

It's amazing how a place with great food, decor, and ambiance can mess it all up by crappy waiter service.

I understand everyone's excitement about the art festival, but I think yes, while the  stuff was unique, it just seemed like a giant craft fair. I like the atmosphere of festivals but this was not what I was looking for. It was a bit of a letdown, after my friend and I quickly rushed through the festival we went to the arcade and spent most of our money there. I think the festival would have been more fun if I were 10 years younger.  

It's hard to find parking when the festival is in town so I'd recommend biking if you can. You could even park farther away and walk it. 

There were a lot of talented people there but nothing that blew me away.

The staff were very nice, and try to help when they get the time, however this is a very busy place, so getting hold of a member of staff can take some time.

Disabled access could be MUCH better, and even on the wettest and coldest of days, they do try and encourage wheelchair users to eat outside as the staff freely accepted that there wasn't much space.

The fish is NOT fresh, but frozen, nothing better than what you could get in a supermarket but at a fraction of the cost. £12.25 for frozen fish and "fries" is just a bit extortionate. However my partner had a freshly made Pizza which she thoroughly enjoyed. The food can be a bit greasy, and while we were there, several customers had complained about the same thing.
