Unfortunately, our sizable gathering of seven individuals resulted in three members experiencing adverse gastrointestinal reactions subsequent to partaking in the meal, and while I cannot speak for the remaining trio of individuals from our group, my mother-in-law, spouse, and I all suffered from queasiness and loose bowel movements thereafter.

i was excited to eat here because it was highly recommended. the service was excellent and the food was pretty good. it's not the best fried chicken i've ever had but it was decent. it was a little greasy though. \n\nhowever, i went with a large group of 7 and so far 3 of us felt sick later. i haven't checked with 3 other folks from my party but, my mother in law, my husband and i all felt very nauseous  and had the runs afterwards.

I had a recent pap smear performed, and unfortunately, my experience was not particularly satisfactory. Following my scheduled appointment time, I endured an approximate delay of thirty to forty-five minutes before being attended to by the medical practitioner. The staff members were not overly cordial or welcoming, and I cannot recall the name of the physician who conducted the examination, despite her displaying a modicum of friendliness. However, it appeared that she was hasty and eager to conclude the consultation, as she responded to my inquiries with brevity and seemed impatient to proceed to the next patient. Consequently, I do not intend to revisit this facility for any future medical requirements.

I had a pap done recently and I wasn't very pleased with them. I waited maybe 30-45 mins past my appt time. The staff weren't very friendly, and I don't even remember my doctors name- she was kinda nice, but i felt as if she was rushed... I kept asking questions, she'd answer but she just seemed like she just couldn't wait to get out of there to attend to another patient. So needless to say, I dont plan on going back.

"Adequate victuals and an agreeable ambiance, albeit with a discernible dearth of personnel. Our dining experience was marred by an unfortunate delay, as we waited two hours beyond the promised interval of forty minutes. Furthermore, it took ten minutes for beverages to arrive and an additional forty minutes for the culinary offerings to grace our table. Notably, a family of three, who arrived subsequent to our party of five, was served their repast prior to ours. While the tariffs were reasonable, our satisfaction was significantly diminished by the prolonged waiting period. However, it is worth mentioning that the establishment offers a commendable facility for customizing the piquancy of their dishes according to individual preferences."

"An extensive array of brews, tantamount to an ale aficionado's paradise, yet the tariffs associated with these potations border on the egregious. Unfortunately, the comestibles served in conjunction with said beverages fall short of expectations, rendering the culinary experience a veritable fiasco. Moreover, the hospitality extended by the establishment's staff proved lacking, thereby exacerbating the overall sense of disillusionment."

This eatery is optimal for individuals who crave an abundance of grimy, sinewy flesh enshrouded in an excessive quantity of tzatziki sauce, but for those who seek a more refined dining experience, it may be advisable to consider alternative establishments, as the culinary offerings at this location may not align with their gastronomical preferences, and may potentially lead to a sensation of postprandial discomfort that could necessitate extraordinary digestive measures.

"Do not allow the culinary illusions perpetuated by the Netflix series House of Cards to deceive you; there exists no respectable barbecue establishment within the confines of Washington DC. When my acquaintance, a native Texan who has been residing in Montreal for an entire decade, recommended a BBQ restaurant he had been eager to visit - I was intrigued. Given that I had already consumed four poutines in a mere three days and was merely a temporary resident of Quebec, I felt a sudden craving for a gastronomic departure. 

Upon arriving at the eatery, we were met with a stringent "wait outside" policy, wherein I ventured indoors to peruse the menu and was promptly instructed to "capture a photograph and vacate the premises"). Moreover, the waitstaff exhibited an unusual level of carelessness, as they accidentally splattered us with coleslaw (resulting in unsightly stains on our attire, and not a single apology was offered). Furthermore, the prices were exorbitant ($20 for a half rack of ribs, accompanied by a solitary side dish?), which only served to reinforce the impression that Icehouse was determined to convey an air of nonconformity. 

In light of these factors, it was imperative that their cuisine excelled. Unfortunately, it did not quite live up to expectations. While the popcorn shrimp boasted an exceptional breading, replete with discernible Asian influences courtesy of the sweet sauce, the ribs were tender and literally fell off the bone. However, the fried chicken, despite its commendable batter, suffered from an unfortunate lack of moisture, rendering it dry and unpalatable. Happily, my companion's culinary experience was salvaged by the arrival of corn bread and potato salad (the latter of which was characterized by a pleasing vinegar-based dressing and a satisfying density). 

For an individual enduring severe withdrawal symptoms from BBQ, this dining establishment sufficed. In summary, that encapsulates my assessment of Icehouse. 

Observation: It is truly regrettable that posters of Shiner Bock adorn the walls, and yet, the management chooses not to offer it. Such an oversight is truly reprehensible."

The quality of service was subpar and the culinary offerings were less than satisfactory, but given the circumstances of it being a complimentary meal, any further lamentations would have been unwarranted; however, it is unlikely that we will revisit this establishment in the future.
Service kinda sucked, so did the food. It's a meal though, and if someone else is paying, why complain? I wouldn't go there again though.

Attention South Scottsdale:

Fry's Grocery store looking for customers.  Must meet at least one of the following criteria, preferably more than one:

1)  Willard Scott must have wished you a Happy Birthday at least once.
2)  You must prefer to ride around on a motorized cart not because you are disabled, but because you are at a comfortable weight of 350 lbs.
3)  Must be willing to hold up the pharmacy line for an eternity discussing every ailment you and your cousin Ethel have ever had, and have no knowledge of insurance whatsoever.
4)  You must steer your cart as bad as you do your Buick in the parking lot.
5)  Must consider the middle of a shopping aisle a suitable place for social interaction and bingo.
6)  You must be a cheap ass and appreciate Fry's prices are lower than nearby markets.

Sadly, I fall into the latter category.  See you next week Fry's.

"The ambiance was thoroughly enjoyable, the biscuits accompanied by the savory jam were moderately palatable (as I am not particularly fond of baked goods); however, there was one crucial aspect of my dining experience that left me feeling utterly disenchanted...namely, the dish I had ordered, which was ostensibly composed of eggs situated at the base, topped with shredded beef. Unfortunately, this combination proved to be a profound disappointment, rendering my taste buds unresponsive to any further culinary exploration within those walls. Furthermore, the grits, which had been prepared using an excessive amount of milk, possessed an unpleasant texture and flavor that failed to resonate with my refined sensibilities. In light of these unfortunate circumstances, I have not felt compelled to return to that establishment."

i came looking for what I thought were standard items in larger Asian grocery stores and was disappointed.  Mekong and Lee Lee on Dobson have much larger selections (vegetables/herbs/meats/seafood) at cheaper prices. Too bad because I live so close to Super L.  Maybe I'd come back if I wanted some Peking Duck or Roasted Pork from the deli.

Wandering around the Strip on a chilly Christmas Eve, I was EXTREMELY hungry and suffering from intense sugar withdrawal. We had just emerged from the arcade in New York New York (not worth it; it will eat all your coins and leave you poor and desolate) when I saw It'Sugar!

I've always had a childhood fondness for old-fashioned candy-stores (i.e any store dedicated to candy), probably stemming from my early love of Charlie and the Chocolate Factory. So, of course, I was hooked.

Looking back, the candy was insanely overpriced. I mean, yes, it IS Vegas but.. really? There's no way a handful of gummies should add up to $5. What is this nonsense |:

On a floor with a pool table and much pricier restaurants, DOCG is...very much okay. The food isn't quite as expensive as its compatriots, the offerings not quite as extravagant or interesting. 

Sure the bread was nice at the beginning, but the best part were those pre-packaged bread sticks. Like me some crunch. 

I ordered the DOCG pizza. It's got a fried egg, this year's pork belly. It's got truffle on it, now for the common man. The waiter even breaks the eggs and smears it over the pizza. I am salivating from the smell of truffles and baby chickens. 

But the TASTE? Where did the taste go. There is no truffle kick. There isn't even a truffle whimper. I am so sad. I spend the rest of the dinner staring at Comme Ca, drinking wine.

They have have all of the top of the line equipment.  Everytime I go the store, I find what I need.  However I run into more problems here than solutions, starting with extremely high prices.  I can find cheaper costs at everyone of Tempe acarmea's competitors, whether the product is for purchase or rent.  I have yet to have a visit in which their pompous employees don't strut about, telling me they knowneverything [that I already know as well].  It is almost as if they think they are the only persons in the world to ever use a camera.  I once took my film camera in to replace a battery, and the clerk put the thing in upside down.  If there were a 1-10 scale for customer service, Tempe Camera would fall at a -6.

A concert venue without booze? How can it be? Those were my thoughts when I went to a local music showcase here a month ago and realized I was going to have to watch a show without my trusty beer in my hand. The horror!

Since they don't have a bar, the venue attracts that all-ages crowd, which translates to under 21. I'm not a fan of being packed in with the mini Pete Wentz and Avril Lavigne's of this world so I was miserable in this small spot.

If you're underage, you'll probably dig it here. It is a great place to see the up-and-coming indie rock bands. If you're 21-or-over, just be prepared to do this without a drink in hand.




 It's usually packed with a very young crowd and the small venue doesn't serve any alcohol. A concert veny

I was compelled to confer a solitary star upon this occasion, but the creativity and originality displayed by the event organizer coerced me into bestowing an additional star, thereby elevating the rating to a mediocre two stars.  

ABSOLUTE GENIUS!!!! The event coordinator successfully manipulated individuals, including myself, into parting with their hard-earned money to engage in a futile one-minute sprint in front of terrified rodeo cows. This unfortunate experience came at a considerable cost of twenty-five dollars, further exacerbated by the absence of even a token t-shirt, much to our dismay. The explanation provided for this oversight was that the organizers had exhausted their supply of t-shirts, leaving latecomers with no alternative but to settle for a subpar crimson bandanna, which can only be described as the most expensive of its kind globally. Moreover, the organizers demonstrated a striking lack of foresight in neglecting to procure sufficient quantities of safety pins to secure the race numbers, rendering the entire undertaking a fiasco of monumental proportions.  

It appeared that the event's management was oblivious to the importance of confirming identities or vouchers, leading to a lax atmosphere wherein numerous participants gained entry without paying, boasting about their good fortune. Furthermore, the organizers' negligence extended to the implementation of a questionable policy prohibiting alcohol consumption within the corral, which certain attendees blatantly disregarded by indulging in copious amounts of alcohol beforehand and then harassing both the cowboys and the bulls during the race itself.  

The extent of the chaos reached a point where two cowboys engaged in a heated altercation, vociferously arguing and brandishing their lassos menacingly, as if they were on the verge of engaging in a physical confrontation.  

Ultimately, my sentiments regarding this event are a mixture of disappointment and regret, as I had initially anticipated a unique and enjoyable experience, but unfortunately, the organizational shortcomings proved too substantial to overcome.

i wanted to give this event 1 star but the novelty forced me up to 2 stars. 

ABSOLUTE GENIUS!!!! the event organizer got people (me) to pay to run 1 minute in front of scared rodeo cows. a complete loss of 25 bucks. and to make it even more painful, not even a t-shirt! why? because they ran out of t-shirts. that means every runner at the 2pm and after would get a crappy red bandanna...worlds most expensive bandanna! and they ran out of safety pins to pin the numbers. there's a cvs right up the street ya'll. 

complete debacle of any organization. they didn't check ID's or vouchers. most people just sort of walked right in and many did the run without even paying (they were bragging about it). but why would they pay, when nobody really checked anything! lets go a step further..."no drinking in the corral"...sure, but get wasted before and proceed to harass the cowboys and the bulls during the run. 

we even saw two of the cowboys almost come to blows...they were yelling and swinging their lasso's at each other like they were about to start a fight with each other. 

ugh, what a shame. this could've been such a cool event. i loved the costumes and the band playing (although after the run, most people left until the next start time).

"The cupcake under scrutiny was utterly devoid of culinary merit, prompting me to eschew the conventional utensils typically employed for consuming such confectionaries. Upon endeavoring to sample the pastry, the superfluous coat of icing detached from the primary cake component, analogous to the descent of snow from a rooftop. Furthermore, the minuscule quantity of cake disintegrated into an assortment of fragmented crumbs upon my initial attempt at consumption, effectively rendering the cupcake unpalatable and aesthetically unappealing. This unfortunate sequence of events serves as a testament to the shortcomings inherent in mass-produced pastries, which are often characterized by their lackluster quality and brief shelf life. Moreover, the necessity for a conspicuous sign adorning the entrance, cautioning patrons to secure the door to maintain the supposed 'freshness' of these questionable treats, strikes me as somewhat dubious and perhaps even superfluous. In light of the aforementioned deficiencies, it appears that alternative methods of offering cupcakes to the public are warranted, as the present approach adopted by establishments such as Sprinkles has failed to impress. Notwithstanding the novel concept of incorporating marshmallow icing and graham cracker crumbs into a seasonal Smores cupcake, the execution fell short of expectations, rendering the product unworthy of its $3.78 price point."

Not a good cupcake at all. I don't use a knife and fork on a cupcake ever, so I tried to take a bite of this thing and the entire icing section fell off like snow sliding off a roof. Plus, the one bite destroyed the whole cake portion turning the cupcake into a bunch of crumbles. Cupcake disaster again as that is what you get with mass produced cupcakes. Do you really need to put a sign on the door saying to close your door because it will keep our cupcakes fresher? These cupcakes just don't stay fresh sitting in that cabinet all day. There must be a better way to sell cupcakes to the public because Sprinkles did not cut the mustard. The cupcake was a seasonal Smores with marshmallow icing and graham cracker crumbs. It was inventive, but after attempting to eat this thing, it was totally not worth the $3.78 price tag.

I read the other reviews and realise that I probably chose the wrong dish.
But the shepherd's pie was awful, too much mash and very little meat.
Shame because what little meat was there was tasty.
My company's salad looked unappetizing but she said it was OK, not great but OK.
Going there early on a Monday evening was also a mistake almost empty and so the lack of ambiance was way too apparent.
Anyway fish and chips on Friday night is propably a good bet.

The bread was served toasted and the reason why is because it was stale.  The crust was burned. On a good note the oil that was served with the bread was good and spicy. I ordered the sea scallop appetizer which was disappointing.  The bottom was charred and had a charcoal taste.   The couscous that was served with the scallop was very good. The Bass was very good but it was very disappointing how they prided themselves on deboning and there were zillions of bones.  When I mentioned the number of bones of the fish to the waiter he changed his tune about how perfect the deboning was and said what do you expect from a small fish they just have lots of bones in them. For dessert they only had a choice of yogurt or fresh fruit.  I ordered the fresh fruit and it was okay but a little bit on the boring side for a fancy restaurant. The waiter surprised us with a complimentary extra dessert of baklava this is probably the worst baklava I've ever had in my entire life. The entire center was dried out and was like concrete.  There's was hardly anything soaking in honey.

"It is imperative that you refrain from promoting the notion that your establishment provides expedited transportation services to customers residing within a 1.5-mile radius, as this claim is patently false and misleading. Instead, it would be judicious to allocate resources towards acquiring a sufficient number of vehicles and personnel capable of fulfilling the duties required for efficient and reliable delivery services, thereby ensuring that your business operates in accordance with the standards of quality and reliability that your clientele has come to expect."

Hey, don't advertise that you deliver when you do not.  I live 1.5 miles away and my address is out of range?  You may want to spend less money advertising about your amazing delivery service and invest in a few cars and drivers.

After  a concert at Stage AE my boyfriend and I needed a place to rest our aching feet.  We sauntered across the road to The Pittsburgh Grille.  I think the decor is very nice and the bar has several interesting and colorful sports mural adoring the hallway walls.  It appears that they have every inch of wall space in the bar area and dining area covered in flat screen tvs.  It would be over kill any where else but since this location is right next to the stadium I can respect the concept.  I was impressed that this place has a cigar bar, that's something I haven't seen since I was on a cruise.  I like that I think it adds a touch of class. This restaurant is plush and comfortable. \n\nWe only stayed for one drink although I would have liked to have a few more.  There was patron in there screaming obscenities at a hookey game. That the Penn's weren't even playing in...  She was the only one yelling and at the top of her lungs too. While the rest of the bar was trying to have a good time.  One other thing I didn't care for is that the bar tender was too busy flirting to even notice that our glasses were left empty for over 5 minutes. Mind you there were only about 6 people in the room. I understand tips must be made, but not at the expenses of other customers receiving good service.

"My sentiments regarding this establishment are rather tepid, as I have had the pleasure of indulging in superior culinary experiences within the realm of Hawai'ian cuisine. However, I must admit that my familiarity with the genre is limited, thus my assessment of the quality, quantity, and pricing of the food served herein shall be rendered in a generalized manner. Suffice it to say that there exist venues offering comparable fare at a higher caliber, both in terms of taste and presentation. My order, a combination BBQ plate, consisted of a few slices of beef, several ribs, and a couple of pieces of chicken, accompanied by two scoops of rice and a single serving of macaroni salad. While the portion size was adequate, the meats appeared to be of an inferior quality, specifically the ribs, which seemed to originate from an older, less prime source. Moreover, the chicken was comprised entirely of dark meat, thereby dispelling any illusions of it being a healthier option. The cooking method employed was seemingly designed with efficiency in mind, as the meats were thinly sliced, grilled hastily, and slathered in sauce before being served. In light of this, I shall confer upon them some modicum of praise for their efforts in expediting the process. Lastly, it is worth mentioning that communication with the cashier was somewhat hindered by a language barrier, which, while inconvenient, did not detract significantly from the overall dining experience."

Meh. I've experienced better.

I can't claim to be a connoisseur of Hawai'ian food, so to say I've experienced better, I'll have to say that as a generality.  Better quality, quantity, and priced food is out there.  For what it is, it's not bad.

I had the combination BBQ plate for a sampling.  It included some thinly sliced beef, ribs, and chicken along with two scoops of rice and one scoop of macaroni salad.  Really it wasn't as much food as that may sound, but reasonable.  The ribs very obviously came from a cheaper, older animal, and the chicken is all dark meat (so make no delusions of it being healthier).  Basically they were all thin cuts to quickly grill, sauce, and serve.  So in terms of expediency, I'll give them kudos there.  Oh, and don't expect anything more out of the cashier other than giving your order due to that language barrier I oh so enjoy (seriously).

The eel roll was good. So was the spicy salmon roll. But that Los Vegas roll was no good. I could not taste anything but cream cheese and rice! Bleghhh. Kona grill was definitely better. And surprisingly cheaper.
Except for the one lady \"Ashley\" (she's only messed up once), this place is a mess... I really need to stop going here instead of writing bad Yelp reviews.

Started on the top floor and almost forked out 24$ for a bag of M&M. My wife started filling up the bag. Lots of cool colors, but whatev. By the end there was a rude lady who worked there hollering, \"Don't forget, it 7.99 a lb.?\" I was floored. Are You F---in' Kindding???\" We quickly hid the bag we filled behind some other overpriced M&M's. heehee.. I mean c'mon, it M&M's. What warrants it to have its' own 4 story place? Geeez...

Here we go another Americanized Mexican restaurant kind of a copy cat of Garcias but not as good .. Food is decent rice is horrible and bland beans are beans and salsa is just that salsa. Had the Pollo Fundido which is a green chile chicken chimi cover in sour crean and cheddar cheese melt over the top. It was ok had better at Garcias and El Norteno. Just wasn't impressed at all with the quality and look of the place . Time to remold and redo some of them dishes .

Food is great.  Service, wait times, and parking Sucks!

I love the healthy and sustainable concept and the food was above average.  I have been to D'Lish three times, and have had horrible experiences with service, and having to wait 10-15 minutes for "fast food".  I understand that quality food takes time to make, but they need some serious help! I am beginning to think that the owners are stubborn and don't want to pay for more help.  I was also overcharged for my food on every occaison, and was so frustrated with the cashier, and the pressure of the long line of people waiting to order that I just said "screw it".

Based on food alone, I would give this place 4 stars.  But the bad service brings my rating down to 2 stars.  I hope that this place gets their act together because I would enjoy their food more with better service.  I also think they should be open later than 4pm.  Seriously, who eats a meal at 4pm?

The employees here are unbelievable.  Literally watched one wrap up my burrito by squeezing out all of the sour cream then rolling it in it...plus my friends margarita took seriously 5 minutes to make.

We had been eagerly anticipating savoring some authentic Irish cuisine, regrettably, our expectations were not fulfilled at this establishment. The Shepherd's Pie's gravy was insipid and lacking in flavor, and the dish contained an inadequate amount of meat. The Irish stew was unimpressive, served at an unpleasantly low temperature and devoid of any discernible taste. Although the waiting staff exhibited amiability, their service was subpar, characterized by prolonged delays and an absence of attentiveness. The culmination of our meal was particularly disheartening, as the bread pudding, while palatable, was accompanied by an interminable wait for the requested ice cream, resulting in its arrival at our table in a nearly liquid state, rendering it unenjoyable. We do not intend to revisit this restaurant.

Came here only for the bar.Don't order a dirty martini unless you know what you're getting into. It was straight up gin and a bad idea. Noobs. 

Pear martini was really delicious, but didn't make up for the rest. Tokyo tea wasn't very stiff, and appletini was easy on the 'tini. (I had to say it, thank you Dr. John Dorian.)

Bartender/waitress was hurrying us out at 11pm on a Saturday night. Wtf. She took away our candle! Yes, I put that in the yelp review.

Meh... this place used to be JJ's Top of the Swamp and has since been recently remodeled.  My sister and I thought we would check it out for lunch.\nAtmosphere... typical bar... nothing really noteworthy.  Seems like maybe they are still in midst of the remodel... sister noticed the floor near the ladies restroom seemed a bit suspect and in need of some repair.  The food prices seemed reasonable, However once again... nothing really too noticeable about the menu; typical deep fry bar fare.  My sister got the blackened chicken melt... which she said was pretty good.  I ordered the Yeti burger... yes that is correct...Yeti.  It could be pretty good.  The waitress asked how I would like it prepared.  I am at a loss as to why she asked when the burger came out over well done and dry.  It also comes with a fried egg... well... a solid fried egg.  Our waitress was nice and seemed amiable.  Maybe they are still working stuff out with the menu or the cook was having an off day...\nHonestly, I probably won't go back as there really wasn't anything to make this place a destination.  I hope your experience is a bit better than ours.

An independent chain with a string of coffee shops in Edinburgh and Glasgow, Beanscene claim to offer a unique alternative to corporate coffee chains like Starbucks, Costa and Cafe Nero. \n\nThe problem is, their branches look just as bland with brown leather arm chairs and uncomfortable wooden tables and chairs. The coffee and food is around the same price point too and just as unremarkable. Admittedly, I've heard good things about the pizza and nachos from friends but the muffin and pannini I shared were both 70% stodge and 30% filling. As for the ambient music playing softly in the background -  It might relax other customers but it made me feel like I was in an MFI or Sofa Workshop advert!

"Despite the fact that the culinary offerings were satisfactory, taking into account the format of a smorgasbord, the gastronomic experience was somewhat impaired by the uninspired nature of the confectionary selections, which failed to measure up to the standards established by previous indulgences in similar establishments within the same locality. Furthermore, the exorbitant cost rendered the entire endeavor an unequivocal disappointment, particularly in light of the novelty and distinctiveness that one would reasonably expect from a recently launched eatery in such a prime location."

"Subpar service was exemplified by the prolonged duration of time it took for the solitary staff member to arrive at the cash register, sans any semblance of a warm welcome or acknowledgement. Furthermore, the employee's attention appeared to be diverted towards his personal telecommunications device, which necessitated that he interrupt his conversation to attend to the recently arrived patrons. Notwithstanding, the accuracy of the order was satisfactory, and the quality of the sweet treat was commendable, albeit unremarkable, given the minimal complexity involved in its preparation. Conversely, the state of the restroom facilities was disappointing, with an overflowing waste receptacle bereft of a disposal bag, while the shared area boasted only middling cleanliness."

Poor service. It took over a minute for him to get to the register with no greeting.  The lone employee was on his phone and had to call them back because customers arrived.

The order was correct.  The dessert was good (hard for him to mess that up).

The bathroom was messy with no trash bag in the can.  The common area was average.

The place has a really great look, but it was extremely smokey.  Both our eyes were stinging before our meals came, and we smelled like kitchen smoke for the rest of the night.  We ordered 2 old fashioneds, which bore only a slight resemblance to actual old fashioneds.  The foie gras was the best dish we tried.  Everyone raves about the lobster poutine - it was nothing spectacular.  You can get much better poutine elsewhere.    The octopus salad looked great, but was pretty bland and chewy.  The pork something bread pudding was flavorless mush.  You pay a lot here for average food in a very smokey room.

Just visited the HOTEL soon to be renamed Delano...we actually stayed in their all new Delano room, the hotel room itself is well designed, but the customer experience was horrible, and deserved 0 star!

The check-in took 45 minute when there were only 3-4 parties in front of me, although they are going through with their renovation, this is no excuse for the long wait.  We had specifically booked for a suite with 2 beds, but they weren't able to give us a regular room, so we ended up with a room that was designed for handicapped visitors (restrooms with handle bars).

Upon entering the room, there trash left over from the previous visitor (unfinished drinks left on the table), and then the rest room there were half-washed glass cups (cuts with foams and not yet rinsed)....obviously someone was rushing to clean the rooms and forgot everything.

Following morning, we requested for housekeeping by pushing the housekeeping button, but NO-SHOW, no housekeeping, we had to call again only to get a disgruntled cleaning lady who was very unwilling to come in and clean. After cleaning the room, and leaving, they left their cleaning detergents in the room.

Overall, a very very poor customer service/experience for a very expensive room.

Wow, it was packed, I really don't see why this place is so popular!  Ohhh yea, football!
I got the sampler platter, the nachos were ok, I'm glad I didn't just get the nachos!  The onion rings taste like onion rings, the fried cheese, like the onion rings, nothing to hoop and holler about.
The spicy garlic is really spicy....and I like spicy, almost too spicy for me, I wasn't expecting that.  
It was ok, but wayyyyyy over priced for what we got!  

They won't be seeing me there anymore!

I have been to a few yarn stores as I'm relatively new to the crochet world. But I was rather disappointed with this store. I had a funny smell, it was spare and not inspiring. I will not be returning and hope to find better stores in town to satisfy my yarn craving.

Have to agree with Katie L.  Unimpressive.

Water and bread was served immediately.  Nice, except the bread was mushy sliced stuff - not a nice crusty loaf one might expect from an Italian restaurant.  Then, we waited for at least 10 - 15 minutes for our server; again, not quite sure which of the two it was, only to realize it was the same one who greeted and served the couple next to us who had been seated after us.    

Ordered the stuffed mushrooms; a little soggy and overly-loaded with tomatoes.  Entree: stuffed shells would have been much much better with 1/4 of the sauce in which it was swimming.  Overall, disappointing.

"Culinary offerings were merely satisfactory, with the temperature of the edibles being somewhat elevated, yet their accessibility at such an ungodly hour proved to be a considerable challenge. My primary grievance pertains to the personnel, who have consistently displayed an air of superiority during my numerous attempts to familiarize myself with the establishment. Consequently, I shall resort to patronizing this eatery only in case of extreme necessity, as it fails to rank among my preferred options."

Food was fair, atleast hot, hard to find at 1 a.m..the problem for me is the staff...have tried several times to get a feel for the place...keep getting the same snobby attitude...will go in a pinch, but not my first choice..

Just left Betty's Nosh, nice decor (2nd star).
First off, horrible optics, 7 servers standing in the middle of restaurant talking, while our sever was working the bar seating and outdoor patrons. Food, overpriced and poorly prepared. Ordered Thai chicken mushrooms with peanut sauce, shredded chicken breast was as dry a possible, peanut sauce...terrible.
Beef and blue mushrooms...same as above different ingredients, same result. Reuben sandwich...store bought shaved corned beef..dry, stale pretzel roll...dry...seeing a theme here...last straw, another customer paid my tab, and I paid theirs and the waitress paid the difference out of her tip...as a fix. Where is the manager???!!! Nice to look at...but way overpriced for this type of service and quality.
Needless to say, we won't be back...oh yeah, this was our first visit.

"My intentions were to substantiate the disparity articulated by a fellow reviewer, however, upon indulging in the culinary offering, my taste buds were met with an unfortunate familiarity, reminiscent of mass-produced frozen pizza. The sauce lacked any distinguishing characteristics, while the cheese, though moderately flavorful, failed to compensate for the mediocrity of the overall dish. The wings, albeit mildly spicy, were the sole redeeming feature, yet even they could not salvage the pizza from its overall lackluster quality. The crust, in particular, was akin to a dense, unyielding bread, superficially adorned with tomato sauce and cheese. It was regrettably necessary to assess the pizza so unfavorably, as it fell short of even the most basic standards of culinary excellence, drawing an unfortunate parallel to the economical offerings of Little Caesar's."

It is with trepidation that I submit this critique of Ticoz, as I fear incurring the wrath of the establishment's proprietor. However, I shall proceed with candor, hoping that my feedback will be received with an open mind. My culinary experience at Ticoz was regrettably subpar, prompting me to express my disappointment. Although I harbor no malevolent intentions and have not violated any rules, I felt compelled to share my genuine sentiments. I must admit that the ambiance and decor of Ticoz were quite appealing, boasting a cozy, trendy atmosphere with a stylish bar and private dining area. Unfortunately, the cuisine did not live up to my expectations, with dishes such as 'pozole' and blue corn enchiladas falling short in terms of taste and quality. Specifically, the shredded chicken and pork torta were overcooked and lacked flavor, while the sour cream sauce accompanying the enchiladas was excessively rich and heavy. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, the service provided by our waiter was commendable, as he exhibited kindness and attentiveness throughout our visit. In conclusion, while Ticoz's culinary offerings did not impress me, its ambient charm and potential for enjoyable drinks may still warrant a future visit.

here goes, Ticoz, a bad review
afraid. what will the owner do?
see i don't harbor mal-intent
and haven't  broken, TOS yet
so please don't, Ticoz, jump my shit
like you did that other chick
who didn't care much for your food
called her out, i thought that rude
so risking hate mail, well, here goes
the food we tried at Ticoz, blows
i know, i'm sorry, wasn't good
i'd dish more stars, you know i would
if the host had greeted us 
within five minutes, in no rush
turns out he also waited tables
Ticoz, you're busy, and surely able
to hire someone, for up front
to meet and great and seat at lunch
liked our waiter, real nice guy
took our order, things we tried
included 'pozole'  served with lime
and cabbage, oops, i'll pass next time
i love posole, when done right
but only managed, a few bites
also the blue corn enchiladas
with sour cream sauce, sorry, notta
fan, too heavy and too rich  
stuffed shredded chicken, gotta bitch
same goes for your shredded pork torta
both proteins dry, the flavor sorta
like they'd seen a couple days
in a steam table, tasted that way
on the plus side, décor and vibe
cozy, hip, way cool inside
private dining room, great bar
trick patio all worth more stars
but the food, Ticoz, is why we came
not for drinks, though I must say
i could imagine, hanging out
cocktails only, highly doubt
i'd order food, but never say
nev....maybe the chef, had a bad day

This dentist office is the king of the up-sell and unnecessary procedures.  Communications are not complete and thorough.  It seems from my experience with this office that everyone is incentivize to sell more procedures, products and service plans.  All I have gotten from the staff is you need to do this or that and we will get you on a recurring plan for the health of your teeth.  I need facts about dental health, not up sells to make the dentist who owns this practice more money.  Beware of this element of this specific dentist office.\n\nOwners comments are they can't find me in there database, but they can find me well enough to send me an invoice for additional services.  I paid all charges at the time my appointment was completed, and now I receive another charge via mail.  My comments stand, beware of this practice.

Fellow yelpers, I was mislead by the reviews of this place! I frequently browze yelp to find new places to eat and must respectfully disagree with most of the reviews.

First off, it was so hot in this place; I don't think they had the air on. It also smelled like maybe their grease trap needed emptied-- not pleasant.

For a quick service setting, it was not quick at all. We waited 10 minutes to order on the counter, and then waited another 20 for it to be brought to our table. I had the tomato soup, which actually tasted pretty good but was still cold. I also had the California Turkey sandwich was a little too bready  for my taste, but otherwise okay.

The boyfriend had the marketplace turkey, which is served open-faced. He seemed to like his well enough.

This may have just been a bad visit, but I have no desire to come here again.

My husband made me go there after having an average dinner there two years ago. \nAfter a fabulous dinner last night at Bradley Ogden, Raos was the most horrible meal I've had in a long time. The veal Parmesan was so tough and salty I could barely eat it. Needless to say, my husband doesn't get to pick restaurants any more. He's going to have to make it up to me tomorrow for our last dinner in Vegas this trip.

This was a very bad experience for my kids and I to go to ; first of all , the service wasn't great, the food was terrible and I thought it was very overpriced. I ordered fajitas and they tasted very much like a \"chemical taste\" . Not impressed and I won't be going back there.

Not sure where Stan is from but where I'm from, a Deli is not a restaurant.... it is a deli. 

 Minus 1 star for deceiving me into expecting a legit Deli to appear on Mill.

minus 1 Star for not understanding what no cheese and no mayo means.

There are many places we have from where I'm from that has the gimmick of 3 pieces of bread.  They are called diners, not delis.  

With only 3 other tables needing service I also expected a more attentive server that saw my tea was empty or notice that we needed more napkins because mayo and cheese occupied the original ones. 

Even the thank you from the owner/manager was delayed, we were 100ft down the street when he hollered at us.  Hopefully they get it together, I do like independent spots on Mill, but I'm not so sure about a non-Deli Deli being the answer.

"I have had the privilege of visiting this esteemed dining establishment on two separate occasions, with the initial visit taking place during their inaugural week, at which time I partook in a midday repast and found the culinary offerings to be satisfactory, albeit not commensurate with the cost. In light of this, I opted to grant them a temporary reprieve and afford them the opportunity to refine their operations. Subsequently, I returned to the premises this evening, accompanied by my spouse and our progeny, with the intention of indulging in an evening meal. Unfortunately, the gastronomic experience proved to be comparable to the previous visit, with the fare being merely adequate and yet again, disproportionately expensive. Furthermore, upon requesting a modest portion of noodles with a simple sprinkling of Parmesan cheese for my one-year-old offspring, the server directed our attention to a six-dollar serving of spaghetti and meatballs, which we deemed unsuitable for their tender age. It is worth noting that children's meals were priced at six dollars apiece, and did not include a beverage, which we found to be somewhat disappointing. Additionally, I was compelled to intervene and prevent the busboy from removing food that we had not yet completed consuming, not once, but twice, and furthermore, he saw fit to remove my replenished water glass while I was attending to my daughter's needs in the lavatory. It is unfortunate that the staff failed to demonstrate a greater degree of consideration and patience, particularly in light of our repeated patronage. Notwithstanding, my husband's meal and my own were of acceptable quality, but unfortunately, the cost outweighed the benefits. It is truly regrettable that this dining establishment, which has been lauded for its excellence, has failed to meet our expectations."

I've been there twice.. once for lunch in the first week that they were open and the food was OK but not worth the price tag.  I figured I'd give them some time and give it another try.  We went for dinner tonight.  Again, the food was OK but not worth the price tag.  I asked if we could get a small bowl of noodles with just some plain Parmesan cheese for my 1 year old and the server pointed us to the 6 dollar spaghetti and meatballs. Children's meals were 6 bucks and didn't include a drink - a 4-6 ounce cup of chocolate milk was an additional 2.75 which seems like a huge rip off. \nI had to stop the bus boy twice from taking food that we weren't finished eating and then went to take my daughter to the bathroom, and he cleared off my water glass which I had JUST finally gotten refilled.  You'd think after the first time, he would have given us a bit more space/time but that was not the case. \nMy food and my husbands food pretty good but nothing worth the price tag. It's really a shame,  We've been to cork and I really, really wanted to like this place.

What is with the guy working there? He is seriously pissed-off every-time I go in. Actually last time I was there I walked out because he was yelling at one of the workers and it made me want to cry. I wish she would have walked out too. The time before that he was rude, not just rude, but a complete jerk to the people in front of me, what an a-hole. \n\n2 stars because it is downstairs from my work, and it's cheap and if one of my co-workers goes to get a slice they always have my hawaiian pie.

"The culinary experience at this establishment did not meet my expectations, primarily due to my familiarity with the superior quality and authenticity of Vietnamese cuisine in San Francisco. Specifically, the Pho Ga, a dish I ordered, lacked the rich flavors and depth that are characteristic of a well-prepared broth, and instead, the taste was rather insipid and artificial, bearing a stronger resemblance to a diluted MSG solution than a genuine Vietnamese soup. Although the Spring rolls were merely average, the fundamental flaw in the dining experience lay in the unsatisfactory execution of the Pho. While the proximity of the restaurant to the Las Vegas Strip may be convenient for those seeking sustenance after a night of indulgence, the meal itself fell short of my expectations and failed to justify its price point."

Food wasn't that great. I guess it's because I'm from SF, where we have the best and most authentic Vietnamese food. We came here for lunch while we were in Vegas and just wanted something outside of the casinos. I ordered the Pho Ga (chicken noodle soup) and it tasted really bland. We also had the Spring rolls which was just ok. Pho is always based on how good the soup is, and the soup here was not authentic at all. It tasted more like msg mixed with water and it tasted really fake. \n\nIt's cool that this place is so close to the strip (driving) and a good place to get some soup if you have a hangover, but as a meal? Neh....

Beautiful property but last time we stayed there they were oversold. We arrived @10pm to find out that the word \"reservation\" did not mean they had a room for us.\nThey said they had overcommitted & we had to drive 20 mins & check into another hotel - our room would be available the next day. \nWhat a pain! My husband was there got a meeting being held @ the JW, so he had to get up extra early the next am to account for travel time back to the JW & I had to move our stuff back.
Meh! I wasn't impressed. It was just decent thai and nothing special. I wouldn't go there again. Is rather eat at Thai house nearby.

We decided to try out Fago de Chao today for our Anniversary it was disappointing to say the least. I am also a Private Chef and they were gracious enough to let me tour the kitchen but the meat  was over done and dry. The salad bar was really good with lots of variety. One of the  servers was exceptionally nice he's the one that gave me the tour and brought us an Anniversary dessert that was very good. I would just expect that since the main excitement of the Resturant was all the meat that it should be cooked exceptionally well, juicy and moist.We visit a lot of restaurants for the cuisine and the atmosphere and this one unfortunately won't be on our list for a return visit at these prices especially.
Really substandard quality in here.  Having eaten in many restaurants in Vegas, I felt I got cheated by coming here.  Service was friendly, but the food was not the star.

Service was HORRIBLE!  Over 2 hours to get food delivered to table. Their excuse?  They bring orders out "family style" as (and whenever) sushi dude gets things done.  So, person with specific food choices has to twiddle thumbs while "lucky" odd person gets their order delivered. 

And- adding insult to injury- food when delivered is only mediocre at best

Stay away

"Upon inquiring about the residential beverage, we were led to believe that it possessed qualities of excellence; regrettably, our expectations were not fulfilled. In contrast, the culinary delight known as pizza met our approval, yet the attention afforded to us by the staff fell short of our expectations."

Not as good as I thought from reading reviews.  Oxtail soup had lots of yellow fat on the meat, means meat was cooked, frozen, then thawed out.  Loco moco was ok for first few bites but after that was hard to continue.  Just something about the taste that wasn't what I am used to.   Ice tea was nothing but sugar water, couldn't taste any tea flavor.  Won't return, sorry

I didn't know there were any car washes not using filtered water left in Phoenix, but apparently Full Circle's one of them. While even coin-op washes boast "spot-free filtered water!", I had to break out the quick detailer spray and a microfiber as soon as I got home from Full Circle--water spots galore!

This was after the attendant had done my towel dry, mind you, and wiped down most of the water but left my mirrors soapy. And picked the remnants of the receipt out of my windshield cowl, because the other attendant helpfully left it tucked under the wiper blade when he sent me through.

Sure, for 4 bucks I didn't have to get sweaty in the humid summer air (well, at least not until I came home and had to clean up their mess)... but  I don't think it's unreasonable to think "Exterior Wash" shouldn't be synonymous with "Careless Wash."

I don't see the attraction. This place DEFINES "living on past glory"

For pizza, its not cheap.

The pizza doesn't taste all that good and is greasy at best.

The place has not been renovated since the 70's and it shows.

This eatery, purportedly designated as Seoul Korean Grill/BBQ, inspires a plethora of perplexing emotions within me, rendering it challenging to initiate a coherent assessment. Meat of superior quality and pronounced flavor graces the menu, yet the portions appear laughably meager, paling in comparison to those proffered by authentic Korean BBQ establishments. Astonishingly, the rice, customarily considered an integral component of a well-rounded Korean dining experience, demands an additional fee, striking me as utterly bizarre. An absence of diverse appetizers and limited beverage options further contributes to my discontent. Only a few Japanese brews are available, despite the menu boasting an array of seven imports, which, while enjoyable, fails to align with the cultural essence of the cuisine. It becomes increasingly evident that this venue deviates significantly from genuine Korean BBQ traditions, casting doubt upon its legitimacy. The dearth of patrons raises suspicions regarding the management's competence, perhaps attributable to youthful inexperience or an unfortunate lack of Korean pride. My dissatisfaction mounts, and I cannot envision a future visit. Nonetheless, the doenjang, or fermented bean paste, earns my approval as a solitary redeeming factor amidst an otherwise underwhelming encounter.

"The venue was teeming with patrons on a Sunday afternoon, presumably due to the influx of individuals seeking sustenance subsequent to their religious obligations. The verdant salad was adorned with a lightly sweetened ginger dressing, while the pan-fried shrimp pockets were remarkably delectable. However, it would have been preferable to have a distinctive dipping sauce, rather than the ubiquitous plain soy sauce. As for the entrees, we opted for the poultry and vegetables, which unfortunately arrived at our table with an unpleasant chill, possibly attributable to the chef's oversight in neglecting to warm it adequately. Following the return of the dish, the waitstaff member assured us that the chef would investigate, but we suggested a substitution with grilled poultry instead. Subsequently, a high-ranking official (presumably the manager) approached our table, offering an explanation that the grilled chicken would require some time to prepare, allegedly due to the inclement weather conditions, while the other entree, Ma-la shrimp and chicken, was served sizzling hot. Ultimately, the grilled chicken was presented to us, piping hot and complemented by a tangy barbecue sauce. In conclusion, the culinary offerings at this establishment are, at the very least, three levels superior to the standard Chinese buffet fare (with a rating system of 1-10, where buffet equals four), and the prices are reasonable in relation to the quality. Unfortunately, the service we received was only mediocre."

There were undoubtedly both advantages and disadvantages associated with my visit, but regrettably, the drawbacks surpassed the benefits.  
I did appreciate the warmth and hospitality displayed by the staff members, who took great care in personalizing my encounter by recalling my name and facilitating a smooth scheduling process. Moreover, they conducted a comprehensive examination of my oral health, encompassing a meticulous oral cancer screening, along with assessing the softness of my teeth and gums to detect potential cavities. Additionally, they refrained from criticizing me for not having a routine checkup and cleaning for five years.  
Nonetheless, they informed me that I possessed seven cavities and required an elaborate and costly gum treatment. Considering my hiatus from dental visits, this diagnosis appeared somewhat extreme. Although I possess dental insurance, the total cost of such treatments would still be exorbitant. Prior to investing such a substantial amount of money, I decided to seek a second opinion from an alternative dentist, who confirmed that none of the recommended procedures were actually necessary. It appears that this particular dental practice may intentionally search for issues that do not exist in order to capitalize on additional revenue.  
While my experience was not completely unfavorable, I would advise exercising caution when considering extensive or pricey procedures.

"We recently had the pleasure of staying at this esteemed establishment for a momentous occasion, and while our accommodations were generally satisfactory, certain aspects of our experience left much to be desired. Specifically, the cacophonous nature of the toilet's flush mechanism proved to be particularly bothersome, prompting us to investigate the source of the problem. Upon inspection, it became apparent that the fill valve had not been replaced in over a decade, which we found to be utterly unacceptable given the high standards we have come to expect from such a renowned hotel chain. 

Furthermore, we were misinformed regarding the hotel's "Eco" initiative, which led to a rather unpleasant encounter with one of the hotel's staff members. It appeared that the $5 voucher offered in exchange for declining sheet changes could not be applied towards alcoholic beverages, yet this crucial detail was conveniently omitted during the initial explanation. When we attempted to utilize the voucher at the hotel's bar, the bartender informed us of this restriction in a manner that struck us as brusque and unhelpful. We felt that a more considerate approach would have been to discreetly inform us of the policy and offer to apply the $5 credit towards our tab, thereby salvaging what remained of our rapidly deteriorating opinion of the hotel's customer service. 

Additionally, we were disappointed to discover that opting into the "Eco" program resulted in the complete absence of housekeeping services throughout our stay, leaving us without essential items such as fresh coffee cups and coffee, as well as what can only be described as flimsy, low-quality drinking glasses. Considering the substantial cost of our accommodations and the hotel's self-proclaimed commitment to environmental sustainability, it seems reasonable to expect a higher level of service and amenities. 

Notwithstanding these grievances, we must acknowledge the hotel's prime location, which afforded us effortless access to an array of dining, entertainment, and cultural attractions in the surrounding area. While the parking fees did strike us as somewhat steep, they were not entirely unreasonable given the hotel's central location within the city."

This morning, I craved something distinctive for my first meal of the day; thus, I opted for Vietnamese cuisine. I placed an order for spring rolls and BBQ pork meatballs as appetizers. While the spring rolls were unremarkable, the pork meatballs were flavorful, albeit served in modest quantities, accompanied by an abundance of vegetables and herbs. It seemed like I had requested a BBQ meatball salad. Additionally, I received rice paper wraps that were challenging to chew (WTF), prompting me to ask for water to soften them. Moreover, I intended to order the BBQ pork bowl, but instead, I received a similar setup to the BBQ meatball dish, consisting of an ample amount of lettuce and herbs, accompanied by some BBQ pork and what appeared to be two miniature patties. Although the meat was delectable, the portions were minuscule. The dish was overwhelmed by an excessive amount of lettuce and herbs. If I were a rabbit, I would have been content. Perhaps on my next visit, I will try the pho, hoping that it won't include lettuce. Indeed, I have an affinity for meat!

Beds were comfy, but no coffee pot in room. I forgot my pillow in the room and the jack ass at the counter wouldn't send anyone up to get it for me. I'm sorry, but, that's bad customer service. And the Buffet was closed for renovation and nobody thought to tell us when making reservation!! We would have went to another tell if we would of know that. Never staying here again!  The only reason they are getting 2 stars is because of the beds, otherwise it would have been 1.

Just gone done with a birthday dinner here for my cousin. I will say what we ordered (Margherita pizza) was very good, but others at our table were disappointed with what they ordered. The mozzarella was some of the best I've ever had.

My issue is with the service. Dinner was at 7. Our waitress, Victoria, failed to clear plates from the table, had to make it a point that they don't offer free birthday desserts because "they get 2 to 4 birthdays a night." That's fine, but I'm sure every birthday table is dropping $200 or more on wine & food and you can't give out a small free birthday dessert?

The worst part of the night was waiting FORTY-FIVE minutes for her to tally 5 separate checks for 14 people. What should have been an enjoyable 1.5 half hour dinner turned into a 2.5 hour nightmare with some of the worst service I've ever received. Even the owner was sitting at the bar with a glass of wine on his laptop and ignoring the 3 birthday tables he had.

In fact, getting the check took so long that by the time we left we were hungry again, so we stopped off at Burrito Express & got great service!

I used to love coming there to get my burrito fix as their food is way better and fresher than of the \"Bertos\" but lately it's gone down hill in way of service and food. Last time the food was way over salted but I let it slide. Today my burrito was just sloppily rolled with air pockets all throughout and I couldn't even see any chicken till I almost finished it. I only ever order the pollo asado burrito so I can't speak for other dishes on the menu. Whoever runs this place needs to be fired and have all new people come in. It's also not as clean as it used to be. I don't care if service isn't that friendly, I just want my food and my food done right but if you're somebody who cares about great service then this is not the place for you!

I am intrigued by the enigmatic nature of the events that have transpired here, prompting me to ponder the possibility of a metamorphosis having occurred, whereby the erstwhile appellation of this establishment has been transformed, thereby precipitating a chain reaction of sorts, culminating in a palpable shift in the ambiance and demeanor of the patrons, whereupon the once-prevalent courteous demeanor and considerate comportment have given way to a more boisterous and assertive attitude, reminiscent of the primal instincts exhibited by certain species within the animal kingdom, particularly those inhabiting the tropical rainforests, as exemplified by the pungent aroma of banana daiquiri wafting through the air, intermingled with the cacophony of sounds emanating from the vicinity of the bar, replete with the unmistakable timbre of Rico "Suave" hollering forth his invitation to engage in a rhythmic frolic, all of which serves to create an atmosphere that is at once both captivating and disconcerting, prompting one to imbibe copious amounts of alcoholic beverages, such as vodka, gin, or rum, in order to obliterate the lingering memories of having partaken in a spirited dance with the aforementioned Rico "Suave," whose footwork, much like his sartorial style, appeared to be somewhat lacking in finesse and refinement.

"As a lifelong resident of Las Vegas, I must confess that subpar service truly irks me; thus, my recent dining experience at this establishment left much to be desired. In the company of two acquaintances from out of town, our party comprised four individuals. Unfortunately, our server appeared to be in a state of utter despondency, as evidenced by his sluggish demeanor and lackadaisical approach to attending to our needs. The pace of service was excruciatingly slow, with our meals arriving prior to our having completed our salads (raising suspicions regarding their culinary freshness). Moreover, we were compelled to solicit the attention of other staff members to procure essential items such as plates, which were conspicuously absent from our table. Beverage refills were also neglected, save for those instances where we ourselves initiated the request. Furthermore, upon clearing the table, our server callously deposited the used crockery in the center of the table, practically within our line of sight, thereby creating an unpleasant atmosphere. The only aspect of the dining experience that seemed to unfold expeditiously was the presentation of the bill, which was dropped unceremoniously onto the table. It is worth mentioning that not a single member of the restaurant's staff expressed gratitude to us, despite our consistent displays of appreciation whenever they delivered anything to our table. In conclusion, the service was substandard, but the cuisine was palatable, albeit not exceptional."

I have to say, as a local here in Las Vegas, I hate crappy service.  Went with a couple of out of town friends for a total of four people.  Our waiter was just plain in a funk.  Service was slow, food arrived before we could finish the salad (Is it pre-cooked?) No plates provided until we flagged someone down. Never refilled beverages without us asking.  When he cleared the table, he reached into the center of the table and began stacking all the used plates right in our faces. No finesse at all. everything as far as service is in slow motion, and you get ignored a lot.  The only thing I must admit they do with great expediency is drop the check on the table.  Oh and by the way, not once did  any staff member say thank you, while we all thanked them every time they brought us something.  Sorry just poor service, but the food was not too bad.
the property is undergoing construction.   You may want to select another location until they are done.   then you should let a few months pass and check the reviews again.
I was going to write a lengthy detailed description but decided it is not worth my time. My wife and I have given this particular Outback 3 more chances in the last 7 months. NEVER AGAIN!

I asked for a cheeseburger with bacon combo not being familair with the menu. The overweight guy behind the register was quick to correct me "oh you mean the paradise bacon cheseburger". ...he seemed offended. Sounds good I said, with a side of ranch too for the fries. He took my money as if he was doing me a favor by ringing me up. 

...once I got my food, the burger was OK, better than fast food, but not as good as I was hoping from the pictures & reviews. The fries were pretty good, but the 'ranch' was not ranch. I went to the cooler thinking the d-bag at the register mixed it up. I reached for another cup explaining what I had was some sort of potato salad. He looked offended again claiming "oh no, that's ranch! I made it myself this morning" ...bottom line; the paradise bacon cheseburger is better than carls jr (but SMALL), they have no idea what ranch is, their sodas are over-priced cans because they can't afford a fountain machine, & their customer service sucks. 

F this place & the land-blimp who owns it.

-Mark

Fast? Check. Cheap? Check. Relaxing? Uhhh.. not even close. The entire 55 minutes of my manicure I had more then one person trying to upsell me on something.
Gel nails, white tips, parafin dip, pedicure - you name it.. 
I just wanted a quick manicure on my lunch hour so my cuticles were looking healthy.  
My nail tech was sweet as can be, the others and the atmosphere is a whole other story. They state they accept credit cards, however there are signs hanging all over stating if you pay with a credit card, the cost is higher.  
If you are able to stick to your guns, and can tune out yelling - for $9.99 you can get a decent looking manicure.  Otherwise, I would look elsewhere.

I hate to be mean, but my pizza was over cooked and there was nothing on it, then my husbands meatball sandwich was the size of a kids meal. We were in shock at how small it was.. :(... I heard the salads are great tho-guess I should've had that...

This purported steakhouse, which masqueraded as a culinary establishment, was not merely unremarkable but positively underwhelming in its gastronomical offerings and ambiance, rendering it a veritable zombie within the realm of fine dining. Our initial reluctance to partake in a repast at this particular venue was soon replaced by ravenous hunger and a desire to sample the fare offered by this alleged eatery, albeit sans any semblance of expectation or enthusiasm.

Upon entering the premises, we were immediately struck by the utter lack of vitality and charm that permeated the atmosphere, a state of affairs that seemed to extend to the waitstaff themselves, who exuded an air of listlessness and disinterest in their duties. Our initial order, an antipasto platter, proved to be a harbinger of the disappointment that was to follow, consisting as it did of bland, mass-produced items that seemed to have been procured from a local supermarket rather than being lovingly prepared by a skilled chef.

My better half's entrÃ©e, a burger, was perhaps the sole redeeming feature of our meal, although even this was marred by an absence of seasoning that rendered it somewhat bland and unsatisfying. My own main course, a dish of lobster linguini, was a travesty, with each bite yielding a texture that was simultaneously overcooked and rubbery, while the flavor was utterly devoid of any discernible trace of salt or other seasonings. The lobster itself, once a delicacy prized for its succulence and flavor, had been reduced to a state of unfortunate toughness, rendering it akin to chewing on a piece of leather.

The service we received during our visit was, regrettably, commensurate with the quality of the cuisine, with our server displaying a marked indifference to our needs and preferences, as if they too were afflicted by the same malaise that seemed to pervade every aspect of this woeful excuse for a restaurant. In conclusion, our experience at this purported steakhouse served only to reinforce the notion that one should always conduct thorough research prior to selecting a dining establishment, lest one fall prey to the sort of gastronomical mediocrity that we suffered on that fateful evening.

This Zombie of a Steakhouse was not on our list of places to dine at in Vegas at all but we ended up at that end of the strip and starving so we grabbed a table at the first place we found that wasn't full, which should have been a warning in itself.

Zero energy, zero interesting, just a complete cookie cutter streakhouse, and way overpriced for the level it delivers.

Our appy was an antipasto platter, which was all clearly storebought out of a bottle, bland hummus, bland baba, everything in desperate need of salt, a tiny amount of grocery store pita...

My wife's entree was the burger, it was good, but again really in need of salt.

My lobster linguini was not good, no salt, beautiful pieces of lobster totally overcooked, pasta completely overcooked as well. Chewy lobster?

Service was utterly bland as well, the wait staff appeared to be sleepwalking as well.

Oh well, I guess that's what you get for picking blind.

As far as national fast food chains go - Wendy's is one of the better ones. I appreciate that you can get a salad instead of fries here. Their burgers usualy seem fresher and better tasting too. However, this location appears to be one of the worst run Wendy's I've ever been to. My salad not cold, was wilted, and had lots of brown bits. Service was far from enthusiastic.

My companions partook in a romantic evening at this establishment, during which they procured an order for me to consume off-premises.  He relished his steak thoroughly.  She expressed that the fried pickles lacked the desired crispiness and were fabricated with inferior quality pickles, while the ribs were moderately satisfying, the pulled pork was tender but devoid of moisture, the garlic mashed potatoes were passable, and the creamed corn was delightful.  She concluded that the culinary experience was merely average and did not warrant a future visit.  
My own order consisted of a beef brisket sandwich accompanied by macaroni and cheese.  The presentation of the dish diverged from the depiction on their internet platform (on a dissimilar type and shape of bun), and it failed to include the essential au jus for dipping purposes.  The meat was tender but lacked flavor and was rather dry.  The macaroni and cheese possessed an excessive amount of heat, causing me to be unable to consume more than a single bite, as my taste buds were overwhelmed by the intense jalapeÃ±o flavor.  The menu did not provide adequate warning regarding the dish's spicy nature.  The entire experience was utterly underwhelming, leading me to strongly advise against patronizing this establishment.

My friends went here for date night, and brought me an order to-go.  He really enjoyed his steak.  She said the fried pickles were not crispy and were made with poor quality pickles, the ribs were pretty good, the pulled pork was tender but dry, the garlic mashed potatoes were okay, and the creamed corn was delicious.  She said overall it was mediocre and she won't go back. \n\nMy order was the beef brisket sandwich with macaroni and cheese.  It did not look like the one in the picture on their website (on a different type/shape of bun), and did not come with au jus to dip it in.  The meat was tender but very bland and dry.  The macaroni and cheese was so spicy that I could not eat more than one bite, all I tasted was jalape\u00f1o.  The menu did not mention that it would be spicy.  It was very disappointing.  I would not recommend this place at all.

Make sure you get that Palms Club card to save some payola here. The only reason I would recommend dining here would be for the club prices.\n\nThe food was ordinary at best. What follows is my late night breakfast experience. Though the strips of bacon were on the smallish side, they were prepared with a good blend of tenderness/crunchiness, with an average taste. i ordered my eggs scrambled soft, and they were prepared perfectly. I ordered wheat toast; the bread thickness was in-between the norm and Texas toast. The last item, the home fries, were unbearable. In my travels home fries are typically not fried potato bits, as these were. and as such, the taste was more grease than potato.

"Ambient factors at Le Cartet are undeniably captivating, boasting an array of striking castor-esque light bulbs suspended from the ceiling, complemented by visually appealing cutouts of maps adorning the walls, and further accentuated by the presence of substantial pots of poinsettias positioned at the rear of the establishment. Evidently, this venue exudes an energetic atmosphere well-suited for brunch or lunch. However, Le Cartet falls short in its provision of hospitality, as my experience was marred by the absence of a warm welcome, the omission of customary queries regarding beverages, and the need for me to request the day's specials.

My culinary excursion yielded a salmon sandwich, a satisfying yet unremarkable dish, albeit with an unexpected consistency resembling a creamy tuna melt rather than the anticipated slices of salmon. Accompanied by a meager green salad, this offering seemed overpriced at $15.

In conclusion, while Le Cartet's ambiance and proximity to the market may warrant a revisit, the underwhelming experience and inflated pricing leave room for improvement, thereby eliciting a mixed, somewhat indifferent sentiment towards the establishment."

VIBE 
The decor at Le Cartet is awesome. Cool castor-esque light bulbs hang down from the ceilings. Cool cut outs of maps are on the wall and big pots of poinsettas are in the back. I can see it's a buzzy type of place for brunch/lunch. I came for lunch but where Le Cartet really misses out is on its service. 

I was not greeted. I was not asked normal things like: would you like something to drink? I had to ask for the specials. 

I ATE 
I had the salmon sandwich. It was a decent sandwich but I assumed I'd have slices of salmon as opposed to it being a creamy mishmash of a tuna melt. It was solid food but way overpriced with a measley green salad for $15. 

OBLIGATORY CATCHY REMARK 
Le meh. That said, I would come back if I'm directly in the area for ambiance or to buy something in the market. Otherwise, it's a bit on the edge of Old Montreal and out of the way for something that is ho-hum.

Crustaceans are tricky buggers and with them, you have limited courses of action. The most optimal choice would be to carry around a small kit of instruments carefully rolled up in a jewelry case with which to extract the meat skillfully and gracefully. 

If you are not an international spy, however, you end up doing what most of us do, which is look at the animal with a bit of confusion, poke it with a fork, fail to extract meat with fork, and finally revert to caveman status, ripping the damn thing apart. 

Once you finally gain entry, you realize that there is very little meat in the legs and claws, the body holds some type of ill-colored jelly-like substance which you assume are organs and you decide not to take your chances with, and all for $25. To top it off, waitstaff is going to be picking crab shell out of the woodwork for weeks that has inadvertently been jammed in there like ninja throwing stars during your caveman frenzy. 

Hole In The Wall Crab Shack, I will be back. However, not to try this dish. I understand that crabs are expensive, though I don't understand why for the amount of work involved with what I consider a low-yield payoff. I understand that for what they are, you probably do them best (though the garlic crabs I got were more salty than expected). My friend's shrimp looked very appetizing, and I did regret my purchase. Hopefully my next visit will be regret-free.

This is a very expensive steakhouse in Las Vegas that runs out of STEAK (as well as 4-5 other important menu items) & doesn't even apologize sincerely.  It was only 8pm and not even particularly busy. Epic Fail. There are plenty of great steakhouses in Las Vegas. Good luck!

Looking at all the reviews, perhaps I inadvertently selected an unfavorable evening, but I have undoubtedly enjoyed superior steaks at home, prepared on my own grill, using prime cuts procured from the local market.  In the company of nine other discerning diners, I opted for the so-called "surf and turf" combination, featuring a ribeye accompanied by a seafood mashed potato complement.  
The positive aspects of the dining experience included the mashed potatoes, which were indeed exceptional, boasting an abundance of succulent lump seafood and a pronounced flavor profile.  The side dishes, too, were impressive, contributing further to the culinary delight.  
The ribeye, unfortunately, proved to be something of a letdown.  Both my companion and I requested our steaks be cooked to a medium rare temperature, yet upon arrival, they appeared to be closer to a medium level of doneness.  Moreover, the meat lacked tenderness and juiciness, seemingly devoid of any significant marbling, and its texture exhibited an unpleasant granular quality.  
As an enthusiast of diverse culinary experiences, ranging from casual eateries to more refined establishments, I typically approach dining with an eager attitude.  However, this particular encounter came as a mild surprise, considering the substantial cost involved.  Indeed, I have relished ribeyes at a fraction of the price, vastly superior in quality.  
In conclusion, while I would not dismiss the possibility of revisiting this restaurant, I am inclined to explore alternative dining options, primarily to avoid the likelihood of a repetitive, underwhelming experience at such a premium price point.

Unfortunately, despite my initial enthusiasm, this establishment failed to meet my expectations, and it is evident that the quality of the food has deteriorated significantly.  Judging from the numerous vacant parking spaces, it appears that the restaurant's popularity has declined precipitously.  The reason for this downward trend becomes apparent upon sampling the cuisine, which suggests that the proprietors have either lost their passion for creating delectable BBQ dishes or, quite possibly, the food was never truly exceptional.  It is worth noting that there are prominent displays of Guy Fieri's image throughout the premises, leading one to speculate that perhaps the restaurant's reputation was purchased rather than earned through culinary excellence.  The chicken, in particular, was disappointingly arid, lacking any semblance of flavorful seasoning, while the sauce, though unremarkable, was reminiscent of mass-produced varieties available at most supermarkets.  In fact, my own homemade BBQ sauce proved superior in both taste and quality.  The remaining meats, including ribs, brisket, and pork, were merely adequate, with the latter two exhibiting notable deficiencies in texture and flavor.  Specifically, the ribs were tender but lacked any discernible flavor, while the brisket was excessively fatty and possessed an unpleasant texture.  Moreover, the pork had an unusual aftertaste that detracted from its overall enjoyment.  The sides, including coleslaw, BBQ beans, and potato salad, were equally underwhelming, with each dish suffering from an absence of proper seasoning.  Notably, the coleslaw lacked the necessary acidity, while the BBQ beans failed to impress, with my husband commenting that Bush's canned variety surpassed the restaurant's offering.  Similarly, the potato salad was uninspired and lacked any distinguishing characteristics.  However, the breaded pickles, though uneven in their coating, were moderately successful, with their paired ranch dipping sauce enhancing their flavor.
