The ambiance of the restaurant itself was reminiscent of a Five and Diner, with a quaint, charming atmosphere that seemed incongruous with the subpar fare served.  Ultimately, it is disheartening to encounter a nearby BBQ eatery that fails to deliver on its potential, rendering it an unfortunate disappointment.

"The specific information that I am seeking pertains to the individual or individuals responsible for placing sweet relish on a burger, particularly when said burger already features dill pickles as an ingredient. My query stems from my profound aversion to sweet relish, which rendered the culinary experience significantly less enjoyable for me. Notwithstanding this, my curly fries were cooked to perfection, and the establishment offered Cherry Coke, thereby warranting a rating of two stars."

What I want to know is who the hell puts sweet relish on a burger? Especially a burger that already has dill pickles.. I mean I love pickles as much as the next asshole, but I fn HATE sweet relish, so it pretty much ruined the whole thing. \n\nAside from that, my curly fries were perfect, and they have Cherry Coke.. so here, have 2 stars.

Quite possibly the worst Krispy Kreme experience ever! We came here around 9:45 to get two boxes to take home on the evening of Black Friday. The lady that helped us was incredibly rude. No matter the circumstance, and I don't even know if she worked an all day/night shift, she should have been friendly. That aside, I notice some man mopping the floors, water going *wooosh* inside where the donuts are just laying there on the machine. I could not believe my eyes!! The labels did not match the donuts on display and when we asked her to clarify, she gave us a long speech about how they distribute donuts to the gas stations and blah blah blah. I was honestly ready to walk out but we were lucky enough to just pick out the donuts on display that were at least covered by a glass door. I will not come back here... ever

What happened to this place?  I went a few years ago and remember enjoying it.  Now, everything looks run down.  Mildew, stains, steam room not working correctly and outdated.  So very disappointed.  I did not have any services done, this is just for using the facilities.

oh 5th and wine, i like your name, but it felt more like 5th and whine....the service was terrible.  very very slow...after dropping off the tab we tried to get the waiter's attention for 30min, to no avail, so ended up having to pay cash so we could leave.  the art on the walls was cool though.  and my grilled cheese sandwich was good, but the dressing on my salad tasted like dish water, which was awkward.  i wouldn't go back, there are so many restaurants in that area to choose from, i recommend choosing another one.
Barf. I can usually eat anything. The pad thai was the first dish in 10 years I couldn't eat v   The wifes cashew chicken was a 4/10. Keep driving to Naga if you want Thai.

"Would you like some stamps or ice with that?"

With my Snickers bar? No thanks, they don't go well together. How about this, Circle K..."If I wanted stamps or ice I WOULD HAVE ASKED FOR THEM!"

Ugh, I can't stand this Circle K. Always trying to up sell me on shit I don't need. It ain't that clean either. It's jam packed with the many farm and construction workers in the area so it is convenient for them. The location earns them a second star since there isn't much in the area. Also, Circle K fixed their overcharging for 5 Hour Energy drinks by offering a 2 for $5(reg) and 2 for $6 (extra strength) special. I don't know, probably still too much for them, but they help me get through the day.

"Two stars due to the panoramic view, however, the culinary offerings did not live up to expectations. This establishment could be more aptly classified as a drinking venue, transforming into a breakfast spot in the early hours. An extensive selection of menu items is available, yet we opted to maintain a focus on the initial offerings in pursuit of a satisfying breakfast experience. While the ambiance and beverage options are sufficient reasons to return, the edible fare does not warrant a second visit."

Two stars because of the view. the food wasn't amazing. I think this would be better identified as a drinking spot. In fact it probably is a bar turned breakfast in the morning. Huge menu options, but we were on the hunt for breakfast so we didn't go far from the first page. I'd go back to sip cocktails on the patio and watch the fountain, but not for eats.

I must be at a different place than I went 2 years ago.  I remember a fun atmosphere and good food at a decent price.  Tonight I had a 15$ juicy burger which was anything but.  Dry and flavorless is a better description.  My wife had the pulled pork and her exact description was \"meh\".  The place is dirty and not as lively as it was.  The wait staff was friendly and attentive, so I give this two stars and not just one.  If you are about to pull into the parking lot, you would be much more satisfied walking over to Jac's or driving a little farther to Gates and Brovi for the same price.

"When my spouse and I went to this establishment during the evening hours, it was teeming with patrons. The interior design was aesthetically pleasing, albeit slightly tacky. We opted to share the pear salad, despite the fact that the pears were canned, which was a questionable decision. The special of the evening was beef cheeks, which, if you possess familiarity with and an affinity for them, can be truly exceptional. However, the dish was overwhelmed by a rich, dominant sauce that made it challenging to discern the beef cheeks from the surrounding ingredients. My spouse ordered the lasagna, which was satisfactory, and I must admit that I consumed more of his entree than my own. Considering the quality and quantity of the food we were served, the prices were exorbitant. It's conceivable that a comparable dining experience could be had at a more affordable price point at a chain restaurant such as Olive Garden."

The place was pretty busy when my husband and I visited one night. 
The decor was ok but very kitschy.
My husband and I split the pear salad although the pears were the ones out of a can. 
The special that night was beef cheeks which if you are familiar and like them, they can be amazing. But I could barely find them on the plate because they were drowned in a heavy overpowering sauce.
My husband had the lasagna which was decent and I honestly had more of that then my entree.
For what we had, it was totally overpriced. I could imagine Olive Garden would be just as good.

I have been to many a deli my friend and this is not a very good deli. The kosher style corned beef they attempted was fatty, some of it was chewy and parts of it had been exposed to the air too long and gotten a bit hard. 

I also suggest more training on the deli equipment before someone is in need of stitches from the slicing wheel. The girl making my sandwich was having a hard time as a result of the previously mentioned hard portion and nearly pushed her finger into the wheel before deciding to shut it off while she fussed over the meat. 

I like to watch someone fussing over meat as much as the next guy but no one should lose a finger.

The potato salad was very bland.

Rather than leaving me with a fond memory of deli's I have been to in NYC, Boston, Cleveland, etc it left me wishing I had skipped it and wanting the real deal even more.
I travel for business for 11years. I had my share of airports. CLT needs improvements in the drop off and pick up areas. Need to expand the roads.

I am thoroughly disillusioned with the service provided by Gallo Blanco. The experience was utterly abysmal! Our server took an inordinate amount of time to acknowledge our table, and when he finally did, he seemed completely disinterested in our needs. We placed an order for some drinks, but were informed that certain items were unavailable, including the Paloma margarita, dos x, and Negro Modelo. While this was mildly vexing, we opted to proceed with alternative selections. However, our appetizer was inexplicably dropped by another server, and we were left waiting for our main course for an extended period of time. When our server finally returned, I inquired about the delay, to which he responded with an excuse that was both flippant and incomprehensible. He claimed that we should have ordered "right of way," whatever that means. His attitude was utterly unprofessional, and his absence from our table made it impossible for us to order additional items or request assistance in a timely manner. The tacos we received were frigid, and when I requested the Cajetas (an allegedly delectable dessert) and the check, our server brought only the latter. I was forced to ask again for the dessert, and even then, it arrived after we had completed our meal. I was utterly flabbergasted by the ineptitude displayed by our server. His lackadaisical demeanor and unkempt appearance (he wore a white belt that clashed with everything) only added to my dissatisfaction. I must say, I have never encountered such poor service at any establishment, let alone one that purports to offer a high-quality dining experience. My expectations were not merely unmet, but utterly decimated. Needless to say, I will not be returning to Gallo Blanco in the future.

Calabria's exterior presents an visually appealing faÃ§ade, boasting well-manicured landscaping that contributes to its aesthetic appeal, thereby attracting the attention of passersby. However, upon entering the establishment, one cannot help but notice that the interior design appears dated, reminiscent of the 1990s. Despite this, the venue's private party room exudes an air of elegance and sophistication, particularly during special events such as bridal showers. It is worth mentioning that the menu offerings in the party room deviate from the traditional breakfast fare served in the main dining area, which may seem incongruous to some patrons. Notwithstanding, the quality of service and culinary offerings at Calabria's are satisfactory, although the overall ambiance leaves much to be desired.

Calabria's looks like a really beautiful restaurant from the outside. The landscaping is always kept up with and the building is attracting to most of us who drive by it often. Although, when you go inside, it is outdated and stuck in the 90s. I went to a bridal shower here, which was elegant and beautiful compared to the regular restaurant area. The party room served breakfast foods later on in the day, which seemed odd to me for a fancy party room. I would recommend this place for a party because it is separate from the restaurant itself, but I am not impressed with the restaurant as a whole. The service was good, the food is alright but the ambiance is just not there.

1.3/5 stars - Almost so bad I can't eat it. The hand tossed pizza is about 25% edge, 50% air bubble and 25% soggy mess. Sauce tastes like catsup and the toppings always taste like they are frost bitten. The thin crust Philly cheesesteak pizza is surprisingly good, but it only comes around once in a while.

When dining at the Bellagio, I'm aiming for a 4 or 5 star experience.  This was way below expectations! The service was extremely spotty.  \nWe had a large party, and I do understand if certain mistakes are made during busy hours.  However, they weren't super crowded.  Took a while for everything to come out.  What I really disliked the most was the waiter dropping off everything at certain spots of the table.  If you're a fancy sushi restaurant, wouldn't you at least know or remember who ordered which food and where it went? Also, there was clearly timing issues, and dishes came out one or two at a time.  For a large party, some people had to watch others eat.  It just amazed me how they dropped off the food, and since we were a large party, it took a while to determine who had ordered it.... And the waiter was pretty clueless also! The food itself was pricy, yet it was decent. The edamame was good, as it was well seasoned.  Besides that, definitely not worth it.  I would only go here again if I was forced to... If not, definitely visit other sushi places on the strip!!

Scheduled a 8am appt on a Sunday so I could get in early and get on with my day. Except for the receptionist, the staff slowly showed up between 8:10 and 8:15. I expect a medical staff to be a little more professional.

Expensive and the food wasn't very good at all and there was no one in the restaurant and they still tried to put us at a bad table! Vodka pour was pathetic and the portions sizes were very small.  No way will this stay in business longer than a year.

This hotel was actually fairly nice for being so cheap. The rooms were clean and they have a free continental breakfast. \nI would have given this place 4 stars but their free wifi was broken and they've charged my credit cars 4 times now for this room. I understand that mix ups happen when charging hotel rooms, so I placed a call to the front desk to clear this up. The front desk clerk basically went psycho on phone screaming at me he can't help me. Didn't offer to take down my phone number and have me called back, just went straight to screaming as soon as I explained my situation. So now I'm dealing with their corporate office and my bank. Super 8 is a franchise, so there's not much their corporate offices can do to help even though they can view the transaction history and that I've been charged 4 times for the same room. What a headache! I would have saved myself a bunch of stress by staying at the Hilton Garden Inn for $25 more

Upon briefly halting our culinary excursion to partake of a midday repast at this diminutive drinking establishment, we were immediately struck by the lack of sterility that permeated the premises, with frayed chair upholstery and an overworked server struggling to accommodate our modest party, as well as several other patrons. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the gastronomic offerings proved to be quite delectable, particularly the British Burger, which boasted an impressive array of flavors and a generous portion size that satiated our hunger. Our companion's selection of pulled pork sliders also garnered her enthusiastic approval. While the edibles were undoubtedly satisfying, the same cannot be said for the pace of service, which left much to be desired. Moreover, a cursory glance about the dining area revealed a conspicuous absence of ornamentation or any other aesthetic enhancements. In conclusion, a visit to this eatery might be worthwhile for those seeking a hearty meal, but one would do well to temper their expectations regarding the ambiance and promptness of service.

"My sentiments regarding the culinary excursion we embarked upon at this establishment are rather tepid, as the gastronomical offerings, despite being prepared with adequate skill and employing fresh components, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, a vital element that would have elevated them beyond the realm of mediocrity. Furthermore, the ratios of the various ingredients in each dish were somewhat askew, leading to an imbalance in flavors and textures that did not particularly appeal to our collective palates. The service we received during our visit was also subpar, as there were noticeable lapses in attention and responsiveness, resulting in prolonged waiting periods for both food and beverages, which proved frustrating and inconvenient. Lastly, the state of the bathrooms was regrettably unkempt and uninviting, failing to provide an appropriate ambiance for either commencing or concluding a meal, thereby further contributing to our overall dissatisfaction and diminishing the likelihood of a future return."

Meh. Food was cooked well, ingredients were fresh, but everything was bland, and the proportions in the food were off on everybody's plate (e.g. way too many mushrooms when compared to the meat or eggs). Service was blah; there weren't many customers, yet we waited, and waited, and waited, for everything. 

Bathrooms were pretty disgusting, not how I prefer to either begin or end a meal. 

We probably won't be returning anytime soon.

On a trip to Vegas a few months ago  we decided to give the stratosphere a try for our last night in town. Paid les than 100.00 for the oasis suite on Sunday night. We were looking forward to dinning at the Top of the world restaurant mainly for the view. Getting to the restaurant was somewhat of a challenge from the time we entered the elevator loading area on the main floor to the restaurant.  Had to ask for directions a couple a times. Once seated we began with their very taste bread basket and wine.   My wife ordered the ribeye and was fairly satisfied with it, but not a memorable steak. ( I prefer a fire charred steak)  We shared a huge twice baked potato (very good) and field greens salad. I ordered the lobster bisque (not bad, I've eaten better) and the prawns, scallops and lobster plate. The roasted salad and the scallops were very good, that's where it stopped. The lobster and the shrimp had a little bit of foul fishy taste. I could not identify it at the time but the other day I was eating crab legs and took a bite of the shoulder meat, there's that the taste I remember. We will not be back for the food, but if we book a room we may have a drink at the bar for the view.(fantastic view)  There are much  better restaurants in town for the same prices. I give the view 5 stars.

OVER FRIKKIN RATED.

So we had to wait in line for over an hour (cuz we had our BFs with us) while we watched countless hootchie mamas stroll right to the front of the line to get in. My girls and I could've easily ditched the BFs and get in while THEY waited in that horrendous line... LOL... but of course we didn't.

On top of that, when we got in line they said it was going to be a $20 cover charge, so we say "OK, not bad" and stay. But when we finally get to the booth, they drop a bomb on us and tell us its $40.... EACH. WTF? And for some stupid reason we actually paid that shit.... I think it was because we had waited in line all that damn time and we didn't want it to be for nothing. But a big FUCK YOU goes out to you Pure Night Club for lying and jacking up the prices at the last minute.

Ridiculously steep prices on drinks, even a bottled water would set you back almost $10. Uhh, no thanks. 

Highlight of the night was that we saw Dave Chappelle and Chris Rock while we were in line. *see pics*

I hate when you buy a groupon and then to actually get what you want they up charge you for everything once you get there. Total turn off and Such was the case at canyon falls. I had a groupon for a massage and it completely fell short. The building itself is nice and the massage area was bigger than I expected. But a soon as the massage therapist came to get  me and said oh you have the groupon massage, I knew it was going to be bad and it was. It wasn't even the full 60 min it was supposed to be and she barely used any pressure. I basically left an oily mess still wanting an actual massage. Very disappointing and I definitely will not be returning.

If I had penned this review subsequent to my maiden visit, it conceivably would have constituted a five-star appraisal. Nonetheless, taking into account my most recent sojourns, all it genuinely merits at present is a two-star evaluation. My recent culinary excursions transpired during Restaurant Week, and on the majority of instances, the gastronomic offerings were quite satisfactory. Although, I do surmise they should revert to their former macaroni and cheese dish, featuring bacon rather than the lobster rendition. Anyway, the hospitality during my initial visit was faultless. I experienced an altogether enjoyable encounter, and even received a missive via post a week later expressing gratitude for my patronage. The most recent occasion, however, was simply disheartening. I comprehend that generally, the waiting staff at eateries detest Restaurant Week, as it attracts clientele who are oblivious to the principles of gratuities based on the original cost, adding supplementary dishes, et cetera. Well, I possess an understanding of all such concepts, and I don't appreciate being treated like some unsavory diner who will leave a paltry tip. Throughout this visit, the waitress barely conversed or acknowledged us. Whilst we did opt for the Restaurant Week menu, each member of my party also ordered additional sides. A bit later, the servers endeavored to deliver our cuisine to the incorrect table, and toward the conclusion, we were compelled to hail someone down to obtain take-out containers for our dessert. Such service, in my estimation, is unacceptable for one of the premier steakhouses in Charlotte. I do not anticipate a return visit in the near future.

If i had written this after my first experience here it probably would have been a 5 star review. However, after my last trip all it really warrants is now a 2. My recent visits were during restaurant week and on most occasions the food was very good. Although i do think they should go back to the old macaroni and cheese dish with bacon instead of the lobster one but anyway.... The service the first time was impeccable. Had an all around great experience. Even got a card in the mail a week later thanking me for dining there. The latest time, it was just very disappointing. I get that generally the wait staff at restaurants hate restaurant week. It attracts people who have no idea about the concept of tipping on the original price, adding additional dishes etc. Well, i happen to understand all of these concepts and i don't appreciate being treated like  some jerk diner who will leave a shitty tip. During this visit the waitress barely spoke or acknowledged us. While we did order from the restaurant week menu each person in my party also ordered an additional sides. A bit later the servers tried to deliver our food to the wrong table, toward the end we had to flag someone down to get to-go boxes for our dessert. This kind of service is in my opinion unacceptable for one of the \"best steakhouses in Charlotte\". I am not planning a return visit any time soon.

"The omnipresent and profoundly pivotal nature of the Allvitalis is undeniable. However, its inherent lack of coherence and structural integrity raises questions about its ability to justify the requested price. Despite its novelty, a closer examination reveals that the themed rooms are merely superficial embellishments, ultimately leading to disappointment. It appears that the creator has inadvertently incorporated a fatal flaw into the design, rendering it unfit for purpose."

This establishment, situated directly opposing a brick manufacturing facility, had aroused my anticipation for quite some time, and thus, I was eager to partake in their culinary offerings. Unfortunately, the experience proved to be a considerable disappointment, as it required an excessive duration of twenty minutes to ready my order, which, needless to say, is an unacceptable delay for a midday meal collection. Furthermore, upon the arrival of my order, it became apparent that the eatery had exhausted their supply of containers, resulting in the necessity of transporting the pizza in a makeshift package composed of foil. This unconventional packaging proved detrimental to the quality of the cheese, which adhered stubbornly to the foil, refusing to relinquish its grasp. The dough, unfortunately, failed to impress, possessing a texture that could be described as lackluster and unyielding. Despite its advantageous location, this establishment falls short in terms of the quality of its edibles, leaving me with no choice but to seek alternative dining options in the future.

"I had been eagerly anticipating a delightful experience at Walgreens, primarily due to its advantageous location. However, much to my dismay, what I actually encountered was a densely populated and exorbitantly priced establishment that proved challenging to maneuver. While I could have excused the elevated costs owing to its prime location, the haphazard arrangement of the store, particularly in the vicinity of the checkout area, was utterly inexcusable. Furthermore, given that the adjacent Venetian hotel charged exorbitant prices for even the most basic items, I had expected Walgreens to display more competitive pricing. Alas, this was not the case, leaving me feeling disappointed and underwhelmed."

"As a locally grown Las Vegas resident, it is disheartening to witness the current state of this establishment. Prior to its two expansions, it was an exceptional, unpretentious Vietnamese eatery that enjoyed widespread popularity among locals and visitors alike. Its culinary offerings were sublime, with a flavorful hot broth complemented by fresh vegetables and noodles that were cooked to perfection. However, following the implementation of its expansion plans, it appears that the proprietor's primary focus has shifted towards optimizing profits, which has resulted in a noticeable decline in the overall quality of its cuisine and service. The pho broth has become insipid, the prices have increased disproportionately, and the wait staff's attentiveness has diminished. While their Chinese dishes are passable, they pale in comparison to those offered at K.J. Kitchen. Perhaps I am being unduly discerning or nostalgic for the restaurant's former excellence; nonetheless, this venue has regressed to mere mediocrity. Fortunately, Saigon 8 has since emerged as a superior alternative."

As a homegrown Las Vegas local, its sad to see where this place is now. 

Before the 2 expansions, It was a excellent, hole-in-the-wall vietnamese restaurant. It was all the rave in town, constantly packed and everything about it was great. Great tasting hot broth and fresh vegetables and noodles. 

Then, the expansion. It seems that all the owner is thinking about now is maximizing profit. Such is apparent by the reduction in overall quality and waitstaff. Pho broth is bland, food is overpriced in accordance to the price and the service is negligible. I do have to say however their Chinese food isn't half bad. Although I'd rather go to K.J. Kitchen for that. 

Maybe I'm just being an elitist, or am still bummed that this place used to be so good. Nonetheless, this place is nothing more than average by far. 

Ahh, then I discovered Saigon 8.

Awesome food, TERRIBLE service. I recommend calling ahead with a take out order and eating their delicious food in the comfort of your own home. 2 stars for service and 4 stars for food. Just spent 2 hours there, watching people who had arrived after we did get their food and even leave before we got our main dishes. Food was great, won't be eating in the restaurant again.

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are of superior quality, particularly the chicken and waffles, which are unparalleled in their flavor and presentation. However, my experiences with the service staff have been inconsistent, with instances of unfriendly and unhelpful behavior marring an otherwise enjoyable dining experience. Specifically, I have encountered difficulties in obtaining basic courtesies such as refills on beverages and additional time to peruse the menu, which have been met with visible disdain and reluctance. It is conceivable that the servers were experiencing personal difficulties on these occasions, but such attitudes are unbecoming of a reputable dining establishment. Notwithstanding, I would recommend sampling the signature combination of chicken and waffles, but be prepared for the possibility of a suboptimal service encounter."

"Deceptive marketing practices on Travelocity, as the recently renovated accommodations portrayed on their platform were nowhere to be found during our stay. The poolside furniture was in a state of disrepair, while the two individuals named Yvonne at the front desk exhibited an unfriendly demeanor. The culinary offerings at the on-site restaurant were unremarkable, and the absence of a refrigerator and an uncomfortable bed made for a less than satisfactory sleeping arrangement. Furthermore, the lack of a refrigerator and the discomfort of the bed resulted in physical discomfort. It is unclear how this establishment continues to operate successfully. I will never consider returning to this hotel again, and instead recommend staying at alternative accommodations in either downtown Scottsdale or Talking Stick. The only redeeming qualities of this hotel were the pleasant attitude of certain staff members (excluding the front desk personnel) and the picturesque backdrop of the neighboring mountains, which garnered a rating of two stars."

We were eager to experience affection towards this establishment, having recently relocated to the surrounding locality and feeling a profound yearning for the proximity of downtown Gilbert. Following a recent football match, we visited the premises with our offspring and were regretfully disenchanted. It was during the midday hours when we discovered that they did not possess any French fries, which we found perplexing given the prevalence of greasy culinary offerings. The atmosphere was saturated with the pungent aroma of fried delicacies, leading us to speculate that they were in the process of preparing such items. Although the server exhibited great amiability and our children were enamored with the popcorn machine, the gastronomical selections failed to justify a repeat visit in the near future.

"I award a passing grade to Burger Bar, albeit barely! There is ample room for improvement, and I expected significantly more given the acclaim it has received. While the servers were friendly and attentive, the culinary experience fell short. Firstly, there was a lack of efficiency in the kitchen, as my meal took an inordinate amount of time to prepare, and it wasn't particularly busy. Furthermore, my neighbors at the adjacent table were offered two complimentary drinks by the establishment, which contributed to an unusually prolonged wait. My food could have been served at a higher temperature, and while the fries were satisfactory, the chicken wings were not cooked adequately. It is worth noting that they only accept cash or credit payments, so patrons should be aware of this policy. Despite these shortcomings, I may give the restaurant another chance in the future, perhaps motivated by the prospect of redeeming another Groupon coupon..."

"My expectations of indulging in a gratifying dining experience at Indulge were regrettably thwarted, as the restaurant failed to deliver on its promises of offering a slightly upscale atmosphere and delectable cuisine. Instead, it closely resembled a Fuddruckers, which was not in line with my anticipations based on the website, local magazine reviews, and drive-by observations. My companions and I opted for the build-your-own burger option, while another member of our party selected a pre-made selection from the menu. We also sampled the fried pickles as an appetizer, but unfortunately, none of us was particularly impressed with our meals. In fact, we collectively concurred that we did not relish the idea of revisiting the establishment. The ambiance was also subpar, with cramped and closely situated tables that contributed to an excessive level of noise within the dining area. Our servers displayed an eagerness to expedite their duties by promptly removing plates and soliciting dessert orders even while we were still engaged in consuming our meals. Overall, the experience was marred by haste, discomfort, and an absence of the luxurious indulgence that I had envisioned."

I really wanted to enjoy my experience at Indulge, but didn't. From the website, local magazine reviews, and driving by, I expected it to be a slightly upscale neighborhood joint, but it really is no different than a Fuddruckers.
We were underwhelmed by the food and hated the environment. Two of us built our own burgers, and one ordered a pre-made pick off the menu. We had the dill chips (fried pickles) as an appetizer. I can't say that any of us loved our meal, and as soon as we walked out we all agreed we weren't interested in going back. It was just no better than you could make at home (and I burn soup).  
The tables were crowded, too close together, and the place was uncomfortably noisy. Our servers were trying to clear plates as soon as one of us set down a fork (no one was waiting for our table), and asked for our dessert orders while we were still eating. 
The whole experience was rushed, loud, uncomfortable, and not "indulging" in any way. I'm so disappointed.

Not impressed at all. I heard they dd a big renovation and had all the goods from Fountainbleau.. Well. it still stinks like smoke.. looks nice but smells.. The bartenders were jerks.. Seriously.. I sit down with gf and a friend.. we order three drinks and he starts.. u gotta bet to get free drinks.. bla bla bla.. so i drop $5 in three machines fo us.. so I figure.. okay we should be good to go now.. for a drink.. my girl orders scotch.. he gets all. u gotta drop $10 per machine for scotch.. i was stunned how bad this clown was.. I was embarrassed for him it was such a stupid play for money.. So I drop $10 more in and say... here is your tip lets see what happens.. guess what.. he lost.. lol\n\nseriously.. total waste of space. get me drunk and i might drop a $1000 but piss me off and I leave.. its that simple people.. not going to waste my time at a smokers paradise like this.. so see ya

I had never had the pleasure of experiencing the original iteration of the pink pony, however, I felt compelled to investigate its revamped version. Unfortunately, I cannot provide any assurance regarding the current ambiance they are striving to achieve, as my familiarity with the establishment's former atmosphere is limited. Nonetheless, I must admit that the notion of Old Arizona, which the venue previously embodied, holds a certain charm that I believe is worth preserving. It appears that the management is making a concerted effort to appeal to the younger demographic of Scottsdale, but regrettably, they seem to have fallen short in capturing the essence of that particular niche. My spouse and I, being significantly younger than the majority of the clientele, were conspicuously out of place.  

The quality of service we received was, unfortunately, subpar, and one of the primary aspects that left much to be desired. Although our server was amiable, her lack of knowledge regarding the menu offerings was glaringly evident, and her prolonged absence necessitated me to seek assistance from another staff member to procure ketchup and an additional soft drink. The culinary offerings themselves were unremarkable, with my crispy chicken dish failing to meet its promised texture, while my husband's burger was unimpressive.  

Furthermore, I firmly believe that a restaurant's restrooms can serve as a reliable indicator of its overall standards. Sadly, this establishment appeared to attach little importance to maintaining a clean and well-maintained facility, as evidenced by the presence of a partially used toilet paper roll and an untidy floor.  

In conclusion, my experience at this venue was thoroughly underwhelming, leaving no room for future visits.

I had never been to the original version of the pink pony but decided to check it out as the new revamped version. I cannot say with any certainty what they are going for now. From what I know of the old place it was Old Arizona.  A concept which I feel is worth hanging on to. I think they are now attempting to attract the young Scottsdale crowd but they didn't seem to capture that space. My husband and I were by far the young ones in there. 

Our service was one of the worst parts. She was nice but not any good. She had no knowledge of the menu. I can't stand that. You work here, know your product. I would get fired from my job if I knew nothing about it. She also disappeared for a very long time so I had to hunt down someone else for ketchup for our fries and another soda. 
The food itself was mediocre. I had the crispy chicken that wasn't crispy and my husband had the burger which was not a stand out. 

Something else that I ALWAYS find to be an important way to know more about a restaurant is by visiting their bathroom. A truly good restaurant leaves no part of itself unattended. This place could have cared less. There was a soaking half used roll of toilet paper sitting on the vanity and crap all over the floor. 

There was no part of my experience here that would ever make me go back.

We went for breakfast. The service sucked. The waitress unknowledgeable about the menu. Food was just ok. Nothing special nothing that makes them stand out. I can make all the same stuff at home. Bottom line we'll never return.

My spouse and I partook of a culinary excursion at this esteemed establishment last evening, and unfortunately, I must confess that my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, and I felt somewhat exploited in the process.  Notwithstanding, the overall ambiance was quite pleasant, encompassing the luxurious transportation, captivating dÃ©cor, and attentive hospitality.  However, it is with profound regret that I must disclose that none of the consumables we sampled truly amazed me, and I did not depart feeling that the considerable sum of nearly $700 for the two of us was even remotely justified.

Furthermore, my experience was significantly tarnished by the fact that upon being seated, and prior to receiving either a wine list or cocktail menu, we were presented with a glass of champagne.  Evidently, we should have politely declined without first soliciting the menu, but I must admit that I was utterly flabbergasted to discover that they had unknowingly served us a $45 per glass Veuve Clicquot without ever divulging the price or even intimating that it was such.  Moreover, my better half was not apprised that the minuscule vegetable starter he requested came with an additional $50 surcharge when they inquired if he desired to augment it with bone marrow.  I recognize that for certain individuals who frequent JR, fiscal concerns are inconsequential.  Unfortunately, although we had anticipated expending a substantial amount, I did not feel that it was judiciously allocated.

 (Incidentally, when we brought the bone marrow supplement to their attention, it was promptly removed from our invoice.  We opted not to voice any objections regarding the Veuve, as I was still reeling from the unexpected shock.)

My husband and I ate here last night and I was disappointed and felt taken advantage of.  The experience as a whole was lovely, from the limo to the decor to the service.  But nothing - nothing - I ate blew me away, and I certainly did not leave feeling like the nearly $700 bill for the two of us was close to worthwhile.

I will also add that my experience was very tainted by the fact that the moment we sat down, before we were given a wine list or cocktail menu, we were offered a glass of champagne.  Obviously we should not have accepted without requesting the menu first, but I was shocked to find that they automatically served us $45/glass Veuve without ever telling us that was what we were drinking or hinting at the price.   Nor was my husband informed that the tiny vegetable starter he ordered had a $50 surcharge when they asked him if he wanted to add bone marrow to it. I realize that for some people who dine at JR, money is no object.  And although we went there expecting to spend a lot, I did not feel that it was well spent.

(I will add that when we questioned the bone marrow surcharge, it was graciously removed from the bill.  We did not say anything about the Veuve but I  suppose I was still in too much shock.)

Although the ambiance was pleasant and tranquil, the waiting period for a meal was protracted and arduous, requiring approximately forty minutes to receive our culinary selections after placing an order. Furthermore, my dining companion and I were dismayed by the desiccated and overcooked poultry in the chicken quesadilla, necessitating prolonged mastication to break down its unyielding texture. Additionally, we would advise against adding grilled onions to this dish, as it results in an unpleasant sogginess that detracts from the overall dining experience.

Although the atomsphere was nice and quait, the wait time for a meal was long.  It took almost 40 minutes to get our food after we order it.   Also, I had the chicken quesadilla the chicken was so dry and overcooked I had to chew for ever to break it up.  I would not reccomend getting the grilled onions on it, makes it soggy

After indulging in multiple visits and thoroughly savoring the culinary diversity, exceptional wine offerings, and bourbon-centric promotions, it was challenging to resist the allure of this esteemed establishment. However, during my most recent excursion, accompanied by a group of acquaintances who typically remain within the confines of their self-proclaimed "Southpark Bubble," our expectations were unfortunately not met. Despite the restaurant's commendable efforts to accommodate our party of five, the depletion of four initial wine selections and the underwhelming quality of the remaining recommendation left much to be desired. Following a sincere apology and the removal of the unsatisfactory bottle from the menu, we opted for a more expensive alternative, which proved to be satisfactory. Nonetheless, the alteration to their menu, showcasing more conventional options, and the unavailability of the rooftop area contributed to an overall sense of disenchantment. Consequently, I shall temporarily refrain from visiting, and my companions from Southpark will likely maintain their preference for local haunts.

"WEDDING DAY RIPOFF: My nuptial experience with this particular salon was utterly disappointing, as the pricing proved to be grossly deceptive. Despite my hair ultimately appearing satisfactory for the occasion, I can only confer two stars due to the egregious discrepancy between the advertised and actual costs. Following a thorough examination of their website and a confirmatory phone call, I was led to believe that the price range for a wedding updo would be approximately $100. However, upon arrival, my stylist insisted on blow-drying my entirely dry tresses under the guise of 'volume,' despite my hair's natural density and the fact that the requested style did not necessitate such measures. My repeated protestations fell on deaf ears, with the stylist offering a meager concession of charging me only half the price for the blowout. Moreover, I was never informed that an extra fee would be levied for including curls in the updo. Such surreptitious practices are utterly reprehensible. While I am aware that a high-end salon within a luxury hotel in Las Vegas comes with a hefty price tag, the quotation provided and the actual amount my bridesmaids and I were charged differed by nearly $100. To add insult to injury, our hair pins began to loosen and fall out prior to the ceremony, rendering the exorbitant price we paid for our hairstyles even more unpalatable. It is utterly lamentable that such an establishment would resort to such underhanded tactics, sullying what should have been a memorable and joyous experience."

WEDDING DAY RIPOFF: I'm only giving this salon two stars because my hair did end up looking nice for my wedding. BUT the pricing is totally misleading. I checked their website and called to double check on wedding updo pricing and they both said I could expect to pay about $100. Fine. But I showed up to my appointment with completely dry hair and my stylist insisted he needed to blow dry it \"for volume.\" I have nice thick hair and the style I asked for didn't require much volume at all. I asked him three times not to blow dry it and his best response was \"I'll only charge you half for the blow dry.\" Great. Not only that, but they don't tell you they charge an additional fee for curling your hair as part of the updo. Pretty sneaky. Now I'm not stupid. I know a salon in a nice hotel in Vegas is going to cost you, but what I was quoted and what my bridesmaids and I ended up paying was almost $100 more. Oh and one last thing we weren't happy about was that all of us started losing hair pins before the ceremony. If we pay an arm and a leg for a certain hair style, it had better stay in place for at least a couple hours.

I stopped in on a rainy afternoon. My arthritis was flaring up really bad because of the humidity. We were all hungry so we turned onto Main st and end spotted Griff's and gave it a try.\n      I was disappointed they wouldn't let me use my own teapot that I came in with, but there tea was pretty decent. My waitress was at least 350 lbs but she had a warm smile.  I was pretty hungry but I only had enough for a muffin. We sat inside for around 5 hours until the rain let up - I drank a lot of tea lol

Service was horrible. We were not ready to order the first time we were asked, but about 25 minutes later we sure were. Appetizers were good. 

I should have known better than to order steak from a fish place, but I did it anyway. Medium rare at this place has almost no pink left in the center. My buddy sent his back, I won't do that. 

My second beer didn't look or taste anything like the first one. If you don't remember just ask me. I'll tell you what kind of beer I ordered. 

I might try again, but if I got the same waitress I'd run.

We went here primarily due to the fact that the bar we wanted to go to was closed for remodeling through mid december (Fat Tuesday).  We took two trips into here within a few hours of each other with two somewhat different experiences.  The first was at 3 for the happy hour drink specials which was as advertised except the fact that we had a VERY un-attentive  waiter which resulted in delayed drinks each time we got his attention.  The second time we asked to be seated outdoors which was half full yet appeared to have adequate service staff.  WRONG!  We were there for 17 minutes with only a menu and a glass of water which was delivered promptly by the hostess when seated.  When we left as we were walking down back onto the strip the hostess stated \"you weren't helped yet?\" which sounds like is fairly typical and my answer was no and she apologized.  The appetizer of catfish nuggets were pretty good for bar food as was the artichoke dip that was great.  Food however takes people to request it from and to deliver so get your stuff together and this would be a good bar right on the strip.

"I have been eager to indulge in the culinary offerings of this establishment for an extended period of time, and ultimately had the opportunity to partake in Arizona Restaurant Week. Regrettably, my dining experience was marred by subpar service. Our server failed to demonstrate adequate attention to detail, as we were not presented with the Restaurant Week menus upon being seated. Following our request for these menus, it became apparent that our server was not attentive to our needs, as we were forced to explicitly request the replenishment of our beverages on multiple occasions. Furthermore, we did not receive a bread basket, which was readily available to neighboring patrons served by other servers. The prolonged delay in the delivery of our cuisine was particularly noticeable, as parties that arrived subsequent to our seating were served prior to us. To further exacerbate the issue, the pina colada cake dessert we ordered required an excessive amount of time (over twenty minutes) to arrive at our table. While the quality of the food was acceptable, the unsatisfactory nature of the service we received left much to be desired."

I've been wanting to try this restaurant for a while now and finally made it out for Arizona Restaurant Week. Unfortunately I did not have a good experience. The waiter my partner and I had was so unattentive. After we were seated we had to specifically ask for the restaurant week menus since they weren't provided to us to make sure we were only charged the special price for Restaurant Week. Not once throughout our entire meal did our waiter come by to refill our drinks and we were never offered a bread basket that all of our surrounding tables were provided by other waiters. It took forever to get our food while parties that were seated after us were receiving their meals before us. We both ordered the pina colada cake dessert it took over twenty minutes for us to receive our cake slices. Food was okay, service was horrible.

It was utterly devoid of activity on a Friday evening, directly opposite a cinema that was brimming with animated patrons, which should have served as an omen that my expectations should be adjusted. Despite the cordiality of the staff, the menu presented differed substantially from what was advertised on their website and Yelp, featuring novel items at elevated prices.

I had initially contemplated ordering the asada fries, but upon discovering their inflated price point of $11, I promptly abandoned that notion. Instead, I opted for their tacos azules, comprising one fish and one shrimp variety, in addition to a fundamental carnitas taco. The salsa bar offered a meager selection, with merely a fiery, mild, and piquant alternative, accompanied by limes.

Upon collecting my takeout order, I was taken aback by the discovery of three azules-style tacos, with the carnitas version being adorned with cabbage and a creamy sauce, rather than the customary cilantro and onions. The carnitas itself was arid and crunchy, while the fish and shrimp offerings were unremarkable: the former was baked and lacking in flavor, instead of being prepared in the traditional Baja style, while the latter consisted of minuscule, insipid bay shrimp.

I was utterly dismayed at having expended $10 for three paltry street tacos, of which I could only stomach 1.5 before discarding the remainder. The value was woefully inadequate, leading me to surmise that the management had raised prices to compensate for their dearth of clientele. Perhaps a more judicious approach would entail reducing staff levels, as four individuals seemed excessive for the operation of such a modest establishment, particularly when I was the sole patron and still managed to be overcharged and receive an incorrect order.

This place has top notch marketing. With a name like Noodle ChaCha and a cute Pucca-looking girl as their mascot, how could I not get sucked in?!!!\n\nThe restaurant is a building by itself so its not hard to miss. My group and I came around lunch time and the place was practically empty. Servers greeted us and gave us the lunch specials. I ordered the thai fried rice with sweet and sour soup. They were also running a $1 milktea special which of course I got however, DO NOT ORDER THE MILK TEA. The drink was so watered down it pretty much just tasted like mud water. It was disgusting. The $1 was not worth it. The sweet and sour soup was done alright. Kind of bland for my taste buds. The thai fried rice also did not taste very good. It seemed like something that I could have made at home.... and it didn't seem very fresh either. They topped it with chinese dried shredded pork......... uhhhh WHHAAT?! I thought that was pretty odd........ Overall, I might give this place another shot with their noodles but as of right now, Pucca lookalike did not impress.

The service wasn't all that great and the sushi wasn't anything to write home about either. The lady that served us tried to be funny but was sort of rude. She felt too comfortable with us I think. I'm all for being personable, but I am still a guest and expect to be treated as such and not just a \"bro\"...

"If you possess a predilection for diminutive objects of an ornamental nature, such as beads, buttons, or earrings, and find joy in their vibrant hues, then it is highly likely that you will derive immense pleasure from perusing the wares offered at this establishment. However, if you are averse to spending an extended period of time within a minuscule retail space replete with an array of colours that rivals the palette of a Dulux paint chart, then it may be wise to avoid this location altogether. As someone who has had the misfortune of being coerced into visiting this shop on multiple occasions by well-meaning acquaintances, I must confess that upon exiting, I have experienced a throbbing headache of considerable intensity. Nonetheless, it would be remiss of me not to acknowledge that this store does offer a diverse selection of items that could serve as suitable gifts for those who are challenging to purchase for, particularly given the abundance of handbags, belts, and jewellery available, including an assortment of body jewellery designed to adorn various bodily piercings."

If you're the kind of person who's into beads, buttons, earrings and anything else that's ridiculously small and brightly coloured, then you'll love this place.

If, like me, the idea of spending half an hour in a tiny shop filled with more different colours than a Dulux paint chart is not your idea of fun, the you should probably steer clear. I've been dragged in here by friends a few times, and every time i come out I swear I actually have a headache.

To be fair to it though, this shop is good if you're stuck for present ideas. I know blokes are always complaining that women are hard to buy for, but there are so many handbags, belts and jewellery that you can't go wrong, in particular they have body jewellery for every single body piercing you can think of.

My co-worker called in an order at 1:30 pm, well after lunch rush and was told by the lady that answered the phone that "she needed to order right now or forget it".  Ummmm, seriously?? She's lucky it wasn't me that called it in.  She would have gotten a piece of my mind and NOT received the order.  Luckily for them, she is a lot nicer than me.  

1 Star is for my co-workers Carne Asada Burrito, she says it is "the bomb".
1/2 Star is for my rice that is fairly tasty.
1/2 Star is for the delivery being fairly quick.

I got just a ground beef/bean burrito with lettuce/sour cream/cheese.  Pretty much tasted like Taco Bell's Burrito Supreme.  Nothing to write home about...at all.

Overall completely irritated I wasted good money on this place. 

Get SOMEONE ELSE to answer your phone if you want repeat business!!!!
Soggy overpriced fast food burger with allot of hype. When you have to cover the walls with quotes how good your product is, then you have to something to hide.

We elected to try this \"sushi\" restaurant under the current owners after nearly a year and, unfortunately, it has not improved.  Under the previous owners the fish was always fresh and well prepared and the \"sushi chef owner and his assistant\" were always full of great banter and responded honestly to which fish selections that day had the best taste.  Very much in a true traditional sushi bar manner!  This evening I ordered traditional sushi pieces just to see how the preparation and taste would turn out--hamachi, sake, ono, maguro, unagi, saba, ama ebi, etc.  No rolls!  Starting with the rice it tasted somewhat bland (a starch taste) and no hint of wasabi.  As the fish pieces came out some had a \"fresh frozen\" taste.  The \"hamachi\" had the best appeal but not by much.  The \"ono\" was thinly sliced and the unagi sauce was bland.  The oil used in frying the \"ama ebi\" needs to be changed and the \"shrimp head\" itself was pretty small.  I could go on but I think that speaks for itself.  If you desire a true and traditional sushi experience you might want to go somewhere else!

i've been here a couple of times, but last weekend will most likely be my last. Perhaps i'm just too old now to enjoy waiting in line, or being pushed around like a herd of cattle, or pay $16 for a crappy cranberry and vodka...but Pure has just lost it's charm for me. \n\nThe club itself is pretty, the roof is my favorite part. If i were to go back, that's the only place I would stay if I could have it my way.

"Not precisely an 'employment' or temporary agency, this organization specializes in offering short-term, workload-based positions for outbound calling political surveys, with work assignments that vary daily and unpredictably, often commencing at 2:30 p.m., and terminating at irregular intervals contingent upon the workload. Remuneration is $9 per hour; however, it is not uncommon for applicants to experience prolonged periods of unemployment due to the company's inability to 'place' them for extended durations. It is advisable to avoid investing time and effort into the application and interview process, as the management's treatment of staff is questionable, with reports of employees being treated dismissively and disrespectfully, and allegations of exploiting vulnerable individuals, including the elderly, disabled, and those experiencing financial difficulties."

Not really an ' employment ' or temp firm. They offer seasonal, workload-based jobs outbound calling political surveys. Work is on a day-to-day, start time is 2:30 pm, and end time varies daily based on workload. $9/hr. many days you will call in to schedule and they won't be able to 'place' you for weeks. Do not bother applying or wasting time interviewing here. A/k/a mcguire research. Just work at a DQ drive thru nextdoor- 100x more legit\nThe management clearly treats the employees like they are all trash and jokes about preying on old disabled and poor.

"Picazzo's... it pains me to remark upon your precipitous decline in quality, once a cherished establishment now reduced to mediocrity. Although the service remained commendable, the cuisine sadly failed to meet expectations. My salad arrived with an assortment of unlisted leafy greens, prompting my server to offer an apology for the unsolicited alteration. It would have been considerate to inquire about my preference for kale before incorporating it into the dish. Furthermore, the lettuce exhibited an unpleasant browning around the edges, and the exorbitant price of $1.50 for a minuscule portion of avocado struck me as utterly preposterous. I am currently ambivalent about considering you as a viable dining option in the future, despite your well-intentioned efforts to cater to health-conscious patrons."

Picazzo's ... where have you gone? You used to be one of my favorite places to visit but you have fallen from grace. Service was good and I appreciate that but the food was sub-par. My salad arrived with a variety of greens that were not listed on the menu and my server apologizing for the substitution. You might have asked me if I wanted kale... I did not. That's why I didn't order the kale salad. The lettuce was brown on the edges and the $1.50 I paid for a sliver of avocado was ridiculous. I can't decide if I'll try you again or not.  I appreciate your nod to health, but meh...

When eating a meal on \"The Strip\" one would assume that the service and food are above par.  Sadly this is not the case for Diablo's Cantina.  The service was lacking and there was no sense of urgency or follow up...it took almost 20 minutes for us to even be acknowledged and we were sitting at the bar/counter.  When we finally found a server and asked for a menu, the response was a finger point and a mummbled \"ask the bartender, not me\".  When the food made its appearance it was bland and lacking any spice and flavor.  Overall I the experience at Diablo's was a let down and I will most likely never return or suggest it to visitors.

"The Rockin' Railroad class presents an exceptional learning experience, yet it is crucial to note that any absences cannot be compensated for after the semester's conclusion. Due to the confluence of my toddler's slumber schedule, my occupational commitments, and the class times, I encountered considerable difficulties in attending makeup classes. Despite our eagerness to complete merely two additional classes, the proprietor refused to grant any exemptions. It is unfortunate that my child succumbed to illness, necessitating his absence and precluding him from potentially infecting others. Consequently, the sole alternative offered by the establishment was access to the play gym, which failed to align with our initial expectations. We are deeply disheartened that such a reasonable request could not be accommodated, particularly given our positive experiences with other courses where the instructors were more than willing to provide makeup classes beyond the designated term."

The Rockin' Railroad class is great but beware that you cannot make up any classes after the semester is over.  Between my toddler's nap schedule, my work schedule, and the times that the class is offered, I found it difficult to take any make up classes.  We only need to make up two more and the owner would not make any exceptions.  I can't help that my child was sick and I kept him home so that he wouldn't spread his illness.  Now all they can offer us is time to use the play gym, which is not what I originally paid for.  It's very disappointing that a simple request could not be granted.  We have attended other classes where the instructor would happily make up classes after the session was over.  We won't be returning.

Buon Gusto Gourmet Pizzas & Salads is what remains from the falling out with the Picazzo's chain.  The devotion to local, organic foods remains.  Frequent deals arriving in my inbox remain.  But my two favorite pizzas are dead.  I don't know if they were nixed by Picazzo's or Buon Gusto, but I loved those pizzas.  The first casualty was called something like the Chipotle Barbacoa.  It is the best pizza I have ever had.  It had barbacoa meat on top with some sort of cheese sauce that may have involved chipotles.  It was topped with jalapenos.  This pizza was actually spicy.  Not restaurant spicy, but actually spicy.  The next casualty was originally called That's Italian and then later renamed Spicy Italian.  It consisted of the combination of pepperoni and salami.  And it had this delicious tapenade with olives and carrots.  That's right, carrots.  I told my dad that the tapenade had carrots, and he didn't believe it.  He still had trouble believing it when I pointed out the carrots to him on our next visit.  May they rest in peace.  At this point, I'm just not excited by what remains on the menu.  Everything is good.  My daughter gets her usual mushroom and cheese pizza.  On our last visit, my wife confided to me that her favorite pizza was also deceased, and she is also no longer excited about Buon Gusto.  Now I know why we go less frequently.

"Indubitably, this culinary extravaganza transcends the mundane, pedestrian fare typically associated with all-you-can-eat establishments. With an astounding array of over 500 delectable options, this gastronomic odyssey promises to satiate even the most discerning palates. Prior to embarking upon this epicurean adventure, it is advisable to formulate a meticulously devised strategy, carefully considering which tantalizing delights to sample from the vast smorgasbord of culinary masterpieces. For instance, the charcuterie and cheese platter boasts an impressive selection of cured meats and artisanal cheeses, while the Kobe beef sliders and succulent prime rib showcase the restaurant's commitment to quality and flavor. Furthermore, the innovative tuna sashimi salad offers a refreshing departure from more traditional offerings, and the assortment of sweet treats available at the dessert station is nothing short of decadent. In conclusion, the Bacchanal merits unwavering praise and a rating of 3.5 stars, owing to its exceptional gastronomic experience and sheer magnitude."

"Makmak possessed a certain level of culinary proficiency, yet it failed to surpass the threshold of exceptional taste, while the prices charged for its offerings were marginally elevated. Singha beer was available, which may have contributed to the restaurant's appeal. The tom yum soup, characterized by an unconventional flavor profile, did not quite live up to expectations, although it was not entirely unpalatable. The spring rolls were unremarkable in both appearance and taste, while the pork dumplings demonstrated a commendable degree of culinary skill. The peanut sauce accompanying the dumplings was rich and creamy, redeeming the otherwise middling quality of the meal. Unfortunately, this critic did not sample the pad thai, thereby precluding any assessment thereof. Notwithstanding some reservations regarding the food, the service at Makmak was generally satisfactory, and the ambiance of the establishment exuded a quaint charm."

"I have an immense fondness for this library; indeed, it is my utmost favorite among all the libraries I have had the pleasure of visiting. However, I must express a minor grievance regarding the story time session designed for young children. Upon culmination of the narrative, the children receive an indelible mark on their palmar surface, which, regrettably, has been inconsistently distributed by the designated story time monitor. Specifically, there has been an instance where my two-year-old progeny, who displays an unwavering enthusiasm for these interactive literary gatherings, was unjustly overlooked during the stamp distribution process not once, but twice. As a conscientious parent, I find it imperative to voice my concern regarding this seemingly trivial yet ultimately significant matter, given its capacity to undermine the enjoyment of an otherwise delightful experience. In conclusion, despite this isolated drawback, I wholeheartedly endorse this library and eagerly anticipate future story time events, provided that all participants are accorded equal treatment during the concluding ritual."

Who knew!? It wasn't until I returned from Las Vegas that I truly comprehended the essence of "Twin Peaks." Coincidentally, there's a similar establishment in Scottsdale. Upon entering, my initial reaction was, "Wow, the female staff here are quite attractive!" In comparison to the typical UFC fight nights held at Hooters, this venue undoubtedly offers an ambiance that is far more captivating and alluring. 

In terms of culinary offerings, I would rate them as mediocre at best. The menu features generous portions, with options designated as "Men" or "Girl" sizes. It appears they're attempting to be endearing, much like their "Scenic View" dessert selection, which is complimentary for the waitstaff. A reasonable gesture, given the waitresses' striking appearance. In essence, the fare is standard bar food. The burger I ordered had an excessive amount of bun relative to the beef. However, I did appreciate the crispy fingerling potato fries and the massive mound of nachos. - Carry on... 

The atmosphere within the establishment resembles stepping into an REI store, albeit without the ability to make purchases or encounter scantily-clad women. In summary, a $5 cover charge for a UFC event is acceptable. Nonetheless, I wouldn't frequent this spot solely for the cuisine. While the "Scenic View" is an advantage, I don't succumb easily to superficial attractions. - Enjoy!

Who knew!? 

I didn't really understand the concept of "Twin Peaks" until I came back from Vegas.  Hey we have one here too in Scottsdale.  My first thought when I walked in here -- "Wow the girls here are pretty hot"!  Compared to the usual UFC fight nights at Hooters this place definitely "out-hots" Hooters by miles.  

Food wise I think its okay at best.  I huge portions and Men/Girl size options.  Guess they're trying to be cute just like one of their dessert option (Scenic View - NC) is actually the waitresses NO COST.  Fair enough since they are smokin.  Needless to say, the food is bar food.  The burger I ordered had way more bun then beef.  I did enjoy the fingerling potato fries and the Nacho is a massive mound! --- Get it!? Anyways, carry on.....

The place itself is like walking into an REI store except you can't buy anything and hot chicks.  Overall, a cover charge of $5 for a UFC is cool.  I probably wouldn't come here for the food.  The "Scenic View" is a plus, but I'm not one for cheap thrills. - Enjoy!

"A recently established eatery in Goodyear boasts an aesthetically pleasing interior, which is unsurprising given its novelty. The culinary establishment serves an exceptional thin crust pizza, though it deviates from the conventional New York or Chicago styles. As a native New Yorker who has been pursuing a superior NY-style slice for approximately one year, I can assert that this pizza does not conform to my expectations. Nonetheless, it remains a delectable dish. An observable distinction between this restaurant and its competitors in the West Valley lies in the quality of cheese employed. While it may not attain a five-star rating, it surpasses numerous other dining options in the vicinity of Phoenix."

This secondary site for Lukes of Chicago sustains the custom alive and thriving on the northeastern side of the valley.

Lunchtime at this venue can be unpredictable; I have arrived at 12:30 and promptly placed my order, while at other times, I have waited in line with eight other patrons at 2 p.m.

My usual preference is for the chili cheese dog, which is consistently scrumptious and messy. However, it is crucial to allow the dog to cool slightly before consuming it, as it arrives extremely hot. Moreover, I appreciate that numerous menu options include fries, as they offer an exceptional crinkle-cut variation.

Unfortunately, on one occasion, my order was misplaced at this establishment. Although it was a hectic lunchtime rush, and the eatery is modest in size, the old-fashioned handwritten tickets can sometimes get mislaid or mixed up with another customer's order.

If you are in Scottsdale and desire a more relaxed dining experience without the pretentiousness of upscale restaurants or the typical fast food fare, consider visiting Luke's of Chicago. It is conveniently situated in the strip mall area adjacent to Sam's Club and Walmart.

"Although my expectations were elevated due to the ostensible superiority of Las Vegas buffets, I was unfortunately disillusioned by the actual quality of the culinary offerings, notwithstanding the aesthetically pleasing presentation; ultimately, my experience was underwhelming and characterized by a lingering sense of disappointment, underscoring the notion that even the most elaborate of buffets can still fall short of their promised potential."
I thought Vegas buffets were supposed to be better... yes the display looked nicer, but the food was still... ehhh it's still a damn buffet.

Definitely a delectable menu with a very classy yet stylish ambience. 

Steaks, poultry, fish, and duck are big on the menu. If you're into duck, sushi, or tartare you'll enjoy the appetizer selections otherwise opt for lobster artichoke soup or the sprout pear and bacon salad. 

The meats are very well prepared and incredibly rich. Presentation was fantastic. 

I was quite surprised by the extremely slow service. We rarely saw our heavily French accented server though his support staff was always close by for water. I enjoy long eventful dining experiences but this was not eventful; it was almost boring. We spent most of the time with empty glasses or no bread and there's no server around to even request another drink.  

At the end of our meal, we shared the white chocolate ganache dessert because of how full we were. It was a little medicinal in flavor, licorice maybe? We ate half, then the aforementioned support staff cleaned the table. Approx 15 empty glass minutes later, our server made his 3rd appearance of the night to say that the dessert was well worth the wait. He had no clue that we already had it, didn't like it, and were done with it. 

I would give 3.5 stars. Honestly the food is fantastic but the service really killed the experience. Maybe sitting in the bar area would be better.

"Are you guys opting for an aquatic beverage or would you prefer alternative libations... The culinary offerings were indeed satisfactory, however, the hospitality proffered by our server was somewhat subpar. We ordered a salad, two pizzas, three hors d'oeuvres, two glasses of vinous beverages, and a pitcher, yet our server appeared to presume that we were going to be a table requesting solely an aquatic beverage and a pie. The comestibles were quite palatable, but our server's performance was marred by omissions and mistakes; regrettably, this initial experience at Federal Pizza has instilled some trepidation regarding a potential return visit, owing to the unsatisfactory nature of the service."

So are you guys going to to have water or do you want anything else... The food was great but the service from our server was lackluster. We got a salad, two pizzas, three appetizers, two glasses of wine and a pitcher yet our server seemed to think we were going to be a table of water and pizza. Food was great but our server couldn't get it right. Missed drinks and wrong orders; for my first time at Federal Pizza, I don't know if I'd necessarily come back as a result of the service.

Big, sweaty, beefy dudes from all over eastern Europe. Athletic, sexy, flexible and half naked women crawling on top of everything. Acrobatics. Water Stunts. A blur of bodies grinding and groping each other. A two hour thrill ride of sexual intensity I won't soon forget.

When it was over... i toweled off and took a shower. Then I left my condo to check out "Le Reve" at the Wynn. 

Not really a big deal.

This particular location has a bit of a bipolar staff. Some days you get the nicest baristas, who take time and make suggestions, which make me want to come back! Other times, you are just left with the hope you have caught someone on a really bad day. I just hope my visits start to lean toward the better days!

They are currently undergoing an extensive renovation project, and I had the pleasure of occupying one of the recently refurbished guest rooms during my stay. The accommodations were exceptional, boasting a supremely comfortable bed, a spacious and meticulously clean environment, and a picturesque view of the bustling strip below (although, I must admit that I found it challenging to determine whether our vantage point was situated up or down the strip, given the unique layout of the city). Unfortunately, the clientele at the establishment tended towards the seedier side of the social spectrum, which proved to be a slight drawback. However, if management can maintain their high standards of service and facilities until the completion of the remodeling efforts, this venue has the potential to regain its former status as an excellent destination for travelers. The staff members I encountered were generally quite hospitable, with the notable exception of the cabana girl, whose haughty demeanor unfortunately deducted a star from my overall rating and resulted in a minor financial loss for the establishment.

"My girlfriend and I opted to partake in a morning repast at this establishment subsequent to an overnight stay at the Hooters Hotel and Casino, whereupon we became cognizant of the fact that Dan Marino's serves breakfast until noon. Our decision to select the breakfast buffet was influenced by our receipt of a voucher for a two-for-one buffet meal, which we obtained upon registering for the complimentary players club card. The standard tariff for the buffet is ten dollars; however, the spread included an array of fundamental breakfast items such as scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage links and patties, diced potatoes, and dry cereal. Additionally, they offered waffles with strawberries as a topping option, which, although palatable, possessed a texture reminiscent of a dense pancake. Furthermore, a bread pudding-esque dish was present, and a variety of fruits including watermelon, cantaloupe, pineapple, orange, and pink grapefruit slices were also available. Beverages such as coffee, milk, orange juice, or soda were included in the buffet meal. In conclusion, the experience was satisfactory and provided good value for the cost."

The Girlfriend and I came here for breakfast after a night stay there in the Hooters Hotel and Casino. Dan Marino's is located in the Hooters Hotel and  serves breakfast till 12pm. We chose the breakfast buffet because we received a coupon book with a coupon for a 2 for 1 buffet meal when we signed up for the free players club card. Regular price of buffet, $10. Buffet consist of all the basic breakfast goods. Scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage links and patties, diced potatoes and dry cereal. They also had waffles with strawberries as choice for topping. The waffles weren't too bad, tasted more like a thick pancake though.  There was even a bread pudding sort of kinda thing. Oh and fruit, can't forget the fruit. Watermelon, cantelope, pineapple, orange and pink grapefruit slices. Buffett meals include coffee,milk, oj or soda. All in all it was a good bargin and good food.

"For a luxury Las Vegas hotel, the accommodations were somewhat underwhelming, despite their above-average price point. While the elevators were functional, they were also somewhat unreliable, as they frequently exhibited anomalies such as shaking, noise, or unusual sounds. Furthermore, the absence of complimentary Wi-Fi in the guest rooms was a significant inconvenience. However, the main gaming area was moderately sized and manageable, albeit with a few too many opportunities for disorientation. Additionally, the outdoor swimming facility was pleasant, but the cost of amenities and services was prohibitively steep. Overall, the experience was merely adequate, falling short of exceptional but still marginally satisfactory."

If Bistro on the Avenue were to initiate operations in an alternative setting at the present time, it would struggle to endure, attributable to its price point being perceived as excessive by prospective clientele and a dearth of innovation in its culinary offerings. Nonetheless, it enjoys a loyal patronage from residents of Westmount, who deem it a suitable dining venue for casual gatherings or when they are not inclined to prepare meals themselves. In essence, while it may not be a prime destination for an excursion, we would not object to intermittently partaking in the culinary experiences offered by this venerable eatery.

If Bistro on the Avenue were to launch today in any other location, it would not survive, due to its price point and lack of creativity.  However, it is a favorite among Westmount locals, and is a viable option if you live nearby and don't feel like cooking.  In other words, we would not go out of our way with the intent of coming here, but we also wouldn't mind revisiting this long-standing establishment every now and then.

"I recently had the pleasure of visiting this establishment for the first time with a group of acquaintances. Upon entering, I was immediately struck by the well-designed layout, complete with pool tables situated in the rear and a couple of dartboards positioned at the front. Additionally, there was a buck hunting game that unfortunately did not appear to be functioning properly, although I suppose it's understandable given the potential risks associated with intoxicated individuals engaging in such activities prior to operating a vehicle. Nevertheless, the outdoor seating area provided a pleasant setting for those who wished to indulge in nicotine products.
