The bartenders demonstrated exceptional friendliness and hospitality, while the prices they charged were remarkably reasonable in comparison to neighboring establishments in the Westgate area. Specifically, the cost of a tall beer was a mere two dollars, making it an excellent value.  

While the ambiance was generally enjoyable, there were a few instances of questionable behavior from certain patrons, including a few individuals sporting crooked hats and adopting what could be described as a "tough guy" mentality. Nonetheless, the overall experience remained positive.  

One minor drawback was the presence of a man stationed in the men's restroom, who appeared to be expecting tips in exchange for utilizing the facilities. This individual offered various candies and breath mints, but I chose to ignore his presence and proceed directly to the sink. Personally, I find it somewhat perplexing to offer gratuities to someone simply for providing free toiletries and confectionery.  

Despite these isolated incidents, I would still highly recommend paying a visit to this venue. The strobe-lit restrooms and complimentary basket of Starburst candy near the dance floor are certainly unique features that set it apart from other establishments. Moreover, if you're seeking a response to the age-old question posed by your significant other regarding how you spent your leisure time, you can now confidently reply, "My dear, I visited 'The Gym' today."

Just went here for my first time with some friends.  

Nice layout, pool tables in the back, couple dart boards up front, and a buck hunting game that didn't work (that's okay, don't need drunk people in THIS town shooting stuff up before they drive home) and a nice outdoor seating area to smoke, if nicotine is your thing!

The bartenders were friendly and the prices were great compared to the local Westgate neighbors (tall beer was only $2 bucks).  

Of course, for the location, there was a fair share of crooked hats "tough guy" mentalities, but it was fun.  The only weird thing was the dude holding down the bathroom.  The boombox in the Men's room was about as louder as the DJ booth.  It was one of those bathroom host-gigs where a guy expects you to tip him for using the sink or whatever.  He had little candies in baskets and blow pops but I just walked on by.  I guess, to Diego here, it's kind of weird to tip a guy a buck for handing you a free towel and a mint.  

But hey, check this place out!  Can't go wrong with a strobe lit bathroom and a basket of Starburst on your way out to the dance floor!  If for nothing else, you can tell your wife when she asks what your lazy self did all day you can say "Honey, relax.  I went to 'The Gym'".

Frances has amazing sales. I'll admit their merchandise is a wee bit pricey, however, you can find some really unique things - gifts especially! I really love this store, really, I do..but I try to avoid it because most of the time I cannot afford it. I wish they would carry a wider price range. Anyway - I'm just being cheap.

This marks our second visit to this esteemed culinary establishment, and while my previous experience with a fussy infant rendered my recollection of the initial encounter somewhat vague, I can confidently state that the ambiance of the restaurant has undergone a significant transformation since our last visit. Specifically, the interior design has adopted a more modern and sleek aesthetic, which, when coupled with the spotless cleanliness of the facility, creates an atmosphere that exudes both elegance and comfort. However, upon closer inspection, certain aspects of the seating arrangements became apparent, specifically, the disproportionately low height of the chairs in relation to the tables, which resulted in an unfortunate hindrance to the enjoyment of our dining experience. Namely, the elevation of the tables rendered it challenging for our youthful companions to fully appreciate the culinary presentation, prompting them to assume an upright position on our laps, thereby necessitating my manual assistance in elevating their plates to a suitable height for consumption.  
Notwithstanding the aforementioned drawbacks, the quality of the service we received during our visit was truly commendable. The entire staff, including the chef and various servers, displayed a remarkable level of cordiality and accommodation, tailoring their approach to cater to the unique needs of our group, which included a young child who required a slight modification to the customary theatrics of the dining performance. The chef's considerate adjustments notwithstanding, the sushi and complementary appetizers proved to be the undeniable highlights of our repast, boasting an exceptional quality that left us thoroughly impressed. Regrettably, the remaining components of the meal fell short of our expectations, as the chef's liberal application of a distinctive pink sauce resulted in a sense of uniformity that bordered on monotony, rendering each dish indistinguishable from the others. In essence, a simple serving of fried pink paste would have sufficed. Despite this disappointment, the excellence of the sushi and appetizers persuades me to consider a future visit.

This is the second time we ate here. I don't remember much of the first, I think my daughter was still baby and was fussy that night so we didn't stay long. Anyways, this time the restaurant was ok.

The restaurant looks very nice, and it's clean. The chairs are too low for the tables, though. I wasn't the only one who felt like I needed a highchair. The actual high chairs they brought for our toddlers were almost the same height as our chairs, leaving the kids with no chance to see the top of the table, let alone the show. They had to stand on our laps to see anything and I ended up holding a plate at my daughter's level for her to eat.

The service was very good. All the waiters and the chef were friendly and accomodating. We had a young child with us, who was a little scared of some of the flashy parts of the dining show, so the chef toned it down a little for her, but still put on a great show.

The sushi and accompanying appetizers were excellent! Oh, it was sooo good. The rest of the dinner, however, left me a smidgen dissappointed. The chef added a pink paste to everything he cooked. On the one hand, it had an interesting flavor. On the other hand, it made everything taste the same. He may as well have just fried up some pink paste and served us just that. :\

I would go back for the sushi.

Nice hotel! I like to stay here all the time. Eventho they have no cirque du soleil shows and it's preety boring here beside.\nThe parties at the marquee are preety annoying and the drunk people control the hotel.

Nice, clean-cut decor, great menu, kid-friendly and super service.  Need more?

We went for lunch and the menu options were interesting and adequate for the most choosy patron.  Tried the tempura battered asparagus with chili ranch and they were delicious.  Wish the portion was larger.

Hoagie sandwiches were great.  Many like Philly steak-cheese, but these were upscale with sliced prime rib.  Wife had variety with spinach and cheese, I had mine with mushrooms, onions and cheese.  Rolls were soft and your salivating mouth could easily take in the sandwich.   Make certain that you bite into your sandwich over a plate or you will have a dry cleaning bill for sure.  Very juicy.

Fries were perfectly fried.

Will give it a try for dinner, but bet it will be crowded as it is pretty good.

Nice place, the appitizers were good. The steak was so... so... the reason it was so... so... was because I was here for a bachelor party and we had a set menu. I probably will come again to order a better quality steak, because the appetizers and the side orders were good. The ambiance and service was good.

The gargantuan proportions of their half sandwiches are truly remarkable, with the ciabatta bread exhibiting exceptional quality and rumors circulating that the nine-grain variety is utterly delectable. However, my experience with the roast beef and provolone sandwich was slightly tarnished by a subtle yet unsettling sensation in my stomach, prompting me to reconsider my preference for the establishment and potentially seek alternative options, such as the nearby Jimmy John's, to satiate my craving for a satisfying sandwich.

"The peculiarity regarding the Secret Garden and the Dolphin Habitat's separate listings on Yelp, despite the fact that a single admission fee grants access to both attractions, serves as the impetus for my musings. In light of this, my remarks will focus primarily on the Secret Garden aspect of our excursion. Firstly, it is essential to acknowledge that the entrance fees are rather steep, totaling $69 for two adults and two children. Upon inquiring at the ticket counter regarding potential discounts for military personnel or locals, I was met with a negative response. Subsequently, I must admit that the Secret Garden's dimensions are somewhat diminutive. Although the quantity of tigers and lions present was not substantial, the size of their enclosures proved to be inadequate, failing to provide sufficient space for even a brief sprint. Furthermore, during the sweltering heat of the late morning hours, the animals displayed lethargic behavior, which sparked concern within me. However, an unexpected encounter with Siegfried, the famed dolphin trainer, alleviated my apprehensions momentarily. His presence, accompanied by an authentic German accent, added a touch of authenticity to the experience. A separate evaluation will be dedicated to the dolphins. In conclusion, while the visit was undoubtedly intriguing, the cost factor significantly diminishes its overall value."

"Although I have had the pleasure of indulging in superior Hawaiian cuisine at other establishments, I still hold this particular venue in high regard due to its exceptional value. It appears that regardless of what menu item one selects, they receive an abundance of it, which is particularly advantageous for those who are budget-conscious. Each time I visit this restaurant, I invariably opt for the macaroni salad and spam musubi, as they are staples that never fail to satisfy my cravings. Additionally, their chicken katsu is skillfully prepared, boasting a golden-brown, crunchy exterior complemented by a juicy, tender interior. Whenever my appetite is particularly hearty and I am in pursuit of a meal that will satiate my hunger for an extended period, I find myself drawn to this eatery, where I can indulge in a veritable feast that will leave me feeling pleasantly full for a considerable duration."

This marked the inaugural dining experience of my three-day culinary excursion, wherein I partook of delectable Mexican cuisine alongside my sibling, maternal aunt, and paternal uncle at Arriba's, a quaint eatery renowned for its scrumptious fare. Although my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, allow me to elucidate the specifics of my dining encounter:
Chips... 4 stars, they were crisp and warm, accompanied by an impressive salsa and bean dip that contributed to their appeal.

Service  3 stars, our server, while cordial and informative, inadvertently neglected to provide my paternal uncle with the additional hot salsa he had requested, resulting in a delay until midway through the meal before he finally received it.

Food 2-4 stars, my green corn tamale, though palatable, was somewhat disappointing due to its dry texture and conspicuous absence of the distinctive "corny" flavor that I had eagerly anticipated. Conversely, my uncle expressed great satisfaction with his Chile relleno, which he relished immensely. However, I must concur with the sentiment that the ambiance appeared less than pristine.  

Decor.. 3 stars, unremarkable environs, yet suitable for the establishment's purpose. In retrospect, if presented with the option, I might opt for a family-run, independent restaurant in the future.

"My significant other and I were eager to sample the culinary offerings at this novel establishment, specifically their barbecue, and assess its quality. Upon perusing their menu, we decided to order a whiskey from their extensive selection and a tap beer. The beverage was presented chilled to an optimal temperature, allowing us to savor its refreshing taste for an extended period. Their daily specials, featuring both beverages and edibles, were prominently displayed on a chalkboard, facilitating our decision-making process. Our server exhibited exceptional proficiency in attending to our needs, ensuring that our dining experience was seamless and enjoyable. However, we did encounter a brief delay in consuming our meals, as they arrived at our table scorching hot, necessitating a brief waiting period before we could indulge in their delectable flavors. We initiated our gastronomical journey by sampling their fried pickles, whose flavor profile was satisfactory, albeit perhaps slightly lacking in thickness. I opted for the fried chicken, comprising three pieces, accompanied by mac and cheese and baked beans. My companion, on the other hand, selected the pulled pork sandwich, complemented by fried okra. The smoky essence of the pork was particularly appealing to my taste buds."

"For a rapid and economical cleansing of one's automotive conveyance, this establishment provides an adequate service.  Their amenities include complimentary vacuum facilities for patrons' convenience.  During the washing process, customers remain within their vehicles while a staff member performs a manual cleaning of the exterior surfaces at the conclusion.  The quality of their work is satisfactory.  In the event that one's car has been exposed to a heavy rainstorm, this location is an ideal destination for a hasty restoration of its appearance.  However, it is important to note that a comprehensive detailing service is not offered here, nor do they attend to the interior aspects of the vehicle.  Furthermore, a small towel for drying the interior surfaces is no longer provided, as was previously customary.  Nonetheless, this facility remains suitable for a brief, stopgap washing interval until a more thorough detailing can be undertaken at a later time."

For a quick wash that is cheap not bad at all.  They have free vacuums too.  You stay in your vehicle  during the wash and there is a guy at the end who wipes down your car.  They do a good job.  This is the perfect place to take the car after it gets caught in a monsoon rain.  They don't offer the full detail and they don't do the inside.  They also don't give you a little towel anymore to wipe the inside.  But like I said, it is perfect for a quick wash to tide you over for awhile.

"I recently had the pleasure of dining at Ruby Tuesday, courtesy of my esteemed great aunt, who treated me to a delightful luncheon experience, utilizing a coupon, no less. It's quite amusing, really, how my paternal relatives are often jocularly associated with fiscal prudence. My great aunt, however, proved to be an exception to this rule, producing a veritable cache of coupons. I find that when I frequent chain restaurants, I tend to adhere to a tried-and-true formula, opting for either a burger or chicken sandwich, both of which are reliably palatable options. The fact that the chicken may arrive via truck, bearing grill marks, matters not; the essence of the meal lies not in its appearance, but in its gustatory satisfaction. Ruby Tuesday, in particular, offers a tantalizing deal, featuring two diminutive burgers accompanied by a salad bar, all for the reasonable sum of $8. Furthermore, they have recently introduced a pimento cheese alternative, much to my delight. Alas, there are two items that I sorely miss from the halcyon days of yore, both of which graced the salad bar: bread and butter pickles, as well as pineapple. Why, oh why, have these delectable ingredients been exiled from the menu? The absence of these culinary treasures elicits a dramatic lamentation, replete with flair and flourish."

We possess a quartet of offspring, and we effortlessly expended two hundred dollars and two hours within this establishment. It is utterly captivating; however, it does tend to attract an abundance of tourists, thereby creating a congested atmosphere. We do not bring our progeny to Las Vegas, but we bestow upon them numerous presents during each excursion. This emporium encompasses multiple levels, and if your progeny harbor an affection for M&Ms, you will undoubtedly discover an item within these premises that they will be absolutely delighted to acquire. As a matter of fact, my daughter has already petitioned me to procure something for her during our impending journey in January, thus we shall indeed revisit this location. The staff exhibited amicability and helpfulness, although the queues were somewhat protracted. Everything was slightly pricier than we had desired, yet it is essential to consider that the experience and site are integral components of the cost. It is quite advantageous for a leisurely stroll along the strip to culminate in stores of this nature. That is precisely why such establishments are situated in these locations. To be candid, without my offspring, this venue would not hold nearly as much appeal, and I would not have had the tolerance to navigate through the dense crowds of diminutive children who were darting about in all directions. Furthermore, negotiating one's way through the store was somewhat arduous; although not particularly intuitive, we did not find it overly vexing.

"A laid-back, informal eatery specializing in pizza and pasta dishes, where patrons can order at the counter and enjoy their meals delivered to their tables. The dinner entrees offer an exceptional value, with a mere $9 securing a hearty serving of spaghetti and meatballs accompanied by a side salad and garlic bread. Although the ambiance may lack a certain je ne sais quoi, the friendly service and spotless facilities, including well-maintained restrooms, more than compensate for any aesthetic shortcomings. However, it is worth noting that refills incur an additional fee of $1, and the establishment only accepts cash payments."

"Chipotle holds a special place in my heart as my preferred culinary establishment due to their consistent delivery of delectable dishes. However, my rating is not solely based on the gastronomical offerings, but rather takes into account the quality of service and efficiency of the staff. On this particular occasion, I must commend the employees for their amiable nature, despite the apparent stress and anxiety that permeated their demeanor. A mere three patrons stood in line, yet the personnel seemed overwhelmed, struggling to maintain a pace that would accommodate the demand. Notably, the gentleman preceding me in the queue had his meal prepared, only to have it abandoned by the attendant, leaving it to languish until her return. Upon her arrival, she discarded the previously prepared dish and began anew, contributing to an already prolonged waiting period that exceeded 15 minutes. Despite these setbacks, the edibles themselves maintained their customary excellence. It is my sincere hope that with time, the team will acclimate to their responsibilities, thereby enhancing the overall experience."

Chipotle is my favorite restaurant because Chipotle IS LIFE! My rating is not based off the food because Chipotle food is always great and always deserves a 5 star. My rating is specifically based off of the service and speed. 
Let me say that the workers there were very nice. They were nice, but you could tell they were flustered and nervous. 
There was like 3 people in line and they seemed overwhelmed (this is compared to others who do fine with lines out the doors). 
The gentleman in front of me started his order and the lady behind the counter left his food sitting there. When she came back, she threw away what she started (since it was cold) and made him a new one. 
Total time took about 15 min to order and everything, so it was a lot slower than most chipotle. 
Food was great like always. 
Hopefully once they get used to working it will speed up!

"Although the assemblage of individuals cannot be readily classified, this establishment boasts an abundance of seating and a proficient team of servers. The interior bar has undergone recent renovations, yet the ambiance is contingent upon the time of day and day of the week, much like the majority of drinking establishments. During less busy periods, the bartenders exhibit an exceptional level of cordiality, and are eager to assist in alleviating the effects of a hangover."

Though the crowd can't really be categorized, this place has plenty of seating and a quick staff. The inside bar is newly renovated, but like most bars the atmosphere completely depends on the time of day - and day of the week.\n\nOn slower days, bartenders are even more friendly than usual, and definitely want to help rid you of your hangover.

The service was outstanding. Everyone on staff was pleasant and helpful. Not the most kid-friendly (no cups with lids). The stuffed mushrooms were tasty, but only slightly warm to cool. The eggplant  and veal parm were tasty, but I think overpriced for what you get. It feels like a restaurant that can't decide whether to be casual or fine. Linen napkins (with paper napkin centerpieces) and oil lamps, but tissue paper plate liners. Might go again without the kids. The patio looked nice for alfresco dining.

We indulged in a culinary excursion with the intent of consuming a delectable pastry delight, specifically, a slice of apple pie.  Upon partaking of this gastronomical treat, we discovered that the filling, infused with a piquant flavor, was quite satisfactory.  However, the outer layer of dough, unfortunately, lacked the requisite degree of doneness, rendering it inedible for our taste buds.  Furthermore, the serving size, intended for a trio of individuals, proved excessive for our appetites, although certain patrons may find it suitable.  In contrast, the key lime variety, characterized by an abundant helping, demonstrated a superior quality compared to others of its kind.  Ultimately, our pursuit of exceptional pie remained unfulfilled, prompting us to continue our search.  Additionally, our experience was marred by sluggish service, though the server's amiability somewhat mitigated this deficiency.

After our companions had persistently recommended that we sample the culinary offerings of Texaz, we ultimately relented and indulged in a dining experience at this establishment. Upon perusing the menu, we elected to place an order for two portions, which, much to our satisfaction, proved to be palatable. However, what our associates had neglected to divulge to us was that their previous visits had featured the chicken fried steak as the primary item of consumption, which, according to their accounts, had elicited immense enjoyment. Thus, we shall have to incorporate this particular dish into our future plans. Additionally, we were impressed by the hospitable demeanor exhibited by the staff.

After all our friends had told us to try out Texaz, we finally did. We both ordered, and it wasn't bad! What they forgot to mention to us was that they all had the chicken fried steaks and LOVED them. Guess we'll have to get that next time. Very friendly staff.

"The culinary offerings and hospitality were indeed impressive, however, we were taken aback by an unforeseen tariff, albeit, the management did make an effort to apprise us of the additional fee prior to our dining experience. Notwithstanding, the advertised 'all-you-can-eat' breakfast buffet for $5.99 proved to be a tad misleading, as it failed to account for the mandatory participation in their 'player's card' loyalty program, which tacked on an additional $3 per person. A rather dubious business practice, in our humble opinion."

"An aesthetically pleasing venue, with a singular aspect that precipitated my departure. The pervasive presence of cigarette smoke, which enveloped the atmosphere for an extended period, rendered it difficult for me to remain there for an extended duration. Despite the DJ's melodic mixes, the ubiquity of smoking patrons created an environment that was less than salubrious. Notwithstanding the entrance fee of $10 per female patron, the ambiance was distinct from that of numerous other establishments. If circumstances permit, I shall consider visiting XS on a future occasion."

"Although the service was satisfactory, my culinary experience was marred by the unpalatable nature of the 'pollo poblano' entree, which failed to elicit even a modicum of gastronomical delight. The accompanying rice and bean dish was unremarkable, yet palatable; however, my overall satisfaction was irrevocably compromised by the unfortunate texture and consistency of the aforementioned poultry dish. Furthermore, the chips and salsa provided as a complementary amenity were somewhat disappointing, as the latter exhibited an excessive fluidity, suggestive of an overzealous addition of aquatic substances. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the gratuituous dessert offering proved to be a fascinating conclusion to the meal, thereby augmenting the overall value of the dining experience."

The service was good but I got the 'pollo poblano' entree and it was so not appetizing. The rice and bean stuff was fine but ugh I am never getting that again. They gave us some chips and salsa. The salsa was too liquidy. It sort of seems like as thought they added much more water into it. The dessert thing that they just gave us was interesting. So technically got an appetizer an dessert for free and they give you more so that's nice

"I have an immense fondness for The Venetian, encompassing its ornate painted walls and ceilings, as well as the captivating street performers that permeate the atmosphere with a touch of Venetian charm. Thus, indulging in a meal at this open-space eatery seemed like a brilliant notion. Following a brief wait of 20 minutes, which was hardly an issue given the abundance of establishments in the vicinity, we opted to partake in a glass of wine at a nearby bar. Upon being seated, we placed our beverage orders, and as a Miami native, I always consider the fact that not everyone may be familiar with the distinct flavor profile of a caipirinha. Unfortunately, the rendition presented to us was utterly unpalatable, prompting both myself and my companion to return our drinks. Subsequently, upon the recommendation of our server, I hesitantly agreed to sample a pomegranate mojito. Although lacking in quality, I chose not to return it for fear of appearing overly critical. 

Moving on to the culinary aspect of our experience, I must say that it was rather uninspired. Perhaps my expectations were elevated due to my previous encounter with the exceptional cuisine offered by Wolfgang Puck's Bar and Grill at the MGM, but the dishes we were presented with fell short of impressive. Anticipating a delectable pasta dish, I was instead served a bland and unremarkable meal. Ultimately, my visit to Postrio was a letdown, as it possessed all the essential elements necessary for a truly satisfying dining experience but failed to deliver."

"An interior ambiance that exudes an assorted array of styles and influences, complemented by the hospitable demeanor of the staff, serves as the backdrop for an epicurean adventure characterized by diminutive portions of culinary delights, augmented by potent potables artfully infused with house-made syrups. A suitable venue for socializing with acquaintances during the initial hours of the evening, albeit, it is essential to exercise fiscal vigilance, lest one's financial resources be depleted prior to the witching hour; ultimately, this establishment has the potential to ascend to a rating of four or five stars as time progresses."

I had breakfast here this morning with a friend before we did a little grocery shopping at Whole Foods. 

It was my first time here, but my friend eats here all the time.  It's one of her favorite restaurants.  

I went with the garden omlette and apple cinnamon toast.  It was good and definitely tasted healthy.  Heather had the oatmeal with brulee topping and fresh berries.  I tried hers, it was pretty good too.  Everything was good, but not spectacular. 

There is lots of seating and the service was fast.  I wasn't wow'd by anything.  I will definitely try this place again.  I hear the sweet potato fries are excellent.

Have had the pleasure of partaking in the indulgences offered by Tao on multiple occasions, and while my initial experience was enjoyable, subsequent visits have led me to reassess my opinion of the establishment.  
Upon arrival, it became apparent that entry would be contingent upon adhering to a strict gender ratio, with a minimum requirement of a 50-50 split between males and females. As our group consisted of four men, we were met with resistance from the doorman, who refused to allow us to queue, effectively barring our entry. Fortunately, through a stroke of serendipity, we had established a connection with an alternative doorman earlier in the evening, who graciously facilitated our admittance without hesitation.  
Once inside, the venue's ambiance initially captivated my attention, boasting an intriguing aesthetic that permeated the space for the first fifteen minutes, prior to the influx of the bulk of the clientele. However, as the club reached capacity, mobility became severely restricted, with limited space for movement, standing, or dancing. It is mystifying how such an overcrowded environment does not pose a safety hazard. The dÃ©cor is undeniably impressive, augmented by the presence of bathing girls, which serves as a unique and alluring feature. The bartenders consistently provide exceptional service, yet the conduct of the doormen and bouncers leaves much to be desired, and navigating the premises proves challenging. Despite these drawbacks, a visit to Tao remains a requisite experience for anyone seeking to partake in the city's nightlife.

"Well, it serves as an appropriate location for families with children to spend time together, as it offers a variety of species that are sure to captivate young minds. However, for adults who are not particularly fond of penguins or other avian species, the experience may prove to be somewhat underwhelming, as the zoo's collection of animals is not particularly extensive or diverse. That being said, the zoo does boast some unique features, such as the meticulous recreations of the natural habitats of various species, which may appeal to those with a keen interest in environmental design and conservation efforts."

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are merely adequate, with generous helping sizes that are commensurate with the cost. However, the gustatory experience they provide is somewhat unremarkable. Despite their proximity to my place of residence, I would not consider it worthwhile to make a special effort to partake of their fare, unless they happen to be the most convenient option in the immediate vicinity."

Pretty average mexican food.  The portion sizes are big for the price, but the taste is just okay.  I'll give them another shot because they are so close to where I live, but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here.

Great food when they have it. They seem to run out of goat cheese curds a lot. \nDon't go on trivia night or you won't get good service. They act like you're an inconvenience when you want to eat before trivia starts.

"The morning repast is exceptionally satisfying, particularly the skillet dishes, and owing to the recent installation of misting devices on the outdoor patio area, partaking in a delectable breakfast alfresco has become an unparalleled delight."
Breakfast is very good especially the Skillets and since they put misters outside on the patio breakfast outside is superb.

"Basha's culinary offerings are palatable, utilizing authentic meat for their sandwiches, rather than the dubious substance resembling Spam, and their salads are consistently fresh. However, the establishment would benefit from training their female staff members, who appear to be of Middle Eastern descent, to engage in professional interactions with male patrons. In Western societies, it is customary for men and women to interact during commercial transactions in public settings, such as restaurants, supermarkets, shoe stores, and pharmacies. If these female employees are unable or unwilling to comply with this cultural norm, they may consider alternative employment opportunities that do not involve direct customer service. It is crucial for Basha's management to familiarize their staff with the social conventions of Canada, where they operate, to ensure quality customer service. I have personally dined at Basha on two occasions; the first visit was at the Ste Catherine/Peel location, where the cuisine was satisfactory, but the female employee behind the counter displayed an unmistakable aversion to her job or serving male clients. During my second visit to the food court on Place Mont Royal, the bald man, presumably the franchise owner, exhibited friendliness, while his female companion, likely his spouse, manifested visible disdain when providing change, suggesting she would prefer male customers to be absent. If her aversion to interacting with male patrons persists, a role in the kitchen would be a suitable solution."

"Upon recent visitation for extrication of consumables, my visual sensory organs experienced sudden and profound discomfort due to the vibrant floral patterned seat covers, which seemed to be an amalgamation of various hues and designs, thus creating a sense of optical disparity. However, upon further exploration of the interior, it became apparent that the establishment had been fastidiously arranged, boasting circular tables and crimson Chinese lanterns suspended from the ceiling, thereby creating an atmosphere of conviviality and festivity, augmented by the melodies of traditional Christmas songs emanating from the sound system. My culinary selections consisted of soup dumplings and fried string beans, for which I had hoped would be generously proportioned, given the tariff of $20 for two dishes. Upon consumption, the dumplings proved to be merely satisfactory, possessing a tendency to solidify rapidly upon cooling, while the green beans, although seasoned with considerable skill, were somewhat compromised by their excessive oiliness. Despite these drawbacks, I remain willing to accord this eatery an additional opportunity to demonstrate its gastronomical prowess."

I came here for take out recently and upon entering the restaurant my eyes burst from the bright floral patterned seat covers. They were a bit of an eyesore. As for the rest of the restaurant, it was cutely arranged with round tables and red Chinese lanterns lining the ceilings. They were playing old school Christmas songs which got me in a cheery mood whilst waiting.

I ordered the soup dumplings and the fried string beans. I was hoping for them to be big portions for the amount I paid, which was $20 for two dishes. 

So the verdict: 
The dumplings were ok and hardened as soon as they started to cool down. The green beans were seasoned nicely and was a good portion but the down side was how greasy they were. 

I'm willing to give this place another shot I didn't really love what I had.

After relocating from the metropolitan area of Chicago, it became imperative to locate an exceptional sushi eatery within the vicinity of Madison. Initially, I harbored reservations regarding the prospect of finding a suitable establishment, given its location within a modest strip mall adjacent to a discount store. However, upon conducting a thorough assessment, I was pleasantly surprised by the culinary excellence that this particular venue had to offer. Over the ensuing year and a half, I have remained a loyal patron of Takara, albeit with a brief period of diminished satisfaction. Notwithstanding, I would unhesitatingly endorse this dining establishment, particularly in light of their exceptional lunchtime offering, which comprises two sushi rolls accompanied by a bowl of savory miso soup, all at a remarkably reasonable price point.

After moving from Chicago, it was a must to find good sushi restaurant in Madison.  I was a little skeptical at first with it being in a strip mall next to a dollar store.  This place indeed went beyond my initial expectations.  I have been going to Takara for the last year and half and although I feel it has lacked a little since discovering it, I would still recommend this establishment.  They have a awesome lunch special as well, 2 rolls and miso soup for low cost.
They have a wide variety of sweets. Although they are crazy expensive. The staff was not that friendly. The gelato is delicious.

"My offspring and I endeavored to sample the culinary offerings of Elmer's establishment for the first time last night. I surmised that it would be beneficial for him to familiarize himself with the ambiance and gastronomical options of the venue, thereby enabling him to make an informed decision regarding his future dining preferences. 

Upon perusing the menu, my progeny opted for the Asada burrito, which he later professed to have relished. In contrast, I selected the green beef hot burrito, which, despite its delectable flavor, proved to be somewhat challenging to consume due to its generous size and juiciness, thus necessitating the utilization of utensils to complete the meal. 

It is worth noting that Elmer's menu boasts an extensive array of options, with prices that are remarkably reasonable. Furthermore, the eatery accepts debit cards and offers complimentary chips and salsa, features that set it apart from its competitor, Guedo's. In addition, the quality of the food, the affordability, and the courteous demeanor of the counter staff all contribute to a superior dining experience at Elmer's. 

However, it must be noted that the establishment's maintenance and upkeep could benefit from some attention, as evidenced by the presence of remnants of food on the floor adjacent to our table, which slightly marred the overall enjoyment of our repast."

"Had the opportunity to partake in a culinary excursion to this establishment subsequent to our corporate gathering, and upon perusing the menu, I opted to sample the last remaining portion of clam chowder, which unfortunately failed to impress due to an apparent lack of seasoning. However, the calamari proved to be moderately satisfying, primarily owing to its light batter, which aligns with my personal preference. Additionally, the aioli accompanying the dish was quite palatable. The pizza offerings were generally enjoyable, and the shrimp cocktail was also of notable quality. The service we received during our visit was adequate."

"I had the pleasure of meeting a acquaintance for a morning meal at this establishment, and I must say, the hospitality we received was quite satisfactory. The ambiance of the restaurant was reminiscent of a certain chain of restaurants that shall remain nameless, but the quality of the cuisine was undoubtedly superior. I opted for the farmer's omelette, which, to my delight, was assembled with fresh, locally-sourced ingredients. My companion, on the other hand, selected the corned beef hash and eggs, which, according to their account, was also expertly prepared. Notably, the generous serving of corned beef hash was crafted entirely from scratch, a testament to the culinary prowess of the chef. While my omelette was, regrettably, not as impressive as my companion's dish, it was still a satisfying repast. However, I must express my mild disappointment at the absence of any complementary fresh fruit or vegetables, as such an addition would have elevated the dining experience to a truly exceptional level. Nonetheless, I would unhesitatingly recommend this eatery to anyone seeking a hearty, satisfying meal in a welcoming atmosphere."

Met a friend for breakfast here. Service was good. It is an Eat n Park / Denny's type of place so if you enjoy those kinds of places you will love Drew's.. I ordered the farmers omelette and my friend had the Corned Beef Hash and eggs. The big plate full of CBH was made from scratch and not canned. Delicious per my friend. My omelette was ok... Because it was the farmers and had some potatoes in it I did not receive any hash browns just a couple of slices of small toast. A great place would have included some fresh fruit to fill the platter but not Drew's just a small burrito sized omelette in the middle of a big platter..

Everyone was raving about the oxtail chili cheese fries but it just tasted like a regular chili cheese fries with an egg on top. Nothing extravagant. But the fries itself was pretty good. 

I originally ordered the Kiki's burger and my husband ordered the Miyagi Wagyu burger but then I totally changed my mind so we switched burgers. I personally like the Miyagi burger better. It reminded me of the Manly burger at Umami burger. And my husband says he liked the Kiki's burger better so I guess it all worked out. 

I'm giving it a 3 stars because their food is really yummy but it's also expensive. Also this is the first place in Vegas that has decent boba. I've searched long and hard for boba places that can give me almost the same thing I had in California and this place came pretty close. The only problem is, like I said, it's expensive. And such small portions. But I mean overall I'd still eat here again.

"Inexpensive culinary options, variable quality, and inconsistent service are hallmarks of this establishment. Ideally suited for large gatherings of friends and family, comparable to Paradise Buffet or other Freemont buffets. An interesting aspect is the bathroom's connection to the Berlin Wall. 
  Sunday brunch costs $12 with the club card, offering an excellent value. My experiences have shown the food to be relatively consistent with the price, albeit the prime rib is satisfactory, and the brisket could benefit from slower cooking and proper cutting. Notably, the nearby bar serves beer at a reasonable price of $1 per cup. 
  Unfortunately, the service is unpredictable, sometimes meeting expectations and other times neglecting to provide essential drink refills throughout the meal, resulting in only two sightings of our waiter. The ambiance, cleanliness, and location are generic, reminiscent of Bioshock Infinity, within the Main Street Station casino at the end of the Freemont Street Experience. 
  My rating system involves three categories, each starting at 3 points. Impressive aspects earn one point, while disappointing elements deduct a point. Calculating an overall rating by rounding the average of the ratings yields a score of 3."

Pretty good neighborhood coffee spot. 
The girls that work here are always super friendly, coffee is good, not the best I have ever had, but I prefer it over Starbucks. I love the Kona brew, always get excited when I come in and see it on the board.
My biggest complaint is I wish they served b'fast sandwiches. They always have some pastry's made at local spots, and bagels. But I want a bacon, egg, & cheese with my coffee.
 Also careful what time you go if you decide to visit on a Sunday morning, it gets crazy in there with all the people who attend the church at the theatre. It becomes a mass of people who know each other just standing  in the middle of an already cramped coffee shop, just talking.

I've been going here for over 4 years.  We've done comedy in just about every room.
I still have trouble understanding WHY the bathrooms are so...destroyed!  Some of the doors are off their hinges, there is never enough hand soap or paper towels.
On the flip side, though, there is something to do for everyone.  Pool, air hockey, ping pong, music and the outdoor atrium.
Staff is very friendly

It's hard not to love anything on gorgeous William Street, but for some reason I didn't get too excited about The Melville when I came here the other day. It just seemed a bit too olde worlde, in a bad way, for my liking. Whether it was the three gents of a certain age smoking in the doorway, or the smell when I walked in that made me think for a second that the smoking ban had never been implemented.\n\nDrinks were pricey compared to a lot of other pubs in this area of the city centre, and although it was no more expensive than Teuchters just across the road it lacks the same relaxed and trendy vibe that Teuchters has. Although in its defense, the food menu did look nice and inviting as well as being good value for money, so I'll probably head back here at some point to try it out. It's just not at the top of my list.

"My expectations were favorably surpassed upon dining at Les Deux Gamins, a quaint French bistro nestled among an array of overpriced establishments catering primarily to tourists on Prince-Arthur. Although not a bring-your-own-wine (BYOW) venue like many neighboring eateries, the prices were relatively reasonable. The menu offered traditional French cuisine, including steak tartare, steak frite, and lamb shank, without any unexpected variations or contemporary twists. While the kitchen encountered a minor mishap with our appetizer order, they graciously compensated us with a complimentary bottle of house wine. Ultimately, although superior French restaurants exist in Montreal, Les Deux Gamins presents a satisfying dining experience, especially considering its convenient location."

I am originating from Southern California, where an abundance of sushi options are readily available. Upon relocating to Arizona, I have been ardently seeking a local sushi establishment that can provide comparable quality to that of Los Angeles, all while maintaining reasonable price points. Considering the fact that the seafood in LA is often fresher and not previously frozen due to the city's proximity to harbors, I entered Hiro's with tempered expectations to avoid potential disappointment. Generally speaking, the atmosphere and sushi quality are quite satisfactory for a venue situated in Arizona. Nonetheless, the prices are somewhat elevated, which is only natural given the restaurant's location in Scottsdale and the associated increased costs of procuring premium seafood in an inland area. Furthermore, I find it perplexing that the bento boxes, such as the Teriyaki Chicken and Mixed Tempura, carry such a hefty price tag. In light of this, I am unlikely to return to Hiro's, particularly if I am seeking non-seafood options. Such items should not be priced so exorbitantly, especially when they are sourced locally. I would comprehend if they were offering Kobe beef or something of similar caliber, but for chicken, it seems unjustified. To compound matters, the chicken I received during my visit was slightly dry. Although it may have been an isolated incident, for such a steep price, I rightfully anticipate superior quality or, at the very least, naturally raised organic chicken. Thus, I feel misled in this regard. My apologies, Hiro; I shall continue my search elsewhere.

I'm from S. Cali where the Sushi options are plentiful. Moving to AZ I've been in desperate need of finding a local sushi spot that would be at least semi-comparable to the quality we get back in LA and at reasonable price-points. Taking in to consideration that the fish might be fresher and not previously frozen because LA has its harbors, I went to Hiro's with lower expectations so I wouldn't be disappointed. Overall, the ambiance and the sushi quality is pretty good for being in AZ. However, the prices are a bit high as to be expected being that it is located in Scottsdale and that the rent and getting quality fish so far inland from the coast would raise cost. The portions could be larger to justify the higher prices. Moreover, I don't understand WHY the bento boxes (i.e. Teriyaki Chicken & Mixed Tempura) is priced so high! For that reason, I probably won't be returning here, especially if I want non-fish options. That kind of stuff shouldn't be priced so high because it's produced locally. I would understand if it were Kobe beef or something.. but chicken? And to add insult to injury, the chicken that I received that night was a bit on the dry side. Not sure if it was an isolated incident but for the high price I expect quality or even naturally raised organic style chicken...now we're talking! Anyway, now I feel cheated in that respect. Sorry Hiro, on to the next spot!

"Although the culinary offerings at this establishment were satisfactory, they fell short of excellence due to a few key deficiencies. Specifically, the poultry dish we sampled was somewhat lacking in moisture, while the BBQ sandwich was comparably unremarkable. However, the ribs truly stole the show, boasting an impressive richness of flavor that nearly compensated for the previous disappointments. Furthermore, the abundance of side dishes available was truly astounding, and each of the four we selected proved to be delectable. Unfortunately, our experience was marred by a notable delay in the fulfillment of our order, during which time numerous patrons who placed their orders subsequent to ours received their takeout meals before we did. This inexcusable lapse in service was partially redeemed by the apologetic demeanor and generosity of the gentleman manning the cash register, who offered us a complimentary dish as restitution. Despite these setbacks, I remain willing to give this restaurant another chance, optimistic that our encounter was merely an anomaly."

My spouse and I opted for an early evening repast, selecting an alfresco dining experience on the outdoor patio, which, while pleasant, was somewhat marred by the audible sounds emanating from the adjacent thoroughfare. The interior atmosphere was stifling and cacophonous, rendering the exterior seating option a more appealing alternative. The flatbread and garlic-infused spherical bread basket was satisfactory, arriving at our table warm and fresh. However, upon the arrival of the primary course, my spouse expressed disappointment with the meager proportions of his linguine and clam dish, quipping that a visit to a fast food establishment may have been more satiating. The portion consisted of a scant seven minuscule clams and a mere half cup of pasta, raising questions about the sufficiency of the serving size. In contrast, my chicken marsala was generously proportioned, boasting rich flavors and an artistic presentation. Kindly sharing my culinary delight with my partner, we collectively decided to forgo a subsequent dining excursion to McDonald's. Unfortunately, the service we received was sluggish, further contributing to our ambivalence regarding a future visit.

"Subpar sushi experience with too much repetition."

Ra was the inaugural edifice where I had the privilege of partaking in sushi, and my initial impression was one of enjoyment; however, subsequent to expanding my culinary boundaries and sampling the offerings of various other sushi establishments (Hiro et al.), I came to the realization that there exist superior alternatives throughout the valley.

In the event that you opt to visit this establishment, I would recommend indulging in the Las Vegas roll, whose ingredients remain unclear to me, and the calamari roll, which boasts a combination of fried calamari, cream cheese, white rice, and is topped with both eel sauce and tempura flakes. These two options are relatively palatable and outshine their other offerings by a considerable margin.

It is worth mentioning that Ra offers satisfactory happy hour deals. Nonetheless, it is imperative to acknowledge that the sushi rolls served here are noticeably diminutive in size compared to those offered at other establishments I have visited.

Sub par sushi. 

Ra was the first place I had ever tried sushi and I really enjoyed it. However, after broadening my horizons and dining at other sushi establishments (Hiro, etc.), I discovered that there are much better options all over the valley. 

If you go, I would recommend the Las Vegas roll (not sure what's in it) and calamari roll (fried calamari, cream cheese, white rice, and topped with eel sauce and tempura flakes). Both are decent and are much better tasting than their other rolls.

They have good happy hour deals. Rolls are definitely much smaller here than anywhere else I've been.

Decent Chinese fast food that is similar to Panda Express.  About what you would expect at a food court.  

The prices for the food entrees was a bit high.  The price for a bottle of beer was way too expensive.  Just get your alcohol at the casino while playing.

Good place for a quick meal.  I would stop by again.  I just would not buy beer.

"A veritable gem, this eatery is nestled inconspicuously within a strip mall, adjacent to a secondary educational institution and a main thoroughfare. Its diminutive stature belies its welcoming ambiance, which is augmented by a diverse array of seating options, including booths, tables, and a sushi bar. It appears to be operated by a veteran culinary couple, who have crafted an affordable and delectable menu that features an assortment of traditional Japanese dishes and innovative fusion creations. Particularly noteworthy are the bento box specials, available during the meridian hours, which offer a generous portion of delights such as soup, an egg roll, tempura vegetables, a half-portion of a California roll, and a choice of rice, all complemented by a selection of savory entrees. Our experience with the General Tao Chicken and Mongolian Beef was nothing short of satisfactory, and we eagerly anticipate our return to indulge in the bento boxes and sample the authentic sushi and sashimi offerings. It is our fervent hope that this culinary treasure will continue to thrive, and we implore you, dear reader, to disseminate the news of its existence, thereby ensuring its continued success."

What a hidden treasure.  Tucked away in corner strip center at 19th Ave. and TBird next to high school we found a new sushi and japanese restaurant.  Very small but comfy.  Booths, tables and sushi bar.  Looks like it's run by the owners - an old couple.  We ordered the bento box specials for lunch today.  $6.95 = choice of soup + egg roll + tempura veggies, + 1/2 a California roll, + white rice and a choice of several entrees.  Bro picked General Tao Chicken.  I picked Mongolian Beef.  Both were great.  We'll be back for bento boxes and to try the real sushi and sashimi.  Spread the word - they need business.

The store is very clean, and looks a lot newer and bigger on the inside than it does on the outside. I got my order to go, which was chicken noodle in a bread bowl. The bread bowl was cold when I took it out of the bag, and I had to microwave it for a few seconds. The soup tasted amazing but the bread was pretty bland and got soggy VERY fast. Basically the bread bowl was just a dinner roll with a hole punched in the middle of it. I read someone else's review about the man scratching his behind and then returning to making the sandwiches and also thought that was pretty gross. I have to commend them for having the coke soda machine with over 100 flavors, though. I will probably just eat somewhere else next time, but it wasn't too bad of an experience.
Still good food like before the fire, but the salads seem smaller. The new modern style totally ruined the comfortable atmosphere.

Trusty old Beanscene. Academic year after academic year this has been my favourite place to grab a large mug of Americano, pick up a copy of the Metro and slip into one of its leather booths for a quiet read and a flick through my lecture notes.

Inviting staff, mellow beats playing in the background and a more personal alternative to the bigger corporate cafe brands result in a pleasant and reliable service that will keep coming back for more.

Admittedly, I've never come here for the food: Nachos, Paninis etc are the typical fare. But for a coffee and a place to sit and read, Beanscene will do just fine.

I have been intrigued by this establishment for an extended period of time, and whenever I visit Las Vegas, I am drawn to its distinctive architecture. During my most recent excursion, I finally had the opportunity to experience it. However, the wait for a table was rather protracted (in excess of two hours), so we opted to partake in sustenance within the food court of Caesar's Palace before returning to the exterior window to place an order for frozen hot chocolates. The queue was considerable, and upon our arrival at the window, it became apparent why; the lone staff member was struggling to manage the workload, juggling multiple tasks simultaneously. We shared two large frozen hot chocolates among seven individuals, which proved sufficient, albeit with an additional request for straws. While the beverage possessed a rich chocolate flavor, it was reminiscent of a typical chocolate milkshake, save for a slightly gritty texture, which I found pleasing. Although satisfying, the price of $8.00 seemed somewhat steep.

The ambiance was somewhat kitschy, yet the gastronomical offerings were undeniably delectable, specifically the trio of carne-based tacos that I had the pleasure of sampling. However, I cannot say the same for the arroz con frijoles, which regrettably lacked a certain je ne sais quoi. Notwithstanding, I shall return, albeit with the hope of encountering more satisfactory side dishes.

"While this establishment offers a satisfactory breakfast experience, the prices charged are somewhat prohibitive. For a more cost-effective option, consider visiting Cora, where the value offered is superior. Alternatively, if your culinary preferences lean towards more gastronomic indulgences, Cafe Orange is worth considering, as its menu offerings are of a higher quality. However, if proximity is a factor and convenience is paramount, then this venue may still be a viable, albeit relatively pricey, option."
Decent breakfast place but a bit expensive. You get better value at Cora and you get better food at Cafe Orange. Still, if you're in the area and want to eat, it's not a bad choice.

"A perceptible enhancement has transpired since the era of Terrible Herbst, with a palpable improvement in the culinary offerings and a marginal acceleration in the pace of service. The $10 special deals continue to represent a reasonable value. My personal preference for the Cafe over the Buffet remains unwavering, despite the latter's previous complimentary status. Notwithstanding, a lingering issue persists, specifically, the tendency for elderly waitstaff to experience a gradual decline in their work ethic, resulting in sluggishness and the necessity to request items such as condiments or supplementary settings for additional patrons on multiple occasions."

There has been an improvement from when this was Terrible Herbst. The food is better and the service is slightly faster than before. The $10 specials are still a good value. I have always liked the Cafe over the Buffet even when the buffet was comped. The one remaining problem is that this is where old waitresses go to die. Slow and often need ing to ask two or three times for condiments or set ups for additional people.
Pretty standard theatre, never had a bad experience here, except sometimes it can be crowded, and of course its expensive. Except matinee = $5!

"My expectations for an elevated chocolate experience were not entirely met at this purportedly high-end chocolate establishment, as the ambiance, while unique, seemed to borrow more from the aesthetic of a luxury cosmetics retailer rather than a refined chocolatier, and the samples I tasted, while diverse in their flavor profiles, did not quite live up to my expectations in terms of quality and left me somewhat underwhelmed, despite the inclusion of a few complimentary treats and an intriguing, albeit not particularly appetizing, tortilla chip and Cayenne pepper-infused chocolate pairing."

I had held such elevated expectations for this establishment, given that my colleagues had extolled its virtues to such an extent. The carne asada tacos were indeed impressive, possessing a certain je ne sais quoi that rendered them tantamount to culinary perfection. Conversely, the shrimp tacos were somewhat lackluster, prompting me to express a desire for additional carne asada tacos in lieu of the crustacean variety. Alas, the service proved to be sluggish, with a prolonged delay of approximately 15 minutes elapsing before the procurement of my beverage, specifically a beer, which, according to my associates, was frequently unavailable, particularly in the case of Dos Equis. Our party consisted of eight individuals, thereby necessitating a sizable table. Unfortunately, the majority of orders were botched, with only a pair of checks being executed correctly. The rectification of these errors required a considerable amount of time, approximating 20 minutes, during which period the server appeared visibly exasperated. The male staff member responsible for transporting the comestibles manifested signs of annoyance, understandably so, given the multitude of mistakes that had been committed. However, as paying patrons, it is reasonable to assume that our orders should be fulfilled accurately. Thus, I shall endeavor to visit this establishment once again prior to relinquishing hope entirely, with the expectation of potentially modifying my assessment in the future. Additionally, I must advise against the frozen margaritas, priced at $7 for a diminutive quantity of questionable potency, suitable only for those who are less than robust in their constitution.

I had such high hopes for this place since my coworkers talked it up so much. The carne asada tacos were bomb. Shrimp tacos were meh, I wish I would've ordered more carne asada instead of the shrimp. Service was very slow it took like 15 minutes to get my beer and they're always out if Dos Equis (according to my coworkers). We had a group of 8 so we had a decent sized table. Almost every order was messed up and only two checks came out right. It took her 20 minutes to correct the issue. The guy bringing out the food was getting frustrated because nothing was right they were clearly upset with us because we kept telling them \"This is the wrong order.\" Or \"We're missing a taco from this order.\" But hey we're paying for our stuff so I think our orders should be correct. I'll probably try this place one more time before I give up on it. Hopefully I'll have an updated review soon! Oh and I don't recommend the frozen margaritas $7 for a small super weak drink it's good for light weight ;)

"Satisfactory culinary experiences. Beverages of an alcoholic nature. Regrettably, a prolonged waiting period is customarily associated with the consumption of piscine entities on the fifth day of the week. Notwithstanding this inconvenience, the aforementioned edible aquatic organisms, whether submerged in oil or subjected to heat via direct flame, are of superior quality. A strong fondness exists towards the aforementioned establishment's deep-fried fungi."
Good food. Good drinks. Too bad there's always a long wait for fish on Friday. Their fish and chips are both very good, either fried or broiled. Love their fried mushrooms!

"Although the service at this establishment was commendable, the beverages and pricing left much to be desired. Specifically, the Mojito and margarita were presented in unremarkable plastic vessels, replete with an excessive amount of ice relative to the actual liquid content, and were procured at a cost of eleven dollars apiece during the lunchtime hours. Furthermore, the nachos, while palatable, did not conform to our precise specifications. Thus, it is unlikely that we will return to this particular venue in the future, opting instead to patronize locales with which we are familiar and have had consistently favorable experiences."

"Two days and two excursions to the rotisserie stick of culinary euphoria. 

I must admit that I had already placed an order for the dolmas when I sat down to peruse the critiques, and regrettably, Valerie's assessment of them is not drastically different from reality. Dolmas bear a resemblance to pakora, which are commonly offered within Indian eateries, in that they are ubiquitous yet unpredictable in their quality. The ones I received appeared appetizing, but aside from a faint citrus aroma, extracting a distinct flavor from them proved challenging. I was left with five and a half out of eight. Now, I am becoming increasingly anxious about what will follow. However, I was relieved to discover that my concerns were unwarranted.

The gyro salad was generously portioned, fresh, and featured an abundance of succulent meat. The pita bread was satisfactory, and the accompanying dipping sauces met my expectations. My partner opted for the Gyro Pita Basket, and I must say, it was also quite satisfying. The fries served alongside it were decent, further contributing to its appeal. Based on the strength of the entrees alone, I would unquestionably return, and if it weren't for the underwhelming experience with the dolmas, my rating would have been a perfect four."

Two days  and two trips to the spinning meat sticks of happiness.  

I have to say that I'd already ordered the dolmas  when I sat down to read the reviews and sadly Valerie's take on them isn't too far  from the truth.

  Dolmas seem like pakora , within Indian restaurants, in that they nearly all have them ( except  for the insane places that have them only at weekends) but you never quite know what you're going to get.   What I got looked the part,  but  apart  from the citrus smell it was hard to pull any  real taste  out of them.   Out of the 8   5.5  were left.   So  now I'm getting a bit  worried about what's coming out next   but thankfully I didn't need to worry. 

The gyro salad was large,  fresh and the  meat was plentiful.  The pita bread  decent and the accompanying sauces within expectations. My partner had the Gryo pita basket and the  damn thing was also good,  decent fries served with it too.    

I'm certainly going back based on the strength of the entrees and  without the dolmas  would have been a four

Watched a lot of shows, this one was well below average. Lot of mistakes in the co-ordination among performers spoiled all the fun, add to it the rude staff. One of the performer announced at the beginning of the show that flash photography is not allowed, after which people turned off the flash to take snaps, only to find a rude old lady coming up and almost getting physical with them and snatching their cameras- saying photography is not allowed at all. They need to be specific in giving the instruction. No one wants to take a snap of their mediocre show if they are not allowed to, but for God's sake save them the humiliation by telling them. Gamble and lose your money than to watch this show!! \nOverall Average Performance, Poor staff, overrated

"Indulged in the fried chicken salad, despite my aspirations for a healthier dining experience, as the inclusion of grilled chicken would have been more conducive to my dietary goals. However, the presence of fried chicken strips on the salad proved to be a formidable obstacle in my endeavors to make wholesome choices. The attentive waitress/bartender provided exceptional service, though I did request her assistance in adjusting the blinds to mitigate the intense glare emanating from the window, which, due to the position of the sun, resembled a potent gamma-ray radiation. Upon my suggestion, she considerately closed all blinds except the one through which the supernova-like sunlight persisted in piercing through."

Had the fried chicken salad. Wish they would add a grilled chicken salad. Trying to make good choices with my dining, and fried chicken strips on a salad is counter productive. Waitress/bartender was on the spot.\n\nIf you go between 4 - 6 don't sit facing the window, the Sun blinds you like a Gamma Ray. I asked the bartender if she could shut the blind as the sun was reflecting off a wind shield and boring a hole in my face, I pointed at the window.  She proceeded to shut all blinds but the one that had the super nova coming through.

Regular sports bar with a couple of unique amenities.  Large patio on the Scottsdale greenbelt.  Menu where every sandwhich has a corresponding salad version (essentially replace the bread with lettuce).  Lots of specials, and a fun birthday offer.  It's quite large with multiple sections, and televisions all around.

Good food but service could have been a bit better. Try the dumplings on the appetizer menu... They are the best! Also the blended margaritas are stiff so watch yourself because before you know it you will be riding a nice buzz!

A cursory examination of the gaming facility revealed a substantial quantity of individuals meandering throughout the premises, which seemed to suggest a high level of popularity among patrons. The employees were quite hospitable, offering assistance and answering queries with great alacrity. However, the prices charged for beverages were somewhat prohibitive, and one could infer that the establishment did not cater specifically to those with limited financial means.

"It's Walgreens, three stars, as it's merely a standard, unremarkable establishment offering nothing extraordinary or unique, thereby precluding the possibility of a higher rating; however, I would consider awarding an additional star if they were to diversify their offerings by introducing alcoholic beverages such as wine and beer, which might enhance the shopping experience for patrons like myself."
its walgreens, 3 stars since its just the same ole thing...hmmm...I wish I could give it 4 stars, maybe if they start selling wine and beer!
Pretty good, not the best but very far from bad. Haven't been disappointed yet and we eat here about once a week. The Thai basil is really good as well as the steak salad.

"A conventional dining establishment with a familiar ambiance, devoid of any extraordinary features. The refurbishment from its predecessor within the Tropicana resort primarily involves superficial alterations, yet still manages to create a welcoming atmosphere that dispels the need for post-dining cleansing rituals. The interior design exudes a tranquil coastal charm, incorporating calming hues and elements reminiscent of a seaside setting. Patrons can relish the picturesque views of the Tropicana pool's cascading water feature from select vantage points, while having the option between indoor and alfresco seating areas. The hospitality of the staff is warm and inviting, complemented by the scrumptious fare and generous portion sizes, all of which justify the slightly elevated prices compared to its antecedent eatery."

This particular Dillard's location can be described as merely satisfactory, as my experiences within its confines have been inconsistent and varied. During my previous visits, I have procured several dresses and blouses, yet the service provided by the sales associates in the women's dress department has been either excessively intrusive or utterly absent, failing to strike a balance between the two extremes. In contrast, my encounters with the accessories department personnel have been relatively more pleasant, as they appear genuinely interested in understanding customers' needs and providing appropriate assistance. However, a recent episode involving a return of an item in pristine condition with accompanying tags attached, albeit slightly beyond the return policy time frame, resulted in the store manager offering me a store credit, which I appreciated, considering my awareness of the return policy limitations. In summary, this store can be characterized as average, and while I intend to revisit it due to its diverse selection of dresses and tops, I remain hopeful for a truly exceptional customer service experience, which I believe should be a standard aspect of any shopping excursion.

This Dillard's location is just okay. I have purchased a few dresses and tops from this location over the last couple of months and every time I have been in my experience has only been so so. The sales associates in the women's dress department can be either too pushy or completely non existent but not a good balance of one or the other. I have had a little bit of a better experience in the accessories department and the associates in that department seem to be more interested in what you are looking for and how to help rather than just making a sale. I also had an issue recently with needing to return an item that was in perfect condition with tags attached but it had been just a few days over the return policy limit. The manager was able to give me a store credit which I appreciated because I knew I was over the limit of the return policy. Overall this store is just okay. I will be back because I like their selection of dresses and tops but I am still waiting for that wow customer service experience that I think you should get no matter where you are shopping.

"The consumption of falafel was analogous to ingesting granular particles of earth, genuinely resembling the sensation of devouring sand. Indeed, the exterior presented an excessive crispiness, evoking memories of seaside excursions where the fine grains of sand had an unfortunate propensity to insinuate themselves into my oral cavity. Furthermore, the falafel plate was accompanied by a serving of rice, a mixed greens salad, and a pita bread, yet lacked any substantial dipping sauce, such as hummus, to alleviate the aridity of the meal. A minuscule quantity of tahini was provided in a small plastic ramekin, which proved insufficient in offering respite from the pervasive dryness. In light of this, I implore my fellow Yelp reviewers to opt for either the falafel sandwich or alternative value meals, thereby avoiding the unpleasantness of parched oral cavities at a Greek pita eatery. Additionally, the prices charged for these meals were deemed excessive, with a falafel plate accompanied by a carbonated beverage amounting to nearly $12, while the inclusion of hummus as a means of addressing the aforementioned dryness issue would result in a total cost of approximately $16 to $17 for a single individual."

"The culinary offerings at this establishment were merely adequate, but the service we received from the peculiar pair of waitresses was truly bizarre and off-putting. Their unconventional demeanor and eccentric behavior made for an unsettling dining experience that precludes us from ever returning to this location again."

The culinary experience was thoroughly enjoyable, however, the quality of service was subpar and left much to be desired. Despite my decision to take a seat at the bar, the portly bartender remained oblivious to our presence, necessitating my departure to an adjacent sports bar to procure a beverage prior to his belated acknowledgment of our arrival. It was approximately 6:30 p.m. on a Saturday evening.

As a fervent Milwaukeean residing at the Wynn, I felt compelled to partake in the culinary offerings of the in-house Bartolotta's restaurant, despite my ignorance of their origins as a Milwaukee export. However, my gastronomical journey was somewhat curtailed due to my personal aversion to seafood (which is flown in fresh from the Mediterranean daily), which I deemed excessively extravagant, albeit comprehensible given the arid climate's dearth of aquatic delicacies. Thus, I opted for a select few pasta dishes and a portion of pancetta. While the pancetta proved to be somewhat chewy and fatty, I anticipated such characteristics; nevertheless, it could have been more refined. In contrast, the sheep's milk ravioli delighted my taste buds, although the spaghetti accompanied by ragu could have been more flavorful. Ultimately, my satisfaction with Bartolotta's was limited, primarily due to the premium pricing; nevertheless, I acknowledge that dining alfresco might have enhanced my overall experience. In my modest opinion, the Wynn would greatly benefit from incorporating Bartolotta's Lake Park Bistro, a Milwaukee staple, into its establishment.

Back in June I wrote an unsatisfactory review of this company due to them damaging our gazebo from the fallen palm tree branches. We've come to an agreement and they were nice enough to replace/compensate for the damages it caused. Thank you for that so I'm sure it won't happen again. They have been nice enough to work things out with us no matter what and has shown good customer service regarding the issue. It has been resolved nicely.

I visted Edinburgh on my honeymoon in September. Our first full day of exploring must start with a bountiful breakfast so we had energy to explore all day. We strolled down to the Grassmarket from our hotel on Prince's St. Looking up and down, we chose Cafe Jacques because it had the most customers dining. A good indicator is how busy the place is, right?

We squeezed in, and I DO mean squeezed because it's tiny, and found a seat. I had a traditional English breakfast and my hubbie the American. The coffee was SO HOT and I made the mistake of trying to gulp my first taste as I tried to caffeinate my jetlagged self. My mouth was scorched for the next two days at least. Although we received a weird look, the waiter brought my husband two tall glasses of milk on request. Is that an American thing to drink milk with breakfast?

As my three stars indicate, this place was A-OK and got us going on our first full day in Edinburgh.

Yesterday, I had an imperative to convene with a patron hailing from the northern region of the valley, and coincidentally, I had several other clients to visit in Deer Valley. Owing to the dearth of establishments in the vicinity that serve breakfast and are not part of a chain, I opted to dine at this particular eatery. Arriving at 8 a.m., I presumably avoided the majority of patrons who typically frequent the restaurant for breakfast or acquire sustenance for lunch. The proprietor of the establishment exhibited a somewhat abrasive demeanor, although I hastened to acclimate myself to his disposition in a relatively brief period. 

I placed an order for the Max burrito, which includes an assortment of ingredients such as egg, potato, cheese, and a choice between bacon, sausage, or ham, all for the sum of $4.29. The culinary creation was quite flavorsome, albeit its dimensions were of a moderate magnitude. Considering the price per ounce, it becomes evident that the cost is approximately twice that of a comparable burrito offered by nearby Mexican fast-food restaurants. This discrepancy in pricing can be attributed, in part, to the prime location of the establishment in Deer Valley, as well as the associated employee expenses. 

During my visit, a steady influx of patrons entered the premises, although the atmosphere remained unpretentious and unhurried. However, it is worth noting that accessing the parking area can prove challenging due to the proximity of the Dunkin' Donuts located at the opposite end of the building, which tends to generate a considerable backup. Notwithstanding, I am inclined to revisit this establishment in the future, primarily due to its non-chain status, passable cuisine, and agreeable service.

"To provide clarity and resolve the prevailing confusion regarding the three China Stars within the city limits, I shall elucidate the distinctions between them.
