Through my daily commute, I have observed both China Stars situated on Murray Avenue (across the street from a Giant Eagle store, curiously positioned to intensify the enigma), and upon investigating their addresses, I have ascertained the following factsâ?

1. THIS CHINA STAR: 
-Location: 4219 Murray Avenue, Greenfield 
-Occupies the former site of Yen's Gourmet 
-Lacks any affiliation with the China Star in the North Hills 
-Offers standard American-Chinese cuisine 

2. THE OTHER CHINA STAR (<http://www.yelp.com/biz/china-star-pittsburgh-3>): 
-Address: 1900 Murray Avenue, Squirrel Hill 
-Former site of Pacific Ring 
-Associated with the China Star in the North Hills 
-Serves traditional Chinese fare 

Thus, there exists a definitive dichotomy between the two China Stars along Murray Avenue. Personally, I have solely patronized this particular China Star and cannot comment on its counterpart. 

When it comes to Chinese takeoutâspecifically, affordable, oily, fried âChineseâ?foodâChina Star excels. Although every Chinese takeout establishment with the ubiquitous red menu appears identical, I feel compelled to share my thoughts on one such eatery on Yelp. However, after sampling various Chinese options in Pittsburgh based on price and accessibility, I must confess that China Star ranks as my top choice. Their dishes simply taste superior."

I'm going to settle this once and for all, since everyone seems beyond confused about the three China Stars in town. I drive past both of the Murray Ave China Stars every day (both located across the street from a Giant Eagle, presumably just to puzzle us more) and based on the addresses have confirmed the following--

THIS CHINA STAR:
-4219 Murray Ave, in Greenfield
-At the old location of Yen's Gourmet
-No affiliation with the China Star in the North Hills
-Standard American-Chinese food

THE OTHER CHINA STAR (http://www.yelp.com/biz/china-star-pittsburgh-3):
-1900 Murray Ave, in Squirrel Hill
-At the old location of Pacific Ring
-Affiliated with the China Star in the North Hills
-Traditional Chinese food

So, there you have it. A guide to the China Stars of Murray Avenue. I, personally, have only ordered from this China Star and cannot comment on the other.

For Chinese takeout--and I mean cheap, greasy, fried "Chinese" food--China Star is awesome. I mean, yeah, every Chinese takeout place with the infamous red menu is pretty much the same, and I feel stupid even writing a review of one on Yelp. But I get a craving for General Tso's Chicken, Pork Lo Mein, Cold Sesame Noodles, and Fried Dumplings about once a month, and now having tried several of Pittsburgh's Chinese options based on price and convenience, I gotta say China Star is my number one choice. Everything just tastes GOOD. I totally can't justify giving a Chinese restaurant more than 3 stars, but next time you feel the need to pig out on greasy takeout food, I'd highly recommend China Star.

cooked food are ok. but the ingredients selection is not high quality. nice decor but services could be better. Got to try the fried bananas, which is the best thing I like in this japanese all u can eat restaurant!
Fish and chips typical irish fare, have some good bands that plays there as well great for happy hour and hang outs great staff as well. U2 tribute band Joshua tree usually plays out there.

This place is cool, but it pales in comparison to the Foundation Room, which sits at the top of the same hotel.  The music here was okay and the atmosphere here is kinda cool, but get yourself on the list for the Foundation Room to check out the cool club at Mandalay Bay.

"Despite my profound affection for Rugged Wearhouse, I must express my consternation regarding an anomaly I encountered during a recent visit to the establishment. Specifically, I purchased a pair of boots for $25, a reasonable price point, yet the label affixed to the footwear bore a discrepancy in pricing, indicating a value of $20. Perplexed by this incongruity, I opted to acquire the boots regardless, but I cannot help but wonder why the store would deliberately attach a tag proclaiming a higher price than the item's actual worth, particularly when sold at a department store. This seemingly trivial detail has sparked a sense of annoyance within me."

I really like the ambiance of Beckett's Table, from the way the restaurant is set up to their water glasses and table settings. I just didn't fall in love with their food. 

I liked the bacon cheddar buscuits, but would have liked them more if the apple honey butter wasn't so rock hard and was easily spreadable. I tried to the green chile pork stew and the osso buco and I definitely wasn't blown away by either of them. Neither dish had anything special to it, not to say they were bad, but didn't overly impress me. 

My favorite dish was probably the chocolate dipped bacon s'mores. I definitely went out on a limb ordering this, but I was pleasently surprised. The homemade peanut butter was excellent and all of the parts of this dessert complimented each other very well.

"Situated in close proximity to the Henderson Whole Foods, LYFE Kitchen enjoys an optimal location that makes it an establishment of considerable convenience for those seeking nourishment. Prior to embarking on our regular shopping excursion, we opted to partake of a culinary experience at this eatery, thus we ventured a short distance to savor their offerings. My order consisted of a vegan Thai curry bowl, accompanied by a hibiscus tea, while my companion chose a grass-fed burger, complemented by a cafe mocha. 
 
The beverages proved to be truly exceptional, as the hibiscus tea displayed an impressive degree of flavor and refreshment, and the cafe mocha was described as satisfying and invigorating. However, the primary courses gave rise to some misgivings, specifically regarding their modest proportions and questionable composition. Although my vegan Thai curry bowl possessed commendable taste, its spiciness surpassed my expectations, and it lacked a sufficient amount of wheat berries and tofu, instead featuring an abundance of secondary vegetables. The grass-fed burger of my companion was deemed satisfactory, with a subtle smoky flavor, yet it failed to satiate our hunger entirely, prompting us to crave additional sustenance. Furthermore, concerns regarding the organic nature of the tofu and grass-fed beef arose, leading me to ponder the rationale behind consuming non-organic ingredients at an establishment that purports to prioritize health-consciousness. 
 
Despite these reservations, we might revisit LYFE Kitchen to sample alternative menu selections, but we will be certain to arrive with lesser degrees of hunger."

I've never been terribly impressed with the food. Way overpriced for the mediocre entrees they're serving up. But this is a great place to go for drinks & appetizers - sit on the patio around the fountain. The appetizers are decent and fairly priced and the ambiance is really nice. I like to take tourists here when they visit me. (Then if they're still hungry, we'll go to Los Sombreros for dinner!)\n\nDo try their homemade tortillas with flavored butter - they're better than anything on the menu.
The food was really good, but the service was bad. The waitress was hard to find and they were far from busy. It also took like 5 minutes just to get a soda & the same amount of time for water.

It's like Samurai Sam's, but not as good. \n\nThe prices are reasonable and the portions decent, but the steak is really too thin for my liking.  The sauce is ok.  It's actually not as sweet as other places in town (I prefer it more soy/salty than sweet) and they give you a small container if you want more.

"We were compelled to revise our assessment subsequent to sampling the Thin Crust variety, which regrettably failed to meet our expectations in terms of both taste and texture. The pizza was utterly deplorable, and its removal from the menu would be a judicious decision. Despite being persuaded by staff members that it was superior to alternatives offered by Rosati's and Oregano's, we were sadly mistaken. The crust was unyielding and tasted more like cardboard than dough, rendering it nearly impossible to bite into. However, the Penne pasta accompanied by a rich meat sauce proved to be an agreeable exception to the disappointing pizza experience. If pizza remains your primary preference, we suggest adhering to the Butter Crust Deep Dish option."

"My initial experience at this recently established Panera Bread location warrants a three-star evaluation, primarily due to the extended waiting period for takeout, despite the excellent service provided by the counter staff. Upon realizing that several patrons who placed their orders prior to mine were dining in, thereby contributing to the delay, I appreciated the quality of the sandwiches, particularly the Cuban chicken panini and the signature Steak and white cheddar, which boasted an impressive level of flavor enhanced by the horseradish spread. Notably, the presentation of the meals in two compact cardboard boxes was thoughtfully executed, yet lacking an effective means of identifying the distinct sandwiches without removing parts of the bread. In light of this concern, I submitted a recommendation to the headquarters, which elicited a positive response expressing their intention to examine the matter further. My future plans include revisiting this establishment and taking advantage of the inviting dining area or outdoor seating when the weather permits."

A good club, no casino, no pool or extra whistles found inside nothing extravagant here. 54 it's strictly a dance club. Just dancing, drinking, chilling with friends and enjoying the tunes. 80s music is played a bit too much some nights if you ask me but then the DJ switches it up and you start dancing to the current tunes you like without feeling weird about it. One night, Floyd Mayweather hosted his official boxing fight Afterparty here. The dude made it rain\n\n54 tends to be frequent by an older good looking crowd, late 20s to late 30s with some just turn 21 hotties mixed in. But the best part of studio 54 is the gogo dancers, they're pretty cool, will talk and say hi to you and for what they wear, leaves very little to the imagination. So try not to get carried away!
Unfortunately, we didn't have dessert.  Instead, we had brunch, and enjoyed it, although the potato pancakes were weak.  If I go back, I'll try dessert or go late in the day and sit at the bar.

Being that I had resided in South Carolina for an extensive period of time, I wasn't anticipating a particularly exceptional culinary experience in Hokkaido, as my previous exposure to seafood dishes in the region had been limited to uninspired, overcooked Americanized adaptations of traditional Chinese cuisine. However, upon perusing the menu at this particular establishment, I was pleasantly surprised to discover a few intriguing and palatable options. My companion enjoyed some of the cooked beef dishes, while I personally found the crab and sushi to be satisfactory, despite the latter not being as impressive as I had hoped. The seaweed salad surpassed my expectations, and I must admit that the chocolate fountain was a delightful indulgence. 
  Notwithstanding my general satisfaction with the cuisine, I must confess that I had envisioned a more distinct ambiance for the restaurant, as the present atmosphere was somewhat marred by the presence of boisterous children in the seating area and elsewhere throughout the premises. It is worth noting that while the eatery imposes an additional fee for wasted food, it would perhaps be reasonable to consider implementing a similar charge for disruptive juveniles, in order to maintain a more pleasant dining environment for patrons.

"I had the misfortune of lodging at this establishment for a solitary night this week, and my experience was marred by a plethora of issues. The furniture, including the sofa, was covered in a thick layer of dust, giving the impression that it had not been cleaned in some time. The coffee maker and hair dryer were both grimy and unhygienic, and I could continue enumerating the deficiencies in the room's maintenance. Furthermore, I was unable to procure an itemized room service receipt or even a receipt for my stay via email, which led me to question the hotel's preparedness for guests. While the location may be convenient for some, I would strongly advise against selecting this hotel for accommodations. Instead, I would recommend the HGV on the strip, which boasts exceptional upkeep and customer service."

Stayed for one night this week.  Furniture (even the couch) was dusty.  Dirty coffee maker, filthy hair dryer...I could go on...

Could not get an itemized room service receipt or even a receipt for my stay emailed to me.  It is almost like they opened the hotel without being ready.  

I would recommend this hotel for the location only.  If you are in town for work, I would highly recommend the HGV on the strip.  Very well maintained and amazing customer service.

Rehab burger is your total local dive bar but has a cool vibe to it as well. They offer great drink specials, and have a great burger menu. I had there Hangover burger with the sweet potato tots and to me it was pretty mediocre plus I ordered my burger medium rare and received a well done burger so of course I am sure that had something to do with the taste. Would I go back and give em another shot? Probably not considering there are alot more great burger joints in Scottsdale.

While my desire for Art Your Way (AYW) to be more economical in pricing persists, it remains an enjoyable venue for children to explore their artistic inclinations. The staff, with a few exceptions, has demonstrated a propensity towards cordiality and helpfulness. However, there have been isolated incidents where younger female employees appeared to prioritize interpersonal interactions amongst themselves over attending to customers, although this does not seem to be standard practice. Notably, the efficiency of their turnaround time is commendable, typically requiring only a few days for completion, much to the satisfaction of clients.

"I thoroughly enjoy the culinary offerings and the geographic convenience of this establishment, and the rooftop patio is an idyllic setting in which to indulge in said culinary delights. However, I must express my utter dismay and consternation at the exorbitant prices charged for potations. It appears that the proprietors have adopted a pricing strategy more commonly associated with gentlemen's clubs or high-end cocktail lounges, with beverages priced at a premium that is unprecedented in the local market. As a former employee of various drinking establishments, I am cognizant of the factors that contribute to the cost of libations, and I must aver that these prices are unreasonable and will unlikely resonate well with the local patronage. A more judicious approach to pricing would be advisable, lest the clientele opt for alternative beverages or, heaven forbid, take their business elsewhere. A modicum of fiscal restraint would be wise, lest the establishment suffer financial duress due to an overzealous attempt to recoup investment costs in the early stages of operation."

I love the food, location is great, love the rootop patio...no problems there\n\nBUT...the drink prices are FRIGGIN OUTRAGEOUS, as has been mentioned in other reviews. To get drink prices this high you either have to be drinkin' in a strip bar  or one of the ultra chi-chi bars uptown like Blue.....at least $2 higher on beer and $3-4 higher on drinks than ANY OTHER P-Wood bar. As I've worked in bars before I understand how drinks are priced and these prices are NOT gonna be popular around here. Everyone that I've heard talk about it has the same thing to say: \"great food, great location, plan on drinking tea or soda when you go unless you want to go broke..\"...C'Mon guys, you don't have to recoup your investment the 1st month by gouging folks on drinks; price them reasonably and you'll be around for a long time to make money...

"A thoroughly unremarkable, pedestrian establishment specializing in the culinary delights of fried dough, this donut shop boasts an impressive array of delectable treats that are sure to satiate even the most discerning palate. Maintaining a fastidious level of cleanliness, this eatery is open for business around the clock, conveniently situated alongside a Subway restaurant. The donuts themselves are freshly prepared, ensuring an optimal taste experience for patrons. Of particular note is the devil's food cake, whose moist texture and rich, chocolate flavor make it a standout item on the menu. Additionally, the glazed donuts are endowed with a pleasing sweetness that complements their subtle crunch. While it is true that some may prefer the offerings of Winchell's over those of Dunkin' Donuts or Krispy Kreme, it is important to recognize that such preferences are inherently subjective and often vary from person to person. In conclusion, this humble abode of gastronomic delight warrants a respectable grade of C, with its selection of edibles being suitably diverse and satisfying."

I have invariably been an ardent devotee of Outback, and my unwavering allegiance to this esteemed eatery has been consistently rewarded with a culinary experience that transcends the mundane and ascends to the realm of gastronomical excellence. Upon entering the establishment, I customarily opt for a seat at the bar, where the hospitable staff, with their unfailing affability and solicitous demeanor, orchestrate an atmosphere of conviviality and warmth that permeates the entire dining area. In a recent visit, I elected to sample their takeout offerings, and my expectations were once again met with an impressive display of culinary prowess, as the salmon and broccoli were prepared to perfection, with each bite showcasing the ideal balance of flavors and textures. However, my enthusiasm was momentarily curtailed by the sweet potato, which, regrettably, had been subjected to an excessive duration of thermal exposure, rendering it tragically overcooked and resembling a culinary casualty of an unfortunate magnitude. Nonetheless, this minor faux pas did not diminish my overall satisfaction with the meal, as the remaining components more than compensated for this isolated lapse in culinary judgment.

I have always been an Outback fan. For a chain restaurant, Outback does a really good job. I typically sit at the bar and the bar staff is ALWAYS friendly and accommodating. Last week I decided to take out. I ordered salmon, broccoli and a sweet potato. The salmon and broccoli were very good - they were cooked the right way and seasoned well. The sweet potato however was so overcooked it was as if they had kept it in the oven for several months ;-) Just kidding but the po-ta-to was killed to be sure.\nA minor detail but worth mentioning.

"Celebrated my natal anniversary at this culinary establishment in the company of colleagues and found the ambiance to be quite pleasing, thus prompting a return visit during the restaurant's 'happy hour' period, whereupon I experienced an enjoyable social interaction with acquaintances.  

While the prices may be considered somewhat elevated, the attentive and courteous demeanor of our server, a young woman adorned with a robot-themed tattoo, greatly enhanced our dining experience. 

Personally, I found the mixed drinks to be superior in quality compared to the food offerings, specifically the POLYNESIAN CHICKEN SANDWICH accompanied by SWEET POTATOE FRIES, which proved to be a satisfying culinary choice.  

The assortment of beverages available was quite impressive, and I would recommend attempting the Scorpion bowl, ideally in the presence of multiple companions."

We eat here occasionally and the experience is consistent and mediocre. More Arby's than Subway, because the ingredients are uninspiring. Nor is it a great value in that it is only slightly less expensive than real sushi. All that said, it is convenient fast and strangely satisfying

Loved the set up..drinks. .and staff were friendly. .but the bald manager with the moon boot on ..totally had some kind of attitude. .even our waitress said he was a jerk..\nOther then that I would go back amd totally avoid this dick..prices are decent. .I only had appetizers they were ok..

It causes me immense consternation to pen an update for this establishment, given the sublime encounters I experienced during my previous visits. However, my recent appointments have been marred by considerable delays, which may be attributable to the peak hours during which they were scheduled. Specifically, my appointments took place at 5:30 pm, a time when working individuals often visit after work, resulting in a substantial wait time. On both occasions, I endured a prolonged wait of approximately 30 to 45 minutes in the waiting area, followed by an additional 15 to 20 minutes in the examination room before being attended to. 

Despite the extended delay, I must acknowledge that Dr. Langford displayed genuine remorse for the inconvenience caused, which somewhat alleviated my frustration. Nonetheless, it is reasonable to assume that the clinic could mitigate such waits by avoiding overbooking appointments, particularly during peak hours. Notwithstanding the delay, I continued to receive the doctor's unwavering attention and dedication, which made the wait relatively more tolerable. 

Regrettably, my interactions with certain staff members have been unsatisfactory. During two separate instances, I contacted the clinic and spoke to an individual who exhibited discourteous behavior. In the first instance, she failed to follow up on a query despite her assurance to do so, leaving me with unanswered questions. In the second instance, she provided an incorrect response, claiming that she had previously furnished me with the information when, in fact, she had not. Such conduct is unacceptable, especially towards devoted patients who have consistently sought care at this facility. 

Although my recent experiences have been less than satisfactory, I must acknowledge that other staff members have demonstrated kindness and proficiency in their roles. My satisfaction with the majority of the staff and my doctor remains intact, albeit slightly diminished due to the unfortunate events described above. Consequently, I award 3.5 stars instead of the perfect 5 stars.

The ambiance of this establishment exudes an aura of conviviality, rendering it an optimal venue for spectating athletic competitions. The personnel appear to be attentive and concerned with ensuring that patrons enjoy their experience. The menu boasts an array of delectable options, and the culinary offerings are generally perceived as savory and satisfying, particularly for a drinking establishment. However, my personal encounters at this location have been marred by instances of lukewarm fare arriving at my table, which has engendered a sense of displeasure and disappointment.

"As a neophyte, I indulged in my first meal of the day at this establishment, which offered an alimentary experience that was somewhat expensive but nonetheless delectable and served in an ambiance that was singularly captivating. Being present prior to the commencement of the midday repast, the venue was remarkably tranquil, with nary a soul in sight. However, my encounter was slightly marred by the youthful mechanical attendants, whose lack of warmth and courtesy, manifested in their failure to proffer a simple greeting or smile, detracted from the overall quality of my visit, thereby rendering it less exceptional than it could have been."

First timer had breakfast. A little pricey but the food was very good and atmosphere was unique (in a good way).   We were there just before lunch started so it wasn't busy at all. The only disappointment was the young robotic staff. A genuine smile and \"good morning\" would go a long way to making this a special place.

"The culinary offerings presented at this establishment deviate considerably from the conventional Charlotte menu, boasting an array of deep-fried delights that, while undoubtedly flavorsome, fail to possess the fiery or piquant qualities one might anticipate. Despite these departures from the norm, the venue maintains a relaxed ambiance, rendering it an appropriate setting for a casual luncheon excursion and ensuring that return visits are indeed plausible."

It is not your average-Charlotte menu. Most of the food is fried and it is certainly flavorful, but I wouldn't say spicy or hot. \n\nIt is a decent casual place to grab lunch and I would certainly go back.

"It is a peculiar occurrence, indeed, when I opt to dine at an establishment with another individual and, subsequent to perusing Yelp, discover that said eatery possesses a mere two-star rating. The hospitality we received was somewhat unorthodox; specifically, the host's articulations were utterly incomprehensible to both myself and my fellow diner. Furthermore, there was a considerable delay between the arrival of my companion's soup and my own, and the noodles accompanying my duck meat soup were arguably undercooked. Notwithstanding these issues, the broth proved satisfying, as did the duck meat I managed to extract from the murky liquid. However, a dubious, overly salty, and potentially seaweed-like substance floated in my bowl, casting doubt upon its quality. Considering the premium prices charged by this particular venue (located within Caesar's Palace, no less), it seems wiser to venture outside and explore alternative dining options."

Russ suggested My Florist for lunch since we were in the area, but I said, "well I always go there at night and while sitting at My Florist, see this cute little lunch place across the street that I've been wanting to try, so let's go there." 

It's good for a quick lunch and an alternative to fast food (anything is better than the F food).

I got the chicken feta pita, it was okay, kinda boring.  I think I liked the design of the place better than the food. So, ++ for good marketing and design, now if they'd do something more interesting with the menu :)

"Pink's Hot Dogs, I am utterly perplexed as to how you successfully enticed me into consuming your culinary offerings, yet somehow you managed to do so. A coterie of individuals, including myself, opted to partake in a gastronomical excursion to your esteemed establishment, primarily due to the widespread acclaim and praise that it has received from various patrons. My adventurous palate led me to order the Chili Cheese hot dog burrito, which consisted of two frankfurters enveloped in a tortilla along with chili and cheese. Although it provided a fleeting sense of satisfaction during a night of indulgence, I must admit that it had a rather deleterious impact on my digestive system. Perhaps, if I were to patronize your restaurant again in the future, I would be wise to opt for a more rudimentary hot dog, thus avoiding any potential gastrointestinal repercussions."

Pink's, I don't know how you seduced me, but you did. \n\nA small group of us stopped here because we were hungry and have heard people rave about this place. I was feeling brave and got the Chili Cheese hot dog burrito with two dogs, chili and cheese wrapped in a tortilla. It did the trick for a drunken evening, but man talk about super upset stomach! Maybe if I ever ate there again I should just try the basic hot dog.

"One of my preferred destinations due to its proximity to my place of employment, situated directly across from the building, thereby rendering it easily accessible via foot. The parking facilities are quite satisfactory, and even more so for myself, as I am able to traverse the short distance by walking. The prices of consumables are rather reasonable, with a hot dog or soda available for $4, and a combination package consisting of a hot dog, beverage, and popcorn offered at the affordable cost of $11. The vantage points afforded by the seating arrangement are quite acceptable, and provide ample opportunity for enthusiasts to pursue autographs from players. However, it is regrettable that the outfield grass is absent, a feature that has been lamented by another commentator. Additionally, the sensation experienced within one's gluteal region subsequent to occupying the metal bleacher-style seats positioned along the left field line for an extended period of time is less than desirable, although at a cost of $7, coupled with the advantageous parking, favorable location, and economical concessions, I find myself quite content."

One of my favorite locations because it is conveniently located across from my work building. The parking is good - even better for me since I can walk. The concessions are cheap - $4 for a hot dog or soda. A combo pack of a hot dog, drink and popcorn for $11. The views are good and provides good access to players if you want to try for an autograph. As another reviewer pointed out, there is no outfield grass, which is a disappointment. Another thing that is down is the feeling in your ass after sitting on the metal bleacher style seats down the left field line  - but for $7, good parking, nice location and cheap concessions, I am a fan.

"Optimize for DATE NIGHT or collective encounter

As an ardent devotee of hiking, white water rafting, and running, I must confess that my experience at Victory Lanes fell short of my expectations. The underwhelming sensation of traversing in circular motions at high velocities, coupled with the physical constraints of the kart, did not conform to my notion of an enjoyable escapade. However, I am willing to accord it another opportunity, provided that I am accompanied by a coterie of companions who share my fervor for adventure. 

Location: Prominently visible from the highway, although utilizing GPS is advisable to avoid any confusion. 
Price: We opted for a membership pass. 
Staff: Capable of responding to inquiries; be prepared to sign a waiver. 
Children can observe as spectators, but I would not recommend entrusting them with the responsibility of operating the vehicles. 
Bathrooms garner a rating of 2/5, primarily due to their limited capacity and inadequacy as dressing rooms. 
The suites, on the other hand, merit acclaim for their inventive and visually stunning designs, which undoubtedly contribute to the overall excitement and make for impressive photographs."

Recommend for DATE NIGHT or group experience

So I am a hiking, white water rafting, run on a regular type of woman.
I am all about active activities, yet my experience at Victory Lanes was really disappointing. Riding in circles at high speeds and cramped in a kart aren't my idea of a good time. It just did not wow me, but I will give it another try if I had a group of friends.

Location: Easy to spot from highway, but use GPS or you will get lost 
Price: we bought a members pass
Staff: Able to answer questions; prepare to sign your life away
Children can act as spectators, but I wouldnt encourage driving
Bathrooms would get a 2/5 not big enough for dressing room.
Suites are cool and help with excitement, the look awesome in pictures.

So the first time I went here, I don't remember a thing. Did I have a good time? I think I did.

Anyway, I went to Rok again and it wasn't that bad. In comparison to other clubs, this place isn't that bad. The bar service was slow but the music was usually good.  

Good: This place is good, if you get in for free.

Bad: Not my number one choice in Vegas.

Final: If you can get in for free or close to it, this place is the place to be.

"My acquaintance and I are embarking on an expedition to discover the most delectable steak in the Valley, hence every time we gather for dinner, we opt to sample a distinct steak restaurant. Our excursion to Fleming's fell short of my expectations. 

I had been apprised of Fleming's exceptional happy hour offerings, which indeed presented numerous remarkable options. I shall return for that purpose. The service was adequate; we were seated at the bar. Furthermore, they boasted an impressive wine list with reasonable price points. 

Nonetheless, with regard to the steak: mine was cooked beyond my requested doneness (medium) and lacked sufficient trimming (I chose a filet). The sides were forgettable."

A friend and I are on a quest to find the best steak in the Valley, so every time we meet for dinner, we choose a different steak place to try. Our visit to Fleming's was far below my expectations. 

I had heard wonderful things about Fleming's for their happy hour, and, indeed, the happy hour has some great options. I'll return for that. Service was decent; we remained at the bar. And there was a fantastic wine selection with reasonable prices. 

However, when it comes to steak: mine was overcooked (I ordered it medium) and not sufficiently trimmed (I got a filet). Sides were unmemorable.

Great place for a quick cheap meal. If your new to Filipino food, I would start off with the barbecue and pancit. If you're feeling more adventurous, try the dinuguan (blood stew) or balut (fertilized duck egg), if available. My mom still makes better dinuguan and pancit but this place is pretty good for price and convenience. I prefer to get take-out because sometimes they play terrible and depressing Filipino dramas on their TVs. The constant crying in the background is not appetizing.

Ok, I am not going to talk about the service too much because I think It's a cultural issue. their wait service is NOT friendly at all. The waitress and waiter do not know how to smile.

However, I have to say that the service never detracts us from going there. The reason is the food is so good. If you are there during there lunch special, try the shredded pork pan fried noodles order it "Hong Kong Style"

Our second favorite dish is the salt and pepper shrimps with the head on. Some people find eating the head weird, but it is so rich.

The third dish to try is the salt fish and chicken fried rice. Salty but really good. I know this is not the typical "American ordering Chinese food" (i.e. General Cho's Chicken and Shrimp fried rice) type of order but trust me These are the best things on the menu.
The fish department was good someone always there to help and didn't wait to long but they need to train \"Tyler\" the cashier on good customer service :)

The service here is ok, depending on the time of day.  What is pretty funny is in the morning the first thing we always got asked was if we needed a drink to cure our hangover.   So on Saturday and Sunday I ordered the Chicken Fried Steak for breakfast.  It was pretty good. Anywhere I go, if a place has chicken fried steak, I'll try it.  This place did not disappoint.  On Sunday everyone at my table ordered Chicken Friend Steak accept one person, because I thought it was good. After they tried it, they were glad they ordered it.  It has the right amount of batter to meat ratio.\n\nI didn't like the coffee shake.  It didn't taste like coffee, and Jack in the box can make a better shake.  But I will go there anytime I stay at the Hard Rock and really there is either this or the Pink Taco. Pink Taco was good too, but that is another review.

Not the best car wash on Bell road that's for sure. Two times I have brought my car for a wash and the keys were left in my vehicle. This scares me as auto theft is huge in Arizona. Customer service is so-so. I usually bring my vehicle early morning before 9. If you want to get the early bird discount be sure to pay before 9am as I learned from experience. Brought my car in at 7am walked across the street to work, picked it up at lunchtime and paid to find out I can't get my early bird discount because the hand written receipts are not time stamped.

I want so much to love the Daily Dose.  It is in the perfect location for me to make it my go-to spot for weekend brunches.  But I just can't get 100% behind it.  Every time I'm there, I search the extensive menu over and over again for something that jumps out at me.  But every time, I find myself at a loss and just ordering an omelette or french toast or something equally banal.  I'll keep searching, but with every trip my hope dwindles.

It has a Vue Cinema, the entrance to Britannia, Starbucks, Bear Company, M&S Food-Court, H&M, Superdry, Fat Face, HMV, Boots, FCUK, Baxter, GAP,  Debenhams and a beautiful laid out Food Court - with Zizzi, Burger Company etc.. 

I do like the food-court,  with its view over Fife and new developments of Newhaven. (I compare those views with Blade Runner scenes..) 

Not my favourite shopping centre - as it is more like an main street shopping missing the charity shops (apart from the Superdry Store) 
I go shopping here when I have a few hours to spare on a Sunday. 

It is clean building in and out and has got a straightforward layout  rectangular and 3 stories high. 

There is a car park and a bus terminus for Lothian buses 22, 35, 34, 36, 11
Also the tourist buses stop here. 

There are (still) plans to extend the (in)famous tram line to here but those are currently shelved

One of the smallest airport in the U.S.  Flew here for a short layover to Greenville (GSP).  Can't really stand small airport since all the planes are so small and me being 6'4\" is very difficult to sit comfortably in my seat.  Next time I'll fly into big airports.

Last night, we endeavored to partake in the culinary offerings of this establishment, and our experience was somewhat dichotomous. The ambiance was quite vibrant, with a considerable number of patrons present at 9:30 pm on a Tuesday. The interior design was tasteful and effectively utilized the available space. We sampled their miniature burgers, which were rather delectable. However, our interactions with the staff were not entirely satisfactory. A bartender approached my spouse and inquired about his desire for a beverage, yet failed to acknowledge my presence. Subsequently, my husband was served a beer that he had not requested. Two other bartenders demonstrated proficiency in their roles and exhibited a welcoming demeanor. Unfortunately, the initial bartender continued to neglect us throughout our visit, leaving our drinks unreplenished and ignoring us for an extended period of time after we had pressed the button to signal for payment. A fourth bartender proved adept at collecting empty plates and glasses, but did not inquire about our need for any additional assistance. Considering their recent opening, I may grant them another opportunity to demonstrate their capabilities.

Tried it out last night and I have mixed feelings. It was busy at 9:30pm on a Tuesday.  The decor is nice and they made a good use of the space. We tried the sliders and they were good. We sat at the bar and a bar tender came up and asked my husband if he wanted a drink but did not even acknowledge me.  My husband was then served a beer he did not ask for. Two of the other bartenders were very nice and clearly knew what they were doing. The bartender who ignored me then decided to ignore both us for the rest of our stay. Never refilled our drinks and we waited 20 minutes after hitting the cash out button before anyone came to check on us. There was a forth bartender who was good at collecting plates and glasses but didn't ask if we needed anything else. I will probably give them one more chance since they are new.

We indulged in an alfresco dining experience during a balmy evening, whereupon we encountered a convivial gathering of ten individuals who were engaging in rapid consumption of potent beverages. This confluence of events somewhat diminished our culinary enjoyment, as five members of the group were also partaking in noxious fumes, thereby creating an atmosphere that was less than optimal for our server, who, despite his valiant efforts, appeared somewhat overburdened by the sheer magnitude of the large party. Furthermore, he was requested to capture photographic memories for three separate tables, which, in our opinion, bordered on the unseemly side of things. Notwithstanding these minor drawbacks, the cuisine proved to be quite satisfactory, with only a single order being erroneous, albeit marginally so, and we chose to accept it with equanimity. Specifically, we received a fajita chimmichonga instead of the conventional chicken variety, yet it still managed to tantalize our taste buds. All things considered, we would unhesitatingly revisit this establishment.

We sat outside since it was a nice night. There was a party of 10 outside that immediately started doing shots. Add that to the fact that 5 of them were smoking and it took away from the experience. Our server did his best but was a bit overwhelmed from the large party. And was asked to take photos by 3 different tables. Tacky on the patrons part. He was clearly struggling as it was. The food was good, even though one of our orders was wrong. We chalked it up and took it. It was close. Fajita chimmichonga instead of just chicken. Still was good. Would definitely go back.

This Whole Foods is the baby bear of the three in town, but doesn't skimp on selection or variety. I don't come to this one too often, but I do like the feel it has just because it is in a smaller space.

I did notice they have an attractive produce section that included nopales! Their produce section is always really nicely put together when I'm there and very rarely do I see anything out of place-but again, I don't come in here that often.

Their meat counter is significantly smaller than the other two locations, but deli, salad bar, prepared foods section were about the same size as the other locations.

All in all, a decent branch of this chain.

What's better than mini golf? Mini golf with drunk people! After DW we came here to pass some time before those who did bottomless mimosas red glow receeded. Thanks Anthony M. for treating us to mini golf. You're nice and sassy when you're drunk. 

I think the name Putt Park is accurate as it was more like putting course than mini golf with fun themes. So judging purely from the course though, I wish they tried to at least make a few of them more difficult and unique. There were some that was rather similar. Still it was a good way to pass time and have fun bonding silly time with some of the best people. We did try to play a normal game, at least I did since I was pretty sober, but the drunkeness took over. A few times it took everyone to get the ball in which was entertaining. Aayyeeehehe. 

For $8.50 it is decent enough and at least your ball doesn't disappear into a hole that takes it like a lot of mini golf places does. It could have replay value I suppose if you really like to putt and get the most out of your admission, but once was good for us. 

Best advice - come here after being plastered at DW during brunch and it would be way more fun and be a great way to spend your afternoon like we did.

(Yelp 100 Challenge 23/100)

hmm.. $20 lunch buffet (on a Monday). not bad. definitely cheaper than the Wynn.

I pretty much ransacked the cocktail shrimp station and must've eaten half their supply when we were there. i tried the lamb, duck, turkey, pretty much a little bit of everything. all was decent enough.. but nothing amazing. the lamb with mint jelly was probably the highlight of my meal, along with the napoleon (dessert). dessert is my favorite part of the meal! i was slightly disappointed that they didnt have crab or lobster, but i guess for $20 wut do you expect. sushi was california rolls.. the kind i can make at home. the service (aka the person bringing us drinks) was good. 

hmm.. wut else.. nothing else i can really say about the buffet here.. i think next time i'll try the buffet at Paris.

"The smorgasbord presents an impressive array of culinary delights, however, it is unfortunate that the experience has been marred by several alterations over the years. Specifically, there is now only a single station where patrons can procure crab or lobster, which often results in an excruciating wait time of up to 15 minutes merely to receive a plate, subsequent to the already prolonged period spent awaiting seating. Ostensibly, these changes have been implemented to minimize costs, while inadvertently burdening customers with an excessive delay. This aspect of the dining experience requires considerable enhancement. In former times, the buffet was markedly superior, and it appears that management is endeavoring to subtly diminish the quality without arousing patron suspicion. Consequently, I must deduct two stars from my overall rating."

The buffet is great, yet the downside is the changes over the years. There is only one station to get crab or lobster now. You can wait up to 15 min just for plate AFTER waiting to get seated. Obvious they are trying to reduce cost and make you wait a huge amount of time instead. This needs improvement. It used to be much better and they are seeing if they can get away with no one noticing. -2 stars for this.

The lobster pot pie was fabulous, as billed, but the service was lacking.  Our waiter disappeared for a half an hour.  They could have sold us a lot of drinks in that amount of time, but missed out.\nI realize the pot pie is a signature dish, but they should set a better expectation of how long it takes to get it to table.  Perhaps if we three women instead of fifty year old guys we would have gotten more attention.

"Similarly to Jenny, I must aver that A-ok is an apt description of this establishment in a nutshell. On a recent Saturday visit, I endeavored to alleviate my hangover at this purported burger haven, being an ardent devotee of carnivorous cuisine. While my expectations were partially met, certain aspects fell short of excellence. The service, however, was commendable; the staff exhibited remarkable hospitality and offered insightful recommendations to patrons. My culinary selection included the Pestorica burger, adorned with relish, pesto, and mozzarella, accompanied by a side of onion rings paired with diverse dipping sauces. Upon presentation, the burger's appearance was indeed impressive, boasting a generous size and vibrant colors from the vegetables and cheese. Unfortunately, the patty itself was too diminutive in thickness, rendering it incapable of retaining a desirable juicy, red center. Additionally, a pinch more seasoning would have elevated the flavors. The onion rings, though crispy, lacked the satisfying crunch of a well-executed batter, instead displaying a tendency towards greasiness and disintegration. In contrast, the Oreo milkshake I sampled subsequently proved to be a resounding success, reaching the pinnacle of excellence. In conclusion, while this eatery has the potential to rank among the premier burger joints in town, several aspects require refinement to realize such aspirations."

"On a recent Saturday morning, I opted to partake in the brunch offered at the establishment, arriving at approximately 11 am. Upon entry, I observed that the queue was not excessively prolonged, which I deemed to be a favorable circumstance. During my departure, I noticed that the venue had implemented several self-service payment kiosks, which I believed would be particularly advantageous when confronted with extensive queues.

The eatery featured an omelet station, from which I selected two eggs cooked to a doneness level described as 'over easy.' I would like to suggest that this option surpasses the quality of the egg mixture utilized in the creation of omelets, as well as the powdered eggs employed in scrambled eggs. In a separate section designated for breakfast fare, I discovered potatoes and Portuguese sausage.

Furthermore, I managed to assemble a sandwich consisting of salmon lox, capers, onions, and a croissant, which I considered to be quite satisfying. However, I did not observe any bagels among the available options. To conclude my repast, I elected to consume some fresh fruit accompanied by Greek yogurt.

While many items appeared appetizing, my associates expressed dissatisfaction with their selections. It is worth mentioning that the menu did not include high-end offerings such as prime rib, crab legs, or lamb. Nonetheless, I would rate the dining experience as a solid 2.5 or 3 stars, contingent upon one's culinary preferences and the practice of mindful eating habits."

I am having difficulty comprehending the essence of this establishment; despite my perception of their intentions, the culinary offerings fail to meet the standards of numerous upscale steakhouses in Las Vegas, and the prices are exorbitant. The sole rationalization I can muster is that the majority of patrons receive complimentary meals, thereby creating an illusion of luxury for ego-driven gamblers. While the quality of service is unquestionably exceptional, the discrepancy between the fare served and that offered by esteemed venues such as Cut, Delmonicos, and Del Frisco's is palpable. For those seeking an authentic Old Vegas ambiance, a visit to Hugos, located within the Four Queens, is recommended, as the cuisine is delectable, the atmosphere reminiscent of a bygone era, and the prices significantly lower than those of this establishment.

I don't quite get this place. I see what they are trying to do,but the food is not as good as most high end steak houses in Vegas and he prices are way too high. The only thing I can figure is most meals are comped and it makes the ego driven gamblers think they are really getting a three hundred dollar meal, your not. The service cannot get any better its  just the food does not compare to Cut,Delmonicos,Del frisco ect. If you want old Vegas feel go to Hugos in the four queens the food is good with the same mob look but the prices are one third this place

We selected this venue due to its proximity to the Luxor, where we were scheduled to attend a Tuesday evening performance. However, upon arriving at the establishment, we encountered an egregiously discourteous hostess whose behavior was utterly preposterous. Despite the absence of a waiting list, our group opted to proceed directly to the bar area with the intention of expediting our service. Following a brief interval of approximately five minutes, during which we had settled at what we believed to be a suitable table, the hostess, distinguished by her protracted blonde tresses, approached our party to inform us that we were, in fact, seated at a dining table, and subsequently escorted us back to the waiting area to await the availability of a table (apparently, there were no tables that met the criteria for "bar seating"). Subsequently, we endured an additional ten-minute delay, only to have the hostess return us to the identical table we had previously occupied. Her actions were truly baffling, as she carelessly flung the menus onto the table and promptly departed without affording us the opportunity to even take our seats. Our server, however, redeemed this dismal initial encounter with his exceptional attentiveness and proficiency, ably assisted by his busser, who displayed commendable teamwork in their efforts to accommodate our request for expedited service. While the culinary offerings were satisfactory, they did not particularly impress us; nevertheless, we did enjoy the steak quesadilla and steak/bacon tacos.

We chose this place because it was convenient for a Tuesday night show we were seeing at the Luxor.  Hostess reception was beyond rude and completely ridiculous.  There was no wait, but our party went to sit in the bar because we wanted quick service.  After sitting at what we thought was a bar table for about 5 minutes, the long-blond-haired hostess came up to tell us that we were at a dining table and escorted us back to wait for a table (apparently, there are no tables that qualify as \"bar seating\").  We stood there for another 10 minutes, just to have her take us back to the EXACT SAME TABLE!  She then, literally, tossed our menus on the table and walked away before we had even sat down.  Disbelief is the only word I can use to describe this experience.  Thankfully, our server more than made up for this terrible first impression.  There was good teamwork between him and his busser as they both worked hard to accommodate our need for speedy service.  Food was good, but nothing to get excited about.  We enjoyed the steak quesadilla and steak/bacon tacos.

If you want to stop off to see the worlds largest thermometer and have some food, then this stop is for you. The Mad Greek in itself is an ok place. There are two locations; one in Baker (near Death Valley) and then one near the entrance to LV. It's usually packed so if you like Greek food, then this may be for you. From what I remember, the falalel balls were tasty and weren't overly fried. A creamy Tahini sauce accompanies most dishes which is perfect since the weather here is HOT! The restaurant designed with roman statues and columns on the outside so you can't miss it when you are exiting. The inside is more like a greek cafeteria and is congested with a lot of seating space and people to match. The Baker stop has an option for a decent bathroom and like I said before, if you look to the left of the Mad Greek, you will see a large pole showing the temperature. This is the only one found in America and although it boasts that it shows the right temperature, its actually off a couple of degrees.

I genuinely aspired to relish this eateryâI reside in close proximity and was delighted to witness the establishment of yet another locally owned restaurant in Northeast Mesa. Alas, my expectations were not fulfilled, as the culinary offerings and hospitality failed to meet my standards. The tabletops were covered in adhesive substances, while the service was hastened, giving rise to the impression of being pressured to articulate our orders promptly. Moreover, the entrÃ©es were served mere moments after we had devoured our initial course, leaving us with an unsettling sensation of being rushed. Our meals were merely passable, failing to elicit any profound satisfaction. 

We initiated our repast with the bruschetta, which regrettably did not live up to our expectations. Despite the palatable toppings, the flatbread was unpleasantly cold and possessed a stale flavor. Personally, I prefer this delicacy when it is served on sliced bread, similar to how it is prepared at Postino or DâVine. 

My spouse opted for the orecchiette accompanied by sausage, which was unfortunately overseasoned with salt and featured underwhelming sausage. As for my selection, I chose the porcini ravioli complemented by a tomato cream sauce. While the dish had potential, the sauce was excessively salty, thereby diminishing its overall quality. 

The ambiance of the establishment was tolerable, boasting large televisions in the bar area. Although these displays may be suitable for patrons seated in the bar, they proved somewhat distracting from the dining area. 

In light of our underwhelming experience, it is improbable that we will revisit this restaurant, particularly considering the substantial cost involved.

"A remarkable geographic locale, but it is imperative that you ensure an early arrival and confirmation of your accommodations, as I learned the hard way during my visit in June 2010. Upon arriving well after the appointed hour of 11:00 PM on a weekday, I was dismayed to discover that the establishment did not have a suitable room available, and I was subsequently assigned to a space designated for those with auditory impairments who also partake in smoking; needless to say, this was not ideal. Following an extended period of time, specifically 2:00 PM the next day, I was finally able to take advantage of a superior room, which was indeed impressive. However, I must admit that I was somewhat miffed at having to return to my quarters in the early afternoon to await the upgrade, as it proved to be a tad inconvenient. Aside from these minor drawbacks, the lodging was passable, and the aquatic facility, while not particularly extravagant, served its purpose adequately."

Great location, but make sure you check in early! I checked in after 11pm on a wkday in June 10' and they didnt have a decent room available. I was put in a room for hearing impaired smokers! I had to wait until 2 pm the following day to be upgraded to a nicer room. The upgrade was amazing, but i was annoyed that i had to make sure i was back at my room early afternoon to change rooms. Other than that the hotel was OK. \n\n-oh & the pool isnt anything too fancy.

This mall is a lot smaller than the ones that I walked through in Vegas, especially since they don't have a huge number of stores for you to look at.

While the interiors and decorations of the mall looked really nice, the stores that they had were super pricey.

Well, if you want to take a nice little walk in a shopping area, then this place is okay to do so.

I had the privilege of witnessing the renowned Blue Man Group's performance last week, boasting an impressive longevity on the Las Vegas stage, with additional productions taking place in select cities nationwide. My anticipation was palpable, given their acclaimed reputation. However, despite certain captivating scenes, I felt that the show suffered from a lack of cohesion. The trio of blue men would engage in prolonged drumming sequences, only to abruptly shift their focus to ascending the audience's chairs without any discernible motivation. This was followed by a remarkable marshmallow-throwing feat that, although undeniably impressive, appeared somewhat disconnected from the preceding events. Perplexity ensued as I struggled to establish a connection between these diverse elements. 
  Notwithstanding, the show deserves commendation for its humor. The three blue men demonstrated impeccable comedic timing, resulting in several instances of unrestrained laughter. They also incorporated enjoyable audience participation, lending an air of unpredictability to each performance. Additionally, the simplicity of their humor made it suitable for a wide range of ages. 
  In conclusion, while the show provided entertainment, it fell short of both my elevated expectations and the cost of admission.

I saw the Blue Man Group last week with high expectations. It is one of the longest running shows in Las Vegas (although it is moving soon to the Monte Carlo) and is performed in a few other cities across the country. Understandably, I was excited.

And while there were many great scenes, I thought the show lacked continuity. The three blue men would spend 5-10 minutes beating on drums and then for seemingly no reason start climbing the chairs in the audience. Then in the next scene they performed a very impressive marshmellow throwing trick (I won't spoil it) that seemed really random in execution. While everything they did was impressive, I've seen similar things done on the streets of Las Vegas Boulevard. I was especially confused with what each had to do with one another.

The show does get points for humor though. The comedic timing of the three blue men was terrific and there were at least a couple full laugh-out-loud moments. They also had some fun audience participation that would presumably make each show a little different. Plus it was very simple, slap stick humor, so it was appropriate for the whole family.

Ultimately, I enjoyed the show but it just didn't live up to the hype or the price.

"I visited this establishment in the company of several colleagues, seeking a rapid midday repast. Having previously partaken of beverages at this locale, I was curious about the quality of their luncheon offerings. The Kilted Pig presents a diverse array of modestly priced fare (ranging from Â£3.50 to Â£8) that includes soups, sandwiches, baked potatoes, fish pie, risotto, and stovies. Furthermore, patrons can still peruse the regular menu. My associates and I opted for selections from the luncheon menu, and while the dishes may not have been particularly sophisticated, they were certainly satisfying and generously portioned. Our total expenditure for six meals, a bottle of wine, and three soft drinks amounted to a trifling Â£50, rendering our dining experience eminently affordable. Prior to our visit, I reserved a table, and upon divulging our requirement for a prompt turnaround, the accommodating staff furnished us with menus in advance, enabling us to place a pre-order before our arrival, thereby ensuring an efficient and satisfactory dining experience."

Came here with some work colleagues for a quick lunch. I've been for drinks a few times and I find it a reasonable local pub but wondered how it would be for lunch. 

The Kilted Pig do a reasonable lunch menu of light bites (I think priced between £3.50 and £8) and includes soup, sandwiches, baked potatoes, fish pie, risotto and stovies. Plus you are still able to order off the normal menu.

We all ate off the lunch menu and although nothing fancy, everyone was impressed with their portions and enjoyed the food. We were just over the £50 for 6 lunches, a bottle of wine and 3 soft drinks so we couldn't complain.

I had booked a table a couple of days before. After explaining we needed a quick turnaround, I was given menu's away with me so we could phone in a pre-order before heading down so good service too.

Good.  Not great.  Service is quick as expected.  Too much coleslaw for my liking. Sandwich is good but pastrami was chewy.  Fries were a little undercooked. Asked for double meat but same amount as friend.  Don't go out of your way

It was spa day at the camelback inn spa. We had facials and massages, lunch, and then wanted to have some FaceTime since we don't see each other often. That's when the trouble began. The quiet police were after us! Finally, we escaped to the outside where there were no water spritsers. We found some icy towels to cool us. Andrea gave me a great facial and spent a lot of time with me answering questions about my skin, eyebags, and products that could help. If you favor silence to read and relax you will enjoy it! They offer lemon water, tea, and when you leave you can make your own sachet which was awesome. My sachet has lavender in it and really helps me get to sleep. A nice touch!! The food and drink offerings were very good and the attendants were always nearby to help or keep everyone quiet. Shhhh when you go there!

"This eatery is proximate to one of my workplaces, and my colleagues and I frequent it so often that we have become familiar faces. The midday meal specials are fairly delectable, particularly option number one, which features tender short ribs. Additionally, I have sampled some of their unique sushi rolls, including the Arizona Diamondback, which boasts an interesting combination of flavors and textures. However, the quality of service varies greatly, as the staff occasionally becomes overwhelmed by a surfeit of patrons, resulting in a subpar dining experience. Nonetheless, the cuisine is generally satisfying, and I intend to try their Korean dinner offerings at some point in the future."

"Although my previous visit during happy hour yielded a satisfactory encounter, my subsequent dining experience on Friday evening proved to be a disappointment, as my margarita lacked the desired taste and my spouse's corned beef entrÃ©e was overcooked, resulting in an unpleasant texture and devoid of any distinctive flavor associated with the dish; however, my order of pita pizza was palatable, yet the inconsistency in quality has rendered me perplexed and uncertain regarding future visits to the establishment."

Ok I'm going to leave my rating at 3 stars because this place is a hit or miss. We were here the other night for happy hour and had such a great experience we came back on Fri for dinner. Not happy. My margarita was not good and my husband ordered the special - corned beef. It was over cooked, rubbery, and did not have any corned beef flavor. Highly disappointed. I ordered the pita pizza which was great again (thank goodness).\n\nI've had equally good and bad experiences here now. Not sure what to think. They aren't consistent.

Bars on the Royal Mile are, if you ask me, pretty much exclusively reserved for tourists who don't realise how overpriced they are, and aren't looking for a 'local' with any sense of community.

And to a certain extent, The Albanach fits all of those criteria: a cheeseburger and chips wiill set you back the best part of a tenner, and at every second table in the outside area there'll be somebody staring at a map of the centre with a slightly puzzled expression on their face.

That said, if I ever go for a drink with friends in this area we nearly always end up here at some point during the evening. House wine, although not exactly going to win any vintage awards, is only £12 a bottle which isn't much more than the price of a glass of equally average wine in some George Street bars. Not too shabby at all. Also, I don't know if they've recently had a big refurb but inside it is really nicely decorated. Unlike lots of traditional pubs in the old town, where "traditional" means it still smells of the pre-smoking ban days and is always full of old men drinking pints of real ale, The Albanach has lovely slate floors and new polished wood everywhere.

Just watch the step up as you go through the door on your way in. It catches me out every time and yes, everyone can see you.

"I visited Todai with my significant other for a midday meal, as he was yearning for some Shrimp Tempura, and needless to say, he obtained multiple plates of said dish. For a tariff of $20 per individual, the culinary selection was relatively diverse, primarily consisting of sushi rolls, but also including Salmon and Tuna Nigiri, salads, an udon station, and various sweet treats. Regrettably, there was an absence of crab during the lunchtime hours. My preferred aspect of the smorgasbord would have to be the udon station, whereupon ringing a bell, a staff member would emerge to prepare a bowl, allowing me to add ingredients such as fish cake, sweet tofu, green onions, and several other options. However, I must caution that the broth has a tendency towards excessive saltiness, so it is advisable to refrain from consuming it in large quantities. Given the abundance of alternative buffet establishments in Las Vegas, I would not be inclined to return to Todai in the future."

I came to Todai for lunch with my boyfriend since he was craving some Shrimp Tempura. Needless to say, he got plates and plates and more plates of Shrimp Tempura. 

For $20 per person, there was a pretty good variety of food, mostly sushi rolls. There was also Salmon and Tuna Nigiri, salads, an udon station, and some desserts. Unfortunately, there was no crab during lunch. 

My favorite part of the buffet would have to be the udon station. Just ring the bell, and someone will come out to make you a bowl. You can add fish cake, sweet tofu, green onions, and a few other things. As a warning, the broth is on the salty side, so I wouldn't drink it if I were you.

With the plethora of other buffets to choose from in Vegas, I don't think I would care to come back.

"Although it's acceptable to have differing opinions regarding culinary preferences, I believe that certain establishments, particularly those offering breakfast and brunch options, tend to rely heavily on factors such as visual appeal, generous portion sizes, and brand reputation, rather than the actual gastronomic quality of their offerings. In my experience, there are numerous superior alternatives for breakfast and brunch in Las Vegas that offer a more satisfying dining experience for discerning patrons."
It's ok.  I think they survive more on presentation, big portions, and name recognition than actual taste of food.  There are a bunch of better breakfast/brunch options in Vegas in my experience.

My offspring thoroughly enjoy this establishment, as it offers an array of apparel and paraphernalia inspired by popular cable television programs and musical ensembles, catering to a younger clientele. The sales personnel, who personify the target market, provide excellent customer service, offering assistance in selecting items that fit within their budget constraints. The prices, though slightly elevated due to the licensing fees associated with these products, are still reasonable and align with the quality of the merchandise offered.

My kids love this place.  Cool shirts and gear based upon cable shows and rock groups.  Obviously for a youthful demographic.  Sales people certainly represent that.  Prices seem reasonable for licensed items.  Quality seems good too.

This eatery purports to serve Colombian cuisine, which differs considerably from its Mexican counterpart in terms of the menu offerings. The portions are generous, but the prices reflect the quality, ranging from $13.00 to $25.00. Despite its location, the establishment does not offer particularly affordable options. However, based on my numerous experiences, the dishes are generally worth the cost. My personal favorite is the #25, consisting of succulent shrimp smothered in a rich coconut sauce, served atop crispy fried green plantains known as tostones. In addition, their fruit juices are quite refreshing. Another notable mention is the fried yuca, which boasts a unique flavor and texture reminiscent of French fries.  
The service at this restaurant is satisfactory, with friendly staff members who provide relatively prompt service. However, my experiences have been limited to less busy evenings, so I cannot comment on their ability to handle larger crowds.

"As individuals hailing from the nation of India, it is customary for us to partake in culinary delights that are synonymous with our cultural heritage, thereby necessitating the consumption of Indian cuisine on multiple occasions throughout the week, both within the confines of our domiciles and at external establishments specializing in such fare.  During our visit to Persi's, an eatery renowned for its excellence in providing delectable Indian dishes, our expectations were not disappointed, as the quality of the food presented during the lunch buffet was indeed commendable. Although the variety of options available was not extensive, each item was skillfully prepared and exhibited notable attributes of culinary proficiency. In particular, my personal preference was the chicken tikka masala, served in conjunction with steaming hot white rice, which complemented the rich flavors of the dish perfectly. However, the chicken biryani, while undoubtedly flavorful, possessed a level of spiciness that bordered on overwhelming, thereby detracting slightly from the overall enjoyment of the meal. Furthermore, the dearth of options in the realm of desserts was palpable, as the menu offered only gulab jumun and fresh fruit, leaving a lingering sense of dissatisfaction due to the absence of additional choices."

Being from India, we eat Indian food several times a week both at home and outside the house.  Persi's has a great reputation and they didnt let down on our visit. Good food for a lunch buffet overall.  The selection is not big but it was all pretty good.  My favorite was the chicken tikka masala with white rice.  The chicken biryani was also good but it was a bit on the spicy side.  Intense flavors are good but the heat was a bit overbearing.  The desserts lacked as they only had gulab jumun and fresh fruit.  It was good but I was left wanting something more.

I was genuinely thrilled about this venue, based on personal endorsements and Yelp reviews, boasting an impressive rating level that compelled me to choose it as the ideal setting to host out-of-town acquaintances. Initially, we opted to visit during the day instead of the evening. I joined forces with three other individuals to partake in the brunch offerings. Now, I am aware that Charlotte is still in the process of refining its brunch scene relative to other municipalities, yet brunch remains a fundamental meal. Unfortunately, the edibles were unimpressive, and the service was sluggish. Our server was quite friendly, albeit laid-back, attending to our coffee needs with diligence while periodically vanishing for intervals of 10 to 15 minutes. The dining area was not teeming with patrons. While my Breakfast Burrito was tasty, it lacked the desired temperature, and the cheese had solidified. My companion raved about the Shrimp Omelette, although they noted it was merely lukewarm. This could be attributed to our server's knack for disappearing acts, reminiscent of Houdini. In conclusion, this establishment is suitable for brunch, but it falls short of exceptional. If I had to choose a fourth or fifth brunch spot, I might reconsider visiting this location during the same time. Nevertheless, I harbor no reservations about returning here for dinner, as I am eager to sample their authentic Shrimp And Crawfish Etouffe and Bloody Mary Bar.

Circuit training constitutes an effective methodology for enhancing physical fitness, as it involves an uninterrupted sequence of exercises, thereby simulating a constant flow of motion. This dynamic approach necessitates a high level of physical endurance, making it a challenging experience for those who are not in peak condition. Our session consisted of six sets of four repetitions, with each set lasting approximately three to four minutes, culminating in a total duration of one hour. 

The incorporation of television monitors displaying participants' heart rates and a friendly trainer were aspects that garnered my approval. However, the presence of numerous individuals and the emphasis on continuous comparison among them had the potential to become a source of distraction, detracting from the primary objective of focusing on one's personal performance and attaining the desired physical state, commonly referred to as the "zone." Despite this minor drawback, I availed myself of a complimentary class starting at 6:30 am on a Saturday, which drew a sizable crowd of fifteen individuals, with a single male participant. The fitness center's diminutive size and welcoming ambiance, complemented by the vibrant hue of orange, created a comfortable environment. While perusing the premises, I noticed a limited selection of items available for purchase, albeit at somewhat elevated prices. 

My assessment of the program's cost yielded the conclusion that it was rather steep. Nonetheless, I acknowledge its potential efficacy for individuals who prefer varied exercises and periodic changes in their routine, as opposed to remaining stationary at a single machine throughout their workout. Wishing everyone success in their fitness endeavors.

"Gastronomical excellence is indubitably conveyed through the consumable delights offered at this eatery, specifically pertaining to the delectable fare which warrants an unwavering five-star rating. However, a caveat exists in the form of inconsistent and unpredictable service quality, particularly during peak luncheon hours when an overwhelming influx of patrons tends to precipitate an inadequacy in staffing, resulting in an unsatisfactory dining experience. It is indeed perplexing that the management has yet to implement an augmentation of personnel, albeit on a part-time basis, to alleviate the aforementioned deficiency. Notwithstanding the aforesaid shortcoming, my patronage persists, motivated by an unrelenting craving for the establishment's signature matzoh ball soup."

For the food I would have to give 5 stars.

The only problem is the shaky service.  If you to during lunch rush except very bad service.  Not sure why they can't hire another part time server.

There have been times that we almost had to leave because of the bad service.

I have to admit that I keep coming back for the matzoh ball soup!

took advantage of the coupons and got the chicken fingers. fast service and friendly. the chicken fingers were good,just be careful ordering hot! I still have much to try here so the jury is still out,but so far so good!

"As an ardent devotee of this establishment throughout its various monikers and proprietors, I have had the pleasure of indulging in a premium cigar, a pintsized portion of beer, and savoring the experience within the welcoming confines of its interior. The personnel here are remarkably hospitable, maintaining a formidable array of cigars within their meticulously curated humidor, complemented by an assortment of local brews that cater to diverse tastes. Patrons can choose to situate themselves at the bar, lounge comfortably in armchairs, or observe the television from a table, affording a versatile range of options for an enjoyable visit. My sole criticism pertains to the ambiance, specifically the atmospheric quality of the air, which, while undoubtedly conducive to the indulgence of cigar enthusiasts, proved somewhat challenging for my own sensitivities as a casual smoker; the lingering scent of smoke necessitated an exhaustive cleansing process upon my return home, underscoring the notion that this venue is perhaps better suited for those with a more robust nasal tolerance."

Been a fan of this place through several names and owners. It's one of the few places in town to get a cigar, a pint of beer, and enjoy it inside.

The staff is very friendly, and they have a pretty good selection in their humidor. They carry a small but solid lineup of beers, including some of the local breweries. You can sit at the bar, grab a comfy chair, or sit at a table and watch the TV.

My only ding is for the atmosphere. Literally, the air. I like a cigar once in a while but am not a heavy smoker, and the smoke in there was on the edge of what I can stand. I had to fumigate my clothes when I got home. So definitely not for the weak of nostril.

In search for late night prime rib, my friend who lives in Vegas brought us here. It was only $15. The place reaked of horses but it wasn't bad enough for us to leave. It was a good deal. The meal comes with soup or salad and your choice of potatoes. We all ordered it medium rare but was served a more rare one instead.  When we sent it back, they gave us a new one cooked to our liking. That was awesome customer service!  Although it was slightly chewy, the flavor and crust was really good! 3.5 stars total and yes I would probably come back.

"A further notification pertaining to Groupon has arrived. I am unable to resist the allure of a local establishment offering a Groupon, and thus, I have been compelled to indulge in yet another culinary excursion. 

The eatery in question was merely adequate. I opted for the spicy chicken bowl, which, while possessing an acceptable level of piquancy, exhibited a sweetness that did not align with my gustatory preferences. Moreover, the accompanying rice was not particularly impressive. However, the shrimp tempura we shared was moderately satisfying, and the orange chicken and chicken teriyaki samples I obtained from my companion's and mother's plates were palatable, with the former displaying a pleasing texture despite my general aversion to the ubiquitous orange sauce utilized by most establishments. 

In conclusion, this restaurant may be classified as a passable venue for a rapid, casual dining experience. Although it does not excel in any remarkable manner, its offerings are sufficient for a hasty, unremarkable repast. I might consider returning, contingent upon the availability of another coupon or special promotion."

Yet another Groupon alert. I just can't say no when I see a place in my area offer a Groupon.
