The place was just ok. I ordered the spicy chicken bowl and although I like the heat, I wasn't a huge fan of the flavor. It had a sweet flavor that I disliked and I wasn't a big fan of the rice. The shrimp tempura we shared was ok and the orange chicken and chicken teriyaki I tried from both my fella and my mom's plate were pretty tasty. I liked the texture of the orange chicken, despite not typically liking the orange sauce most places use.

All in all, it's a good little fast food teriyaki place. I'd recommend it for a quick on the go meal, but it's just ok overall. I'd probably go back, but only if I had another coupon.

Cool for children... Not so much for adults. I came especially for the mummy exhibit and I was kind of disappointed. I liked the little computer stations that talked about Egypt and the actual mummy. Other than that, it was mediocre. I wouldn't recommend paying extra to see it.

"Gastronomical excellence is undeniably evident in the culinary offerings of this establishment, however, operational deficiencies, discourteous staff, and an absence of managerial oversight have conspired to create an unfortunate dining experience, characterized by protracted waiting periods sans any tangible justification. Despite the delectability of the fare, a second visit is conditional upon the implementation of tangible improvements in service quality, as the patron is unlikely to be accorded any consideration or compensation for inconvenience incurred, and indeed, may be subject to financial penalty for lateness, much to their chagrin."

Great tasting food, really, it is.

Problem, disorganized, rude, lack of management, long waits for no specific reason.

Willing to give it a second shot because the food is really good, but would recommend to ensure you have nowhere to go to afterwards because you may miss that event or appointment and they won't care, will still charge you and give you now deal, boo!

I love this airport... whether your arriving or departing, you move quickly.  I love how well organized parking and taxi/shuttle service is.... the taxi lines move quick.  Tons of shops, food, and slots to pass the time. Free wi-fi is a PLUS!

Just your basic burger joint..  They do have a few other interesting things on the menu which I have not tried.  For the money I would rather go to Smashburger if it were closer.  I would eat here again because it is the best burger nearby for sure.

"For the paltry sum of $40, my spouse and I indulged in a veritable cornucopia of delectable delights, satiating our culinary cravings and lingering over our repast for what seemed an interminable duration. Arriving at the eatery shortly after the eleventh hour, we opted for a diverse medley of victuals, including a crepe replete with an array of savory ingredients; gnocchi; a fresh salad; grilled vegetables; dolmas; hummus and other dip-like condiments; pita bread; and an assortment of sweet treats and baked goods. The net result of such unbridled gluttony? A crippling food coma that left me somnambulant in the elevator en route back to our hotel, from which I did not awaken until several hours had elapsed, and only then to prepare for my impending nuptials."

"Beverages are reasonably priced, however, the ambiance is not particularly characteristic of a dive bar, per se. There is a disc jockey and a minuscule dance floor, yet the absence of exceptional service is palpable. The barback's stature and physical attractiveness captured my attention, prompting me to engage in rhythmic movements with my lower torso. The entrance fee of four dollars seemed somewhat unremarkable. It is worth mentioning that certain patrons appeared youthful, almost juvenile, which struck me as mildly peculiar, given the venue's reputation. Nonetheless, the prices for Jameson, Jack Daniel's, and most beers were reasonable, amounting to approximately 6.50 Canadian dollars. If one seeks an establishment conducive to fostering a sense of hipsterism, this may be an appropriate destination. Despite my personal preferences skewing towards a slightly more mature atmosphere, I must admit that this location possesses certain merits."

Drinks are decent price. Honestly it's not the most divey spot but its cool. There's a DJ and small dance floor. No services to remember. The bar back was pretty tall and handsome so I felt fascinated. I danced, shook my butt everywhere- 4$ cover: meh! \n\nSome of the people in it looked 15 years old which was weird but hey I'm on Vacation. 6,50 CAD for jameson, jack, most beer. If your into more of the I need to feel hipster scene come here. Its a great place just young for my lifestyle.

"Indubitably, the inaugural special offer of $16 for AYCE Korean BBQ may appear advantageous, but upon closer examination, it becomes evident that it falls short of expectations in various aspects. Firstly, parking poses a significant challenge, as the limited capacity of merely 20 spaces results in a cramped lot, raising questions about the feasibility of accommodating a large influx of patrons. Moreover, the service, despite the servers' attempts at cordiality, proved subpar, with forgetfulness regarding certain dishes and a tendency towards overcooking, leading to disappointment. Furthermore, the culinary offerings themselves were unimpressive, lacking depth of flavor, particularly in the marinated bulgogi and galbi, while the other meats suffered from dryness and an unpleasant chewiness, perhaps indicative of questionable freshness. Additionally, the AYCE appetizer selection was scant, with only gyoza and steamed eggs available, which, though palatable, failed to satisfy the craving for greater variety. In light of these deficiencies, it becomes apparent that this establishment must elevate its standards to surpass the competition among AYCE Korean BBQ venues in Las Vegas."

Yes the grand opening special $16 for AYCE krn bbq is great and all but its still not worth it in my book. 

First off, parking. IF this place ever gets off, where will all the customers park? Is everyone forced to carpool? because there are literally only 20 spots and its a cramped lot. Gotta fix that.
Secondly, service. Our service didn't suck as bad as everyone else's but it was still bad. I mean the servers try to be nice and all but they did forget a couple of dishes. I also don't mind them cooking for us, however  much of our food turned out burnt. boo.
Lastly but most importantly, the food was just not that good. I really like strong flavors and both the marinated bulgogi and galbi were too bland for my taste. The other meats were also too dry and chewy.. maybe an indication that stuff wasn't too fresh? There was also a lack of variety in the AYCE appetizers. Sure gyoza and the steamed egg are good and all but I wanted more. I mean you're up against all the other AYCE krn bbq places in Vegas.. step it up yo.
Solid variety of options, on the pricey side. We had sushi, chicken lettuce wraps, and a shrimp noodle dish. The food was good, but not quite authentic the way pan-asian places often are.

My favorite thing about this comic store is the fact that they just about always have a copy of something I'm looking for. They tend to order enough of books that come out. Other stores might be out but they will usually have some left. They have a bunch of figures and tons of books. Deforest will continue Coming in and maybe even subscribe for a box!

Last week, I had the pleasure of dining at a restaurant with a friend, and while the culinary experience was satisfactory, it did not exceed my expectations in terms of quality. Specifically, the chicken dish that we ordered lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, leaving me with a feeling of underwhelment. Furthermore, I did not get the impression that high-quality meat was a priority for this establishment, which was reflected in the price. Nonetheless, I would give the restaurant three stars for its adequate service and delicious, albeit fiery, rice noodle soup.

"The culinary experience afforded by this establishment's pizza and salad offerings is satisfactory, but the level of service provided falls short of exceptional standards. Notwithstanding, this venue remains an acceptable setting for socializing in the evening, particularly following a cinematic excursion."

"I had the privilege of attending a performance of the iconic musical production, 'Oklahoma!' at this venue several years ago, and I must say, I thoroughly enjoyed the experience. However, my culinary expectations were not entirely met, as the dinner buffet proved to be somewhat unremarkable, with the exception of the delectable assortment of sweet treats available for indulgence. Despite the inconvenience of its remote location, which made it challenging for me to frequent the establishment, given my residence in Chandler at the time, I would have eagerly returned on multiple occasions if circumstances had been more favorable. Interestingly, I have since been presented with opportunities to acquire significantly discounted gift certificates for this very venue, albeit online, yet the considerable distance of 28 miles from my current whereabouts in Scottsdale has regrettably deterred me from pursuing such offers."

"My significant other and I opted to lodge at Aria, indulging in a two-month residency at The Steakhouse, yet our dining experience was marred by an unfortunate seating arrangement orchestrated by an incompetent female receptionist during the check-in process; her egregious oversight in accommodating our table preferences left much to be desired, prompting us to reconsider our loyalty to this establishment. Despite the commendable service exhibited by our server and the edible quality of the cuisine, the ambiance was significantly impaired by the inconvenience caused by this thoughtless woman, thereby undermining the overall satisfaction of our dining excursion."

I have had the pleasure of visiting Gilbert Pizza on multiple occasions, and I must say that the culinary experience has been nothing short of delectable. However, I must admit that my most recent visit was slightly tarnished by an unfortunate encounter with a certain staff member. As I entered the establishment, I was greeted by a young woman behind the counter who, unfortunately, did not seem to be particularly enthused about her job. In fact, she barely acknowledged my presence, choosing instead to focus her attention on meticulously sanitizing the already spotless countertop. After patiently waiting for several moments, I finally managed to catch her eye and place my order. To my surprise, she responded with a terse and somewhat condescending tone, informing me that it would be a further five minutes before my pizza would be ready. My dear sir or madam, might I suggest that a modicum of enthusiasm and customer service skills might be beneficial in your line of work? Needless to say, I left the premises feeling somewhat disillusioned and disappointed. It is truly unfortunate when businesses fail to prioritize the importance of cultivating a positive rapport with their clientele.

I've been to Gilbert pizza many times. It delicious... However the girl behind the counter is the rudest person I've ever encountered in my life. Walked in she looked right at me didn't say a word. Just continued to wipe down the entire counter before slowly walking to the register and just asking me what I wanted... I placed an order over the phone... She snapped at me saying it would be 5 more minutes. Seriously bitch? How much do u care about your job? Let's try a little harder... I'll take my money and spend it else where. Who let's their staff treat their customers like that? She was rude to every single person who walked in after me.

Beware of the nefarious machinations of the EBAY MAFIA and their coterie of crafty accomplices...

In the event that you choose to peruse the offerings at Last Chance, cognizant of a few salient points you must be:

1. A plethora of exceptional deals, unparalleled within the locality, awaits your perusal at this establishment. 
2. Obtaining said deals, however, proves a formidable endeavor, as a cabal of scheming females and unscrupulous individuals, in concert with staff members of questionable ethics, conspire to preclude unsuspecting patrons from accessing said deals. 
3. A coterie of "team shoppers" convenes daily at Last Chance, their mission being to expeditiously procure each item of superior quality the moment the store opens its doors. To maintain their stranglehold on these coveted items, they engage in collusive efforts with staff members, thus ensuring that innocent bystanders are effectively barred from acquiring said items. Furthermore, some of these individuals even resort to peddling their ill-gotten gains on Ebay. 

Seeking irrefutable evidence? Simply navigate to Ebay and conduct a search for such esteemed brands as Marc Jacobs handbags or True Religion Jeans within the Phoenix metropolitan area. You shall observe an abundance of listings originating from Last Chance, easily identifiable by telltale markers, such as unique bag markings and truncated tags on denim apparel, which serve to thwart attempts at returning items to Nordstrom. 

In conclusion, Last Chance holds the potential to be an exceptional shopping destination, were it not for the rapacious machinations of the Ebay Mafia and their malevolent associates.

Beware of the EBAY MAFIA and their evil friends...

If you are going to Last Chance there are a few things you should know:

1. They have the best deals in town.
2. You have little chance of getting these deals, as bitchy women and evil sleazoids plot to keep these deals away from regular consumers.   There is a group of "team shoppers" who go to Last Chance every day. Their mission is to scoop up every piece of good clothing the minute the store opens. They work in teams to keep "outsiders" out. They even work with unscrupulous staff members to keep regular people away from the best clothing. Many of these people even sell the stuff they score at Last Chance on Ebay.

Want proof? Go to Ebay and search for things like Marc Jacobs purses or True Religion Jeans in Phoenix. You will see TONS of items from Lat Chance listed on Ebay. You know it's from Last Chance because of markings in the bags, cut tags on jeans and other things Last Chance does to prevent returns to Nordstrom.

So in summary - Last Chance would be great if the Ebay Mafia and their evil friends would stay away.

Love the Nola food, the authentic and delicious flavor of this kitchen is unique In Las Vegas, had the Shrimp and grits so delightful, the bread pudding outstanding, is a carnival of flavors melting in your mouth, the service is not that great, waitress get lost for long time, you can see them chatting with hostess and have to wave many times in order to get their attention, I have been here tree times the soft shell crab is so crispy and delicious, the jambalaya, the gumbo so much layers of flavor, once again, you come for the food not for the service. But the food is so great, I'll be back as many times I'm craving New Orleans Food.

It's like Korean and Japanese fast food. You can get sushi (its hard to get good sushi in Pittsburgh so by those standards, its pretty decent). You can also get the usual Korean fare: bulgogi, galbi, and kimchi. My favorite is the galbi bento (although its over $8 so I don't usually get it), or the bulgogi bowl. 

The bento boxes come with a little bit of chap chae (Korean glass noodles), kim chi, a salad with "oriental dressing", japanese yellow pickles, a few pot stickers (not bad, not good), and of course, whatever entree you ordered. 

The bowls are simple: rice topped with meat. Yum! 

The space is small though so its okay for 4-people groups.

"Commenced a corporate gathering with colleagues at this establishment, indulging in a delectable culinary experience that, while satisfying, did not linger in my memory as a standout occasion. The ambiance was vibrant and conducive to socializing, characteristic of Las Vegas venues, and situated within the luxurious Cosmopolitan hotel, amidst an array of dining options. Notwithstanding, the wait times for seating were generally prolonged at neighboring eateries, rendering this particular location a relatively convenient alternative. While not necessarily a personal favorite, it remains a passable choice for casual dining."

My significant other and I did not particularly relish the ambiance of this eatery. Its interior was rather diminutive and raucous, which made for an unpleasant dining experience. Despite this, I opted to sample their culinary offerings and selected a mushroom and cheese omelette, accompanied by bacon and a biscuit. My companion, however, decided upon a Spanish omelet, complemented by salsa and home fries. Unfortunately, my omelette was devoid of any discernible seasoning and lacked overall flavor, save for the palatable bacon and biscuit. In contrast, my companion expressed satisfaction with his meal. Notwithstanding our divergent opinions regarding the food, we concurred that the coffee served was subpar.

My bf and I weren't a fan of this place. It's very loud and small inside. I ordered a mushroom and cheese omelette, bacon and a biscuit. Bf ordered a spanish omelet with salsa and home fries.\nMy omelette wasn't seasoned at all and lacked flavor. The bacon and biscuit were great tho. The bf liked his meal. The one thing we both agreed on was that the coffee was awful!!

This review will be an example of how the service staff can ruin a dining experience.

Let me start by saying, we love the Wicked Spoon!!!  We try to make it in for a meal everytime we're in Vegas.  The food is great and they always have a new suprise on the menu.  The way they set up smaller portions in those cute little crocks is perfect.

Unfortunately, on this visit, we got a grumpy old server with a bad memory.  Everytime we ordered drinks, she either had to be reminded of our order or she'd put the drinks in front of the wrong person.  We'd order a couple of cokes and a cup coffee.  She'd bring back 3 coffees and tell us "Oh, someone at the table will drink them".

But the biggest buffet party foul of all is not clearing the plates quick enough.  We literally had to stack our plates at the edge of the table, while we watched her clear an empty table next to us.

Wicked Spoon, there are a lot of good people out of work.  Review the quality of your people and bring back the "A" level dining experience.

The Garage was once my favorite little spot but they're starting to seem pretty basic compared to all the other creative options out there. Nonetheless, they have good food and friendly staff. I've never had to wait for a table either which is great when you're starving or on a schedule but makes me wonder why more people don't come to this place? I wish they still had lamb as a starter. That would win my heart back right away.

I want to shop local .  I appreciate the fact that my local purchase support local people. But I am not sure Next  is really interested in my business.  
The line on a Wednesday was 4 or 5 people in , which first made me think it must be a great place. but then after watching , I am think it's just a matter of workers who are interested in being helpful . They appeared to just leisurely make the orders with  little enthusiam or interest. When  I got to the counter I had a few questions . I was wonderfing about their holiday flavor , if it could be blended etc . But I felt as though getting info or suggestions was like pulling teeth. I felt embarrassed like I was inconvincing him but I then I remembered I was paying them to make my order.
When the equally apathetic barista made my order she also refused to intereact or say anything to me. As I gave her my sweetest Polly Anna smile  she may have even grunted at me. I hate grunters.   Guess the big chain will get my bucks next time.

Please NEXT  make an effort to engage the customer and try using those nifty words , thank you , please and your welcome ....maybe even , glad I can help....

"Having had the privilege of residing in Southern California and Las Vegas, my palate has been accustomed to the rich and diverse culinary offerings of these regions, particularly when it comes to Asian cuisine. Thus, it was with great anticipation that I visited Republic Ramen Noodles in Tempe, hoping to indulge in a delectable bowl of noodles that would transport me back to those halcyon days of gastronomic bliss. Alas, despite my eagerness to bestow upon this establishment the highest praise, I must confess that it fell short of my expectations, garnering a mere three stars from this fastidious critic.  

While the portion sizes at Republic Ramen Noodles are undoubtedly generous, and the flavors they proffer are indeed unique, their interpretation of "spicy" leaves much to be desired for those who crave a truly piquant experience. In fact, I found their notion of heat to be rather tepid, bordering on blandness, which may prove underwhelming for ardent devotees of fiery cuisine. To remedy this deficiency, I resorted to supplementing my meal with a dash of trusty Sriracha, thereby elevating the flavor profile to a more satisfactory level.  

Regrettably, Republic Ramen Noodles does not quite compare to the authentic ramen establishments found in other cities, where the rich broth, tender noodles, and savory toppings conspire to create a transcendent dining experience. However, until I have the opportunity to venture forth and sample the genuine article, this venue shall suffice, albeit with a certain degree of wistfulness for the real thing.  

In conclusion, while Republic Ramen Noodles may not fully satiate the cravings of those who seek an authentic ramen experience, it nevertheless warrants a visit, if only to temporarily assuage one's hunger for this delectable dish. With a return factor of 65%, I shall likely revisit this eatery, albeit with tempered expectations and a healthy dose of Sriracha on hand."

"I am uncertain regarding the nomenclature of this establishment, as during my visit, none of the musical selections played were affiliated with the Fab Four; nevertheless, this did not perturb me. The DJ presented an adequate mixture of tunes, yet no individuals, with the exception of the exotic dancer situated near the pillar, displayed any inclination towards terpsichorean movements. Upon entering, we obtained a complimentary beverage coupon, which, upon presentation to the barkeep, was met with a restrictive selection of potables, necessitating a thorough perusal of the minuscule script. Notwithstanding, we elected to abstain from consuming any alcoholic beverages. Throughout the venue, a young woman circulated, offering gratis shots whose hue resembled that of cranberries; however, we politely declined these offers. This lounge presents an optimal setting for observing human behavior, as demonstrated by two senior females, whose ages could be estimated somewhere beyond the prime of life, engaging in chain smoking and attempting to entice younger companions. This spectacle was undoubtedly humorous; nonetheless, it is not advisable to visit this establishment with expectations of dancing or enjoying Beatles melodies."

"Upon approaching the establishment, I was met with a rather discourteous reception from the hostess, who displayed a lack of enthusiasm in addressing my inquiry regarding the seating arrangement. Her nonverbal response, a mere shrug, conveyed a sense of indifference that was somewhat surprising, given the high volume of patrons present at the time. Notwithstanding this initial encounter, my experience improved significantly upon being seated, as a friendly server named Jack attended to my needs with promptness and attentive service, save for a minor mishap involving the incorrect beverage, which was swiftly rectified upon my request."

The host was very rude when I walked up although I wasn't expecting amazing service from an airport bar. I asked her a question about the seating situation and she just shrugged her shoulders. She literally didn't say a word. I think her name tag said Della or something starting with a D. Once I sat down my experience here got better. A young lady by the name of Jack greeted me and took my order. She brought me back the wrong beer but quickly offered to fix my order. I'm not one to let drinks go to waste so I didn't make her fix it.

I like this place a lot, good food, good service. Only thing I do not like at ALL, is the fact that they allow minors to be seated in the bar area. There is a restaurant portion with plenty of seating too. Really kills the vibe!

"Initially, it is essential to acknowledge that the panoramic perspective of the Bellagio, complemented by the captivating water display, is undoubtedly breathtaking from this particular vantage point. However, regarding the culinary offerings, it is somewhat disappointing to note that the quality of the fare does not quite live up to the elevated standards one might expect from an establishment of this caliber, particularly given its prime location atop Las Vegas's quasi-Eiffel Tower. Nonetheless, the experience itself is unquestionably worthwhile, and it may be suggested that indulging in beverages at this lofty perch would be a preferable alternative to consuming a meal."

First off, the view of the bellagio and the water show is AMAZING FROM HERE!!

The food here is just decent. You're paying more for the view and the fact you're on the top of las vegas in a qausi eiffel tower. 

Def worth the experience. Not sure if they have a bar up there, but i'd just get drinks up there if I could instead of eating

These delectable, visually-appealing cupcakes possess an aesthetic quality reminiscent of those that are meticulously crafted and presented at upscale social gatherings, specifically weddings, evoking a sense of refined elegance and sophistication attributed to the renowned lifestyle icon, Martha Stewart; they would undoubtedly be the centerpiece of attention when displayed in abundance and diversity on a serving tray, exuding an air of lavishness and charm. My admiration for their allure is complemented by my fondness for the judicious application of frosting, which strikes a harmonious balance between restraint and indulgence, further enhancing the overall visual appeal of these delightful treats. Additionally, I must commend the creators of these culinary gems, whose expertise and dedication to their craft are evident in the unique and intriguing flavors they have created, imbuing each cupcake with its distinct character and charm. While the cupcake itself may be experiencing an identity crisis, straddling the line between its traditional form and a muffin-like transformation, my curiosity and appreciation for its unconventional nature prompt me to consider revisiting this establishment, provided that I am in close proximity, as the flavors are truly captivating and worthy of further exploration, although I would not undertake a special journey solely for the purpose of sampling them.

"In the event that you possess the ability to make a selection, it is recommended that you opt for the lodging establishment situated approximately one mile north of the aforementioned location. (14245 S 50th St) This particular facility boasts accommodations that are superior in quality, and furthermore, features internal passageways. Although the tariff may be slightly higher, amounting to an additional $10 per night, the enhancement in comfort and convenience merits the additional expenditure."
If you have a choice, stay at the one about one mile farther north. (14245 S 50th St) The rooms are nicer, and they have indoor corridors.  Might cost an extra $10/night, but it's worth it.

Was this place good? Yes. 

Are there a lot of better places? Yes!

I had dinner here and we ordered the Jumbo Shrimp Cocktail and the Shrimp Spring Rolls as appetizers. The shrimp cocktail was exactly what I expected, cold shrimp with cocktail sauce.The spring rolls were actually really good and if I came back here I would start my meal off with an order of these.

For the main course I got the Crown Cut Bone In Filet Mignon, 12 oz. This steak really didn't do much for me. At this price point, I can go almost anywhere else for a better steak.

Next time, if I'm in the forum shops and looking for a steak I'll probably go next door to Joes.

The service is friendly.. and the ambiance is cool!  I love the outside benches where you can sit, have a beer, shoot the shit.... and just chill.  On a nice night, it's a really nice place to just BE.  

The waitresses are friendly... as well as the patrons.... 

I do believe that they serve food... though instead of ordering food, I ordered beer.  Beer was excellent.  hahaha!

Prices aren't to bad either.... what I really dig about this place is the outside seating area.  I just like being outside.  

Thanks for the good times Al's!  I'll be back

"The quality of the food can be somewhat unpredictable, with certain items demonstrating a propensity for inconsistency in terms of taste and freshness. However, the tacos and breakfast burritos are generally considered to be satisfactory, boasting a palatable flavor profile and an appreciable crispiness. The salsa, while ostensibly intended to augment the culinary experience, often falls short of expectations, with its spicy kick bordering on overwhelming. It is recommended that patrons opt for a milder, more balanced condiment, such as that offered by Trader Joe's, in order to avoid discomfort or dissatisfaction. Furthermore, the chimichangas are best avoided altogether, as they tend to be rather large and difficult to manage, particularly for those with sensitive digestive systems. Lastly, it is advisable to procure a substantial quantity of horchata, albeit with some difficulty due to its unwieldy size, in order to quench one's thirst and complete the meal."

Can be hit or miss. The tacos are usually pretty good and fresh, as are the breakfast burritos. Salsa seems to be more of a hot sauce... I'd say pick up a tub from Trader Joe's and pile that on instead. (Haha.) Chimichangas are a big NO, especially for ye of sensitive colons. I always get a big ol' awkwardly sized styrofoam jug of horchata that I can barely hold in one hand. \n\nOverall, don't expect a gourmet culinary experience. Also, just park and order from the window when there's more than two cars in the drive-thru or else chance attacking your sleeve, your friend, or yourself out of sheer desperation and hunger.

"Although I may not be the most suitable individual to evaluate Brew Lab, as I do not partake in the consumption of coffee, I must admit that I did appreciate certain aspects of the establishment during my visit. Despite the fact that the coffee-centric nature of the venue may not resonate with me personally, I found the ambiance of the location to be somewhat reminiscent of a bustling train station, with patrons constantly seeking seating arrangements. The interior design and demeanor of the staff were certainly appealing, and my peppermint tea, prepared with fresh leaves, was quite satisfying. However, due to the crowded atmosphere, I would deduct a star from my overall rating, as I prefer a more tranquil setting when enjoying a cup of tea. Nonetheless, the popularity of Brew Lab among its patrons is undeniable."

Okay, so I might not be the best person to review Brew Lab as I don't do coffee. At all. The whole coffee thing is properly lost on me. So a place famed for this particular beverage probably has to work harder for me. 

However, I liked Brew Lab when I could finally get some space to sit down and soak up the place. It feels a bit like a train station with people constantly wandering around trying to find a spot to sit, and it's rammed full of rich student types. 

I like the decor, the staff were very pleasant and my peppermint tea was really very nice. Fresh peppermint leaves and all. Lovely. Couldn't fault the cuppa - would happily sup another one.

However, it's losing the fourth star for me just now because it's so busy and I don't find it very relaxing. If I want to enjoy a pot of tea I'd rather go somewhere a bit less packed. But hey, that's just a testament to how popular the joint is :)

Comfy couches & low lighting really had me excited as we were celebrating our 40th wedding anniversary.  The music was okay but as soon as we ordered with a groupon for two Headhunter drinks the server couldn't be bothered.  Even though we had planned to order more we couldn't even get her attention to get a bill which we would have at least give her a tip.  I read the other reviews and had great expectations - maybe we should have sat inside where we could have tried various drinks.

"It is imperative that I confess the TB constitutes a culpable junk food indulgence when adhering to a vegetarian dietary preference. The vast majority of items listed on the menu can be tailored to accommodate vegetarian patrons, which is quite advantageous when time is of the essence. This particular establishment appears to be on par with its peers, and while I am uncertain regarding my ability to bestow four stars upon it, the cuisine is unquestionably consistent with the TB's customary offerings - neither revolutionary nor particularly memorable, but reliably satisfying. The personnel at this location are predominantly youthful individuals, as is often the case with fast-food establishments, yet their demeanor is invariably cheerful. My experiences with the drive-thru have been pleasant, as the staff members are scrupulously polite and relatively prompt; although their efficiency does not approach lightning-speed, I have yet to encounter substantial delays. Therefore, if an individual seeks to acquire TB fare, this venue is a suitable choice, owing to the presence of affable and competent employees manning the drive-thru."

I have to admit the TB is a guilty junk food kinda thing when you are vegetarian.  Pretty much anything on the menu can be made vegetarian which is pretty great when you are in a hurry.  This location seems to be about the same as the rest. I'm not sure I can bring myself to give them 4 stars, but the food is what you would expect from the TB nothing life changing, but consistent.  The staff at this location are younger people as are most fast food places who always seem pretty cheerful.  I usually go through the drive-thru and they are always very polite and pretty quick.  Not lightening speed or anything, but I have never driven by because there were a few people in line ahead of me.\n\nSo basically they have very nice staff running the drive-thru so if you want some TB then this is a good one.

"Today, my expectations were not met with regards to the flavor profile of the chai tea latte that I consumed, as it lacked the robust and nuanced characteristics that I have come to associate with this particular beverage; specifically, the taste was diluted and unpleasantly watery, which made it difficult for me to even consume half of it, ultimately leading me to discard the remainder, much to my disappointment."

"While it may be considered an unpretentious and tranquil setting for local patrons, the adjacent Orleans presents a more captivating ambiance, complete with an aesthetically pleasing alleyway and a state-of-the-art theatrical venue. Furthermore, the Gold Coast area boasts an array of establishments catering specifically to the needs and preferences of Chinese clientele, such as the renowned PingPangPong and Noodle Exchange, as well as the ever-popular Baccarat gaming facilities."

"Their prices convey an air of exclusivity, as if they are the sole purveyors of gastronomical delights within the vicinity. The cost of their culinary offerings, however, borders on the exorbitant - a whopping $49.00 for a meal suitable for a child and two adults, while the beverages, a $5 Guinness and a metered pour of $4 Pinot Grigio, though not unreasonably priced, pale in comparison to the extravagant expense of the food. Furthermore, the presentation of the salad, served in a humble styrofoam takeout container with plastic cutlery, serves as a harbinger of the premium one must pay for a second helping, while the diminutive size of the salad dressing container portends a substantial fee for an additional serving. Notwithstanding the quality of the salad and its accompaniments, including the gristly chicken and satisfactory bacon, the utilization of a pizza sheet and genuine tableware for my spouse's Stromboli, and the pedestrian nature of the cheese pizza procured by my daughter, the extended delay between the arrival of our beverages (approximately 15-20 minutes) and the subsequent delivery of our fare (an additional 15-20 minutes) only serves to further underscore the need for more appropriate pricing and a greater attention to detail regarding the presentation of their cuisine. A more judicious approach to pricing, coupled with a commitment to employing authentic dinnerware, would greatly enhance the overall dining experience at this establishment."

They are priced like they know they're the only game in town. The food is too expensive - $49.00 for a child and two adults, my husband had a $5 Guinness and I had a metered pour of $4 Pinot Grigio, not bad prices, then came the food. They served  my salad in a styrofoam takeout container with plastic cutlery, the miniature size of the salad dressing container was warning enough that a steep price would be paid for a second. It was a good salad and dressing the chicken I got on top had a lot of \"gristle\" , the bacon was fine. My husband got Stromboli , ordinary but good, he got a real fork and knife and was served on a pizza sheet. Daughter got a cheese pizza.   It was 15 to 20 mins before our drinks came about 15 to 20 more for food. I really wish the place had actual dinnerware and was more appropriately priced, the bar is a great addition.

Worth the money, but not too great.  All of the dishes were less than 10 dollars, and the portions are really big.  However, what you get is basically a bowl of noodles with very few vegetables and meat.  If you're looking for a cheap, filling meal this is a great place.  If you want good Asian food, look elsewhere.

I ordered Take-Out.  I got the Masaman Curry with Tofu & Vegetables.. it was okay.  Not very note-worthy, but not horrible.  I wish I had gotten it for lunch, it would have been cheaper and would have come with more stuff.  I would return for lunch in or take-out to give them another try.

"Dave's Canine Culinary Establishment fabricates exquisite, delectable, gourmet hot dogs, boasting an exceptional, East Coast-style bun, characterized by its robust, yet pliable texture, reminiscent of a slice of hearty, artisanal bread. The sausages themselves are of superior quality, brimming with rich, bold flavors, and offered at a reasonable tariff. Although the fries are somewhat unremarkable, they remain a palatable accompaniment to the primary dish. Following their relocation to a site proximate to the Gammage Parkway loop, accessibility to the eatery during academic hours has become somewhat more arduous for students situated on Mill Avenue. Nonetheless, Dave's Dog House maintains a distinct advantage over its competitors in terms of the superiority of its canine cuisine."

Dave's Dog House makes unique, tasty hot dogs. They have a delightful, back-east bun that's more like a piece of thick, foldable toast. The dogs are high quality and flavorful, and priced well. The fries are alright, but sadly nothing to write home about. \n\nThey've since moved ON campus, just off the Gammage Parkway loop, so it's a bit trickier to get to from Mill during school, but they're a much better dog than some of the other options available on Mill.

Not my favorite club in Vegas. But after a while, every club is really the same. Came on a Wednesday night. Good crowd. Our cocktail waitress in VIP was very helpful and attentive to everyone's needs in our party. I like that LAX has a mezzanine area for some of the VIP booths, but every VIP booth houses two different parties which can prove to be problematic if the two parties conflict (which happened to us). The security attempted to remedy this by dividing the booth with one of the couches. The DJ was ok. I guess I would come back if I absolutely had to.

This Boca Park Target Greatland was remodeled last year and is now just a regular Target, but has the expanded food format, so it includes fresh food with a really big grocery section similar to SuperTarget without the services like deli and bakery. It is much more appealing now that it has been given a red face-lift, but I'm still a little bitter that they removed Taco Bell Express. -2 stars because the team members here aren't as available or as willing to help as a typical Target, and this location is ALWAYS insanely busy. This has to be the busiest Target store in Nevada. They do have a really nice electronics section now though. Target Cafe on the left enterance with Pizza Hut Express, and store services include Pharmacy, Photo, and Portrait Studio.

I had been fervently anticipating that my experience at Port of Subs would be thoroughly enjoyable, given the plethora of establishments they boast in Las Vegas; however, upon perusing their offerings and sampling their fare, I was left with a somewhat mixed impression, as the quality of the ingredients and the freshness of the meats and cheeses utilized in their sandwiches were certainly palatable, yet the bread itself lacked a certain je ne sais quoi in terms of both texture and flavor profile, which ultimately led me to conclude that while the prices they charge are indeed reasonable, they do not necessarily represent the most judicious expenditure of resources when compared to alternative dining options in close proximity.

"Culinary indulgences served as the pinnacle of my dining experience, precipitating a profound sense of satisfaction. However, certain aspects of the service fell short of my expectations, specifically, the interaction between staff and patron lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, thereby precluding me from assigning a rating of four stars. Subsequently, I ventured to the restrooms, which regrettably, did not meet my standards of cleanliness, ultimately leading me to downgrade my assessment by one star. Notwithstanding this drawback, the complimentary miso soup, iceberg salad, and fresh fruit offered at the conclusion of the meal served as a pleasant surprise, providing a glimmer of hope that this establishment has the potential to attain a higher rating in the future."

"Aesthetically pleasing retail establishment, seemingly situated beyond my customary geographic parameters for perusing consumer goods, yet I chanced upon its premises today while traversing the locality, thereby necessitating an exploratory visit. Observed minimal patronage, with a conspicuous absence of shoppers, while staff members appeared profusely engaged in inventory replenishment. Did not encounter the specific item I sought, presumably due to its seasonal nature and association with scholastic paraphernalia, but opted to peruse other regularly procured items, such as feline sustenance and melodic compact discs, and discovered prices to be reasonable, inventory abundant, and checkout queues uncrowded."

I made an appearance at this establishment with the intention of peddling certain antiquated goods. Upon perusing the premises, it became apparent that there was a dearth of vintage wares both in terms of quantity and quality, which rendered my efforts to divest myself of my possessions rather futile. Nonetheless, their array of apparel was quite impressive, boasting a level of distinctiveness that set it apart from the offerings of such establishments as Goodwill and Plato's Closet. Each item I handled evoked within me an intense desire to acquire it, but alas, the prices seemed somewhat exorbitant. Specifically, tops were priced around $15 and dresses started at $25, leading me to surmise that the store catered primarily to a youthful clientele with a penchant for higher education.

I came here to sell some vintage items.  I didn't see very many vintage items in the store nor did they buy much from me.  However, they have a good selection of clothing.  It's not anything you would find at Goodwill or Plato's closet.  The clothing is unique and in very good shape. I found myself wanting every piece I picked up. However, everything seemed a bit overpriced. I noticed shirts were about $15+ and dresses $25+.  The store definitely has a young college vibe.

"First and foremost, let us set aside the fact that I am rapidly approaching my thirtieth year and still revel in the musical offerings of My Chemical Romance, whose primary demographic consists of teenagers. Observe, young ones, that I am legally permitted to consume alcoholic beverages and, indeed, I possess a cold brew in hand! Wooooooo ahhhhhhhhhh. 

The ambiance of this particular venue can be described as the less than salubrious, grimy, and somewhat promiscuous sibling of its Disney-inspired counterpart in Anaheim. This may be attributed, in part, to the fact that it resides within the confines of Mandalay Bay. Notwithstanding, the premises boast three fully-stocked bars situated at each corner of the performance area and a sunken dance floor designated for general admission patrons. 

There exists a certain tale, unrelated to the realm of band camp, whereby my closest friend and I indulged in an inebriated girls' night, replete with a visit to this very establishment. Following the consumption of several shots in a futile attempt to erase the memory of a middle-aged couple eager to engage in a'social gathering' with us, we found ourselves onstage, performing the African Anteater Ritual dance from the cinematic masterpiece, 'Can't Buy Me Love.' Does this cinematic masterpiece ring a bell? The one featuring McDreamy, prior to his metamorphosis into a veritable dreamboat."

Ok first off let's get past the fact that I'm knocking on 30's death door and still going to see bands like My Chemical Romance, where the core audience is teens. Look at me kiddies, I'm old enough to drink, and I have a beer! Wooooooo ahhhhhhhhh.

This location seems like the slimier, dirtier, slutty sister of the Disney infused Anaheim location. There is only one level at this one, due in part I'm sure, to the fact that it's in Mandalay Bay. However, there are 3 full bars at all corners of the stage, and a sunken in dance, GA floor.

There was this one time, not in band camp, where my BFF and I were having a drunken girl's night with a stop here. Oh wowwie, after downing some shots to try and forget the fact that a couple in their late 50's wanted to have a "party" with us, we ended up on stage doing the African Ant Eater Ritual dance from "Can't Buy Me Love". You remember that movie right? The one with McDreamy, before he went all, dreamy

I would come back. 

I don't live in Vegas though. My sister and her family took me here before they dropped me off on the strip. It's not too far from the strip. The food is descent for the rice. We mainly ate the bul-go-gi and the marinated pork. They have jap chae along with all the little kimchi sides. I went during lunch so I'm not sure if they put more out for dinner. They have this rule where if you waste food, they will charge you $5 or more. So make sure you eat everything on your late or else you'll be paying more! You pay after so there's no way to avoid it. 
If you want something asian and are willing to venture off the strip, I would say come here and enjoy some korean food. You get to cook on the table!

My first time in Vegas, and its for a conference (work related).  

Conference area:
The distance from my room to the conference room was at least a mile. I thought I was doing a half marathon. I was looking for people passing out Gatorade. I really didn't have to go to the gym my whole stay in Vegas. Be sure to bring gym shoes.

The food that was available in the conference room was delicious. Breakfast was hearty, and lunch was basically dinner because the portions were so huge. There was a lot of choices so you weren't bored. Con for having good food was getting so sleepy after the meal, and trying to stay awake during the 2nd half of the conference.

Casino:
My stay at the Rio was on a weekday, so it wasn't packed. A variety of tables and slots to choose from. I  didn't gamble much at the Rio. I went to the strip for that. Free Shuttles to the casinos that are under the same company as the Rio was nice.


The room was nice. I just wish they got rid of some outdated features. Had an old CRT TV, but who has time to watch tv while in vegas? No wifi in the rooms. Had to use an Ethernet cable. There was wireless in the conference area though.

Overall, a good experience because it wasn't on my dime. =) Just the gambling.

"My culinary experiences at this establishment have been thoroughly satisfying, primarily due to the uncomplicated nature of the menu, reminiscent of Chipotle and similar eateries. The nachos are particularly appealing, largely owing to the delectable tri-cheese sauce, which boasts a subtle yet palpable spicy kick. Additionally, the freshness of the salsa served here is noteworthy, surpassing that of rival establishments in my opinion. While the burritos are unremarkable in terms of ingenuity, their consistency is undeniably impressive. However, I do take issue with the practice of charging extra for fajita vegetables or rice when ordering veggie nachos or burritos, as it seems counterintuitive given the absence of meat, thereby rendering the dish inherently less costly to prepare. Notwithstanding this minor grievance, I shall continue to patronize this establishment regularly. Furthermore, I must commend the staff for maintaining a spotless environment, with a relatively low volume of customers and generally attentive service."

"It is my ardent desire to possess an unwavering fondness for the culinary offerings, comparable to the extent of my appreciation for the panoramic vistas and ambient surroundings. Although my enthusiasm for the edibles does not rival the aforementioned sentiment, I must confess that the assortment of breads proved satisfying, particularly the variety infused with the rich flavor of peanut butter. The shrimp cocktail, with its unique and playful twist, contributed further delight to the dining experience. The beef tenderloin and cod, both showcasing the chef's proficiency in cookery, emerged as palatable options as well. Lastly, the MiX candy bar, an indulgent sweet treat, rounded out the meal on a delectable note. Notwithstanding a few instances of haughty behavior from certain members of the waitstaff, the service generally met expectations."

I wish I loved the food as much as the views and atmosphere. Breads were good, especially enjoyed peanutbutter butter. Shrimp cocktail had a fun twist. The beef tenderloin and cod were good. The MiX candy bar was a tasty dessert. Service was a bit snooty, but otherwise good.

Does anyone actually shop here?

My husband and I were staying next door at Aria and wandered over to see what this mall was all about ... and it's all about High End Things for Rich People. Now, I didn't go there expecting to see an Office Max, a Lane Bryant, or a combo KFC / Taco Bell in a food court, but I hoped there may be -some place- I might feel comfortable walking in to and at least browsing. 

Nope. It was all super high end, and I saw very few people actually in those stores shopping. Most people were just wandering through (like we were) on their way to somewhere else, or gawking at the fabulous architecture and art installations. The only place we found that looked like it didn't require an American Express Black Card to enter was a place humbly called The News Stand, tucked away downstairs under the escalator near a (presumably) rarely used entrance, like the fabled red-headed stepchild. 

The only reason I'd ever go back would be to grab some bottled water from The News Stand, maybe get a coffee at Starbucks, or just enjoy the A/C and the art on my way to The Strip.

"I am utterly perplexed by the widespread fascination with this establishment, as my experience was riddled with ambiguity and disappointment. Determining the appropriate location for placing an order and procuring sustenance proved to be a formidable task, compounded by the fact that beverages are ordered in a separate queue, thereby augmenting the bewilderment. Furthermore, the prices charged for their fare are equivalent to those of a full-service restaurant, yet the absence of attentive service only serves to exacerbate the feeling of disorientation. My culinary selection, an avocado pizza, was merely adequate, lacking any distinguishing characteristics or flavors of note. The crust was excessively oily, and the cheese employed was unidentifiable, although it did not possess the rich, creamy texture of mozzarella. Moreover, the sourdough foundation imbued the pizza with an unpleasant tang, which only served to further diminish my enjoyment. In light of these factors, I would not consider returning to this establishment unless absolutely necessary."

"I visited this establishment on a recent evening in celebration of a friend's milestone birthday, having previously frequented the venue on multiple occasions. My experiences have been inconsistent, contingent upon my emotional state at the time of visitation. 

Advantages: The location offers an excellent opportunity for observing diverse and intriguing individuals, comprising a mix of distinctive and aesthetically pleasing patrons. The prices for beverages are reasonable, and I have yet to encounter an entrance fee. The ambiance is lively and engaging, suitable for entertaining younger acquaintances or relatives. 

Disadvantages: The atmosphere can occasionally exhibit attributes associated with pretentiousness or conceit. Patrons may subject themselves to overt examination by fellow revelers, potentially contributing to an uncomfortable experience. Additionally, the bar may lack sufficient space for dancing, leading to an awkward congregation near the entrance. Furthermore, expect to endure an extended waiting period when ordering beverages. 

In conclusion, this establishment may satisfy those seeking a quintessential Old Town experience, such as commemorating a significant birthday. However, it does not rank among my preferred destinations due to its variable nature and certain drawbacks."

"Well, I truly desired to hold this venue in high esteem, based on the accolades it has received, but unfortunately, it falls short of exceptional and settles at a respectable three stars. 

Service: Five stars without a doubt, however, the server's oversight regarding my wine selection proved problematic. Specifically, when requesting a 'house' wine, which customarily signifies the most economical option, I was taken aback by the price of each glass being $13.50. This egregious error precipitated a drastic decline in the rating of the server's performance, plummeting from five stars to a solitary star. 

Food: Enjoyable and of decent quality. My dining companion and I sampled the osso buco, which, while not the finest specimen, remained palatable. Conversely, the insalata bianca, though highly touted, fell short of expectations, amounting to little more than an unremarkable dish. My spouse opted for the sea bass special, the flesh of which was cooked to perfection and presented in generous portions. Regrettably, it was accompanied by a lackluster spaghetti squash, devoid of flavor and uninspired. It appears that certain culinary aficionados persist in promoting squash, despite its inherent mediocrity. 

Price: Reasonable, yet the inflated cost of the 'house' wine resulted in a significant setback in our overall satisfaction. 

In conclusion, a rating of three stars seems appropriate, potentially rising to four, were it not for the wine faux pas."

"In light of the considerable size of our gathering, it became necessary to temper our expectations to some extent, given that the establishment's primary focus was on providing adequate service and offering a limited selection from their menu.  Opting for the onion soup with Gruyere cheese proved to be a satisfactory decision, as it was indeed quite palatable.  The main course presented us with a trio of options - Prime rib, herb-infused chicken, or salmon.  While my personal preference would have been the salmon, its rarity rendered it less than desirable, and thus, I settled for the chicken.  Unfortunately, the chicken was accompanied by a side of string fries, which seemed somewhat incongruous within the context of a formal dining experience.  Notwithstanding this minor drawback, the service we received was generally commendable, though the prices charged for beverages did seem slightly exorbitant."

"Upon culminating a vigorous Friday evening jog with the Charlotte Runner's Meet Up assemblage, I decided to halt and partake in a libational pint and a savory burger at this sprawling establishment, which boasts an expansive outdoor terrace and three tiers of bar and dining space.  The venue offers an extensive array of artisanal brews, featuring at least six regional varieties, in addition to a diverse selection of expertly crafted mixed beverages.  My gastronomical curiosity piqued, I opted to sample their signature Ghost Burger, accompanied by a creative sweet potato mash.  While the burger itself was somewhat overcooked, the incorporation of crispy bacon slices within the sweet potato puree elevated its flavor profile.  The spicy undertones of the Ghost Burger were balanced, yet the grilled onion slices added a welcome depth to the dish.  Although the service was not exceptional, it is worth noting that the staff may have been preoccupied with preparations for the impending busy evening ahead.  The prices, however, were moderately steep, totaling $20 for a single burger and beverage.  Given the caliber of the cuisine presented, a more reasonable price range would fall between $10-15."

Stopped in for a pint and a burger after a Friday Night run with the Charlotte Runner's Meet Up group.  Place is huge, with an outdoor patio and three floors of bar / restaurant space.  Lots of beers on tap - at least six local brews - as well as just about any mixed drink you could want.  I tried the Ghost Burger with the sweet potato mash.  Actually preferred the mash to the burger - the bacon slices in with the sweet potatoes were quite tasty!  The Ghost Burger itself was spicy but not outrageous.  A bit overcooked, but the grilled onions on touch were a nice touch.  Waitstaff was not great, but it was a Friday night so they probably were just prepping for a long night.  Prices were high - spent $20 for a burger and beer.  Would expect to pay about $10-15 for the quality of the food served.

After pigging out at the Wynn buffet for lunch we just wanted something simple and quick for dinner. We came here as it is my mom's preferred pho place in town. It was ok. Summer rolls lacked any mint, the veggie sides were only some bean sprouts, sad looking basil and a few slices of jalepeno.  But then we were in the middle of the desert not SoCal or Hawaii.  The broth was ok and overall just ok.

I'll be perfectly honest.  I probably never would have gone here if it had not been for my husband's coworkers.  College bars just aren't my scene, living in Boston will do that to you.  But given it was the summer and we were in a group of 50 I thought it would be ok. 

We took over the whole back part which was nice.  The drinks were well made and I'm assuming cheap.  They have two pool tables in the back, which are slightly awkward given their close proximity to the bar.  The music was fairly generic ranging from your classic drunk girl anthems (Pour Some Sugar on Me) to current Top 40 hits.  My husband enjoyed the bathroom attendant, whom he swears must have be related to Lil Jon, saying things like "Get yo piss on!"  

They have a "no pictures" policy which I found to be incredibly lame.  You can't snap a picture of you and your friend having a good time without their written permission?  Really?  Guys, its not that impressive of a place that you have to try to keep it secretive.  I've actually never experienced something like that before and most of the places I frequent are a lot nicer than this.

Would I go once classes start in the fall? Heck no.

I was looking for a place that served Gyro's and this place serves them. I ordered mine to go so I cannot comment on the wait service but the taste of the gyro meat was pretty good. I was a little put off by the overall condition and cleanliness of the place, I did not see any bugs but would not have been surprised if one came strutting out of the back at any moment. It just didn't look clean and although I did like the Gyro, I have decided not to return because I have a feeling it is not very clean and that means the food is probably in nasty conditions in the back, I would suggest they clean and make the place look better with some nicer furnishing and maybe some paint and bleach. Just sayin'.
Ugly exterior. Nicer than expected interior. Stay here as cheaper get away experience, does the job I suppose. Didn't stay here, visited a friend. That's pretty it.

We ate at La Porte Grecque as part of a party of 40 (dinner after a baptism). The location of the restaurant and the ample parking made it ideal for group events. There were 2 indoor sections and 1 outside section allowing for lots of options. We were in the larger of the 2 indoor sections.

Service was good considering the size of our party. We were offered a nice menu and they happily accommodated any dietary concerns with off-menu items. 

The food was just ok. The starters were small but tasty (choice of feta and olives (2 whole olives...), tzatziki or vine leaves (3). The mains were big but the food was pretty dull. Desert was a cake. 

The restaurant is a BOYW joint which is nice.

"Thus, I opted for the Com bi cha suon nuong, and my gastronomical expectations were adequately met, as the pork chop boasted an impressive sapidity, with the seasonings harmoniously complementing the natural flavor of the meat, without an excessive reliance on salt. However, my satisfaction with the dish was not entirely unmitigated, as the bi, while palatable, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, which was attributable to the meatloaf (cha), whose texture bordered on the unpleasantly dense, suggestive of an overzealous exposure to heat, thereby slightly detracting from my overall enjoyment of the meal."

I have been frequenting this hair salon for approximately a year, and while I have enjoyed my visits, I have not experienced an overwhelming sense of satisfaction; thus, I believe it is time for me to explore other options. Despite my ambivalence towards the salon, I must acknowledge that the atmosphere is quite pleasant, and the majority of the stylists are cordial and welcoming. In particular, Julia has won my affection due to her striking resemblance to one of my closest friends back home, which has contributed to my prolonged patronage. 

Upon securing a last-minute appointment with Megan following several weeks of sporting an unkempt, albeit practical, ponytail, I was delighted to discover that she possessed a friendly and conversational demeanor. However, upon closer inspection of my coiffure, I noticed that the precision and attention to detail were not up to par with my previous experiences at the salon. This, coupled with the recent price hikeâa staggering 50% increase, I might addâleads me to surmise that the salon's transition to exclusively utilizing Bumble & Bumble products may have played a role in the subpar quality of my cut. 

While I harbor some misgivings about the salon, I must admit that the stylist did exhibit a commendable level of friendliness and approachability. Nonetheless, the style she fashioned for me struck me as somewhat uninspired and lacking the edgy, youthful flair that I have come to expect from my hairstyles. In point of fact, the end result seemed to lean more towards a stereotypical soccer mom aesthetic, which, although endearing in its own right, does not align with my self-perceived image as a vibrant, 21-year-old individual. 

In light of these factors, I have resolved to seek out alternative salons where I can indulge in a more exceptional and invigorating experience, culminating in a triumphant exit, brimming with confidence and an enhanced sense of attractiveness.

I genuinely aspired to cherish this establishment immensely, admiring the concept, commending the excellent service, appreciating the cozy ambiance, and relishing the culinary offerings. Unfortunately, the price point proved to be significantly discordant with the prevailing market rates, rendering the dining experience financially untenable. It is essential to emphasize that the cuisine was not of poor quality; however, the prices charged were incommensurate with the quantity and quality of the dishes served.

The cheese and charcuterie plate, offered at $18, was regrettably minuscule, appearing somewhat lackluster and questionably fresh. My companion and I opted for the lamb bolognese and cassoulet, both of which were palatable yet insufficiently substantial for the price of $24 per dish. Additionally, the portion sizes were relatively meager. We also sampled the Russian honey cake, which, while pleasant, would have benefited from being freshly prepared. Its slightly chilled temperature and faintly synthetic taste suggested that it had not been recently baked.

In light of the above, it is reasonable to assert that the cost of our dinner was disproportionate to the value received. Considering the modest scale of the enterprise and its recent inception, it would be more judicious for the restaurant to cultivate a devoted clientele by providing reasonably priced, refined comfort food, rather than overcompensating for expenses by inflating menu prices. This approach may potentially foster a loyal patronage and facilitate sustainable growth.

An additional observation reinforces this argument: the eatery's decor and tableware appear somewhat economical, employing inexpensive materials. While there is no inherent issue with frugality, the incongruity of consuming a $24 entree with low-cost utensils becomes apparent. The key challenge lies in determining the optimal balance between fiscal responsibility and strategic investment to ensure a harmonious dining experience for patrons.

"Intriguing conceptualization. Construct-your-own sushi roll. I appreciate the ability to select the components that will be incorporated into my sushi, however, the cost is somewhat prohibitive considering the quality of the ingredients utilized. Furthermore, the portions of fish and meat are rather meager. Although the rolls themselves are of considerable size, the primary component remains rice. \n\nThe employment of mechanical devices to distribute the rice and slice the sushi, among other tasks, is indeed fascinating to observe. This establishment is situated within a college town and caters primarily to students, thus, one cannot expect an excessive level of refinement."

They effectively captured the essence of their culinary objectives with a focus on Scandinavian cuisine, but unfortunately, it did not align with my personal preferences, despite the exceptional quality of the poutine.
They nailed exactly what they are trying to do hear with Scandinavian food. Problem is that it's not the right genre for me. Poutine was lights out though.

This place is probably great for a lot of people but I didn't care for it. I had the enchilada omelet and it had nasty American processed cheese on it I guess that's what they use for omelets and that probably doesn't bother most people but It makes me gag.. Ew on the menu it says jack cheese but it should add that it's processed. Anyways enough of the cheese rant. The service was good and the coffee cake was really good.

"The culinary offerings were adequate, failing to transport my gustatory senses to a higher plane of existence, yet still managing to satisfy my hunger. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the blackened salmon, which necessitated the application of an additional condiment to enhance its flavor profile. The attentive server proffered a maple honey glaze, which contributed a modicum of taste, albeit insufficient to elevate the dish to a truly delectable experience. In response to my query regarding alternative sauces, he presented me with the marinade utilized in their chicken wing preparation, a blend of soy sauce, pineapple juice, and orange juice. When combined with the maple butter, this confluence of flavors finally endowed the salmon with the missing je ne sais quoi. The fried okra was indeed palatable, boasting a satisfying crunch and subtle seasoning. Additionally, I sampled the Mac and cheese, possessing a faint spicy undertone and purportedly crafted from scratch, leading me to assume a more substantial, baked format. However, the reality fell short of my expectations. Notwithstanding, the overall quality of the fare, coupled with the excellent service, encourages me to consider a future visit, during which I would endeavor to explore further items on their menu."

The food was okay.  It didn't send my tastebuds to another dimension, but it was good. I ordered the blackened salmon -which needed ask me type of sauce to make it taste better.  The waiter gave me maple honey to try, which gave it a little more taste. I asked if he had anything else....he gave me the marinade that they use on their wings.  It was a combination of soy sauce, pineapple juice, and orange juice.  This combined with the maple butter gave it what it was missing.  The fried okra was really good.  I also got Mac and cheese which had a little kick to it.  They stated that it was made from scratch so I was thinking that it would be something baked.  \n\nOverall, the food was okay, the service was good, and I would give them another try, but would want to try some other recipes of course.

"While I do manage to procure an adequate amount of my required items at this particular Whole Foods location, I must admit that its diminutive size in comparison to other stores of the same chain, coupled with a noticeably limited selection and variety of products, does leave something to be desired. 

Nevertheless, I do appreciate the establishment's commendable dedication to catering to the dietary restrictions of its patrons, as evidenced by the impressive array of gluten-free options available. 

However, I must confess that navigating the store's compact layout can, at times, prove to be a somewhat arduous and time-consuming endeavor, often resulting in my failure to locate a significant portion of the items on my shopping list. 

Furthermore, I cannot help but feel that the prices charged by Whole Foods, including this specific location, are somewhat exorbitant and perhaps even a tad excessive, thereby contributing to my overall dissatisfaction with the experience."

Watched a preseason Laker game at this venue against the Sacramento Kings, and it proved to be an enjoyable experience, owing to the fact that we had procured relatively decent seats. Upon our arrival, I apprised the attendant of our ticket possession, and she directed us towards the queue designated for purchasing tickets, which, unfortunately, was quite extensive. Following a ten-minute wait, we sought clarification once more, and this time, the attendant informed us that we could bypass the line and proceed directly into the arena, which struck us as somewhat perplexing, considering the unnecessary delay we had endured. Moreover, the lines for procuring sustenance and beverages were considerable in length, requiring a significant amount of time to navigate.

Watched a preseason laker game here against the sacramento kings and it was a fun experience as we pretty good seats.

Upon arriving I told the attendant we had tickets and she pointed us in the line to purchase tickets which was rather long.  We stood in line for about 10 min before asking again to make sure and this time she said we didn't have to stand in line and we can just go in, wtf man what a waste of time!

Lines for food and drinks were rather lengthy and took awhile.

The only street level spot for morning coffee on First Avenue between Fillmore and Monroe.   The lights were on, the OPEN sign too.  I had a few minutes before my appointment with a Very time-fixated appointment coordinator.  Coffee Time!

Opening the door, I walked into a clean hive of sound and energy.  GaGa's techno pop driving busy bees making a sandwich tray for somebody's event, prepping for lunch, serving breakfast, and generally revving up for a busy Tuesday at the Hero Factory.  

The coffee was my style of Americano - Folgers or Farmer Bros.  Vacuum pots, sweeteners and stir sticks on a small south wall table.  Half and half and milk were in the cooler.  Help myself, pay my dollar, find a sunny table for sipping and dumping the chaff from my e-mail.   

The past three years a lot of downtown Phoenix restaurants have been raked from the streets like dead leaves after a dust or thunder storm.  Places I've seen for years and patronized occasionally stand empty, waiting for new  cheftrepreneurs.  Other places, pruned hard by the economy, live and serve. An energetic beehive like Hero Factory is great to have around.  Nicole invited me back for lunch.  I'll do that, and bring some friends.  Maybe I'll order a sandwich tray instead, bring it to work, invite everybody and goober up the conference room table with breadcrumbs, lettuce fragments, onion snippets, mayo and mustard.  I'll be back for a rewrite no matter what.

My Husband and I took my Grandma here for the first time this past Mother's Day (I know sorry for the late review).  I was really pleased that they took a reservation for the day because I've heard there can be a long wait.  Upon arrival we were greeted and seated quickly (after they cleared the table).  Our waitress was prompt and nice.  Overall, I like the decor, but the atmosphere felt very crowded and overwhelming to me... maybe it was just because of the holiday.\n\nI ordered the crazy biscuits, which I didn't love.  It was very heavy, which was obvious that it would be, but the taste didn't blow me away.  The Hubs had pancakes, which were really good.  My Grandma had the hash, which I didn't try, but she loved.  Based on this experience alone, I would go back considering so many people love it.  I would probably try something completely different though.

"Satisfactory culinary experience with a caveat; exorbitant pricing! If you're willing to splurge, this establishment offers an all-you-can-eat option for $30, allowing you to select your own side dishes, which are merely adequate. Their premier meat options, Bulogi and short ribs, are undoubtedly delectable. The service was impressive, as the staff were attentive, helpful, and enthusiastic about assisting with food preparation. However, an unfortunate incident occurred upon payment; the cashier/server inquired as to why I hadn't left a gratuity, stressing that it was obligatory. This encounter left a sour taste, prompting me to reconsider my initial inclination to leave a tip, ultimately resulting in a rating of three."

Good food and service but very pricey! if your willing to spend then its a good place to eat , 30$ alll you can eat you choose your own side dishes which are alright. the Bulgogi is there best meat and the short ribs. Service was great very helpful and they love helping you cook the meat. The reason i gave it a three was that at the end of the meal after paying 100$ for three al you can eat , the cashier/server harassed me why didn't i leave a tip that it was mandatory ,which was very unappreciate i was going to leave the tip but the fact that i was told i had to made me not do it

"The culinary experience at this establishment was indeed satisfactory, as anticipated, but patrons should be prepared to incur a significant financial burden in exchange for the prestige associated with dining here. Additionally, my significant other informed me that adult beverages were available, which heightened my enthusiasm for spending an extended period of time at the venue; however, the selection was limited to a mere five or six varieties of beer, all of which were served in bottles rather than on tap. Despite this, I would still advocate for visiting this restaurant if you are already in close proximity, but I would not suggest traveling a moderate to considerable distance specifically to dine here."

Food was really good, as expected, but be ready to spend quite a bit. You really are paying a price premium for the reputation of the place. 
Also, my girlfriend told me there was alcool served, so I was really motivated to spend a good portion of the night there, but they really offered only 5-6 beer types and all in bottles.

I would recommend it if you are in the area, but I would not recommend you to travel a medium to long distance to go there.
I went in one time and had terrible customer service... Went in another and it was really good! Thanks Mariah. I think that's what her name was.
Old school mexican restaurant.  Food was good,  no beer, A/C was marginal.  Not for those looking for the chain restaurant atmosphere.  Very traditional.  I'll visit again when the weather is cooler.

No doubt a popular venue as judged by our wait even after we had a reservation. 

Ate my usual bone in filet and was utterly disappointed. In fact I was underwhelmed by every dish that came out.  

I guess I should have gotten the seafood?

"I have had the pleasure of partaking in the morning repast at this esteemed establishment on a solitary occasion, and I must confess that the culinary offerings were indeed of superior quality. However, I must deduct a star from my overall rating due to my personal preference for a more subdued ambiance during the early hours of the day. Specifically, I find the presence of techno music at 9 am to be somewhat jarring and detrimental to my dining experience. Additionally, I believe that a simplified menu would better align with my desire for a tranquil morning meal, as opposed to the extensive selection of 18 distinct omelette options. Notwithstanding these criticisms, I would still recommend this venue to individuals who appreciate a lively atmosphere and a diverse array of breakfast choices, as it undoubtedly surpasses Eggspectation in terms of overall quality."

I've only been here for breakfast and I must say it is damn good. The only reason I'm giving this place 3 stars because I'm not such a fan of the atmosphere for the morning. At 9am I don't want to hear techno music and I much prefer a relaxed atmosphere with a simple menu; not 18 different omelette!\n\nAlthough if you want a fancy breakfast and enjoy the hectic atmosphere, this place is definitely better than Eggspectation, so give it a try!

Great service from Christian. The truth is sometimes I just want good old WT food. The food is greasy and good. To many people want to rate places by comparing them to one of the best steakhouses. I try to rate it for what it is. It's a good place to go for some good greasy food. I enjoyed everything I had there!
The food is excellent but the service leaves a bad taste in your mouth.  Definitely not a kid friendly place.
