"Based on my initial visit, I believe Bouchon warrants a rating of three stars; however, I am willing to give it another opportunity to demonstrate its full potential. The dining area exuded an elegant ambiance, and the surroundings were aesthetically pleasing. My companion and I opted to partake in the brunch menu on a Saturday, selecting chicken and waffles, steak frites, half a dozen oysters, and specialty cocktails. 

To summarize briefly...
Freshly baked bread and rich, creamy butter accompanied our meals. The oysters were exceptionally fresh, and it is recommended to specify the type of oyster desired to ensure utmost satisfaction. The chicken and waffles were satisfactory, yet unremarkable, while the steak frites were cooked to perfection. 

My sole concern, which is not truly a grievance given the friendly demeanor of the staff, lies in the desire for a consistent and timely service. We were attended to by multiple servers, resulting in irregular intervals between courses. A considerable delay existed between the bread and butter and the arrival of our oysters, and our primary dishes did not arrive simultaneously. Furthermore, upon inquiring about the status of my beverage, our waitress seemed genuinely taken aback that it had not been delivered, leading me to speculate whether the bartender's direct delivery of drinks contributed to the discrepancy. Enhancing communication or assigning a single individual to oversee the entire process could potentially address this issue."

I think Bouchon probably deserves 3 stars based on my first visit, but I'm willing to give it another try. It is a very pretty dining room and the atmosphere was really nice. My boyfriend and I went for brunch on a Sat. We ordered chicken and waffles, steak frites, 1/2 dozen oysters, and cocktails.

Just briefly...
Bread and butter: awesome soft butter...hard bread
Oysters: really fresh but specify what types of oysters you want to your waitress
Chicken and waffles: pretty good but nothing out of the ordinary
Steak frites: good

My only compliant, which isn't really a complaint because the staff was really nice...is that I wish we were served by one person only so that's it's more consistent and timely. We had our waitress and different servers who delivered each of our items. Our items came at odd intervals. There was a big gap between the bread and butter and our oysters, our main dishes didn't come at the same time...and when I asked the waitress if my drink was still coming after we had started our dishes, she seemed genuinely surprised it hadn't. Maybe it's because the bartender delivers the drinks himself? I'm not really sure, but that would be my only suggestion, one person to take care of everything or better communication.
Don't get me wrong, steiner's is one of my favorite places but, the \"hashed browns\" served this morning were horrible!  It was like a paste that was smeared onto the griddle & cooked.  So sad

"A palpable dearth of essence permeates the ambiance of this establishment, rendering it inferior to alternative dim sum locales I have had the pleasure of experiencing. The service, characterized by an overzealous demeanor, proved intrusive, as the staff persistently endeavored to expedite our ordering process despite the absence of our complete party. Nonetheless, certain items on the menu, specifically the custard buns, shumai, and duck, did manage to elicit my approval. However, the lobster pasta failed to impress, with its unremarkable noodles overshadowing the otherwise satisfying lobster. Furthermore, the practice of removing dishes from the table for reheating in the kitchen prior to serving strikes me as inconvenient and detrimental to the overall dining experience. In light of these factors, I would not recommend revisiting this restaurant, as superior alternatives for dim sum exist."

Something is just missing at this place compared to other dim sums I've had. Service was pushy to start. They kept rushing us to order when we were still waiting for our entire party to be seated. I liked the custard buns, shumai and duck. Don't waste your time or money on the lobster pasta. The lobster was good, but the noodles were bland and forgettable. Not a fan of them having to take the food to the back to be reheated before serving, either. I probably wouldn't go back, there are better places to have dim sum.

"Ideal for perusing patrons or indulging in a beverage while awaiting a table at Le ProvenÃ§al, this charming setting boasts an ambiance conducive to both relaxation and people-watching. Although the gelato offerings are invigorating, the culinary selections lean towards the unwholesome end of the spectrum, and the pace of service is leisurely, to say the least."
great for people watching or sitting with a drink while waiting to be seated at le provenal.\n\nthe gelato is refreshing but the food is on the junk food side. service is slow.

My standard for Vietnamese food maybe a little high given the fact that I lived in SoCal about a 20 minute drive from Westminster/Little Saigon.\n\nWhile the service here is very good for an asian restaurant, and the restaurant itself is clean and modern compared to most vietnamese restaurants, the food was just OK. I ordered the Grilled Pork and it was too fatty and salty (even for me who likes to eat salty) :-(

"Prior to returning our rental car, I implored my spouse to visit this establishment, as the reviews had piqued my interest. Upon consuming their maple donut, I would unhesitatingly award it a perfect score of ten out of five stars. The donut's exterior was delightfully crispy, while its interior was characterized by a satisfying moistness and cakiness, thereby exemplifying the quintessential donut experience. My second favorite variety was the cinnamon crumb donut, which boasted an agreeable flavor profile. However, my enthusiasm waned when I sampled the apple fritter, as it exhibited an unpleasant greasiness akin to double-frying and an overpowering sweetness that rendered it difficult to consume more than a single bite. Furthermore, the coffee served at this venue was subpar and elicited a negative response from me, with one reviewer accurately describing it as 'diner style,' which I unfortunately did not recognize as a pejorative term until after I had ingested it. Notwithstanding these criticisms, I would still frequent this establishment to indulge in their exceptional maple and cinnamon crumb donuts, and perhaps even attempt their old-fashioned glazed variety. Nonetheless, I would unequivocally avoid both the apple fritter and coffee offerings in the future."

I begged my husband to come here prior to returning our rental car due to the reviews. If I was only reviewing the maple donut, I would say 10 stars out of five. The maple donut is absolute perfection - crispy on the outside, moist and cakey on the inside, and everything a donut should be. Next on my list in order of flavor was the cinnamon crumb donut, which was also pretty good. I tried the apple fritter based on the reviews here but found it entirely too greasy, almost as if it had been double-fried, and way too sweet. I could only take one bite. The coffee was also pretty bad. I think one other reviewer described it as \"diner style\" which I didn't realize was an insult until after I drank it. I'd come back here every week for maple and cinnamon crumb donuts, and maybe to try the old fashioned glazed, but I definitely wouldn't get the coffee or the apple fritter again.

"A luxurious abode, equipped with an array of facilities, boasting a remarkable assemblage of aquatic areas. However, it is crucial to select a room located at a considerable distance from the Vista Lounge, as the cacophony of mediocre live music emanating from the lounge, audible throughout the surrounding rooms above it, persists for an extended period of four hours daily. A truly unpleasant experience. 

Furthermore, the absence of complimentary internet access is a disappointment. 

While the room service is satisfactory, it is regrettably overpriced by approximately 40 percent, a common trait among resorts. 

In conclusion, a pleasant lodging, marred only by the aforementioned drawbacks."

Nice hotel, all the amenities you need, great complex of pools. Just make sure your room is as far from the Vista Lounge as possible; otherwise you'll be bombarded with crappy live music, fully audible from the lounge to all the surrounding rooms above it, for four hours a day. Horrible.

The Internet access is not free, which is lame.

The room service is good but overpriced by at least 40 percent. So it goes with resorts.

Otherwise a very nice hotel.

Cali-style men's and women's clothing.
Men's tanks, board shorts, tshirts, jeans and shoes.
Women's dresses, shorts, tops, shirts, swimwear, jeans, and shoes.
Also, lots of brands to choose from like Brandy Melville, Volcom, Billabong, Quicksilver, Vans and some Nike SB shoes. They have cute accessories, too!

The store is pretty big and quality of clothing is pretty ok.
Definitely a store for teens, or skinny people (lol) .. 
I like a few things, but a little over priced if you ask me!

Not bad! Nice decor with cute serving dishes. I ordered the triple B burger, almost $20 (you pay for the name) but wasn't really worth the $20. Our hostess ignored us for while (with no one else waiting) before seating us and our waitress gave really poor customer service, however our runner was great and should've been our server! \n\nIf we want a great burger we'll just go to Bachi burger and get a grass fed burger for $8 cheaper! All in all, I'm glad we tried but we probably won't eat here again due to the high prices and not so attentive staff.

The Flamingo is what it is:  one of the original strip hotels trying to keep up with the never ending crop of new, ultra-modern hotels.  The flamingo succeeds on some levels:  full amenities, clean rooms, recent redesign.  It mostly fails though.   Service is poor, casino floor is dingy, the rooms are not up to par with neighboring hotels, and dining/nigh life offerings are poor.  Margaritaville is a nice try, but it comes off as dated and cheesy.  \nFlamingo is centrally located though and the rooms are nice.  The value is high too (relatively cheap).  Not a bad choice and MUCH better than the Imperial Dungeon.

Good food for the price, and one of the better places that is available late night. This location is in need of serious cleaning. Which is the ONLY reason why I'm giving  3 stars and not 5. The best food and great service doesn't make up for filth when it is dead in the middle of the night / early morning and there are employees standing around.

I've been here a half dozen times or so, mostly because it's pretty inexpensive.  If you're looking to fill up after a long day of pressing the slot machine "spin" button, you should probably give it a shot.  The champagne brunch is worth the price, and the servers I've had have all been fast and generous with the mimosas.  

There's probably not a single item on the buffet that you'll "need" to go back for, but as far as overall value for your dollar, it's hard to beat.  

I'll go back.  More than once.

This place was ok I'm my opinion. We had to wait an hour to be seated then had to wait about another hour for our food to come out. I ordered the waffles and it was a good size, not sure i would split it since i don't think it was as much, however my hubs ordered something different and his plate was huge  it could easily feed to adults. Overall i recommend eating there at least once.

We were meandering through the picturesque landscapes of Southern Highlands, questing for an establishment that offered wireless internet connectivity... 
  Following a brief peregrination, we stumbled upon an enchanting edifice known as Perk Up, which piqued my curiosity and prompted an impromptu visitation. 
  Upon entering the premises, my gaze ascended towards the menu, which was embellished with an array of coffee and tea varieties, accompanied by an assortment of delectable pastries and quiches. 
  Initially, my attention was captivated by the beverages, but subsequent to a thorough examination of the menu, I discovered a supplementary list of breakfast and lunch options, articulated on a freestanding chalkboard. 
  Prior to perusing the menu, I requested a pot of tea, and subsequently, I opted for a savory repast, engaging in a dialogue with the hospitable cashier regarding several sandwich selections... 
  The young woman enthusiastically elaborated on the particulars of each dish, even mentioning the imminent emergence of freshly baked pumpkin muffins from the kitchen, which kindled my interest and precipitated an unwavering decision to sample their culinary delights. 
  My order consisted of a slice of quiche, complemented by a modest portion of fruit, which, upon arrival, proved to be satisfactory, albeit not extraordinary, while the fruit appeared slightly wilted, perhaps due to its advanced age. 
  My companion astutely observed that the fruit seemed unappealing and likely remained uneaten for a few days, prompting the staff to expedite the preparation of fresh fruit, which they graciously presented to us. 
  Although the cuisine did not evoke an intense yearning for a future visit, the spotless interior, combined with the attentive service, rendered Perk Up an agreeable venue for socializing over a cup of coffee or tea.

We were in Southern Highlands, looking for a place with Wi-Fi... 

We found one, Perk Up.. Since I'm always excited to try something new, we rushed right in. 

At first when I looked up at the menu all we saw were coffees & teas. They also had a display case that had muffins and sweet rolls, and slices of quiche. 

I finally looked to the right and there was a stand up menu chalk board that offered some breakfast & lunch options. 

I ordered some tea then decided I wanted lunch.. I asked about a couple of the sandwiches and the girl at the cash register was great in describing some of the offerings and even mentioned how she had pumpkin muffins coming out of the oven. YUM! 

I ordered the quiche, which came with a side of fruit. Once served the quiche was good, but I've had better, the small portion of fruit looked as though it had saved from last week, perhaps so since it was a Monday. My friend had mentioned that the fruit did not look appealing and most likely was a couple of days old. They immediately cut up some fresh fruit and brought it out to us. 

Nice, clean place with great service. It's not a place I am craving to go back to for lunch, but to meet for coffee or tea, you betcha!

We came here for lunch and a view of the strip.  There's not much of a weekday lunch crowd and getting a nice table with a view of the strip, Bellagio, and Caesars' Palace was easy.  I had a nice $16 burger that was cooked medium rare as requested.  Wife had baked vegetable crepes for $17.  Food was ok, but you're really paying for the view.   They also served complimentary bread puffs and a nice pistachio pudding.   Having recently gone to the Hancock's 95th floor Signature Room, I thought we might be going to the top of the Eiffel Tower, but this place is like at the 5th floor elevation.  Makes sense - they wouldn't have a whole lot of tables at the top of that skinny tower!

An update in my last review, since the improvements have been made. Unfortunatley I wanted to improve my 3 stars...but alas I cant. Yes the improvements have been made and you can see the results, but its still so bleak. Why are train stations always so cold even although they have an indoor waiting area?? \nThis is a well used station, more effort needed !!!
Located at one end of the Miracle Mile Shops.   Plenty of seating and lots of help behind the counter.   You can look out into the pool area during the day.
Basic burger and onion rings were good not great. Decent meal if you're at the Mirage but otherwise I'd look for another option if I was inclined to go elsewhere.

The events center was nice, but nothing special from a trade show perspective. Perhaps I would have liked it better if I were there for a concert or boxing event.

I tried to get wi-fi outside, but it was $500 per day!!! PER DAY! I want to say it was a typo or a bug in the system, but I was so turned off I didn't even try connecting. There's taking advantage of an audience, and then there's straight robbery. $500 for wi-fi is ridiculous. The Las Vegas Convention Center has free wi-fi.

Also, I tried to get a cab afterward, and there were none. I was about the 10th person in line, and I had to wait 20+ minutes for a cab. I'm not sure why that area's not well served by cabs. I would have been better off walking to the front of the hotel which is about 10 minutes from the event center.

Overall, I'd say go for the event, not the event center itself.

Went here because it's associated with Floyd Mayweather. Cute spot, kind of a tourist attraction, but a bit pricey. Not a plus size store by no stretch if the imagination. I'm really into customer service and perhaps I may have bought something if it were a bit more genuinely welcoming. I'd give them another try I'm totally down for small businesses and #girlpower

"It is utterly hilarious to observe the peculiar restrictions implemented at this establishment, specifically the conspicuously displayed signage that stipulates a mere 20-minute time frame for patrons to engage in the act of consuming sustenance while seated, thus implying that an individual's duration of satiety must be restricted to a specified interval; hence, it is advisable to arrive with an adequate level of hunger."
This place is funny!\n\nThey literally have a sign on the wall that says you can only sit and eat for a max of 20 mins!  So I hope you are hungry!!!

Lovely location overlooking the lake.  Flexible with last-minute reservations (and we were a party of 7).  Not ideal for small children.  Had to flag down the server multiple times (more water, ready to order, ready for the check)...The food wasn't bad, but overly priced.  The wine and dessert lists were both extensive.  But here's why I won't return: two antipasta plates were brought out by the server and as we did not order/ask for this, we assumed it was a complimentary offering.  When the bill arrived, we were charged $72 for the plates ($12 per adult), which we naturally disputed.  On top of the server not removing the antipasta from the bill, he refused to assist us by separating the bill into 4 checks (which in honesty wasn't something we asked for upfront, but hey, it happens).  With Lake Las Vegas' Village struggling the way it is, you'd think the businesses there would bend over backwards to bring their patrons back, especially the locals.  Long story short, I've got a bad taste in my mouth after this experience, and won't be recommending this restaurant any time soon.
If you're a gringo, than this is the place for you. The drink specials here are killer, but the food is better at Taco Bell...

So I don't normally expect a lot when eating at IHOP, but this one isn't that bad! And it's actually quite a busy location. I made the mistake of going here to eat during spring training season - it was insanely packed and we waited quite a while to be seated. However, once we were at our table the service was good and so was the food. This IHOP is open 24 hours, which may be good to know in case I get a midnight pancake craving.

You always walk out feeling healthy. The thinly sliced beef and veggies in broth or sauce is enough to be filling without making you feel like you just ate a truck because it is light on carbs. You get a small portion of noodles but most of the meal is protein and vegetable. Good deal for the money. The sukiyaki can sometimes be a bit too salty, especially when it boils down. I prefer the shabu shabu.

I LOVE this place and if I had a million hours to waste I would walk my lazy self across campus and pick up some sweet and sour chicken and have a free Styrofoam cup of green tea every day of my life. Unfortunately they do not deliver and I don't even think they know how to use a phone. The last time I was there the man was so busy he picked up the phone and put them on hold and never picked it back up. I found it funny, but I'm sure that customer did not. \nAnd, you know, if they opt out of delivery they should really clean the place up a bit. I get worried what the kitchen looks like and have peeked back there a few times to see complete chaos (mostly because there's 8 or 9 women cooking for too many customers to handle). \nI love the food, but this place is great to go to maybe a few times per semester. It's just too crowded for my liking.

Hype precedes realty here at Chocolat Bistro. Unfortunately the Las Vegas tourist TV plug doesn't help matters... It is a good crepe by non enthusiast standards, however this is Vegas,  so giddy up and REALLY indulge at a 4 star buffet!

"An indispensable yet problematic aspect of the electronic industry. Customer service is often unpredictable, with occasional encounters of helpful sales associates juxtaposed with frequent instances of inadequate or overly aggressive assistance. It is advisable to possess a clear understanding of one's desired purchases prior to entering such establishments."

Oversold flight... How exactly that happens? 

Was flying back home from an Iron Maiden concert in Phoenix and found, to my surprise, that although I'd paid for my reservation and checked in early, my flight was oversold. I was pissed to say the least. This review started @ 1 star. I raised it to 3 because the staff actually found me a very comfortable seat on the same flight... and I was able to get out quickly. The flight attendants were really nice and courteous.

So? I was happy.

This establishment represented my initial culinary venture within the city of Phoenix, and I was graciously accorded the privilege of partaking in a midday repast at this locale preceding a scheduled appointment, during which my mental state was characterized by a considerable degree of apprehension, thus rendering my recollection of specifics somewhat limited; however, I would unhesitatingly endorse this venue to devotees of Japanese cuisine or individuals seeking a rapid and convenient meal to be consumed at their workstation, and it is worthy of note that the hospitality we received was indeed commendable.

This was my first restaurant in Phoenix. I was taken here for a lunch prior to an interview I had. I was pretty nervous about the whole situation so I don't remember too many details, but I would recommend this place if you're a sushi lover or on the go and need a quick lunch to eat at your desk. Service was great too.

what i haven't reviewed this place yet and iv been here 100 times ...no serious at least, it is the best eatery in the east valley but my friends at Corbin's could really help spice up there menu. the food is good here but once you get use to the menu it gets old quick. there pasta dishes are over sauced or buttered chicken wings are some of the better ones iv had pizzas are good ect all the times i have been there and the owner has seen me he has never said hi,thanks for coming,good to see you AGAIN.........get out......... oh this place is usually packed between 5ish and 8ish again because its one of the few and far between better places in the east valley....they do have a great beer slection

I'm not going to deny one bit, the food was pretty good. I got the barbacoa burrito and the meat was really tender and sweet. Nothing was too dry, but that could also be the result of the wet beans and sauce they put in the burrito. The problem with that is that you cannot pick up the burrito and eat it with your hands, you're going to need a knife and fork. That was one downside of the food and it's not one of the cheaper places either. 

The food is quite pricy for the amount that is given. Chipotle is slightly cheaper and quite similar. That being the first time i went to Cafe Rio, they knew i was a beginner and asked tricky questions. When you order, they ask after they form your burrito if you want it enchilada style. I said no as well as my friend behind me and they did it with his and they charge you .95 cents more for it! Is it really worth it? i highly doubt it especially since it's just sauce and cheese. They don't even tell you these things cost more money, they just ask you and make you fall into their trap. Tricky people.

Bottom line, food is good, kind of pricy, and the people are tricky. Not an everyday kind of place if you don't have the money to spend and it's not so bad if you know the menu and style of the place and how you order food.

If there existed a button emblazoned with the phrase "not intended for consumption by vegetarians", I would unhesitatingly engage its surface with my index finger, as an expression of my culinary inclinations. Notwithstanding the aforementioned statement, my associates who partake in the consumption of meat products have expressed their satisfaction with the edibles offered by this establishment, and the personnel operating the bar have demonstrated proficiency in their duties during the designated period of reduced alcoholic beverage prices. A considerable portion of the clientele present during the late afternoon and early evening hours consist of legal professionals, likely due to the proximity of this venue to their places of employment within adjacent structures.

This undiscovered treasure trove of culinary delights, nestled within the confines of Planet Hollywood, offers a veritable cornucopia of gastronomical indulgences at a price point that is eminently reasonable and accessible to the discerning patron. Although the speed of service may vary contingent upon the time of day and the influx of clientele, the ambiance of this eatery remains palpably electric and unwaveringly conducive to satiating one's hunger pangs, particularly during the nocturnal hours when other establishments have ceased operation. While the quality of the fare served may not necessarily qualify it as the most exceptional or delectable offering within the city's vast gastronomic landscape, it nevertheless fulfills its intended purpose with aplomb and serves as a welcome respite for those seeking sustenance following an evening of revelry and merriment in the city of Las Vegas. Moreover, the convenience of round-the-clock availability renders it an invaluable asset for those who find themselves in need of a satisfying repast during the wee hours of the morning.

"The accommodations merited a rating of three celestial bodies due to the exceptional benevolence of the personnel and the spaciousness of the chambers. However, the experience was somewhat marred by the unavailability of the room until after the designated check-in period, which necessitated a brief excursion to pass the time. Upon returning to the resort, I was compelled to indulge in some nocturnal slumber in my friend's suite before gaining access to my own quarters at an ungodly hour of 4:15 a.m. Furthermore, the bedding presented an unfortunate state of uncleanness, prompting the staff to effect a replacement with fresh linens, pillows, and a comforter obtained from an external cleaning service. Although certain minor inconveniences arose, the staff maintained a persistently pleasant demeanor, leaving me uncertain about the prospect of future lodging at this establishment."

The ambiance/decor is really great. It's fun and hip. You can sit on the balcony or step out to the balcony during the Treasure Island pirate ship show and have a great view.

BAD: prices are high.

BAD: stir-fry shrimp with sambal sauce. Way too salty, had to send it back.

BAD: kobe beef sliders were way too salty. came with an untraditional ketchup, mustard, and good onion rings.

OK with major potential: Lychee beignets. These arrive in traditional round beignet form but are filled with a substance that tastes like batter with chopped lychees. I guess the chef doesn't know that beignet are supposed to be light and airy. These are more like doughnuts and are too sweet because they're covered in sugar crystals. I loved the lychee taste when I could taste it.

OK: the yellowtail sashimi with jalapeno preparation was tasty but the slices were really thin and the fish could have been fresher.

GOOD: edamame. served warm with some salt.

GOOD: sushi. Hubby is very picky and he enjoyed his nigiri and hand-rolls.

GOOD: hubby really liked the steak yakitori in the sauce that has a long name starting with a K.

Second time partaking in a culinary excursion to this gastronomical establishment specializing in delectable burger delights, I must confess that my appreciation for the edible offerings presented by the venue has augmented considerably since my initial visit, with the succulent burgers being the undeniable piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance; such tantalizing treats possess an unparalleled capacity to satiate my gustatory desires, leaving me in a state of utter fulfillment and contentment, rendering any further exploration of the menu unnecessary. Although alternative comestibles such as burritos and bowls are available, my fascination with the burgers remains unwavering, precluding any inclination to diverge from the tried and true favorite. Furthermore, the eatery's commitment to maintaining a spotless environment and staffing friendly, accommodating personnel serves as a testament to its dedication to ensuring a pleasurable dining experience for all patrons, thereby fostering a sense of confidence in the establishment's ability to persist in offering its delectable fare for an extended period.

The frequency of my patronage was once a week, and my fondness for their culinary offerings, specifically their pizza, was unwavering; however, my satisfaction with their ravioli was consistently thwarted by its tendency to be overcooked, thereby negating my preference for the texture to be al dente; furthermore, their lasagne, while palatable, did not quite meet my expectations. Additionally, I had to issue repeated requests for them to refrain from overcooking the bread knots, as they had a propensity to arrive burnt and crispy, which rendered them inedible. Furthermore, on at least three occasions, they failed to deliver my order in a timely manner, despite my proximity to their establishment, which was located a mere five minutes away. These instances of tardiness transpired during the lull period between lunch and dinner, which I would not classify as a peak hour. Consequently, I am unlikely to revisit this establishment in the future.

I used to order almost weekly. I like their pizza but their ravioli is always overcooked. I like it Al dente. Their lasagne is ok. I always have to ask them not to overcook the bread knots because mine were burnt several times.  They were late with my order at least three times even though I live 5 min away. This was after the lunch hour and before dinner hour, not what I would consider to be a busy time. I probably won't be back.

"The server was exceptional, as they consistently ensured that our beverages remained full and that our orders were delivered in a prompt and efficient manner. My dining companion and I opted for the chili cheese fries and 12 wings, which we requested to be prepared in the honey BBQ style. Unfortunately, the sauce proved to be somewhat overpowering, and both the wings and fries failed to maintain their temperature for an extended period. Specifically, the wings became cold within a mere five minutes, while the fries followed suit shortly thereafter. 

As a former bartender, I possess a discerning palate when it comes to the preparation of beverages. Thus, I was slightly dismayed when my Shirley Temple was crafted with the grenadine positioned at the bottom. This particular method of construction rendered the drink somewhat challenging to blend properly, resulting in an excessive sweetness. 

Despite these minor setbacks, the ambiance of the establishment was quite pleasant, particularly since we had the opportunity to sit outside. Moreover, the strategically placed televisions allowed us to conveniently view the Carolina versus Duke game. While the quality of the food may not have been the primary focus of the restaurant, I would still consider returning to partake in their offerings and enjoy the sporting events they showcase."

I had an immense desire to appreciate Tao, as it represented my maiden nightclubbing venture in Las Vegas, and I must say that my expectations were rather elevated due to the captivating ambiance and theme that permeated the venue; specifically, the majestic Buddha statue, the females luxuriating in bathtubs, and the restroom doors that required a deliberate effort to secure them opaquely, all contributed to an atmosphere that was unquestionably engaging.  Unfortunately, the club encountered an unforeseen influx of patrons, resulting in an excessive degree of congestion that rendered the experience somewhat disagreeable, and the assemblage of individuals present did not possess the same level of appeal as those found at the clubs situated within the Encore and Wynn establishments, thereby leading me to conclude that a return visit would not be forthcoming.

"There exists a duality of beneficial and detrimental aspects at this establishment.  The happy hour experience is generally satisfying, as the atmosphere is conducive to conviviality and the clientele is typically abundant.  The staff members are also courteous and efficient in their duties.  However, the physical layout of the seating area is somewhat cramped, resembling a tight fit reminiscent of an overindulgent individual's waistband following a particularly indulgent dining excursion at a Golden Corral.  Furthermore, parking facilities are limited, necessitating a moderate walking distance from alternative parking locations within the surrounding complex.  The culinary offerings are merely average, failing to impress discerning palates.  In conclusion, while this venue may serve adequately as a starting point for nocturnal revelry, those seeking a satisfactory dining experience would be well-advised to explore alternative options."

"This modest yet captivating establishment serves as an inconspicuous retreat for those seeking respite within the midst of downtown Phoenix's vibrant urban landscape. Additionally housing a bookstore and bakery/restaurant, the expansive gallery boasts an impressive interior, replete with exposed brick walls and polished concrete floors that pay homage to its rich historical roots. While the artwork on display may be perceived as exorbitantly priced and lacking in exceptional quality, this quaint cultural oasis remains an idyllic setting for a leisurely meal, book perusal, or simply relishing the allure of the surrounding artistry, providing a tranquil escape for those who venture forth into this charming enclave."

"Not all barbecue is created equal, and as a native of Chicago, I have been indoctrinated with a profound appreciation for the authentic variety, characterized by pork barbecue ribs and rib tips that hail from the southern precincts of the city. The type of barbecue that necessitates a concerted effort to extricate the meat from the bone, accompanied by the unmistakable aroma of charred ribs wafting through the air several blocks away. Needless to say, this specific genre of barbecue reigns supreme in my culinary hierarchy. However, it would be remiss of me to suggest that I am incapable of acknowledging and enjoying alternative styles of barbecue, as evidenced by our shared repast of pulled pork sandwiches and a slab of ribs, which, albeit satisfying, did not quite measure up to the lofty standards I have established for genuine barbecue. Furthermore, I must commend the exceptional customer service we received, courtesy of the hostess and waitress, whose politeness, attentiveness, and general amiability were nothing short of laudable. It is unfortunate that not all establishments can boast such impressive levels of competence, but Bobby Q stands out as a shining example of how a well-run establishment should operate."

"It is utterly captivating to possess an unwavering fondness for Groupon, albeit occasionally. In this particular instance, the sudden influx of patrons proved to be overwhelming for the establishment, leading to an unfortunate state of disarray. The pace of service was excruciatingly slow, almost to the point of exasperation. Furthermore, there were instances of erroneous orders being delivered, which, although problematic, did not deter us from partaking in the culinary experience due to our unrelenting hunger. Ultimately, despite the operational challenges faced by our local sushi restaurant, we remain steadfast in our intention to revisit and indulge in their offerings once again."

"Indulged in an evening of conviviality with acquaintances at a watering hole in Rutland, characterized by elevated prices yet commendable ambiance and hospitable personnel; an establishment exuding refinement and sophistication, ideal for engaging in leisurely conversation while enjoying a street-level perspective of Princes Street."

Rudy's, an establishment purporting to offer consumers a satisfactory barbecue sandwich experience, possesses certain attributes that may be deemed advantageous by patrons. Specifically, the restaurant boasts an abundance of sauces, each exhibiting a distinct flavor profile, and a spacious interior with ample seating, conveniently situated in close proximity to numerous retail establishments. However, several drawbacks have been noted, including a dearth of French fries, a staple side dish customarily accompanying barbecue meals, and a so-called "general store" that fails to live up to expectations, particularly when compared to the quintessential Cracker Barrel. Notwithstanding these limitations, a visit to Rudy's may be worthwhile, primarily due to the exceptional quality of their creamed corn, an item that, despite the author's professed ambivalence towards it, has been described as nothing short of extraordinary.

Rudy's is a pretty decent place to get a BBQ Sandwich.  

Pros:  -There is sauce a-plenty and they are all pretty tasty
            -Creamed Corn is OUT OF THIS WORLD 
            -Big space with plenty of seating
            -Location is easy to find and near lots of shopping

Cons: -Service is a bit unprofessional flirting and weird comments abundant
           -There are no french fries (BBQ without fries is kind of un-American)
            -"General Store" is pretty lame.  Nothing like a Cracker Barrel.  
           
I say try it.  If for no other reason than that freaking amazing creamed corn!  I know this sounds weird.  As a rule I am not even a big fan of creamed corn, but WOW!  This stuff is GOOD.

Honestly, the food was probably 2-star quality, but I'm giving it 3 because it was late, and we were hungry, and it was open. That said, it was very generic quality breakfast/diner food, and while it satisfied my hunger, it didn't quite hit the spot.
The ultimate skillet was more like vegetable skillet. Barely any sausage. Pancake is good. Food is decent too. Overall just an average.

I came here around 4 times and the food is amazing\nI tried many italian food and I am really picky about taste but  this is best among vegas italian restautants.  One thing that i did not like is Service from server.  I hope server check customer more often and give nice smile at least

I extol the aesthetic appeal of this establishment and the creative layout of the sushi bar, which exudes an air of refined sophistication that complements my desire for a brief respite from my professional commitments. My primary objective was to indulge in a leisurely repast for approximately half an hour, during which I sought to savor a delectable appetizer accompanied by a refreshing beverage, and Fujo's efficient service did indeed fulfill these expectations in a timely manner.

Given my geographical location within the Carolinas and my yearning for a dish imbued with a modicum of piquancy, I elected to sample the Cajun Roll, which boasted an intriguing amalgamation of crayfish, shrimp, and crab. Although it failed to elicit any profound sentiments of culinary amazement, it likewise did not evoke any strong feelings of disgust or disappointment. As a resident of the South, I have become accustomed to tempering my expectations regarding the availability and quality of sushi, hence I have learned to appreciate whatever options are available to me. However, my experience with the hot-and-sour soup was somewhat less satisfying, as the ingredients lacked a certain freshness and the broth's flavor was precariously close to being unpalatable, thus necessitating a concerted effort to consume it in its entirety.

Despite some minor shortcomings in the culinary realm, this eatery retains a certain je ne sais quoi that renders it an agreeable dining destination, even if it may not rank among Charlotte's most exceptional gastronomic offerings.

"I recently visited Fuel to partake in their culinary offerings, specifically the delectable Extreme Fuel Pizza, which boasts an array of savory toppings including pepperoni, Italian sausage, meatballs, ham, and ground beef for those unfamiliar with its composition. Additionally, I sampled their flavorful Garlic Knots. This establishment has experienced a succession of tenants in recent years, but my intuition suggests that Fuel will enjoy a prolonged tenure at this location. The pizza was indeed impressive, and the customer service was equally commendable. To avoid the inconvenience of waiting in a lengthy queue, it is advisable to telephone and place an order in advance, as this eatery tends to attract a sizable clientele rather quickly. In comparison to the standardized pizza fare offered by national chain restaurants, Fuel presents a marked upgrade in both quality and taste."

Went to Fuel to grab lunch.I had two slices of The Extreme Fuel Pizza which is pepperoni,Italian sausage,meatballs,ham and ground beef for the uninitiated as well as the Garlic Knots.There have been several restaurants in this particular spot over the years but I believe this one is gonna stick around on a while.The pizza was great and the service even better.Call and order ahead if you can because this place gets crowded really fast.This is a definite step up from your local corporate pizza fare.Enjoy.

"Although my culinary expertise does not extend to the gastronomical offerings within these sacred walls, I must admit that the seemingly incongruous nature of consuming beer within a religious institution paradoxically conjures up feelings of both moral reprehension and unadulterated delight. However, our taste buds were sufficiently satiated by the trio of artisanal brews we sampled from the establishment's own microbrewery, with a particular Belgian-style ale eliciting an especially effusive response. Unfortunately, our experience was slightly marred by the rather lackluster service, which, coupled with the servers' evident discontent at our failure to order any edible fare, led us to deduct a star from our overall rating. Nonetheless, Church Brew Works remains an intriguing destination primarily for its unique setting and an impressive array of craft beers."

This watering hole formerly served as the closest establishment to my previous domicile, thereby rendering it a convenient destination for seeking respite during the late afternoon hours. It boasts an unremarkable ambiance, with prices that are relatively affordable, albeit subject to fluctuations in accordance with the ever-changing legal parameters governing the sale of alcoholic beverages. Formerly, the cost of a single serving of Kopperberg beer amounted to Â£2.85, a price point deemed reasonable within the context of Edinburgh's culinary landscape. Situated in close proximity to the city's central bus terminal, this pub presents itself as an ideal haven for those seeking temporary refuge prior to embarking upon their respective journeys. Its laid-back atmosphere lends itself well to facilitating casual gatherings among acquaintances or colleagues seeking a brief interlude from the rigors of daily life.

We opted to venture out to an unfamiliar sushi establishment during the previous weekend, despite the unfavorable weather conditions, which rendered traveling extensive distances rather impractical. Upon arriving at the modest venue, we were uncertain about the quality of the culinary offerings, but our experience ultimately proved to be gratifying.

We placed an order for four sushi rolls, accompanied by Goyza and edamame as introductory courses, all of which demonstrated impeccable taste. Notably, the diamondback roll stood out as the most exceptional among the trio, boasting an extraordinary lightly fried texture that would undoubtedly warrant another visit. Similarly, both the fried cali roll and the dragon roll lived up to our expectations. However, the spicy shrimp roll did not align with my personal preferences, although my spouse found it appealing.

We would eagerly return during happy hour to capitalize on financial savings, and while the ambiance and physical space may have been somewhat underwhelming, the sushi itself was truly impressive. In fact, the restaurant's tranquil atmosphere and ample seating capacity make it an ideal setting for an intimate date night for two, although it may not accommodate large gatherings.

In conclusion, Sushi Rocks earns high praise from us, notwithstanding minor drawbacks concerning the interior design and spatial constraints.

My sibling and I ventured out into Chinatown on a Friday evening, hankering for sushi, but upon discovering a ninety-minute waiting period, I inquired of my sibling whether she had ever indulged in Korean BBQ, to which she responded affirmatively, thereby leading us to our destination.

I pose this inquiry due to my reluctance to sample unfamiliar cuisine without prior knowledge and guidance, as I prefer to rely on someone else's expertise before embarking on a solo adventure and introducing others to novel culinary experiences.

Upon entering the establishment, we encountered rows of compact booths, each equipped with a central grill, facilitating an indoor BBQ dining experience. Patrons could select from an assortment of beef varieties, such as tongue and rib, succulent shrimp, and pork alternatives, rendering this venue an unadulterated carnivorous haven.

Apart from a meager selection of vegetarian options presented in a salad bar format, other prepared Asian delicacies included sweet and sour pork, sushi, tempura vegetables, and diverse additional salads, albeit with an Asian twist, leaving me uncertain of their specific designations.

Throughout our visit, our beverages remained consistently replenished, and the staff diligently maintained a tidy grill surface, ensuring a pleasurable dining atmosphere.

Ultimately, this excursion offered a distinctive and captivating experience that I wholeheartedly endorse and encourage others to attempt.

We serendipitously arrived at this establishment, which appears to be a popular gathering place for senior citizens who reside in the adjacent Sun City community and are equipped with various medical accessories, such as oxygen tanks. The dinner service commences promptly at 3:00 PM, and we typically opt to be seated at the bar area, where we can indulge in an assortment of delectable hors d'oeuvres and refreshing beverages. The bar staff is quite hospitable towards younger patrons like ourselves, and they proffer an array of well-crafted mixed drinks that we find quite satisfying. While there may exist superior seafood options elsewhere, we concede that Red Lobster provides a reliable and gratifying dining experience, especially during times of unexpected culinary cravings.

"My preferences do not include this establishment, as it tends to showcase an excessive amount of shabby chic and country-style novelty items, which detracts from the authenticity of the antique pieces that are interspersed amidst them. Furthermore, the pricing of these items appears to be arbitrary and unpredictable. Additionally, the staff members seem to be either indifferent or overly attentive, which can create an uncomfortable atmosphere for patrons such as myself and my offspring. Despite these drawbacks, I shall continue to persevere in my quest for hidden gems, as some of the newer vendors have successfully created an ambiance that is conducive to an enjoyable shopping experience."

I had a Papa Kelsey's Special Pizza while my wife had a Calzones with extra toppings  like tomato, green bell pepper, olives and onion. We both ordered two Italian salad with blue cheese and ranch dressing. Can't believe I had so much root beer.\nOver all the food was alright. We had a good lunch. One of their booth seats, the upholstery is torn. Not a good thing. But, Folks like what I said we have to continually support our local restaurants.

Go here for the strong margarita's to escape the heat of the strip. .

The margaritas we had were great.  Try them on the rocks or frozen--doesn't really matter.  I was pretty surprised to be honest, as they just make huge batches of the stuff and pump it out en masse. 

The food wasn't anything spectacular, but you most certainly could do worse on the strip for your money.  You are really paying for the atmosphere here.  Everything is tacky and very Vegas, but that's why you are there in the first place.

Definitely would go again, just nothing incredible or mind-blowing in my book.

"Enthusiastically endorse the establishment's ambiance, specifically appreciating the provision of billiard tables, colossal displays, exceptional acoustics, and an overall convivial demeanor. Particularly fond of their gourmet grilled cheese sandwich, which surpasses expectations and brings joy to my culinary companion's countenance. However, the vegetarian burger option does not resonate with my taste buds. Nonetheless, I generally approve of this dining venue."

Love the setup, love that they have pool tables, love the big screens, great music, great atmosphere, great servers, good food.  Ultimate Grilled Cheese is indeed ultimate...it's a stand out dish that put a smile on my foodie friend's face; not a fan of the veggie burger tho.  But overall, I can dig it...

This specific site is characterized by a high level of activity and traffic, which is indicative of its popularity and appeal to a diverse range of patrons seeking convenient and satisfying dining options. Notably, it offers an advantageous promotion on the iconic Big Mac sandwich, which is a significant draw for customers seeking a substantial and gratifying meal at a reasonable price. Furthermore, the speed and efficiency with which this establishment provides its culinary offerings make it an ideal choice for busy parents seeking nourishing fare for their children while on the go.

I have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on three separate occasions, and each experience has left me feeling thoroughly satisfied. Upon entering the restaurant, I am immediately struck by the inviting ambiance that permeates the space. The friendly staff greets me warmly and takes my order with efficiency, ensuring that my dining experience gets off to a prompt and seamless start. My go-to item on the menu is undoubtedly their delectable Acapulco Express omelette, a masterful blend of savory ingredients including chorizo, avocado, green chilies, onions, melted cheese, sour cream, and their signature freshly made salsa. The flavors harmonize beautifully, creating a culinary symphony that delights my taste buds. Furthermore, their French toast offerings are equally impressive, with each bite boasting a satisfying texture and rich flavor profile. The Floridian French toast, in particular, has undergone an exciting transformation, now featuring a sweet and tangy combination of berries and kiwi that complements the dish nicely. Throughout my visits, I have consistently received exceptional service, with servers demonstrating a keen attention to detail and a genuine commitment to ensuring customer satisfaction. The presentation of their dishes is also noteworthy, often accompanied by delightful little bowls of fresh fruit that add a welcome burst of color and flavor to the meal. Lastly, the quality of their coffee is commendable, with a generous pour that never leaves me wanting. In conclusion, this establishment stands out as a top-notch breakfast destination, offering a satisfying and well-rounded dining experience that I highly recommend.

"I experienced an immense sense of disillusionment, which persists to this day. My anticipation for an exceptional culinary experience at this establishment was utterly unfulfilled, despite my initial enthusiasm. While I do appreciate the aesthetically pleasing ambiance and the friendly demeanor of the staff, my expectations for a superior quality of cuisine were sadly unmet. However, I would consider returning in the future, contingent upon the availability of dining options and my curiosity regarding their bread offerings, which demonstrated a notable level of taste and texture."

I was so disappointed. I'm still disappointed. This place was supposed to be the best Italian food ever and quite frankly it wasn't. I like the layout of the place, its beautiful and the people that work here are awesome, but my expectations were so high for the food to be so low. I would come back though. I dont know when since there are so many other restaurants to try in LV, but if this was one of the only places open on a certain day then yes count me in. I don't even remember what I ordered. THAT is a bad sign. Their bread was tasty though.

Good pub with a great selection of beer. Food was pretty damn good but our waitress was a little slow to start but on Point after we got our beers. I definitely will come again but maybe not for dinner. Over all, I was happy with my visit.

Wasn't the best buffet. The shimp tasted like rubber, the Chinese food was overly salty, the sushi was tasteless . The crab legs were really small. Nothing like the king crab that were in the other pictures. Only thing good was the deserts, prime rib and open bar. Very pricey $30.

Okay overall - nasty burnt garlic in sag paneer (big points off) but naan was good.  Mango lassi was great.  

The sign on the door about beer & wine was confusing - I thought it meant they had only beer & wine and no cocktails.  But it actually means there is no alcohol - you can bring your own, but only beer and wine.  

The decor is very nice.

"I had the pleasure of partaking in a culinary excursion to Shoku Ramn approximately three weeks ago, at which time I opted to sample their tonkotsu ramen and potstickers. While the latter was quite satisfactory, with a delightful crunchiness that was enhanced by a subtle charring, the former left much to be desired. Specifically, the broth was excessively saline, rendering it difficult to discern any other flavors, and the noodles were unfortunately overcooked, resulting in an unpleasant mushiness upon biting. Such issues notwithstanding, I might consider returning to Shoku Ramn in the future if I found myself in close proximity and experiencing a strong desire for sustenance, but I would not venture out of my way specifically to dine there again."

Went to shoku ramn about 3 weeks ago. I ordered the tonkotsu ramen and the potstickers. the potstickers were good they were slightly burnt thats usually how i like it. its a lot crunchier when you bite into them. the ramen...now the ramen needs work the broth was extremely salty and the noodles were way too overcooked. basically when you bit into the noodles it was mushy. i definitely did not like that. i felt like the broth was so overly seasoned i couldnt taste anything but salt. i wouldnt go back to shoku unless i was really hungry and i was extremely close to it. i wouldnt drive out my way to go eat there again.

"The prices are somewhat prohibitive, however, the quality of the culinary offerings and the ambient surroundings justify the expense. The portions, albeit diminutive in size, are artfully arranged and presented, thereby enhancing the gastronomical experience. The interior design is visually stunning, creating an atmosphere conducive to relaxation and enjoyment. The ahi tuna dish is particularly noteworthy, its flavors and textures coalescing in a manner that elevates it to a position of prominence among the menu options. Regrettably, I was unable to partake in the establishment's mixological offerings, a deficiency that I hope to rectify at some point in the future."
A bit pricey. Portions are rather small but the food is good. The decor is beautiful. The ahi tuna is my favorite. Unfortunately I never had the opportunity to have a cocktail here. :-(
A very nice spa pedicure that made my day!  Heck, my week!  They are clean and friendly but need new massage chairs.  Will definitely go back again and again, new chairs or not!

"I patronized this establishment with the intention of partaking in their happy hour offerings, accompanied by a acquaintance whom I had arranged to meet here. Upon arriving 20 minutes prior to the appointed time, I opted to procure a beverage and engage in a game of Draw Something on my mobile device while awaiting the arrival of my companion at a table situated proximate to the bar. Despite my anticipation of expedient service, it took a considerable amount of time, specifically 15 minutes, for a staff member to extend a greeting and inquire about my desire for sustenance or potables. The delay was somewhat perplexing and unexpected, given my previous experiences at this venue. Following this initial hiccup, the service was generally satisfactory. I sampled their happy hour wine, specifically a Cabernet, while my associate selected a Sam Adams. We both opted for the culinary delights offered during happy hour, with my companion choosing the blackened fish tacos and myself selecting the chicken and shrimp lettuce cups. While they were indeed flavorful, the dishes were also rather greasy, which rendered them somewhat challenging to consume due to the excessive moisture. However, I have previously enjoyed the fare served here, so this minor drawback did not significantly detract from my overall satisfaction. In conclusion, I would still consider visiting this establishment again in the future, perhaps to indulge in their flatbread or sushi offerings."

I am not the biggest fan of fast food ever. But I really like Five Guys and this location is superb! 

They have really yummy fries and they give you so many! Like your bag overflows with the greasy buggers. Say what? Yeah they are really greasy. But good!

The burgers are really quite the bang for your buck too! Not the best burgers in the world but it is fast food not gourmet burgers. Be considerate for what you are eating and enjoy it for what it is. 

The pop machines are radical. You can pretty much have flavoured any beverage you like. 

The staff here is really friendly and that is a plus anywhere you go!

I love the food at Noodles. Always delicious, portions are faily large, selection is great. The service leaves a bit to be desired. The last time I was in, there were approximately three occupied tables in the dining room. Every single other table, aside from one small 2 seat table had dishes and food left on them waiting to bussed. We had to ask to have a table cleared for us before we could sit down. Maybe if the restaurant had been busy at the time, it would be a bit more understandable, but the place was dead.

I cannot express an excessive amount of dissatisfaction with this establishment, primarily due to the fact that my stay was complimentary, courtesy of my platinum player status. Although the hotel's age and lack of modernity may have contributed to its relatively low level of appeal, I did not find it particularly bothersome during my brief period of occupancy. However, I must admit that certain aspects of the service left much to be desired, specifically the housekeeping staff's tendency to disregard our explicit requests for privacy by entering our room unannounced, even when the 'do not disturb' sign was prominently displayed. This particular incident occurred in the early afternoon, when my companion and I were attempting to take a brief nap, and the sudden intrusion left me feeling understandably uneasy. Furthermore, I must caution potential guests against the inconvenience caused by the live music performances that take place on the strip side of the hotel, which can be heard throughout the day and late into the night. Specifically, the band responsible for these musical offerings possesses a questionable level of talent, and their prolonged sets can prove to be particularly grating on the nerves, especially for those seeking a peaceful rest. In light of these factors, I would advise future visitors to exercise vigilance when booking their accommodations, particularly regarding the chapel hours, as my acquaintance discovered that the third-floor chapel was already closed by the time he attempted to utilize its services. Despite these drawbacks, I do not wish to discourage prospective guests from experiencing the hotel's amenities firsthand.

I like the idea of interacting the least amount possible when ordering food and this place has it down to a science. You walk in, look at the menu, choose the bag that corresponds with your sandwich, pick your toppings and hand it to the cashier. Done. They make your sandwich and you're on your way. I had the turkey with cole slaw and thousand island dressing. It was ok. The bread wasn't my favorite. It was crusty and didn't feel fresh. The turkey was very salty. Not sure if I'll try them again on my own but would be willing to try another sandwich if someone wanted to take me there:)

"Hof Kelsten has recently joined the ranks of Mile End's plethora of boulangeries, and its entrance into the competitive landscape of Montreal's bustling bakery scene has been nothing short of remarkable. Indeed, the establishment's proprietor, Mr. Jeffrey Finkelstein, has managed to cultivate an impressive reputation among local gastronomes by virtue of his unwavering commitment to providing an array of delectable bread products to various esteemed eateries throughout the city, prior to branching out and catering to the needs of an eager public clientele. Hof Kelsten's culinary approach is deeply rooted in the rich traditions of Central European baking, with an emphasis on artisanal breads such as caraway rye, rugelach, and babka, among others. However, cognizant of the local palate's predilection for Gallic influences, the bakery also offers an assortment of quintessentially French loaves, including what this writer considers to be the most exceptional Montreal baguette currently available. Patrons may partake in a variety of savory meals during lunch and brunch hours, although this critic has elected to concentrate primarily on the baked goods, which, while occasionally marred by instances of undercooking, showcase an undeniable inventiveness and flair that sets them apart from the customary offerings ubiquitous in Montreal's bakeries."

Hof Kelsten is the latest addition to Mile End's boulangerie scene, and it instantly became recognized as a city-wide contender.  Baker/owner Jeffrey Finkelstein built up a reputation supplying many of Montreal's top restaurants with their bread before opening up to the public.  The approach leans towards Central Europe (caraway rye, rugelach, babka, etc.), but Hof Kelsten bakes some French loaves too (including my favourite Montreal baguette at the moment).  \n\nThey also serve meals (lunch, brunch), but so far I've stuck to the baked goods.  The pastries are generally good, and they're definitely refreshingly different from the kind of fare one tends to find in Montreal's bakery scene, but I've encountered problems with undercooked items from time to time, so now I just focus on their bread.

You get what you get for this price. The check out time was 11:00am and I called at 11 and asked for late check out at 1pm since we arrived late at the hotel and we're all tired. I've never had a problem w late check out since I'm not asking for like 5 hours extra. The lady said no 1pm, only till noon. And this pissed me off lol. Out of 100 other hotels I've stayed at(not exaggerating) I've never got turned down for this kind of little request. Especially in Vegas you don't want to get an experience like that. The room itself is decent and modern but not the service.

I have been employed at Planet Hollywood for an extensive period, yet I had never had the opportunity to dine at this particular establishment until now. A recommendation from an acquaintance prompted us to explore the venue, as they boasted an assortment of meats that were allegedly quite delectable. Furthermore, the presence of a Groupon offer made the experience even more appealing. For the sum of $79, we availed ourselves of the all-you-can-eat surf and turf option, which encompassed an array of meat and seafood delicacies, including sirloin, lamb, and an assortment of seafood such as mussels, shrimp, salmon, and tilapia. The surf portion was presented on a separate plate, allowing us to sample each item individually. While some of the meats were slightly disappointing in terms of their texture, I found the shrimp and sirloin to be rather satisfying. The salad bar offered a diverse selection of vegetables and hot dishes, making it a well-rounded culinary experience.

As part of the package, we were also treated to an alcoholic beverage of our choice. I opted for a Chinahuia, which was expertly crafted with pineapple, lime, and tequila. Although it was not a terrible drink, it did not quite live up to my expectations. My companion, on the other hand, enjoyed a Rum Runner, which was generously poured and packed a potent punch.

In conclusion, while the restaurant offered an acceptable dining experience, I would still prefer to dine at Texas de Brasil, where the quality of the meat is superior. Our server, Marcile, provided attentive service despite the challenges posed by having a divided section. Despite some reservations based on unfavorable reviews, the actual experience was not as unpleasant as we had anticipated.

I have worked at planet Hollywood for years but have never been up here. Someone suggested that they had a pretty good variety of meats so we decided to give it a try since there was a groupon. So for 79$ you get all you can eat surf and turf( meat and seafood) the consisted everything from sirloin to lamb. Then the surf part which consist of mussels, shrimp salmon and tilapia? Comes on a separate plate. I can't rave too much on the food because some of the meats were quite dry but I did like the shrimp and sirloin. The salad bar was decent  with a variety of vegetables and hot dishes. 

So an alcoholic beverage is included in the deal, I got a chinahuia (sp?) with pineapple, lime and tequila. Not too bad; definitely my  kinda drink. The hunny had a rum runner and it was poured much heavier than my drink. 

So overall, it's an okay restaurant but for the same price I would go to texas de brasil. They have much better meat. Marcile was our server tonight and he was running around because his section was split, which I understand because I've worked in restaurants.  I was hesitant coming here because of all the bad reviews that I saw. But it wasn't as bad as anticipated.

After perusing the critiques and hailing from the Eastern Seaboard, we felt compelled to sample In-N-Out Burger during our recent sojourn to Las Vegas. I must admit that while the culinary offeringings were satisfactory, the frenzied zeal with which patrons endorsed this establishment struck me as somewhat perplexing. It appeared to be a run-of-the-mill fast food chain, albeit with an emphasis on expediency and perhaps a tad unrefined in its presentation.

Upon placing our order at the drive-thru window, the attendant inquired as to whether we desired ketchup, to which we replied in the negative. His subsequent prolonged gaze of incredulity was quite amusing, as if we had just revealed that we were extraterrestrial beings unfamiliar with this staple condiment. Evidently, he held a deep affection for ketchup, for his countenance conveyed a sense of utter disbelief.

While I would recommend In-N-Out Burger to those who have yet to indulge, I would caution against going to extraordinary lengths to partake in their offerings. A hamburger, by any other name, remains simply a hamburger.

After reading the reviews (and being from the East Coast), we needed to try In-N-Out Burger on our recent trip to Vegas.

I will give it to you guys - it's a good burger, but people seem to go insane for these things!! LOL. Fries are good too. An average fast food chain. Quick and dirty - more emphasis on the 'dirty'.

A note to the guy at the Drive-Thru Window: when you ask someone if they want ketchup, and, they reply 'no thank-you' - DO NOT stare at them blankly for 10 seconds like they're from another planet.  I guess you really like ketchup - don't you buddy - LMAO!!

If you've never tried, go for it, but, don't go too far out of your way. A hamburger is a hamburger......

"An optimal location for novice patrons to familiarize themselves with the intricacies of Thai cuisine, provided they have not had the pleasure of indulging in such gastronomical delights previously, which, admittedly, would be a rather unusual circumstance given the widespread popularity of Thai food. Upon entering the establishment, it becomes apparent that the staff are inclined to steer customers towards partaking in a buffet-style meal, as opposed to selecting individual dishes from the menu. This preference is conveyed with considerable enthusiasm by the waitstaff, to the extent that one might infer that their livelihood is contingent upon the success of the buffet option. Furthermore, a financial analysis of the bill reveals that the cost per person is Â£21, which, when juxtaposed with the quality and quantity of the culinary offerings, does not constitute an unreasonable expenditure, particularly in light of the fact that the buffet provides an excellent opportunity to sample a variety of dishes and thus, enables patrons to make informed decisions regarding future dining experiences."

"While not exceptional, the culinary offerings at Egg Works are by no means reprehensible. The gastronomic experience they provide is, in fact, rather unremarkable, with dishes that are neither particularly delectable nor objectionably unpalatable. The prices, however, are commensurate with the quality of the fare, which may be perceived as a positive aspect of this establishment. Despite the uninspiring nature of the cuisine, I shall likely return to partake of their edibles once more, as the health benefits associated with consuming eggs are undeniable, especially when compared to the detrimental effects of indulging in sugary pastries such as donuts. Interestingly, Yelp! has assigned a rating of three stars to this venue, which they have designated as 'A-OK.'"

Not great but not terrible. Just run-of-the-mill quality food at typical prices. The food isn't bad tasting, but it surely isn't the highest quality. On the flip side, it isn't trying to be. Egg Works embraces its mediocrity and prices appropriately.\n\nI will almost definitely eat here again because eating eggs is surely healthier than being lazy and eating donuts, for example, but the food is just okay, and the 3-star is labeled \"A-OK\" by Yelp! so that must be the one I have to pick.

Dear Breadfruit,

You would be worthy of four stars if you were not so utterly overpriced.
I will, however, always take you up on a slice a dat sweet potato pie. 
And coffee, if you insist upon it.


Sincerely,
Rachel

It's not the best, not the worst. They do t advertise their specials, however they are good. The prime rib unlimited use to be to die for. Since they removed it I haven't been back. In reality, the price wasn't all that good for what the food taste was. All in all its on par with Denny's.
Really average food in buffet for lunch. It was a good selection but food was a little less than I would expect.

i cannot belive this place has not been reviewed this is a smalltown cafe with great and some times tweeky service not bad service just tweeky help but the breakfast here are very  good standard breakfast fair the interior is old cowboy john wayne/gene aughtrey kind of kitch fun breakfast place

Upon my arrival at the Wynn well after sunset, I was feeling rather fatigued and had a strong desire for a prompt and convenient culinary experience, thus, I opted to investigate the offerings of The Cafe.

Upon perusing their menu, I discovered that they presented an array of delectable sandwiches, salads, and pastries. I decided to sample their Chicken Portabella sandwich, albeit, I was slightly dismayed upon discovering that the sandwich was not prepared fresh, but rather refrigerated, then warmed in an oven before being served. Considering the price point of $11.00, I would have anticipated a greater emphasis on freshness. Nonetheless, I chose to apply a portion of the accompanying Garlic Aioli and upon taking a bite, I found the flavors to be quite satisfying. Additionally, I purchased a bottle of Coke for $4.00 (a rather steep price, in my opinion) and thus, I was content for the evening.

It is worth noting that The Cafe experiences a significant influx of patrons in the mornings, particularly those seeking a caffeine infusion. Therefore, for those seeking to avoid the crowds, I would recommend embarking on a leisurely morning stroll and crossing the street to visit Starbucks located within Fashion Show Mall.

"It must be conceded that my initial acquaintance with the Krispy Kreme phenomenon transpired approximately a decade ago in Canada, and I must admit that the ardent assurances of my unwavering fondness for these confectionaries struck me as somewhat dubious. Nonetheless, upon receiving an abundance of said doughnuts from a magnanimous colleague hailing from Edinburgh, I must confess that their delectability was rather impressive. The team's collective enthusiasm for the sugary bounty was palpable, and it became apparent that the Krispy Kreme craze had indeed permeated our workplace in diverse, saccharine, and deep-fried forms. However, despite the munificence of the complimentary pastries and the ensuing euphoria, I cannot help but harbor reservations regarding the necessity of such copious amounts of sugar and grease. Furthermore, I am compelled to ponder whether we have, in some manner, reverted to the early 1990s. Consequently, I shall assign three stars in recognition of their gustatory appeal, but that is the extent of my endorsement."

"It is our profound consternation that the culinary experience at this establishment did not meet our expectations, as the server appeared to be preoccupied with an array of tasks, thereby compromising their ability to provide adequate attention to our needs. Furthermore, the gustatory delight of the comestibles did not conform to our standards, specifically the Steak Gorgonzola and the Pappardelle Pescatore, which lacked the pictorial representation and emitted a dubious odor reminiscent of marine products. Additionally, the Northern Tour of Italy and the accompanying salad were found wanting in terms of dressing, leading us to speculate that the serving staff may have been parsimonious in its distribution. The calamari, too, was devoid of flavor, and our request for supplementary lemon was unfortunately ignored. Lastly, the novel iteration of Italian-style buffalo wings was observed to possess an unpleasant aridity. Notwithstanding, our steadfast loyalty to this eatery remains unwavering, as we have frequented this establishment bimonthly and have customarily enjoyed superior cuisine and hospitality. Perhaps this visit can be attributed to an anomalous day."

Eh, the server seemed too busy to actually take care of our needs. The food was kind of dry. I ordered the Steak Gorgonzola and the pasta was dry. We also ordered the Pappardelle Pesctore. Didn't look anything like the picture and was very \"fishy\" smelling. The Norther Tour of Italy was OK too. The salad was also lacking in dressing, like it was coming out of the servers pockets! The calamari was also bland tasting. We asked for more lemon for the calamari but didn't get it toward the end. The \"new\" Italian style buffalo wings was dry. Why a three, because we are loyal Olive Garden people! We come here once every other month and normally we\nget EXCELLENT FOOD AND SERVICE. Maybe it was an off day?

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
The text starts off by expressing disappointment with the slow service, which is emphasized by the use of the word "sloooooooooow" to convey the duration of the delay. The writer then describes the cramped waiting area and lack of seating, highlighting the discomfort caused by the limited space.
The writer then describes their meal, starting with the positive aspect of the delicious mussels, which were small and flavorful, accompanied by a tasty white wine sauce. However, they express disappointment with the French fries, which were soggy and not up to their expectations, despite the server's recommendation.
The main course, bouillabaisse, is described as "pretty awesome," with its rich saffron sauce and generous portion of seafood. In contrast, the writer's husband found his brie-stuffed chicken to be merely "OK," indicating a less satisfying dining experience.
The writer concludes by expressing frustration at the lengthy two-hour duration of their meal, which they attribute to the restaurant's lack of staff. They suggest that they might return during the week, but would not consider bringing a group due to the inadequate service. Overall, the review highlights the restaurant's strengths in terms of food quality, while criticizing its shortcomings in terms of service efficiency and staffing.

"My culinary experiences at this establishment have been limited to the wonton soup, which I have had the pleasure of indulging in on multiple occasions. Upon ordering, I request that the noodles be omitted, thereby allowing me to fully appreciate the rich flavors of the broth, which boasts a subtle sweetness and an aroma that is simply captivating. The dumplings, too, are quite impressive, with their delicate texture and savory filling. While I cannot attest to the quality of the other menu items, as I have not had the opportunity to sample them, I can confidently assert that the wonton soup is truly exceptional. In fact, it has become a staple of my dining repertoire, and I would highly recommend it to anyone seeking a satisfying and delectable meal. Additionally, I must mention that the Crown Bakery, located upstairs from this restaurant, is also worth visiting, as it offers an array of delightful pastries and baked goods that are sure to satisfy one's sweet tooth."

I have only ever had the wonton soup here.  I order it without noodles and it is some of the best I've had.  I love the slightly sweet, aromatic broth and the dumplings are very good.  I've heard the other food is just so-so and I haven't tried it.  But I am a repeat customer for their wonton soup.  \n\nCheck out the Crown Bakery upstairs from this place - it's great.
