We had a great dining experience, however the food was just average. Great cocktail specials from 3-6pm! Wish we would have gone for an earlier dinner.

This was my first time here. We sat in the bar and caught the tail end of happy hour. 
Apparently that have complementary hors d'oeuvres, although I did not have any. 
We had a few cocktails and ordered some Salmon and Yellow tail sashimi and nigri. I love good salmon and I must say their salmon is pretty good. The Yellow tail sashimi was cut too thick for my liking. 
My biggest complaint was the smell of the restaurant. It smelled like a mix of disinfectant and cheap cologne. It was really strong and made me a little sick to my stomach...

Golden Phoenix is the kind of place you visit when you want a decent, inexpensive lunch. The place is rarely full during the week, especially if you arrive closer to 11am, so be prepared to eat your meal while the (slightly creepy) waitstaff sits at a nearby empty table and watches you eat.  The food is nothing spectacular, but it's decent quality, flavorful (although \"very, very spicy\" is really closer to \"my tongue has a slight tingle\"), and dirt cheap.  Today I paid $16 and change before tip for myself and my friend, including soft drinks.  I'll keep coming back for the reasons I listed plus its close proximity to my office.  You can't beat a good deal!

I have made a couple visits over the years (I don't live in Champaign). Located along a major thoroughfare for the city and near campustown. The donuts are pretty good. Quick service. However, not all the donuts are in stock at a given time. I was just there and didn't even see glazed yeast donuts (the classic).- just glazed cake and the glazed minis. I appreciate having someplace to grab a snack with early morning Black Friday shopping.

"If you seek an establishment that offers a tangible representation of southern hospitality amidst the extravagant indulgences synonymous with Las Vegas, then this venue is worth considering. Located within the Treasure Island Hotel, this particular destination boasts an impressive array of amenities designed to cater to patrons who appreciate a more laid-back atmosphere reminiscent of the Deep South. Featuring a spacious dance floor illuminated by vibrant lights, the ambiance is further enhanced by the sounds of country music that permeate the space, creating an environment ideal for enthusiasts of line dancing and two-stepping. Moreover, for those who harbor a sense of adventure, there is a mechanical bull available for riders to test their mettle. However, be cognizant of the proficient skills exhibited by a specific blonde cowgirl, whose prowess on the bull may inspire awe in onlookers. Although the kitchen had closed by the time of our visit, the bartenders remained accommodating and friendly, ensuring that drinks were served promptly despite the modest crowd. Notably, the demographic comprising the majority of patrons appeared to be older, ranging from their late thirties to forties, although this did not detract from the enjoyment experienced by our group, which included ardent country music devotees."

I am compelled to frequent this establishment solely due to my associates' fondness for it, despite my personal reservations regarding the cost-effectiveness of the fare, with the exception of the pizza offerings, which provide a satisfactory value proposition. The alcoholic beverages, particularly the beer, are also reasonably priced, but the same cannot be said for the wine and other potables. While I do not particularly relish their brews owing to their robust and saccharine nature, this venue does boast a certain je ne sais quoi that makes it an agreeable choice for groups seeking a convivial atmosphere in which to partake in copious amounts of food and drink.

"Fairly satisfactory, but I can conjure up alternative Mexican establishments that I might favor over this one. The hospitality at this venue was ATTENTIVE, yet somewhat unsystematic. I solicited three separate individuals to provide hydration for my companion and myself (we were the final members of our gathering to arrive), and we ultimately received a solitary water vessel. Nonetheless, they were prompt in delivering replenishments of triangular tortilla chips and savory dip, and they regularly checked in on us throughout the duration of the meal. The water vessels may have been an isolated occurrence, considering the large number of patrons and the fact that we didn't encounter any further difficulties with the service. \nThe culinary offerings were adequate, albeit slightly piquant for my taste buds. Indeed, I am aware that it is Mexican cuisine and that I possess a relatively low tolerance for spicy fare. Nevertheless, none of my dining companions appeared to be troubled, so it is worth considering that perspective. It did seem to sit somewhat lighter in my stomach compared to the majority of Mexican dishes, which was a welcome aspect. The margaritas were potent and a pitcher sufficed for the four of us."

"Satisfactory for a rapid Asian-inspired culinary experience. Maintained establishment with amiable personnel. A casual, unpretentious eatery that, while not exceptional, does not warrant criticism. Efficient, affordable, and of passable quality."

"It was indeed surprising that no assembly was necessary, no specialized implements were required, and no essential components were absent from our culinary experience. Nonetheless, the value I would have anticipated from such an establishment was conspicuously lacking. To clarify, this refers to the upscale eatery situated upstairs, rather than the food kiosk located downstairs. The menu showcases a diverse array of options, encompassing wraps, salads, soups, and a hot tray line featuring an assortment of sweetish favorites. My spouse opted for a vegetarian wrap, which, due to the disorganization of the shelves and labels, nearly resembled a chicken wrap. While neither exceptional nor unpalatable, it was deemed satisfactory at a cost of $4. The smoked fish platter, priced at $7, boasted a generous helping of creamy horseradish sauce, varied greens, and a few beans, all complementing the flavorful smoked fish. A pleasant addition was the vegan sweet potato soup, available complimentary upon presentation of one's IKEA Family card. This resulted in a meal priced at $14 for the two of us, which, while not exorbitant, was consumed within a self-service furniture retailer. For individuals seeking mild cuisine in a child-friendly atmosphere with expansive views of furniture, this venue may prove to be their ideal destination."

Surprising there was no assembly required, no special tools and no missing parts to our meal. However it also lacked the value I would have expected from such a venue.

Just to be clear this is the "fancy" upstairs cafe not the food stand down stairs.

The selection is wider, including wraps, salads soups, and a hot tray line of what I assume are sweetish classics. 

My wife had a veggie wrap, that was almost a chicken wrap as the shelves and labels were in disarray. It was neither great nor terrible at $4 it was acceptable.

The smoked fish plate for $7 was quite good, creamy horseradish sauce and mixed greens with a few beans accompanied the well smoked fish. 

The nice touch was the vegan sweet potato soup.  Flash your ikea family card for some free stuff and you have a meal. at $14 for the two of us it was not pricey but we were eating in a self service furniture store. 

If you are looking for some mild food in a kid friendly environment with great views of furniture this may be your spot.

I went here today feeling a bit meh. I was going to meet some clients, and they had chosen it - and I kept thinking of all the other groovy places in the area that we could have gone to instead. Cafe Grande just seems a bit old school, and the menu was all burgers and paninis...

But, in fact, i did have a pretty good lunch. The fishcake was small but tasty, with chips and a little salad - and the cheeseplate afterwards was good, with a choice of Scottish cheeses. Various desserts round the table looked decent too - the banoffee pie got a rave review.

Other lunch choices weren't quite as good - the soup and sandwich in particular seemed a bit dull and "like something you'd make at home", while the beanburger arrived looking forlorn on a plain bun.

So - a nice enough lunch if you're in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way.

In my relentless pursuit of gluten-free culinary delights, I serendipitously encountered Nello's, a restaurant that, despite having limited gluten-free options, offered an unparalleled dining experience, showcasing their commitment to catering to the diverse dietary needs of their clientele. Upon perusing their menu, I opted for a ham-pineapple pizza, which, much to my delight, proved to be an inspired choice, as the flavors melded together in perfect harmony, the gluten-free dough serving as a worthy canvas for the savory toppings. Furthermore, I was impressed by Nello's dedication to transparency, evident in their provision of a comprehensive list of ingredients and toppings, thereby enabling patrons to make informed choices and avoid potential allergens or dietary restrictions. The exceptional service I received during my visit further enhanced my overall satisfaction, as the friendly and attentive staff ensured that my dining experience was nothing short of exceptional. While it is worth noting that Nello's may not cater exclusively to those with gluten intolerance or sensitivity, their willingness to accommodate such dietary requirements is undoubtedly commendable, making them an excellent choice for those seeking a welcoming and inclusive dining environment, where the absence of lofty expectations allows for an authentic and enjoyable culinary encounter.

I am just looking to my right... as I write and I just saw "better that Roscoes"... Not a chance...  But is good no doubt.  The problem is the chicken.  The chicken at Roscoe's is what one would describe as an addictive experience.  It's Crack... Once you have it you can quit.

Back to Lolo's.  Nice place.  An improvement over Roscoe's in terms of the place.  Very colorful and big jars of Kool-Aid.  The chicken and the waffles are good... That is if You have never been in LA and had roscoes.

The breading of the chicken is dry and different.  The waffles and the syrup are great.  Need to improve the chicken thing.  I sure will be back as is definitely better than some fast food chicken but it ain't no roscoe's.

Ok in case you are wondering about Roscoe's.

http://www.mixiaosblock.com/twin_cities_lunch/thats_some_darn_good_chicke.html

"Satisfactory experience with too much repetition." 
Service was commendable.  Beverage was adequately chilled.  However, my preference would be a robust India Pale Ale, which unfortunately was unavailable. 
Fare was unremarkable.  Commonplace buffalo wings.  Sandwich bread lacked freshness, and fries were not particularly crispy.  Ambiance was satisfactory, boasting an abundance of televisions, rendering it an appropriate venue for a brew and a sporting event.  Aromatic wood smoke emanating from the pizza oven created an inviting atmosphere, suggesting a pizza may be a worthwhile option on a future visit.

I unfortunately fell into the trap pf ordering chips and salsa first. Way too much food. But other than that, it was exactly what you would expect from a Mexican place. Big serves, as often happens in Mexican, and fresh ingredients. Nothing earth-shattering but reasonably priced. I would go back, next time I am in the area and in the mood for Mexican.

I came here with my mom because she has an insatiable sweet tooth. She asked the girl behind the counter if the coffee flavored gelato had caffeine in it. The girl replies, "I don't know. I don't make it."

We kind of laughed it off but then when I asked her if they had anything that was dairy-free she says, "I don't know. I don't make it."

After complete shock we just shook it off and ordered our gelato. My mother attempts one more time to get something useful out of this girl. She asks her to suggest another flavor to go with chocolate. The girl replies, "I don't know. I don't eat it."

I couldn't believe it. I mean sure she's probably in high school and it's true...she doesn't make it and most likely doesn't eat it. But hello....CUSTOMER SERVICE!

Besides that the gelato was amazing and pretty okay priced. Banana Yum!

The food was average and everything is overpriced. My friend and I were playing video poker the whole time yet only 1 drink was comped. Kinda disappointed because I was hoping to find a good hole-in-the-wall Mexican joint with video poker.

"It is utterly perplexing that individuals who have ostensibly partaken in a culinary excursion to Las Vegas would lavish such effusive praise upon a buffet that patently fails to deliver an adequate gastronomical experience, leading one to wonder whether said individuals have indeed sampled the myriad of other superior buffets available in the city. The allocation of a mere quarter of the buffet's offerings to bread, a staple that is hardly worthy of such prominence, is particularly vexing, especially considering the exorbitant cost of $40 per person. Furthermore, the quality of the fare is not commensurate with the price, as the standout dish, a California roll, relies solely on the utilization of authentic crab meat to salvage its flavor. The service, while satisfactory, is rendered inconsequential by the fact that it is only accessible to those seated at the bar. One must ponder what distinguishing characteristics this buffet possesses that warrant such lofty acclaim, as prime rib, cold shrimp, and crab are ubiquitous items offered by every buffet in Las Vegas, and certainly not at such an extortionate price. In contrast, the Rio Carnival World Buffet, Rio Seafood Buffet, and Wynn Buffet are infinitely superior options."

Holy crap, people actually eat here?  The last several times I've been to this RA, I can gauge my level of intoxication between pretty buzzed to blackout-absolutely wasted.  As you can tell, neither I nor any of my compatriots make it a point to actually dine here, mainly drink.  That's right, awesome happy hour and on Sunday night it's Service Industry Night (aka happy hour on Sunday night).  The happy hour menu is pretty extensive with appetizers ranging from the standard california roll to gyoza, seafood dynamite, and coconut shrimp skewer things.  However, where RA truly shines is it's specials on alcohol.  Food may be ordered when the hunger arises concurrently with inebriation, but at that point it doesn't matter if it's just so-so or even sub-par (it's like having beer goggles, but for food, not chicks).  However, I can't give this place a complete crap rating because of all the wonderful drunken memories I've had here (the few times I actually remembered the outings/the first half of the outing).

"My spouse and I visited this establishment in the company of acquaintances, having previously explored the surrounding area of Luxor together. Upon arriving at the restaurant, we were immediately struck by the vast array of culinary options available on the menu. Indeed, the sheer diversity of choices proved somewhat overwhelming, making it challenging for us to arrive at a decision regarding our meals. Nonetheless, we were unanimous in our satisfaction with the food, which we deemed to be of exceptional quality, warranting a rating of five stars. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said of the service we received, which left much to be desired. Specifically, our server's curt response to my inquiry regarding the virgin margaritas was utterly unprofessional and bordered on disdain. Had I been aware of the manner in which he had addressed the previous patron, I would have refrained from posing the question altogether. Furthermore, the server's demeanor was generally unfriendly and conveyed a sense of reluctance to be present at the establishment. This unfortunate state of affairs significantly impacted our dining experience, thereby precluding me from providing an unequivocally positive appraisal of the restaurant. In essence, had the service been more satisfactory, I would have been far more inclined to offer a glowing endorsement, rather than a mere 'okay' assessment."

a good tho not great buffet. peel n eat shrimp and the dessert variety were the standouts. prime rib not very good, but oh they do get an extra star for the tequila-infused watermelon, you could get drunk off that stuff. also rice krispy pops & candy apples. i would have liked to see more salad variety to at least create the illiusion that I was eating healthy but i did like that there was a wide array of breakfast options even at 2 pm. I would probably go back but then Aria and Paris have much better choices on their buffets, I would probably chose those over Wynn. Sorry Steve!

"It is worth mentioning that Excalibur Hotel and Casino boasts an enviable location, as evidenced by our arrival on a Saturday, which afforded us the opportunity to check in to a recently refurbished room in Tower 2. Upon entering our accommodations, we noticed something peculiar; specifically, the entrance was not fully closed, which prompted us to contact the front desk. We were informed that we would be relocated to an adjacent room, which we found to be satisfactory, albeit temporarily, as the new room featured a modernized aesthetic, complete with a flat-screen television and comfortable bedding. However, much to our chagrin, we encountered an identical issue with the door in our subsequent room, which refused to close properly. This led us to contact maintenance once again, resulting in a timely resolution. It is worth mentioning that the pool area at Excalibur is quite pleasant, despite the presence of strong gusts of wind during our stay. Unfortunately, the walls separating our room from those of our neighbors were remarkably thin, allowing us to overhear their conversations with unsettling clarity. Furthermore, the hotel's checkout time of 11 am proved to be somewhat restrictive, particularly given our indulgence in alcoholic beverages the previous evening. Fortunately, upon request, management graciously granted us an extension until 12 pm. In conclusion, while Excalibur Hotel and Casino presents itself as a reasonably priced establishment in a prime location, complete with passable lodgings, it may benefit from addressing certain logistical concerns."

This buffet is more in line with a Golden Corral/Hometown Buffet than some of the higher-end buffets you'll find on the Strip. We came for brunch. It has all of the staples: salad bar, carving station, dessert bar, pizza, pasta, corn, mashed potatoes, roasted potatoes, green beans, fish dishes, sushi and a few Asian dishes, and bread. Nothing very imaginative, but you can certainly leave very full. Price isn't great, but better than others, and the line wasn't long. If you're just looking to fill up on a decent meal for a relatively low price, go for it. Foodies should head elsewhere.

"The culinary offerings were merely adequate, failing to elicit any profound sense of gastronomical amazement within our party. Specifically, the rice accompanying the sushi dishes appeared somewhat sodden, lacking the desired texture and consistency. Furthermore, the quality of service was only moderately impressive, with our server seeming to be somewhat harried and inattentive at times, contributing to an overall feeling of being hurried and pressured throughout the meal. Additionally, we were disappointed by the relative dearth of knowledge displayed by the staff regarding the menu, particularly given the establishment's reputation for excellence in this particular epicurean domain."
Waitress was very friendly and provided great service.  Steak boxty was tasty and filling.  Went well with a pint of Harp.

I think Abuelos is very good for a chain Mexican food restaurant. They are pretty consistent with nice servers and decent food. I remember a time when there were huge lines out the door and hour long waits, but maybe that was in spring training season because the last time I visited, we got right in with a party of 6. I will go there again with out of town guests because they seem to love it but i prefer to frequent local establishments if I can.

I have not had the opportunity to partake of the culinary offerings herein, but I did visit this establishment on an evening when a fraternal gathering was taking place, which elicited some apprehension regarding the admittance of minors, as it was my understanding that entry was restricted to patrons of legal drinking age, however, upon further observation, it became apparent that said restriction was not stringently enforced, as both underage individuals and those sporting identifying wristbands were able to partake in alcoholic beverages; notwithstanding, the ambiance remained convivial and engaging, featuring recreational activities such as beer pong, an impressive selection of potables, and a visually striking and unconventional interior design that facilitated enjoyment and merriment for my spouse and myself, as we observed the musical videos and engaged in impromptu dance performances.

"Conducive to alleviating the symptoms of a hangover, albeit somewhat boisterous in ambiance.  It's not the culinary offerings that have precipitated my vomiting in the restroom on numerous occasions; rather, it's been the aftermath of an evening of excessive indulgence in adult beverages. \n\nThe fries, while lacking in girth, have underwhelmed my expectations.  Succinctly put, the victuals are passable, but by no means exceptional.  A plus aspect of this establishment is the potency of their specialty cocktails."

I came here for a haircut because I was near here and needed a haircut.  I just get a standard men's regular scissor cut, so most places are basically the same.  I just walked in and there was no wait for one of the stylists, so I got my hair cut quickly and efficiently and everything was pleasant and pretty much what I expected.  The haircut was a better than average, and she clearly cared about doing it correctly, so that's nice.  But at $20 for a men's regular and no rinsing or product or anything it's a bit pricier (25% more) than other places in the area that produce similar results, but  it's still not a bad deal for a decent haircut.

I should start with the positives.. The food here is excellent. I have been here many times and the bruschetta is out of this world..the best I have ever had. The service is here is awful!! We went on a Friday night and even with 3 bartenders behind the bar  and a near empty bar, it was impossible to get service. They were very interested in talking to eachother though. They take empty glasses away without offering refills and when the food arrived I had to retrieve some silverware and plates since the bartender(s) didn't even acknowledge that we needed anything. No joke, it took almost 10 minutes to get the attention of that bartender to get another glass of wine or a beer.\nThe food is what keeps us going back and they do have a great happy hour with $5 glasses of wine. We will try the other location next time to see if the service is any better there.

My assessment is largely consistent with the general consensus expressed by others.

Good aspects include:

* The culinary offerings (once procured) were undoubtedly impressive, particularly the lobster and corn, which elicited a profoundly enthusiastic response. Additionally, the beverage named in honor of nobility, although forgotten, was indeed commendable.

* The menu boasted an array of diverse options, providing ample opportunities for exploration and discovery.

* The beverages, both alcoholic and non-alcoholic, were meticulously crafted and presented in abundance, complemented by an assortment of innovative weekly specials.

Conversely, the following drawbacks were observed:

* The quality of service was subpar, characterized by an excessive number of personnel clad in black attire, alongside two hostesses, which seemed disproportionate to the needs of the establishment. Moreover, the bartender demonstrated remarkable dedication to their duties, reminiscent of the cinematic portrayal of someone possessing exceptional skill or aptitude. However, management would benefit from addressing this discrepancy within the staff.

In conclusion, the eatery offered delectable cuisine, superlative drinks, yet was marred by deficient service.

Below are the daily drink specials:

Margarita Monday: Enjoy $3 off specialty margaritas from 7 p.m. until closing time.

Guys Night Out Tuesday: Relish 1/2 off whiskey, bourbon, and scotch from 7 p.m. until closing time.

Paper Bag Beer Special Wednesday: Savor a randomly selected beer encased in a paper bag for a mere $1 from 7 p.m. until closing time.

Ladies Night Thursday: Indulge in $3 off glasses of wine and $3 360 vodka drinks from 7 p.m. until closing time.

Fireball Friday: Partake in $2 shots of Fireball from 7 p.m. until closing time.

$10 Mimosa Carafes Saturday: Obtain a mimosa carafe for $10 between the hours of 11 a.m. and 3 p.m.

$10 Bloody Mary Carafes Sunday: Acquire a bloody mary carafe for $10 between the hours of 11 a.m. and 3 p.m.
"A culinary establishment offering authentic Italian cuisine in a pleasant ambiance with generous servings at an affordable cost, strategically positioned near the central plaza."
Friendly service, dated rooms but it's well worth it for the price paid.  The adjoining rooms are a big plus when traveling with kids
Not the best burger by any means, but passale   Horrendous setup by the drink machine almost impossible to get by because it is so crowded and tiny aisle to go past

"Personnel exhibiting cordial demeanors and a predominantly youthful clientele characterize the establishment, with a palpable sense of urgency permeating the atmosphere, as though patrons are eager to engage in romantic or sexual liaisons. However, the subterranean section of the venue appears somewhat uninspired, lacking the vivacity and pizzazz that would encourage conviviality among the patronage. A designated dance area, devoid of any actual dancing, exists within this space, its absence of a mirrored sphere, illumination, or laser beams contributing to an overall dearth of ambiance. If the proprietors desire to foster an environment conducive to merriment and movement, they might consider investing in elements that would enhance the experience, such as suitable lighting and perhaps even a DJ spinning melodies that might entice revelers to sway in unison."

Champaign is a great restaurant city, but the options for Middle Eastern food are rather limited, so I'm glad that Holy Land Grill exists.  It isn't the best Middle Eastern food I've ever had, but it's pretty good.  I was there yesterday and had the falafel and a Greek salad and enjoyed both.  Service was attentive and friendly, which was a welcome change after the last few times we'd been there.  They started our meal with complimentary bottles of water, which seemed odd and wasteful (but I suppose washing water glasses wastes resources, too.)  They also serve Mexican Coca-Cola, which was an interesting change of pace.  Dessert was baklava-very good but came topped with a simple syrup that didn't do much for it.  Serving the baklava plain or with a drizzle of honey would have been better.  One more thing;  I know I'm always complaining about loud music in restaurants, but there was no music at all at Holy Land. Some soft Middle Eastern music would have been a nice touch.  All in all, I enjoyed my meal at Holy Land and plan to return soon.

The Golden Nugget buffet is under construction so we were able to use the buy-one-get-one-free coupons at Carson Street Cafe.  Sweet.

As a Golden Nugget guest, I loved that the Carson Street Cafe was located so close to the elevators.  After a long day walking up and down the Strip, it was nice to be able to grab a bite to eat and then head back to the room.

The food is decent.  I would recommend sticking to the basics.  My BLT was fine and the chicken in the Caesar salad was really tender and tasty.

The customer service varied from person to person but it did seem to be on the slow side overall.
A kind of cool place to get a drink and a snack. Pay with cash to avoid awkwardness. Don't go there for customer service.

This particular venue was situated directly opposite the university's performance hall, and we were in the vicinity for a production, thereby making it an extremely convenient stopover. Upon entering, we were promptly accommodated and our beverage requests were expeditiously recorded. However, there was a brief hiatus in the midst of the post-beverage order process, with our server taking approximately 15 minutes to collect our orders and deliver our drinks. The hostess ultimately stopped by our table to place the order, presumably owing to the fact that our waitstaff member was somewhat overburdened. The culinary offerings arrived approximately 15 minutes subsequent to our placing the order, and we were compelled to consume them with haste in order to avoid missing our scheduled showtime. I opted for the Turkey Dinner, while my companion selected one of the pancake combinations (specifically, the white chocolate raspberry variety, if my memory serves me correctly). My turkey entree was merely passable, as the bird was sliced into diminutive portions and did not resemble the depiction in the menu's photograph (a common occurrence, unfortunately). My partner's pancakes, on the other hand, proved to be a delectable choice, with the Egg Nog pancakes appearing to be another viable option. Following the completion of my meal, I settled our bill without delay, allowing us to vacate the premises at the earliest opportunity once my fiancee had finished dining. In conclusion, this establishment merited a rating of B-, with commendable service complemented by edible, albeit unremarkable, fare.

Was at the W last night for a Bachelorette Party.  Clearly, I don't get out much... well, at least not to hoity-toity Scottsdale spots... so I was floored by the ridiculous $16 drinks.  No, thanks! Water, please!  

The people-watching was topnotch.  The girl prancing around the lounge in her tiny turquoise bikini is still making me laugh... seriously - cover it up.  You are inside and the sun isn't shining!

The pretty waitresses that are all stuffed into teeny, tiny black dresses were very friendly and happily separated the check into smaller tabs for our large group.  

Certainly, the W is a good place to go and drop tons of money... and do some hilarious people-watching of the Scottsdale crowd... but it really isn't my thing.

I am subtracting two stars here based on an experience I had this week.  Was here for drinks on a Tuesday night, the place wasnt packed so my friend and I sat at the bar.  There were two bartenders but obviously their friends were at the bar and they had zero interest in serving anyone else.  It took 15 minutes to get the menu, the bartenders could not have been ruder!!!  When i asked for a beer they didnt have she threw the beer list at me and didnt come back for another 15 minutes.  It was probably some of the worst service I have seen in Charlotte!  Take some midol beotch!!!

We descended to the smorgasbord, as it was the most proximate venue to obtain a morning repast on a Sunday. The quality of the cuisine was satisfactory, given the convenience of merely stepping onto an elevator and having an array of delectable options presented before us. While we did not anticipate indulging in delicacies such as lobster or crab at 11:00 am, the selection included several savory cuts of meat, including prime rib.

The tariff, however, was somewhat prohibitive, amounting to $25 or more per person, which seemed exorbitant considering our origins in Chicago. Nevertheless, given the unique ambiance of Las Vegas, we might be inclined to return, provided we possessed either an insatiable appetite or an abundance of complimentary credits. Those who are financially unrestricted and desire a convenient dining experience may also find satisfaction here.

The Yard House, from my perspective, serves as an optimal venue for indulging in libations during the fleeting hours of happy hour, boasting an impressive array of artisanal brews that would daunt even the most discerning aficionado; however, their culinary offerings, while satisfactory, fail to surpass the plethora of superior gastronomic alternatives available within the immediate vicinity.

The establishment known as The Big Dogs on Sierra had ceased its operations, which was a source of dismay for us since it was a place we frequently visited during our stays in town, enjoying their delectable beverages and savory nachos on multiple occasions. Consequently, we opted to venture towards the Draft House on Rancho, hoping to find a suitable alternative for our cravings. However, upon arriving at the destination, we were disheartened to discover that the nachos did not meet our expectations, falling short of the standards set by our previous experiences. Despite this letdown, the quality of the beer remained satisfactory, providing some solace in the face of our disappointment.

"While the culinary offerings at Bellagio's buffet are undeniably delectable, the exorbitant prices during peak hours make it challenging to justify the cost, especially considering the availability of comparable quality food at more affordable establishments. A reduction in price by half would likely elevate the buffet's rating to four stars, but as it stands, the premium charged does not align with the gastronomic experience provided. Ultimately, it is advisable to explore alternative dining options that offer similar quality at a lower price point, allowing you to allocate your financial resources more judiciously and potentially even indulge in a game of chance at the slot machines, where a fortunate outcome could result in a substantial windfall."

Close to my domicile, I have a predilection for visiting this establishment, as it affords me the opportunity to partake in their delectable vegetarian or supreme pizza, accompanied by a pitcher of refreshing cold beer and an assortment of mouthwatering chicken wings, all while reveling in the sporting atmosphere and observing the action on their multitude of televisions. Although the prices have increased somewhat and the culinary quality has diminished slightly, I still find the ambiance, hospitality, and takeout options to be quite appealing. A diverse array of pizzas is available, which serves as the primary draw for patrons, whereas the alternative fare caters to individuals seeking a modicum of variety in their dining experience.

Love Grand Lux. Corned beef hash is excellent.  

One big problem during his visit was the Mrs found a hair in her fries. Waiter and manager handled it properly tho. Took it off our check and profusely apologized. 

Desserts r fantastic.

"The reality is such that the hospitality extended by Tea Lite's staff is truly commendable, as they exhibit remarkable kindness and efficiency in serving patrons, and the culinary offerings are both wholesome and promptly prepared. Furthermore, the cost-to-quality ratio is quite favorable, making it an appealing choice for a nourishing repast. However, my reservation concerning their rating stems from the fact that their menu selections appear to be overly predictable and lacking in boldness, which may be attributed to the eatery's concentration on providing expedited lunches and a simplified menu. Specifically, the pho broth is conspicuously absent of tripe or tendon, and no alternative exists to incorporate these elements should a patron desire a more adventurous dining experience. While various seasoning options are available, they fail to provide the depth of flavor customarily associated with Vietnamese cuisine. It is conceivable that this dearth of variety stems from Tea Lite's emphasis on catering to the local demographic, yet I cannot help but feel a sense of disappointment when comparing it to its competitor in the vicinity. Despite this, I wholeheartedly endorse paying a visit to Tea Lite and expressing gratitude for their exceptional service, all the while politely requesting that certain ingredients be included in their phá»?so that, in the future, they might reassess their menu and warrant a higher rating."

I went here based on a couple reviews and I was expecting something fabulous.  The food was really good! Four stars for the food but two for the service equals a three star review.  What went wrong?  It took about 45 min's for a couple of pita sandwiches and we were the only ones there, and when the order came it was wrong!  My friend had to get his to go while I ate mine.\n\nDon't get me wrong the food is really good and I would probably go back but come on people please get the order right, and speed up the service a little! Maybe somebody should tell them or leave a Yelp card to let them know that we love the food, but the service needs to be improved!

Ive been here a handful of times and it is always packed and a good time for me.  We had a VIP table which always helps getting in and enjoying the time spent there. The DJ music was good to dance to, but the dance area is tight. They offer a platform pole where several women get up and dance on so that is fun to watch. This time the large private back room area was closed....renovations?! The private area last time is separated from the main area and offers private tables and dance areas for larger groups and a separate DJ.  Not a bad place to come with a group, but not so great for just a couple guys. There are better options in Vegas.

I bought the onion and mushroom poutine and a Montreal smoke meat sandwich.  The sandwich was very good.  The meat was warm and so moist.  Very good.  
The poutine was ok, I wish I bought something with bacon or something also meaty to enhance the flavour.  I did like the onion and mushroom though, but just thinking about the possibilities.

The weird thing is, maybe because I was in a hurry, I under tipped.  The waiter asked me if there was something wrong with the service but honestly there was nothing wrong with it but nothing exceptional either.  I happened to go early on a Saturday morning, right when the store opened.  So after I told him nothing was wrong, he informed me that in Montreal the tipping is 15%.  So he asked me for $1.50 more.  I felt embarassed because I wasn't paying attention and I just wanted to give him a flat $30 after eating $26 something. Maybe I am cheap.  Before entering, my brother and I wanted to see how much their poutine was, and already they were shouting at us that it was not opened yet.  So the food was good, but I'm not sure about the service.  I still gave it a chance after being shooed away.
one of the nicest view rooms ive stayed at nothing to go crazy over but liked how it was located right at the miricle mile shops

"I appreciate the expansive nature of this establishment, which offers a diverse array of seating arrangements tailored to accommodate various preferences and requirements. Its proximity to the freeway renders it an ideal venue for gatherings among business associates, as well as casual meetups between individuals engaged in academic pursuits, such as myself, who have benefited from the convenient setting for tutorial sessions. Consistency in the quality of beverages, specifically coffee and tea, is a notable aspect of this location. Complimentary Wi-Fi access is also available, although patrons are advised to request the relevant password upon ordering their drinks. Unfortunately, a single star has been deducted due to the prevalence of untidy tables and littered floors within the premises."
Good drink selection with some interesting cocktails and was pretty empty when I was there in the afternoon. I didn't try any food but it looked pretty good.

3.5 stars.

Like others say, it's better than airline lounges in US in terms of food and beverage offering. Cookies, cheese, some vegetable/hummus/cold pasta salad, cous cous and spring rolls and mini quiche. And full bar with wine, liquors and beverage. Also soup...

Sitting area can get crowded and it's closed after morning around 10:30 am and re-open at 2:30 pm.  Well.. better than sitting in the hallway..
The calamari was fantastic. The tacos were nice but there are better ones around. Our server was very funny and definitely enhanced the experience. Worth checking out.

It was an enjoyable experience, reminiscent of the renowned television show, The Amazing Race, albeit with a few caveats. Specifically, I had anticipated a greater emphasis on intellectual puzzles that could not be readily solved through the utilization of modern technology, such as smartphones. Additionally, physical fitness and swiftness were essential components of the competition, as the victors were required to sprint to the finish line in order to emerge triumphant. Notably, the organizers neglected to present the winners with their promised $100 gift certificates; however, upon being apprised of this oversight, the staff assured us that they would mail them to the recipients at a later date.

Four of us went for breakfast.  2 of us had the $5.99 steak and egg special, which includes house fried potatoes (which are amazing) and toast.  2 of us had the veggie omelet, which was packed with fresh veggies, smothered with cheese, and also served with potatoes and toast.  With coffee and tip, total bill was less than $35. Great deal.  \nService was very good, servers were really friendly and refills of coffee/water were abundant.\nWe returned for dinner the next day.  2 of us had the penne al forno, which was creamy and delicious.  2 of us had the burgers with no complaint.  The best part-- $2.25 20 oz. beers that are brewed in house.  Both the Hefe and the Light are very smooth.  Total bill for 5 beers and 4 entrees was $45, a steal for being walkable from the strip.

It's a small hole in the wall place that my boyfriends co worker told him about. We went for his birthday dinner . The place is small with a few booths and tables but clean. The service was good and we didn't have to wait long to get our food. They have happy hour all day everyday so the price is pretty good. The food was good but not great. I really like the baked salmon and baked  scallops and the fried tofu appetizer. Do not get the fried calamari! No flavor and it just tasted like tempura batter

I bought a Groupon for cut, all over color and style. The services I received were great, my stylist listened to what I wanted and delivered on my vision. The reason I am giving this experience 3 starts was due to the following two issues:\nThe stylist had my color mixed in her bowl and just as she started to do my hair she informed me that if she ran out of color and needed to mix a second bowl I would have to pay an additional $15. I was shocked and felt cornered as at that point I could not say no nor change what I wanted for my hair. I would not have had an issue if this was clearly explained to my either on my Groupon or when we first started talking about my hair. \nThe shirt I was wearing was ruined because my hair color bled through the robe. When I showed this to the stylist she spoke to her manager who just stated it should come out in the wash. I have not tried this yet but I double it will.

This critique has been precipitated by an extended hiatus, and it is my utmost pleasure to proffer my musings regarding the establishment in question, which has become a veritable haven for me and my associates due to its proximity to our place of work and its assiduous personnel who persistently promote their felicitous happy hour offerings. The variegated array of potables they provide is indeed impressive, featuring an abundance of delectable draught beers that cater to diverse tastes and preferences. However, the culinary options available do not particularly stand out as singular or exceptional, being merely typical bar fare that fails to elicit any remarkable recommendations. Nonetheless, the venue boasts numerous televisual displays, which are invariably tuned into various sporting events that captivate the attention of patrons throughout the day. It is worth mentioning that the quality of service one encounters here can be somewhat capricious, oscillating between extraordinary hospitality and, regrettably, utter disappointment. Notwithstanding these inconsistencies, the convivial atmosphere that permeates this establishment makes it an ideal setting for socializing with companions, rendering it an agreeable destination for those seeking recreation and relaxation.

Decent coffee. Pretty nice place. I like the "back space" they have - it's usually crowded with student who wants to read book or work on homework in a relaxed setting. 

Bring cash; they don't take credit card. There is a ATM machine inside if you don't mind withdrawing your money with $2 fee.

By the way, the barista guy is so hot.

Looking for old fashioned soul food? You have defiantly found the right place. The fried chicken and cornbread was really good. Lots of sides to choose from.\n\nThe service was good. Defiantly a good place for lunch if you are downtown!

"It is my fervent hope that the powers that be at The Mirage have taken the necessary steps to terminate the employment of the irresponsible and hazardous valet driver who, with callous disregard for the safety of others, nearly struck me with his vehicle while attempting to beat a red light, resulting in a collision with another hotel guest's Hyundai. Notwithstanding the fact that the hotel management had hired a driver with questionable mental stability, I cannot express excessive dissatisfaction with The Mirage, as rooms are offered at a reasonable tariff, albeit slightly higher than in previous years. The picturesque gardens situated at the main entrance provide an excellent opportunity for photography. Each dining establishment within the hotel offers an unparalleled culinary experience that should not be missed. Specifically, I highly recommend Japonais, Kokomo, and Samba. Furthermore, there are numerous tables scattered throughout the casino floor, providing ample opportunities for gaming enthusiasts. For those who are novices in the realm of gambling, the minimum limits for blackjack begin at $5-$15, making it an ideal location to initiate one's gaming endeavors. It is regrettable, however, that the poker room does not offer additional remuneration for quad aces, despite the fact that I have been fortunate enough to win substantial sums of money at this establishment. In conclusion, taking into account its advantageous location on the Las Vegas Strip and proximity to various points of interest, I would unhesitatingly suggest staying at The Mirage, but exercise extreme caution when traversing the street."

"The ambiance of the rooms is rather dim, ostensibly necessitating additional illumination to facilitate a comfortable stay. Furthermore, the absence of certain amenities such as a refrigerator and microwave oven is somewhat inconvenient, albeit understandable in the case of the latter. The LCD television provided is relatively diminutive in size, specifically measuring 32 inches, and appears to be a product of Philips. It is worth mentioning that the water temperature during showers or baths is not satisfactorily warm, which may prove unpleasant for some guests. Additionally, a resort fee of approximately $20 is charged, which could be perceived as somewhat dubious since it is not explicitly included in the overall cost. Instead, it is presented as an extra charge, potentially leading to confusion or annoyance among patrons.  

In contrast, the location of Treasure Island Hotel is relatively advantageous, situated as it is in the midst of the renowned Las Vegas Strip. In fact, hotels in close proximity to Wynn, Paris, and Bellagio (and possibly Planet Hollywood) are generally considered the epicenter of attractions, rendering stays at these establishments particularly desirable. Fremont Street, located nearby, is also worth a visit, providing an immersive experience for those interested in exploring the local culture and entertainment scene."

"Panchos presents itself as a veritable cornucopia of culinary delights, boasting an extensive array of delectable dishes that cater to an assortment of palates. Upon entering the establishment, one cannot help but be struck by the vibrant color scheme that permeates the interior, imbuing the atmosphere with a festive and lively ambiance. In order to partake in the gastronomical offerings, one must first navigate a cafeteria-style line, whereupon a diverse selection of comestibles becomes readily available. Encompassing everything from succulent chili rellenos (colloquially referred to as 'cheese sponges') to various iterations of enchiladas, tamales, diminutive chimichangas, flautas, and taquitos, in addition to staples such as rice, beans, tacos, and tostadas, the menu showcases a veritable smorgasbord of options sure to satiate even the most discerning diner. Furthermore, the tariff for such a copious amount of fare proves eminently reasonable, making it an attractive proposition for those who relish rich, savory, and decidedly non-authentic Mexican cuisine. A unique facet of Panchos' service model lies in the implementation of a small flag, which patrons may utilize to signal their desire for additional items from the buffet; this innovative approach ensures prompt attention from the attentive wait staff, who materialize at one's table with alacrity. While opinions regarding the eatery's overall quality remain divided, there exists a general consensus regarding the efficiency of the aforementioned flag system, which undoubtedly enhances the dining experience. Moreover, the restaurant's cleanliness and the availability of fresh, hot sopapillas post-meal contribute to its enduring popularity among those who crave a hearty, satisfying repast."

This particular establishment, situated on the renowned Las Vegas Strip, purports to be an outlet of the ubiquitous coffee franchise, Starbucks; however, it must be noted that its authenticity is somewhat dubious, as it does not adhere to the standardized menu and pricing of a bona fide Starbucks location. Despite accepting the Starbucks gift card, this ostensible Starbucks also accepts Total Rewards cards, thereby betraying its true nature as an unaffiliated entity capitalizing on the brand's widespread recognition. Furthermore, a cursory examination of their offerings reveals a tendency to inflate prices egregiously, rendering the experience financially prohibitive for the average consumer. 
  My order, a passionfruit iced tea infused with a hint of strawberry, typically retails for a modest sum of approximately $2.85; yet, upon placing my order, I was taken aback by the exorbitant price quoted by the youthful server, a staggering amount approaching six dollars. Abiding by the adage "ignorance is bliss," I opted not to interrogate the staff regarding this anomaly and instead tendered my Starbucks card as payment, thus facilitating the procurement of my beverage. 
  The dimensions of this establishment are quite generous, affording ample space for patrons to indulge in their preferred beverages while availing themselves of the numerous electrical outlets provided. Additionally, a diverse array of items, including the customary "you are here" Vegas mugs, juices, and an assortment of sandwiches, are available for purchase. 
  In light of the aforementioned factors, specifically the flagrant price gouging, I have elected to confer a rating of three stars upon this establishment, cognizant of the fact that, as a business, it must strive to generate profits, but simultaneously recognizing that such an astronomical increase in price for a product normally available at a fraction of the cost is utterly untenable.

There is a long hallway to get in so it is definitely pretty secret. There is not much seating inside, about 6 seats. You have to wait for your pizza, atleast 20 minutes so I would call ahead. \n\nThe pizza was alright, I honestly like Slices in Dublin, CA so much more. If I were in Las Vegas again I would not come by here but it was a nice expierence.

Food was really good,  I've been to other Popeyes and was nOt impressed but this one just may change my mind...it will take more than one visit to determine that. I do wish there was a menu prior to the order menu in the drive thru, just because I'm not familiar with their menu and felt rushed once I was at the order menu. Also I given my box of food....no bag just my box of food which I thought was weird, would've liked a bag to carry my food from my car back to work (along with my purse, drink and other stuff).... and no straw for my drink (that's always annoying) but food wAs good so next time I'll walk in and check it out

This is a solid three. I'm still not sure how I feel about super thick pepperoni as I do prefer the thin sliced stuff. Overall, the pizza wasn't bad, but not exactly what I think of when I think of New York style thin crust. I tend I picture something a little different, maybe more like a Villa or Verrazano.  I'm not a fan of black edge crust either, a dark golden brown is my own preference. They definitely spent a bunch remodeling it from the old Atlanta bread Company that was there.  That being said I'm not from New York although I have been there and have had a couple different slices of pizza.  I will probably go again, but not sure if this will make it to the regular rotation.

They no longer put the chicken back on the grill when you order. The chicken is not big chunks of white meat anymore, it is stewed chicken sitting in a broth all day and I'm not even sure it is all white meat anymore. Another issue is the woman who was making the burrito used her gloved hands to fill the burrito with all the toppings. That is fine for rolling, but when your sticking your hand (gloved or not) into each bin of lettuce, corn, tomatoes, cilantro, etc, it just doesn't seem normal. They need to use spoons on thongs for the fillings.

Nothing special, but a bank. \nThey have a convinient, safe on-location drive thru and walk up service. Of course, personal safety is always an issue so just be 'aware' of your surroundings. \nThere is a Smith, Nail place and other business in this corner. Definitely a convinient location.

I don't normally go into American Apparel. Mostly because I like vintage and things that are skintight don't look good on me. But, I was dressing up as a mermaid and found myself in need of a top to wear under my shells so I didn't expose too much skin. Of course, American Apparel had all the selection of shiny, skintight (and skin colored) tops I needed. While I feel like I way over-paid for what I got, at least I got what I needed.

The Saloon feels very corporate and a bit overpriced.  However, the service is also good, and the beers are always cold.

I do not like the set up of the Saloon and the Comedy Zone.  I don't like how you have to go through the Saloon to get to the Comedy Zone.  Poor design lay-out.  I have been here on more than one Saturday night and had my night somewhat interrupted by huge crowds waiting in line to get into the Comedy Zone.  It sucks for everyone that is in the Saloon chillin, having a good time.  The bathrooms are packed and there is literally a human traffic jam towards the rear of the Saloon.

I usually go to the Saloon when looking to pregame before a show at the Fillmore, or before heading to another location within the Music Factory on Friday and Saturday nights.   

It is what  it is.  The live music and DJ there on Saturday nights are a huge plus.  Its still your standard, corporate, expensive bar in Charlotte.  With that being said, I would definitely go back again.

I genuinely aspired to bestow a perfect rating upon this festival, but unfortunately, certain aspects precluded me from doing so. Last year, my fiancÃ© and I participated in the celebration and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves, indulging in delectable cuisine and reveling in the diversity of melodies. However, our experience was marred by an unfortunate encounter with the host of the jousting match, who exhibited reprehensible behavior. 
  Initially, he publicly embarrassed a spectator by demanding she bounce for him, proceeding to offer her financial compensation for the task, only to subsequently admonish her daughter not to emulate her mother's conduct when she declined. This incident left a sour taste in our mouths, as Renaissance festivals are traditionally intended to be lighthearted, family-oriented gatherings where attendees can immerse themselves in merriment and escape reality temporarily. Moreover, it is reasonable to expect that all cast members maintain their characters consistently throughout the day, which sadly, was not upheld in this case. 
  Although I would relish the opportunity to revisit this festival in October, the presence of that individual would compel me to reconsider my attendance.

We went for the breakfast buffet which is at $ 20. There was a queue outside but when we got in there were empty tables so don't understand the queue. The server was good kept topping up our orange juice regularly. The ambience is not so great though. There is an omlette live counter which is quite good n they have crabmeat and shrimp as toppings. There was also salads, pizza, softee machine, fruits etc. What we really liked were the omlettes, danish, almond croissants, turkey sausage,waffles. Most stuff was good. Pancakes weren't tat great though, there was a guy making them but I guess the backlog made them cold n not so fresh. The muffins were dry. Not bad overall though. Definitely worth a try.

I was eagerly anticipating the consumption of a delectable and copious burger at a reputable establishment specializing in gastronomical delights, specifically Fuddruckers, which was to be my maiden visit to said eatery. Alas, my lofty expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as the culinary experience proved to be merely satisfactory rather than extraordinary. While undoubtedly a tasty and adequate specimen of its genre, the burger failed to elicit an enthusiastic response from my palate, leading me to surmise that perhaps other venues might offer more exceptional fare. Thus, if presented with the opportunity to dine at Fuddruckers once more, I would not decline, though I might suggest alternative locales offering superior burgers, provided the choice was mine to make.

"My experience at Rehab was relatively satisfactory, as I attended the venue today at approximately 1 pm, anticipating lengthy queues and exorbitant entrance fees. However, my expectations were pleasantly subverted, as the admission price was merely $60, and the waiting time for a solo male patron like myself was a mere fraction of an hour. Additionally, the security measures in place were nowhere near as stringent as previously described by other patrons. My entry was expedited, owing to the fact that I possessed only a few essential items: a car key, credit card, and identification. 

Upon entering the premises, I was struck by the considerable number of attractive individuals present. Nonetheless, the crowd was not as dense as it appears in videos and photographs. Even at 4 pm, the venue was not overwhelmingly crowded, which I found somewhat surprising. Furthermore, the atmosphere was not as frenzied as one might expect, with only a couple of individuals engaging in intimate activities. In essence, Rehab is not nearly as chaotic as one might imagine. 

It is worth noting, however, that the prices of beverages at this establishment are quite steep. A single drink can cost upwards of $28; however, buckets of Heineken Light were available for $25, which includes five beers. While I would not categorize my experience at Rehab as exceptional, I cannot deny that it was an interesting diversion. Therefore, I would not necessarily return to this venue, as it did not quite live up to my expectations."

Been to this place for bday parties and although many prefer such a place to celebrate a birthday, I am not one of those people. It smells and the people who work here aren't the friendliest. I only gave it 3 stars because it's quite entertaining for kids.

I only had the beer, but I was very happy with this brewery's take on a wheat beer. The bar is very nice and designed in a square with the tvs and bartenders in the middle. There's a nice litte fishtank in the middle as well. The crowd was pretty small for a super bowl night, but decent. There was also an adjacent bar with table tops for two and stools. If you are staying in Middleton and are not trying to travel too far into Madison, this is a good stop.

My recent breakfast at Perk was OK.  The food was good, but the lackluster service will make me think twice about coming back.

My mom and I both enjoyed our breakfast burritos (mine with bacon and hers with ham).  They were smaller than I anticipated, but tasted good, especially when topped with the side of cilantro jalapeno sauce.  However, our waitress was pretty brusque - no interaction at all after taking our orders.  It would have been nice if she could have managed to come by to check on us, refill our water/my mom's coffee or even make eye contact at all.  The restaurant was NOT busy - less than half of the tables were occupied.  

I had to ask the hostess for both a water refill and our bill.  When our waitress finally showed up with the check, she slapped it on the table without even breaking her stride, all while looking out the window.  Hello!?  No 'thank you', or 'have a nice day'.

Eh...  I can make my own breakfast burrito, thanks.

Me and my significant other opted to visit this establishment one evening, seeking economical potations. My companion had previously frequented this location during his residency in Arizona, and I was aware of its reputation as a dive bar upon arrival, thus I did not express any dissatisfaction with the atmosphere or restrooms. We experienced a tranquil evening, and I requested my preferred beverage, Tokyo tea, and inquired about the device that enables participation in the trivia game displayed on the screen. Additionally, I ordered the honey hot wings, which surprisingly piqued my taste buds. As we departed, we briefly entered the karaoke room and observed patrons enjoying themselves immensely. An adequate venue for affordable libations and culinary delights, unpretentious and straightforward.

"Indubitably, I would be delighted to partake in a Beerarita, my good fellow! As for the culinary offerings, while the quesadilla was indeed copiously filled with poultry, it regrettably lacked a certain je ne sais quoi in terms of flavor. However, the complementary chips and salsa proved to be an utterly delectable accompaniment, the latter of which supplied precisely the piquant zest that the quesadilla itself was deficient in."

"Although my culinary expectations were not entirely fulfilled during my visit to this establishment, I must admit that the gastronomical offerings were not entirely without merit. My assessment of the venue's quality is predicated upon a thorough examination of the cost-to-culinary-quality ratio, and I must say that my overall satisfaction was somewhat diminished by the fact that each item was served separately, thereby necessitating an additional expenditure for what I deemed to be an already adequate meal. Notwithstanding this minor drawback, I did enjoy the Caesar salad, which was quite generous in portion and did not fail to satiate my hunger. My spouse, however, was not quite as taken with his dining experience, as he found the basic hamburger to be somewhat lacking in both flavor and value, particularly in light of the absence of any complementary side dishes. In conclusion, while I might consider returning to this restaurant at some point in the future, it would largely depend on the availability of alternative dining options and their relative levels of crowding."
Good coffee & tea. A little loud on the radio and blenders constantly whirring... But good wifi and now that I know how to get there will use often...

"Upon arriving at this establishment with two acquaintances of the feminine persuasion subsequent to perusing various commercial establishments within the shopping center, we discovered that the ambiance of the venue was adequate, possessing qualities reminiscent of a conventional barbecue eatery. Upon initiating our dining experience, we were presented with jalapeÃ±o bread, which demonstrated satisfactory culinary attributes. My personal selection from the menu consisted of a turkey sandwich enhanced with stuffing and cranberry sauce, effectively constituting a Thanksgiving-inspired creation. Although the flavors were palatable, the texture of the meat was somewhat lacking in moisture. It is worth mentioning that my companion was displeased by the absence of Pabst Blue Ribbon beer, a preference shared by numerous patrons according to the server, yet unfortunately unavailable at this particular business. The hospitality of the wait staff was quite commendable, as they exhibited kindness and attention to detail, exemplified by the prompt replacement of an undercooked burger. In conclusion, while the cuisine and atmosphere may be deemed unremarkable, the pleasant decor and respectable service contribute to a satisfying dining encounter, particularly following a prolonged and fatiguing day."

I had the pleasure of indulging in the culinary delight known as the "Juan Turkey Wrap," and unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely met. Despite my predilection for gastronomical indulgences, I opted to sample this establishment's fare, hoping to broaden my epicurean horizons. However, upon consuming the wrap, my taste buds were not adequately stimulated, as the texture and flavors failed to distinguish themselves from one another, resulting in an unfortunate blandness that even the copious application of hot sauce could not salvage. Notwithstanding this disappointment, I am resolved to persevere in my pursuit of a satisfying dining experience at this venue and shall endeavor to explore the "happy" side of the menu on my next visit, with the hope that it shall yield a more gratifying culinary adventure.

"Upon entering the establishment for a morning repast, I opted to sample their Mediterranean Omelette, which unfortunately did not quite live up to my expectations in terms of its culinary excellence, as it fell short of the 'gourmet' label that the restaurant purports to offer. Notwithstanding, the cost for the quantity of sustenance provided was reasonable, amounting to a total expenditure of $22 for three individuals. However, the menu selections were somewhat limited, with little variation in options available to patrons. Furthermore, I must express my gratitude for the utilization of disposable utensils, which obviated the need for dubious dishware sanitation practices. Nonetheless, I was dismayed by the scarcity of napkins provided, with a solitary example being offered, rendering it insufficient for my needs, even considering my relatively neat demeanor during meals. The quality of service received was unremarkable, at best, and failed to augment the ambiance created by the charming setting within historic downtown Chandler, conveniently positioned opposite a picturesque park and boasting ample parking facilities. Unfortunately, a single restroom was available, resulting in an unnecessary queue in the cramped passageway. In conclusion, while my experience was not entirely unpleasant, I cannot envision a compelling reason to revisit the establishment in the near future."

"Bearing in mind the geographical context, it's not entirely unpalatable. Not the most delectable Chinese cuisine I've had the pleasure of consuming, but neither is it utterly reprehensible. It precariously teeters between the realm of Panda Express and genuine, authentic Chinese gastronomy."

Juicy Pho off the strip

This place is pretty good for Vegas Pho. Vegas Pho is not the same as SGV Pho. 

Ordered the pork chop rice. It wasn't that good and the amount of pork chop there was very small.

Ate some of  my friend's korean bbq ribs, it was pretty good. 

Ate some of my friend's Pho, it was decent. 

What was really good was the Egg Roll wrapped with lettuce. It was delicious!!!!

Kinda far from the strip, was driving at least 10-15 mins to get here.

"Gourmet burgers at an exorbitant cost, evoking memories of the synthetic patties served in elementary school cafeterias. Underwhelming experience for the price of ten dollars. Unlikely to revisit in the near future."
This place was \"OK,\" but I probably wouldn't go back. Food was kind of low end Chinese although service and atmosphere were fine. Not really bad, just not good either.

I visit this establishment with the intention of engaging in the recreational activity of poker and, on occasion, observing a cinematic production. However, it is advisable that prospective patrons be cognizant of the fact that they will likely be enveloped by an odor reminiscent of smoke, the intensity of which rivals that of the aroma emanating from kalbi following a meal at a Korean BBQ restaurant. It is recommended that individuals who wish to avoid the unpleasantness associated with such an olfactory experience take measures to launder their attire promptly upon departure, as the pungent scent of an ashtray tends to linger. 

The poker room within the premises boasts an abundance of tables, thereby providing ample opportunities for enthusiasts of the game to participate in lively competition. It is worth noting, however, that the demographic composition of the clientele tends to skew towards senior citizens, with the writer, in their thirties, being among the younger patrons. 

In terms of culinary options, the selection is satisfactory, with Fuddruckers and Subway offering viable choices for those seeking sustenance. While the oyster bar may not compare to the offerings at Palace Station, it remains a respectable alternative for those seeking a comparable dining experience.

Colectivo is an aesthetically pleasing and contemporary coffee establishment situated in a prime location on the northeastern corner of the Capitol square, boasting an ambiance that exudes a rustic yet trendy vibe, replete with an eclectic selection of musical offerings, visually appealing decor, and ample seating options both indoors and outdoors, including a spacious "porch" area that invites patrons to linger and enjoy their beverages in a relaxed setting. Patrons can indulge in a diverse array of expertly crafted coffee and tea beverages, complemented by a select assortment of delectable edibles and potables, all while availing themselves of the complimentary wireless internet access available throughout the premises, with the exception of weekends.

Now, upon reflection, it has become apparent to me why I was advised to remain at the Westin; however, I was not particularly keen on traversing a considerable distance to reach my place of employment.  Initially, upon obtaining the room, I began to perceive an anomalous auditory phenomenon, which, at the time, I failed to attribute any significance to. Following the deposit of my belongings, I proceeded to the office, only to return and discover that the noise was still persisting; further investigation revealed that the source of the disturbance was, in fact, a toilet that refused to cease functioning properly. In order to rectify the situation, I descended to the ground floor to seek assistance from a staff member, subsequently departing to acquire sustenance. Upon my return, approximately one hour and thirty minutes later, I was dismayed to discover that the issue remained unresolved. Prompted by my growing frustration, I elected to descend once more to remind the hotel personnel of the problem. Fortunately, the matter was ultimately resolved within a span of forty-five minutes. However, my relief was short-lived, as I soon became aware of a pool of water accumulating behind the toilet, indicative of a leak. I promptly contacted the hotel staff and awaited the arrival of a maintenance worker, who, much to my relief, arrived in a timely manner and efficiently addressed the problem. Notwithstanding the aforementioned inconveniences, there exists a silver lining; specifically, the majority of check-ins occur around three o'clock in the afternoon. Moreover, I must express my gratitude towards the accommodating nature of the hotel staff, who graciously allowed me to check in at eight o'clock in the morning, facilitating my transition from the Hilton Garden to the aforementioned Hilton property.

"Upon my initial visit, I must admit that my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as the culinary offerings, although fresh, were somewhat limited in scope, particularly with regard to the lunch menu. However, I did appreciate the extensive breakfast selection and salad bar, which provided a satisfactory array of options. Unfortunately, the absence of salmon from the menu proved to be a significant disappointment, and the dearth of delectable desserts further contributed to my dissatisfaction. Given the steep price point of $65.00, I cannot say that I will be inclined to return in the near future. Nonetheless, I must commend the staff for their attentive and courteous customer service."

"2.5 stars. Following a culinary excursion to a neighboring pizzeria, I opted to pay a visit to this particular Whole Foods Market, situated within close proximity to the intersection of Tatum Boulevard and Shea Boulevard. Although I had not previously frequented this establishment, I was aware that its dimensions would be more diminutive than those of the Ray Road location, which holds a special place in my esteem. Upon entering the premises, I was struck by an unpleasant olfactory sensation reminiscent of the aromas commonly associated with Asian supermarkets, specifically the combination of scents emanating from their inventory of rice and meat products. This initial impression was followed by a discovery of the limited scope of their 'olive bar,' which offered a mere eight containers, each approximating the volume of a small bread loaf. It is worth noting, however, that the selection of meats appeared fresh and of satisfactory quality, with beef top loin available at a reasonable price of $5.99 per pound and center-cut pork chops priced at an affordable $2.99 per pound. Furthermore, the cheese counter, despite its modest proportions, showcased an array of fresh-looking items. Generally speaking, the interior of the store was well-maintained and brightly illuminated. Unfortunately, I was unable to locate my preferred brand of peppered uncured Wellshire bacon, but I did manage to find a single loaf of Natural Bread Company's Honey Whole Wheat bread, which I have found to be palatable without causing discomfort. A cursory examination of their bulk section revealed an assortment of sweets, which, had I not already satiated my hunger, would have proven tempting. In the event of an emergency requiring immediate restocking, I might consider returning to this location. However, my inclination is to favor the Tatum/Shea and Mayo branches (neither of which I have had the pleasure of visiting thus far) for my future dining experiences at Whole Foods."

"My sentiments regarding this establishment are rather tepid, as the accommodations, although pleasant, fail to exceed my expectations. However, I must acknowledge that the personnel have been courteous and helpful during my stay, despite the minor inconvenience of being assigned a room on an incorrect floor. It is worth mentioning that the hotel is currently undergoing renovations, which has resulted in a significant amount of construction activity and the presence of numerous work vehicles. Notwithstanding, I would not recommend this particular lodging to prospective travelers, primarily due to the subpar service I received upon check-in. Nonetheless, the physical structure of the hotel itself is quite impressive, and the staff members have been exceptionally hospitable."

So after that tragedy of a burger I had earlier from Carl's Jr., I felt a redemption could be made if I just ordered two cheeseburgers at BK.  How hard can it be to make two plain cheeseburgers?  So I waited, and waited, and waited, while other people were getting their chicken nuggets, Whopper Jr's, and Extra Long BBQ Cheeseburgers.  While all that was happening I was staring at their order board and saw my order was in red letters and was passing 5 minutes while all the others were in green letters and most were finished in under a minute.  For two plain cheeseburgers?  C'mon, now!!  Well I finally got my cheeseburgers and they definitely made up for that hot mess I had earlier from Carl's Jr.

Out of the gate i called for a reservation. they said no need.. just come on in. So i was upset to find a 30 min wait for a table. they told me they dont take reservations. it vegas... sat night... you guys should take reservations. just my opinion.

menu is small... food is over the top. 

truffle fries were incredible.. everything else was good.. not great.. but good. i had good company which made the meal fun. so all in all we had a good time there. Its a pretty good place. i guess i would return under the right circumstances... but wouldnt run back there on my own...

"A delectable brunch and captivating ambiance on the patio were sadly marred by a conspicuous shortcoming that warrants no higher than a mediocre rating.  If the ability to omit an ingredient from a dish upon request is either present or absent, with no middle ground, then the response to our query regarding the absence of onions in the dish should have been met with an emphatic affirmation rather than a feeble attempt at placating our preference.  Alas, the dish arrived with onions included, despite assurances to the contrary, raising concerns about the culinary team's capacity to accommodate dietary restrictions and allergies.  Furthermore, the server's indifference towards addressing our concerns only exacerbated our disappointment.  Although commendable efforts were made to ensure a positive experience, recurring lapses in customer service and staff proficiency unfortunately diminish the likelihood of a future visit."

"Having experienced an extended hiatus from the delectable delights of an authentic Asian buffet for a duration of two days, I decided to indulge in a culinary excursion to this establishment, which, according to the esteemed review platform, Yelp, is designated as 'E-Z Buffet,' although the proprietors have opted to interchangeably refer to it as either 'EZ Buffet,' 'EZ Chinese Buffet,' or 'Easy Buffet,' depending on the specific signage or promotional materials in question. Thus, allowing me to partake in a gastronomical journey that encompassed a diverse array of 75 primary dishes, showcasing an eclectic mix of traditional Chinese cuisine, such as Clam Chowder, beef roast, Stuffed Bell Peppers, Calzone, pizza, and even pink marshmallows, which piqued my curiosity and left me feeling both intrigued and amused.
