Furthermore, this spacious eatery, characterized by its refined ambiance and hospitable staff, offered an extensive selection of customary Chinese fare, including Sushi (albeit being of Japanese origin), Kim Chee (being Korean in nature), Egg Foo Young (prepared authentically), and an assortment of fried chicken, boneless spare ribs, stuffed mushrooms, various chicken preparations, fish, shrimp, and numerous other options, ultimately culminating in a satisfying medley of desserts, highlighted by genuine ice cream of superior quality. Consequently, I would confer upon this commendable dining establishment a rating of three stars, denoting its well-rounded appeal and reasonable pricing, with lunch buffet prices set at $6.75 or $6.08 for seniors from Monday through Saturday, $8.75 or $7.88 on Sundays, and the availability of a standard menu for patrons seeking alternative dining options."

Chase Field, the domicile of the Arizona Diamondbacks, boasts an impressive architectural design, replete with multiple tiers and an expansive seating capacity. Strategically situated in the central district of Phoenix, this state-of-the-art stadium garnered widespread acclaim upon its inauguration, courtesy of its groundbreaking retractable roof feature, which facilitates the admission of natural light and provides protection from inclement weather conditions. My personal experiences at this venue have been pleasant, characterized by an enjoyable atmosphere and ample space for socializing with companions. However, I would advise against consuming a full meal within the premises, as the culinary offerings are overpriced and lacking in quality. Instead, consider dining external to the stadium and reserving appetite for a few beverages once inside. Regardless of whether you are a long-term resident or a transient visitor, a visit to this imposing structure is certainly worth your while.

The sushi here is always very creative and yummy, and the decor makes for a nice environment to bring anyone to--even a casual date. Im giving them 3 stars because recently I've had pretty bad service. It appears the servers don't work sections or even tables. I had a group of 6 and we had four or five different people putting in orders and checking on us throughout the night. This worked out at first, but then of course we started getting ignored. I guess each server thought the other was checking on them, but it wasn't happening. We waited almost 45 minutes before flagging someone down to keep ordering sushi and to get a roll we head ordered what seemed like ages ago. Everyone was super friendly it's just inefficient. After all this flagging down we had to do, they of course tacked on a 20% gratuity and told us we could only split the check 3 ways, causing us to have to work out with each other who will be paying for who. All of this is making me less likely to return.

"Had I not had the privilege of dining at Wicked Spoon prior to this experience, my perception of the establishment might have been somewhat skewed, leading me to erroneously assume that the quality of the food and service was of a superior caliber. However, due to the high volume of patrons and the relatively exorbitant prices for the quantity of sustenance provided, I was compelled to reassess my initial impression and liken the ambiance to that of a bustling Disneyland buffet, albeit with a slightly more refined atmosphere."

We have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, and our experiences have been rather dichotomous, with the service being either exceptionally impressive (5 stars) or subpar (1 star), while the culinary offerings have consistently met our expectations. Thus, we have arrived at an overall rating of 3 stars, which we deem to be a fair assessment given the variable quality of service we have encountered. However, if there is a decline in the gastronomic experience, we would be compelled to reevaluate our patronage of this venue.

I almost feel bad giving this three stars, but we went today earlier in the day with my 7 year old and three adults.... 7 year old played in the fort thing and found a friend, had a great time. We walked down to the Fremont street experience and decided to have dinner there in the park. We walked back and ordered our meal (at about $20 a plate for tacos and beer!!!!) around 8:48 and my daughter asked if she could go out and see the mantis on fire... I told her yes! Then my husband went to get her and they told her she couldn't come back in!!!!!  She walked back in anyway. At 9:00 they announced that if you are under 21 the park is closing.  Mind you we were still waiting of our meal! This was Saturday night. So we then felt like we had to rush through our  meal we had JUST purchased in order to leave with the under age one. Not so great. If they are marketing this for families, then it needs to be that- 9pm is not that late for families on a weekend. If they aren't, then market it that way but they do need to decide what it is. I didn't appreciate having to rush through my meal.

I've been here for dinner once and twice for brunch. Out of the three times, I would still give it a three star. I honestly don't think the food is that great here even when I come HUNGRY. But I have to admit, they have the presentation on lock-down.

My family visited this restaurant during restaurant week, and it offered the most extensive and diverse menu options among the four establishments we contacted. The ambiance was vibrant, sensual, and welcoming, which made us feel comfortable and relaxed. We enjoyed their creative cocktail selection while waiting for our table at the bar. Our server was friendly, charming, and attentive, which added to our delightful dining experience. The restaurant week menu offered an impressive variety of dishes, and the crab cakes were undoubtedly the most flavorful and well-prepared I have had in Charlotte. The steaks were cooked to perfection, and although the dessert could have been more satisfying, it was still a delectable treat. I would highly recommend returning to this establishment, particularly for happy hour with friends.

Red Ridge Park constitutes a mere ten-minute pedestrian excursion from my present domicile, which I shall be vacating in the near future, thus rendering my erstwhile frequent visits to this picturesque park a distant memory. During my days of unyielding physical fitness regimentation, I would endeavor to circumnavigate the park's perimeter, whose distance approximates a mile, albeit with slight variations in elevation, owing to the park's topographical configuration, comprising of two inclined sides and two flat expanses, thereby facilitating an unencumbered running experience. Moreover, I have always appreciated the park's nocturnal illumination, which engenders a sense of security, particularly when traversing the premises singularly. 

The park's amenities include a diminutive water-themed recreational area for juveniles, an extensive playground for older children, a smaller play area designated for younger offspring (refer to visual depictions), basketball courts, and a baseball diamond (visual representation provided). Despite its constant throng of patrons, I have yet to experience a sensation of overcrowding within the park's confines. Observations have revealed that visitors indulge in various activities such as ambulating, interacting with canine companions, or simply luxuriating in the sun's radiant warmth while partaking in gastronomical delights. 

Of late, residential dwellings have begun to materialize directly opposite the park, specifically, the Dunhill abodes, whose prices range from approximately 200,000 units of the local currency as a starting point, and the neighborhood is undergoing rapid development. These habitats merit consideration, especially for those who harbor an affinity for the southwestern sector. Furthermore, the proximity of these residences to the park grants the benefit of verdant vistas, whereas alternative perspectives may encompass views of neighboring structures. Additionally, the recently established Wet n Wild Water Park lies in close proximity. Notwithstanding, a certain feature that I ardently desire to witness within this park's precincts is the presence of an enclosed canine recreational area, akin to those encountered during my peregrinations to other parks.

3.5 stars. Fan of the appetizers: the salumi and the grilled asparagus. We had for entree the fish and chips and although the batter was quite good the fish didn't have a lot of flavor, we had to add a bit of lime to improve it.\nOther people in the group liked their entrees except for one beef entree that was too salty. \nThe berries for dessert were outstanding. The ice cream was ok, the problem is they serve it in bowls that melt it really quick. The caramel dessert was again too salty.

"The culinary offerings were merely adequate.  It is an establishment specializing in alcoholic beverages.  It would be more suitable for individuals who partake in such libations.  Unfortunately, I do not possess a predilection for beer.  I opted for a black bean burger, which was presumably a product of Morningstar Farms.  The supplementary fee for this item was $1.99, a cost I deemed dubious.  The hospitality was inconsistent, but we did receive a replenishment of our beverages upon the delivery of our bill."

Based on the perusal of patron reviews, I experienced a sense of disillusionment with my entree selection, specifically the chicken pasta dish comprised of linguini, basil, and a rich cream sauce. The culinary execution yielded a dish that was overly substantial and heavily laden with an excessive amount of creamy sauce, which detracted from the overall enjoyment of the meal. Notwithstanding this disappointment, the quality of service provided by the restaurant staff was exceptional and worthy of high praise, leading me to consider giving the establishment another opportunity to demonstrate its culinary prowess. It is conceivable that the subpar experience may have been an isolated incident attributable to an off night in the kitchen. Additionally, I was pleased to note the availability of one of my preferred beverages, Dos Equis amber, which contributed to a more satisfying dining experience.

I've been to Osteria twice now. Once to grab a sandwich for lunch, and then to get a takeout pizza for dinner. I've really hoped this place would be good as I live across the street. My experience has been mixed. Sandwich was a very good Italian deli sandwich. Pizza was mediocre though. While the pizza had the unintended positive effect of reminding me of free pizza consumed when I was in grad school in NYC that's not the best sign of quality. Not bad but could be better. \n\nThere's a lot of potential for Osteria and I hope they succeed. Maybe a weekend brunch would be a good addition? And make pizza less like basic takeout pizza and more \"fancy\" (tasty too).

It's fine.  No, really, it's fine.

Seriously, it's fine.

I'm not being sarcastic, it's fine.

__________________________________

(this is just for the breakfast buffet, which I've had 10-15 times since I usually stay here when I come to Pittsburgh)

You know going in that the food isn't going to be incredible, but you'd at least expect the staff to be friendly. This particular OG is very hit or miss. I've had both good and horrible dining experiences due to the waiter/waitress.

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are of considerable quality, and it is likely that I will frequent this location for breakfast on multiple occasions. The savory crepes are particularly delectable, surpassing their sweet counterparts in my esteem, and the coffee beverages are similarly well-crafted. However, there are certain aspects that could benefit from improvement. Firstly, the absence of a hostess or clear indication of service style resulted in confusion upon entry, requiring me to seek out an employee for clarification. Additionally, the service was inconsistent, with lengthy wait times for both ordering and food delivery, which may deter patrons who have schedules to keep. Nonetheless, my fondness for crepes, coffee, and satisfactory service generally leaves me content with this venue, despite some drawbacks."

Great value in vegas, $109 per night on a weekend compared to $400 for a cramped little room on the strip.  Throw in the free breakfast and free drinks in the evening and you have yourself a great value.

The hotel has been upgraded.  The rooms are nice enough.  The lobby atrium is a bit dated and the faux plants are a bit dusty.

There were some service issues.  We ordered food to go at the restaurant.  The place was empty and we were quoted 20 minutes to get our food.  In the end, it took 40.

Check in took forever, as did many interactions with the front desk.  The guys working the desk had to always stop and answer phones which was annoying.  But the one guy working the desk called me "cute."  Not sure if I should be flattered or horrified.

There was never a consistent answer on the shuttle to the strip.  We were told they would take us anywhere (and they did) and pick us up.  But when I called for pickup, they said they only pick up and drop off at Planet Hollywood.  In the end, we had to use taxis a lot which ran $10 a trip to the strip.

All things considered, I like the other Embassy Suites on Paradise just a touch better and I have stayed there many times.  But they were $50 a night more when I booked so we stayed here.

"Conveniently situated within the confines of the Gyle Industrial Estate, this shopping centre serves as a haven for those seeking a brief respite from the mundanity of office life. While some may perceive this establishment as somewhat dilapidated and lacking in amenities, I, on the other hand, regard it as a veritable oasis, replete with an array of apparel stores, dining options, and a Starbucks franchise that affords me a brief interlude of liberation during my lunch break. 

Although it is likely that the Gyle Shopping Centre has experienced better days, with its former lustre having diminished over time, the assortment of retailers and services available remains impressive. Boasting one of the largest Marks & Spencer food halls, a substantial Morrisons supermarket, a sizeable Boots pharmacy, and a diverse selection of fashion outlets, including New Look and Dorothy Perkins, this complex caters to a wide range of needs and preferences. Furthermore, the presence of a Millie's Cookies kiosk only serves to heighten my affection for this venue, as I am unashamedly enamoured with their delectable cookie cakes. 

While the ambiance of the food court may leave something to be desired, and the options for health-conscious individuals may be limited, this shopping centre remains a suitable destination for a leisurely lunchtime excursion or an urgent errand to procure essential items such as mascara or concealer. Moreover, the allure of that latest Dorothy Perkins dress, as featured in my favourite gossip magazine, often proves too great to resist. In conclusion, despite its slightly worn appearance, this shopping centre continues to offer a passable experience, with a diverse array of attractions and amenities at its disposal."

Ever since this was built a number of years ago, I've been wanting to check it out but whenever I'm in Vegas, I usually hang along the strip most of the time and never made it out here.  My last trip I finally did.  

The things I do like about the "experience" is that it's an outdoor party and I have to say the screens are pretty impressive.  

This is "Old" Las Vegas where everything is dirt cheap.  All the drinks and food are inline with the prices I want to pay when I come to Vegas.  

But.......   
It's pretty damn ghetto here.  At least the night I came.  There were a lot of street people.  You could see some paperbags with some "8 Ball" protruding from them.  But I guess that's part of the charm here cause you can just have an open container here with no damn worries....  

It's all good I guess but whenever I looked up at the screen, I had to make sure I looked back to street level here and there just to make sure my wallet was not leaving me.  haha..  

Maybe the earlier shows are not so seedy.  I did come for the very last show of the evening so maybe I was asking for it....

My wife and I stopped here after seeing Zumanity the night before Halloween. Fortunately there were a ton of people out and about in their costumes. We wanted to find a place where we could have a drink and watch people. This place fit the bill perfectly. 

Fortunately for us we had a couple free drink coupons, so we didn't have to pay. However, the prices aren't too bad for a great selection of craft and microbrews ($6-7). I had a Sin City Amber and the wife had a Sam Adams Cherry Wheat. They had a lot of good beer here from places like Sierra Nevada, Alaska, Abita, Rogue, Stone, etc. This place has a better selection than a lot of other bars in Vegas. 

Being a Friday night NYNY was pretty hopping, but this place wasn't overwhelmingly full, though you would have thought so watching the bartenders running around, that was really my only issue with this place. Even with the free drink coupons, I tip well, so I was hoping for a bit better service. I will chalk it up to a bad night, and will go again, especially as a place to meet friends staying on the Strip.

Fun place, and we will be back.

One of the better Italian restaurants in the city, and one of the nicest restaurants in Oakland, Lucca would be a fantastic choice at a lower price point.  The food is well prepared; the staff is usually friendly and helpful; and the ambiance is nice without being stuffy.  But the pricing for this experience is more appropriate for a city like New York or San Francisco.

I guess I expected more.  Great view.  I watched Vegas from the day time to night, which was nice.  The food and decor was average, it could be better. The only thing about this restaurant that makes it so special is it's view, but I live here.

I have watched Viva Elvis a few times, from grand opening to a few months ago.

The show has improved since it first open but it hasn't progressed too much.  Don't get me wrong the show isn't bad, it just doesn't seem to fit well with Cirque's other show.  

What i liked about the show was the awesome music, scenes, and costumes.  As soon as you walk in you are greeted by some of the performers that are dressed up in elvis era.  My favorite number was jail house rock and return to sender.  

What I didn't like was the choreography wasn't as thrilling as other cirque shows. It seemed very minimal and not much to the "awe" factor.  I really didn't like that in a few scenes they have women sing elvis songs.. i just rather it be.. idk.. ELVIS singing his songs.  They are not bad singers, however the singers would change it to their style and it just didn't seem right.  I also didn't like the awkward transition of each scene.  
BUT besides that.. i did enjoy it.  

I would recommend to go watch it, especially since it will be leaving soon.

Unfortunately, it appears that this establishment has recently undergone a change in proprietorship, and my experiences with the quality of the eyebrow waxing services provided have been less than satisfactory. Specifically, the new owner seems to have neglected to maintain the standard of excellence previously upheld by the former proprietor, as evidenced by the fact that one of my brows was left uneven and noticeably thinner than its counterpart. This disparity has necessitated an extension of the time interval between waxings, which unfortunately precludes me from patronizing this business further.

Second time i have been to a culinary dropout, first time at this one.

As always love the atmosphere, especially because the Yard was right there as well.

Happy Hour beware are only at the bar, hightops, or outside. We didn't go for that so it wasn't too big of a deal, but could have been.

Only had the hip bar type food when we were here for a work hang out. It was good from what I had. 

Definitely a fun place to come to hang out and just kick it with friends. Consider it an adult playground.

"The seared tuna carpaccio, ninja roll, and elephant roll exhibited an impressive culinary proficiency, boasting a flavor profile that was undoubtedly tantalizing. However, the ambiance, while trendy, suffered from a somewhat claustrophobic atmosphere, which was further exacerbated by the low rise sushi bar counter that, although functional, proved to be aesthetically displeasing to this writer. Nevertheless, the price point for the all-you-can-eat dinner option remained reasonable, rendering it an accessible indulgence for those seeking a gastronomical adventure. Furthermore, the ample parking and melodious background music contributed to an overall pleasant dining experience, despite minor quibbles regarding the physical space. Ultimately, the fare served at this establishment demonstrated a satisfactory quality, thus ensuring a positive outcome for those who partook in the culinary journey."
Good place to watch a game, the bartenders were fairly attentive but food service time was poor. After 30+ minutes waiting for an app, I canceled the order and asked for my check.

I was decidedly more taken by the charms of Squirrel Hill than those of Bangkok Balcony, and my companion and I chanced upon this venue via a website proffering guidance for vegan travelers to Pittsburgh, which we found appealing given their late hours of operation. We encountered minimal difficulty in securing street parking, and while my enthusiasm was somewhat dampened by the preponderance of shuttered boutiques, owing to an unfortunate temporal confluence, I must admit that my attention was captivated by the diverse array of vintage and contemporary attire on display. Digression notwithstanding, I must confess that the layout of Bangkok Balcony did strike me as rather appealing, what with its elevated position and modern appointments that stopped short of sterility. My companion and I were both enamored of the flatware employed by the establishment, which, though perhaps seeming a trivial detail, did indeed warrant mention. Furthermore, the menu boasted an impressive selection of tofu options, and I must say that I appreciated the consideration evinced by the staff in inquiring about my desired level of spiciness, scaling said preference from one to ten. Additionally, the prices charged by the restaurant struck me as quite reasonable, especially considering the bustling atmosphere and aesthetic appeal of the premises. In conclusion, while my culinary excursion did prove satisfying, albeit with a tinge of subsequent indigestion, my fervor for Thai cuisine knows no bounds, and thus, I feel compelled to assign three stars to this establishment.

They gave us a great table right next to the floor to ceiling windows. overlooking the strip. the HUGE Jumbo screen and parking lot that were in view aren't very romantic but the Eiffel tower in the distance was. 

Drinks - great cocktails

My only comment is the live music is on the other side of the bar from the windows. so you have to choose -  view or live music.. not both. :P kind of sleepy. everyone here was paired up. good for the "mature" or "date" crowd. I wanted to meet people and laugh so we had one drink and left. still worth checking out.

"I opted for the frozen hot chocolate, electing to consume it extramurally, as the temporal duration preceding its procurement proved to be rather protracted. Notwithstanding the lengthy delay, the beverage's quality was sufficient to justify its consumption, rendering it an acceptable culinary experience. While I am not inclined to endorse the exorbitant price point of $9 for a limited quantity, I acknowledge the existence of certain circumstances that may warrant such a tariff. Upon fulfilling my long-standing desire to sample this item, courtesy of its prominent placement on Oprah's list of preferred products, I shall endeavor to partake in their gastronomical offerings at a future date."

"While my culinary excursion to Price's Chicken Coop in Charlotte, North Carolina, in May 2012, was merely average, it was also somewhat underwhelming, given the excessive buzz surrounding this establishment. As a native of Maryland, I had included this eatery on my list of'must-visit' destinations during my trip, primarily due to its reputation for serving delectable chicken wings. However, upon sampling their offerings, I found the portions to be minuscule, which was utterly astonishing, and the flavor was merely passable. In fact, the most memorable aspect of the dining experience was the substitution of tater tots for French fries, which brought back nostalgic memories of my high school days. Nonetheless, I can obtain comparable pressure-fried chicken wings from various Amish markets in Maryland, which are not only more substantial but also more satisfying overall. Therefore, Price's Chicken Coop has been removed from my list of recommended dining establishments."

"Although the culinary offerings at this establishment are merely satisfactory, it remains the sole viable option in close proximity for a rapid consumption of nourishment. Furthermore, my temporary lodging at the Mandala Bay, situated in close adjacency to this venue, rendered it an even more convenient dining choice."

When I saw that a Korean BBQ place had moved in to the empty Mcdonalds store front, I was pretty excited! I would finally be able to try Korean food at a good price..Which was partially correct. They are pricey for 'fast-food', with most of their options, including a la carte, being around $7-9. I have tried their Bulgogi, with steamed vegetables and kimchi, which was all really good! The sweetness of this dish was great with the garlic and spice of the kimchi! 

I really want to try their Mandu and tempura, but they keep it under heat lamps in the front, which makes me wonder how long it has been there..but will probably try it one day ( I was watching ABC 15 and saw they got a D for their health inspection in July. It was for things like improper holding temperatures, kimchi made at home(was removed from service), thermometers, ect. BUT Most of these problems were solved on the same day)

I see now that they have added Boba tea, which I'm also really excited for, seeing as how it's hard to find without driving to the far west or Scottsdale to find!

Hopefully the busier they get, the lower prices will become, but being one of the only Korean places on the East side of Phoenix, they might not.

Not too bad. I am not at all the Old Town Scottsdale nightlife kind of gal anymore, so this wouldn't be my scene during those times. However, about 12 of my girlfriends and I went to The Mint for Happy Hour on a Friday and had a pleasant time. The food is really good! The drinks are good and the 1/2 price makes them very reasonable. The interior was pretty cool. Later at night you probably wouldn't be able to notice all the cool details. The co-ed bathroom is weird - just weird. I really didn't like that. The staff while very attractive and friendly, seemed a bit new. Our very sweet server had a lot of trouble with our big group. She didn't want to do separate checks at the beginning and told us doing one group bill would be easier for everyone. Then, when we tried to pay, it was a problem and someone else told us we should have done separate checks...we tried! I waited 30 minutes for my bill when there might have been 3 other patrons in the Mint other than our group. I would definitely come back for another happy hour and check out the outdoor bar, but would probably insist on separate checks.

"This venue possesses an ambiance characterized by an abundance of artwork and large televisions in the primary bar area, which creates a captivating atmosphere that attracts a diverse clientele. Additionally, the upstairs section boasts pool tables, arcade games, and skee-ball machines, providing entertainment options for patrons of all ages. An outdoor patio area is also available, much to the delight of those who partake in smoking activities. It has become a popular destination for locals to congregate on Sundays to observe sporting events, further enhancing its appeal. Although their menu does not include food, they occasionally host special events such as a complimentary chicken wing buffet, which is readily availed by patrons. Furthermore, they showcase an impressive selection of locally brewed beverages, which aligns with the preferences of many visitors. Lastly, ample parking facilities are provided, both on the street and behind the building, ensuring convenient access for all patrons."

I must admit that my experience did not quite live up to the lofty expectations engendered by the plethora of glowing reviews lavished upon this establishment, with many patrons effusively extolling its culinary virtues in effusive fashion, going so far as to assign it a perfect score of five stars; personally, I found the fare to be satisfactory, but by no means exceptional, particularly considering the rather steep tariff of sixty dollars for a single burger, fish sandwich, fries, and a pair of sodas, which, in my estimation, failed to justify the cost, leaving me feeling underwhelmed and unimpressed, and, I might add, my lovely companion concurred with my assessment, thus necessitating a rating of three stars, denoting an experience that, while certainly passable, fell short of excellence.

Dissapointingly different from how the original Canyon Ranch is represented in books and other reviews.  Over-priced, smaller than the spa @ The Venetian and offers nothing novel besides the expensive energy massage \"without physical touch\".  Huh??  \nThis isn't my first choice.

Husband and I went for HH and also ordered some regular menu items. The drinks were a decent price (hh prices). We ordered the Gladiator burger & daily dose burger which were both just okay. They were both lacking flavor and the msuhroom brie was mediocre. Despite the fact it was dead, we felt very rushed. Hope was training another waitress - I hope the trainee doesn't listen to her. Besides rushing her patrons, she talked down to her own trainee. When she introduced her trainee, she literally said, \"Don't ask her questions because she's new and won't know.\" WOW. I've been a waitress before and I would have been furious if I was talked to like that during my training, and as a patron - it looks horrible that you are degrading your own coworker.

All Apple stores, for the most part, possess expansive interior spaces that are well illuminated, allowing their products to be prominently showcased, thereby creating an ambiance conducive to a pleasant shopping experience, which is further enhanced by the friendly and professional demeanor of the staff members; however, it is worth noting that the prices of their products are exorbitant and disproportionate to their actual value, hence, it is advisable for ardent admirers of the brand to exercise fiscal prudence and consider alternative options that offer better value for their money, and, if they are inclined to make charitable contributions, they can do so by donating to organizations that support worthy causes, thus contributing to the greater good, while simultaneously enjoying life's indulgences in a responsible and festive manner.

The gastronomical experience was satisfactory, with a diverse array of options that catered to our taste buds' delight, yet did not quite attain an exceptional level of quality that would have rendered it truly remarkable. The ambiance, while not particularly captivating or vibrant, did provide a suitable setting for an enjoyable dining experience, albeit one that was not characterized by an excessive degree of liveliness or energy, which might have been expected in a city such as Las Vegas, known for its exuberant nightlife and entertainment options. Our visit was facilitated by the utilization of a Groupon, which afforded us a reasonable price point that would have otherwise been considered somewhat steep in light of the restaurant's unremarkable reputation and relatively subdued atmosphere.

Did a detail there, they did a good, but not oustanding job, but for a reasonable price (like $150).  Tons better than Danny's would ever do!\n\nI've had other, better, details in the area, but they were closer to $250... so comparing the quality of the work versus the price, Airpark was a good/very good value.

This Panda Express has a drive-thru, which is great when it's 103 outside and I want lunch without stepping out into the broiler.   It was a fast queue and they got my order right.   \n\nThe orange chicken/Beijing beef was pretty unpalatable though, it was really dried out and sauceless.  It's a Panda Express, that happens.  Basically your average Panda without getting out of the car.

Although I frequent this establishment with considerable regularity during my sojourns in Las Vegas, it is prudent to caution that, should you possess a Caucasian complexion, certain menu items may be subjected to an unsolicited and unfortunate process of extreme culinary sanitization, ostensibly tailored to conform to your presumed gustatory preferences. For instance, during a recent visit, I opted for the premier combination pho (customarily positioned atop the menu at any reputable pho purveyor) and was dismayed to discover that it had been stripped of its customary tendon and tripe components...and no additional quantities of the'standard' meats were proffered as compensation for the omission.

"Despite my unwavering fondness for the opulent Galaxy Luxury cinema, there are instances in which the constraints of time and space render it impractical for me to traverse the distance required to partake in the cinematic experience, or, regrettably, the establishment does not possess an adequate number of seats for the particular film that piques my interest. Conversely, the Brenden theater, with its welcoming ambiance and courteous staff, has consistently provided me with satisfying encounters, and the tariffs for admission are within the realm of reasonableness."

Oh no's!

Mamma Mia has revised their delivery boundary. I live 0.7 mile away. 
No longer close enough to be considered for delivery.
(according to their online system)

If you're:
East of 20th St
West of 64th St
North of Washington
or
South of Lincoln

Just drive!

Pretty good pizza. 
Offered by the slice!

"3.5 stars

As an ardent devotee of Flamebroiler (do they have such establishments in AZ?), I am endeavoring to locate a passable teriyaki bowl restaurant in close proximity to my location. It is my conviction that rice bowls serve as the equivalent of sandwiches for Asian/Indian individuals, that is, they are rapid, economical, delectable, and generally salubrious meals. I believe that this particular establishment fulfills the aforementioned criteria! 

I opted for the Cayman combination, which encompasses two of their offerings. I sampled both the Fiji and Singapore curries. The Fiji dish was reminiscent of slow-cooked chuck roast, infused with teriyaki sauce, albeit slightly tough. In contrast, the Singapore curry boasted chicken and carrots immersed in a Japanese curry, akin to the cubes purchasable at Asian markets, yet with a subtle tang. Unfortunately, the meat (chicken) exhibited a stringy texture due to slow cooking, which did not particularly appeal to my palate. 

Despite these minor drawbacks, I thoroughly enjoyed my meal, and the portion size was generous, rendering it impossible for me to complete the entire bowl. The price was remarkably reasonable, a mere five dollars! Furthermore, their distinctive menu showcased an admirable departure from the ubiquitous chicken or beef dishes blanketed in teriyaki sauce, although it failed to elicit a profoundly remarkable impression. Nonetheless, I appreciate the uniqueness of their offerings, and given the proximity of this establishment to Midwestern, coupled with the affordable pricing, I shall certainly revisit it. In fact, I eagerly anticipate sampling their appetizer selections, specifically their crab puffs and egg rolls. Lastly, it is worth mentioning that Midwestern students are entitled to a ten percent discount."

Great hotel room but can be really overpriced depending on when you go. I came here over Memorial Day weekend with a few people. I loved the hotel room but they charge for everything! For a roll-away bed was an extra $20 per night, you couldn't even use the mini-fridge without being charged. 

There are some perks that included it was in a central location, minutes from the strip. They host Rehab, which is a concert. When I came Drake and Lil Wayne was there but guests still have to wait in line to get their complimentary tickets that are for only 2 guests. And make sure you get in line early because prices double, they will stop selling tickets, and the line will be close to 2 hours and up to get a ticket. Then the casino, restaurants, and night club in the hotel so you don't have to leave the hotel at all to have a good time! 

After all of that  I'll still try another hotel next time I'm in Vegas or try on a less crowded weekend.

"Steve's Greenhouse Grill embodies an unpretentious, idiosyncratic charm that defies conventional culinary norms, much like a Cracker Barrel sans corporate support and augmented by sporting accoutrements. Its vibrant color scheme, boisterous ambiance, and prolific display of alcoholic advertisements create a kaleidoscopic atmosphere that transcends traditional dining conventions. The menu boasts an extensive array of delectable options, catering to diverse palates with its heterogeneous assortment of culinary delights, while the bar offers an assortment of reasonably priced libations. The servers exude enthusiasm, effusively extolling the virtues of each menu item with infectious zeal, creating a convivial ambiance that permeates the entire establishment. Our dining experience was thoroughly satisfying, with some dishes exhibiting a subtle saltiness, others achieving a delightful balance of flavors, and a few selections bordering on blandness. In essence, if one were to envision a Cracker Barrel with a reduced budget and an eclectic approach to clientele, the result would closely resemble Steve's Greenhouse Grill."

Like others in the surrounding vicinity, we patiently awaited and attentively observed as this particular space underwent transformation into Central Bistro, boasting a captivating ambiance that, while quite vibrant, was not without its auditory intensity; with the windows open, allowing the gentle breeze to permeate the establishment, it was truly sublime. However, one cannot help but ponder the potential impact on the sonic landscape once the windows are sealed, effectively enclosing the space.  
The culinary offerings were undoubtedly delectable, and the service was generally satisfactory, yet one glaring concern marred our overall experience: during two separate visits, we noticed bartenders engaged in the preparation of garnishes with uncovered hands, exemplified by the peeling of an orange, resulting in the release of juice that flowed down their arms and hands, followed by the slicing of said fruit for use in various beverages. Moreover, during our most recent visit, a bartender was observed inserting his hand directly into an olive jar, retrieving a handful, and depositing them into the garnish tray, prompting us to swiftly remove the olives from our martini.  
To the esteemed personnel of Central Bistro, we implore you to address these issues forthwith, lest a visit from the Maricopa County health authorities prove problematic.

I determined that I would prefer to conduct all my culinary indulgences at the counter of vintage refurbished residences in the central business district of Phoenix. Fortuitously, I stumbled upon Coronado Cafe. We halted our activities for the midday repast, and thus, I did not feel compelled to order an extensive quantity of comestibles as I customarily enjoy doing when sampling a novel eatery (it was a workday). Alas, my assessment shall be restricted to a solitary menu item. I assure you, dear reader, that I shall compensate for this deficiency in my subsequent visit. We visited the establishment during the noontide hour, and there existed a brief delay in securing a table designed to accommodate two patrons. Consequently, we opted to situate ourselves at the bar. The interior space was somewhat diminutive in size. The bar itself possessed sufficient capacity to accommodate four individuals comfortably, with a maximum occupancy of five patrons. An array of potent potables and vinous beverages were visible to my sight, although unfortunately, I was unable to partake in their consumption. My dinner selection consisted of a delectable roasted fowl sandwich, accompanied by a preference for the potato salad instead of the traditional baked beans. The poultry was delightfully succulent, and the peppers contained within the dish manifested an appropriate degree of fiery zest. The potato salad served as a scrumptious complementary side dish. The entire dining experience was straightforward, yet gratifying. I yearn to revisit this eatery at a later time when the atmosphere is less hectic. The temperature during the month of August rendered the outdoor seating area unsuitable for comfort, and obtaining the attention of the server or bartender proved to be a challenging endeavor.

I have to agree with both Pierre and Donald. However there are 2 menu items worth ordering. I get them togo all the time for lunch. The lettuce wedge and the willy burger. The steaks are awful! They put some crap they describe a seasoning that is so overpowering you can't eat it. Also someone needs to teach the cook the difference between Med rare and Well. I know I know that is a big difference but when I ordered the rib-eye med rare I got a hockey puck! Sidebar the bread is really good when you get it hot. \n\nThe wrap up burgers are good and the lettuce wedge rocks, skip the steaks!

Liked this place. Went on a Sunday so the guy didn't make much because he said their slow on Sundays. We tried a little bit of everything and liked it. I would have given more stars but the service was bad, maybe the guy was in a bad mood, not sure. Make sure you have somewhere to eat after you buy the poke unless you want to eat outside in the Vegas heat! No indoor seating. Would recommend you come here to pick up poke because overall the food was good.

"Satisfactory victuals are proffered at this establishment, with prices that are reasonable and within the means of most patrons. My spouse and I opted to partake of a morning repast at this venue, situated in the midst of a workweek, subsequent to perusing numerous laudatory assessments. We were particularly eager to sample one of their loaves of bread, which had been the subject of extensive acclaim. 

Upon our arrival, we were pleased to discover that there was no waiting period, as the restaurant was only moderately occupied. Our server was exceptional, exhibiting a combination of cordiality, attention to detail, and promptness. 

The menu presented a diverse array of options, which led to a certain degree of perplexity on our part, as each item appeared equally appealing. Following a prolonged deliberation, I elected to indulge in Jamm's French Toast, while my better half selected an omelet. 

In conclusion, the culinary offerings were adequate, albeit perhaps not exceptional. It is conceivable that we did not select the most suitable dishes from the menu. As there are numerous alternative establishments serving breakfast in Las Vegas that remain to be experienced, it is unlikely that we will return to this particular venue in the future."

"It is abundantly evident that a vast improvement has transpired, owing to the revamped entrance that has replaced the erstwhile arduous ascent of five flights of industrial parking garage-style stairs, followed by an additional two floors to reach the primary dance area. Instead, an unpredictable guest elevator now ferries patrons to a random floor, where they must navigate through a poolside concert before ascending yet another flight of stairs to arrive at the coveted destination. Kudos are extended for this enhancement. However, certain drawbacks persist, such as the minuscule dance floor that remains inaccessible, rendering it challenging to partake in rhythmic movements when the venue reaches capacity. Moreover, the absence of visual proximity to the dance floor when the space becomes congested renders it impossible to relish the experience fully. A brief respite can be obtained outdoors, but this option proves less than desirable during the winter months. It is reasonable to surmise that the same designers responsible for TAO also played a role in creating this establishment, given the lack of fluidity, atmosphere, and enjoyable revelry that permeates the space."

Went out here with some friends on Sunday night, right when you walk in it is a little small, but they do have an outdoor section where it is heated. The menu is fairly large with lots of selections. We all ordered different things but the portions are large! So be careful many items on a small table can make it difficult to eat! BUT- I enjoyed the food, tea gets served in a metal dish container. The food is heavy on the saucy side. The service could have been better.

Great pizza, HORRIBLE customer service. The black girl at the cash register did not acknowledge my presence when I came up and was very rude when she did. After I paid for my slice, I asked if I should just sit down and she just rolled her eyes at me. No answer, nothing. 

One guy, kind of reddish hair actually greeted me when I walked in and the man making pizzas behind the window actually said thank you to me, but at one point I heard the red haired boy and the black girl get into it because she was yelling at him before he walked out for a delivery. Very unprofessional.

Not to mention how dirty this place was. I couldn't find a table that wasn't filthy and when I ordered my pizza, it was from a pie that was just sitting out on a stool and thrown in the oven for a couple minutes. 

Good pizza, but please work on the customer service.

stopped here for a quick dessert b/c my wife love red velvet cupakes.  we came after lunch on a sunday and the selection was extremely limited.  each cupcake runs $3.00 which isnt bad for a "gourmet" cupcake shop.

the cupcakes are definitely loaded with frosting, however i wasnt overly impressed with the taste of caramel on my cupcake and the red velvet ones were not made with cream cheese frosting.

all in all great for a nice dessert.

Good place to dine while in the Phoenix airport. The service is friendly, the atmosphere is nice, and the food is good. I ordered the grilled chicken stuffed pita with lettuce, tomato, hummus, and a vinaigrette. There are plugins too. Can't beat that.

"The club boasted an ambiance of unparalleled elegance, which was undoubtedly enhanced by the predominantly masculine demographic that comprised the clientele on the evening in question, given that my particular industry's trade exhibition was concurrently being hosted in the vicinity, resulting in an anomalously skewed gender ratio that was decidedly disproportionate, with a veritable plethora of gentlemen in attendance, in contrast to a marked dearth of feminine presence, rendering the atmosphere decidedly testosterone-charged, to say the least; however, despite the conspicuous absence of estrogenic influence, the experience remained enjoyable, as I had the opportunity to socialize and imbibe libations in the company of both acquaintances and colleagues, as well as the occasional visually striking female model, albeit at a price point that could be considered somewhat prohibitive, and with a potency that left something to be desired, yet, notwithstanding these drawbacks, I would still consider returning, provided that entry was not contingent upon an exclusive familiarity or connections, as the case may be, with the establishment's gatekeepers, which, regrettably, appeared to be the prevailing policy during most instances."

I was looking for best Peking duck in town and found Blossom. According to our server, it takes 2 days to prepare. I had a very high expectation for this place since it is $79 per duck. Fyi: I had pecking duck from one of the best Peking duck restuarant in Beijing. The duck was served with skin and meat and sauce on a wrap. Ummm. It should be served with skin only? The skin is not crispy enough. The sauce is ok. After that the duck was brought back to chop. The meat was juicy but have a bit of distinct smell of the duck. Overall, the Peking duck is better than other places in So cal like duck house. But it is far from comparable to the Peking duck I had in Beijing.  And for the price, I would expect better quality.

Always exemplary. Unequivocally eschew the pasta entrÃ©e. Lamentably unimpressive. 
  Moreover, they purport to serve a Pizzookie that is ostensibly half-cooked; regrettably, it was not even partially prepared, with an unacceptable level of doneness barely surpassing a meager twenty percent. 
  I brought this to the attention of our server (whose name was Thomas, I believe), who responded with an apathetic and dismissive attitude, callously stating, âItâs supposed to be like that,â?before hastily departing, leaving us feeling ignored and disrespected. 
  Consequently, owing to the subpar service we received, our rating has been downgraded from its previous standing of four or five stars. However, we remain optimistic that future visits may yield more satisfactory experiences.

"We arrived on a Thursday evening and were pleasantly surprised to find no waiting period for our dining experience. The extensive dinner menu boasted an array of delectable options, including seafood, poultry, and beef dishes. However, we opted for the more modest summer dinner menu, which featured an assortment of sandwiches, pastas, and pizzas. Our initial course consisted of the chicken buffalo wing 'lollipops,' which, while unremarkable in terms of flavor, were notable for their innovative presentation, with the bone and chicken situated at opposite ends, facilitating effortless consumption. As an ardent admirer of Italian cuisine, I faced a dilemma in choosing between the pizza and pasta offerings. Ultimately, I selected the 'pasta a la bolognaise,' which proved to be a regrettable decision. The penne-like pasta was accompanied by a tomato and meat sauce that resembled something a novice chef might prepare, and its uninspired taste and unimpressive presentation failed to meet my expectations. Notwithstanding, the portion sizes were generous, and the service we received was satisfactory. The pizzas served to adjacent patrons appeared appetizing, so I would consider ordering one on a future visit, should I decide to return."

Not a bad place to hang out or swing by for dinner, but it's pretty pricey in terms of drinks and the food is meh. Sandwiches are always very salty and the meat doesn't seem so fresh. However, if you're here just for beer or UFC night, it is a pretty decent place to relax with friends. Karaoke night is fun too.

This is growing to be your local hipster students' HQ. Yes, now tea is cool..or whatever expression kids use nowadays. And I guess the key to that success is that everything's colorful, and young, and YAY! versus your imagined usual dark, damp tea-drinking place. My opinion of this place changes every time I go. On my first visit, I had a couple of questions, and a suspiciously young employee promptly told me...to go online. Well, uh, thanks...I guess? 
The second time went more smoothly, and the employees were keen on giving me the "DavidsTea experience" (again, fresh, young, colorful and YAY!). Turns out, you can both buy tea for yourself at home, or to carry around. Teas for immediate consumption are labelled 2,50$. Expensive, but I figured I needed a pick-me-up. So I choose my tea, hot or iced? latté, black, or with milk? with honey or agave? I picked a chocolate-orange mix, with whisked soy milk and agave...for 4,50$!!! Hold on! Was everything optional? Even more heart-breaking is that the tea-making lady throws whatever brew that doesn't fit your cup in a sink! 
Was it good? Yeah, epic! Epically expensive as well, if you ask me.
This shop is more for your quick cafeine fix, and gets cramped quickly. Might not want to buy your glass kettle there.

Ok!!!! Update with thrifty rental car service....  Had to call in for road side service some how a huge nail was attracted to my rear right tire... Road side service was there with in. 5 mins....  Called to exchange car today customer service with corporate office was Excellent.... Exchange of vehicle took less than 30 min... They even let me pick the vehicle.... Customer service improved a lot... \nFeels like they read my review....

Stayed here on business earlier this year. Was just OK. It took FOREVER to check-in and seemed like their check-in procedure was pretty low tech (hence the slowness). They f-ed up a delivery I needed (which was late and they had issues finding where it went in house). I didn't try and of the restaurants on site but hit up one of the cafes (forget the name but it's the one that has all the yummy pastries). It was fine but got tired of the Frenchness after a couple days:)\n\nRoom itself was fine, maybe a bit better than your usual room. Overall though, the hotel left me feeling a bit blah and I wouldn't plan on staying here for a personal vacation.

I popped in here looking to see if they had any antenna balls. They were out and were getting new ones in, but didn't know exactly when. They had a picture to show me what they looked like but that didn't really help me.\n\nI grabbed a Jumbo Jack while I was in. It was tasty and gave me my taste of JITB that I can't get in Canada.

I was not thoroughly impressed by this establishment. It possesses an unremarkable ambiance reminiscent of a Fox restaurant within the Scottsdale Quarter. 
  The menu exhibits limited options and lacks comprehensive descriptions. The culinary offerings are unexceptional and fail to tantalize my taste buds. I opted for the roasted chicken, influenced by my server's description of it as "half a chicken," which led me to anticipate the presence of breast meat. However, I was disappointed to receive a meager thigh and drumstick, accompanied by an excessive amount of sodium-saturated baby spinach and runny polenta. 
  While the dishes appeared inventive, their flavors fell short of impressive. This dining experience proved to be underwhelming. 
  Observing the waitstaff, I noticed a sense of disarray, as they presented us with various appetizers that we had not ordered. This raises concerns about the potential impact on TK's profit margin. Nevertheless, they seem to compensate for it through modest portion sizes. 
  In conclusion, this restaurant does not warrant a repeat visit in my opinion.

Decent Chinese take-out.  The Lo Mein is good, as are their shrimp and beef dishes.  Did not care for their shrimp and lobster sauce.  Their ribs can be hit or miss, depending on how fatty they are.  Also did not care for their Won ton or egg drop soup.  Their fried rice is good, but then, I've rarely had bad fried rice...

"I recently had the privilege of visiting the authentic location in Fort Lauderdale, and let me tell you, it was an unforgettable experience. The cuisine was exquisite, and the ambiance was truly captivating. However, my recent visit to this particular location fell short of my expectations. Despite being a busy Wednesday evening in Florida, the atmosphere was lackluster, and the quality of the food did not live up to the standards set by its predecessor. 

The meatball was disappointingly dry, and the pasta was undercooked. Although the chicken parmesan was palatable, it failed to impress me. The sauce, however, remained a highlight. 

It's intriguing to observe that the vast majority of favorable reviews for this establishment mention Steve's presence. Perhaps his involvement does have a bearing on the quality. I recall him meticulously examining nearly every dish that emerged from the kitchen at the original location. Unfortunately, such attention to detail was absent during my visit. 

Consequently, I shall confer three stars upon this eatery. While our server was attentive, the culinary offerings did not measure up to the lofty standards established by its sister restaurant. I must confess that I am unlikely to return to this specific location, given the abundance of exceptional dining options in Las Vegas. Nonetheless, my anticipation for my subsequent visit to the Florida location remains unwavering!"

Gave Chang's another chance this week, and this time the service was much better. Quite friendly and efficient, as a matter of fact. Shared the Salt and Pepper Prawns and Shrimp Fried Rice, and both were delicious. I've always liked their food. No, it's not the greatest or most original Asian food around, but it's pretty good. It's the service that I've struggled with - but if they're able to maintain the level they displayed the other day, I will definitely continue to grace their restaurant with my presence. Ha!\n\nOh, also told our waiter about my fortune-less fortune cookie on my last visit, and he apologized profusely, said they got a bad batch last month in which one out of every three cookies was empty. The problem had been resolved, he assured me, and sure enough this time I got a fortune. Not a very good one, something about me having a deep appreciation of the arts and music (Well, duh), but hey, it was a fortune. Sort of. Ok, not really. But it was a saying on a little piece of paper, which was all I really wanted..

The decor alone seals the deal for me. Mid Century modern, and the restaurant is done well. Favorite place to dine with one of my friends and catch up. Sitting in the booths makes it feel super private. The chopped salad is what I always get simply because I adore it. Green goddess dressing is incredible. They serve rolls and butter, and they are the real thing! A throwback for sure...super soft and warm! I might be addicted to iced tea (jury is still out) and I am delighted by how it is served here...big, tall glass, mint, a side of simple syrup for sweetening, and an iced tea spoon! It's the simple things sometimes that really add to my experience :) Not sure if they still serve this, but their cake & a shake for desert is to die for. Tiny chocolate shake served with tiny chocolate cake. Perfect little treat!

This place is cool and cheap but you are paying for what you get. I got this key chain for my mother. It was 12 dollars. It broke about a week later while she was holding it. I was actually there when it happened. So then I came back returned it for her and gave it another shot. Again about a week later it broke. I went back and finally just got a gift card because I paid cash and didnt have the reciept or else I would have just gotten a refund. This place is a hit or miss. Some of the stuff is good priced but some of it not so much. Since it is inside tivolli there is a  lot of parking options

This Thai Rama is a small little place located near the light rail but in a spot that can be easy to miss. Being a huge fan of Thai food and a little picky, I was slightly worried when we approached it. However, one of my friends was craving Thai and I was thinking I could always get a little something :)  

The menu was very large and seemed to have a lot of good offerings. Not being very hungry, I was enthusiastic they had a dessert they called F.B.I. which was friend bananas and coconut ice cream. Myself and another guest ordered that and the other member of our party ordered shrimp pineapple curry (yum). The food came out fairly fast with the ice cream dishes coming out only a minute before the main course dish. 

The ice cream was a little on the ice side (as if it had been overfrozen) but overall was a delicious meal. I tasted some of the shrimp pineapple curry and it was just the right temperature and full of flavor. However, the pineapple was obviously canned which make it lack that something.

I'm not sure I'd go out of my way to come back here again, but with the pleasant staff, if I was in the area, I might swing on in.

"It is the team of employees who are responsible for the smooth operation of this retail establishment, and it is their exceptional level of customer service that motivates me to return time and time again, as they consistently strive to surpass expectations by providing assistance that extends beyond the scope of their assigned duties."

"The proximity of this Dairy Queen establishment to my domicile renders it the most convenient location for my brother and I to visit with regularity, particularly when we have an inclination for indulging in delectable frozen confections such as shakes, blizzards, and ice cream cakes, which we find to be quite scrumptious on the rare occasions when we partake of them. However, I must admit that the quality of service provided by the staff at this particular DQ has been subpar, with a high percentage of employees displaying a lack of enthusiasm and courtesy towards patrons, although this does not necessarily preclude me from patronizing the establishment, as my primary focus lies in the culinary offerings rather than the hospitality aspect."

Once upon a time, you could walk into Uncle Sal's on a Friday night with no reservations and be seated immediately. (Holy crap - has it really been 20 years since I lived in the area?!?!)
Those days are long gone. Dinner was on me for coordinating - and I dropped the ball.

Luckily, the Blind Pig was right next door, and we 4 hungry patrons could be seated and served right away.

We shared a couple plated for the table, and nibbled each other's entrees. The steak salad was a winner. The short rib was well cooked and flavorful. And everything else was perfectly OK. I had a trio of tacos  - none of which really stood out. Nothing wrong with them. Fresh, flavorful, well executed. I am just spoiled by other places in my current 'hood.

If I am in the area, and someone suggests the Blind Pig, I won't object. 
I also don't think I'd plan another meal there. Nothing in the world wrong with the place - just no "wow" factor for me.

"Upon our initial arrival, it was approaching the late hours of the evening, specifically midnight, and we were delighted to discover that this establishment remained open and operational, extending its hospitality to accommodate our group of twelve individuals. Although the pace of service was somewhat lethargic, it was comprehensible, given the unconventional hour and the substantial number of patrons in our party. My recollection of the culinary offerings is somewhat hazy, although I seem to recall enjoying a satisfactory steak; however, the true highlight of the dining experience was the refreshing and delectable cup of fresh watermelon juice that was presented to us. Despite the slight delay in service, the staff maintained a friendly and courteous demeanor throughout our visit. It is worth mentioning that the prices listed on the menu were slightly elevated, yet this was to be anticipated in a high-end venue such as Aria. Subsequently, we opted to explore alternative dining options, including the hotel's room service, its extensive buffet, and eventually, we made the wise decision to sample the local cuisine, thereby saving ourselves a considerable amount of expenses. In conclusion, while the dining experience at Aria was not particularly memorable, it was not entirely disappointing either."

If you take a plate of breakfast potatoes, au gratin potatoes, and vegetable chow mein, then you cover the whole thing in melted  butter, what do you get?  You get the reason why the terrorists hate America... 

The place was clean, the service was decent, and the food choices was what I expected for a downtown LV casino buffet: ordinary and plentiful.

But the large vat of melted butter?  You can put that sh*t on everything!

"This establishment serves as an ideal destination for individuals seeking sustenance subsequent to an evening of alcoholic indulgence. The culinary offerings are characteristic of traditional Mexican fare. The drive-thru experience was expedient and devoid of any significant delays. However, I did encounter a notable deficiency in the quantity of certain items within my order, specifically the Carne Asada fries. Previous experiences at diverse locations have led me to anticipate a more generous allocation of constituents. Unfortunately, this particular venue seemed to adopt a rather parsimonious approach, which ultimately proved disappointing. I shall revisit this establishment in the forthcoming weeks and assess whether this phenomenon persists."
Nothing too impressive. Burgers were pretty decent, but not out if this world. Onion rings were good. Price was expensive for what it was, in Vegas.

"No grievances pertaining to the culinary offerings or hospitality were expressed, and while it may be conceivable to identify alternative dining establishments within the city of Las Vegas that serve superior burgers at a more reasonable cost, the quality and value provided by this particular eatery are undeniably satisfactory."

This particular site falls within the proximate vicinity of both my domicile and that of my parental unit, thereby rendering me a habitual patron. The diverse beverage preferences of my two offspring and myself often pose a formidable challenge for the establishment's staff, which has experienced periodic fluctuations in personnel. Despite this variable consistency, the venue's accessibility continues to attract me. During peak morning hours, queues tend to accumulate, yet the staff efficiently expedites customers through the line. On the rare occasions when I've needed to return an order, the staff members have demonstrated profuse apologies and cooperation.

Came here on a friday night for drinks. Fun place to check out. People said its like being at a beach, definitely didnt get that feeling. However, drinks were good. Bartender didnt make a three wise men correctly. DJ played really good music. Probly wont come here for tacos though.

"Without encountering a delay, we were able to secure entry, which is partially attributed to its association with the Westin Hotel. Although the ambiance of the OFM exudes an air of refinement, it appears that the patronage has opted to venture elsewhere. 

Our server exhibited exceptional hospitality and provided us with recommendations on what to order. Upon inquiring about suitable sushi rolls to initiate the meal, he suggested a pair of options that harmonized effectively. Both variants were tuna-based, with one showcasing a milder flavor profile while the other offered a spicier experience. Indeed, OFM's sushi offerings live up to their acclaimed reputation. 

Subsequently, we placed orders for our primary dishes, and my selection was the cioppino. Now, my customary expectation of cioppino entails a hearty stew featuring chunks of fish immersed in a savory broth. Nonetheless, the culinary expert at OFM chose to present an entire slab of mahi, resting atop a shallow layer of the broth and accompanied by assorted shellfish. While the dish was prepared proficiently, the unconventional presentation (absence of a genuine stew) left me yearning for a more comprehensive experience. 

The caesar salad demonstrated a commendable quality, boasting authentic anchovies positioned atop. 

The Hawaiian waluu entrÃ©e garnered approval from those who sampled it. 

Likewise, the crab cakes were described as quite delectable. 

In summary, the visit transpired in a pleasant and tranquil atmosphere, complemented by hospitable service. However, a revitalization of the menu items, excluding the sushi, may be necessary to elevate OFM's culinary experience to compete with the latest establishments in the area."

"Upon my return on multiple occasions subsequent to the transition of ownership, I have observed a marked improvement in the quality of service, precipitating an upward adjustment in my rating. The reinstatement of certain culinary artisans previously associated with the establishment has contributed significantly to the enhancement of the dining experience. While the proprietor's persistent presence near the sushi bar may engender a sense of scrutiny regarding the portioning of seafood delicacies, it is my belief that a visit to this restaurant is indeed warranted."

"I placed an order for two eggs and potatoes, which amounted to a mere $3.85, a veritable bargain!  Upon requesting that my eggs be scrambled, they arrived accompanied by home fries and toast.  While my meal may have lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, it is indeed challenging to botch such fundamental fare as eggs, toast, and potatoes. 

The eggs and toast, while unremarkable, were adequate â?a far cry from the uninspired effort exhibited in the preparation of the home fries.  It appeared that someone had merely boiled some potatoes, carelessly plunked them into a pan, and then served them without so much as a cursory seasoning.  My futile attempts to enhance their flavor with salt and pepper notwithstanding, the potatoes seemed resolute in their blandness.  After a few half-hearted forkfuls, I relinquished my efforts.  

My visit took place during a morning meeting, and the establishment was relatively unfrequented.  Although there were a smattering of regular patrons present, the ambiance was generally subdued.  It is conceivable that this venue might appeal to individuals seeking sustenance following a night of revelry, when the craving for nourishment often surpasses concerns regarding culinary refinement.  However, I would not deliberately seek out Ritters except in the event of an unexpected late-night hunger pang or the need for a 24-hour eatery.  It is worth noting that payment is restricted to cash transactions."

You know - I wanted to write "I love Sunset Grille", but then I thought about it and it really occurred to me that I don't love Sunset Grille.  I like Sunset Grille, and I will return to Sunset Grille, but it's not my favorite place in Charlotte.  

It's OK.  The service is great, the layout is cool and it appears to have a happening bar if you hit it at the right time.  Food-wise, it's just OK.  I love breakfast sandwiches (and you should try this place for brunch...), but they do not have a typical breakfast sandwich, which was disappointing.  I had an Eggs Benedict's, sans Hollandaise (because you should not really eat that in a restaurant unless you know they made it right then - Thanks Anthony Bourdain for that tip).  The canadian bacon was really, really, really salty though.  

Other things I have had: An open face turkey sandwich, which now that I think about it - was salty too.  I also tried a blackbean burger with fries that was OK.  

So, as I wrote above - the more I think about it, Sunset is OK.  They try hard and are extremely attentive there, but there are better places for food in my opinion.

Is it better than Chipukele?  Sure.  Is that saying much?  Not really. The best part about this place is their tortillas which are hand-made right in front of you.  The corn tortillas are delicious.\n\nI found the sweet pork to be WAY too sweet.  The shredded beef was OK.  The rice and pinto beans, IMO, were the best part.  I guess if I had to go to Chipotle, I'd pick this place, but if there was no gun to my head, it would be easy to forget about this establishment.  There wasn't really anything wrong with it, it's just there.
I love Thai food.  The food here is okay, the price is too much for the portions at lunch.  I told him I did not want it too spicy, he did not add any seasonings.  I may go back just not on my dime.

After complaining about NC BBQ in another review, I feel guilty admitting that the chicken sandwich here was not too bad. The fried pickle was delicious, firm and warm and just the right amount of batter. I'd go back just for the pickle! The price was okay for an airport establishment and afterwards I could enjoy the free wi-fi (and power source) from one of the rocking chairs. Charlotte Airport is not too bad, and this restaurant is worth a stop.

"Culinary excellence. An atmosphere marred by excessive commotion and a dearth of seating due to inadequate table clearance, resulting in an environment that falls short of the tranquility and aesthetic appeal typically associated with establishments offering comparable gastronomic experiences at slightly higher price points."

Perhaps the allure of In-n-Out has diminished for me due to overexposure; or maybe my culinary preferences have evolved, becoming more refined and discerning. Despite the widespread acclaim and rich history surrounding this establishment, I found this particular location to be unremarkable and comparable to others I have visited in California. Ultimately, it can be argued that In-n-Out offers a superior fast food burger, yet it remains, at its core, a pedestrian meal.

"My tardy arrival, precipitated by a hangover of considerable proportions, unfortunately diminished my capacity to relish the totality of the culinary excellence on offer; however, despite the somewhat claustrophobic seating arrangement, the proximity of our table to the kitchen afforded an unencumbered view of the chef's artistry, thereby enhancing the overall gastronomical experience. The fare was indeed satisfactory, albeit at a price point that would likely induce fiscal trepidation in even the most affluent of patrons. It is advisable to secure reservations well in advance, as the demand for tables at this establishment appears to be unusually high, as evidenced by the offer of $500 for my reservation mere hours prior to the appointed time."

The BEST THING about this hotel is the made-to-order breakfast.  We received a ticket to take down to the dining room and selected an entree:  eggs, french toast, or pancakes, which came with potatoes and sausage or bacon.  Also provided is a selection of cereals, oatmeal, bread/toast, muffin, and fruit, as well as juice, milk and coffee.

The LOCATION is great!  It's right across (a block or so away) from the mall and several restaurants; it is also right off the interstate too.   

We liked how spacious THE ROOM was (King with sleeper sofa)  The room was like a little studio/efficiency with a full refrigerator, stove, and microwave.  The room was clean.

The not-so-good things are as follows:

1.  The room felt stuffy every time we entered.  We kicked up the air conditioning but got too cold.  There was no happy medium for crisp, cool air at a comfortable temperature.  

2.  The pillows were flat; using two pillows didn't help.  

3.  The stairs are steep in this two-story hotel, which lacks an elevator.  If you have trouble with stairs or have lots of luggage, you may be better off to request something on the first floor.

OVERALL, this is a very decent place to stay.  It's not too expensive; it's not too fancy; and it provides an amicable atmosphere for an overnight stay.

Apparently this is the largest restaurant in the state of Arizona. From the outside and the dining area I ate in, could have fooled me. A good friend of mine was working his last shift as a server so that is why I went. Not a huge fan of steakhouses. 

The atmosphere was pretty throw-back, 70s vibe, someplace your grandpa and dad would take you for your first real steak experience. It was dark inside and they sitting area had a retro feel like an Arizona mobster may be biting down into his steak right next to you. I was told there's a lot of history in the building so I respected the decor. 

I order a wonderful shrimp salad that came topped with the biggest, juiciest shrimps I've seen in a long time. I saved them for last because they were so crunchy to eat. My roommate ordered a sirloin and sadly had to send it back twice to get it recooked. Our wiater said that wsn't the first time that evening that had happened with someone's food and that particular chef. But the bread basket made up for it. With wonderful rosemary topped, the bread was light and buttery. 

Best part of the night? Check in on Foursquare and you can get a beer for .5 cents at the bar. We knew the waiter so he hooked us up at the table, but I have NEVER seen a deal that insane on Fourswaure before.

"The aspects I appreciated about this dining establishment were: 
-The reasonable pricing of their casual lunch fare, which is quite uncommon in Las Vegas. 
-The brief waiting period of less than ten minutes to accommodate our group of ten individuals. 
-The availability of seating shortly after the conclusion of the Rock and Roll half-marathon, which is quite remarkable given the race's proximity to the venue. We presumed that the restaurant might be congested. 
-The culinary quality of their burgers, although it's worth mentioning that our palates were heightened due to completing a 13-mile run. 

The elements that did not meet my expectations were: 
-The depletion of their sweet potato fries inventory. We were eagerly anticipating savoring them. Disappointment ensued. 
-The sluggishness of their service, despite the absence of a large clientele. We had to seek assistance from multiple staff members to procure water and place our orders. 
-The inconsistent preparation of our meals. Onions were included in dishes where they shouldn't have been. Salads arrived after the main course. Some entrees were served five to eight minutes prior to the rest of the party. Missteps of this nature. 

In summary, it was an average dining experience. I am not particularly enthusiastic about revisiting this establishment in the near future."

"Our most recent dining excursion to this esteemed establishment proved to be somewhat disparate from our previous visits, as various aspects of the experience appeared to be somewhat disorganized and lacking in coherence. Specifically, there was a considerable delay in being seated, despite having made a reservation well in advance, and certain technical issues pertaining to the processing of our club benefits arisen, which hindered our ability to fully enjoy the dining experience. Furthermore, the Caesar salad we ordered was of an inferior quality and quantity compared to our expectations, and the lobster entree we shared failed to meet our expectations in terms of both its size and visual appeal. Throughout the meal, we encountered numerous minor yet cumulatively significant mishaps and inconsistencies, leading us to surmise that perhaps there have been some recent changes within the restaurant's management or staff that may have contributed to the overall feeling of 'glitchiness' that permeated our visit. Despite these issues, the taste and preparation of the food remained satisfactory, and we shall indeed return to this establishment in the future, albeit with a heightened sense of vigilance and caution, in light of the aforementioned anomalies."

Steak and Eggs!!!

After a night of drinking and dancing, this is the place to stop by before heading back to the hotel.  Cheap food (although not the best quality... but you get what you pay for) and a place to rest your head while waiting for the food.
