Usually there is a long waiting line because everyone has the same agenda as you (eat before going back to their hotel), but if you put your name on the list and wait around, you will see that the people ahead of you in line will start to disappear because they are tired of waiting or a slot machine nearby was calling their name.  LOL

I procured an almond taro milk tea, which proved to be moderately satisfactory. Nonetheless, the popcorn chicken did not conform to my preconceived notions of its composition, and I was left with an abundance of breaded fragments.

This was was my first visit to smash em up, bash em up burger.  The staff was very friendly upon taking my order and was really good about saying about how long it would take for the food.   I had the classic smash 1/3 pounder and it was good, except it was not done quite enough.  I found it surprising that they didn't ask me how I liked my burger cooked.  For $10, I thought they should have asked.  The food was hot and tasty, I just didn't find it visually appealing for the price.  For a couple bucks less I'd rather go to Culvers.  The decor is minimalist and feels very corporatized.  My friend who suggested the place asked if they actually grilled their burgers and we found out they use 80/20 ground beef.  That was also a bit surprising but then they seemed a little on the greasy side.  I'd come back again, but seems like these places are a dime a dozen.  This one does not come out on my top five burger places.

"The poultry served at this establishment is among my preferred selections from any other rapid service eatery in the vicinity. The manner in which it is prepared, with its crispy exterior and southern-style seasoning, renders it exceptionally delectable. Furthermore, the restaurant boasts an impressive array of side dishes, encompassing mashed potatoes, various types of beans, coleslaw, and even macaroni and cheese (which, in my opinion, is the most superior option). 

However, despite the culinary excellence, the customer service provided by the staff leaves much to be desired. I have yet to encounter such a high concentration of individuals who appear to detest their occupations as I have at this specific location. Upon entering the premises, the cashier greets you with a haughty expression that seems to convey, 'HOW DARE YOU DEIGN TO PATRONIZE THIS ESTABLISHMENT.' It is almost as though they expect you to tender their firstborn child in exchange for your meal, rather than merely providing courteous and efficient service. 

Moreover, I strongly advise against utilizing the drive-thru option at this location, as my experiences have consistently demonstrated that the staff tends to botch orders or neglects to provide essential utensils. On top of that, the young woman manning the drive-thru window possesses an unsightly complexion, replete with acne, which can be quite off-putting and potentially ruin one's appetite."

Came here on a Sunday afternoon to catch some football and grab a bite - was able to get seated at the bar fairly quickly which was nice. 

Portions are large. Interesting classics as well as special items... however the food was still just ok. It got the job done, but I definitely would not come here JUST for the food. 

Service was pretty terrible... our server/ bartender Randi was really nice and sweet, however when it came time to pay the billl (which we had a comped code for) she messed up the transaction and had to get her manager. HE took about 30-40 minutes trying to figure out the issue... he literally just disappeared for 30 minutes.... the least he could've done was come back and say he's still working on it, or SOMETHING?! 

In the end though, our meal was comped (through gambling enough) and the manager figured it out. Great place to come check out sports, but don't expect more.
"This diminutive, cramped eatery, offering economical yet palatable fare, has garnered an excessive amount of acclaim on Yelp, unwarrantedly so, in my opinion."

Nothing to do on a summer night? Head out to a Hounds game. Prices are cheap - certainly more so than about any other sports team in the area, and most nights you'll get to hang out with a bunch of other folks and see and be seen.

The only problem? While lacrosse may be an up-and-coming sport, it's in the same boat as soccer when it comes to being a spectator: It just isn't that great to watch. That isn't to say that these guys don't play hard, because they do. But since there just isn't much to do other than hang out and watch them run around, and occasionally score, the best thing to do at a Hounds game is to socialize and enjoy a nice summer evening.

Also, huge kudos to the Hounds for making use of Memorial Stadium. Have to love that this oldie isn't going to waste, or even worse, being demolished to make use for some new development that may never even happen.

"While my overall assessment of this establishment would be a moderate 3.5 stars, I comprehend the reasoning behind certain patrons' inclination to confer a perfect 4-star rating. Although the culinary offerings and hospitality are undoubtedly deserving of a 4-star distinction, the steep tariffs attached to the tapas selections are somewhat problematic. As a seasoned traveler who has had the privilege of sampling an array of authentic Spanish cuisine, including tapas, in various upscale and casual eateries throughout Spain, I must assert that the prices associated with Jaleo's tapas are exorbitant, particularly in relation to the cheese tapas. Nonetheless, I would highly recommend the delectable paellas served here."

This place is alright. Kitschy name, fine food. Nothing spectacular at the bar. Nothing amazing on the menu. \n\nThis is a neighborhood bar, there are always regulars in. Not a bad sort, some of them can be quite drunk at times though.

"It was utterly impossible to consider purchasing a divided pizza due to the exorbitant cost, which was tantamount to an astronomical figure, rendering it unfeasible and unjustifiable to indulge in such an extravagance. The sum of twenty-six dollars for a single large pizza was nothing short of preposterous and egregious, especially when juxtaposed with the superior quality and comparatively reasonable pricing offered by Athens Pizza, located just down the road. In point of fact, the latter establishment's culinary offerings were not only more affordable but also boasted a markedly superior taste and overall experience for the consumer."

its always good to have some Chinese food after a few buffets...

came here for lunch... food is pricy for chinese food and dim sum... but i came here on comps... so it didnt matter...

the salmon cold noodle was superb... apart from that... everything is just slightly about average...
We all need a good British pub in our lives. The bar tenders are down to earth. No frills just drinks and ok food. Great to watch games and after work HH.

The reviews for this restaurant were overwhelmingly positive.  Service was great and we were served an accompaniment of vegetables with our dish.  We had the fried dumplings as an appetizer which were tasty but I wish there was more to the filling.  The same goes for the bibimbap.  It was served in a sizzling stone pot.  It had beef but honestly the pieces were minuscule and I was hard-pressed to find or taste it because the rice made up most of the dish.  I suggest they increase the amount and size of the beef and veges and reduce the amount of rice.

"Three stars. 

This establishment boasts an impressive size, complemented by an tasteful interior design. Unfortunately, the climate during our visit rendered the outdoor balcony area unsuitable for utilization. However, the venue featured two separate rooms, each equipped with its own disc jockey. The first room showcased a hip-hop genre, while the second room played a variety of top 40 hits. Our experience was marred by the disappointing performance of the latter DJ, whose struggles with beat-matching and playing mainstream music left much to be desired. Considering Las Vegas' reputation for hosting premier entertainment and the fact that it was New Year's Day, we expected a higher caliber of talent behind the turntables. Perhaps this particular DJ was simply enduring an off-night. 

Contrary to the common perception of surly bouncers and staff in many clubs, our interaction with the employees at this venue was quite pleasant. A standard cover charge of $40 on weekends and $20 for women may seem steep, especially considering the price of $10 beers at the bar. We opted against paying the full price for entry, as the bouncer kindly allowed my companion to enter gratis, while I paid the reduced fee of $40. For two individuals, this translated to a cost of $20 apiece, which is comparable to customary Vegas club prices for those without connections. 

While our time at this club was not marked by any major issues, we likely would not return unless we were lodging at Caesar's Palace. This decision stems from a desire to explore alternative clubs and experiences, rather than any specific dissatisfaction with our visit."

"I recently partook in a culinary excursion to this establishment, opting for the convenience of takeout, and my gastronomical exploits led me to sample both the pad tai and PH\u00d2. Upon entering the eatery, I was immediately struck by its bright and pristine ambiance, which suggested a recent renovation or inauguration. The service was indeed cordial and expedient, as the staff displayed an admirable level of proficiency in their duties. The pad tai lived up to my expectations, boasting a delectable combination of flavors and textures that left me thoroughly satiated. My companion's beef dish also garnered praise, further reinforcing the kitchen's reputation for culinary prowess. However, my primary motive for visiting this venue was to indulge in a bowl of steaming hot ph\u00f2, owing to my unfortunate absence of such delicacies in my local vicinity. Unfortunately, my enthusiasm was quickly extinguished upon opening the container, as the broth lacked the characteristic pungency and instead presented a sickly sweet and viscous consistency. Moreover, the coloration of the broth appeared unnaturally dark brown, even though I had specifically requested chicken ph\u00f2. In spite of these shortcomings, I elected to afford the dish the benefit of the doubt and incorporated the noodles and spices, as well as cooked chicken, in accordance with my personal preferences. Alas, my efforts were futile, as the offensive odor and flavor persisted, leaving me no choice but to discard the broth and consume only the noodles. It is conceivable that my experience was an isolated incident, perhaps attributable to an aberrant day in the kitchen; nonetheless, the underwhelming encounter with the ph\u00f2 unfortunately nullified my initial inclination to bestow a perfect five-star rating upon this establishment."

Cheap drinks for happy hour for sure. Tiny bar with real \"creekers\".. very smokey and loud with serious drinkers. This is where you find the locals. Hit or miss with the entertainment but the crowd itself is entertaining enough. I have had a few dishes there that were tasty. Free popcorn inside if you go into the indoor bar. P.S. The dartboard sucks, bring your own plastic darts if you want them to stick. The staff is friendly, never had a problem here.

"In the vicinity of Thunderbird Road and 59th Avenue, the superior fast food establishment is indubitably Chipotle Mexican Grill, offering consistently high-quality fare, particularly in the form of bean or vegetarian burritos. Notwithstanding, it is rather vexing that an additional fee is charged for chips and salsa, thereby elevating the cost of a humble burrito, soft drink, and accompanying sides to nearly $8. Furthermore, this particular location could benefit from more diligent maintenance of its dining area, ensuring a more pleasant ambiance for patrons."

I've been to Daisho sushi twice, once when it first opened, and earlier this evening. It was ok. Their nigiri was good & fresh, and their green tea ice cream was yummy. The service was ok, and the rolls we ordered didn't have much flavor. Perhaps we ordered the wrong rolls... Since I live across the street I thought I would give it a try, but I'll keep going to my regular sushi spot for the same AYCE price.

I always drive by this place and decided to see what it's all about.  I wasn't hungry, so decided to buy a loaf of sourdough bread.  Granted it was a few days before Christmas, so I guess it was busier than usual.  There were less than 10 people when I came in, but I waited about 10 minutes to pay for my bread.  Maybe I was a little impatient, but if I waited any longer I would've walked out of that place.  In my opinion, the workers were really slow.  I've worked in retail and you never want your customers waiting too long to pay, especially if it's bread!  I'm mean, don't they want my money?  \n\nOn a positive note, the sourdough bread was really good and would probably continue buying my bread there.  Hopefully their cashiers become more efficient.

My family and I have an ardent affinity for the culinary offerings at this establishment, and we typically procure our sustenance through the convenience of the drive-thru window. Our orders have consistently been prepared to our satisfaction, with the food being fresh, hot, and delectable. However, of late, the elderly female employee with the heavily pencil-thin eyebrows, who has been tasked with the responsibility of attending to customers at the drive-thru window, has displayed a marked propensity for irritability and a perceptible lack of enthusiasm towards her occupation. Her behavior has been characterized by an air of superiority and a palpable reluctance to accommodate even the most trivial of requests, thereby creating an unfortunate ambiance that has significantly diminished our overall dining experience. It is with great relief that we have discovered the recent opening of an alternative Mexican food restaurant located further down Greenway, which we eagerly anticipate will provide a more pleasant and hospitable dining environment. Notwithstanding, we cannot help but express our profound disappointment and discontent with the unfortunate prevalence of surliness and discourtesy exhibited by said employee, which has regrettably tarnished our erstwhile favorable impression of this eatery. Consequently, we feel compelled to confer a rating of three stars, accompanied by our fervent hope that a concerted effort will be made towards rectifying this unacceptable state of affairs.
Great location overlooking the pool and the food was good!  A little pricey for how basic the meals were, but nothing above the norm for the M.Bay.

I was amazed how large the place was once inside and how quickly they were able to seat me even though they appeared busy.  I had my drink order in quickly and was reviewing their menu within minutes of sitting down.

I ordered the AYCE which is a great price of $20 especially given the majority of the rolls were $10 or more each.  I ordered 5 in total, so it was a great deal for the quantity of food I received. The quality however was just about average to maybe a little better.  The presentation of the food was bland and once my initial order was in, it took several attempts to stop my waitress, even though the place had cleared out completely by then.

I felt a little uncomfortable having to keep asking for more tea and waiting almost 20 minutes after asking for the bill.  The food was good for $20 AYCE, however the service wasn't.  I will give them another try in a few months as I could have caught them on a bad night, but for $20 and the fact I was stuffed when I left, it is worth another try.

"Although situated within the city limits of Las Vegas, this eatery does not purport to offer an epicurean experience characterized by an extensive selection of exquisite wines and delectable culinary creations. Rather, its primary function is to provide patrons with a rapid and convenient means of satiating their hunger, sans the pomp and circumstance typically associated with fine dining establishments. My recent visit afforded me the opportunity to sample their prosciutto sandwich, which, much to my delight, proved to be a faithful representation of its constituent elements - a crusty baguette, thinly sliced prosciutto di Parma, fresh mozzarella, peppery arugula, and a tangy balsamic glaze. While undoubtedly satisfying, the cheese pizza we ordered could have benefited from a slightly longer tenure in the oven, as the underside of the crust had become unpleasantly soggy."

I stopped in earlier this month with a friend. We went on a Tuesday night, and almost completely had the place to ourselves. That was OK  as we were able to chat without yelling @ each other, and were able to chat a little bit with Heidi. Great gal...very friendly service. I ordered the Oggie (The Traditional Pasty), mushy peas (mainly after gauging my friend's expression of comfort to see them on the menu...childhood memories no doubt), and chips (potato wedges). I wasn't overwhelmed by the food. However, is English food ever overwhelming?. The pasty was a little dry and the wine gravy takes some getting used to. Although the beef was lean, it wasn't too tender. I can't say I'd recommend on the food, but the Strongbow Cider and the Hoegaarden were both pretty good. Also stuck around to play some Cricket @ the dartboard, which probably wouldn't have normally been available. I think it seems like a good place to have some drinks with friends, and soak up a good crowd atmosphere on a busier night.

Meeeehhh...it was ok.  My friend and I had heard good things, so we decided to buy tickets for our second night in Vegas....it was very cheesy and most of the guys couldn't dance at all!!  Some were very ahead/behind the rest of the group and it just looked like they haphazardly put the routines together...for what it was, it was entertaining, but would I go again?  No thanks....some of the guys were cute, but some were kind of scary looking (the long-haired guy that got wayy too into it, for example)...the best part?  The host/announcer was hilarious and made the show much more tolerable.  If you ladies are out for a bachelorette party, this really is a good place to embarass the bride-to-be...trust me!!
Not bad for Vegas but any one from Chicago will tell you the bread is wrong fix that and you got a great sandwich

Stopped by here because we needed a quick bite to eat before the Michael Jackson One show.  Thought it would be faster if we went to the bar. Took a while for the bartender to show up, but once she did service was fine. We had the chili cheese kobe beef fries, which hit the spot. Decent place to watch sports as well.

Going to Avalon always appears to be a fantastic notion until I physically attend. Let me clarify, this store does possess an aura of hipness, and one can indeed discover some intriguing items on occasion; however, my personal experience has been that it's either a resounding success or a catastrophic failure. I find their pricing system to be perplexing at times. For instance, I once selected a t-shirt with visible holes, and the price tag read $14. Concerning the term "thrift store," I wouldn't categorize it as exceptionally frugal. Nonetheless, I have acquired several items at a lower price than their original retail value (AE jeans, Urban Outfitters top).  

Another enigma is their purchasing procedure. I've brought clothing to sell on multiple occasions, and the outcome has been inconsistent. I've presented nearly new, stylish attire, only to be met with rejection, while the racks are stocked with garments that appear to belong to someone's grandmother.  

In summary, shopping at Avalon is invariably a mixed bag. Nevertheless, whenever I find myself in Squirrel Hill, I ensure that I visit the store to explore their inventory. Additionally, they maintain an impressive assortment of Halloween costumes throughout October.

"This establishment manifests itself as a veritable behemoth in comparison to its contemporaries, boasting an expansive square footage that is approximately twice the magnitude of its competitors, thereby providing an impressive array of merchandise for perusal and purchase. Upon entering the premises, I was acknowledged by a staff member whose demeanor, while not exuding unbridled enthusiasm, remained courteous and welcoming. As I conducted my brief shopping excursion, I elected not to seek guidance or advice from the sales personnel, opting instead to independently select and procure a specific cosmetic item utilizing a discount coupon that I had obtained through my membership in the Sally Beauty Club loyalty program. During the checkout process, the cashier exhibited a cordial demeanor, thus culminating a satisfactory retail experience that will likely ensure my future patronage."

3.5 stars for cheap Jameson, somewhat decent food, and a fun patio.

Never thought I'd be a Yelp app regular at Gilley's, but lo and behold, there was my golden checkmark (of shame). I visited a while back with Dana S (the S is for Some Hot Bitch) where we got cheap Jame-O and loled at karaoke. 

Visited again recently for food and more drinks, and I was not disappointed (but then again, I was not paying). The nachos were alright--tasted like my beloved Taco John's  which is a pretty good compliment coming from me. The chicken strips were just that--frozen animal flesh fried in un-food batter and grease--but the vinegary mustardy sauce sold me. Also had a bite of the jalapeno grits which were the highlight of the meal.

Overall, not a terrible place, but not the best either. The Strip has so much more to offer but in a pinch, this place wasn't horrible.

"Consequently, my rating of this establishment would have been lower, had it not been for the presence of prominent figures, who graced the premises with their illustrious presence...It remains uncertain whether a dance floor existed within the confines of the venue, as its diminutive size rendered it nearly imperceptible; however, the musical offerings were passable, and the ambiance was conducive to relaxation. It is worth mentioning that during our visit on Valentine's weekend, ladies were accorded gratis admission, and champagne was provided compliments of the house. Our intention to depart at midnight, motivated by the uninspiring nature of the music, was abruptly reversed upon the arrival of LMFAO, whose electrifying performance rendered the remainder of the evening thoroughly enjoyable. My associates have also frequented this club on previous occasions, specifically last year, when they had the privilege of encountering Far East Movement, thus it is advisable to exercise judicious selection when choosing the date of your visit."

"If you possess a predilection for partially clothed, stunning wait staff and an affinity for alcoholic beverages, you may find this establishment conducive to an enjoyable nocturnal experience. However, if you prioritize superior culinary offerings and exceptional customer service, it would be advisable to seek alternative dining options. Notwithstanding the possibility of receiving an incorrect bill at your table on multiple occasions and experiencing inconsistencies in both beverage and food quality, one must acknowledge that such shortcomings are of little consequence in the grand scheme. After all, the beer is adequately chilled, and the female staff members are undeniably attractive, rendering any additional aspects of the dining experience somewhat irrelevant."

"When it comes to selecting an optimal venue for a midday meal, Jimmy John's undoubtedly ranks as a premier choice, offering the convenience of both delivery and takeout options. Furthermore, their menu boasts an array of delectable subs, which can be further customized by opting for a nutritious nine-grain bread alternative to the traditional white roll. Specifically, the Beach Club sub, featuring turkey breast, provolone cheese, tomato, lettuce, and guacamole, constitutes a personal favorite, with the latter ingredient being a particularly noteworthy aspect. In addition, vegetarians will find solace in the Veggie sub, which showcases a medley of fresh sprouts, cheese, tomato, cucumber, and, once again, guacamole. Lastly, those with a sweet tooth would be remiss not to sample one of their gargantuan cookies, especially the chocolate chip variety."

Always a good choice. Service is VERY slow but the corn chowder makes up for it. Good menu choices and staff seems to always be friendly. They also have good breads and muffins. Good place for any of the 3 meals.

I had the pleasure of partaking in a culinary excursion to Enso, in the company of a singular companion, on a recent luncheon outing. Upon perusing the menu, my eyes landed upon the ginger salad, which, much to my delight, proved to be a flavorsome and visually appealing dish, its ingredients expertly balanced to create a harmonious union of taste and aroma, reminiscent of those delectable offerings commonly associated with the traditional Japanese cuisine that the establishment purported to embody. However, my enthusiasm was somewhat tempered upon sampling the sushi, which, while aesthetically pleasing, failed to distinguish itself from the myriad alternatives available at numerous other eateries specializing in this particular genre of gastronomy. Happily, the spider roll, with its judicious blend of flavors and textures, proved to be an unexpected highlight of our repast, its quality surpassing my expectations and providing a welcome respite from the relative mediocrity that had thus far defined our dining experience. Unfortunately, the ambiance of the restaurant left much to be desired, with an excessive emphasis on opulence and dim lighting that bordered on the excessive, creating an environment that struck me as contrived and lacking in authenticity, particularly given the fact that the proprietors themselves were not of Japanese extraction; furthermore, the cost of our meal, which amounted to a hundred dollars, exclusive of any alcoholic beverages, seemed decidedly steep in relation to the quality of the fare provided, leading me to question the overall value proposition offered by this particular dining establishment, particularly when compared to such competitors as the New Zealand Cafe, where one might obtain comparable, if not superior, culinary delights at a fraction of the cost.

First off, I love their sandwiches. I always get the Turkey, ranch and bacon. But, I cannot stand the new Coke machine all these places are getting. Every drink comes out tasting like it has lime juice in it. What's up with that? Even if I let it run for a few seconds it is nasty. I cannot eat there because of this reason. Too bad because the sandwiches and staff rock! I guess it's take out or nothing.

We entered the establishment with the expectation of capitalizing on one of the most optimal rooftop settings within the city limits, only to be informed that while we could indeed consume food and beverages upstairs, we would be responsible for tidying up after ourselves and procuring any necessary items independently.  Such an underutilization of exceptional terrain! 
The hospitality we received was adequate.  Our server was quite personable, though perhaps a tad distracted.  She delivered two beverages of the alcoholic variety to my spouse and me, despite the fact that we had only placed an order for a single drink. 
The culinary offerings were unremarkable.  While not utterly deplorable, they failed to impress us to the extent that we would actively seek them out.  We sampled the pork queso dip, which, while lacking the fiery zest we customarily associate with queso, was undeniably palatable.  I would certainly consider ordering it again in the future.  My spouse opted for the Cuban sandwich.  Following the waitress's recommendation, he attempted to consume it with both lettuce and tomato, but unfortunately, these additional elements overpowered the inherent flavors of the BBQ, rendering it somewhat unpalatable.  Upon removing the produce from the sandwich, the BBQ itself proved to be fairly satisfying.  My better half relished the flavor of the meat, but, much like the rest of the dish, it did not particularly stand out. 
While this eatery will not be incorporated into our regular dining rotation, I would not object if others wished to frequent it.

I live down the street from this WH so my circle of friends often finds ourselves here after a night of debauchery. It's really nothing special, trucker food at it's best, but the staff is really nice and there's something about it that makes my hangovers feel better.

What I liked about this place was that it looks like you have landed on Mars. Just check out some of the rock formations outside. What I do not like about this place is that it is in Arizona. Enough said.

I am really torn about this review.  Our server was fantastic and we really enjoyed the food and drink, but two of our group members ended up with food poisoning (we think that it was the mussels) after our meal.  We opted to do a mix of plates including their jumbo lump crab cake, braised short ribs pierogies, arancinis. potato gnocchi & lobster, and the mussels.  Overall, during the meal - I enjoyed all of the food with my favorite being the lobster gnocchi and the arancinis were a bit bitter from the port wine.  \n\nWe also tried a smattering of their drinks from the Braddock's smash to the moscow mule and prohibition pear martini.  They also have a make your own manhattan option.  For a hotel restaurant, this was a really great option inside of The Renaissance which is eclectically upscale.  If it wasn't for the food poisoning, this review would be four stars.

This is quite an inconspicuous wee bar at the bottom of Howe Street, but it's pretty popular with New Town and Stockbridge locals, and actually surprisingly larger than it looks when you get inside. 

The interior of The Standard is smart and plushly furnished, so it's a pretty comfortable place to sit and have a beer, or a nice Sauvignon, or whatever your poison may be. The bar has a good feel about it, so you can sit for quite a while and banter away without actually feeling you're really in a bar environment (apart from the fact you're glugging down alcohol). 

The menu is decent too and inexpensive, so if you're in the mood for proper pub food, like a big helping of burger and chips, or a full breakfast to soak up the hangover, The Standard is a good call. I am automatically biased against anywhere that blares out sport at high volume levels, but I know half the world love watching a good sports match/game on decent screens, so I would recommend The Standard for such activities, and it gets very, very busy around rugby match season.

I visit Chili's with family and friends about two times per month. We usually go to the the one at Bell and 7th St. or 27th Ave and 101. The food for the most part is at least average to above average. The chips and salsa are a good deal and the green chile and enchilada soups are great. The food is pleasingly the same at each Chili's we visit. However, there seems to be an ongoing kink in the service at the one on North Valley Parkway. When they first opened a while back, we tried them twice because they are close to home. Both times, the orders were messed up and the waitresses were friendly but not very knowledgeable about the menu. The food took forever to arrive and no hint of an apology anywhere. A few months later we decide to try again. maybe they were just new and by now they have the kinks out. Again, the wait time for our food was incredible and getting a drink refill was just wishful thinking.  \nFast forward over a year. Last Saturday-Nice waitress, seemingly nice greeters, food was as expected. Over 90 minutes for soup and salad and water to drink. Four times with the same problem is probably not coincidence. The Chilis on 7th St always has the exact opposite. Great service and normal wait time. Hope it changes, it is a decent place to go.

A delectable smorgasbord of regional culinary delights, this local buffet boasts an impressive array of fresh seafood, including sashimi of exceptional quality, notably the succulent salmon. The traditional Chinese dishes are expertly prepared and presented in generous portions, ensuring a satisfying experience for gastronomes who relish the rich flavors of the Far East. The crab legs, in particular, are a highlight, with their tender flesh and subtle nuances of flavor. However, the spring rolls fail to impress, lacking the delicate touch and finesse that distinguish the establishment's other offerings. Dumplings, too, could benefit from greater attention to detail in their preparation. Notwithstanding these minor shortcomings, a visit to this buffet is highly recommended, particularly for those who appreciate the diverse and intricate flavors of Chinese cuisine. Moreover, it is imperative to note that a careful perusal of the sign positioned on each table is essential prior to partaking in the bountiful spread, lest one incur an additional fee of $8 due to excessive consumption and waste.

French press coffee tasted like water, with leftover grounds in it. One thing you expect from a breakfast place is good coffee, if not great. The coffee I got, at least, was terrible.\n\nAnd you would think place called \"Morning Squeeze\" would have fresh squeezed or blended juices; this place does not. Hopefully, they'll make some tweaks and get themselves up a notch or two. The place has a good vibe.

this place has some serious potentional. the tv's are set up perfect including in the bathrooms. i would definitely give this place 5 stars if they had higher quality food and more selection of beers on tap and liquors. i've tried getting crown royal cask no 16, jack daniels honey, kracken, captain morgan private stock, jack daniels single barrel but they don't any of them. half moon hello!!!! not everyone wants to drink bottom shelf or bottom of the barrel liquor. please fix these 2 problem so i can give another review and it be 5-stars

"Culinary offerings exhibit inconsistent quality, with a considerable decline in edibility during the afternoon hours, characterized by excessive saltiness in french fries and an absence of flavor in meat dishes, whereas the nocturnal fare boasts remarkable improvement, rendering sandwiches delectable and occasionally showcasing pitiful barbecue ribs, all the while remaining bereft of potent potables, thereby precluding commentary regarding the bar, leaving solely the grill subject to evaluation."

During my independent travels in Arizona, I felt compelled to indulge in regional delicacies that accurately represented the area's indigenous population, rather than simply consuming generic tourist fare. In pursuit of this goal, I made a point to visit establishments renowned for their authentic preparation of Native American cuisine. My maiden venture to The Fry Bread House provided me with an opportunity to sample the cultural essence of the region through their delectable offerings. The bold flavors present in their dishes were undoubtedly a pleasant surprise, as they deviated from the monotony of standard fast food fare. The aromatic flatbread, freshly prepared upon order, proved to be particularly satisfying. Although I cannot offer recommendations with certainty, given my limited exposure to their menu, I can confidently assert that their flatbread is indeed palatable.

The enigmatic disparity between the two Bruegger's locations is nothing short of remarkable, with the staff at this particular establishment exhibiting a conspicuously elevated level of enthusiasm and efficiency in their work, which is palpably discernible in the manner in which they expeditiously attend to customers' orders; furthermore, this location boasts an array of de rigueur items such as bagels, sandwiches, soups, coffee, and tea, all of which are presented in a welcoming ambiance characterized by comfortable booth seating situated alongside an exterior window, thereby providing patrons with an optimal setting in which to enjoy their culinary indulgences.

"The ambiance is thoroughly enjoyable, the tariffs are reasonable, the wine-a-ritas offer a distinctive and flavorful experience, albeit slightly subpar, while the locally procured vintages possess a certain je ne sais quoi, yet lack the robust qualities that I typically associate with California wines, although they are still palatable, if somewhat overpriced; I would have been inclined to purchase the pinot grigio had it been more affordably priced, but I shall certainly return and take advantage of the exceptional value offered by the flight selection, which allows one to sample six diverse varieties for a mere $6, an absolute bargain."

"This eatery specializing in sushi manifests an overall quality that can be classified as ranging from mediocre to slightly above average, with a physical bar area that exudes a sense of elegance while simultaneously possessing limited seating capacity, a characteristic commonly observed in establishments of this culinary genre. The sushi served within this establishment is of a quality that, while palatable, lacks any truly distinctive or remarkable attributes, positioning it on a parallel plane with respect to Ra, but ultimately falling short of the exceptional standards set by Sakana, thereby prompting me to engage in a deliberate and thorough assessment before finally determining a rating of three stars, as the experience, though satisfying, proved to be merely average."
Great wings but sad to say they are now closed - looking at the past reviews of slow service, that might have been the reason why.

"Adequate pizza, albeit with some reservations regarding the texture of the wings, which seemed slightly desiccated, yet attributable to an isolated production mishap, rather than a systemic flaw. The sauce, however, demonstrated a satisfactory level of flavor and richness, although it failed to fully satiate my yearning for an authentic New York-style pizza experience in Pittsburgh."

Food was great as usual.  Love the new building.  However, the chairs are probably the most uncomfortable chairs I've ever sat in and the music was way too loud.  I don't like shouting at my dinner companions to be heard.  Get better chairs and turn it down during dinner time, please.  If it's going to remain that loud, I'll just get my food to go.

It is gratifying to discover a dining establishment in the upscale district that prioritizes authentic wellness rather than resorting to ambiguous menu descriptions and outdated health information, as many others tend to do.  This particular venue leaves me thoroughly impressed with its unwavering dedication to utilizing healthy and natural ingredients.  While I find the cuisine to be quite satisfactory, and the variety of menu items sufficient for a weekly visit, I do take issue with the pricing, specifically pertaining to morning meals.  The cost of a breakfast sandwich appears excessive considering the actual value received, with a price tag of $5 hardly justified by the presentation of a two-hour-old poached egg carelessly placed upon a stale wrap, accompanied by a paltry portion of turkey bacon, and passed off as an adequate breakfast.  Nonetheless, the luncheon offerings prove truly exceptional, providing a substantial return on investment, particularly when consumed on the premises, as complementary froyo and tea refills enhance the dining experience.  Based on my encounters, the fare consistently exhibits freshness, healthiness, and delectability, leaving me moderately satiated subsequent to consumption.  Assigning a rating of two stars for breakfast and four stars for lunch, respectively, yields an overall rating of three.

First off, I am not a 20-something who regularly hangs out in Old Town.  But, I have lived in Phx for 30+ years and have been to most upper-level eating establishments around town.  We went with friends for Restaurant Week.  We will not be heading back any time soon.  Service was very attentive.  The ambiance has been overstated by many other reviewers - it's got a little bit of kitsch, but in the end, the tables are extremely close to each other and the noise level is on the high end.  It is definitely not an intimate dining experience.  The food was very good, but not home run material.  The entree of venison that I ordered was served raw on the inside.  I'm not talking a little bit on the rare side, it was sashimi raw.  Having not been asked how I would like my meat prepared, I assumed it would be cooked.  I'm a medium-well kinda guy, but my dining partner likes her meat medium rare and she sent hers back to be cooked.  We ordered a dessert of foie gras and donuts, and it was just weird.  All 4 of us tried it, but none of us liked it.  You must really have to like foie gras to enjoy this dessert.  We are not really cocktail kinda people, but they did look tempting.  The regular menu looks like it is probably over-priced for the serving sizes that we got during Restaurant Week, but it was worth trying once.

We recently had the privilege of dining at Vogue, a culinary establishment that has been highly recommended by various sources, and thus, our expectations were suitably elevated. Upon perusing the menu, we elected to sample the meatloaf and lasagna, respectively, as our primary courses, and decided to share the calamari fritta appetizer, primarily due to its intriguing combination of flavors and textures. Our initial impression of the entrees was overwhelmingly positive, as both dishes demonstrated an unwavering commitment to quality and presentation, making them undoubtedly worth the expense. However, our enthusiasm was momentarily curtailed when we sampled the calamari fritta, which, unfortunately, did not live up to our expectations. Despite the novel incorporation of ginger amidst the julienned carrots, the overall execution of the dish seemed somewhat lacking, with the tempura-fried calamari pieces being sparse and somewhat lost amidst the abundance of vegetation. Notwithstanding this minor setback, we generally enjoyed our dining experience, albeit with a few reservations regarding the service, which, although polite and relatively prompt, seemed somewhat detached and unengaging, leaving us with a lingering sense of indifference.

after 1 visit

ambience B+ loved the decor, however, the lighting was quite dark. it was hard to see anything. 

service B+ i would have given pin kaow an A, however, they over-killed on the table touches. i think we had 5 people check on us in the matter of 5 minutes. 

food B+ i enjoyed the dishes, but it didn't make me say, "wow, this is REALLY good."

chicken satay
the chicken was grilled perfectly. the peanut sauce (most likely an authentic sauce), fell a little flat on my palate.

tom ka koong
lemon grass soup with coconut milk, galanga root, mushroom, and shrimp
great in small doses. i could only eat one small bowl, because it was a rich and slightly sour broth. the sourness wore on me at the end of one bowl. that same sourness is why so many people love this soup. it's just not for my palate.

roasted rice beef
beef, cabbage, roasted rice, thai basil and spices
roasted rice is a new concept for me. basically, it is crushed rice that has been roasted and scattered on the beef. interesting texture and a great experience. but not my favorite dish. 

chicken yellow curry
delicious.

overall: B+
hope to be able to visit this place again. sample some other dishes i've never sampled before.

"It is utterly vexing when a local establishment fails to meet expectations, particularly when it falls short of the quintessential general store experience offered by the likes of Mast Drug or Renfrow in Matthews. While Monroe Hardware may possess some charm, it falls short of embodying the essence of a traditional general store, and yet it does not boast the extensive resources of a behemoth like Home Depot or Lowe's. Rather, it occupies a nebulous middle ground that proves problematic in terms of creating an optimal customer experience. My exposure to Monroe Hardware has been limited to the Mint Hill location, and it is conceivable that the vast expanse of the store (formerly a Winn Dixie, I believe) contributes to the sense of emptiness and lack of personalized attention. If the space were halved, the atmosphere would likely become more inviting and intimate, thereby enhancing the overall shopping experience. Presently, the sprawling layout necessitates a greater dispersal of staff, leading to periods where customers may feel neglected. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the proximity of Monroe Hardware to my domicile renders it a convenient option for casual excursions. However, when undertaking more elaborate projects, I tend to favor the comprehensive resources and expertise available at Home Depot or Lowe's, which I encounter during my various errands."

This Dillard's has metamorphosed into a mere outlet center, with the entire lower level lying dormant and uninhabited. The upper level has transmogrified into a terminus for last season's, damaged, and irregularly sized designer attire, eliciting a sense of familiarity with Ross, albeit sans the plethora of inferior brands and foul-smelling changing areas.

The minimum reduction observed was a substantial 40% discount, while the majority of racks flaunted a 50% price decrease, and a select few were adorned with a remarkable 75% markdown. Furthermore, the assortment was methodically categorized by size, facilitating a seamless shopping experience.

Prominent designers were responsible for the majority of the merchandise, including a stylish Michael Kors top that originally retailed for approximately $50 but was acquired for a mere $18, exemplifying a substantial savings.

Garments constituted the primary focus, complemented by a medley of bedding, accessories, and footwear. However, the selection of shoes proved to be underwhelming, catering only to diminutive feet, colossal sasquatch feet, or those enamored with flamboyant styles, leaving the rest in a state of dismay.

Well, I think I established rather quickly that I am not the Vegas kind of gal.  I went with a friend who has connections, so we skipped the line and cover.  I wasn't wearing heels because I have a pinched nerve in my back, and the bouncer almost didn't let me in (I was wearing cute flats).\n\nFor such a \"great view\" of the strip, I expected more- or for it to be at least be a bit higher.  It was just like-- oh hai! bright lights!  The dance floor was so packed you could barely move, and drinks were very expensive ($8/bottle of bug light).  Basically you're going to have people you don't know touching you at all times unless you pony up for a table.  Should you choose to go, do your wallet a favor and buy a few bottles of liquor at the CVS just north of the circus (~13 for smirnoff) and have a damn good buzz going before you get there.

"In terms of reliability, Bravo excels in offering a consistent dining experience, particularly with regards to their salads, which are invariably fresh and flavorful. The availability of reservations is an added convenience, allowing patrons to circumvent protracted queues and waiting times of up to three-quarters of an hour. Among the menu items, the Romano crusted chicken salad and balsamic chicken salad are standouts, with the latter being particularly noteworthy for its judicious use of Parmesan dressing, which has prompted this writer to attempt replicating it in a domestic setting. While the entrees may be somewhat heavy-handed with regard to sodium content, the salads remain a compelling reason to visit Bravo, especially when combined with other activities such as shopping at the adjacent Waterfront or taking in a film. Furthermore, the ample parking facilities ensure that patrons can access the establishment with ease, a factor that cannot be overstated given the frequency with which parking can pose a challenge in busy commercial areas."

"Black bean taco, priced at an economical two dollars, boasted flavors that surpassed the culinary experience offered by any burrito sampled within the confines of Manhattan subsequent to my relocation thereto, although it failed to measure up to the gastronomic standards set by certain esteemed establishments within the Phoenix metropolitan area. Prior to the commencement of the monthly art festival known as First Fridays, we had the pleasure of partaking in this delectable dish on the picturesque patio, which was illuminated by the evening light, thereby creating an ambiance conducive to conviviality. Furthermore, our server engaged us in a most agreeable conversation, the subject matter of which revolved around the popular television program Shark Week, thereby further enhancing the overall dining experience."

"Concurring with Jamie C.'s sentiment, I shall defer my definitive verdict until a subsequent visit, during which I aspire to demonstrate my gratitude towards our exceptional serverâwhose name, unfortunately, escaped my attentionâby acknowledging his meritorious service. Our culinary excursion began with two glasses of sangria, which I thoroughly relished, while Michael's initial skepticism towards his mojito eventually gave way to satisfaction upon switching to Stella. We opted to share the calamari and a blue corn chicken enchilada, both of which elicited unwavering approbation from us due to their gastronomical excellence. Notably, the accompanying sauces complemented the dishes perfectly, leaving us eager to sample more of their offerings in the future."

We've heard and seen on the Food Network great things about Bouchon and certainly was not disappointed with the service. The dining hall is elegant and proper. Brunch was good, but not blow- your- mind great. We tried the Salmon Baguette, a take on salmon and smear on a bagel only for $15, but this is to be expected. Nevertheless, it was good. We also had the Bouchon French Toast which is done in a bread pudding- like style. It shouldn't be be called French toast because it does not resemble anything like it. It really should be called bread pudding. It was more like dessert-- too sweet to be had as a brunch meal.

"Ah, the quaint charm of Kamakura, how it has captivated my family's taste buds for an array of years, emerging as a culinary sanctuary of sorts! My father, a gourmet visionary, introduced us to this haven when it first sprouted onto the gastronomic scene, as sushi was merely a nascent delight, savored by a select few. We revisited intermittently, reserved for momentous occasions (my senior prom ensemble graced its presence here), given its elevated pricing relative to our modest standards at the time. Presently, I make it a point to partake in their delectable Teppan offerings during my visits, yet I cannot help but sense a subtle metamorphosis in the wait staff's enthusiasm. Or perhaps, my perception has matured, mirroring the evolution of my palate. Despite this, Kamakura maintains a sturdy foothold, boasting an impressive record, particularly amidst the unforgiving culinary landscape of Los Angeles, where I currently reside. In fact, I would venture to assert that this esteemed establishment would comfortably secure a respectable 3.5-star rating, a testament to its enduring appeal and the region's discerning epicurean inclinations."

A very cute gift shop, with adorable and quirky gift ideas. 
However, as Emily T pointed out the price tags are quite high when you start considering the actual item on sale. 

Still Miam Miam can be a saver when you are stuck on a present for someone that's a bit more unique but not too crazy. When I came in here it was empty (coincidence or economic crisis effect?) but the staff are super friendly and I got a great card for my friends graduation.

I got the Gold Standard, he got the Longhorn. They were pricey dogs with minimal toppings. These are no Buldogis dogs...look it up and go there now and get one! You won't regret it. \nThey were edible and satisfied our hunger but I wouldn't go any further. Las Vegas Pinks is below them, so they have something going for them. Staff was helpful and pleasant. We expected high prices...it's the strip.  I say skip it unless your a hot dog fiend.

RESULT: The parent company, Frias, effectively addressed my concern by dedicating sufficient time to investigate and locate the specific taxi and driver in question, utilizing our credit card information. Their thorough approach and diligence in the follow-up process were impressive, although the severity of the driver's consequences remains unknown. Despite the uncertainty, I would still consider using Ace Cab in the future, but I will certainly exercise greater vigilance to ensure that all personal belongings are retrieved before exiting the vehicle. 
  EDITED: Below is my initial post. One day after posting, I received communication from the parent company, and they are actively examining the situation. I appreciate their efforts and will update everyone on any progress made. 
  ORIGINAL POST: The driver displayed both rudeness and dishonesty! We discovered that our iPad was missing and, subsequently, left a message on the taxi company's lost and found number without receiving any response. However, we received a call from an individual who acquired the iPad from the taxi driver, raising suspicions of a potential scam. Regardless of the circumstances, the driver failed to return the iPad, and the company showed indifference towards my concerns by neglecting to follow up. Considering that Ace is merely one of numerous cab companies operated by a single parent company, I will deliberately avoid them all if this is how they conduct their business practices. At the very least, I expect them to demonstrate a pretense of concern and follow through on their responsibilities. While it may be challenging to monitor every driver, a mere show of effort in customer care would suffice.

TIP:  use their free wifi here (very spotty though)\n\ni only fly southwest here at McCarran, and the layout is very disjointed.  I can't say for other airlines but southwest has two areas with available gates.  So if you went to the wrong gate (or wanted to visit a friend from the other gate) , and that gate happens to be on the side, you have to pretty much run to the other side of the airport.  Also, the rental car center have to be shuttled (wastes time).  There is also one rental car company that is not even in the rental center (i think it's fox).  Do not rent from them!! they are far away, which is a waste of time.  Rentals in LV are cheap anyways.

We indulged in a culinary excursion at this esteemed establishment during the previous week, predicated upon an array of laudatory assessments. Although our gastronomical expectations were not entirely fulfilled, our repast did boast certain notable highlights. Specifically, we sampled their duck, steak, and salmon offerings, with the duck proving to be the most satisfying, while the steak fell somewhat short of our expectations. However, the cheese plate appetizer preceding our main courses elicited unanimous praise from our party. Furthermore, the hospitality we received throughout the evening was quite commendable. Notwithstanding some minor shortcomings, we shall afford this venue an additional opportunity to demonstrate its full potential prior to rendering a definitive verdict.

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are of satisfactory quality, albeit at a somewhat elevated cost. Specifically, the roasted duck appetizer did not meet expectations, possessing a lack of succulence in the meat and an absence of crispiness in the skin. However, the sweet and sour pork dish was quite delectable, and the coconut rice was truly exceptional, eliciting a desire to consume it on a daily basis. Notwithstanding, the total cost, inclusive of gratuity, exceeded our budgetary constraints by a considerable margin. We shall return to sample the coconut rice in conjunction with the satay, and will provide an updated assessment at that juncture."

"I placed an order for brisket accompanied by nacho fries, in conjunction with an outlaw burger. However, my cousin, who placed his order subsequent to mine, received his meal prior to mine, despite the fact that I had ordered before him. Furthermore, I noticed a patron who had placed his order after mine, and yet, he received the identical burger before my order was served. Upon inquiring about the delay in receiving my meal, the server responded nonchalantly, implying that my order was forthcoming. Following a ten-minute interval, my fries were brought out, devoid of the burger. The server assured me that it would be delivered shortly. After an additional ten minutes had elapsed, I finally received my burger. Unfortunately, the prolonged wait made it challenging to fully appreciate my dining experience. Notwithstanding, the fries were quite satisfying, and the burger was equally impressive. The prices charged for the cuisine were reasonable. Had it not been for the blunder in handling my order and the server's attempt to downplay the error, I would have awarded four stars. Despite these issues, I would still consider returning and hoping for improved service in the future."

I pretty much come here with large parties (the tables allow for huge groups) or when I just can't make my mind up on what I feel like eating because this place has a little bit of everything. 

I've tried quite a few different things on the menu and it has all been pretty good. Nothing spectacular, but not disappointing either. The Chicken Madeira and the Farfalle w/ Chicken and Roasted Garlic (tell them to hold some of the garlic) are among my favorites.

And the cheesecake is always good. Lots of different varieties. Snickers, turtle, tuxedo, strawberry, etc. They are all good. But I've never met a piece of cheesecake I didn't devour.

"Underwhelmed by the culinary offerings and subpar service at Davio, my dining experience was akin to consuming a meal at a fast-food establishment, specifically Eat 'N Park. While the edibles were passable, they failed to meet the standards of comparable eateries. Furthermore, the server's lack of knowledge regarding the menu and inability to respond to queries regarding it effectively rendered the dining encounter even more unsatisfactory. In light of these factors, it is advisable to allocate additional funds and opt for either Arlecchino or Alla Familia for a superior gastronomic adventure."

Visited 5/8/12...

Came across this location in travel while looking for a something a little different for lunch.  I think this is pretty new. 

It is located on same building as gas station at Northeast corner of Southern and Higley. 

I only wanted something simple. Ordered Gyro and Fries.  Did it as take out. At 12:15 p.m. there was only one other person there eating.  Not sure if that says something or maybe they just have not been discovered yet. 

It tasted good. However, I have had a better at some other locations.  I was disappointed in portion.  Three pieces meat, two slices tomato.  For a quick lunch it was satisfying.

I looked at menu and saw some interesting items on menu.  Might be interested in trying these at some point later. 

It is a nice option to other fast food.  Not a place that I would go out of my way for, at least at point.  But would definitely return for a Gyro if in the area. 

Will try back again in a month or so and see if they are still up and running.  Difficult location and visibility from street..

I stayed three nights in Paris. I requested a room with King bed. They gave me room with two queen beds. Next day, there was availability and they moved me to a room with King bed. Queen size bed was very uncomfortable. King size was not bad. Rooms were very clean. Bathrooms were clean, wide, functional. Check in was fast, although there was a big line. What I really liked about bathrooms were they had closed cabin shower and a separate bath tub. TV was basic, some good channels. It was very quite, had no noise problem. Hotel location is awesome, at the center of everywhere. Elevators worked really fast. My view was back, looked towards airport. I also used their spa company, wrote separate review for it. Paris has good restaurants inside. I also recommend going top of Eiffel Tower, view was spectacular. Monorail metro is also very close, you do not need to leave hotel to get to metro, very convenient. My only problem was that they did not let me use spa the day I checked out, which was disappointing. Overall good place to stay.

Distrito is pretty good, but not memorable.   It  lacks the energy you would expect given all the hype.   Plus the decor was underwhelming.   Too dark and lounge-like.  Boring really.

We started with guac and chips and salsa.   Chips were way over salted, almost inedible.  But I did eat them, found myself brushing off the loads of salt with my fingers.  Guac and salsa were good.  Then we moved on to veggie tacos which were nice and a kind of mexican flatbread with mushrooms and a huitlacoche sauce.   Also good.  The rice with corn, cream and habeneros, a kind of Mexican risotto could have been good if it weren't so over salted.  

Distrito offers a nice variety of margaritas.  We tried the watermelon- cucumber and the cilanto and both were good.

We had heard that the service can be a nightmare, but we received good, if bland, service.  

So Distrito was an OK choice for us, but we are not pining to return.

"Although the culinary offerings of this establishment possess an undeniable appeal, the limitations imposed by their payment policies and the absence of complimentary refreshment refills serve as a deterrent to my frequent patronage."

I have had the pleasure of visiting Aunt Chilada's on multiple occasions during my time in Arizona, and while each experience has been relatively uneventful, there was one particular visit that stands out as particularly memorable. It was an evening when one of my companions and I decided to engage in a playful activity, inspired by the iconic Disney character, Ariel, from The Little Mermaid, where we used plastic forks to groom our hair before entering the establishment. Furthermore, I recall that shortly after making a humorous observation regarding individuals from rural areas, we felt compelled to utilize the aforementioned utensils to tidy up our coiffures. The motivation behind this behavior remains unclear, but it seemed amusing at the time. Moving on, the culinary offerings at Aunt Chilada's have never been exceptional or remarkably poor; they are perhaps adequate enough to warrant a visit if one is in close proximity and desires to partake in a leisurely meal accompanied by refreshing margaritas on the outdoor seating area. In conclusion, while not outstanding, the eatery does not necessarily warrant avoidance, and thus, I shall confer an additional star in recognition of its mediocrity.

We sampled several items on the menu.  The pork sliders were great, the mushroom  burger was great --- and cooked to a perfect medium rare as ordered.  The fries were also quite good with a perfect crunch.  We did not really like the mashed potatoes because the potatoes tasted old.  The biggest disappointment was the buttermilk fried chicken.  Though it was fried to perfection and crispy, it had no flavor--completely devoid of flavor.  If celebrity chef Aaron Sanchez really did create their menu/recipes, he forgot to taste the one he provided for the fried chicken, as no salt was included in this recipe.  Unless the staff forgot it....

"Ambivalently, I ponder the prospect of evaluating this culinary establishment, as my patronage has been consistent over the years, yielding a dichotomy of satisfaction; initially, the dining experience was enjoyable, but recent visits have elicited a sense of mediocrity. It is noteworthy that the staff, despite their proficiency in their roles, have adopted an affected, stereotypical Italian demeanor, which, while well-intentioned, comes across as contrived and insincere. Furthermore, the linguistic execution of the waitstaff and busboys, who hail from Eastern Europe, often results in a butchered rendition of the Italian language, detracting from the authentic ambiance attempted by the restaurant. My gastronomical exploration of the menu has been extensive, with the veal osso buco emerging as a standout dish; however, the quality of the remaining options can be described as unremarkable and comparable to that of a ubiquitous chain restaurant. Nonetheless, the alfresco seating area, with its delightful environs, may mitigate any disappointment arising from the cuisine's shortcomings, rendering the dining experience, on balance, worthwhile. While not exceptional, this eatery merits a visit, particularly for those without access to superior Italian fare in their locales."

"On certain occasions, I have an inclination towards consuming a well-prepared gourmet meal, while on other days, my preference veers towards indulging in a lavish spread at a buffet. Our companions opted for Bouchon for brunch due to our collective yearning for the former experience. 

I sampled a small portion of the sourdough waffles accompanied by fresh strawberries and vanilla bean butter, which yielded a flavor profile reminiscent of a crispy waffle. The inclusion of vanilla bean butter added a welcome subtlety to the dish. 

The vanilla bean yogurt complemented by an ample serving of granola was indeed palatable, although the generous helping of granola rendered the combination somewhat overwhelming for my taste buds. Nonetheless, the granola served to counterbalance the richness of the yogurt. 

The Cobb salad, albeit unphotographed, proved underwhelming. The dish consisted of limp iceberg lettuce, sparse pieces of chicken, and an undersized portion, all for a price point of $17. 

Bouchon serves as a suitable venue for individuals seeking to consume a substantial meal prior to engaging in intense physical activity, such as dancing, later in the evening. The service was attentive, and our water glasses were consistently replenished. 

In terms of pricing, Bouchon's offerings, while satisfactory, do not justify the cost, particularly when considering the quality of the meal. For those seeking a more diverse array of options, Grand Luxe presents a preferable alternative. Individuals with a preference for health-conscious fare may find Bouchon's menu unsuitable, as each item tasted excessively rich and heavy."

I have been to tgi only twice so far. The first time I ordered the filled potato skin appetizer. The portion was big and It could have been great if it had a sauce or something but it was just way too dry. 

And the second time I ordered their Caribbean chicken sandwich with "Caribbean" sauce. The sauce was so disgusting I had to send the entire sandwich back. I couldn't even believe they seriously considered that sauce. So the sandwich was grilled chicken breast (very good) with tomatoes, avocados (still sounds good, right?) and then this sauce, which tasted like Christmas and pumpkin pie!??? It definitely had cinnamon and cloves in it... on a chicken avocado sandwich??? Like seriously? That is not Caribbean! Please if you are a staff from TGI Fridays and you are reading this, please take that sauce off of your menu, it is NOT good and my husband and mother in law who tried it, 100% agreed with me. Well, I sent back my food and ordered the turkey burger. It tasted not bad but I couldn't really enjoy it because everybody else was done eating and I felt stressed out. 

Positive was definitely the service though. Always friendly and professional. And they didn't charge me for the first order.

"Bar-B-Barn offers a convivial ambiance ideal for socializing with companions while partaking in delectable, affordable fare, particularly their scrumptious ribs and poultry. Although lacking a television, which precluded our ability to view a hockey match, the cozy, rustic atmosphere remained conducive to an enjoyable dining experience. The tender, flavorful meat of the ribs, complemented by a sweet and viscous sauce, proved particularly satisfying. Furthermore, the modest serving size of three ribs accompanied by fries sufficed in satiating my appetite."

I took my adorable wife here on a tapas date before a late showing at the Manor Theater across the street. 

We had some strong cocktails, including a delicious ginger cooler with so much real ginger! We shared a variety of tiny plates, little spring rolls and puffs of taro. The veggie offerings were all delicious, although there were not too many to chose from. Actually, I think that is a blessing in disguise because too many choices among delicious little tapas makes for some tough decision making. 

The atmosphere was elegant, the lighting was romantic, and the staff was attentive without being intrusive. We held hands over the table, and played footsie underneath, and ambled into the warm summer night satisfied with our food & drink. 

The prices are pretentious, like the presentation, but it's difficult to say it's not justified with the atmosphere & attention to detail. It's something I need to drop cash on like, once a year.

Our server had a hard time believing that our party was older than 21 (we are all 24 and 25, mind you) and gave us quite the run-around with checking IDs.

After that throwback to my freshman year of college, we put in an order for a few rolls. None of them really wowed us, sadly - Lava (a "special" roll that could have been a lot more special), Dragon (best of the batch), veggie (for the lone ranger who didn't eat meat, yet surprisingly good), and tempura shrimp (tasteless!).

The edamame was good, but how can you really mess that up?

The best part of the meal was the cheesecake for dessert which came with two sauces, raspberry and dark chocolate.

Probably a good date place, if you beat the crowds. And their servers are attractive, probably should mention that :-)

All in all there are much better sushi joints, I just know it.

"An exceptional venue offering remarkably affordable happy hour specials, complemented by spacious, immaculately maintained accommodations. However, it appears that an attempt is made to excessively surcharge, and a gratuity is requested, which raises questions regarding the propriety of such a practice."

"Although the ambiance was satisfactory, the menu options were limited and the prices were somewhat prohibitive; however, I may consider patronizing this establishment once more in the future. The server, while courteous, did not display an adequate level of attentiveness."

My better half and I had been cognizant of the acclaim surrounding Freddy's for quite some time, thus opting to partake in a culinary excursion to the establishment. Upon our arrival, the dining area was brimming with patrons, further piquing my expectations. I elected to sample their flagship offering, specifically the #1, comprising a double burger augmented with cheese. Alas, upon its presentation, I was dismayed by the meager proportions of the entree. It appeared that the beef patties were of a comparable dimension to those of cold cuts, thereby rendering the bread slices excessively dominant. Notwithstanding the palatable nature of the burger, my overall satisfaction was compromised by the conspicuous absence of meat. While Freddy's remains a viable option, my underwhelming experience precludes me from venturing out of my way to frequent the establishment in the future.

Beautiful view at North Show Terrace .... kind of makes the $16 margarita worth it.  

Kind of.  

Also, the misters are a great idea in theory when it's 106 outside, but they aren't so great when the water starts trickling off the umbrella and onto your head.

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are somewhat restricted, with a primary emphasis on noodles and dumplings, yet the prices remain reasonable and affordable for the budget-conscious patron. The ambiance is characteristic of fast food establishments, with an efficient service model that enables patrons to quickly procure their sustenance. This venue experiences high volumes of foot traffic during peak hours, attributed to both the palatable flavors and economic pricing. On a particularly frigid winter evening, I opted for a bowl of pork feet noodle soup, which proved to be an immensely satisfying and comforting choice, with the warm broth and springy noodles providing a welcome respite from the chill in the air. The portion size was adequate, neither excessive nor insufficient, and the service staff, despite their hectic workload, demonstrated a commendable commitment to ensuring a smooth and expedient dining experience for all patrons."

I'm a bit shocked that the reviews on this place are so high.  I do believe I am picky when it comes to comedy but I just was okay with this place and the show that was put on.  The seats are quite uncomfortable, old fashion, gold theater style seats.  The show is interactive which made it fun in some ways and bad in others.  (I wasn't familiar with things like World of Warcraft that were thrown out as suggestions from the audience.)\n\nI would say I was bored more often then laughing.  The skits were drawn out to much at times.  I don't think I will bother to go back.  It is nice that it is so kid friendly though.

Place is alright. The blizzards are really good, especially the Oreo one. I also love the French fries here. The service in the drive thru can be annoyingly slow sometimes but it's worth the wait when craving ice cream late at night.

Grabbed a cab and headed over to Del Friscos arriving to find a dated kinda worn feel to it. Not comparable to a classy Chicago Steakhouse but more of a casual comes as you are feel,  The martini was well prepared and the portion was nice.

I am one for aesthetics and the first one that grabbed me was that the salad fork is the same size as the dinner fork. Call me weird, but I like big man sized utensils  for $50 dollar steaks. 

Now about that crab appetizer.  Being from the wine country, I know I am spoiled but if a big hunk crab mixed with a monstrous amount of Old Bay is your thing, you have come to the right place.  I will eat crab served with cardboard I like it so much, but truly just so so.

Next was the Wedge salad with blue cheese. This dish can be great when done right but if the lettuce is wet and leaking, the dressing and everything else turns mushy and bland.

But, drums please, the steak shines.  There I was with my miniature fork drinking some great cab and enjoying the heck out of my tender flavorful steak with some pretty tasty corn, spinach and mashed potatoes. (Yes I did order three sides.)

So maybe skip everything else and have a steak.

Great bartender was very well versed in the wine offerings and made the night a fun one.

I was walking on the strip and thinking which club to visit. A Bank representative outside Bellagio was handing out \"free entrance\" wrist bands, so I decided to give a try. Turns out it's not free, you still need to pay $20 (reduced price I was told) but you get a free drink. Line was not too long so I was in within 5 minutes. Used coat-check but they charge $5 (better pay than not lose it). I went to bar straight and presented my free-drink coupon, bar tender told my options, I picked one, it was an okay drink. I enjoyed my drink while watching gogo dancers and other girls dancing and partying. GoGo dancers were okay, beautiful but they barely showed some good moves, beautiful though, an friendly because people got pic with them. Girls in the club were beautiful. Did not get chance to dance but enjoyed the music, it was mix dance music and speakers were just loud enough. dance floor looked decent size. They also have VIP area for private parties. I might repeat.

I've been to both Terminals in one day, and it's a nightmare sometimes.

Terminal 1: For all domestic flights. 

Parking:

Covered parking is nice in the parking garage.. but they removed the coin-meter parking, & I MISS IT!!
Well, at least we can pay with card now.

Cleanliness:

It's clean, sometimes. Not spotless, but hey, it's airport.

Service(s):

The information desk employees are friendly, and atleast they know what they're doing.

The signs for departure/arrival are pretty easy to read on nice LCD screens.

I wish there signs for where which escalator flights would be coming down from instead of asking attendants on the floor. 

If you can avoid it, don't schedule flights arrival/departure on Fridays & Weekends. The airport is packed.



Terminal 2: International flights & Hawaii.

The signs for Terminal 2 are easy to miss. 
I hope they can make it easier to access and find. Maybe even just a big TERMINAL 2 sign.

Parking:

No covered parking here, but the parking rates are the same as Terminal 1.

Cleanliness:

It's a mess in there. It looks dirty, and it feels dirty. If you have to stay long for any reason, remember to carry antibacterial.

Service(s):

There are only 4 carousels for luggage. This isn't bad in my opinion. It makes it easier to find your stuff if anything.

Keep an eye on your belongings, it feels pretty "ghetto" in Terminal 2.

While the meal I had was authentic and fresh (more onions than I'd like), I had to settle for the menu item because there are NO SUBSTITUTIONS. I am a diner who believes I should get exactly what I want when ordering at a restaurant because I'm using my hard earned money to pay for it. Romeos believes his dishes are created to absolute perfection and any deviation from this would ruin the taste of the dish. That is fine, but I didn't find perfection with the menu so I will probably not return for a meal. However, the desserts are delectable. Amazing selection. If I return it will be for dessert only.

I'm not really sure how to rate Kung Fu Tea, because it looks like a wonderful and hip boba addition to Vegas. However, our teas left a little to be desired. I think I would rate 3 stars for the actual drinks, 5 stars for the tea quality, and 5 stars for the service = 3.5 stars overall. 

We had the milk black tea and milk oolong tea. We chose 70% sugar, so it was not very sweet. I felt like that took away from being able to taste the flavor or the tea, because the drink tasted more diluted. I would definitely recommend just doing normal sugar, since their drinks are not too sweet. 

The tea leaves taste of high quality. Perhaps too high for us... the oolong is very woodsy and smoky, so you definitely have to really like oolong. The black tea has bergamot oil in it, so it tastes more floral. I thought it was nice, but my friend and bf thought it tasted soapy. My bf went back to the store and told them that he didn't like the taste, and they generously offered to make him something else. It was extremely nice that they were accommodating to personal preference. That alone will get me back to try some other teas next time I'm back in Vegas!

"Opting for an establishment that offers a delectable and revitalizing mid-day snack experience, I would highly recommend this particular venue. Their signature banana Nutella creation is a personal favorite of mine, boasting a perfect balance of flavors that avoids the pitfall of excessive sweetness.
