Additionally, their diverse array of smoothies, priced similarly to the Beaver Tails, presents a comparable value proposition, with the added benefit of incorporating genuine fruit ingredients rather than mere sugary additives."

I've been gunnin' for a Mongolian stir fry in the QC for a long, long time. I have great memories of heading to a similar style of restaurant when I was a wee girl. So, it wasn't too much of a surprise that I was jacked when I read that we now have a Genghis Grill in Charlotte! 

The Good: 
As others have said, you really make your own meal here. As in - if you don't love the components, well, it's your fault. There are a ton of topping options - proteins, starches, veggies, sauces, spices, etc. The instruction from the staff is definitely on point and helpful as you navigate the bowl bar. Overall, I liked my bowl and was able to make it super spicy with plenty of dragon sauce, jalapeno and red pepper. My mouth was on fuego. Plus, prices are pretty affordable at $8.99 for a lunch bowl and $9.99 for a dinner bowl. The kiddos will love this place. 

The Meh: 
It's a chainy chain, so I didn't really find much character in the restaurant. While the service was great, I really didn't have a desire to stay any longer than I needed to. Plus, the quality of the proteins was definitely lacking for me...the shrimp are incredibly tiny and quite a bit of my steak was a bit grisly. 

Would I head back to Genghis Gril? Surely. You have the opportunity to make a healthy meal that's quick and pretty affordable. It's absolutely A-OK in my book.

We came to phat phranks for some Mexican food, more like a 3.5 star restaurant. We ordered the huevos rancheros, breakfast burrito and some flautas. The huevos rancheros came with either red or green sauce, I picked green because it has pork in the sauce. The dish was really greasy for my taste, the beans, eggs and the fried chips were swimming in grease. It wasn't a traditional huevos rancheros. The fried potatoes were delicious And the dish was okay, just too greasy. The flautas were crispy and tasty with fresh guacamole. The service was good.\n\nI had to give it 3.5 stars due to the greasy meal and also, we were charged for tap water. I'm not sure if that is a Vegas thing, but it was a bit unusual for me to see that.

Played at this esteemed golfing venue on November 26th, 2005, and had the pleasure of experiencing a meticulously manicured course, with greens that presented a deliberate challenge to even the most skilled golfers by virtue of their sluggish pace. The visual splendor of the course was somewhat inconsistent, with certain holes offering breathtaking panoramas, while others were less aesthetically pleasing. Notwithstanding, the course presented a unique opportunity for female golfers, as the forward tees measured a mere 4400 yards, rendering it an accessible and enjoyable experience for those seeking a less daunting challenge. At a cost of $100, this course offered a reasonable value, although it failed to rival the excitement and difficulty posed by the nearby Wildfire course.

Visiting town from Colorado, my friend and I love Hawaiian restaurants. Moki's was good. Nice menu selection. Got the chicken katsu and short ribs. Pretty good. Ribs were a little tough, and the katsu sauce was t great. A little pricey also.

It's a hassle to get served if you don't have a reservation.  The bar area is packed and you really have to move fast to score a place to sit.\n\nThat being said, the swedish meatballs were excellent!

"An economical dining venue that offers palatable fare, albeit with some reservations regarding the seasoning of certain menu items. Specifically, the fiery poultry dish at Changs Spicy Chicken is quite satisfactory, while the savory broth of the Hot and Sour soup could benefit from a more judicious application of salt. The ambiance of the restaurant's interior, characterized by subdued illumination, aligns appropriately with the culinary offerings and overall aesthetic. The waiting staff exhibits a commendable level of cordiality, and the quality of service generally meets or exceeds expectations. A diverse array of beverages is available for patrons to select from."

First visit and I had a drip coffee and the tuna sandwich. Both were excellent. Sandwich though was borderline pricey @ $8.  Service was efficient and prompt. Ambiance was nothing special and had a very much starbucks feel. \n\nOverall impressions: not bad, not great

So let's start with 5 stars....well they lose a star just on service.   When I was there this afternoon there was only one other customer.   From the time I ordered to the time I received my food. ..15 minutes...a car pulled up behind me and eventually pulled over and the couple walked inside.  Another star lost due the food  being very heavy on the salt.   However on the plus side the man who took my order was very polite and made sure my order was correct and that I had all my extras condiments.   This place was first known via Food Network's Diners DriveIns and Dives....well this location is a dive. So that is factored in as well. Evidently they filmed at the Decatur St location.   My Pastrami Burger was as delicious as advertised.   The highlight however were the garlic fries.  Absolutely awesome!!  They are thin but moist and flavorful. .....Overall I will go back to try again but maybe try the other location.   It is also rather expensive but you do get a lot of food. ......

My biggest complaint is that the restaurant was FREEZING!!! I realize it's winter, but the AC was on inside. \nThe pico and guac were delicious! I also got the fish tacos which were great. The ceviche wasn't what we expected... Not bad though. \nI wouldn't go out of my way to come here to eat, but I would come back again.

As a gambling lover, I always love coming to vegas.  I've been to many casinos in northern california such as red hawk, cache creek, thunder valley, and even one in redding called win-river casino.  I have never been asked if I wanted a massage while playing cards until today at a pai gow table.  We had a full table and the player on the right of me accepted the massage offer from the worker, which then turned the player's chair around and put a giant cushion in front of him to relax on.  During the game, the massager was going all out on the player beside me.  After ten minutes, the massager told the player that it was $20 and if he wanted to continue for more.  Pretty sweet deal if you ask me.  

As far as their cocktail waitresses, they rarely ever came by to serve us drinks.  I'd say they came by once every 2 hours.  Overall, I'd go back for sure some day to gamble.

Three stars for being an average casino that was good, but nothing stood out from the hotel to me except for the massage therapist.

Loud
Cash only
Boobs
Loud
Get ready to stand a lot
Good, no, great music
Loud
Girls dance on bar
Bartenders are funny bitches
Loud

All in all, a pretty fun bar, but this lilly white blonde girl who likes color felt pretty uncomfortable around all the rough bikers dressed in black leather.  I felt judged.

I was merely traversing the thoroughfare en route to my lodging establishment when one of my acquaintances espied this edifice situated adjacent to the roadway, thereby prompting us to halt and partake in a culinary exploration of the premises; alas, I did not opt for the fried potato strips, much to my chagrin, as my companion opined that it was an unfortunate selection and yearned for the deep-fried courgette instead, which, I must admit, was quite delectable, indeed; furthermore, I had the agriculturalist's omelet, which was tantamount to a gastronomical masterpiece, and the hashed brown potatoes were equally impressive, leading me to overindulge and subsequently succumb to the soporific effects of the indulgence, ultimately surrendering to a state of deep relaxation, with the victuals being utterly scrumptious, nonetheless.

Cute spot. Good food.

The only thing I wanted from Eat was not available--the beignets!! Ugh. My heart was crushed to learn they didn't have any :( Alas, I opted for a chicken sandwich and it was good; nothing too special. The service was okay and given how small the menu is, I expect the staff to know the ingredients of the menu items which wasn't the case.

Would I return? Only If I happened to be in the area but wouldn't be my first choice.

if you're into heavy, rich food, Cowboy Ciao is your place.  i wasn't thoroughly impressed with the food, but the service is good.  very welcoming hostess, if i do say so myself.\n\nhonestly, i'd rather walk around the corner to fnb - it's way better.

This is one of the many MGM-Mirage properties on the strip.  The casino and hotel staff are all welcoming and friendly.   The casino floor and selection of shops and eateries is  decent and complete.\n\nThe casino floor and shops are all looking very nice with the New York theme design and  layout (Obviously very well maintained). The hotel rooms, however, are starting to look a little dated and might be due for updating (My room had a tube TV, which seems like a ancient relic now in 2009 - especially for a large, reputable, mid-strip property).

"The female individual stationed at the forefront of the establishment exhibited a profound lack of courtesy and respect towards us, leaving me in a state of considerable perturbation. Despite having placed an order for seven separate batches of dumplings to be taken away (amounting to a total of seventy individual dumplings), we were provided with only fifty, with the expectation that we would fail to notice the discrepancy. Furthermore, the manner in which the dumplings were handed over to us was utterly unacceptable, as the container was leaking copiously and the woman in question bestowed upon us a most disagreeable facial expression and audible gesture of disdain when requested to furnish us with an additional receptacle. It is utterly confounding and vexing to be subjected to such egregious mistreatment, particularly when taking into account the exorbitant price we paid for the meal. The culinary offerings themselves, however, were quite delectable and satisfying, and we extend our gratitude to the younger waitress who demonstrated a pleasing demeanor and generosity by providing us with supplementary condiments."

Very gorgeous hotel but restaurants are a little too expensive for a locals place. The shows are good there yellow brick road and steel panther. The pool is great but last Saturday they kicked us out at 4 to host a wedding and rushed us out and I had a tab running.

I believe I fell prey to an exaggerated culinary experience, whereby my anticipation was elevated to an unreasonable extent, only to be met with a gustatory encounter that, while satisfactory, failed to surpass the ordinary or elicit an emotional response of profound amazement. The quality of the patty was undeniably superior, and the cooking process was executed adequately; however, I find myself partial to a burger that boasts an abundance of flavor, achieved through the judicious application of seasonings, rather than mere reliance on the inherent taste of the meat. In point of fact, I found it necessary to supplement my dish with a minuscule amount of salt to enhance its flavor profile. The accompanying side salad, though modest in proportions, presented itself quite agreeably, thanks in large part to the commendable dressing that graced its leaves. My dining companion opted for a grilled chicken sandwich, which, while palatable, suffered from an absence of seasoning, thereby mirroring my own experience with its burger counterpart. In light of these observations, I suggest that one consider paying a visit to Tessaro's, albeit with a tempered sense of expectation.

La Place Dupuis peut Ãªtre considÃ©rÃ©e comme un fantÃ´me qui subsiste dans l'esprit de la population locale, malgrÃ© sa transformation en un centre commercial dotÃ© d'un hÃ´tel et d'une tour de bureaux. En effet, cette place importante de l'histoire du QuÃ©bec occupe une position secondaire par rapport Ã  sa vocation premiÃ¨re, qui datait des annÃ©es 1970, Ã©poque pendant laquelle elle abritait la grande surface Dupuis et frÃ¨res, une entreprise de commerce de dÃ©tail fondÃ©e et exploitÃ©e par une famille de Canadiens franÃ§ais. Si l'on effectue des recherches dans les archives des journaux locaux et disparus de MontrÃ©al, on dÃ©couvrira que le plus important annonceur Ã©tait souvent Dupuis et frÃ¨res, dont les publicitÃ©s s'Ã©talaient sur plusieurs pages. Cette institution fondÃ©e au 19Ã¨me siÃ¨cle n'Ã©tait pas simplement un grand magasin trÃ¨s populaire, mais reprÃ©sentait Ã©galement un symbole de rÃ©ussite pour les Canadiens franÃ§ais. De nos jours, on y retrouve principalement des comptoirs de restauration rapide, trÃ¨s populaires auprÃ¨s des employÃ©s de la tour de bureaux et des Ã©tudiants de l'UQAM, qui y mangent leur dÃ©jeuner. On y trouve Ã©galement plusieurs dÃ©taillants, notamment un Bureau en gros, mais il semble que cela ne constitue pas une destination de magasinage pour qui que ce soit. On traverse la Place Dupuis, qui est reliÃ©e Ã  la station de mÃ©tro Berri-UQAM, et on y fait des achats occasionnels, mais sans plus.

We revisited the establishment to partake in a chocolate concrete, which was accompanied by a solitary supplement, specifically toasted coconut that failed to enhance the beverage's flavor profile in any appreciable manner. Notwithstanding, the shake itself was of exceptional quality; however, we were grateful for our decision to share it, as it proved to be remarkably satiating.

I love my chinese food - so I always jump at the chance to go and review a chinese restaurant. We chose this place because of its excellent happy hour deal; something which seems to be amiss throughout the area's chinese restaurants. However, even without the happy hour deals, I would venture this place is a pretty low budget night out as it is. This is reflected in the quality and taste of the food - its not the best I have ever had, and one of my dining companions questioned what type of meat was in his dish more than once. However, as I mentioned, this place is cheap, and you get what you pay for - something not to great, but filling and cheap.

We came here for dinner with my boyfriend's family. They come here often and it was my first time. The prices are good for big portions. I came in with an empty stomach and left fully satisfied.

It's not the nicest place, but for what we ordered it was good. I got walnut shrimp and wonton noodle soup. The shrimp was good and tasty. Crunchy where needed. The broth to the soup however had no taste and the noodles were kinda hard. My boyfriend ordered duck and basically ate the whole thing. He really liked it. It was good but I've tasted tastier duck at Sam Woo. The sweet and sour soup was just as named. And the crispy noodles were thin and crispy. 

The customer service was good. They were nice and accommodating and continuously cleaning our table off because we did order a lot and it got pretty messy. They were also filling up waters constantly so no problem there. 

Their bathrooms were okay. And there was a cart full of dirty dishes by our table, I wasn't so sure about that. But they did clean it out every so often. Didn't really bother us but I was just wondering if that was supposed to go there in the first place. 

Affordable for the whole family.

"As I have reiterated on numerous occasions, my affinity for Italian cuisine is unwavering. Upon arriving at the proximate Best Western, I conducted a thorough examination of the most highly regarded dining establishments in the vicinity, utilizing the popular review platform, Yelp. My culinary exploration led me to the quaint Ristorante Foccaccio, which, while authentically Italian in essence, unfortunately failed to meet the elevated standards of quality I have had the pleasure of experiencing at other esteemed eateries. My primary grievance pertained to the Parmigiano Reggiano; instead of the customary fresh, artisanal variety, I was dismayed to discover that the restaurant opted for a processed, bottled alternative. Although the flavors were undoubtedly palatable, the portion sizes were somewhat diminutive, bordering on meager. Notwithstanding, I would still consider partaking in a future dining experience at this establishment, albeit with tempered expectations, provided that one is seeking a humble, family-operated Italian restaurant that falls short of exceptional."

I would unquestionably opt to lodge here once again. Although I did not anticipate indulging in luxurious amenities, I was pleasantly surprised by the establishment's quality, surpassing my expectations. We required an eleventh-hour accommodation, and booking a room for $50 proved to be a reasonable solution. It is essential to acknowledge that one's financial investment directly correlates with the level of comfort provided; thus, those who express dissatisfaction with the lodging's condition should have been cognizant of this fact during the reservation process. While its location may not be situated directly on the renowned Las Vegas Strip, it remains relatively proximate, with the Hard Rock Hotel & Casino lying at a greater distance. The on-site tavern offers a welcome delight, providing patrons with the opportunity to purchase modestly priced Bud Light beverages for $1.50 each. Motivated by the prospect of obtaining complimentary gaming credits, I chose to enroll in the Owl Club, receiving $200 worth of free slot play. Despite failing to secure any winnings, I was pleased to avoid incurring monetary losses. The staff members manning the reception desk displayed remarkable cordiality and adaptability, ensuring a seamless check-in process. The guest room was well-maintained and featured a functioning television set, meeting my fundamental requirements. As I previously stated, I would unhesitatingly consider this venue for future visits to Las Vegas, particularly when seeking economical lodging options.

Additionally, it is crucial to note that the partition separating the adjacent rooms lacks sufficient soundproofing, rendering audible the slightest noises emanating from neighboring quarters. Consequently, if tranquility is a paramount concern, one may find themselves ill-suited for this particular environment. Moreover, I strongly advise against dining at the Hooters restaurant located within the hotel premises, as the culinary offerings are utterly disappointing. For further details, please refer to my supplementary review.

This particular establishment possesses the inherent capacity to evolve into a captivating venue for socializing, owing to its proficient personnel, an elevated platform for performances, and an array of engaging diversions, as well as a culinary establishment situated on the periphery, which serves palatable victuals. The Living Social arrangement proved to be a judicious investment for the purpose of exploring the premises and sampling their assorted brews.

I came here last night with a friend for dinner and received average service.. Our waitress was very nice and prompt. +1  The margaritas were way way too sour and basically tasted like slurpees.  I ordered the Bleu Cheese Chopped Salad (in which the cheese is made from vegetable enzymes and is imported from Denmark, containing no dairy which was nice +2) and it was very filling. The side of potatoes were very good as well.  I will most likely be returning.

"My experience was somewhat satisfactory, as I partook in a mid-week brunch excursion, during which Wynn graciously covered half of the culinary expenses. While neither the ambiance nor the fare was particularly remarkable, I must admit that the establishment did not disappoint in terms of catering to my gustatory inclinations, especially considering their assortment of saccharine delights, which, in my opinion, rivaled those offered by Wicked Spoon, a local eatery renowned for its extensive array of sweet treats."

"The wine list, while adequate, did not live up to our expectations for a Wine Spectator award recipient, and the prices were exorbitant. Although the fish menu generally adhered to sustainable practices, our server's ignorance regarding the distinction between farm-raised and wild-caught fish, as well as her lack of comprehension of the term'sustainable,' was disconcerting. Notwithstanding this shortcoming, the quality and flavor of the entrees were, on the whole, quite satisfactory. However, the risotto side dish was surprisingly devoid of flavor, which was particularly noticeable given its absence of salt. While the scenic view was undeniably breathtaking, we did not consider the dinner experience to be worth the substantial cost of $100 per person, especially considering that neither an appetizer nor a dessert was included in the price."

I tried the regular coffee. Average. Haven't tried the flavors like the other folks have so I will be looking for some " must have " suggestions! 
Average cup of Joe, but.. that said the staff is awesome and gets my morning going. I am not a morning person but on my way into school they totally get me ready for people interaction or... maybe that is the caffeine. Well, I like the staff so I say its them. Will be going back and may just have to adjust the gold stars if I like what my fellow yelpers recommend!! Post those suggestions. 

Overly Caffinated and so loving it!

I'd been here a while back for a Yelp event so we headed here when we were looking for a place to chill rather than get onto a crowded Light Rail train. Extremely loud music and really, not all that good. But we had a couple of beers and managed to shout over the racket for a bit.\n\nIf you're planning a visit, I'd recommend avoiding the band. Why does it have to be so damn loud?

I was in Vegas last month and had heard about the incredible buffets, so I decided to give it a try. Everyone knows Caesar's is supposed to be the best but this place also had a great reputation. Key word is had. Don't get me wrong, there are still lots of good things about it. But there were also some things that could stand serious improvement. First of all, the meats were not good, kinda dry and just bleh. If you are charging this kind of money, you better have mouth watering prime rib and roast beef to start. Also, some of the side dishes were bland and uninspired. Yes, there was alot to choose from and the atmosphere was nice but for the price they are charging, they need to do more. The highlight of the meal was dessert. Creme Brulee was out of this world as were some of the pastries. The Crepe station knocked it out of the park. It was just sooo good. But the highlight of a pricey meal should not be dessert. The rest of the meal has to stand up on it's own and this just didn't. That being said, it was still better than some of the other major buffets on the strip. I should mention that the service could also stand improvement. Everytime I needed my waitress I could not find her. The dirty dishes piled up and I literally had to get up to get someone's attention. That should simply not be.

"Prioritizing primacy, I would never consider patronizing Digger, as my decision is predicated on an unwavering commitment to personal preference, rather than any personal animosity towards the establishment; albeit, I can appreciate the aesthetic appeal of its sunshine-colored facade, complemented by an array of charming hanging decorations, artisanal greeting cards, and visually striking ornaments, et cetera. Nonetheless, it regrettably fails to resonate with my individualized sensibilities, thereby rendering it incongruous with my distinctive tastes and preferences. Notwithstanding, I can conjecture that the shop's quaint charm may hold appeal for certain demographics, such as mothers and daughters, who might relish the opportunity to peruse its 'twee' assortment, as characterized by my mother."

The steaks we had were disappointing for the price. We both order medium rare, my wife got a rare steak and I got medium. They argued that they we're cook correctly.  \n\nI have better steak at Outback, longhorn.

When I lived in Vegas this was my go to spot for nutrition products, and now that I'm outside of Vegas I still stop in nearly every time I'm there.  Why?  Because the prices are the best I've been able to fine, anywhere.  I mean anywhere, even online.

They have a pretty good selection of nutrition products, anything from protein bar/powder to vitamins.  If you're in need of a nutrition product odds are they have it or something very similar.

As others have said the customer service is not too great.  You're more or less expected to know what you want before you come in.  Questions are often answered in one word responses or pointing to where something is.  Is it is what is is though, the prices are phenomenal so I can live with lack luster customer service.

My third favorite steakhouse. They have the best blooming onion and green vegetable selections with brocolli, string beans, and asparagus. Texas Roadhouse edges them in the steak department. Outback also had the better mushrooms. Delfrisco's has the best steak with a steak called the Wygul but it is pricey. The front entrance position is a little weird to me. That's just my 2 cent.

Visited here for the first time on 1/21/2012 with a Groupon!

Atmosphere was nice, dark with lots of recessed lighting, you could definitely go casual or dress fancy and be in place with either. The service was really good, fairly quick to take your order and bring out plates. Plus, they had a waitress constantly refilling your glass of water (which can be a blessing at an Indian restaurant if you accidentally order something to spicy for your taste!)

Half of the menu was vegetarian, thumbs up for that!!

I was impressed that they immediately bring out a complimentary plate of very thin flat bread and chutneys as soon as you're seated. We ordered the veg sampler appetizer, which was pretty good. I definitely preferred the paneer pakoras and cauliflower pakoras over the samosas. I ordered the malai kafta as my main course, good. Garlic naan and paneer bread were very impressive.

I enjoyed Bombay Grille, but it doesn't top the quality of food at Woodlands... I'm forever spoiled.

These sandwiches are delicious, but there is one problem....Why is it that only the fire department and police officers get a discount in Las Vegas? I am in private EMS, and even when in uniform I am told that there are no discounts for us. Police, Fire and EMS are a TEAM... we work together as public safety guardians! Please fix this error!

Was on our way to noodles of
Asia for a 6:00pm lunch before our 11:30 dinner reservations at Raku (conventional dining time does not apply- it's Vegas!) but stumbled upon Pinot Brasserie, took a quick look at the menu and seemed harmless enough. $9.00 for a bowl of French onion soup and $15.00 for mussles&frites. 

Foodwise
I'm already craving the mussels and it's only been an hour. The white wine+butter+garlic sauce was divine specially when you throw the frites in for
A swim and find them couple minutes later. 
French onion -one of the better French onions I've had. Too many restaurants use salt to flavor the lack of
Onion in their soups but at pinot you can taste the onion broth in the state it's suppose to be.(btw do NOT get the F.O at aria, see my review)

For dessert we got the roasted strawberry with vanilla and mint w/humbolt food cheese.- I'm not a fan of roasted fruit, it's too mushy and makes me think of the ones you try to avoid at the market. Besides that though the flavor
Combination was awesome.

Ok, so foodwise everything was on point, service was a different story. The server was HORRIBlE. Whenever I thanked her for anything she just stared at me like wth? Didn't come around to check up on us. Kept trying to push dessert. I got better service from the busboy/girl. And fr a server that wasn't even ours. Learn to smile girl, and your tips will double.

If you're looking for fabulous, go elsewhere. I've stayed a lot of places in Vegas and the MGM was rather disappointing. When I checked in, they had overbooked the large suite that I booked online, and offered to DOWNGRADE me to a room half the size. Are you kidding me?\n\nEverything from the rooms, to the casino, to the pool, to the service, is extremely mediocre and unmemorable. If you're spending the money to have a nice vacation I'd say take your business elsewhere.

Still a solid three stars from me, which again needs to be put into context of what I enjoy from a bar and a night out. It's a proper pub-bar with a cheeky Australian theme. Postcards of boobs and bums above the bar, a sign saying "dickhead" pointing to an empty space where an unsuspecting punter will stand, slightly sticky and dusty. Reminds me of a slightly better kept student union.

But the crowd are friendly, the bar staff fare no-nonsense friendly. There's one side of the bar that has a big sign saying NO SERVICE do not stand here. If you stand there, they'll be upset. If you don't, they'll be a-ok.

There's two pool tables though, and for me that's a total winner. Just take note of the method of getting a game (adding your name to the chalk board list). The players are friendly and just adding your name up means you'll probably get chatting to some interesting folk.

Standard drinks (as in, no cocktails) for a bar. Good wee location. Inundated with Australians on Australia Day. Not too shabby.

"My most recent sojourn to Las Vegas afforded me the opportunity to partake in a culinary excursion to Chinatown, which piqued my interest due to the presence of a ramen establishment. Our group of five arrived promptly, thereby avoiding the throngs of patrons that typically congregate at this popular eatery. Upon being seated within a quarter of an hour, I opted for the'screaming for vengeance' variety of ramen, which boasted an additional component of corn, given my predilection for fiery broths. Unfortunately, my expectations regarding the spiciness level were not entirely fulfilled, as the broth did not quite live up to my standards. Furthermore, I cannot help but surmise that my taste buds may have been slightly impaired due to previous alcohol consumption, as I found the broth to be somewhat salty. Notwithstanding, I was rather taken by the pork belly, which offered an unparalleled experience of rich, unctuous deliciousness. The noodles, too, were cooked to perfection, possessing a satisfying texture that was neither too soft nor too firm. In conclusion, I would assign this restaurant a rating of three and a half stars, denoting a commendable effort, yet falling short of exceptional."

This establishment offers an enjoyable experience, with its inventive and aesthetically pleasing beverages contributing significantly to the overall ambiance. Our recent visit, during which we sampled two main courses and two drinks, resulted in a substantial financial investment, even with the application of a $20 discount voucher, bringing the total cost to $60. However, our previous visits have proven that this venue provides a unique and entertaining atmosphere in Las Vegas, with delectable cuisine and hospitable staff members.

"An abundance of tea varieties was available for purchase, and my raspberry hibiscus iced tea was prepared with precision, exhibiting a proficient brewing technique. I would have visited this establishment more frequently had it been situated in a more accessible location, rather than being positioned within the midst of Tempe Marketplace. \n\nFewer stars were awarded due to the absence of my preferred selection and the cashier's impromptu diatribe against Starbucks, which ensued without his awareness of my affiliation with a Starbucks manager. It is crucial to recognize that personal beliefs, though significant, should not be voiced in the presence of new or any customers, as one cannot be certain of their audience's composition."

I work late somtimes and they are open rather late and do not mind if you show up 5 min before closing time. The food is better then the normal cheap chinese/asain type places. Ask for a suggestion and they will give it. \n\nChicken fried rice is my usual.

"A significant disadvantage is the unpleasant odour that permeates the dining area, which has the potential to diminish the overall culinary experience. If given the opportunity, I would have preferred to partake in my meal within the picturesque surroundings of the outdoor patio, thereby enhancing the enjoyment of my repast. Notwithstanding, this establishment boasts an extensive menu catering to diverse tastes and dietary preferences, featuring an assortment of delectable options such as gyros and shawarmas for carnivorous individuals, and a medley of Mediterranean delights including hummus, baba ghanoush, tsaziki, tabouleh, and falafel for vegetarian patrons. Generous portions are served with alacrity, particularly the lentil and rice accompaniment, which rivals the magnitude of the primary dishes. The prices are reasonable, rendering this eatery a popular destination, as evidenced by its perpetual throng of clientele."

I work on the North Side and went for a walk to find something new for lunch.  I am quickly growing tired of Eco Bistro directly downstairs from my office at Allegheny Center.\n\nAt any rate, came across this place at the corner of Ohio and the onramp to 279.  The lunch special was inexpensive and grabbed a soda for about $6 in all.  I had the Kung Pao Chicken and it was prepared to order.  Tasty, cheap, fast.  I ate inside - there are only a handful of tables in this place and it's decently clean.

This place has awesome ratings on both yelp and zagat, but i was so disappointed. My expectations must've been too high. I WILL give them props for having the *best* and most smooth Thai Iced Tea I've ever had in my life though. Onto their food? The waiter suggested their duck in red curry. The duck meat tasted a bit... expired.. and rotten. It was also rough, and the curry lacked in flavor. We also ordered a green curry with chicken, which wasn't bad, but it didn't amaze me. I've had much better green curry at any reg Thai joint back home in New York. Now... the appetizer that the waiter said we HAD to order was GROSS. It's some crispy rice sort of thing.. and it's sour, and sour, and sour, and also expired tasting. Why is it their most popular item? People in Vegas must be weird then, sorry guys. \n\nOh, the lady behind the bar area was also rude. She had a huge diamond on her finger and wasn't in a uniform, so she might be some kind of owner/manager. To me though, that means you should step it up a level and be even more nice, not be a snotface. Skinny face, medium long black hair, pale, slender asian woman with a big rock -- BEWARE OF HER, she will make your whole meal unpleasant.

"Casanova represents a quaint and charming Italian eatery nestled within the luxurious Venetian resort, offering an endearing ambiance that exudes warmth and coziness. However, due to its diminutive size, it is essential to be aware of its capacity limitations, as my party of thirteen discovered when we were accommodated outside the primary dining area, situated in the midst of the bustling Grand Canal Shoppes walkway. The proximity of a nearby bar, combined with the high volume of foot traffic emanating from the adjacent food court, contributed to a cacophony of sounds that made conversation somewhat challenging. Notwithstanding these factors, I would still recommend Casanova for smaller gatherings, ideally comprising no more than four individuals, as the interior boasts a captivating and picturesque decor that enhances the overall dining experience. In terms of culinary offerings, Casanova delivers authentic Italian fare at remarkably reasonable prices, showcased by their delectable Timballo dish, consisting of penne pasta enveloped in a rich, creamy pesto sauce, topped with a generous portion of parmesan cheese and baked to perfection. Additionally, the accompanying bread is served warm and perfectly roasted, further accentuating the savory flavors of the meal. For those seeking delicious Italian cuisine at an accessible price point, Casanova certainly merits consideration."

Very busy store. Sometimes long lines but it usually goes pretty quick. Some of the stuff they have is a pretty good deal, 99cents sometimes 2/99cents! Not the biggest 99 cent store in town but it's close. \nThere's still something's I refuse to buy at these stores because I don't know where it comes from or how it was handled. The store can be messy too.\nI usually go in hoping to get something in particular but end up spending at least 5-10$ on other thing I suddenly decided I really needed

Due to location (convenience factor) I decided to check out Beijing instead of my usual fave Ho Ho Cherry House.

I ordered the Sesame chicken (extra crispy) and was pleasantly surprised that for 8 and change you receive a generous portion of chicken, fried rice, egg roll, choice of soup - I went won-ton, and even a little steamed broccoli. Ho ho cherry house doesn't offer soup or broccoli- so I was really pleased.

My order took only 10 minutes - and it tasted cook-to-order. 

I really enjoyed their egg-roll's - definitely better than Ho-Ho's.They use more than just cabbage which is key. The rice was tasty- and the soup was awesome! I actually gave some to the girls that I was babysitting and lets say Ive never seen a 4 year old  down won-ton soup broth versus the chocolate ice cream in front of her! 

Where they fell off the wagon was the crispiness factor. Unfortunately, that is kind of my main test for Chinese and the chicken just wasn't crispy at all. I would hate to see what it would be like if I didn't order extra crispy- it would have been mush! I also didn't care for the sauce as much as Ho-Ho's.

The sides were all cooked so well- and you can't beat the price or the location so I think id try it again and really stress the EXTRA crispy part!

A good friend of mine is a secret fan of gift shops- he can spend hours in them- so long as they are the official ones. Well this one is an official one and despite the twee gift ideas and corny souvenirs there are some more classier and elegant gift ideas in here. 

The quality is also much better than the cheaper alternatives on the Royal mile, minus the bad and loud music and bright colours the later ones have. 
So it really depends on your budget and how much you want to hunt around for gifts or souvenirs. I like the service in the gift shop- the lady is always so nice and didn't mind my friend browsing for an age either. (and didn't follow us around like a certain other cheaper gift shop did). If you payed to get into the Castle might as well have a walk around even if you do choose the cheaper options down the street.

Letzte Woche war ich mit einer Freundin dort essen.
Parken ist mit Glück dort in der Nähe möglich, Hausparkplätze oder so gibt es nicht.
Der erste Eindruck beim Eintreten war, dass es wunderbar nach Gewürzen duftete. 
Der Zweite, dass es dort alles ganz schön eng gestellt ist. Für mich als dickem Menschen leicht beengend. Wir hatten dann aber einen Tisch, wo ich nicht allzusehr im Weg saß und das war ok. 
Das Lokal ist ebenerdig zu betreten, so dass es, mit einer kleinen Einschränkung für gehbehinderte Menschen geeignet ist. Für Rollifahrer schon etwas eng. Im Lokal selber gibt es Plätze, die über eine Stufe höher angelegt sind.

Die Bedienung war nett und freundlich, das Essen frisch, lecker und schnell da (wobei es recht voll war). 
Wie "indisch" das Essen ist, kann ich nicht bewerten, da ich noch nie in Indien war. Auf jeden Fall fand ich es lecker, besonders das Gericht meiner Freundin und das Eis. Der Salat war eher unspektakulär.
Als Dessert hatte ich hausgemachtes Mandel- und Cashew-Eis probiert, dies war echt toll, da es ganz ungewöhnlich mit Kardamon gewürzt war und ein wahres Geschmackserlebnis.
Den Toilettenbereich kann ich nicht kommentieren und bewerten, da ich ihn nicht genutzt habe.
Ob Kartenzahlung möglich ist, weiß ich nicht.

"The ambiance and embellishments of this establishment piqued my interest and captivated my senses, enticing me to partake in a culinary experience while lodging at Caesar's. A visually striking aquarium, replete with an array of vibrant marine life, serves as the focal point of the restaurant's interior design, complemented by an elegant color scheme and sophisticated decor. Patrons are attired in pristine white attire, contributing to the overall aesthetic harmony of the space. My gastronomical endeavors led me to sample a beef and noodle dish, which, unfortunately, failed to impress my palate, lacking the depth and complexity of flavors that I had anticipated. Considering the premium prices associated with dining in Las Vegas, my expectations were not adequately met, resulting in a somewhat disappointing experience. My total expenditure for the meal and a single beer amounted to approximately $35."

"I find myself partial to the ambiance, as it evokes a sense of familiarity, yet simultaneously, it manages to maintain a certain je ne sais quoi that sets it apart from other establishments of its ilk; thereby, creating an intriguing dichotomy that piques my interest and incites my curiosity. 

In our quest for a satisfying repast, we opted to sample the luncheon special, which consisted of an open-faced green chili meatloaf sandwich, accompanied by a grilled salmon salad. Upon their arrival, both dishes presented themselves in a visually appealing manner, with the ingredients artfully arranged to create a culinary masterpiece. However, upon closer inspection, it became apparent that the meatloaf sandwich suffered from an unfortunate flaw, as the mashed potatoes, which served as the foundation for the dish, were excessively mixed, resulting in a texture that could be described as gelatinous. 

In contrast, the salmon salad, while possessing certain qualities that rendered it palatable, also gave rise to a degree of perplexity, as the inclusion of a chive risotto cake seemed to clash with the citrus dressing, thus creating a discordant flavor profile that detracted from the overall enjoyment of the dish. 

The service, while adequate, did not excel in any particular manner, nor did it falter to such a degree as to warrant criticism. 

In conclusion, while my experience at this establishment did not inspire an overwhelming desire to return in the near future, I cannot dismiss the possibility of a subsequent visit, as the allure of the atmosphere and the potential for a more satisfactory dining experience remain enticing."

I had a mere forty minutes to dispose of, and given the crowded ambiance, I harbored concerns regarding the expediency of service, which was substantiated by my perusal of previous patron's accounts. However, upon securing a table, I was promptly presented with a beverage within a five-minute interval, and although I was apprised that the preparation time for buffalo wings would be approximately twenty minutes, I was pleasantly surprised to receive them in under ten. The overall quality of service was laudable. Notwithstanding, the wings themselves were imbued with an excessive degree of acidity, and while they did possess a tangible level of spiciness, I would not consider ordering them again. In contradistinction, the two gentlemen seated adjacent to me professed satisfaction with their fish and chips. Furthermore, while the cost of sustenance was reasonable, the price of a twenty-two ounce Stella Artois seemed exorbitant at nine dollars.

Although I wasn't ecstatic about the food, the service was good. The guy who served us was very accommodating to our needs. Honestly, I don't think I can even give a proper review because I'm a vegetarian. Being named Mr.Tofu, I wrongly assumed that there would be some veggie dishes. To my dismay, there was 1. It was a cold tofu noodle soup. It literally had 3 ingredients. There was noodles, tofu broth (which I'm guessing was made from tofu juice), and ice. It tasted like tofu, which is bland without incorporating any outside elements. I had to eat kimchee with the soup in order to taste anything. The side dishes were good because they added flavor to my meal. I probably won't stop by unless I go back to eating meat.

Can someone tell me why these are so posh?  Name? Comfort? Style?  \n\nBecause my opinion only is that they don't look comfortable, and the style is very old looking, not for someone in their 20's.  But maybe I'm wrong, and it I am, for all you lovers, half the store was 50% off as of last week!!

5 stars for the concept itself (bringing a cupcake store to Scottsdale) and the bright airy store environment. I am totally not a big fan of sweet so maybe my overall rating is a bit biased, but I've had cupcakes at Magnolia (NY) and absolutely loved every single bite.  Sprinkle's, however, didn't really strike me in the same way. I thought they were extremely overtly sweet =/\n\nOne other thing when we were sharing a red velvet, the top came off ! WTH?!

Interesting food creations, using lobster in sandwiches, salad, fried food, and ice cream!  However, the foods in fact tasted just A-OK and prices were sorta steep.  $23 for a 6\" lobster roll was pricey, I think.  The lobster salad came with lots of small chunks of lobster meat and was good for the price.  Lobster bisque was just standard.  Lobster-n-chips was cool though! Beer-battered and fried lobster huh? Yummmmm~  Last but not least, the lobster ice cream that sounded out of the ordinary was actually vanilla ice cream with itsy-bitsy lobster meat.  The ice cream tasted alright but was worth a try!  Just ask for a free sample before you buy, so as to make sure that you would like some savory ice cream that tastes like seafood. *wink*

Located inside the Tuscany Casino where we stayed while in Vegas for a convention.

Our party of ten came for dinner.  Plenty of seating for large groups.  Our server was very patient and didn't get frazzled when we all wanted to use our 2 for 1 dinner entree coupon.

Food was decent.  Prices decent.  Portion size decent.

If you like carne asada, I mean if you really like carne asada, this place is definitely worth checking out. If you like a variety to choose from, maybe not.

The menu is a little limited with the main dishes being carne asada taco, burrito, tostada (Vampiro) and quesadilla. They do have one vegetarian dish and, of course, chips and salsa.

Now for the good news. The carne asada is pretty good. I tried the Vampiro and the quesadilla. Both were very tasty. Some people have mentioned that the chips and salsa are extra, but most counter service places I've been to charge for chips and salsa. It's worth it. The chips are fresh and the salsa is not particularly hot but has a great flavor.

It's definitely worth a try, especially if you like carne asada.

"This assessment pertains exclusively to the eyebrow-waxing service provided by the establishment in question. Upon entering the premises on a Saturday afternoon, I was promptly attended to and ushered to the rear of the facility within a mere five-minute timeframe, thereby circumventing any potential delay. Notably, my customary eyebrow-waxing venue is located approximately thirty minutes away from my current location and typically boasts a sixty-minute waiting period solely for eyebrow waxing. In contrast, this particular establishment enjoys a significantly more convenient proximity to my residence. Previously accustomed to a greater emphasis on plucking rather than waxing, I opted to take a chance on this salon despite my reservations. Unfortunately, the outcome left my eyebrows appearing considerably more diminutive than anticipated. However, I have yet to observe any regrowth nearly a week post-service, which constitutes a positive aspect of the experience. The price point for the service itself proved reasonable, set at ten dollars. In the event that I find myself in a predicament wherein I require an expedited eyebrow-waxing procedure, I would consider returning to this establishment. It is worth noting that while they do indeed accept card payments, they express a preference for gratuities tendered in cash."

"On a Sunday, I ventured into this establishment for the first time, taking advantage of their extended hours until midnight, which was quite convenient. However, my experience with the sushi was rather unremarkable, warranting only three stars from me due to the usage of non-organic edamame and soy sauce. As an advocate for sustainable and natural food sources, I find it challenging to support restaurants that serve genetically modified soybeans, which unfortunately, seem to be the norm nowadays. Despite this, I maintain hope that more establishments will prioritize organic and non-GMO verified ingredients in the future, even if it may appear futile at present, considering the majority of consumers remain oblivious to the implications of GMO consumption."

I chose Mesa Grill after hearing Delmonico's is way overrated. Having eaten at the Bahamas location, and despite my aversion to Bobby Flay, I decided to give the Las Vegas MG a try.

1. Awkward seating arrangement: We had a table of six, and it seemed like they had to put a table in the middle of a seating arrangement in order to fit us. We would've been perfectly fine if the wait staff wasn't continually bumping into my friends' chairs and then asking them to move out the way. That was uncool.

2. Food was great. Everyone was really happy with their dishes. Amongst the six of us, we ordered the duck, ribeye and pork tenderloins. For sides, pesto mashed potatoes, baby carrots, tiger shrimp tamale and sauteed spinach. We had to wait a bit for a couple of the sides because the waitress forgot them, but it wasn't too bad. Food came out hot and tasty.

3. Desserts were okay. I enjoyed my spicy chocolate creme brulee in the Bahamas more than the profiteroles I had. I thought they were really stingy with the iced cream which put me off a bit.

4. Service was alright. Our waitress was chatty and came around a few times to check on us.

Mesa Grill Las Vegas didn't disappoint and I wouldn't be against visiting BF's other restaurants.

"Obsolete and antiquated, the existing Target establishment situated at the intersection of Camelback Road and Seventh Avenue, is slated for a comprehensive renovation and metamorphosis into an upgraded, state-of-the-art 'Super Store' format, much to the delight of local patrons who eagerly anticipate the unveiling of the revamped retail hub. However, it is worth noting that not all individuals share the same level of enthusiasm regarding the transformation, with some expressing reservations about the'superstore' designation and the potential for a homogenized, big-box shopping experience that may compromise the distinctiveness and specialization of traditional retail establishments. Furthermore, certain patrons have taken issue with the temporary scarcity of select items and the perceived dearth of adept, ingenious solutions proffered by store personnel in response to inquiries regarding the impending reopening date."

The modified text is: "I placed an order for a set of noodles to be taken home, yet upon perusing the instructions, it became apparent that there was a discrepancy in the clarity of the directions regarding the intensity of the chili component within the dish. Despite the sweltering heat that had enveloped Phoenix throughout the day, I was eager to return home and indulge in the culinary delight. Upon arriving at my residence, I observed that the sauce accompanying the noodles appeared to possess a striking resemblance to molten lava in both color and consistency. Following the consumption of approximately one-third of the dish, I fervently wished that I had abstained from partaking in it altogether, as my lip began to exhibit signs of inflammation and my facial area was overcome with perspiration. In an attempt to mitigate the internal turmoil caused by the fiery ingredients, I rapidly consumed an entire bottle of Coca-Cola. It is imperative that measures are taken to assess the degree of pepper spice incorporated into take-home orders, lest similar unpleasant experiences recur. Notwithstanding, I am willing to accord them another opportunity, provided they demonstrate a concerted effort to rectify the situation and furnish a comprehensible explanation. A reevaluation of my rating shall ensue, contingent upon their ability to convincingly justify themselves."
I shop here all the time.  Staff is friendly and helpful.  But .......the bathroom is always NASTY.  I always question if I should shop there when the bathroom is always disgusting. Yucky

Pretty good sports bar located across from the sports book in the MGM. So cool place to go and grab a beer and some food after making your bet.  The place gets packed on Saturdays and Sundays during the football season so you might have trouble grabbing a table if you're with a big group.  There appeared to be a good amount of seating at the bar if you can get in there early.

Food is basic bar food, I wouldn't get anything other than wings or perhaps a burger, anything else would be a waste in my opinion. They have some decent deals during game day, I went with the shot and beer combos. Nice variety of beer on taps and most of your classic domestics in a bottle.

Nothing overly special but a nice place to chill and enjoy the games on the numerous TVs.

Green river soda pop, fried mushrooms, and all of the typical Chicago favorites such as Red Hots and other miscellaneous hot dogs are served up here.  I lean towards fried appetizers at places like this and they were just alright.  Service was somewhat slow and I miss the old pizza place that was in this location beforehand.

This Dunkin Donuts is one of the first to open around the Madison area.  It's located on the corner of Hwy Q and Hwy 19 in Waunakee, and is attached to the BP Gas Station that's on that same corner.  \n\nThe staff was super friendly and helpful, the donuts were decent.  If you're in the area and craving a donut, give these guys a shot.

"Amidst the verdant surroundings, this eatery presents itself as an enjoyable venue, boasting delectable fare that, while not unwaveringly authentic, remains undoubtedly palatable and worthy of consumption on multiple occasions. Furthermore, the hospitality proffered by the staff proved to be satisfactory, albeit lacking in extraordinary embellishments. Notwithstanding the relaxed ambiance, patrons should refrain from harboring lofty expectations regarding service quality, as the establishment's laid-back nature precludes such extravagances. Nonetheless, certain menu items, such as the savory tortilla soup, managed to elicit my approval and appreciation."

Pluses: great location to be close to The Strip but pay off-strip prices (5/10 minute walk to Ballys/Paris), Westin Heavenly Bed & Heavenly Shower, nice if u want to rest away from the city's hustle & bustle, plenty of free parking

Minuses: Small pool, small spa (it's nice but doesn't have all of the amenities that you'd find at a big spa), surprised they didn't have iHomes in the room

Also I was disappointed with some of the customer service. We wanted to leave our bags with the bellhop because our room wasn't ready yet. He wasn't there but the concierge and all 4 of the people at the check in desk weren't doing anything. I know they saw us waiting! It was so long before someone even acknowledged us that I was literally seconds from putting my bags back in my car! Even if it's not your job, you should at least say "he'll be right back" or "let me find him". Or even better, help us yourself! How hard is it to put a ticket on a bag! That was so uncalled for... Disappointing

This Motel 6 is a-ok with me. It was inexpensive (and this was dead of summer we were talking about here). The room was clean. The staff was friendly. I slept through my wake up call, but that's my fault. They got a little pool to the side. Plenty of parking.\n\nThe only issue I'd warn you about is that this is next to some sort of theme park. This can create some noise in the day. You can't really see it from this facility but it is there. You'll hear it. There's also not a lot around this area, so getting up and getting breakfast is a pain because you usually have to go drive somewhere.

"Satisfactory, yet somewhat unremarkable in terms of overall quality. A diverse array of cake batters, including vanilla and chocolate variations, are available for selection. Additionally, a sufficient assortment of toppings is provided, though it would be wise to specifically request the inclusion of mochi, a traditional Japanese rice cake, to enhance the culinary experience. The interior ambiance is quite pleasant, boasting an eclectic mix of intriguing individuals. Notably, an inquiry regarding my hourly rate was posed by an Indian mother, which engendered a degree of discomfort, given that I was attired in a'rent by the hour' shirt at the time."

"It is gratifying that another individual alluded to the fact that this establishment was previously recognized as the Kabob House, as without their mention, I would have never discovered it. In point of fact, I am unfamiliar with the appellation 'Khaneh Kabob' being used in reference to this eatery, although it is conceivable that it may be denoted thus in the local dialect. Irrespective of this, the restaurant's interior is indeed spotless, albeit somewhat peculiarly connected to a beverage store. This observation is merely a statement of fact and does not detract from the venue's overall quality. 

If one were to order a kabob containing either steak or poultry, it is conceivable that they might experience a degree of disappointment due to the relatively meager portion size. On the other hand, if one were to opt for a kabob featuring ground meat, they would likely have leftovers remaining after consumption. Regrettably, I cannot offer guidance regarding the optimal type of kabob to select, as my acquaintances typically handle the ordering process on my behalf. Nonetheless, I can confidently assert that these kabobs are not of the customary Americanized variety; rather, they adhere to traditional Persian culinary practices. Therefore, it is essential to temper one's expectations accordingly to avoid potential disappointment.

The ground beef-style kabobs are carefully wrapped around a lengthy, flat skewer and cooked directly on the skewer, resulting in an abundance of succulent meat. While it is uncertain whether side dishes must be ordered independently, we habitually request them alongside our meat, as the combination of rice, bread, and other items enhances the dining experience considerably.

The staff maintains a cordial demeanor, yet their service is not characterized by expediency. Moreover, they have historically struggled with communicating effectively in the English language."

Came here during the Christmas week, so there was a premium price on the buffet during lunchtime, about $30-something per person. The regular line up to get in was PACKED, so if it wasn't for the line pass we had, it would've been bye bye to the buffet.

Been here before last year and it seems the quality has gone down. The food was okay, but there really wasn't anything to write home about. They have your standard stuff that can be found in other buffets like shrimps, prime rib, roasted chicken, etc etc. They also have the king crab legs which seem to be the main attraction as I saw many people just having piles and piles of them on their plates. I didn't try the king crab legs as I'm not fond of them in general. I found many of the food to be kinda dry and so I have to put a lot of sauce on them to taste better.

The best part I found was the dessert. They have different kinds of dessert from creme brulee to creampuffs to different flavors of ice cream, as well as brownies, banana fosters, and cookies. I tried the creme brulee and cookies and they're pretty good. Better than the main stuff honestly.

Pop and juice are included in the price, so try to take advantage of that.

Not worth the $30-something for lunch, but ok for the regular $20-something.

Went there with a group of people. the portions where huge! Half of us liked the food, and the other half just thought it was OK. The jerk pork and chicken weren't that tasty. But the pork BBQ was great, as were the sweet potatoes and rice.

"Recently, in the company of numerous colleagues, I partook in an evening excursion to a local culinary establishment, whereupon I sampled their signature Kobe burger, complemented by a delectable assortment of white cheddar and sweet potato fries. Although the gastronomic experience was indeed pleasurable, with the burger being cooked to perfection and the fries displaying an unparalleled crispness, it did not quite ascend to the lofty heights of my most memorable burger experiences. Nonetheless, the convivial atmosphere and camaraderie shared among our group served to enhance the overall enjoyment of the meal."
Alright sushi. At least they have a few good roles for $5 ish. Good and quick for a pick-up lunch during the work week.\n\nNo seating. Takeout/Pick up only.

"While it may not be an establishment that would warrant extensive correspondence with my domestic dwelling, I must admit that Jason's Deli does provide a satisfactory experience when it comes to satiating my craving for a distinctive sandwich that diverges from the norm offered by traditional sandwich shops. Upon entering the premises, I am greeted by a diverse array of soups, which presents me with an abundance of options to choose from. Additionally, their sandwiches are of decent quality, and their ice cream offerings serve as a pleasant conclusion to the meal. Although I wouldn't purposely go out of my way to visit Jason's Deli, I similarly wouldn't deliberately avoid it if I were passing by or meeting acquaintances there."

Good food. I liked the Chicken Marsala but the prices could be better. There is a kid working their that looks like Jonah Hill/Seth from Super Bad - with a white boy fro and all! That made only OK service a little better!

This establishment has the potential to attain a five-star rating if certain adjustments are made. While the menu offers an acceptable selection, the culinary offerings are palatable. The ambiance of the venue is quite impressive, boasting an indoor-outdoor layout that permits patrons to bring their canine companions onto the patio. However, the bartenders exude an air of pretentiousness, which may deter some patrons from fully enjoying their experience. It would be beneficial for the ownership to dispatch these bartenders to Ve Bene in Ahwatukee, where they can observe how skilled bartenders engage with their clientele. Unfortunately, the lack of evening drink specials and the elevated prices of beverages may contribute to the sluggish pace of business, potentially deterring prospective customers. Perhaps management assumes that maintaining a lofty atmosphere is essential to discouraging undesirable patronage.

"On my maiden visit to this establishment, I opted for the shredded beef burrito, priced at $6.29, which, while substantial in size, did not quite meet my expectations in terms of taste. However, their complementary warm chips and guacamole, available for purchase at $0.99 and $2.69 respectively, proved to be a notable exception, as they exhibited a satisfying confluence of flavors and textures that left me feeling satiated. Despite having returned to this location on multiple occasions, my culinary explorations have been limited to these aforementioned items, as they continue to captivate my palate with their simplicity and elegance. Furthermore, while I do concede that Qdoba's chips are somewhat superior, my preference for Baja Fresh's burritos remains unwavering, particularly in light of the fact that the two establishments share a striking similarity, as suggested by their proximity to one another, with Qdoba situated directly across the street from Chipotle. This peculiar coincidence notwithstanding, I remain steadfast in my devotion to Baja Fresh's offerings."

"The culinary experience was satisfactory, neither exceptionally remarkable nor deplorably unpalatable. Upon perusing the menu, I elected to sample the Turkey & Rosemary Omelet, while my companion opted for the French Toast Strata. My platter arrived with an omelet, roasted potatoes from the oven, and fresh fruit. Although all components were adequate, I must admit that I could have easily prepared a comparable meal in my own domicile. If I were to return, I might consider replicating the dish, but I would prefer to explore their luncheon offerings initially. My companion concurred, expressing contentment with his meal, yet harboring a desire to sample their burgers. The restaurant boasts a diverse and extensive menu, catering to both my penchant for vegetarian and lean meat options, as well as my companion's fondness for heartier fare, such as the Wisconsin Pride Burger, adorned with cheese curds and bacon atop a 1/2 lb patty. We visited the establishment on the occasion of my companion's birthday, departing with a cupcake. My satiation precluded me from partaking in the sweet treat, however, my companion relished the carrot cupcake embellished with cream cheese frosting and walnut bits. Following consumption, he proclaimed its quality as satisfactory. A future visit during the luncheon hour may warrant an updated assessment."

We decided to start our Winter Break with pizza!  We had a coupon to try Florencia's. 

We got there just before 3pm and had the place to ourselves, but for two other tables. 

Melissa greeted us at the door and grabbed our drinks super quick. We ordered the XL Cheese pizza, we were all craving cheese!  The pizza looked great and tasted as good as it looked!

Three stars due to the fact that we had to get our second round from the bar on our own. We won't let that stop us from trying Florencia's again. The pizza was cheesy and full of flavor, the crust...perfect!

"Although the accommodation was relatively affordable, my expectations were not particularly elevated, given the price point. During my stay at the hotel, which coincided with a mining conference, I couldn't help but feel that the staffing levels were somewhat inadequate, resulting in an atmosphere that lacked the polish and refinement typically associated with high-end hospitality establishments. Notwithstanding this, the cleanliness of the rooms and the temperature of the water in the showers were both satisfactory, thus rendering the overall experience merely adequate."

Sometimes it pays to be in larger groups when the bill will be larger and provide bigger tips.  

My wife and I seemed to be overlooked, especially towards the end of the meal.  Took 16 minutes to order dessert.  Way too long.

The ravioli was great and pork belly was tender.  Ther prawns were a little over done.  I would try going here again to see what happens.  I was not going to cause a scene, but by the end, I was just trying to get out of there.  The food was a 4, but the service seemed slow.

"The venue, while unassuming at first glance, boasts an impressive capacity, with an expansive bar stretching along the rear wall, which tends to attract lengthy queues, especially during peak hours, and patrons may find the prices for standard draft beers to be somewhat prohibitive, although the amiable staff tend to mitigate this inconvenience. Additionally, the venue employs numerous attendants who diligently maintain the facilities and monitor the crowd, contributing to an overall sense of safety and orderliness. The bathrooms, spacious and well-appointed, feature an abundance of stalls, minimizing delays typically associated with high-traffic areas; meanwhile, the acoustics, though adequate, suffer slightly from an eccentric layout of iron railings that segment the general admission area, seemingly intended to preclude the formation of a large-scale mosh pit, but ultimately lending an air of peculiarity to the setup."

I have had the occasion to partake in the culinary offerings of this establishment on several occasions over the course of my residency in this city, totaling five years, and it is with a sense of relief that I can report that there has been a marked improvement in the quality of the fare provided, specifically in regards to the moisture level and overall taste, which previously left much to be desired, having been characterized by an unpleasant dryness and a strong suggestion of having been stored for an extended period of time in close proximity to the preparation area. It is my sincere hope that this upward trend in gastronomical excellence shall continue unabated.

Little pricey for the food.  The reason it pays to come to this place is the excellent drink menu, and souvenir cups, glasses, mugs, etc. that you can take with you.  The place is packed with movie trivia and buy stuff in the store next-door.\nNice stuff for lunch during the convention...and creates a good memory!

Having had memorable meals at Kai, we were thrilled to learn of its former chef joining partnership here at Mod.   Signature touches and flair were apparent in the presentation, the food was innovative and some of it was excellent, such as the \"shroom\" dish.  The venison lollipops were too rare for me, but my husband said they were tasty.  He also had the pescado loco tar tare, and found it to his liking. I ordered the duck large plate and was disappointed-duck was good, but dish featuring beans, rice, okra, etc. was no better than say one would get at Milagro Grill or The Mission. The okra was unusually salty.  A server came to our table with a covered dish and asked if it were ours.  We inquired as to to what it was. He didn't know. He had come from the kitchen; not a regular waiter, but totally clueless. I do understand it was Labor Day Weekend and staff may have been not the usual crew. Our waitress was very pleasant, the hostess welcoming, and the others we encountered were attentive. Loud music for a younger crowd was intrusive. I could see going again for appetizers and a cocktail, but would not go back for dinner, considering the myriad of choices available here in the Valley.

I'd give Bei a 3.5. Who ever the Yelpers are that compare it to Shin Bay, have obviously never been to Shin Bay. Not even close to Hiro, for that matter. We're talking Ra or Kona Grill at best. 

For shame fellow Yelpers, let's just call a spade, a spade. It's passable sushi in Scottsdale. 

For those who disagree...get out more. Try real sushi.

C'est un peu mieux que ce que c'\u00e9tait il y a deux ans. Premi\u00e8rement pour moi l'exp\u00e9rience varie principalement avec les compagnies a\u00e9riennes. Qatar Airways c'est le check-in le plus vite que j'n'ai jamais eut de ma vie. Sans blague, 30 minutes j'avais pass\u00e9 le check-in des bagages, les douanes. Je me sentais comme un VIP! Air Canada il y a deux ans, oufff c'\u00e9tait dans le m\u00e9diocre absolu. 1h20 pour le check-in des bagages. 10 minutes les douanes...\n\nMaintenant, le hic que tout le monde ont eut c'est la ligne d'attente stupide avec le beau Welcome to Canada ( et l\u00e0 dans ta t\u00eate, t'as l'impression qu'il manque le monde IDIOTS \u00e0 c\u00f4t\u00e9) parce que c'est longggggg. Mais ils ont chang\u00e9 leur syst\u00e8me de v\u00e9rification des passes de v\u00e9rification; c'est un lecteur de passport qui lit  ta fiche de d\u00e9claration et scan ton passeport.  1: Bonne id\u00e9e, 2: le lecteur que j'ai pris fonctionnais mal, \u00e7a a prit trop de temps. Si t'as coch\u00e9 non pour tout c'est ok, merci Ciao! Sinon, Attend!! C'est une coche mieux que c'\u00e9tait.
Food is great. Grilled salmon burrito is awesome! Customer service, very friendly and 'above and beyond.'  I was surprised how unhygienic and gross the men's bathroom was; like a smelly truck stop.

So I went back again after probably 3 years, due to a hankering for Greek food since I was in the area. This time, I ordered their Spanakopita to see if the recipe has changed. The presentation was exactly the same but this time, it tasted great! The pastry was flaky and it had the right amount of saltiness. It looked kind of like a spinach lasagna. It was over a bed of rice pilaf. I did not care for the rice, it was lacking flavor and moisture. I also ordered their pumpkin cheesecake. Way too sweet. Even sweeter than the ones I order at the Cheesecake Factory. I would say 3.5 stars this time around.

"The culinary offerings were merely adequate, with the meat and potatoes failing to impress, yet the ambiance and unique dining concept made for an enjoyable outing. It is worth noting that patrons whose weight surpasses 350 pounds are extended the courtesy of complimentary consumption, whereas all others must tender payment in cash, as credit or debit cards are not accepted. Additionally, it is mandatory for guests to don a gown and bracelet prior to entry. Despite the unremarkable fare, the novelty of the establishment and the ensuing experience render it a suitable choice for those seeking a diversion from the mundane."

Sichuan is a region in China known for hot babes. If you know a thing or two about what brings the heat you know that you need the whole package. Pretty and smart gets it done. Taking one without the other you're either shallow or a chump.

You'll see a ton of these yelp reviews deride the decor or the service or the atmosphere. These are the kinds of kids that like places like Imperial Garden. Who likes that place? (I do. Kind of a lot. I think?). You'll also see a ton of these yelp reviews glow over Sichuan food and eating stuff like oxtail and tripe or pickled soup. I am a big fan, and their spicy crispy chicken is my jam. The only thing I got here that I didn't like was the Kung Pao chicken - it didn't pack much heat and the sauce was thick and sweet. I think they thought I was getting something from the Americanized menu.

So what kind of babe is Ichiban? Obviously she's the brainy one that doesn't care what you think. I kinda wish she did, though.

Grab decent sandwiches and gyros, and enjoy live music if it's scheduled.  I was addicted as a student and still enjoy stopping in when I visit C-U, but it's a simple joint.  Right on campus near the quad.

Went here, not once, but TWICE, in one evening! 

Why, you ask? My friends and I were hungry and this place was cheap, and their nachos didn't mess around. 

At $16 a pop, the nachos was big enough to feed you, me, and everyone we know. The cheese could've been melted a little more, but it was still pretty good, especially when you're trashed. 

If you need more alcohol in your system, scrounge up a couple of bucks, panhandle, get your "Will dance for $" sign out, and get a $1 margarita. It's strong and sweet, and will keep your buzz going.

we told them we were on guestlist but they didnt seem to care.  then we all paid $20 including girls even though there was no one inline.  it turns out if you stay at the venetian you dont have to pay.  

inside the club was pretty crowded though.  the booty shaking girls were pretty impressive and the ones massaging each other were too.  the buddhas all over the place were a bit creepy to me but i dont think others mind as much.

they make you walk all the way upstairs to where they usually have tao beach in the daytime.  it s a nice spot.  except for the ugly plastic covering some construction they have going on.  we sat on the couches but they wouldnt let us sit for long because they were bottle service couches.

i think different rooms play different music.  it rains down foam in the main room which i think is yucky.  i was walking around with a drink and some girl bumped into me.  my straw went up my nose.  and it started bleeding.  then i coughed up the blood.  dont worry im ok.  ha

Product:  One of the best meat quality in the Vegas area, variety of selection that cannot be gotten in other restaurants.  It is also very clean unlike other places around. 

Service: It is only good if you speak Korean or sit in the same table with a person that speaks Korea, but i guess it is a common theme in all Korean restaurants around Vegas. 

Price: A little high compared to other, but i would pay it for the quality of the product. 

Overall: If you can live with the poor service of a typical Korean restaurant, i would strongly recommend go there for the quality of the meats.

This establishment exudes an air of frivolity and amusement, albeit in a somewhat kitsch manner, with its patently artificial rustic embellishments and staff attired in apparel reminiscent of burlap sacks. The ambiance is evocative of a cattle barn rather than a quaint garden shed, yet despite its shortcomings, this venue boasts a convenient location and an enticing culinary selection. While it may not be a regular haunt of mine, I cannot deny its appeal to those seeking a lighthearted dining experience.

Oh, San Felipe's you sure did luck out by being right next to the stage at Tempe Marketplace.

Showed up at 7 on a Sat. Yep, I just missed their happy hour. They weren't very crowded.

Short line at the door for checking ID's. Have to wear a bracelet for 21+.

"Wait to be seated". So we wait, & then wait some more. The 2 girls lackadaisically wiping down menus don't say anything. We finally ask about the lack of a server & they finally want to put our name on a list. Gee thanks!

We sit at the bar & order drinks. Bam! The table we wanted on the patio is available. Yay!

We sit & wait. Wait. Wait. Server! Oh, this is the same girl who served us last time we were here.

Ok, basically you do a lot of waiting at this place. *sigh* Pathetic. It took FOREVER for my quesadilla to come. $4.95 for a small. Add $2 for chicken or steak & $3 for shrimp. It was decent. They didn't skimp on the chicken at least.

The heaters came on a little too soon. Got a little warm. Temp dropped & it became perfect. Heaters go off & stay off. Umm OK :(

There was no guy holding the men's restroom door open this time. I was so relieved, you have no idea.

So, why 3 stars this time? Free chips & bomb ass salsa. It's chunky & perfectly spicy with black eyed peas & corn. I want some in a bottle for my house please!

Have eaten here a few times before & was very satisfied...UNTIL THIS VISIT service a little slow had to wait 30 mins. for our burgers which tasted OK but were very much on the small side..we ordered the relapse which is smaller size offered but both of them were about the size patty you would get from Micky Dees so for $9 All I got was a $3 burger. I may have to rethink this visit before we go back again. Because we really like the place. Great people but not burgers on this visit.

"Culinary excellence was abundant at this establishment, which we had the pleasure of experiencing during a recent visit on a Sunday, which happened to fall within the duration of an extended weekend. Unfortunately, the kitchen was temporarily shut down during our tenure, which slightly impeded our ability to fully indulge in the delectable offerings. Notwithstanding, the ambiance of the venue was aesthetically pleasing, albeit not particularly sophisticated or high-end; it leaned more towards a welcoming atmosphere suitable for families or casual outings for couples on weeknights."

Watched Secret Life of Walter Mitty, the theater was ok. It reminded me of home in Stockton. It's quite small, but does the trick I suppose.
