The seats were not comfy and you have to 'look' up at the screen. It's really old fashion including the restroom. \n\nI guess if you have NOTHING else to do and want to see a movie, this is the place.

First visit to the Church Brew Works and can safely say it left a lot to be desired.  Had the Oktoberfest and the IPA and the schnitzel for dinner.  The beers were average, as was the main course.  The ambiance is phenomenal though.

They have an exceptional happy hour, albeit they only provide the happy hour food menu upon request. It is ill-advised to bring both your spouse and girlfriend to the identical venue. Then, things become significantly less joyful. Try the Ginger Bourbon Lemonade; it will surreptitiously affect you like a gay cellmate. Three of these, an irate mistress I attempted to palm off as an unremunerated vendor, and a wife with a predilection for keen cutlery does not constitute a successful happy hour, let alone a prosperous anything else. 
 The Friends with Benefits sushi rolls, which were delectable, should have served as a harbinger of impending calamity. Whatever variety of beverage my wife had, it possessed an agreeable fragrance that lingered on my attire the succeeding day. I speculate it was apples or a comparable fruit. The happy hour menu is no longer discounted by fifty percent, but it remains more economical than the standard menu.

While I retain the prerogative to elevate this rating, my visceral instincts suggest a rating of 3.5 stars, which, upon further deliberation, I have elected to round down to 3 stars, thereby reflecting my overall satisfaction with my dining experience at this establishment, albeit with certain reservations.

Service:  
5 stars. Although the clientele consisted merely of myself and two other patrons during my visit, the staff demonstrated exceptional hospitality and cordiality, thereby creating a welcoming ambiance that greatly enhanced my dining experience.

Food:  
2.5 stars. Despite my cognizance of the fact that the culinary offerings at this restaurant might not necessarily conform to my gastronomical expectations, I opted to sample their burger, which, unfortunately, did not meet my expectations. Specifically, the flat-grilled, hand-pattied, 1/2 pound beef patty lacked sufficient thickness to facilitate medium-rare cooking, resulting in an underwhelming flavor profile that was further exacerbated by the absence of any appreciable seasoning. Moreover, the fries accompanying the burger required salt to enhance their flavor, while the minuscule serving of coleslaw, whose quality was subpar, detracted from the overall dining experience.

Building:  
3 stars. The interior of the restaurant was well-maintained, boasting ample illumination and an inviting atmosphere that contributed to a pleasant dining environment.

Notwithstanding my mixed feelings regarding my dining experience, I remain inclined to revisit this establishment, particularly to sample their breakfast offerings.
Great little brunch spot. All local and organic food. Service was friendly, atmosphere was a little lacking. Will definitely go back.

"The 'build-your-own-burger' concept is hardly novel, but this particular establishment boasts an array of unconventional toppings and a diverse selection of buns. My culinary excursion led me to opt for a 1/3 pound brie (a decidedly underappreciated cheese for hamburgers) and ham burger. The resulting dish was profusely juicy and bursting with flavor. However, the gastronomic experience came at a considerable cost, as my burger tallied just shy of $10. Supplementary toppings such as bacon, ham, fried onions, and mushrooms incurred an additional $1 surcharge, while a secondary cheese selection demanded another $1. The standard lettuce, tomato, onions, and pickles exhausted the four complimentary toppings allotted per burger, leaving any further additions subject to a 50-cent upcharge. Furthermore, a solitary serving of fries fetched $3, rendering it advisable to divide the portion among multiple individuals. Lastly, the delectable yet pricey milkshakes merited a whopping $5, prompting me to emulate Vincent Vega's incredulous expression from Pulp Fiction. In conclusion, while the fare was undoubtedly scrumptious, the exorbitant prices precluded it from being a worthwhile indulgence, in my estimation."

Nothing like waiting 10 minutes at the bar to get service. Nothing like watching the other bartender hit on three girls while you sit there, waiting for this unseen bartender to quench your thirst with a tasty man soda. Even worse, the other bartender won't help you because it's "not his section, sorry." So we got a table and told the hostess why we were going to take a table to get a couple of beers and an appetizer. She didn't seem to care.

The manager even walked by, looked at us, and kept walking. He talked to at least 2 tables around us but skipped us for some reason.

What's really sad about this place is they have so much potential to be good and just fall flat. They have sooo many delicious beers and the staff doesn't know anything about beer.

This place apparently brews beer and has their own beer on tap but our server couldn't even sell us on trying it. He didn't know much about it. It sounded like he didn't know much about beer, which to me is bad if you have 30+ beers on tap and call yourself a pub.

My husband tried it and it was pretty decent; we were quite impressed but puzzled that the server couldn't tell us much about it.

The food was pretty good and didn't disappoint, but it did take a while to get it...

We probably won't be going back to this place again.

For the bad, it's a 1 star. But also for the bad, it's a 5 star. So I'm splitting the difference and going with 3 stars.

The Sirens of TI is like the ugly Christmas sweater. It's ugly and awful. But it's also fun and the theme of hip holiday parties. The Sirens of TI is so bad, it's kinda awesome.

If you go into this free show expecting something amazing, you will be disappointed. But if you approach this show like an ugly Christmas sweater holiday party - if you relish in the badness of it - you will have a good time and understand its awesomeness. If you go with the right mindset, you just might laugh so hard that tears stream down your face.

For best viewing, catch an early show. Prior to the club officially opening for the night, the patio area of Christian Audigier is open - and there is no cover. Access it from the outside. It's a perfect view as you are sitting right alongside one of the pirate ships. And you can sit and have a drink, as opposed to stand in the crowd and get shoved by small children who should not be allowed to view this show.

This place is never very busy, I LOVE THAT! And they have everything I need for my appliances and tool needs (when I'm not hanging out at that \"other\" tool store). I also love that they carry the piece for my refrigerator so I can change the water filter myself (it makes me feel handy and domestic). The customer service is helpful without being pushy.

I have been a fan of this place for a while. I have stayed here a few times throughout the years. I like the rooms, the only problem is the location of the casino from the strip. Although it is still super close walking distance. I love the 25cent wings after midnight. I like playing here as well. The only reason why I'm rating it a 3 star instead of a 4-5 star is because of the horrible rude staff there. Every single person I ran into that worked there had a horrible presence and talked to me like I wasn't worth there time. Which really made me mad. I'm a huge gambler and that made me just walk out the door.

Make sure you sit downstairs. Upstairs is fine, but ambiance downstairs is 100 % better. Preferably a seat on the far left, view overlooks the lovely Pittsburgh downtown skyline. Service was great. I did enjoy the swordfish. Shrimp appetizer was not bad. Food a little cookie cutter boring.

"Prior to my arrival, I had placed a telephonic order for a pasta-based culinary experience. Upon entering the establishment, I sampled two distinct dishes, specifically the chicken parmesan and an additional entree. While the sauces exhibited a satisfactory level of flavor, they were somewhat excessively salted, a characteristic that, ironically, corresponded with my personal preference for culinary sodium. However, despite the hospitable demeanor of both the proprietor and chef, I couldn't help but feel a sense of incongruity within the premises, almost as if my presence was unforeseen or unwelcome. It is worth mentioning that my attire, consisting of designer apparel and a luxury timepiece, may have contributed to this feeling of disparity, given the contrast between my appearance and the ambiance of the strip mall location. Notwithstanding, the edibles themselves were generally satisfying, with the exception of the aforementioned saltiness, which, though not necessarily detrimental, prevented me from fully indulging in their richness. In light of this, I am willing to grant the eatery a subsequent opportunity to demonstrate their gastronomic prowess, particularly with regards to their pizza offerings."

"The quality of the breakfast was unprecedented, with a duration of 8-0 hours, which I have never experienced before! The cost was reasonable, with all items priced at 4.90 EUR, and a discount of one euro for each beverage. However, the most expensive coffee of my life was 3.90 EUR for a large cup, which was quite disappointing compared to the standard coffee. The breakfast itself was satisfactory, but any additional requests incurred additional charges (no exchange of butter and marmalade for Nutella was possible). The service was attentive, friendly, and prompt."

It is an antiquated cinema, to say the least; I utterly abhor the parking arrangements here, albeit, I am under the impression that they are in the process of renovating it...I believe the service can be somewhat sluggish, and they urgently require additional ticket kiosks!!!! The seating is not particularly comfortable, and the screens are merely adequate. I attend this theater solely for its proximity to my domicile and the convenience of not having to traverse a bustling casino to access it; however, I must admit that it is one of the few cinemas that showcases a few independent documentaries and films that I rarely find elsewhere. Although, I previously believed that Village Square was a declining plaza, the influx of novel eateries instills hope that it may still flourish.

HOT TIP: Avoid being misled by the sign at the box office indicating that a kiosk within the lobby is available for use when there is a considerable queue outside. There tends to be a brief line for that solitary kiosk, and trust me, people are generally unfamiliar with its operation and expend an excessive amount of time utilizing it; thus, it is rather amusing.

After two hours of suffering in the YMCA half-marathon this weekend, my wife and I were driving back home and noticed The Nile Cafe. Well, to be fair, we noticed that there was a sign for a new coffee shop called Rev right next to the Quizno's. We got out of our car and noticed that Rev is still a shell with nothing in it, and we walked to the other side of the buildings and happened across Nile.

This place is so new it was tough to tell it was open. Nothing in the way of decoration, but so what? I don't eat paintings!

We just grabbed a large container of their Cilantro-Jalapeno hummus ($5.75)  and some pita bread and took it home. Let me tell ya, it's got some kick! It's definitely my favorite hummus, and I will try putting this even on things hummus doesn't belong on! 

I had to knock a couple stars off for the store-bought pitas. The Nile Cafe is gonna have to do better on the pitas to compete. But I still plan on rounding up some work friends and trying these guys for lunch. Schwarma, falafel, howashi and tabouli all sound good to me! The chicken curry soup sounds tasty, too.

I'll update this after my first real meal there. But go get some hummus. Seriously.

I have has Jason's before at catered luncheons and always enjoyed it,  but never ate in. Salad bar is a five! Very well stocked with everything you could want! However, I ordered the Mediterranean Wrap and it wasn't very good. The tortilla wrap was too thick/firm and the filling seemed meager. I wouldn't order it again. So disappointed!

"In the event that you are seeking East Coast style Chinese cuisine, this establishment constitutes a suitable venue for said purpose. Upon perusing their menu, we elected to exercise the option of ordering individual dishes, as opposed to partaking in the all-you-can-eat buffet, primarily due to our personal preference for selecting specific items. The culinary offerings did indeed meet our expectations, boasting generous portions, an adequate temperature, and a palpable freshness. However, it is worth noting that the waiting staff's proficiency in the English language leaves much to be desired, thereby resulting in a subpar level of customer service. Additionally, the ambiance of the dining area is somewhat marred by the audible shouts emanating from both the kitchen staff and the servers, which detracts from the overall dining experience. Furthermore, the decor appears somewhat antiquated and could benefit from a thorough cleaning. In light of these factors, we shall limit our patronage to their takeout services in the future."

We came here on a Thursday evening. 2 AYCE dinners. 15.12 each with boarding pass

- NEW Sign ups get a 2 for 1 buffet! 
- Already used it? Ask your friend to sign up and use theirs! haha. Cashiers don't check. Make sure you bring cash! haha :D
- 30-35min wait time at 8pm. Err'body hungay bruh. 
- $3.75 ATM fee. dammit! :/
- Nigiri sushi fail. I guess you have to come earlier
- Love the chinese fried chicken! small wings! better than the american style.
- Get the tofu stir fry! 
- Soups are tasty, even though a bit salty. get the hot and sour soup and chicken noodle!
- Always have to get tacos! Not as wet as Sunset Station
- BBQ ribs bonus! summer special! 
- Chopped sweet potatoes! At Sunset, they give you the whole piece!
The fried seafood is good, but a bit overpriced. I could get something almost as good at Long John Silvers for alot less. Overall, it was ok. Nothing to write home about.
Pretty good selection of items.  I have seen better.  The pharmacy people are really nice and helpful.  I would probably be back here to visit the pharmacy.

"A diverse array of culinary options, predominantly comprising comfort foods, with an emphasis on accessibility and unpretentiousness, which may cater effectively to the preferences of those who do not appreciate sophisticated gastronomic experiences. Additionally, the restaurant's welcoming atmosphere and well-prepared prime rib dishes make it a suitable destination for families, while the subpar quality of their coffee may prove disappointing to aficionados of the beverage."

Decent southern food. Great Biscuits!!  I would come here again to try their breakfast, but stopped in for the lunch.  Soup was amazing, but the southern fried catfish was very thin. I am used to southern cooking where the catfish is very thick and real good.  The fried okra was good as well.  I will be back to look into this place some more!

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

The original text expresses a negative opinion of a restaurant, stating that it does not offer the variety of options that a true "burger palace" would have. The speaker also mentions that the food is overpriced and that they would prefer to go to a different restaurant, specifically Five Guys.

To modify the text to use longer and more complex sentences, as well as professional vocabulary, we could revise it as follows:

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

This revised text maintains the same negative opinion of the restaurant, but uses more formal language and longer sentences to convey the speaker's disappointment. Instead of simply saying that the food is "a bit pricey," the revised text describes it as "overpriced," which implies a higher level of expensiveness. Additionally, the phrase "pretty basic menu" has been replaced with "limited culinary options," which uses more sophisticated vocabulary to convey the idea that the restaurant does not offer a wide variety of dishes. Finally, the revised text ends with a statement that the speaker would "rather go to Five Guys," which implies a preference for a different restaurant without explicitly stating it.

The food was a 3.5, the ambiance a 2. When we walked in the employees seemed surprised that we were there to eat.  The only menus that they have are paper to go menus which feel a little weird when you are eating in. They don't have any music or TV in the background which made us feel like we were intruding on their work. As they say, 'the silence was deafening.' The booth where we were seated had a large outdoor sign tucked behind it which awkwardly stuck out during our meal. The seating layout is also very strange. The good news is that the food was really good and they deliver. I think I may order delivery from them, but wouldn't dine in again. Rendezvous Cafe seems like a catering business, not a restaurant.

"The Saturday night Noches Caliente Latin Dance Party features a live band and an animated and fervent assemblage of local patrons and extramural visitors who are ardently devoted to engaging in rhythmic movement. The $10 entrance fee encompasses a beverage (with restrictions on the scope of available orders) and Live Entertainment Tax. There are seats with tables situated on three sides of the dance floor, offering unobstructed vistas of both the performance area and those partaking in the festivities. It is advisable to don footwear with adequate grip, as the wooden floor surface manifests a marked degree of slipperiness, exceeding expectations."

I usually love hole in the wall places.  The service usually ends up being great but the service here was a little slow and seemed in disarray.  I ordered the garlic bread which was your average bread and yummy.  The bolognese was great, but it's also hard to mess up bolognese in my opinion.  There wasn't anything super spectacular about it, so at the end of the day, very average.
Love Amsterdam! Went there forever ago for fun $2 martinis and manicures on Tuesday nights. The show is awesome too, there's no way to go and not have a fun time!

"Despite my non-Filipino ethnicity, I opted to partake in the culinary excursion with my colleagues as a commemoration of our recently concluded training program. Albeit my tardiness, the remnants of the feast appeared delectable indeed. The melodic ambiance was enjoyable, albeit somewhat unfamiliar to this New York City native, who is accustomed to more prevalent and diverse musical styles. However, the initial enthusiasm for karaoke waned substantially as the night progressed and the singing began. Notwithstanding, the hospitable atmosphere and opportunity to engage in a spirited salsa dance rendered the experience thoroughly enjoyable. In conclusion, I would unhesitatingly revisit this establishment, eager to savor the delectable fare and bask in the convivial ambiance once again."

"The location of this establishment renders it the optimal selection for any individual who forgets to bring sustenance to school (CSN), although the quality of the cuisine may vary. Specifically, my recent dining experience at this Chipotle was not the most satisfactory, in fact, it may have been the worst, due to the subpar service and questionable freshness of the ingredients. However, I did not allow the disappointing meal to deter me from completing my mission to consume a filling burrito, which I successfully accomplished by utilizing the microwave in Building Kilo to heat up my Smartpop. It is worth mentioning that there are also micro-ondas available in the Bravo building, which I discovered subsequent to my visit. \n\nIn conclusion, the temperature of the burrito was slightly lacking in warmth, and the appearance of the food during preparation did not exude the same level of freshness as the renowned Doug E. Fresh in the 1980s. Given that the restaurant was not bustling with customers during my early evening visit, it is plausible that a peak-hour excursion might provide a more accurate assessment of their culinary prowess. Notwithstanding, the carnitas burrito composed of brown rice, pinto beans, pico de gallo, and lettuce was adequate, and I thoroughly enjoyed every bite."

After making this post.  My husband received a call from the manager at pep boys.  Well I appreciate his apologizes for the poor service.  I do think the company and people should be aware of the problem we had experienced.  I am updating this review and adding stars because I think it does show a good manager trying to right a wrong situation so thanks.

"Undoubtedly delectable Thai cuisine, albeit with a price point that could be considered somewhat elevated, given the rather unremarkable surroundings. Multiple visits have consistently yielded savory and well-seasoned dishes, yet portion sizes tend to be somewhat diminutive. It is worth noting that the establishment exudes a strong odor of pine-sol or lysol, which has been known to cause headaches among patrons. Furthermore, the ambiance leaves much to be desired, as the restaurant is situated within a dilapidated shopping plaza, replete with unsavory establishments such as adult entertainment venues and massage parlors. The proximity to these questionable enterprises has led to unsightly incidents, including public displays of lewd behavior, which may render this eatery less than suitable for hosting out-of-town visitors. Notwithstanding, the male servers are generally quite affable and accommodating, while the female staff members at the front desk exhibit a markedly frosty demeanor."
Bring cash and small bills. There is a change machine that will give you back coins. They will change it out for bills in the gift shop, but avoid the hassle.

This is one of the few places in Vegas that does not try to rip you off. I think the best time to come to this restaurant is lunch time. They have great lunch specials at $5.99. I ordered grilled chicken with mashed potatoes and vegetables while my friend ordered the mushroom penne pasta. I think my grilled chicken was better than her mushroom penne dish. The chicken was a little dry, but immerse it in the mashed potatoes and all of a sudden it becomes okay.

The most annoying part about the experience is that there is a lady who comes over to your table and asks you if you want your picture taken so you can have a souvenir card. However, as much as this sounds enticing, it is a nuisance because once they bring you the postcard, they also try to sell you your picture. Beware, just kindly decline when this lady approaches you. I do not know why they do this. 

Also, the seats on the outside of the restroom are uncomfortable (they are plastic chairs). The seats in the restaurant look much more comfortable and I'd recommend sitting inside.

The service was very very slow. The waitresses and hostesses were dressed very young and not very professional. (I get this is a chill restaurant with a chill vibe, but when the employees look like they just left the gym with tight spandex leggings, form-fitting tank tops, and messy buns, I couldn't tell who worked there and who was dining there). However, the sweet potato tots were TO DIE FOR (I found myself craving them weeks later) and the burger was really good. I will definitely be back to try the PBJ & Bacon Burger that everyone has raved about, but the slow service could absolutely use some improvement.
Come for the Thursday trivia, stay for the bar fights. Reasonably priced rotating Great Lakes tap is also a plus.

I feel like a little bitch today, but please put down your drink so you can serve mine, especially after you are out of what you told me to order. Usually good beans, but shoddy service today...everywhere. Thanks millenials!

"Disappointing experience with too much repetition."

The original text expresses a negative sentiment towards a club that switches from being gay-friendly to straight-friendly after a certain time, which results in a lackluster atmosphere. To convey this message using longer and more complex sentences, as well as professional vocabulary, the modified text could be rewritten as follows:

"Underwhelming experience with an overemphasis on monotony."

This revised text maintains the same meaning as the original while incorporating more sophisticated language and sentence structure. It uses words such as "underwhelming," "monotony," and "switches" to convey the idea of a disappointing experience with too much repetition. Additionally, the phrase "gay-friendly to straight-friendly" has been replaced with "an environment that alternates between catering to diverse sexual orientations and gender identities." This modification not only makes the sentence longer but also more precise in its description of the club's transformation. Overall, the modified text adheres to the original meaning while utilizing more complex language and sentence structure.

"Pure, while not necessarily catering to a youthful demographic, does possess an ambiance that certain patrons might find appealing, particularly those who appreciate a more mature and refined atmosphere; the interior design, replete with flowing white drapery, evokes a sense of classical Grecian elegance. It is worth noting that during my previous visit, the bartender was in an advanced state of gestation, which, while not necessarily unusual, did strike me as somewhat remarkable. The venue's crowning jewel, however, lies in its uppermost level, where a rooftop bar offers a panoramic view of the Las Vegas Strip, an attribute that unquestionably enhances the overall experience of patronizing this establishment."

I tend to frequent this establishment more out of practicality than personal inclination, as it offers a diverse array of patrons and atmospheric conditions that are conducive to people-watching and social interaction. Although I have yet to experience the venue during nocturnal hours, I speculate that it transforms into an even more dynamic and intriguing setting, characterized by an amplified level of eccentricity and vitality. It appears that Metro SB is struggling to define its identity, oscillating between various roles and functions, including those of a dive bar, nightclub, eatery, and billiards hall. Notwithstanding, I shall persist in visiting this enigmatic locale, cognizant of the proprietors' preference for liquid assets and their provision of an ATM facility, which imposes an exorbitant service charge for the convenience of its patronage.

I've gotta go with A-OK on this one. Not quite ready to commit to being "a fan," yet. 

To me, being "a fan" would mean I would be willing to drive from North Central Phoenix all the way downtown, devil-may-care style on a work day, to wait in line and put up with the slamming of the metal door every time a customer's lunch order was fulfilled. (That's not a complaint, mind you. It was cool. All part of the charm.)

You see, dinner is not an option. They're only open until 4. 

That said, I obeyed Robert M.'s instructions and ordered a green chile burrito, enchilada style with a side of beans. The beans were runny but good for dipping my bites of burrito. The sauce that made it  "enchilada style" had a good heat. 

I was pleased. It was "A-OK." I'd go back. Just probably not devil-may-care on a work day.

I only got biscotti from the biscotti side. Flavors were good, consistency was meh. I don't know what it is about my experience with PIT, but I thought the Italian food was supposed to be better than what I've been getting.\n\nFor some reason, it was just overly crumbly. It fell apart, like dust. Perhaps it was the humidity?

Went to Koi in July.  Just realized I didn't write a review. \nI wanted to eat at the Sushi bar, unfortunately it is not wheelchair accessible, so I ate in the main dining area. My server was very nice and apologetic about it.I ordered Sushi anyway. My standard Salmon and Eel. It was very good, but much smaller portions than at Simon. I also ordered the Sunset roll, which was Eel an cucumber inside with Avocado and special sauce on top. Another very good dish.  I had a Sake flight with my food.  This is a very nice way to try several types without sliding out of my chair!   I wish it was more wheelchair accessible, but I did enjoy the food and I am going back in a couple weeks to give it another try! Probably more like 3 1/2 stars.

A acquaintance of mine desired to convene at TT Roadhouse, thus I ended up at said establishment.  She informed me that it possessed an intriguing jukebox, however upon my arrival, I discovered that it did not live up to my expectations.  While it exuded a certain punk rock ambiance, I managed to locate a few tracks by Jawbreaker that somewhat alleviated my disappointment.  The beverages were priced reasonably, and the patrons did not consist of the stereotypical Old Scottsdale demographic.  Although unremarkable, it remains a viable option for those in the vicinity...

"The hospitality proffered at this establishment is truly commendable, boasting an accommodating and amiable staff who ensure that patrons feel welcome and well taken care of.  While the culinary offerings may not be utterly flawless, they are undoubtedly satisfactory, with the chicken makhani emerging as a standout dish worthy of high praise.  In contrast, the tikka masala falls somewhat short of exceptional quality, although it remains palatable.  Furthermore, the naan and paratha prove to be additional highlights of the menu, showcasing the kitchen's ability to craft delectable flatbreads that complement the various curries and stews available."

"Pretty Good Airline overall, more of a Bus in the Sky if you will, taking into account the fact that it provides an atmosphere not dissimilar to that of a bus, albeit one that transcends terrestrial constraints and offers an experience that is arguably more convenient and efficient, given the lack of traffic lights, pedestrians, and other obstacles that can impede the progress of a bus on the ground; I have actually grown to appreciate the anything goes, sit-where-you-want policy they have adopted, which contributes to an ambiance that is decidedly relaxed and informal, although it may not be to everyone's taste; minus 1 star because they always seem to take an inordinate amount of time to unload the baggage here, which can be a source of frustration for those who are eager to retrieve their belongings and proceed with their travel plans, but it is worth noting that they have yet to misplace or lose any luggage, a problem that has been known to occur in other airports such as Burbank and Sacramento."

A small family owned business that I frequent often,  they have excellent pastries and bread!  It would be nice if they expanded on spices and sauces and some other traditional items. 

Word of caution:  I don't know if it a supply and demand issue but the shelves are often very empty...so don't go at the last minute as you may not find what you ate looking for. 

Be sure to get a slice of apple strudel!

"The gastronomical experience at this establishment was truly exceptional, as one would anticipate from a Wynn-affiliated venue. The lobsters were meticulously prepared, boasting a succulent texture that was complemented by a flavorful seasoning, while the filet was cooked to perfection, achieving a harmonious balance between tenderness and juiciness. The ambiance of the facility was equally impressive, exuding an air of sophistication and elegance. However, it was the service that proved to be the Achilles' heel of our dining experience, detracting significantly from the overall enjoyment. The host staff demonstrated a commendable level of professionalism, warmly greeting us and guiding us to the bar area until our table was ready, and subsequently addressing us by name when inviting us to our table. Unfortunately, the quality of service deteriorated substantially thereafter, with our waiter and table staff exhibiting a remarkable lack of attentiveness, neglecting to check in on us post-food arrival, and necessitating repeated calls for drink refills, even resorting to impolite gestures to hail the attention of passing wait staff. While the price point can be considered reasonable within the context of Las Vegas dining options, the subpar service we received will likely dissuade me from returning to this restaurant with guests in the future, thereby rendering Botero a preferable alternative at Wynn."

I'm lucky that I'm able to come during a time when everyone is at work, so I can't really comment on the busy times. 

My biggest complaint? One of the check-in staff is the rudest person I've ever encountered. He never says hi, I have to ask for a towel each time, and he's just straight up impersonal, almost to the point of being hostile. Dude. If you don't like your job, get another one. Everyone else I've ever checked in with manages to make eye contact, say hello, and glance at the screen to know that I get a towel.

Other than that, I enjoy coming here because it's clean, fast, and people don't really bug you.

I am experiencing an elevated sense of enthusiasm concerning the expanded culinary options currently available. Following a query posed to two representatives of the establishment regarding the precise moment at which these novel selections were introduced, neither individual proved cognizant of the specifics. Consequently, I have deduced that their implementation must have occurred recently. My gratification with the culinary excellence of the burger I consumed was somewhat diminished by its preparation, specifically that it had been cooked beyond the point of optimal doneness. In light of this, I shall endeavor to specify a less well-done preparation during future orders. Furthermore, my request for thermally treated potato strips was fulfilled, yet my offspring expressed dissatisfaction with the accompanying beer cheese. Following our communication of this discrepancy to the server, we were informed that the cheese in question was not of the customary orange hue and texture, but rather appeared more akin to a thin, white liquid. Additionally, the price of this item was $7, which seemed excessive in relation to its quality. The dish in question consisted of small, bite-sized pieces of pretzels, accompanied by the aforementioned beer cheese. Upon sampling the cheese, both myself and my offspring concurred that its flavor was unremarkable and lacking in depth, bearing little resemblance to the characteristic tanginess of beer cheese. Indeed, the absence of any discernible flavor was so pronounced that I felt compelled to convey my disappointment to the server, who failed to demonstrate a convincing level of belief in my account or offer any form of compensation. This response was unexpected, as I would have anticipated a greater degree of concern and perhaps even a complimentary replacement. My offspring, having opted for an appetizer in lieu of a main course, left me feeling somewhat remorseful. However, my satisfaction with the broader range of menu items has increased my inclination to revisit this establishment and sample one of the newly listed sandwiches. Previously, my associations with Goldies had been limited to burgers, chicken wings, and pizzas. Now, I look forward to exploring the diversified array of offerings.

Came here to get a full body massage.  It was okay.  The one thing I didn't like is that since it is just one big room, you get distracted by hearing other people chatting, walking about, and some even make noises when they get massaged.  I kinda wish they would separate the beds by a screen or something.  I wasn't totally relaxed but I guess that's what you get for the price you pay. 

The lady that did my massage was nice, at first she was gentle but she went pretty hard on my shoulders...and they're still sore the next day.  

The other weird thing is that when you go pay at the front, your masseurs go to the front and just wait for you to tip them.  It's like they won't leave or let you leave till they get tipped.

It was definitely an experience, but I probably won't be going there again.

"My rating of three stars, rather than five, is predicated upon several factors, which I will now expound upon. Firstly, the ambiance was unremarkable, bordering on uninviting. As a wine enthusiast, I anticipate an atmosphere that is, at the very least, reminiscent of a sophisticated gathering. Instead, the dearth of melodic accompaniment, the scarcity of patrons, and the taciturn demeanor of the staff created an environment that felt more akin to a library than a wine cellar. Furthermore, the bruschetta, a dish that typically serves as a harbinger of culinary delight, fell short of my expectations. The bread, lacking the rustic charm of its artisanal counterpart, was uninspired in both texture and taste. However, certain dishes did manage to surpass my expectations. The mushroom risotto, for instance, was a gastronomic masterpiece, its rich, earthy flavors melding together in perfect harmony. Similarly, the twisted burger and mac and cheese showcased the chef's proficiency in creating dishes that are both satisfying and innovative. The service, attentive and courteous, rounded out the dining experience nicely. In conclusion, while my husband and I did enjoy our meal, the evening's overall experience may not be memorable enough to warrant a repeat visit."

After I found out that Sephora stocks Korres products I headed over to the new store in Fairview, Pointe Claire. Apparently Sephora Quebec doesn't stock Korres but Ontario stores do, due to packaging regulations (i.e language, as Korres products are in Greek and English)

Completely ridiculous and another reason consumers will always find a way to buy elsewhere if they don't get access to what they want. So I can shop online at SkinStore.com and only pay 5$ shipping from the USA for an entire order.

Apart from that, Sephora did have a great selection of brands, not all girly, if you know what you are looking for.   Staff were very helpful and  love to to direct you to the $150 creams (sorry couldn't resist). I would recommend researching the brands first though, many may just be in there because they have compliant packaging rather than really being the best brands you can buy. Many were missing in the store from the Sephora website. The prices seemed inline with elsewhere i.e. Dr. Hauschka prices were the same as Olgivy's, but again, I would compare as some products may have a premium attached to the price simply because you can't readily get access to that brand elsewhere in Montreal. 

Another thing that sucks is that on the Sephora website orders in the US over 50$ are free, however Canadian orders it's over $150 to get free shipping, Again, check out skinstore.com

"An open-air shopping plaza catering to the needs and preferences of an older demographic, offering a pleasant ambulatory experience on temperate days, replete with ubiquitous misting systems and an array of dining establishments serving diverse culinary options."

"The further they move up Eastern, the less I tend to enjoy them. My family and I have been patrons of this establishment for years, purchasing birthday cakes and other pastries, but unfortunately, we have noticed a decline in quality over time. When I first returned from Korea, I was eager to visit Freed's Bakery, as I had missed their delectable treats during my time abroad. Their strawberry shortcake, black forest cake, and fruit tarts were among my favorites, but upon subsequent visits, I noticed that the cakes had become excessively sweet and somewhat dry. It is possible that my palate has evolved, but simultaneously, their prices have also increased. It seems that the quality of their products has not kept pace with their rising costs. Additionally, some patrons have mentioned that the service at Freed's can be inconsistent, ranging from attentive and friendly to neglectful, with staff occasionally disappearing for extended periods, leaving customers unattended."

Decided to take the family here after receiving a coupon and was intrigued by the all natural concept. We loved the decor and the place seemed clean. We were immediately disappointed when we discovered the lack of a kids menu. We were informed by the staff that we could order anything plain. So we get to pay $6 for a burger for our 6 year old. Same with the hot dogs. You pay for a Chicago dog and then tell them to hold all the good stuff.  Fries are separate although the large seemed to feed us all. We ordered waters and were presented with 5 shot glass sized plastic cups. I realize they make money on drinks but this is Arizona!  We need water. 

The only saving grace is that the food was pretty good. The burgers were small but had good flavor.  Just wondering how American cheese made into an all natural place.

We may come back, but I doubt we will make a special trip.

Our contingent opted to lodge here during our sojourn in Las Vegas. Personally, I would have vastly preferred to reside in a coarse, unsophisticated lodging, such as a burlap sack, considering the ambiance presented by this establishment. It is discernible that restorations necessitate both financial resources and temporal expenditures; however, it is quite astonishing that the management has not endeavored to upgrade the quality of their accommodations to correspond with the exorbitant nature of their gaming facilities. It appears that each of the four structures designated for lodging purposes has been deliberately designed to provide an atmosphere of stark simplicity, with minimal furnishings and meager amenities. My acquaintance had the misfortune of being assigned to the oldest edifice, which featured merely two beds and a television set. The reception staff displayed an utter lack of concern towards our plight, while the luggage porter gave us a malevolent stare, as if we were responsible for his dissatisfaction. Although I could not express any grievances regarding my own quarters, I couldn't help but ruminate on why the proprietors have chosen not to refurbish all of their rooms to match the opulence of their gaming facilities. The World Fare Buffet was utterly revolting, and the dining options within the casino itself left much to be desired, consisting solely of mediocre establishments. In order to elevate their standing among the numerous hotel-casinos populating the renowned Las Vegas Strip, drastic improvements must be implemented to enhance the overall experience offered by this venue.

DH & I went to Upper Crust for Happy Hour. We had a pizza and wings, which were on happy hour specials. The pizza was good, similar to the grimaldi's style. The wings were a one star. The ambiance was a little dark, could use some color. Lots of TV's to watch any game were available.

I was genuinely conflicted about whether to confer three or four stars upon H&H, as my experience was characterized by both positive and negative aspects. 
  The quality of the cocktails was unremarkable, lacking any distinguishing features or exceptional elements, yet still maintaining a level of craftsmanship. 
  The ambiance and decor were unimpressive, with an underwhelming sense of emptiness attributed to both the sparse population and the absence of any extraordinary features. 
  Our visit took place on a Sunday evening, specifically at around 8 pm, which may have contributed to the dearth of patrons. 
  The service was adequate, with a single bartender attending to our needs, but their demeanor was somewhat indifferent, as they failed to demonstrate enthusiasm when discussing the cocktails and instead offered a cursory assurance that all options were equally excellent. 
  We opted for two particular cocktails: Agnatha & Anni and August 21st, 1959.  My Agnatha was quite enjoyable, with its crisp, tart, and robust flavors, although the presence of minute ice shards was slightly bothersome; however, this issue was quickly resolved as the ice dissolved.  The August 21st was relatively unremarkable, possessing a smoky essence that, while not aligning with my personal preferences, may appeal to those who appreciate such characteristics. 
  Despite some reservations, I would still consider revisiting H&H due to its convenience, abundant street parking, proximity, passable drinks, and lack of concerns regarding seating availability.

Great Sushi have to try the spicy tuna..I also tried the Fillet mignon steak & chicken and was a bit dissipointed. The chicken was a bit dry.. But after I asked for some teriyaki sauce... It was all god again...Over all I was impressed.. When I'm back in town I defently will be stopping back by to try somthing different...

This is definitely not the place to go if you have older children.  This place is catered for kids under the age of 8.  They do have laser tag though which can entertain the older kids- but beware of the little ones in there too!

"Although the culinary offerings at this establishment are satisfactory, they fail to elicit any remarkable impression, neither does any item on the menu stand out as particularly delectable nor does it arouse any discernible aversion; rather, the fare served here tends to be unremarkable and lackluster, almost as if the dishes were fabricated from pre-packaged or frozen ingredients, which may account for the absence of any distinctive flavor or texture that would otherwise render them memorable."

"Indulging in gatherings at the prestigious Ritz Carlton has led us to indulge in the hotel's esteemed bar and restaurant, Bistro 24, which has proven to be a delightful and serendipitous experience, particularly on a Friday evening. The Grill Night buffet has surpassed our expectations, offering an array of delectable delights that would satiate even the most discerning palates.

The appetizer buffet boasts an impressive selection, featuring Blue Point oysters, lobster bites, seared tuna adorned with wasabi cream, bite-sized filet mignon, succulent shrimp, duck, and an assortment of artisanal cheeses. Moreover, a dedicated sushi stand showcases an array of expertly crafted sushi rolls, further elevating the dining experience.

The outdoor grill station offers a veritable feast for carnivores, with mouthwatering filet mignon, lamb chops, organic salmon, and grilled shrimp accompanied by creamy mashed potatoes and a medley of grilled vegetables. To cap off this gastronomic journey, a decadent dessert stand beckons with its tantalizing treats, while an extensive wine list provides the perfect accompaniment to this epicurean adventure."

I perused all the critiques prior to investing in the Groupon, hence I was cognizant of what to anticipate. As I possess the attribute of being an accomplished procrastinator, I postponed scheduling my appointment until it was practically expired. Fortuitously, the young lady was capable of accommodating me within a few days of the deadline! They assigned the females to collaborate, with Jennifer undertaking my manicure while Kelly performed my pedicure. Both young women executed their tasks proficiently, exhibiting cordiality throughout the approximate duration of ninety minutes. My dual laments are as follows: 1) The positioning of the chairs rendered it somewhat uncomfortable, as I sat sideways for the pedicure and rotated my torso for the manicure, whereas I noticed they possessed a chamber furnished with couches for solely pedicure recipients, appearing considerably more comfortable. 2) I failed to perceive an adequate assortment of hues for my preference, as I incline toward neutral tones. Upon utilizing my Groupon, I retain one additional discounted visit, subsequent to which I shall be subject to the full tariff, which does not compare favorably with the cost of visiting a salon. Although I do not indulge in having my nails treated frequently, I aspire to revisit the establishment in the near future.

"The culinary offerings and hospitality we experienced during our recent visit were truly exceptional, representing a remarkable upgrade from the mediocre fare and lackluster service we have grown accustomed to in recent times; however, it is worth noting that our enjoyment of the establishment's ambiance was slightly marred by the presence of an unsettling individual accompanied by his canine companion, whose questionable adherence to basic sanitary standards left us feeling somewhat apprehensive regarding the overall cleanliness and safety of the premises, despite the otherwise excellent quality of the food and beverages served."

A friend and I made reservations here during Restaurant Week. The atmosphere was welcoming, if a bit sterile-feeling, but the drinks were tasty and potent. I started with the Pickle Plate, which had a variety of pickled veggies. For my entree I had the  pan-seared trout with barley risotto. It was nicely prepared and very tasty. For dessert I had the key lime pie (because I can never say \"no\" to key lime pie).\n\nOverall, it was a pleasant experience and I'm definitely looking forward to returning and trying the regular menu.

"My maiden visit to Vintage transpired on February fourteenth, whereupon I opted to partake in an alfresco dining experience adjacent to a crackling conflagration, thereby evoking an atmosphere of refined elegance. Moreover, their signature Sangria proved to be an unparalleled delight, capable of titillating even the most discerning palate. It is worth mentioning that on most Saturday evenings, Vintage plays host to a talented local songstress named Sarah, whose melodious performances are certain to captivate audiences and imbue them with an unwavering sense of euphoria. In essence, this esteemed establishment serves as an ideal venue for either a romantic escapade or a relaxed gathering among acquaintances."

This establishment has consistently served as our preferred destination for Chinese cuisine in a buffet setting, particularly given our prolonged residency in Las Vegas and exposure to numerous Chinese restaurants that have come and gone. The quality of their offerings has remained unwavering, with a sushi bar that boasts impeccable freshness and attention to detail, including timestamped labels indicating the time of preparation for optimal freshness assurance. Furthermore, their Mongolian barbecue station presents an extensive array of options for customizable Chinese dishes, which are promptly cooked to order, resulting in an unparalleled culinary experience. Spacious in size, this venue accommodates a large volume of patrons, leading to a high turnover rate of dishes and minimizing the likelihood of encountering cold or nearly empty plates. Instead, an abundance of fresh, steaming dishes awaits, showcasing a diverse selection ranging from crawfish to soups, fried rice, wanton soup, fried wontons, potstickers, mussels, hot wings, and even pizza for children. The value offered by this restaurant easily justifies the cost, ensuring a satisfying experience for diners. Enjoy!

It is imperative that we provide an update regarding Bricktop's, as the culinary experience offered therein is truly exceptional and worthy of elaboration. While the celestial bodies remain unchanged, my acquaintance's laudatory melody inspired me to expound upon the delectable nature of their brunch offerings. Hence, my companion and I ventured forthwith to sample the gastronomical delights proffered by this esteemed establishment in SouthPark.  

Bricktop's brunch menu boasts an array of innovative dishes, aligning with their contemporary American eclectic style, akin to their lunch and dinner selections. Patrons may create their own bloody mary cocktails at the bar, complemented by an assortment of specialty beverages such as blood orange mimosas and bellinis served by the carafe â?an absolute delight.  

During my successive brunch excursions, I have had the pleasure of savoring the same scrumptious entree â?French Toast. This sumptuous dish consists of generous slices of brioche bread, skillfully cooked to a golden brown perfection, accompanied by an assortment of sweet caramelized bananas, warm maple syrup, fluffy whipped cream, and crispy bacon strips. Although somewhat indulgent, this treat is undoubtedly worth the modest price of $11. For those seeking an additional decadent indulgence, the bite-sized homemade doughnut appetizer, comprising thirteen sugary doughnuts paired with three diverse dipping sauces â?raspberry, chocolate, and vanilla cream â?is an absolute must-try.  

While the cost of partaking in Bricktop's brunch extravaganza may escalate somewhat owing to the liberal consumption of mimosas, the culinary experience is indubitably worth the financial investment. Thus, I wholeheartedly recommend paying a visit to this esteemed eatery and relishing in the delectable fare they offer.

"Cantina undeniably excels in providing an exceptional dining experience, offering a wide array of delectable cuisine and potent potables that cater to the discerning palate. Despite its unassuming exterior, this establishment is often bustling with a vibrant clientele, particularly during peak hours, thereby necessitating advance reservations to avoid prolonged waiting periods. Rest assured, the delay will be inconsequential, as the culinary offerings and hospitable ambiance are well worth the brief interval.  

Cantina presents an extensive selection of premium Mexican libations, including their signature margaritas, which are undoubtedly among the finest in the city. For those who crave something divergent, the Kiwi/Strawberry Special is an exquisite alternative. Additionally, an assortment of quality Mexican brews is available on tap for your pleasure. Imbibe liberally, as everyone else is indulging in the same manner.  

Their menu boasts an impressive variety of dishes, leaving patrons spoiled for choice. For a lighter repast, the chopped tostada salad is an unparalleled option. Alternatively, heartier appetites will be satiated by the flavorful refried beans and tender pulled chicken. However, the true piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance lies in the Kobe beef fajitas, which are an absolute must-try. Suffice it to say, Cantina warrants repeated visits. Nonetheless, it's advisable to refrain from planning an energetic evening subsequent to dining, as the convivial atmosphere and satisfying fare will leave you suitably sated and exhausted."
The food here is fantastic. It gets really busy at lunch time so you should either come early or late if you want to sit down when you get there.

"Inexpensive alcoholic beverages and satisfactory culinary offerings are readily available in this establishment, which caters to individuals seeking an unpretentious atmosphere; however, patrons should anticipate and accept the possibility of increased decibel levels, as such an environment is customary in a working-class drinking establishment."

During our sojourn in Montreal, we engaged in some retail therapy and happened upon a quaint watering hole that offered a respite from the exorbitant prices typically associated with such establishments. The al fresco seating afforded us an excellent vantage point for observing the local populace, and the hospitality of the staff was truly commendable. Unfortunately, the absence of culinary options - with the exception of the grilled cheese sandwiches that were prepared on a diminutive hot plate behind the bar - proved to be a minor letdown.

Borealis, an eatery nestled in the environs of Cambridge, boasts an unparalleled culinary experience, courtesy of its steadfast commitment to the mantra 'think globally, act locally.' This philosophy translates into a scrupulous emphasis on locally-sourced ingredients, with the restaurant's provisions and beverages being procured from the surrounding Waterloo Region or within the confines of Ontario. The resultant cuisine is consistently impressive, albeit subject to occasional fluctuations in menu items owing to the vagaries of local availability and the whims of the chef. Patrons can indulge in a diverse array of Ontario brews and vintages, showcasing the region's rich oenological heritage, while the interior ambiance exudes a warm, welcoming charm, reminiscent of a bygone era. A spacious concrete patio graces the entrance of the edifice, further enhancing the allure of this gastronomic haven. Although the tariff may prove prohibitive for regular visits, the exceptional fusion of gastronomy, libations, and ambiance that Borealis offers warrants a rating of four stars, thereby recommending it to epicures seeking a truly distinctive dining experience.

"This establishment purveys an array of items that are either exceptional or lackluster, which is a common trait among consignment shops. However, I have had the privilege of discovering a few desirable pieces during each visit. These include babyGap denim trousers and an assortment of other distinguished labels such as Janie and Jack and The Children's Place. I hold this store in high regard and now, as I am expecting once more, I shall have to investigate their maternity department as well."
Don't be put off by the name if you are not a wine fan -- there is plenty to drink.  Went there for lunch and was very impressed by the efficient and friendly staff as well as good food.

Where the sauce is the boss and the toast is the most. Canes chicken doesn't have anything really spacial about it and the fries are not anything exciting either. But the sauce is amazing i have to get four extra every time to dip my chicken and my fries in it. I am a fan of slaw but canes slaw is pretty bland so I usually substitute more toast for the slaw.

I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Both locations are great, but I prefer the west side. They have over 20 vegetarian selections and I gotta tell you I am a creature of habit and I would eat here every day if I could. They have some of the most amazing salads, try the Bruschette Salad and the Athens Fries are amazinggggg.

"Oh, what a delightful culinary escapade I embarked upon in Henderson! Meandering aimlessly in search of a delectable luncheon, my peregrinations led me to an array of unremarkable chain restaurants that failed to entice my gastronomical inclinations. Just as I was about to resign myself to the uninspired fare of Taco Bell, my gaze alighted upon an unexpected oasis amidst the arid retail landscape - a newly established Trader Joe's! 

Boasting an immaculate interior replete with expansive aisles and an abundance of tantalizing products, this novel emporium exuded an irresistible appeal, its pristine atmosphere redolent of the invigorating scent of a new automobile. Furthermore, the absence of the throngs of patrons that often beset the San Francisco locations rendered the experience even more enjoyable. 

My attention was captivated by the pre-prepared sandwich section, which offered several vegetarian options. Opting for the PB&J sandwich lunch bag at a most reasonable price of $3.49, I was introduced to an unprecedented gustatory combination that piqued my interest. This innovative offering comprised a half PB&J sandwich accompanied by a diminutive bag of freshly cut green apples, a similarly sized packet of 100-calorie cookies, a length of string cheese, and a small bottle of water. Although the sandwich itself was not without its flaws - the bread exhibited a certain dryness, while the peanut butter and jelly filling displayed an uncommon stiffness in texture - the assortment of complementary edibles in the bag ensured that my gastronomic excursion remained thoroughly satisfying. 

At a mere $3.49, I consider this culinary adventure an unmitigated success. My fervent hope is that fate will smile upon me, allowing me to encounter this delightful Trader Joe's creation once again upon my return to San Francisco."

There are not many restaurant choices in this area so Squid Ink satisfies that sushi craving! I order carry-out more often than dining in and service is usually quick and food is decent. Happy hour is very good as long as you prefer the less creative rolls. I recommend it but it is a little pricey for the quality.
People honestly review airports? As if you have options? As if you honestly decide whether or not to visit a city because of it's airport? The fact this this has 800+ reviews blew my mind!

"Although Tryst may no longer be considered the premier IT destination in Las Vegas, having been surpassed by the likes of Marquee and XS, it still boasts an undeniable charm and appeal. As the sister venue of XS, it shares a similar ambiance, complete with an outdoor waterfall and atmospheric lighting that envelops the surrounding area. The club's interior is equipped with poles that invite female patrons to showcase their dancing prowess, while the male counterparts enthusiastically capture their performances on their mobile devices. The musical offerings at Tryst were quite satisfactory, and despite the crowded state of the bars, our group of four, comprising two females and two males, opted to venture to Tryst at approximately 1 am, following a lackluster showing of the production, KA, and indulging in complimentary drinks at the casino tables. Prior to our arrival, I had taken the initiative to place my name on a host's guest list; however, upon arriving at the entrance at 1 am, which lies beyond the designated guest list time frame, the courteous door staff allowed us admittance without any issues or additional charges, thereby enhancing our overall clubbing experience and allowing us to maintain our elevated mood."

"Although the eatery's ambiance may not be particularly elaborate or sophisticated, the culinary offerings more than compensate for any perceived deficiencies in terms of aesthetic appeal. Indeed, the flavors and aromas emanating from the kitchen are reminiscent of those found in establishments featured on the popular food network show, Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives. In fact, the quality and presentation of the dishes served at Flavors of Louisiana are such that one might surmise that the proprietors have successfully implemented a formula for creating an unparalleled gastronomical experience. The essence of this formula seems to lie in the harmonious marriage of various ingredients, skillfully combined to produce a symphony of flavors that tantalize the palate and satisfy even the most discerning of diners. Furthermore, the absence of an excessive amount of grease in the dishes allows the natural flavors of the components to shine through, thereby enhancing the overall enjoyment of the meal. Additionally, the generous portions served at Flavors of Louisiana make it an excellent value for the price, especially considering the high quality of the cuisine. While a liquor license would undoubtedly enhance the dining experience by allowing patrons to enjoy a cold beverage alongside their meal, it is not necessary to appreciate the exceptional quality of the food. In conclusion, Flavors of Louisiana is an exemplary establishment that sets itself apart from other restaurants in the area due to its commitment to serving delectable and satisfying dishes that showcase the rich culinary heritage of Louisiana."

"Upon finally indulging in the culinary offerings of Caffe Boa, I must admit that my expectations were surpassed by the gastronomical delights presented before me. Following the unfortunate spectacle of Payton's porcine butchery at Devoured, I felt compelled to sample the fare of this establishment, and I am pleased to report that my experience was largely satisfactory. \n\nThe colossal paper cone of french fries that I requested as an appetizer was indeed impressive, and the accompanying sauces elevated the dish to a level of unparalleled flavor. However, my selection of a calzone as the main course proved to be a questionable decision, as it failed to meet my expectations of a traditional calzone. Although the flatbread housing the ingredients was unique and enjoyable, the overall composition of the dish struck me as somewhat unconventional. While the quality of the ingredients within the calzone was undeniable, I cannot claim that it fully satisfied my cravings. Nonetheless, the service provided by the staff was commendable, and I appreciated the ambiance of the patio area. Unfortunately, the uninspired atmosphere of the strip mall in which Caffe Boa resides detracted from my overall satisfaction."

If you have perused a few of my critiques, you would be cognizant of the fact that I do not frequently visit or endorse numerous franchise eateries. However, Texas Roadhouse constitutes one of the rare exceptions to this rule. I have had the pleasure of dining at eight distinct establishments across five separate states, and each experience has been characterized by satisfactory service, meticulously prepared steaks, and an exceptional value proposition. This particular location upholds the same lofty standards, boasting a commendable server, delectable fare, and a seamless call-ahead seating system that minimizes waiting time to a mere sixty seconds.

"Smooth, rich, flavorful...vegan? Although initially skeptical about sampling soy gelato (soy-lato?), my reservations were promptly dispelled upon indulging in the spicy chocolate variant. While both the chocolate soy and regular mixed berry renditions were palatable, the latter exhibited a slightly icy texture in contrast to the former's velvety consistency. The spicy chocolate iteration, in particular, boasted an abundance of rich, smooth flavor with a satisfying spicy kick, devoid of any discernible'soy' undertones. Furthermore, they offer an array of flavors, inclusive of sugar-free options, making it an excellent destination for indulging one's sweet tooth."

Literally hadn't been here in years. Went today to see 'Takin over the Asylum' and it was a great production! The theatre itself is beautiful, very classical with a massive chandelier and everything! Students get \u00a35 tickets on Wednesday matinees too!

I have to laugh b/c this is the second time I find myself quoting Nicole W. but she said it best "Alexander Michael's is the quintessential go-to spot for solid food, good drinks and superb company all packaged into a quaint little spot in the 4th ward."

Especially if you live within walking distance, this is a place you will go again and again for an uncomplicated place to find simple food done right with quality beer selections.  I had the chicken pita.  I was not expecting that the chicken would be perfectly cooked, seasoned and the pita warm and robust.  A side of beans satisfied an additional protein craving without the temptation of the go-to french fries.

The place is too cute explaining on the back of the menu why there is a beam in the ladies room which finds itself the victim of unsuspecting visitors who inevitably find themselves in close contact with the supporting structure.  They also give some history on the house which makes good reading while you wait for your first round to show up.  

Small complaint that again, tv in the dining area.  I guess many people eat in front of the television at home and grow accustom to it?  Also, low ceilings make for a cozy atmosphere.  Probably not the #1 place for enjoying the natural sunlight of a gorgeous day.

This place is sweet, I highly recommend it.  When you walk in the door be sure to look down at the floor because you're standing on a fish tank - pretty cool.  The decor is very trendy and the atmosphere is chill.  We had a drink at the bar on a Weds. night before heading out to the patio for dinner - not overly crowded which was nice.  The sushi was delicious - quality pieces and very fresh.  My only complaint was the bathroom sink - while very cool looking, the faucets don't work unless you slam the handle in and then the water just sprays out sporadically.  This was a little messy but the rest of the experience was great.

What a great "Americana" restaurant! This place brings back so many memories of what used to be very popular restaurant's back in the day ~  the buffet/cafeteria's.  This Furr's is conveniently located just west of the 101 Hwy on Grand and Sun City.  You can tell this Furr's has been around since the fifties based on their sign and building but they have done a very nice job maintaining everything inside and out.  

I had a very enjoyable lunch last with some fellow Yelper's; Rand H., Mike C. and Scott W..  This Furr's is a cafeteria however once you go through the line once, you can go back as many times as you like to, all for the same price of $7.39.  I really liked this concept because your not picking through what other the prior people have handled ~ you know what I mean!  You choose what you want and they serve it to you.  

They have most of the traditional "Americana" food options to choose from.  I recommend when you first go through the line asking for smaller portions and trying more varieties of things.  This way you can refill on what you really like without over stuffing yourself.  Everything was very tasty and fresh.  I'm looking forward to going back to this Furr's so hopefully I will see you there.

Ive been to Culvers alot. My son loves it and the cheese curds are A-mazing! I always felt like it was a bit pricey for \"fast food\" until I went to five guys... wow! Id pay the extra money for a butter burger anytime! Culvers is way better than any fast food burger place in Surprise hands down and also better than five guys and half the cost. I will never complain about the prices again. The shakes are good. The burgers and fries are good and as I said before.. cheese curds for the Win! :)

"I have been indulging in the luxury of bringing esteemed individuals to this exquisite establishment for a quarter of a century, relishing in the ambiance and delectable cuisine that has consistently impressed my guests, whether it be for commemorating momentous occasions, bidding farewell to respected educators, or simply treating out-of-town visitors to an unforgettable Sunday repast."

Pretty damned good vegan and vegetarian food for not a whole lot of green. Courteous and attentive staff. Solid music choices at an acceptable volume level. Kind of limited menu, but hey they've also got cruelty free pies. Space is also limited, but that just makes it easier for me to get work done while I wait for the delectables to arrive at the table.

"I have an unwavering affection for Grand Lux Cafe, a sentiment that is underscored by my unrelenting enthusiasm for the establishment's culinary offerings and exceptional service. Although the present location may not quite rival the opulence of the Venetian site, it nevertheless exudes an aura of elegance and refinement that is complemented by the spaciousness and pristine condition of the facility. The staff is remarkably attentive and courteous, ensuring that each dining experience is a true delight. Of particular note is the Molten Chocolate Cake, a delectable masterpiece that lives up to its name and promises to satiate even the most discerning palates. It is advisable to place an order for this divine dessert early on in the meal, preferably upon ordering one's first course or appetizer, so as to allow for the approximately 20-minute preparation time and ensure that it arrives at the table in a timely fashion."

This evaluation pertains solely to the lodging facilities. The accommodations were remarkably luxurious, given the cost. They were spotless and contemporary, with a bed that was also incredibly comfortableâsuperb pillows. The shower was the epitome of perfectionâa convenient shelf, adequate illumination, and excellent water pressure. Additionally, there was a beautiful lit makeup mirror that rotated, allowing those who prefer to shave in the shower to do so with ease. The rooms were peaceful, and the ventilation was outstanding. These are the essential elements that a hotel room should be assessed on.

The staff members appeared friendly and cooperative, willing to oblige whenever feasible. However, their room service meals were slightly inconsistent, which prevented them from attaining a perfect five-star rating. The location's reputation precedes it; thankfully, it is not situated on the strip.

"Love this place. I initially discovered it through the Phoenix LocalDines website and have subsequently designated it as our preferred dining establishment for romantic evenings out with my spouse. Although we have only sampled their dinner selections, I cannot attest to the quality of their other offerings, but we have yet to experience any dissatisfaction and the diverse array of options keeps us returning to explore novel culinary experiences. \n\nI would recommend sampling the Blue Corn Enchiladas and Chimi accompanied by a tangy sour cream green chile sauce. Additionally, do not neglect to order the Guacammus and Waffle Fries as initial courses... you will undoubtedly be delighted!"

I thoroughly relished my experience at this establishment! Upon arriving early on a Thursday evening, we opted to partake in some libations, only to discover that the bartender had graciously offered complimentary well drinks for the initial sixty minutes. Such an auspicious occurrence proved to be particularly serendipitous for our group, with the exception of a singular individual who had elected to order a non-well beverage, thereby incurring an exorbitant fee. The ambiance within the venue was remarkably tranquil, featuring ample seating areas and a sonorous soundtrack that contributed to its overall convivial atmosphere. It would be egregious folly to overlook this hidden gem merely due to its location removed from the primary thoroughfare, as the meager cost of a taxi ride and the advantages of arriving promptly render it eminently worthwhile.

I think this place gets a bad rap. Sure, it might not have the same charm as Wrigley Field, but the seats are comfortable, the weather will never ruin the game, they use real grass on the field, and the layout is just designed so much better than any old ballpark. You never have to walk very far for a hot dog or a toilet.\n\nAlso, let's not kid ourselves about the Suns. In the last 10 years, the Diamondbacks have been the local major sports team with the best chance of winning a championship in any given year.

Mystery Castle is pretty dang weird.  You get a lot of the vibe just by looking online, but it's definitely interesting to see in person.  The guy who built it used a lot of cheap, recycled items.  I was most fascinated by the burned bricks, they were super cool!  The two guys working were so incredibly nice and enthusiastic during the tour.  It's cash only, and I thought it was worth the price. However, it really seemed like the creator was a d-bag.  When you read the synopsis, he built a real castle for his daughter - who he had abandoned 15 years before.  Sure, it sounds like he had some redeeming moments when he contacted his wife and kid that he had left without a word and passed on his money to them after he finally kicked it, but the guy had an elaborate bar with a \"wishing well\" (which was pretty clever) so people could order their drinks downstairs and have them brought upstairs, because he hosted a lot of parties.  Just, you know, without his wife and kid.  It would have been nice to go on the tour when Mary Lou was still around, because she's the one I actually find interesting in the family.  Cool experience, but the thing my husband & I talked about most afterwards was the dad who left his daughter when she was 4 years old and thought about her from afar.

The guy who built it used a lot of cheap, recycled items.  I was most fascinated by the burned bricks, they were super cool!  The two guys working were so incredibly nice and enthusiastic during the tour.  It's cash only, and I thought it was worth the price. However, it really seemed like the creator was a d-bag. Sure, it sounds like he had some redeeming moments when he contacted his wife and kid that he had left without a word and passed on his money to them after he finally kicked it, but the guy had an elaborate bar with a \"wishing well\" (which was pretty clever) so people could order their drinks downstairs and have them brought upstairs, because he hosted a lot of parties. Cool experience, but the thing my husband & I talked about most afterwards was the dad who left his daughter when she was 4 years old and thought about her from afar.

The modified text is:

Enigmatic Mystery Castle presents an unconventional and captivating ambiance, which can be perceived through both virtual and physical means. The resourceful builder, who opted for a plethora of economical and recycled materials, has crafted a structure that exudes an air of peculiarity. My fascination with the charred bricks, in particular, was piqued during the tour, as they boasted an undeniable allure. The two gentlemen conducting the tour radiated warmth and fervor, making the experience even more enjoyable. Although cash payment was the sole option, I deemed it a worthy investment. Notwithstanding, the castle's creator appeared to possess a questionable character, as evidenced by his abandonment of his four-year-old daughter and subsequent lack of involvement in her life. Despite occasional displays of compassion towards his family, he prioritized hosting numerous social gatherings, complete with an innovative \"wishing well\" bar feature. Unfortunately, these events took place sans his spouse and offspring. A tantalizing experience, yet the most discussed aspect post-tour revolved around the father's decision to desert his daughter at such a tender age and his subsequent remorse.

"While I would unhesitatingly assign them a perfect score of 5, there exists a singular caveat which I shall elaborate upon subsequently. Firstly, it must be acknowledged that they provided an excessive amount of sustenance in relation to the monetary investment. Although I do not lament the abundance of nourishment, it is worth mentioning that the quantity was truly remarkable. The carnitas, in particular, merit high praise for their exceptional quality. They exhibited a delightful combination of crunchiness and flavor, with a texture that was simultaneously tender and satisfying. It has been approximately eight years since I last savored carnitas of such superior quality, during my visit to Mexico. Furthermore, the tortillas were scorching hot and displayed an impressive level of freshness. The staff members were affable and demonstrated commendable promptness in their service. Additionally, it is worth highlighting that these establishments remain accessible throughout the entire day, a convenience that cannot be overstated. Geographically, they are situated within close proximity to my temporary lodging, rendering them an ideal choice."
 My one and only grievance pertains to the fact that the taco shell of my taco was overcooked, resulting in an unpleasant rigidity. However, it is essential to note that every other aspect of the culinary experience was flawless."

"Goodness gracious! This establishment boasts an abundance of merchandise and an extensive array of options, rendering it a veritable shopper's paradise.
